headline: Bowl Games to Watch on New Year’s Day
text: ROSE BOWL

headline: New Year’s Eve, Stuck in a Church in Bangui
text: In the brutally violent week before Christmas, dozens of families poured into a church in Bangui in the Central African Republic, my colleague Carlotta Gall reported last week. Run by Archbishop Dieudonné Nzapalainga, the building had become a small island of refuge in the Central African Republic’s rapidly unraveling capital.

headline: House Prices Rise Again, but the Pace Could Slow
text: WASHINGTON — It was a great year for the stock market. And it was also a pretty good year for many people’s biggest investment: their homes.

headline: Jaywalking Rules and Habits: L.A. vs. New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Drawn Back Into Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: Egypt Says 3 Journalists Will Be Held 15 More Days
text: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors on Tuesday ordered three detained journalists from the news channel Al Jazeera English to be held in custody for 15 more days, on charges that include belonging to a terrorist group and harming the country’s reputation abroad.

headline: Killing With Kindness
text: WAIKANE, Hawaii — On days he can round up at least one volunteer to help him in his mission to restore native species to the forest, Paul Zweng commutes in an all-wheel-drive pickup from the home he shares with his wife and children in suburban Honolulu. Hugging the coast north toward the striking mountain terrain on the windward side of Oahu, he stops to pick up Sam or Charlotte or Jim. The regulars.

headline: Spiders That Went to Design School
text: John Derian, who sells antique furnishings and curios in his East Village shops, got his start with decoupage. He decorated gridded glass panels with drawings of sea plants or parrots and hung them as murals. Now, thanks to a new line of wallpapers, those images will adhere directly to the wall.

headline: Hello, Here’s Your Closet
text: Good things came to a lawyer who waited — and waited — to renovate his apartment.

headline: Love in the Wings
text: On the theory that if you build it, whomever you’re waiting for will show up, Jay Dubiner decided to renovate his apartment.

headline: Evaluating Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hawaiian Roots
text: Armed with hatchets and herbicides, Paul Zweng and his volunteers thin a forest of invasive trees one section at a time. Their mission: to return the land to its natural state.

headline: Does the Garage Interior Matter to Home Buyers?
text: Q. Does it matter how the interior of my garage looks when it’s time to sell?

headline: Making Way for the Real Hawaii
text: One man’s efforts would restore a part of Oahu to the days before invasive plants and animals altered the land.

headline: Regulating Supplements
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Obamacare We Deserve
text: TODAY marks the beginning of health care coverage under the Affordable Care Act’s new insurance exchanges, for which two million Americans have signed up. Now that the individual mandate is officially here, let me begin with an admission: Obamacare is awful.

headline: Anxious Youth, Then and Now
text: FOR years now, we’ve heard the gripes by and about millennials, the offspring of the Great Recession, caught between childhood and adulthood. Their plight seems so very 21st century: the unstable careers, the confusion of technologies, the delayed romance, parenthood and maturity.

headline: A Guide to Years Ending in 4
text: War, famine, pestilence and death — the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse — have been well represented in years ending in “4,” but probably not disproportionately so. A look at memorable moments in the last seven of these just might lead to optimism for the one that’s upon us. Or not.

headline: Make of It Whatever You Will
text: The son of a lawyer and a historian, Peter Korn was a likely enough candidate for an Ivy League education. But a career in the trades?

headline: My Jewish State
text: LONDON — A year ends, another begins, time for reminiscences and resolutions, regret and hope, best-of and worst-of lists, confessions and crystal-ball gazing — most of it pretty excruciating. It will take a nanosecond longer to scroll back to one’s year of birth. So it goes.

headline: Sales at Waggo, Wolf Home and Others
text: Some of Michele Quan’s ceramic bells are 50 percent off while supplies last (extra-small thrown bells, originally $100, are $50; medium Teardrop thrown bells, originally $180, are $90); mquan.com.

headline: The New Year Within
text: Sometimes the New Year comes in feeling merely newish, a matter of changing months and not much else. But sometimes the New Year brings with it a powerful sense of regeneration, as if, like certain insects, you were entering a new stage of complete metamorphosis.

headline: Saying ‘I Do’ Amid the Roses
text: By all accounts, the standout entry in Wednesday’s Tournament of Roses Parade in Pasadena, Calif., will surely be the marriage of two men, Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots, beaming amid the array of lavishly flowered floats to be viewed on national television and beyond.

headline: ‘Safe From Fire, Rats, Weather and Waste’
text: In the 1940s, R. Buckminster Fuller converted grain bins into emergency housing. It seemed that these structures had disappeared, but at least a dozen have survived in New Jersey.

headline: War Shelters, Short-Lived Yet Living On
text: Camp Evans, a decommissioned Army base in Wall Township, N.J., is frozen in midcentury, its brick administration buildings and boarded-up Quonset huts on hold from World War II. Fred Carl, 59, a former high school science teacher and the unofficial keeper of the site, leads a visitor to other throwbacks from that era: a collection of corrugated metal houses with porthole windows and conical roofs. They look like alien habitations dropped from the sky.

headline: Only the Purest Water Will Do
text: Patrick Jouin was a pioneer in 3-D-printed furniture, but he also likes working with basic tools and materials. The French designer’s new collection for Puiforcat, the venerable silver house, was inspired by water. Each piece is meant to contain liquid, but go ahead, toss in a few flowers.

headline: Homecoming of a Sort
text: The William, an extended-stay hotel, is to open next week at 24 East 39th Street in a 1924 building that for decades was home to the Williams College alumni club.

headline: Cameroon: Kidnapped French Priest Is Released
text: A French priest kidnapped in November by Islamist militants in northern Cameroon was released on Tuesday, according to French authorities. The priest, Georges Vandenbeusch, 42, was reported to have been held in Nigeria by Boko Haram, a group with ties to Al Qaeda. He described his captivity as “terribly boring,” according to Reuters. He paced circles under a tent beneath a tree, he said.

headline: Gaza: Hamas Lawmakers Approve Large Budget Deficit
text: Hamas lawmakers on Tuesday approved a 2014 budget totaling $589 million for the Gaza Strip that included a staggering 75 percent deficit. The Islamist Hamas movement has said that Egypt’s closing of hundreds of smuggling tunnels beneath its border this summer had cost the strip $460 million in taxes and broader productivity. Gaza gets significant funding from the Palestinian Authority and donor nations, but Hamas has rarely made budgetary specifics public.

headline: For Stocks, an Amazingly Good Year
text: It was the market rally that defied gravity and left many with a case of vertigo.

headline: Don’t Knock These Faux-Bois Accessories
text: In the society of fake wood, there are many classes. Materials doctored to have the look of wood grain may be as humble as plastic laminate or as luxurious as silk — in which case the counterfeiting is more likely to be described as “faux bois.”

headline: In Tiny Houses, Hope Lives
text: Kenneth Cobonpue, a Filipino furniture designer with offices in New York, Germany and his native Cebu island, has produced miniature vernacular metal houses that hold tea lights. Proceeds from their sale will help Habitat for Humanity Philippines build shelters for victims of the typhoon that devastated the Visayas region in November.

headline: Arkansas Lieutenant Governor Faces Calls to Quit Over Ethics Violations
text: Lt. Gov. Mark Darr of Arkansas, who said this week that he would settle with his state’s Ethics Commission amid findings that he repeatedly broke campaign finance laws, on Tuesday defied mounting calls for his resignation, including one from Gov. Mike Beebe, and said he intended to remain in office.

headline: Preserving Wireless Competition
text: The corporation that controls Sprint, the third-biggest cellphone company in the country after Verizon and AT&T, is reportedly planning to make an offer to buy the smaller rival T-Mobile in a move that would reduce competition in an important industry that already has too little of it.

headline: Phish Fans Encounter Crackdown at Garden
text: The arrests began almost as soon as the concertgoers amassed outside Madison Square Garden on Monday evening. Uniformed and plainclothes police officers moved through the crowd, picking off targets and leading them to a police van parked around the corner where they were patted down and loaded in.

headline: Supporters of $15 Wage Seek Appeal of Ruling
text: SEATAC, Wash. — Supporters of a $15 minimum wage, approved by voters here in November but partly struck down last week by a county judge, asked the state’s highest court to hear an appeal.

headline: Kerry’s Peace Ambitions
text: Secretary of State John Kerry’s remarks on Middle East peace talks have changed over time.

headline: More Guns Will Not Save Iraq
text: President Obama has done the predictable thing by sending more weapons to Iraq to counter an alarming rise in violence. But arms alone will not solve a problem that has its roots in the political alienation of Sunnis and other minorities and the undermining of democratic processes, especially by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: College, Not Just for Himself, but for His Son
text: The load on a full-time college student is a heavy one. Finals and midterms, especially when paired with the duties of fatherhood, could crush any 21-year old, but Giovanni Classen, who recently became a single father to his 1-year-old son, Ezio, seems to have found a way to make it work.

headline: Power Curbed, Detroit Mayor Faces Big Job
text: DETROIT — For some who have been around this city the longest, expectations for a new mayor have by now become understandably low: Turn some streetlights on. Do not get indicted. Wait for the lawyers to get Detroit out of bankruptcy.

headline: U.S. Solar Panel Maker Seeks to Close Loophole in Duties on Chinese Products
text: A major maker of solar panels opened another chapter in a long-simmering trade dispute on Tuesday, asking the Commerce Department to impose new duties on imported modules made of certain components from China or Taiwan.

headline: Snow May Deal a First Test to de Blasio One Day After He Takes Office
text: Three years ago, Bill de Blasio watched as a heavy layer of snow accumulated outside his Park Slope rowhouse during a post-Christmas blizzard, and waited — and waited — for the city’s plows to arrive. Three days passed before his block was cleared.

headline: Kerry to Press for ‘Framework’ Accord to Keep Mideast Peace Effort Moving
text: WASHINGTON — In an intensifying diplomatic effort, Secretary of State John Kerry is making a major push to secure what Obama administration officials are calling a “framework” accord that would be a critical first step to a comprehensive Middle East peace agreement. But critics are already branding it as an effort to play for time.

headline: Millions Gaining Health Coverage Under Law
text: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans will begin receiving health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act on Wednesday after years of contention and a rollout hobbled by delays and technical problems. The decisively new moment in the effort to overhaul the country’s health care system will test the law’s central premise: that extending coverage to far more Americans will improve the nation’s health and help many avoid crippling medical bills.

headline: Jets, at Least for Moment, Put Entertainment Aside
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Off the top of his head, John Idzik could think of several reasons he still wanted Rex Ryan to be his head coach two days after a third consecutive Jets season of not making the playoffs. After all, they shared a legacy as sons of men who served as coordinators in the organization. They had “similar views” on how to build a team and, Idzik said, had developed a synergy on doing it together.

headline: Old Rivalries Reignited a Fuse in South Sudan
text: JUBA, South Sudan — Few moments conjure as much fear in South Sudan as the massacre of Bor.

headline: Cuomo Prods Assemblymen to Resign
text: ALBANY — In a strongly worded statement about the seemingly endless series of allegations of sexual misconduct in the State Assembly, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called on Tuesday for two assemblymen facing such allegations to either immediately deny the reports’ veracity or resign.

headline: Bowden Adjusts to His Life as a Dadgum Retiree
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Bobby Bowden still lives in the cream-colored brick house he and his wife, Ann, fell in love with in 1976. There was a pool out back, a golf course beyond that and, in the front yard, a sprawling oak tree that canopied the driveway. Its limbs were so big and low that Bowden could walk up them.

headline: 2 Slashed at Port Authority Bus Terminal
text: Two men were injured in slashings at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in New York on Tuesday night, sending frightened people running from the station, just a block from the New Year’s Eve celebration in Times Square, officials said.

headline: Cuomo Issues Pardons for First Time in Office
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced the first pardons of his term on Tuesday afternoon, granting clemency to three New Yorkers whose lives, he said, continued to be “hampered by their criminal records.”

headline: City Makes Deal to Keep Market at Hunts Point
text: On the last day of the Bloomberg administration, city officials bought some time in their long-running effort to keep the Hunts Points Terminal Produce Market from leaving the Bronx for New Jersey or elsewhere.

headline: A’s for Athletes, but Charges of Fraud at North Carolina
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — In the summer of 2011, 19 undergraduates at the University of North Carolina signed up for a lecture course called AFAM 280: Blacks in North Carolina. The professor was Julius Nyang’oro, an internationally respected scholar and longtime chairman of the African and Afro-American studies department.

headline: Not Shy About Expressing Opinions
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you do the puzzle online, you will no doubt see this post before you ring in the New Year, but many people don’t, so let’s pretend it’s Wednesday morning and New Year’s Day. Ready?

headline: De Blasio Draws All Liberal Eyes to New York City
text: Liberals across the country are looking to Bill de Blasio, who was sworn in as mayor early Wednesday, to morph New York City’s municipal machinery into a closely watched laboratory for populist theories of government that have never before been enacted on such a large scale.

headline: As Alumni Meet at the Winter Classic, Even 74-Year-Old Likes to Have Coach’s Confidence
text: DETROIT — So many former Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs wanted to play in the Winter Classic alumni game that they staged two games. So all the old Wings and Leafs converged Tuesday afternoon on Comerica Park, a baseball stadium transformed into a wintry ice arena, where some 35,000 fans in tuques and gloves and red sweaters or blue sweaters stamped their feet and thrilled to the sight of their heroes skating down the ice again.

headline: Justice Blocks Contraception Mandate on Insurance in Suit by Nuns
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Sonia Sotomayor on Tuesday temporarily blocked the Obama administration from forcing some religious-affiliated groups to provide health insurance coverage of birth control or face penalties as part of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: McDonagh Is Expanding His Game, and Adding Admirers
text: Since defenseman Ryan McDonagh made his debut with the Rangers midway through the 2010-11 season, he has been eager to deflect credit to teammates and has rarely sought the limelight.

headline: Boy, 15, Charged With Murders in Newark
text: A 15-year-old New Jersey boy was charged on Tuesday with the murders of two teenagers who were among five people shot and killed around Newark on Christmas Day, the Essex County prosecutor’s office said.

headline: Con Ed Agrees Not to Raise Its Residential Electricity Rate for 2 Years
text: Consolidated Edison has agreed to spend about $650 million to prepare for another storm like Hurricane Sandy without raising its rates for residential electricity for two years, the company and state officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Barbara Bush Hospitalized for Pneumonia in Texas
text: HOUSTON — Barbara Bush, the former first lady, has been admitted to a hospital here for treatment of pneumonia. She is recuperating at the same hospital where her husband, former President George Bush, spent weeks overcoming bronchitis-related illnesses in 2012.

headline: North Korean Leader Says He Wants Better Ties With South
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, on Wednesday called for improving relations with South Korea and boasted of his regime’s tightened grip on power in his first public speech since the purge and execution of his uncle, Jang Song-thaek, last month.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 31, 2013
Nets End Year Gaining Nothing but Sympathy
text: SAN ANTONIO — The 31st game of a team’s schedule may be an arbitrary checkpoint in the N.B.A. season, but as it fell for the Nets on the final day of the calendar year, it seemed to warrant at least a moment or two of reflection.

headline: West Nile Virus Is Behind Bald Eagle Deaths in Utah
text: The mysterious deaths of at least 27 bald eagles in Utah were caused by the West Nile virus, state officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Patricia Ryan, a Managing Editor at Time Inc., Dies at 75
text: Patricia Ryan, who started at Time Inc. as a typist in the secretarial pool and rose to become the managing editor of People and Life, a rare ascent for a woman in what was then a male-dominated company, died on Friday at her home in Boothbay, Me. She was 75.

headline: Corrections: January 1, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Navigating Our World Like Birds and Bees
text: African tribesmen walk through their landscape in a pattern that eerily echoes the movements of scavenging birds, flocking insects, gliding sharks and visitors to Disneyland, a new study finds, suggesting that aspects of how we choose to move around in our world are deeply hard-wired.

headline: Shorter Workweeks Are Likely in New Year
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 11 A.M. (HGTV) ROSE PARADE 2014 The new year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, which heralds 2014 from its traditional perch at the 125th annual parade. Vin Scully, the hall of fame sports broadcaster and grand marshal, will lead nearly 50 floats, centered on the theme “Dreams Come True” and adorned with more botanical elements — including orchids (above), black lichen, Spanish moss, safflower blossoms, coconut flakes and even chive and onion seed — than the average florist might go through in five years, down Colorado Avenue in Pasadena, Calif. The “Property Brothers” — Drew and Jonathan Scott — and Nancy O’Dell will provide a play-by-play of the nuptials of Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots on the AIDS Healthcare Foundation’s wedding cake float with the tagline “Love Is the Best Protection.” And eight former Women Airforce Service Pilots from World War II are expected to ride atop a float titled “Our Eyes Are on the Stars.” (Stanford will take on Michigan State in the Rose Bowl game at 5 p.m. on ESPN.) The HGTV programming moves into prime time at 8 with a tour of the latest “Dream Home” giveaway: a three-bedroom modern mountain house with soaring ceilings and wilderness views near Lake Tahoe. The winner also gets a GMC Yukon Denali and $250,000.

headline: De Blasio Sworn In as New York Mayor
text: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City early Wednesday, at two minutes past the stroke of midnight.

headline: Mike O’Connor, Journalists’ Advocate, Dies at 67
text: Mike O’Connor, a longtime foreign correspondent who had worked in recent years to protect journalists in Mexico, died on Sunday in Mexico City. He was 67.

headline: De Blasio Is Sworn In as Mayor
text: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City on Wednesday morning, at two minutes past the stroke of midnight.

headline: Need Some Greens? Then Eat This Pork Belly
text: Since opening nearly 20 years ago, St. John, Fergus Henderson’s famous nose-to-tail restaurant in London, has developed a justifiable reputation for using underappreciated parts of many different types of animals (rolled pig’s spleen, anyone?). Henderson also helped popularize serving unusual vegetables and vegetables in unusual forms. I remember ordering “English peas” and watching a kitchen worker reach into a crate, pile a couple of handfuls of unshelled peas onto a plate and send them to the table.

headline: The Quest for a Natural Sugar Substitute
text: On a Sunday evening last September, stevia became famous. In the final episode of “Breaking Bad,” an image of the sweetener filled the TV screen. Lydia emptied the packet into her mug of camomile tea, not knowing that Walt, her former partner, had poisoned it. “How are you feeling?” he later asked. “Kind of under the weather, like you’ve got the flu? That would be the ricin I gave you. I slipped it into that stevia crap that you’re always putting in your tea.”

headline: Rebels Seize Portions of Strategic City in South Sudan
text: AWERIAL, South Sudan — On the eve of negotiations to end the conflict in South Sudan, rebel forces on Wednesday seized major sections of the city of Bor, giving them a strategic foothold for a possible march toward the capital and transforming the banks of the White Nile into an impromptu camp for the tens of thousands of people who have fled the fighting.

headline: Europeans United, in Hating Europe
text: LONDON — It may seem bizarre that two far-right, nationalist politicians — Marine Le Pen of France and Geert Wilders of the Netherlands — have reached across borders to form a Pan-European group dedicated to weakening the European Union. Their aim is a transnational political alliance that would compete in the May elections for the European Parliament; once in power, they would cooperate to try to rein in the power of Brussels.

headline: Putin Visits Volgograd, Site of Two Suicide Attacks
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin flew Wednesday to Volgograd, the site of two suicide bombings this week, to hold a meeting with national and regional security officials and visit victims of the bombings in a hospital.

headline: 2013, by the Numbers
text: A look at the news events, babies, hacking and diplomacy that defined the year.

headline: The Best Small-Business Posts of 2013
text: Once again, here at You’re the Boss, we spent the year in the small-business trenches. Rather than hyping the stories of rock star entrepreneurs who never seem to struggle, we focus on the struggle.

headline: Daily Report: Judge Upholds Searches of Travelers’ Devices at Border
text: The government’s right to search travelers’ electronic devices at the border was upheld in a ruling released by a federal judge on Tuesday, which dismissed a lawsuit challenging this policy, Susan Stellin reports.

headline: Lebanon Arrests Leader of Qaeda-Linked Group, Reports Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Lebanese military authorities have detained the Saudi leader of a Sunni militant group linked to Al Qaeda that claimed responsibility for a double suicide bomb attack on the Iranian Embassy in Beirut in November, according to Lebanese news media.

headline: In Our Pages: January 2
text: 1914: Aero Club Prize to Mr. Wright

headline: A Tale of Two Subway Platforms
text: Dear Diary:

headline: After Leukemia, New Year’s Lipstick-Marked Beginnings
text: It was New Year’s 2013, and I was preparing to take my little girl to see the lights on the Champs-Élysées. Bathed, toweled but not yet dressed, she loitered at my side, twirling her chestnut locks around her fingers and making funny faces as I applied lipstick in the mirror.

headline: Security Scare Delays Hearing for Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — For the second time since treason proceedings were opened against him, Pakistan’s former military ruler Pervez Musharraf failed to appear before judges, after explosives were again found along his route to a hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Freewheeling Fun
text: Reading a poem like Byron’s “The Destruction of Sennacherib” (beloved by previous generations of schoolchildren), you can practically feel hooves beating the ground beneath you. But in most contemporary children’s books, cars have replaced horses as the source of exciting noises, rhythms and vibrations.

headline: Big Data Shrinks to Grow
text: What’s next for Big Data? Maybe a little thinning down of the industry and a little more focus.

headline: The State of the Euro, In One Graph
text: Happy New Year! I’m trying to organize my thoughts and data on matters European, and I think I’ve come up with a useful way to summarize what has been happening in the euro area. In the figure below I compare the ratio of government debt to GDP (from the IMF — year-end number) with the 10-year interest rate (from the ECB) for a number of euro nations; I show two dates, the peak of the euro crisis in 2011 and a relatively recent observation:

headline: Up Early and in Line for a Marijuana Milestone in Colorado
text: DENVER — They lined up before dawn and in the snow on Wednesday, baby boomers from Nebraska, retirees from Denver and a young man who had driven all day from Ohio. Some were longtime marijuana users. Some had been arrested for marijuana possession.

headline: Rules of Style | Lou Doillon on Looking Kooky and Staying True to Yourself
text: The model and actress Lou Doillon recorded her first album “Places,” which came out last summer, in just 10 days with no money and zero expectations. Half the songs were written over the previous seven years just sitting around the house. “I always lived with guitarists,” she said over a cappuccino last fall in the lobby of the Dream Downtown hotel in New York, the morning after a show at the Highline Ballroom. “When they would leave, I would just pick up their acoustic guitars and start doing finger picking and write.” When she decided to record the album, she told her producer, “Let’s do it petite. If it works out, good.” And if it doesn’t? “Then I can die in a corner without anyone noticing.”

headline: ... In Which a Bat Flies Into the Schlag
text: Real Champagne tends to provoke sticker shock in cash-strapped young people hoping to drink their way through New Year’s Eve. A popular solution is André, the saccharine, mass-produced sparkling wine that sells for about $4 or $5 a bottle.

headline: Blast Kills Palestinian, a Diplomat, in Prague
text: BERLIN — The Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic died on Wednesday after suffering severe injuries caused by an explosive booby trap security system in a safe at his Prague residence that he apparently had triggered by mistake, the police reported. They said there was no indication the explosion was sabotage or a terrorist attack.

headline: Highlights From the de Blasio Inauguration
text: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City on Wednesday, a few minutes after midnight, but his formal inauguration ceremony on the steps of City Hall began at noon. Times reporters and photographers arrived early to capture the scene, and will continue to cover the event.

headline: Next Stop on Odyssey: The Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Jeremy Tyler was back on the practice court for the Knicks on Tuesday morning as the 15th man. It was no small victory for him.

headline: NASA Responds to Beyoncé’s Use of Challenger Audio
text: Beyoncé’s new self-titled album has won raves from critics and fans, but now it has come under indirect fire from an unexpected authority: NASA.

headline: A 10th Play Is the Charm
text: In an impressive and unusually enduring relationship spanning three decades, the Manhattan Theater Club has produced nine plays by John Patrick Shanley, none of which started on Broadway. But with the 10th, the romantic comedy “Outside Mullingar,” which is in previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, that streak will change. This show, about two neighboring misfits whose families are in a land dispute in rural Ireland, reunites some of the same Tony-winning artists who worked on Mr. Shanley’s only drama to transfer to Broadway, the celebrated “Doubt”: the superb actor Brian F. O’Byrne, here playing an introvert living on a cattle farm, and the veteran director Doug Hughes. Debra Messing, who played the scarf-favoring lyricist in the NBC series “Smash,” makes her Broadway debut as Mr. O’Byrne’s love interest. (261 West 47th Street, Manhattan; 212-239-6200, manhattantheatreclub.com.)

headline: The Hazards of Moving Oil By Rail Again on Display, This Time in North Dakota
text: The fiery derailment of a 106-car oil train in North Dakota on Monday is the latest manifestation of the perils that come with expanding shipments of the country’s Bakken oil bounty by rail. The Wall Street Journal has a good update, as does NPR. An Associated Press report included this context:

headline: Schumacher’s Condition Unchanged, Manager Says
text: LONDON — The former grand prix racing driver Michael Schumacher was in a stable condition, with no significant changes in the 24 hours since his doctors met with reporters on Tuesday, his manager said on Wednesday. The doctors had described Schumacher, 44, as being in critical condition, in a medically induced coma and on life-support systems, after two brain operations.

headline: To Play a Rooster, Do the Research
text: Bobby Moreno studied birds once he was cast as Odysseus Rex, the title bird of Eric Dufault’s dark cockfighting comedy “Year of the Rooster.” He researched how they walk (sharp and jerky), look (his hair becomes a punk cockscomb in the show) and kiss (more on that later). But he also got into their heads.

headline: Finding a King’s Mind, Not Losing It
text: One of the many problems with the role of King Lear, Shakespeare’s oldest and most irascible monarch, is that by the time an actor is old enough to play it, he may be too old to pull it off.

headline: Taking Office, de Blasio Vows to Fix Inequity
text: Bill de Blasio, whose fiery populism propelled his rise from obscure neighborhood official to the 109th mayor of New York, was sworn into office on Wednesday, pledging that his ambition for a more humane and equal metropolis would remain undimmed.

headline: 36 Hours in Chicago
text: Chicago is a city that changes noticeably with the seasons. It is endlessly beautiful in the warm months, when the sidewalks transform into cafes, the Lakefront Trail becomes a Divvy Bike highway and the beaches along Lake Michigan might be mistaken for Miami. As the temperatures fall, the city changes from a playground to a cultural promised land — a place of fine and varied food, inventive theater and one of the country’s great live music scenes. From the historic high-rises of the Gold Coast to regal Hyde Park, from Bronzeville to Boystown, from the Indian and Puerto Rican enclaves of Devon Avenue and Humboldt Park, respectively, to the bohemian barrios of Logan Square and Pilsen, Chicago demands hard choices. It rarely disappoints.

headline: Classical Playlist: Boston Baroque, Rafal Blechacz, Alexandre Tharaud and More
text: HAYDN: ‘Lord Nelson Mass’ (with Symphony No. 102 in B flat)Boston Baroque; Martin Pearlman, conductor; Mary Wilson, Abigail Fischer, Keith Jameson and Kevin Deas(Linn)The political turmoil of the Napoleonic Wars raged across Europe when Haydn wrote this “Missa in Angustiis” (“Mass in a Time of Anxiety”), which came to be named after Admiral Lord Nelson of Britain. Boston Baroque, led by Martin Pearlman, performs the stormy opening movement with rhythmic verve and intensity. A fine quartet of soloists, including the bright lyric soprano Mary Wilson and the magnanimous bass-baritone Kevin Deas, jostle for the spotlight with the orchestra, which shines in the rambunctious Symphony No. 102. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Why Hire a P.R. Firm When There’s TaskRabbit?
text: Several months after Olton Rensch lost his information technology job in a round of layoffs, he heard about a host of new smartphone apps like Sidecar, a ride-sharing app, TaskRabbit, the app marketplace for odd jobs and chores, and Airbnb, a website that connects travelers with housing.

headline: At Newark Airport, a 3-D Distraction
text: Post-holiday travelers facing delays at Newark Liberty International Airport currently have something other than departure screens to stare at, thanks to a recently added distraction: a free 3-D movie.

headline: Snowboarders Push Into Alaska, by Foot
text: After spending 15 years exploring the peaks of Alaska by helicopter and snowboarding down them, Jeremy Jones started to discover remote mountains under his own power.

headline: French Leader Would Reward Companies That Hire More People
text: PARIS — President François Hollande, seeking to reduce France’s punishingly high unemployment rate, has called for a “responsibility pact” with businesses that would reward companies that hire more people with lower taxes and greater flexibility.

headline: Danielle Steel Awarded French Legion of Honor
text: Danielle Steel joined the ranks of Douglas MacArthur, Julia Child, Walt Disney, Alan Greenspan and Bob Dylan on Wednesday when she became the latest American to receive France’s highest award, the Legion of Honor.

headline: Big Chill in the Big House for Toronto’s Winter Classic Win
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Toronto’s Jonathan Bernier wore heat packs inside his goalie pants and blocker pad. Several players wore black balaclavas under their helmets; a few wore knit caps atop them. Water bottles froze on the benches. Amid falling snow and bitter cold on New Year’s Day, more than 100,000 fans packed the Big House to watch the Maple Leafs and the Detroit Red Wings play in the N.H.L.’s sixth Winter Classic.

headline: Video: Snowboarders Push Deep Into Alaska — by Foot
text: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and now “Higher.” These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard remote mountains under his own power.

headline: Cocktail Culture | A Spot of (Spiked) Tea
text: Around New York, boozy versions of “a spot of tea” are warming up winter drink menus this season as Manhattan mixologists blend green, black and white tea leaves with a range of spirits and wines.

headline: Text of Bill de Blasio’s Inauguration Speech
text: The following is the complete text of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inaugural address, as prepared for delivery.

headline: E.U. Labor Market Opens for Romanians and Bulgarians
text: PARIS — The lifting of labor restrictions on Wednesday for Bulgarians and Romanians in nine European Union countries, including Germany, France and Britain, was greeted as both an opportunity and a threat, touching off fear among some about unchecked immigration from Bulgaria and Romania, two of the poorest states in Europe.

headline: Showstopper in What May Have Been Manziel’s Last College Game
text: ATLANTA — Johnny Manziel flung his helmet to the ground, raced to the equipment cart on the Texas A&M sideline and climbed atop it on Tuesday night. He raised his arms over his head and rubbed the tips of his fingers together, sign language for a payday that has just arrived.

headline: ‘Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding’ Coming Back to New York
text: After an interim of apparent wedded bliss elsewhere, the participatory Off Broadway play “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding,” last seen flinging ziti and zingers near Times Square in 2010, will be bringing its raucous participatory spirit back to New York City.

headline: For New York, a Winning Year. Really.
text: Yes, 2013 was not much of a year for sports teams in the New York metropolitan region. The nine major local sports franchises had more downs than ups and, in addition to being mediocre or worse, were often just plain boring.

headline: The Inaugural Address of Bill de Blasio
text: In his inauguration speech in front of City Hall, Bill de Blasio laid out a mayoralty that emphasized social and economic justice.

headline: Minneapolis Fire Injures More Than a Dozen
text: An explosion and fire on Wednesday destroyed a Minneapolis building that housed 10 apartments and a grocery, injuring at least 14 people, the authorities said. Most of injuries were burns or broken bones suffered by people who jumped — or were blown — out of rooms on the second and third floors.

headline: The 109th Mayor of New York
text: Bill de Blasio claimed his place as mayor on Wednesday. On the steps of City Hall, he was ceremonially sworn in by former President Clinton.

headline: Young Poet Speaks at Inauguration
text: Ramya Ramana, the New York City Youth Poet Laureate, delivered the poem “New York City” at Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inauguration ceremony.

headline: Settlement News to Wait Until Kerry Leaves Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government will delay an expected announcement of bids for new settlement construction for the next few days while Secretary of State John Kerry is in the region, an Israeli official said Wednesday, avoiding a potential high-profile clash over the contentious issue.

headline: As Latvia Adopts Euro, Future Growth Is Slowing
text: PARIS — Dace Utinane, a doctor at a private health center, frowned during a stroll this week through Riga, the capital of Latvia, as she contemplated her country’s move to become the newest member of Europe’s currency union.

headline: Vote on New Boeing Contract Highlights a Rift in the Machinists’ Union
text: After Boeing’s workers in Washington State voted down an eight-year contract extension in November, Boeing wasted little time in soliciting offers from other states to build its new 777X aircraft.

headline: 2 Conservatives Join Iran Nuclear Panel
text: TEHRAN — Two members of Iran’s hard-line-dominated Parliament were added to a supervisory council responsible for monitoring the country’s nuclear negotiating team, Iranian news media reported Wednesday. The additions appeared to strengthen the influence of critics of the talks between Iran and world powers.

headline: Would You Rather Run a Restaurant or Sell Tomato Sauce?
text: We just published a case study about the owner of an eight-table Italian restaurant on the cusp of a major decision. Carlos Vega bought the 900-square-foot Father and Son Pizzeria in Guttenberg, N.J., in 2007 and worked long hours perfecting the restaurant’s house sauce, expanding the menu options and building a vibrant takeout trade. Though the business was profitable, revenues plateaued well short of where he had hoped. Two years in, Mr. Vega found himself debating the pros and cons of two very different paths forward.

headline: Some Hefty Chops, Seasoned by Antics
text: During the New York Philharmonic’s New Year’s Eve concert at Avery Fisher Hall, the pianist Hyung-ki Joo revealed the three simple steps necessary to make it in the music business: 1. Always smile. 2. Play only music that everyone knows. 3. Show off.

headline: A Cleaned-Up Hotel in a Cleaned-Up Times Square
text: It isn’t easy for hotels to stand out from their competitors. In 2006, however, the Hotel Carter, at 250 West 43rd Street, found a new way to do so when TripAdvisor readers named it the dirtiest hotel in America.

headline: Ariel Sharon, Former Prime Minister of Israel, Is Said to Be Near Death
text: JERUSALEM — Ariel Sharon, the former prime minister of Israel who has been comatose for nearly eight years, edged closer to death on Wednesday evening, suffering from kidney failure.

headline: A Stock Exchange Expands Its Global Reach
text: Updated, 10:36 a.m. | The face of the global stock market used to be the classically proportioned exchange building on Wall Street.

headline: Civilian Photography, Now Rising to New Level
text: Five years ago, the DJI Phantom 2 Vision would have seemed like a science fiction film prop or a piece of surveillance hardware flown only by the sexiest of superspies. But it is the first camera-carrying drone you may want to own — and you could do that without spending thousands of dollars.

headline: Two Graphic Narratives, Inspired by the Fab Four
text: “Science is the new rock ’n’ roll.” Or so the four scientists at the center of the beguiling new Image Comics series “Nowhere Men” would have you believe. These men have banded together to form World Corp., a research and development company that has a profound influence on the planet through advances in things like cyberoptics and genetics. But ideological shifts and personality clashes cause their alliance to fracture.

headline: Cleaning the Mobile Germ Warehouse
text: TAKE a look at your mobile device. Do you see oily fingerprints and lint on the touch screen? Dust and crumbs forming particulate frost in the corners? Is that a hair stuck at the screen’s edge?

headline: Markets Buoyant, Merger Activity Picks Up
text: What may have been the most auspicious deal of late was not the biggest or the most groundbreaking of mergers. It was just one that took a little gumption.

headline: Resolve to Pay Attention to Resolution Reminders
text: I find New Year’s resolutions tricky and have avoided them in the past. I have difficulty dreaming up resolutions in the first place, and then I have problems sticking to them.

headline: Regaining Footing, and a Leader
text: It seems too simple, too easy somehow, but there’s no denying the evidence before our eyes: “Community” is a worthwhile show again now that Dan Harmon, its creator, is back in his office doing whatever it is he does so obsessively.

headline: Friday A/X Pairs at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
text: The Friday A/X Pairs at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in New York City, which ended Monday, was won by Joan Brody of Morristown, N.J., and Kent Mignocchi of New York City. They finished two-fifths of a board ahead of John McAllister of Charlottesville, Va., and Ishmael Del’Monte from Australia, whose 75 percent second session was not quite enough to snatch victory. Third were R. Jay Becker of New York City and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.

headline: Banned at Home and Noticed by Oscars
text: Maxim Pozdorovkin thought that once he made it past the airport in Moscow, he’d be home free. Mr. Pozdorovkin is a director, with Mike Lerner, of the documentary “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer,” and after two members of that Russian activist group were released from prison in late December, they all put together a screening of the film in their home country, Russia. It was to be the film’s first showing there, and the first time the two group members, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, were to see the documentary, which traces the story of their collective from little-known artists to globally famous political rebels.

headline: Hawaii Tourists Revel in Sun, Surf and Semiautomatics

text: THIS New Year’s, a good number of those who struggle to control their drinking will resolve to abstain from alcohol. No halfway measures. Quitting is the only way.

headline: Body Pulled From Lake in Central Park
text: The body of a man in his 20s was pulled from the Lake in Central Park on Wednesday in what the New York Police Department described as a probable suicide.

headline: After a Death, Keeping a Yiddish-Lover’s Weekly Conversations Alive

headline: High Rollers in a Buying Mood
text: DETROIT — Matt Hlavin, an entrepreneur in Cleveland who owns seven businesses, mostly in manufacturing, bought three Mercedes last year: a $237,000 SLS AMG and a $165,000 S63 AMG for himself, and a $97,000 GL550 sport utility vehicle for his wife.

headline: Two Months in a Homeless Shelter Spurred a Teenager’s Desire to Study
text: “Homeless but Not Hopeless.” That had been the title of the essay Oscar Ibarra submitted along with his college applications, inspired by the two months he spent living in a shelter. “It was about how I pushed myself to do work even though times got hard for me and my family,” Mr. Ibarra said. “I thought I might have to drop out of school.”

headline: A Girl’s Escape
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — She was a 13-year-old girl who said she was beaten daily by strangers who forced her to work unpaid in their home, and she wanted to escape.

headline: Fatal Attacks Strike a Hotel in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least six people were killed and many more were wounded after consecutive car bombings and an attack by armed militants at a hotel in Mogadishu on Wednesday evening, officials said.

headline: A Business Owner Seeks an Alternative to Seven-Day Workweeks
text: FATHER AND SON PIZZERIA is a 900-square-foot, eight-table restaurant in Guttenberg, N.J., across the Hudson River from Manhattan. Opened in 1971, it was bought in 2007 by Carlos Vega, now 45, from its aging founder. Mr. Vega soon doubled sales by expanding the menu, improving service and selling the restaurant’s “gravy,” or red sauce, over the counter in 12-ounce Mason jars.

headline: Carrying On a Presidential Tradition, One Leisurely Round at a Time
text: KANEOHE, Hawaii — No one should ever question President Obama’s passion for golf. He has played some of the country’s most picturesque courses, held a debt-limit “golf summit” with Speaker John A. Boehner, taken on Tiger Woods and found time to steal away for a round in political good times and bad.

headline: Fiat, in Deal With Union, Will Buy Rest of Chrysler
text: DETROIT — Chrysler, the smallest of the three American automakers, is set to be completely absorbed by an Italian company, Fiat.

headline: Plotting Strategic Deals
text: The annual volume of deal-making in the United States was up 11 percent in 2013.

headline: Health Law Challenge Opens Up New Front
text: WASHINGTON — In temporarily blocking enforcement of the part of President Obama’s health care law that requires many employers to provide health insurance coverage for birth control or face penalties, Justice Sonia Sotomayor on Tuesday opened a second front in Supreme Court challenges to the provision.

headline: Totally Final Year-End Quiz
text: One of the great things about being in a new year is getting to wipe 2013 from our minds. Completely. Forever. Except maybe this one last, final, end-of-the-year quiz. (Coming Tomorrow. 2014: What’s Gone Wrong So Far?)

headline: James Avery, ‘Fresh Prince’ Actor, Dies at 68
text: James Avery, who played Will Smith’s pompous but well-meaning uncle on the popular 1990s sitcom “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,” died on Tuesday in Glendale, Calif. He was 68.

headline: Telling the World It Sells Stethoscopes, Too
text: SOME items that were commonplace when Staples, the office products chain, opened in 1986 may seem like quaint artifacts today but are still, in fact, sold by the store, including typewriters, Rolodexes and daily planners. A new ad campaign by the retailer is not promoting basic office supplies of any era, however, but rather the increasingly vast array of other products it sells.

headline: Boy, 7, Is Killed in Fire Begun by Fireplace Spark
text: A 7-year-old boy died on Wednesday morning when a fire ripped through the top floor of a rowhouse in the East Elmhurst neighborhood of Queens, the authorities said.

headline: Redskins’ Coach Search Is Said to Include Fewell
text: The Washington Redskins have requested and received permission from the Giants to interview Perry Fewell for their vacant head coaching job, according to people aware of the conversations between the teams who were not authorized to speak publicly about the job search.

headline: Loan Monitor Is Accused of Ruthless Tactics on Student Debt
text: Stacy Jorgensen fought her way through pancreatic cancer. But her struggle was just beginning.

headline: Consumers Start Using Coverage Under Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Kathy Hornbach of Tucson is not wasting any time before using her new health insurance coverage, which took effect on New Year’s Day. Ms. Hornbach, 57, has an appointment with a cardiologist on Thursday for a stress test.

headline: Garnett’s Spirits Dip With His Production
text: SAN ANTONIO — Kevin Garnett said Wednesday that this season was more frustrating than any of the previous 18 he had played.

headline: Letter Tied to Fight for Independence Is Found in Museum’s Attic
text: It was lying in a drawer in the attic, a 12-page document that was not just forgotten but misfiled. Somehow it had made its way into a folder with colonial-era doctor’s bills that someone in the 1970s decreed was worthless and should be thrown away.

headline: Who’s Who on the Dais
text: Though there was no shortage of fund-raisers and political operatives facing the stage, much of the dais was given over to everyday people. Still, some notable names were in attendance.

headline: Boehner Is Said to Back Change on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio has signaled he may embrace a series of limited changes to the nation’s immigration laws in the coming months, giving advocates for change new hope that 2014 might be the year that a bitterly divided Congress reaches a political compromise to overhaul the sprawling system.

headline: At Issue in Skakel’s Libel Suit Against TV Host, Degrees of Tarnish on a Reputation
text: Is a journalist committing libel if he falsely reports that a known traitor like Benedict Arnold is also a shoplifter, or a notorious mobster like John J. Gotti a dognapper?

headline: After Pageantry, Tough Stop and Timely Passes Lift Spartans in Rose Bowl
text: PASADENA, Calif. — For all the analysis that precedes a contest like the Rose Bowl, for the hundreds of hours of scrutiny, Michigan State’s season hinged Wednesday on a quarterback who started the season as a backup and a linebacker who arrived on campus as a walk-on.

text: Before you forget about 2013 entirely, let’s see how well you paid attention to major events. No peeking at the answer key, people, until all questions have been completed!

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 1, 2014
With Talent Abundant, U.S. Makes Tough Cuts
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Jack Johnson, an American-born defenseman, is a 10-time national team member who played on the 2010 United States Olympic team that won a silver medal at the Vancouver Games and came within one goal of the gold. Johnson’s patriotism runs so deep that he traveled to Canada at his own expense four years ago to march in the opening ceremony ahead of the hockey competition.

headline: Plenty of Reminders of Populism’s Limits
text: Shedding coat and gloves, and the last inhibitions of the inside operative, Bill de Blasio used the ice-edged tapestry of his inauguration to make clear that his campaign oratory would become the lodestar for his administration.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 2, 2014
text: “We are called to put an end to economic and social inequalities that threatened to unravel the city we love.”

headline: Major Florida State Wins Live On in Sod Cemetery
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — North of Florida State’s football stadium, next to the practice fields and near a parking lot, there is a cemetery lined by a fence.

headline: The Campaign for a Bigger Paycheck
text: Aided by a vast flow of corporate and right-wing money, Republicans have spent years persuading the public that the deficit is the nation’s biggest financial problem and that austerity is the answer to it. Their success in making that argument — keeping taxes and government investment low — has helped increase American income inequality to crisis proportions: 95 percent of the income gains since 2009 have gone to the top 1 percent. The majority of the country has stagnated or lost ground, leaving the economy sluggish.

headline: New Yorkers Assess Their New Mayor
text: In his inaugural address at City Hall, New York's new mayor, Bill de Blasio, promised to follow through on promises to address inequality. The mood among some New Yorkers was positive, but pragmatic.

headline: Edward Snowden, Whistle-Blower
text: Seven months ago, the world began to learn the vast scope of the National Security Agency’s reach into the lives of hundreds of millions of people in the United States and around the globe, as it collects information about their phone calls, their email messages, their friends and contacts, how they spend their days and where they spend their nights. The public learned in great detail how the agency has exceeded its mandate and abused its authority, prompting outrage at kitchen tables and at the desks of Congress, which may finally begin to limit these practices.

headline: Colorado Stores Selling Marijuana Open Their Doors
text: At 40 shops across the state, residents and tourists flashed their identifications and took part in what supporters hailed as a historic departure from drug laws focused on punishment and prohibition.

headline: Burning the Midnight Oil
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — You learn a lot doing this job. Besides learning how to care for the emus and emergency-handcode JSON at midnight (which they definitely don’t teach in humor writer’s school), I am lucky enough to learn about all sorts of things that come out of the crossword puzzles. It goes on constantly, and that perhaps explains why, on the last day of the year which is when I am writing this post, my brain just couldn’t find the will to tease Todd Gross’s theme out of today’s puzzle. When I finally found out what it was, however, I thought it was brilliant.

headline: At Inauguration, Seeing Another Sign of Change in What the First Family Wore
text: Bill de Blasio was dressed in a suit that seemed to basically fit. His wife, Chirlane McCray, wore a tailored, aubergine coat, his daughter, Chiara, had on a leopard-print overcoat, and his son, Dante, was in a suit and a plaid scarf, but no tie.

headline: Alfred Marshall, Founder of Stores That Bear His Name, Dies at 94
text: Alfred Marshall, a founder of the Marshalls department store chain, which became a success buying out-of-season, irregular and overstocked inventory from fashionable clothing stores and selling it at a discount, died on Dec. 28 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 94.

headline: Bill Clinton Swears In de Blasio

headline: With Clintons in His Corner, de Blasio Bolsters Ties to His Party’s ‘Gold Standard’
text: At an inauguration infused with populist talk about racial tensions, social inequities and the Dickensian conditions of New York City’s poorest residents, Mayor Bill de Blasio had the support of the centrist standard bearers of the Democratic Party: former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: New Year’s Day, 1864
text: It is easy enough to conclude in hindsight that 1863 was a year of “turning points” — the Emancipation Proclamation, Gettysburg and Vicksburg most prominent among them — on the Union’s road to victory. Indeed, the sesquicentennial commemorations of 2013 featured a wide array of programs, articles, symposiums, forums and blogs with “turning points” as their theme. But as the year draws to a close, we should pause to remember how uncertain “the situation” still looked to Northerners in the first days of 1864.

headline: What’s Missing in My Byline?
text: If you look closely at my Times byline, beginning with Thursday’s column, you’ll notice something odd. Well, actually, you probably won’t notice it.

headline: For Prostitutes Jailed in China, Forced Labor With No Recourse

headline: An Inaugural Pageantry, With Verse, Song and Surprise Meetings
text: There were grandmothers in fur coats, construction workers with gripes about low pay, and friends and former co-workers with memories of basketball games and protests.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Volcano Rumbles To Life Again In Indonesia
text: Mount Sinabung, which has sporadically erupted since September, started again Wednesday. Some 20,000 have been evacuated.

headline: Kale? Juicing? Trouble Ahead
text: I was into health food before it was cool. There were only two other people I knew who frequented my neighborhood health food store in the late ’80s: an emaciated man with a gray ponytail and a woman with a surprising amount of underarm hair, who smelled of B.O. and patchouli.

headline: Netanyahu Demands Recognition of Israel
text: The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has said that Palestinians’ recognition of the Jewish state is an issue that underpins all others.

headline: Sticking Point in Peace Talks: Recognition of a Jewish State
text: JERUSALEM — As Middle East peace talks churn on, Israel has catapulted to the fore an issue that may be even more intractable than old ones like security and settlements: a demand that the Palestinians recognize Israel as a Jewish state.

headline: Peruvian Style Gets a Contemporary Update
text: Mario Testino isn’t the only notable celebrating Peruvian style right now. In his exhibition “Alta Moda,” on view now through March 29 at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in New York, the fashion photographer celebrates the country’s early ornate fashion with a series of images of its traditional costumes. Meanwhile, fashion designers are adding to the country’s style legacy, taking cues from early and modern Peruvian artisans. Saturated colors, rich textures and intricate detailing have become urban-jungle-friendly thanks to a slew of ready-to-wear pieces and accessories, like Chloé’s nubby boucle sheath in playful pastels and Tabitha Simmons’s multicolored Peruvian silk espadrilles. Pom poms, tassels and beads appear on many of the playful accessories, including a knit bag from Mochila and a handmade clutch from the Muzungu Sisters, which could almost pass for souvenirs from a trip to Machu Picchu.

headline: Cleverly Made Carpets That Look Good Enough to Eat
text: Since joining forces in 2011, the Brooklyn designers Chen Chen and Kai Williams have created a number of surprising products derived from experiments with process. One of the most interesting was their cold-cut coasters, made by wrapping materials such as fishnet and rope around a central wooden rod or “bone” and then slicing it, like a maki roll. The resulting multicolored disks really do look almost edible. The coasters were the inspiration for a set of four circular rugs the duo created for the luxury custom carpet company Tai Ping, which was unveiled last month at Design Miami. Using a technique the designers came up with to combine multiple fibers, the carpets were fabricated in wool, cotton, chenille, bamboo, PVC, silk and more, giving the appearance of a cross section of a living organism beneath your feet.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 7 P.M. (Syfy) PAUL (2011) He looks like any other extraterrestrial, with his otherworldly cast, bald bobble head, big eyes and stick limbs. Until you get to the board shorts and the backpack. In other words, Paul, voiced by Seth Rogen and the title character of this comedy from Greg Mottola, is a little green dude. And he comes in peace, man, despite causing havoc while he tries to phone home. Simon Pegg, above with Paul, and Nick Frost are the best friends, fresh from a Comic-Con convention in San Diego, who run into Paul as they guide their recreational vehicle toward Area 51, the military base in Nevada where the conspiracy minded think the government stashes aliens. Jason Bateman is one of the men in black hunting Paul; Kristen Wiig is the love interest who wears a T-shirt depicting Jesus blowing away Darwin; and John Carroll Lynch is her daddy, a member of the Bible and gun club. “As genial, foolish and demographically engineered as it sounds (hailing all fan boys and girls),” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, “ ‘Paul’ is at once a buddy flick and a classic American road movie of self- (and other) discovery, interspersed with buckets of expletives and some startling (especially for a big-studio release) pokes at Christian fundamentalism.”

headline: Private Schools for Poor Pressured by Right to Education Act
text: MUMBAI — In Dharavi, a Mumbai slum, a  ramshackle building houses the Bombay South Indian Adi-Dravida Sangh school, where 1,000 students from poor families take their classes in English, a language increasingly perceived as the key to a white-collar job.

headline: Chinese Copter Rescues 52 From Ship in Antarctic Ice
text: LONDON — In a dramatic operation displaying unusual international harmony in one of the world’s most remote and inhospitable places, a red-and-white Chinese helicopter on Thursday rescued 52 passengers trapped for more than a week aboard an icebound Russian research ship in Antarctica, ferrying them a dozen at a time to an Australian icebreaker.

headline: A Speck in the Sea
text: Looking back, John Aldridge knew it was a stupid move. When you’re alone on the deck of a lobster boat in the middle of the night, 40 miles off the tip of Long Island, you don’t take chances. But he had work to do: He needed to start pumping water into the Anna Mary’s holding tanks to chill, so that when he and his partner, Anthony Sosinski, reached their first string of traps a few miles farther south, the water would be cold enough to keep the lobsters alive for the return trip. In order to get to the tanks, he had to open a metal hatch on the deck. And the hatch was covered by two 35-gallon Coleman coolers, giant plastic insulated ice chests that he and Sosinski filled before leaving the dock in Montauk harbor seven hours earlier. The coolers, full, weighed about 200 pounds, and the only way for Aldridge to move them alone was to snag a box hook onto the plastic handle of the bottom one, brace his legs, lean back and pull with all his might.

headline: Photographing Hiroshima, Fukushima and Everything in Between
text: Kikujiro Fukushima’s life in photography took off when he promised to avenge the Hiroshima bombing. It was 1952, and Mr. Fukushima — a watchmaker, volunteer social worker and photographer — met Sugimatsu Nakamura, a 43-year-old fisherman, who was gravely ill from the atomic bomb’s effects.

headline: Portraits of a Rust Belt Mill Town
text: Zoe Strauss loves monumental undertakings. She embarked on her first photographic project, “Under I-95” — spanning a decade and encompassing “literally everything” — without knowing anything about making pictures. Her new project, “Homesteading,” is similarly all-encompassing, tracing the history and socioeconomic topography of Homestead, Pa., the site of a fabled Carnegie-owned steel mill that closed in 1986.

headline: What Hobbies Have Been Passed Down in Your Family?
text: As the holiday break comes to a close, think about how you spent your time. Did you see a movie, attend a sports event, take a hike or enjoy other favorite activities? Where, when and with whom did you first do those things? What about now? What role did family members play in shaping the hobbies and pursuits that are today a big part of your life?

headline: For Messi, the Best Medicine Is Time
text: Welcome back, Lionel Messi, when you are good and ready.

headline: Complex Effort for Antarctic Rescue
text: Updated, 10:01 a.m. The red-and-white Chinese helicopter with dual rotors hovered over the ice, then settled gently on a flat patch at one of the earth’s southernmost points. At least seven men in puffy orange jackets clambered out and onto the Antarctic polar cap.

headline: Musharraf Is Hospitalized, Delaying His Day in Court
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The former Pakistani military ruler Pervez Musharraf was taken to a military hospital on Thursday over concerns about an unexplained heart condition, Pakistani officials said, derailing for a third time a scheduled court hearing in treason proceedings against him.

headline: Daily Report: Two Views on the E-Book Reading Experience
text: As e-books gain in popularity — and as many of us download new e-books on our shiny, new tablets —  two authors consider whether reading through technology affects the experience of reading.

headline: Delhi Grocers Recall 50 Years of Changing Indian Tastes
text: These days, it’s easy to find once-exotic foods like spaghetti and Parmesan cheese at grocery stores in India. For that, food lovers can thank the proprietors of Steakhouse in central Delhi, one of the first stores that catered to a certain aesthetic of consumerism in India, where an aspiring and growing middle class sought the opportunity to partake in a slice of Western culture.

headline: Body of Former Rwandan Spymaster Is Found in Johannesburg Hotel
text: JOHANNESBURG — The South African police said on Thursday that they had opened a murder investigation into the death of an exiled former spy chief from Rwanda, who was found dead in a hotel room with signs of possible strangulation.

headline: Fiat Gaining Full Ownership of Chrysler
text: The Italian carmaker Fiat said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to take full ownership of Chrysler, the smallest of the three American automakers, in a $4.35 billion deal with the United Automobile Workers retiree health care fund. The deal to buy out the trust’s 41 percent stake, expected to close on Jan. 20, would make Fiat the world’s seventh-largest automaker, Jaclyn Trop reports in The New York Times.

headline: Shanti Atkins, on the 30-Second Approach to Decision-Making
text: This interview with Shanti Atkins, president and chief strategy officer of Navex Global, which handles ethics and compliance issues, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Life Goes On, at Long Last
text: NEWBURY, England — We have raged against fate and come through our stages of grief. We have accepted that no matter how much we miss him — his limpid blue eyes, his good sense in marrying Lady Mary after his tiresome fiancée finally succumbed to the flu — Matthew Crawley is never coming back. He is dead, having been hit by a truck while driving inattentively in the waning moments of last season on “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Repsol Completes Sale of Natural Gas Assets to Shell
text: LONDON – The energy company Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it had completed its $5.4 billion acquisition of Repsol’s liquefied natural gas business outside North America, a deal originally announced last February.

headline: Obama's Golfing Style
text: The president plays a slow and methodical game of golf, taking multiple practice swings and spending up to six hours on the course.

headline: A Smile Defuses Subway Wrath
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Tribalism, Biology, and Macroeconomics
text: I’m a bit late to this party, but Pew has a new report about changing views on evolution. The big takeaway is that a plurality of self-identified Republicans now believe that no evolution whatsoever has taken place since the day of creation — let alone that evolution is driven by natural selection. The move is big: an 11-point decline since 2009.

headline: App Smart: Resolutions
text: A selection of great apps to help you keep your new year's resolutions.

headline: Jehane Noujaim on Filming History as It Happens
text: The Egyptian-American director Jehane Noujaim had already made several prize-winning documentaries about Egypt when massive protests against the dictatorship of Hosni Mubarak erupted in Cairo in January 2011. She knew she had to remain there to chronicle the uprising, and spent the next two and a half years filming “The Square,” which has won awards at festivals from Sundance to Dubai and has been shortlisted for the Oscar for best documentary feature.

headline: A Winter Weekend in the North Fork
text: It’s free to watch the sun set over the wetlands that fringe the causeway connecting East Marion and Orient, near the eastern tip of Long Island’s North Fork. If the weather has been dry enough in this wine country just across the bay from the Hamptons, there’s a good perch on the marshy land near Latham Farms, by a little cabin on stilts known locally as the crab shack. The wine is also free, if your friend Jeanny Pak happens to have brought along a bottle of malbec and some plastic cups without telling you.

headline: Why Walk?
text: “The Old Ways: A Journey on Foot” by Robert Macfarlane caps off a trilogy of books that examine the subtle links between landscape, history and the imagination. Having already ventured into wilds, high and low, this third book focuses on the ancient routes and countless communal pathways that mark the world, connecting people to places, one another and the landscapes they inhabit.

headline: Image of the Day: January 2
text: Members of Indian Army band rehearsing for the Republic Day parade in New Delhi.

headline: Disinformation on Inequality
text: Miles Kimball catches Bret Stephens pulling a fast one on Wall Street Journal readers – but it’s much worse than Kimball says.

headline: Deadly Bombing in Beirut Suburb, a Hezbollah Stronghold, Raises Tensions
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The second deadly car bomb to strike the Beirut area in less than a week exploded on Thursday in a southern suburb of residential apartment buildings that is home to top Hezbollah offices and heavily populated with the group’s supporters.

headline: Father Requests Forgiveness for Teenage Shooter Who Killed Daughter
text: The father of Claire Davis, the 17-year-old Colorado girl who was shot and killed by a fellow student at Arapahoe High School last month, asked people during a New Year’s Day memorial service to honor his daughter by forgiving the gunman and showing empathy and compassion to troubled individuals.

text: 1914: Aeroplane Line Inaugurated

headline: Avoiding the Midwinter ‘Back to School’ Slump
text: It’s back-to-school time again. No, not the exciting September return, with all its newness and promise, but the other one, the January return. The one that arrives not with a bang but a whimper.

headline: Missing a Cancer Diagnosis
text: Stories of misdiagnoses circulate throughout the testimonies of people contending with all sorts of cancers. Such errors, made by patients as well as doctors, bring in their wake a sense of betrayal, self-recrimination and anger. Should we accept them as inevitable?

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Ode’
text: The first Poetry Pairing of 2014 features “Ode,” a poem written by Arthur O’Shaughnessy in the mid-1800s, and the article “The Revolution Will Have Live Music” by Colin Moynihan.

headline: A King’s Counselor, Whittled to Size
text: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — When Hilary Mantel was writing “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” her best-selling novels about the court of Henry VIII, she was so scrupulous about accuracy that she created a card catalog of dates and events to ensure that her characters were never out of joint with the past. But when the Royal Shakespeare Company began cutting her 500-page books into two-and-a-half-hour plays, Ms. Mantel had to act as “the history police,” as she put it.

headline: New York Times to Unveil Redesigned Website Next Week
text: The New York Times said on Thursday that it would launch its redesigned website on Jan. 8.

headline: Video of Second Bombing in Beirut in Less Than a Week
text: As my colleague Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, a large explosion hit the southern suburbs of Beirut on Thursday in an area populated by supporters of Hezbollah. It appeared to be the latest in a spree of bombings over Hezbollah’s support for the government of neighboring Syria in that country’s civil war.

headline: Concern Over an Increasingly Seen Gesture Grows in France
text: PARIS — No one seems to know just what is meant by the “quenelle,” the vaguely menacing hand gesture invented and popularized by a French comedian widely criticized as anti-Semitic, but it is clearly nothing very nice, and it appears to be spreading.

headline: Trying to Sing Their Way to the Oscars
text: The singers of “20 Feet From Stardom” took to the stage of the Rose Bowl on Wednesday to perform a four-voiced rendition of the national anthem. It was part of a campaign by Radius, the division of the Weinstein Company that distributed that documentary about backup singers, to inject some more verve into the movie’s chances with Academy members.

headline: Michael Counts to Join 3-Legged Dog Theater Company
text: Michael Counts, a director and visual artist known for his imaginative multimedia opera and theater productions, is joining the avant-garde theater company 3-Legged Dog as creative director of the 3LD Special Projects Group. The company, which specializes in immersive productions and installations that combine live performance and video, announced the appointment on Thursday.

text: Also on the Minute, married fashion photographers redefine themselves as a lifestyle brand and Capitol Hill in 2014.

text: Shots taken using the Phantom 2 Vision Photo Drone from DJI.

headline: Kerry Quietly Makes Priority of Climate Pact
text: WASHINGTON — As a young naval officer in Vietnam, John Kerry commanded a Swift boat up the dangerous rivers of the Mekong Delta. But when he returned there last month as secretary of state for the first time since 1969, he spoke not of past firefights but of climate change.

headline: Art and Life on the Border
text: Artists explore gang violence and the politics of immigration on the Mexican border.

headline: A Vale of Terror, Transcended
text: MATAMOROS, Mexico — The artist Patricia Ruiz-Bayón recently met with three migrants in a shelter in this ravaged border city and invited them to take part in one of her performance works. The piece, “70+2...,” commemorated an act of extreme brutality that continues to traumatize the region: a 2010 massacre of 72 migrants in nearby San Fernando that the Mexican authorities say was carried out by the Zetas criminal gang.

headline: Qaeda-Aligned Militants Threaten Key Iraqi Cities
text: BAGHDAD — Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda threatened Thursday to seize control of Falluja and Ramadi, two of the most important cities in Iraq, setting fire to police stations, freeing prisoners from jail and occupying mosques, as the government rushed troop reinforcements to the areas.

headline: Distracted Drivers and New Drivers a Perilous Mix
text: An inexperienced driver who reaches for a cellphone increases the risk for a crash by more than 700 percent, a new study found.

headline: Blast Inquiry in Prague Finds Weapons
text: BERLIN — Officials investigating an explosion that killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic on Wednesday at his residence in Prague found illegal weapons in a search of the compound, the Prague police chief said Thursday.

headline: Russell Banks: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “A Permanent Member of the Family” steers clear of any book described as fantasy, “which to me says, ‘Don’t worry, Reader, Death will be absent here.’ ”

headline: Joseph Lieberman Joins Private Equity Firm
text: Over lunch in Manhattan several months ago, Brendan Carroll, a partner and co-founder of the private equity firm Victory Park Capital, had a proposition for his former boss, Joseph I. Lieberman, the former senator from Connecticut and onetime vice-presidential candidate: Would Mr. Lieberman be interested in joining his firm?
