An impeccably renovated Upper East Side townhouse and a two-bedroom condominium at the predictably prestigious 15 Central Park West both traded for $15.5 million, according to city records.

headline: Not Quite All Spoonfuls of Sugar
text: For nearly 50 years, moviegoers have embraced “Mary Poppins” as a whimsical Disney classic about a magical English nanny, a twinkly chimney sweep and a London banker’s fractured family. But the new Disney film “Saving Mr. Banks,” written by Kelly Marcel and Sue Smith, shares two less cheerful tales. In flashback, it reveals the “Mary Poppins” author P. L. Travers’s sad past as an Australian girl with a hard-drinking father and a suicidal mother. The other story is of two weeks in 1961 when Walt Disney (Tom Hanks), who had been trying to secure the film rights from Ms. Travers (Emma Thompson) for nearly 20 years, finally lured her to California, where Disney staff composers, the Sherman Brothers (Jason Schwartzman and B. J. Novak), struggled to collaborate with her.

headline: Storm Shows Off a Less Stoic Mayor Now in Charge
text: He trudged out with a shovel soon after sunrise, scraping the snow from his sidewalk and reminding New Yorkers to “lift with your knees.”

headline: Are Sugary Drinks Fattening? Depends Who You Ask
text: Are there good scientific studies that show that drinking sugar-sweetened soda increases the risk for obesity? The answer may vary depending on who is paying for the study.

headline: Knowing When to Compromise
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Diving Into the Wreck
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Sean Greer reviews Chang-rae Lee’s new novel, “On Such a Full Sea.” Mr. Greer writes:

headline: Music Becomes a Real Game Changer
text: The composer Austin Wintory’s office in Burbank, Calif., contains a desk, a chair and a life-size model of R2-D2. A windowless adjoining room, with an electric piano and two computers, is where Mr. Wintory, 29, says he spends up to 14 hours a day working on his music.

headline: A Makeover for the Affinia 50 in New York
text: Affinia 50, a 10-year-old hotel property in Manhattan’s Midtown East neighborhood, has undergone a $20 million transformation. The 10-month renovation included an overhaul of the 251 guest rooms and public areas like the lobby, corridors and second-floor Club Room, which is a social space for guests.

headline: Divining a 5-Year Investment Strategy
text: FIVE years ago, it would have been easy to predict that the stock market would be higher today than it was then. But no one would have paid attention. Stocks were in a free fall and wouldn’t hit bottom for two more months.

headline: ‘It’s Just How He Carries Himself’
text: A year before the actor Chiwetel Ejiofor, born in England to a Nigerian immigrant family, began filming “12 Years a Slave,” he was in Savannah, Ga., making another movie when he signed up for a tour of the city. One stop left a deep impression on him: a 19th-century slave pen, used to hold newly arrived Africans before they were sent to auction, and had, he recalled, “a sequence of bolts high on the wall.”

headline: Barberry and Orange Tea
text: I have in my pantry a rather large bag of dried barberries, bought at my Persian market, and I had been using them up slowly. Now I know where much of what remains of these sour, zingy vitamin C-rich dried fruits will go.

headline: Meyer Lemon and Ginger Infusion With Turmeric and Cayenne
text: There is a lot going on in this lovely infusion, with the tart lemon and pungent ginger. Turmeric contributes beautiful color, along with its nutritional benefits – it has been shown to have powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant attributes — and the tiny pinch of cayenne packs a small punch. If you feel a sore throat coming on I highly recommend this tea.

headline: Dried Apricot, Cherry and Cranberry Infusion
text: Whenever I soak dried fruit in hot water, to plump it for another recipe, I am always reluctant to throw out the soaking water because it tastes so good. I decided to simmer dried fruit with sweet spices and orange to obtain a delicious infusion that I would decidedly not throw out. A great beverage for a snowy day.

headline: Coconut Ginger Tea With Lime, Honey and Turmeric
text: I love the fair trade teas produced by Zhena’s Gypsy Tea, especially her Coconut Chai. Inspired by the perfume of coconut in that tea, I infused shredded coconut and ginger and added a little fresh lime juice, honey and a smidgeon of turmeric. The idea of making a turmeric and honey paste comes from Heidi Swanson’s 101cookbooks.com.

headline: U.S. Winter Training Camp Tilts Toward M.L.S.
text: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national soccer team, named a 26-man roster for the team’s January training camp on Friday, giving a mix of veterans and newcomers one last chance to make a case for a roster spot for next summer’s World Cup in Brazil.

headline: Is 2014 the Year of the Connected Home?
text: Tech companies have been talking for years about the so-called connected home, in which home appliances and accessories connect to the Internet. Judging from Christmas with my family — as well as the news expected at the International Consumer Electronics Show next week — this year it might become a reality.

headline: Justin Timberlake Album Was the Top Seller in a Diminished Market
text: The year-end chart news is mixed for Justin Timberlake. On the bright side, “The 20/20 Experience” (RCA), the comeback album he released in March, was the top selling album of 2013, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Back to the Future in Algeria
text: The legacy of Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect who died in 2012 at the age of 104, is most familiarly seen in the Modernist buildings he designed for Brasilia, the planned city that became the country’s capital in 1960. But his work in Algeria — not nearly so well known — has also enhanced his reputation as one of the 20th century’s great architects. Niemeyer, a Communist who fled to France following the military takeover of Brazil in 1964, designed several buildings in Algeria in the late 1960s (as well as a library in recent years that is still being built). The plan for one, La Coupole, a sports arena in Algiers, which can be seen in the slide show here, was made on a napkin. Mekki Damerdji, an architect and professor in Algiers, says Mentouri University (shown here), in the city of Constantine, is a favorite of his for its stark contrast to the more traditional buildings that dominate the country’s landscape. “We’re not used to seeing this shape in our country,” Damerdji says. “We haven’t anything like this in Algeria. It’s very beautiful. It’s like a bird.” Julie Bosman

headline: What I Love | Jill and Jimmy Haber
text: The couple’s 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side boasts six fireplaces and an indoor basketball court.

headline: A Fine-Feathered Family Nest
text: Jill and Jimmy Haber love every square inch of their five-story, 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side. Brimming with pride and a palpable sense of contentment as they stand in their foyer with its welcoming fireplace, they worry only about whether to commence a visitor’s tour on the bottom or the top floor.

headline: Abortion Restrictions Passed by States
text: State legislatures enacted 70 restrictions on abortion in 2013; over the past three years, they passed more of these laws than they did from 2000 to 2010.

headline: In a Man’s Mind, Anything Goes
text: This is the week when television comes back to life after the holidays. New series like CBS’s “Intelligence” make their debuts. Shows that had their premieres this past fall, like “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.” on ABC and “Almost Human” on Fox, start their “winter seasons”: i.e., new episodes after a spate of reruns. A few shows even have season finales, like CBS’s “Hostages.”

headline: Unemployed in Europe Stymied by Lack of Technology Skills
text: DUBLIN — Week after week, newspapers issue a stream of hopeful headlines: Microsoft, PayPal, Fujitsu and scores of other companies are expanding their investments in Ireland, creating thousands of jobs as unemployment hovers near record highs.

headline: Festival Opens With Soviet Tale
text: It seems apt that the New York Jewish Film Festival should open with a joke. This one, at the beginning of “Friends From France,” the opening-night film on Wednesday, goes like this:

headline: Captured in Time: A Certain New York
text: Unfettered optimism was the unofficial religion of the United States in the early 20th century, but the photographer Lewis Hine (1874-1940) declined to buy in, refused to be steamrollered by our natural cultural euphoria, as the retrospective “Lewis Hine” at the International Center of Photography clearly shows. The exhibition includes Hine’s earliest work, from Ellis Island (1905), and includes selections from his later major photographic essays, including those on immigration, child labor, working men and construction of the Empire State Building.

headline: Political Torment, Teenage Angst
text: Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now, an ambitious festival started in January 2013 by Beth Morrison Projects and the Here Arts Center, returns on Wednesday for a second season, with four principal shows and a bevy of side attractions.

headline: Gems of Jazz for Winter’s Night
text: This year’s edition of Winter Jazz Festival runs five nights instead of two. It was already a significant jazz event in New York — now even more so. The first three nights are self-contained, concerts at Le Poisson Rouge and Town Hall: the drummer Bobby Previte’s all-star group, Terminals, on Tuesday; a head-to-head, double-piano concert involving Jason Moran, Robert Glasper and their various associates on Wednesday; and the Revive Big Band on Thursday.

headline: 20 Companies at Joyce and N.Y.U.
text: Every January, the Association of Performing Arts Presenters meets in New York, and one subject delegates are sure to ponder is the choosing of dance groups to present in coming months. No wonder dancers hope to attract attention by performing at conference time. Gotham Arts Exchange, which provides management assistance to artists, hopes to entice both presenters and the public with its Focus series at two theaters. Eight companies will appear at the Joyce Theater (opening Tuesday), and there will be 12 at the Skirball Center (opening Friday), with each performance offering at least two attractions.

headline: Stranded Antarctic Ship Story, Like the Ice, Will Not Let Go
text: A team of rescuers from a Chinese icebreaker may need to be rescued themselves, soon after they plucked dozens of people from the Antarctic ice aboard a ship that had been stranded for more than a week.

headline: Duck Dynasty Diversifies
text: Selling plain old duck calls — simple tools that lure prey with fake quacks — underpins the phenomenal financial success of “Duck Dynasty’s” Robertson clan, one of cable’s favorite families. Phil Robertson, the outspoken evangelical patriarch, got into trouble lately with some homophobic, fire-and-brimstone remarks, but after a brief suspension from the show, he was reinstated—in a fight between high-mindedness and ratings, ratings always win — and the duck calls kept selling by the millions. Actual hunters comprise a minority of sales, according to Willie Robertson, the family business executive who said most are bought by people who “put it on their desk and toot on it.”

headline: Writers Guild Unveils Picks for Screenplay Categories
text: The Writers Guild of America has released its nominations for best screenplay. Here’s a quick look at its picks. Stay tuned for the Bagger’s analysis.

headline: Access to Abortion Falling as States Pass Restrictions
text: A three-year surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has altered the landscape for abortion access, with supporters and opponents agreeing that the new restrictions are shutting some clinics, threatening others and making it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.

headline: AT&T Offers Customers Credit for Leaving T-Mobile
text: Updated | This post now includes a statement from the chief executive of T-Mobile US.

headline: Daughter of Palestinian Envoy Killed in Czech Republic Suspects Foul Play
text: GAZA — The daughter of Jamal al-Jamal, 56, the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic who was killed this week in an explosion at his home in Prague, said Friday that she believed he was murdered.

headline: World War II Bomb Kills One Person in Germany
text: BERLIN — The explosion of a World War II bomb in a town in western Germany killed one person and wounded at least 13 others on Friday, the police said.

headline: Momentum Builds for ‘Hustle’ and ‘Dallas’ as ‘Llewyn’ Lags
text: Not all Oscar-hopeful screenplays are eligible for the Writers Guild Awards: heavy hitters like “12 Years a Slave” and “Philomena” didn’t qualify (for lack of membership or other bureaucratic reasons), along with the indies “Short Term 12” and “Fruitvale Station.” But several of the top contenders for the Little Golden Guy got nods today from the guild. There were surprises like the inclusion of “Lone Survivor,” the director Peter Berg’s adaptation of a true story of a Navy SEAL mission gone terribly awry; and the omission of “Inside Llewyn Davis,” from the Coen brothers, whom the Writers Guild has favored before. (Perhaps the members were bothered by what the Coens themselves described as the film’s lack of a plot.)

headline: Court Grants Secrecy for Memo on Phone Data
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday ruled that the Obama administration may continue to withhold a Justice Department memo that apparently opened a loophole in laws protecting the privacy of consumer data.

headline: Israel and U.S. Test Interceptor Missile
text: JERUSALEM — The missile defense agencies of Israel and the United States carried out a second test of the advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system over the Mediterranean Sea on Friday, Israel’s Defense Ministry said in a statement.

headline: Questions About Inmates’ Holiday Food, Orange Cabs and Bogart’s Brooklyn Ties
text: Q. Did the inmates at Rikers Island get a special Christmas dinner? I’m curious about the menu.

headline: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
text: The song "Green Green Rocky Road" performed by Oscar Isaac in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
text: Oscar Isaac, Justin Timberlake and Adam Driver perform "Please Mr. Kennedy" in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: Wooing Filmgoers Through Their Ears
text: LOS ANGELES — In the new film by Joel and Ethan Coen, a struggling folk singer, Llewyn Davis, plays a song for a music promoter. After listening intently, the promoter issues his review: “I don’t see a lot of money here.”

headline: Thrift Store Owner Finds His Calling and Salvation
text: Anthony Cody gained the nickname Tony Bargains after cleaning out a crack house on Boston Road in the Allerton section of the Bronx and opening Tony’s Bargain Basement Thrift Shop.

headline: A Lexicon of Instant Argot
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Millions watched and gossiped online as Miley Cyrus “twerked” on stage at MTV’s video music awards in late 2013. Then, they rushed to Urban Dictionary to figure out what that was — making “twerk” one of the most-searched terms on the site all year.

headline: Spinach Salad With Prosciutto
text: The addition of prosciutto, persimmon and croutons to a regular spinach salad makes light fare substantial enough for a full meal.

headline: Bradley, Former U.S. and Egypt Coach, Joins Norwegian Club
text: The career of Bob Bradley, the former national team soccer coach for the United States and Egypt, took another interesting turn on Friday when he was formally introduced as the manager of the Norwegian club Stabaek. The two-year deal makes Bradley, 55, the first American head coach of a top-tier European team.

headline: Obama Announces Gun Control Actions
text: Updated, 10:46 p.m. | HONOLULU — President Obama announced two new executive actions on Friday that nudge his gun control agenda forward by making it easier for states to provide information about people with mental illness to the federal background check system.

headline: An Artistic Armchair Travel Platform That Visits the World’s Most Amazing Places
text: Growing up in rural Maine, the brothers Darrell and Oliver Hartman learned to love the outdoorsy, adventurous life from their dad, who was the director of the state’s parks. Trips in early adulthood to places like Greece, Nicaragua and India ensured their passion for wanderlust, as did the jobs they pursued: Darrell, 32, is a lifestyle and travel writer; Oliver, 30, is a director for the production company North. Last year, the pair decided to combine talents to create a website that celebrates the kind of travel they like to do.

headline: Chasing the Northern Lights in Alaska
text: We hurtled across the tundra in the dark. The old train chugged, rattled, occasionally whined. As the sun came up around 10 a.m., the world faded from black to cobalt to white and every shade between. All was snow; it was just a matter of how much, where, what shape. Black spruce trees draped in white rose up from the ground like crystals of hoarfrost.

headline: Traveling While Black
text: As I walked through the Forbidden City, the majestic imperial palace at the center of Beijing, with a friend and her teenager, I scanned the crowd. In the maze of shrines and courtyards, there was no one quite like us: I am an African-American with long dreadlocks, and my friend, Maria, a Mexican-American, had her half-Dominican son in tow.

headline: A Big Salad That Stands In for Dinner
text: I’ve never been very good with New Year’s resolutions, especially the ones along juice-cleansing, teetotaling, diet-and-exercise lines. All those high expectations inevitably set me up to fail.

headline: Aloof Felines
text: Reverend Run, king of (sheet) rock; dual showering, considered.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A home in Fairfield, Conn., with views of inlets on Long Island Sound; and one in Manalapan, N.J., with a heated pool and a hot tub.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Greenwich Village apartment with built-ins; an East Village home with exposed brick; and a Brooklyn Heights condo with harbor views.

headline: Clip: 'Another Day Another Time'
text: Oscar Isaac, Marcus Mumford and the Punch Brothers perform “Fare Thee Well” in the documentary “Another Day Another Time,” which celebrates the music of “Inside Llewyn Davis.”

headline: Cyberdeal Hits the Sweet Spot
text: At first glance, the latest cybersecurity deal looks like a breach of logic. FireEye’s market value shot up by a third on Friday, a move worth $1.6 billion, more than it said it had spent to buy Mandiant. The deal marries FireEye’s threat protection with its target’s capabilities to respond to cyberattacks after they happen. Even with the industrial fit, the welcome from investors was unusually warm.

headline: Annual Sales for American Automakers Reach a 6-Year High
text: DETROIT — It was the best year for American auto sales since 2007, and among the biggest winners were the car companies from Detroit.

headline: Ballet Without Borders
text: At 45, the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky and his work have become internationally ubiquitous.

headline: In Britain, Housing Prices Rise the Fastest Since 2006
text: LONDON — Housing prices in Britain rose last year at the fastest pace since 2006, adding to fears that the country’s real estate market is overheating.

headline: An App That Helps Users Cut Calories
text: New York City’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is proud of its technological prowess: The rotating banner of the agency’s home page features a link to the four smartphone apps that the agency has created. One of those apps, CalCutter, would seem a great download for this time of year, both to celebrate the now-concluded tenure of that most health-conscious of mayors and to aid in that ubiquitous resolution for a healthier diet.

headline: The de Blasios: A Simple Outfit
text: Inaugurations are a bit like weddings in that clothing choices on the in-law side are suddenly and harshly on display. So that’s what they look like?

headline: Bundling Up With Lamb
text: This is not the season for roast lamb. Wouldn’t you rather have a warming stew during these bitterly cold days?

headline: British Company Names Year’s Best Album Covers
text: Music collectors have long lamented the effect that miniaturization – the move from 12-inch LP jackets to 5.75-inch CD booklets, and then to thumbnail photos on digital downloads – has had on record jacket art. But Art Vinyl, a British company that makes frames for record covers, has been encouraging performers and collectors to think more carefully about cover art since 2005, when it established its annual Best Art Vinyl award, with the winners chosen through online voting.

headline: Williams Continues Dominance of Sharapova
text: BRISBANE, Australia — Defying the conventional script, the two main characters in women’s tennis faced off in the first scene of the 2014 season.

headline: Steps Heard ’Round the World
text: The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is 45. It’s safe to say that no choreographer in history at that age has made such pervasive inroads into the international ballet repertory. He has now created ballets for the leading companies of America, Australia, Britain, Canada, Denmark, France, Italy, the Netherlands and his native Russia. Most of those troupes, shopping around in the global supermarket of dance today, have also acquired other works of his. In 2013, he had no fewer than seven world premieres in five cities on three continents. It becomes increasingly evident that he is the most prolific choreographer alive, the most travel-hungry and the most historically conscious.

headline: Claire Danes’s Fashion Choices
text: Ms. Danes’s style includes clean shapes and flirty prints.

headline: Arctic Temperatures for Players and Fans, but No Blackouts on TV
text: The first winter storm of 2014 has largely come and gone, but it has left snow, frigid temperatures and untold delays in its wake. Caught in the mess are the thousands of N.F.L. players, fans and members of the news media trying to get to Cincinnati, Green Bay, Indianapolis and Philadelphia, where wild-card games will be played this weekend.

headline: On Journeys of Discovery, One Is Cut Short
text: Doe B

headline: How to Keep Your Resolutions
text: IT’S that time of year again. Maybe it’s your waistline you’re worried about, or maybe it’s the smoking habit you just can’t seem to kick. To improve your chances of keeping your New Year’s resolutions, we offer four tips inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health. We focus on health, but our suggestions should help with other goals, too.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 3, 2014
text: Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioner’s departure.

headline: With Crisis Behind Him, S.E.C.’s Co-Chief of Enforcement Is Leaving
text: Updated, 8:08 p.m. |

headline: Family and Football, With a Few Audibles, for Music Executive
text: Since the 1980s, when Lyor Cohen was one of the young executives who helped establish the business infrastructure of hip-hop, he has been one of the music industry’s hardest-charging figures. The former head of Def Jam records and the recorded music division of the Warner Music Group, Mr. Cohen, 54, recently announced his new venture, a boutique music company named 300. But on weekends, he devotes himself to family — and football.

headline: Dazzling, on Screen and Off
text: WHO Claire Danes

headline: N.H.T.S.A Tells Child Seat Manufacturer to Conduct Recall; Chevrolet Pickups and Range Rovers Are Also Recalled
text: About 33,000 child safety seats are being recalled by Combi USA because the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says the restraining straps could break during a crash. The recall comes after the safety agency rejected Combi’s request that it be excused from a recall because the failure to meet the federal safety standard was “inconsequential to motor vehicle safety.”

headline: More About Jerry Goodman
text: I see that Bloomberg has an obit up; still waiting on the Times. I’m not going to do a proper life, just say a few things.

headline: General Cleburne’s Radical Plan
text: On Jan. 2, 1864, Gen. Joseph Johnston, the commander of the largest Confederate army outside Virginia, called an evening meeting of his subordinate generals in his headquarters in northwest Georgia. The purpose of the meeting was kept secret from all but a few. When they arrived, they found Gen. Patrick Cleburne, an Irish immigrant and one of Johnston’s best division commanders, who presented a radical proposal: to enlist slaves as rebel soldiers in exchange for their freedom.

headline: Videos of Fighters and Air Raids in Iraq’s Anbar Province
text: Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda fought for control of Falluja and Ramadi on Friday, escalating a battle over the two cities that have increasingly become centers of Sunni extremism since American forces withdrew from the country at the end of 2011.

headline: Evangelicals Find Themselves in the Midst of a Calvinist Revival
text: For those who are sad that the year-end news quizzes are past, here’s one to start 2014: If you have joined a church that preaches a Tulip theology, does that mean a) the pastor bakes flowers into the communion wafers, b) the pastor believes that flowers that rise again every spring symbolize the resurrection, or c) the pastor is a Calvinist?

headline: Bratton and Miller Back in Blue for Round 3
text: Minutes after the news conference last month announcing that he would serve a second term as New York City’s police commissioner, William J. Bratton and a group of close friends sat down over rigatoni and meatballs at Ferdinando’s Focacceria, a subway-tiled Sicilian joint a few blocks from the docks in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The location and the lunch guests were classic Bratton. Gathered at a table in the back, under photos of Palermo and a stamped-tin ceiling, was a kind of kitchen cabinet: Mr. Bratton’s wife, his retired-detective bodyguards, some former aides from the Police Department, a few associates from his private security firm and the TV reporter John Miller.

headline: The Alien Hunter as Lounge Lizard
text: There’s plenty of reason to be curious, even excited, about “Space Dandy,” a new anime television series beginning on Adult Swim on Saturday night. Shinichiro Watanabe, credited as the show’s general director, is responsible for two of the best Japanese anime series to have made it to American TV in recent years, “Cowboy Bebop” (1998-99) and “Samurai Champloo” (2005-6). The animation studio behind it, Bones, has produced high-quality series like “Fullmetal Alchemist” and “Eureka Seven.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New York, Indonesia, Egypt and Cambodia.

headline: Dominant in Dome, Saints Face Tough Road as They Try to Defy Trends
text: NEW ORLEANS — The New Orleans Saints’ victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in their final regular-season game Sunday featured their trademark passing game, key defensive stops and 70,000 rollicking fans fueled by brass bands and beer.

headline: Reclaiming Fatherhood After Afghanistan
text: During my enlistment, I had the privilege to serve as an infantry rifleman, the primary infantry job in the United States Marine Corps. My role was to locate, close with and destroy or repel the enemy, by fire and close combat. As I advanced through my career, I learned valuable teamwork, communication and leadership skills that I continue to use.

headline: A Circuitous Route to Outer Space
text: In a radio interview not long ago, Alfonso Cuarón compared his movies to ex-wives: He’s grateful, wishes them well, but has no desire to go back and visit. What he didn’t say, but could have, was that none of these wives bears much resemblance to any of the others.

headline: Ask About ‘The House Edge’
text: (Update: A post with the reporters’ replies has now been published.)

headline: Reprising a Lindberg: Same Cast, New Date
text: For even the most successful and popular living composers, a truism exists: It’s much easier to secure a world premiere, with all the first-night appeal and media attention such an occurrence brings, than to gain a second performance of the same work, once the hubbub has faded. Even the most well-received contemporary piece can take some time to resurface, if, indeed, it ever does.

headline: Visual Portents of a Silent Bolt of Thunder
text: On Feb. 7, 1943, John Cage made his first New York public appearance at the Museum of Modern Art with a performance of percussion works that featured his wife, Xenia (whom he would divorce three years later), and Merce Cunningham (who would replace her as his life partner).

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 3
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioner’s departure.

headline: In Praise of Art Laffer
text: No, really. Business Insider contacted him about his 2009 warning that soaring inflation and interest rates were just around the corner — and he not only admits that he was wrong, he admits that his error signified something wrong with his overall economic model:

headline: Palestinian Teenager Dies of Wounds From Israeli Gunfire
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian teenager died on Friday after being wounded by Israeli gunfire near the Israel-Gaza border a day earlier, according to medical officials in Gaza.

headline: Churro Shop Owner Serves Up a Spanish Tradition
text: It was a singular procession that filed into Le Churro on Lexington Avenue between 83rd and 84th Streets one recent afternoon. Eyes wide, riveted on the menu hung high above the counter, children buckling under their backpacks and harried mothers all seemed transfixed by the weight of the decision: Chocolate or caramel sauce?

headline: Lightening the Load on an E.V.’s Batteries
text: Small zero-emission city cars may have cute faces and small footprints, but they also pack more weight than you might expect, forcing engineers to come up with innovative diets.

headline: Electric Service From $199 a Month
text: Electric cars are getting cheaper. Although purchase prices vary, the Chevrolet Spark E.V. and Smart Electric Drive Cabriolet can be leased for three years at $199 a month, and the Fiat 500e at $239. That means consumers are likely to weigh factors other than the bottom line when deciding which — if any — of these small, stylish battery vehicles to put in their driveway.

headline: Cute, but Not Precious
text: The Fiat 500e, Chevrolet Spark and Smart Cabriolet, three tiny battery-powered urban runabouts, aren’t just fun, they’re fairly affordable.

headline: An Underground Portfolio
text: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.

headline: A Night at the Opera, Lost in the Memory of Another
text: I was ready to end 2013 by looking in on a fancy New Year’s Eve party that was supposed to be unfolding in fin de siècle Vienna. The invitation was right there on a curtain that went up at the opening performance of the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “Die Fledermaus.” But when the conductor walked into the pit and bowed, I was transported not to Vienna in 1899, but to Michigan in 1985.

headline: Bringing the Underworld to Light
text: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.

headline: Qaeda-Linked Insurgents Clash With Other Rebels in Syria, as Schism Grows
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Deadly clashes were reported Friday in northern Syria between Sunni Islamist jihadists linked to Al Qaeda and insurgents in other alliances, punctuating a growing schism within the armed Syrian opposition over the power exerted by its religiously radicalized members, many of them from other countries.

headline: Love, the Universal Scenario
text: Enough Said

headline: Call Waiting ... and Waiting
text: Taylor Kitsch, star of NBC’s “Friday Night Lights” and the new war movie “Lone Survivor,” doesn’t field many phone calls when he is in Austin, Tex., where he lives alone.

headline: German Politician’s Rush to Lobbying Brings Scorn
text: BERLIN — If there is one hallmark of Angela Merkel’s chancellorship, it is that, despite her widely acknowledged tactical prowess and skill in winning, keeping and expanding her power, she is uninterested in the material trappings of office.

headline: Feeling For | The Ultimate Vintage E-Shop for Fashion Fanatics
text: After the chaotic holiday months of planning the perfect gifts for others, it’s finally time to think about ourselves. For the fashion conscious, that means planning out your purchases for the upcoming season. But it’s hard to think of the future when you still haven’t crossed off dream items from wish lists of old, like, say those Balenciaga SS 2002 cargo pants or that black oversized Céline coat. Enter Resee, a website that helps track down coveted items that got away. Unveiled last fall by Sabrina Marshall, a former editor at Self Service magazine, and Sofia Bernardin, a Vogue advertising veteran, the secondhand e-shop specializes in vintage pieces by high-end designers like Alaïa, Hermès, Helmut Lang and Raf Simons. In addition to browsing the curated finds — sourced from some legendary sources, including the Paris vintage shop Nella, which gave Resee all its inventory when it closed last year, and the closets of some of the world’s most stylish women — guests can even fill out a virtual want ad for particularly elusive items. The site’s magazine-caliber design and photography is sure to suck you in for hours at a time — then send you forth into 2014 looking your very best.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wonderland
text: Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion.

headline: Not All the Days Were Good
text: The eye rolls, the swivel, the gowns and the platinum hair: The singer Peggy Lee has been parodied so often, especially by drag performers, that it is easy to confuse the caricature with the complicated pop-jazz singer who died 12 years ago this month. Sorting out the contradictions of Lee’s life and career, Stacy Sullivan’s show at the Metropolitan Room, “It’s a Good Day: A Tribute to Miss Peggy Lee,” paints an empathetic, melancholy portrait.

headline: A Sleeping Beauty of Ferraris
text: SANTA MONICA, CALIF. — After being knocked out of commission in 1969 by an engine fire and then spending the next 44 years hibernating in Pennsylvania, a graceful 1967 Ferrari 330 GTS will come under the glare of spotlights on Jan. 18 when it is auctioned in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Fixes for Ticks, Clicks and Leaks
text: Audis needing new brake discs and Corvettes with low oil in their differentials are among the mechanical problems addressed in the latest technical service bulletins from automakers.

headline: Adventures in the Sub-Luxury Category
text: In case Santa didn’t give you everything you wanted, there’s a new submarine in the water.

headline: Opening Champagne With a Saber at the Baroness
text: On the eve of New Year’s Eve, one neighborhood bar was already celebrating — as usual. The Baroness, six weeks old, in a nearly 100-year-old building in Long Island City, was offering instruction in the French art of sabrage. That is to say, patrons could open their own Champagne bottles with a saber, after a quick lesson from Mélanie Lemieux, owner and sommelier.

headline: A Mixed Message From the Boy Scouts
text: On New Year’s Day, the Boy Scouts of America began allowing openly gay boys to participate in its activities, while still prohibiting openly gay and lesbian adults from serving as troop leaders.

headline: The Power of Three
text: THE GIST When trying to persuade, four claims are one too many.

headline: Bisexual: A Label With Layers
text: “Of course I still fancy girls.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wonderland
text: The holiday season ended with a blast of arctic air and several inches of snow, which hardly fazed the intrepid tourists in Times Square or the skaters at Rockefeller Center. Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion. The adventurous skied. The diligent shoveled. And winter showed its beauty, as in Bryant Park, where cascades of ice turned the fountain into art.

headline: De Blasio’s Next Task Is Turning Passion Into Policy
text: A week after his election, the mayor-elect, a tall crane of a man, edged into a low-ceilinged conference room in Downtown Brooklyn to celebrate the city’s progressive movement and its progressive victory, which happened to be his own.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Privacy and Sharks on Twitter
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: The Woody Allen Genome
Inside the Tale of North Korea Execution by Ravenous Dog
text: Updated, 10:07 p.m. | BEIJING — There is no end to shocking stories from North Korea, many involving the myriad cruelties of the brutal police state as reported by defectors. But the latest tale — a news media report that the young North Korean leader might have had his uncle torn apart by ravenous dogs while he watched — may say less about the North than what outsiders have come to expect of it.

headline: At Lincoln Center, a Marriage (but Not for Figaro)
text: By the time they decided to marry, neither Kristin Koslowski nor Holt Wilkins saw much appeal in a traditional wedding, particularly the part that often calls for spending a year in planning for that single day.

headline: Once Labeled a Traitor, Korean Aims to Be a Hero
text: SEOUL, South Korea — HONG YOON-HEE had an extraordinary tale to tell, to anyone who would listen, about how he risked his life trying to save South Korea during a pivotal moment in the Korean War but was then condemned to death and had to flee to the United States.

headline: Liz Goldwyn: Making a Name for Herself
text: LOS ANGELES — The Gala in the Garden, a benefit given every October by the Hammer Museum here, draws a reliably motley cross section of this city’s art, fashion and film tribes. While those contingents mingled last fall on the museum’s third-floor balcony with some of the stiffness of the jocks, brains and beauties mixing at a high school dance, one guest navigated the crowd as effortlessly as a prom queen.

headline: Preparing for Coldest Weather in 20 Years
text: After digging out from a winter storm that disrupted air travel across the country and created treacherous road conditions, people from the Upper Midwest to New England are now preparing for the coldest weather they have experienced in years.

headline: Schools Chancellor Brings Joyful and Fierce Style
text: Late in the afternoon of New Year’s Eve, Carmen Fariña was preparing to have 10 people over to dinner, a plan, she joked, she wouldn’t have made had she known that the next day would mark the beginning of her tenure as the city’s new schools chancellor. Perhaps out of a subliminal sense of premonition or foresight, or just grandmotherly efficiency, she had arranged for a caterer.

headline: Sending Artworks Home, but to Whom?
text: The paleontologist Richard Leakey has called their removal a “sacrilege.” Kenyan villagers have said their theft led to crop failure and ailing livestock. It is little wonder, then, that the long, slender wooden East African memorial totems known as vigango are creating a spiritual crisis of sorts for American museums. Many want to return them, but are not finding that so easy.

headline: Quick, Get the Camera: Fido’s Levitating
text: The “Paranormal Activity” franchise aims straight at its Latino fan base with the fifth installment of the series, “The Marked Ones,” and the changes — goodbye, white suburbia; hello, gritty diversity — recharge the batteries somewhat. But there’s no escaping that the found-footage phenomenon has gone from fresh and original to just plain annoying.

headline: Liberty Media Seeks Full Ownership of Sirius XM
text: Liberty Media already controls Sirius XM. Now, it wants to own the entire company.

headline: Fear Keeps Thousands of South Sudanese on the Run
text: AWERIAL, South Sudan — As the city of Bor fell into chaos, Lual Alier watched a fellow teacher pick up a Kalashnikov rifle and kill a shopkeeper. Then the man turned and began firing at him, too.

headline: Fleeing the Bombs in Aleppo, Syria, and Ending Up in New Jersey
text: PATERSON, N.J. — They had heard the bombs before, but never this close. They gathered whatever was at hand — a purse, a bag containing their passports — ran out of their house in Aleppo, in northern Syria and headed on foot to a quieter neighborhood. There, they figured, they would wait out the fighting and return home.

headline: Sunday A/X Pairs at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
text: The winners of the Sunday A/X Pairs at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last Sunday were Janet and R. Jay Becker of New York City. They were one day shy of celebrating their first wedding anniversary.

headline: Syrians Protest Assad and Islamist Militants
text: As my colleagues Hwaida Saad and Rick Gladstone report, Syrian opposition activists said that an alliance of seven rebel groups launched attacks across northern Syria on Friday against the jihadist militants who call themselves the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS — a powerful Qaeda affiliate that includes foreign fighters.

headline: Make a Resolution to Budget? Here Are Some Apps to Help
text: There’s something brilliant, but also insidious, about services like Amazon Prime, where you don’t have to reach for your credit card to pay. Spending is painless.

headline: A Cult Motorcycle From India Takes On the World
text: NEW DELHI, India — The Royal Enfield Bullet, often described as the oldest continuously produced motorcycle in the world, is a cult product for enthusiasts who love it for its vintage feel as much as for the thrum of its engine.

headline: Video and Images of the Crisis in South Sudan
text: As my colleague Nicholas Kulish reported, thousands of South Sudanese have fled their homes in recent days as fighting between forces loyal to the government of President Salva Kiir have fought against a rebellion led by his former vice president, Riek Machar, plunging the young nation into chaos.

headline: Let It Snow
text: The first snowstorm of 2014 left nearly a foot of slush in some neighborhoods Friday, with freezing wind. As snowplows cleared roads, there were subway delays, but many New Yorkers made it to work.
