headline: An Error Message for the Poor
text: WASHINGTON — MORE than two million people have signed up for health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act, a tribute to the effectiveness of the “tech surge” the Obama administration deployed to overcome the highly publicized problems with HealthCare.gov that emerged in October. The website’s initial rollout will long stand as a monument to how badly technology contracting can go wrong. But the remarkable recovery also demonstrates what a determined response to such bungling can achieve.

headline: Brazil Is Abuzz About Snowden
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — When I visited China in June, my trip happened to coincide with the discovery that Edward Snowden was hiding out in Hong Kong. By then, Snowden’s revelations about the voracious data-collection operation by the National Security Agency was front-page news all over the world. Snowden hadn’t yet been charged for the leak of tens of thousands of pages of classified N.S.A. documents, but it was clear that it was coming. So it was only natural to ask — as many journalists did — would Hong Kong give Snowden asylum if he requested it?

headline: Visits With School Pals Are a Touchstone on President’s Trips to Hawaii
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has called Hawaii his refuge, and so it has been throughout his political life. In 2006, Mr. Obama used the family Christmas holiday there to decide whether to run for president. For the past two weeks, he has been recharging on Oahu after an unpleasant year in the job.

headline: Susan Rasky, Award-Winning Reporter for The Times, Dies at 61
text: Susan F. Rasky, a former political reporter for The New York Times who won a George Polk Award for her coverage of the congressional budget crisis in 1990, died on Dec. 29 at her home in El Cerrito, Calif. She was 61.

headline: Prosaic Pipe Stymied Seattle’s Big Bertha
text: SEATTLE — The unknown object buried beneath this city, big enough to stop the world’s largest-diameter tunnel-boring machine in its tracks last month and tantalizing enough in its mystery to set off a cottage industry of wispy romantic speculation, turns out to be an ordinary metal pipe, tunnel engineers said Friday.

headline: Indoctrinating Religious Warriors
text: In 2009, the gap between the share of Republicans and Democrats who believed in evolution was just 10 percentage points, 54 percent and 64 percent, respectively.

headline: Mystery in Hezbollah Operative’s Life and Death
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As a little girl, Noor did not know exactly what her father, Hassane Laqees, did for Hezbollah, but even then, she knew she might lose him early. During his long absences, she recalled recently, she would gaze at a photo of him lying asleep and imagine that she was seeing his corpse.

headline: Architect’s Sentence in Death of Firefighter Angers Fire Crews
text: LOS ANGELES — The blaze broke out in an opulent new Hollywood Hills home that was scheduled to be the set for a television series, “Germany’s Next Top Model,” just a few days later. Flames escaped from a fireplace — designed for outdoor use, but installed indoors in violation of the fire code on the home’s top floor by Gerhard Albert Becker, a wealthy German architect.

headline: Solar Power Craze on Wall St. Propels Start-Up
text: The first inklings of the idea came to Elon Musk and a cousin in an R.V. heading to the Burning Man festival in 2004.

headline: Pictures from The Week in Business
text: Latvia adopts the euro, small-scale gold mining in Indonesia poses risks and and the expansion of the Panama Canal may be halted.

headline: George Goodman, Who Demystified the World of Money, Dies at 83
text: George J. W. Goodman, who demystified financial complexities in best-selling books and on a long-running public television program under the name of one of history’s most famous economists, Adam Smith, died on Friday in Miami. He was 83.

headline: Chaplain’s ‘Plantation’ Reference at de Blasio Inauguration Gains Defenders
text: The Rev. Frederick A. Lucas Jr. stepped to the dais at the inauguration of Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday as a pastor with impressive mainstream credentials. A Harvard-educated minister, he was on clergy committees for President Bill Clinton and President George W. Bush and serves as a chaplain for the Sanitation Department.

headline: Tangled Role in G.O.P. War Over Tea Party
text: WASHINGTON — In the year since he stepped down from Congress, Steven C. LaTourette, a Republican from Ohio, has emerged as one of the top generals in the establishment Republicans’ war against the Tea Party.

headline: Auburn’s Offense Runs to a Hip-Hop Beat
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — It was early December, and Auburn had secured a berth in the national title game. The final minutes of the Southeastern Conference championship game ticked away. Two running backs stood together on the sideline.

headline: Medical Center Hires Lhota as an Executive
text: As Bill de Blasio settles into City Hall, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican who ran against him for mayor, is also getting a new job.

headline: The Ticking Mideast Clock
text: Five months into the latest American effort to nudge Israelis and Palestinians toward a peace agreement, the one party clearly committed to a deal is the United States. This week, Secretary of State John Kerry made his 10th trip to the region to get the two sides to stick the timetable he set forth when he started new negotiations last July.

headline: School Experiment That Burned Boy Was Focus of Federal Warning
text: Only weeks before a chemistry experiment sent a plume of fire across a Manhattan high school science lab, engulfing two students and leaving one with life-threatening burns, a federal safety agency issued a video warning of the dangers of the very same experiment, a common one across the country.

headline: Not Getting Their Money’s Worth
text: At first glance, two recent crises to hit the White House — the revelations about unlawful surveillance and the botched health care rollout — have nothing in common. But each is a reminder of the increasing extent to which government work has been contracted out to private-sector companies. Currently, Washington spends about $500 billion a year on private-sector contracts, more than twice the amount in 2000.

headline: Stopping Mentally Ill Gun Buyers
text: Rebuffed by Congress on stronger gun safety laws, President Obama is wisely using use his executive powers in a more focused attempt to bar mentally ill people from eluding federal watch lists and purchasing firearms. Two sensible changes proposed for the background check system would allow states and mental health providers more discretion than they have now in reporting information about potentially violent people.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 3, 2014
Governor Cuomo’s Stingy Pardons
text: The power to grant clemency is a critical function of the executive branch. It serves as a last, case-by-case resort to remedy an unjustly long sentence, erase a wrongful conviction or show forgiveness where it is merited. But New Yorkers seeking clemency from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, either from within prison or after their release, have found virtually no consolation during the three years of his tenure.

headline: Academy Ballots of Our Own
text: The critics make their Oscar choices.

headline: U.S. Is Facing Hard Choices in South Sudan
text: WASHINGTON — South Sudan is in many ways an American creation, carved out of war-torn Sudan in a referendum largely orchestrated by the United States, its fragile institutions nurtured with billions of dollars in American aid. But a murky, vicious conflict there has left the Obama administration scrambling to prevent the unraveling of a major American achievement in Africa.

headline: A Brain Is Dead, a Heart Beats On
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It started out as an operation to treat an increasingly common medical problem in America, childhood sleep apnea. It has become an anguished fight over the fate of a 13-year-old girl who, though pronounced legally dead by doctors, remains alive in the opinion of her religious parents.

headline: Family of Caddies and Players Stays Close
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Long before the golfer Mallory Blackwelder was even a sparkle in their eyes, her mother, Myra, was playing on the L.P.G.A. Tour, and her father, Worth, was a professional tour caddie.

headline: A Desperate River Crossing
text: Residents of Bor, a city in the Republic of South Sudan, fled deadly violence there by taking ferries across the White Nile to Awerial, where an estimated 76,000 displaced people are stranded.

headline: Security Official Moves to White House
text: Rand Beers, a counterterrorism official at the Homeland Security Department, will leave the agency to work as a senior adviser to President Obama, administration officials said Friday. Mr. Beers will be a deputy assistant to the president on the National Security Council staff, the officials said. Mr. Beers served as acting secretary of homeland security for several months last year.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 4, 2014
text: “For 63 years, I lived with the stigma of being a traitor. The truth is I helped save South Korea during one of its most critical times.”

headline: Corrections: January 4, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Offering Help in Passing
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I take back what I said yesterday about the question marks. There are quite a few of those today, but it’s O.K.; with those question marks comes a lot of fun wordplay.

headline: Lower East Side Students Have a Gift of Uniforms, and Better Focus
text: The school day is over, yet the majority of students at Public School 188 will happily continue to wear their uniforms well into the early evening hours.

headline: Once a Criminal, He’s Now a Victim, Shot Twice in a Year
text: New Year’s Eve, 2012: Richard Dunbar, 52, spent the night in Brooklyn with his sister and her family, “two little-bitty nephews,” he recalled. They watched the ball drop on television. Nice night.

headline: Returning of Refugees to Bulgaria Worries U.N.
text: GENEVA — European countries should stop returning asylum seekers to Bulgaria, because they could face “inhuman and degrading treatment” in Bulgaria’s reception centers, which have been stretched thin by a rising number of arrivals, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday.

headline: Modesty, With a Little Smoldering
text: “I thought that if Nancy Reagan and Jackie Kennedy were the first ladies of the White House, then Gloria was the first lady of the Gaines house,” said Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for “Lee Daniels’ The Butler.” Inspired by the real-life story of Eugene Allen, the film follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (portrayed by Forest Whitaker), and his wife, Gloria, as history, particularly the civil rights movement, unfolds over seven presidential administrations.

headline: Deadly Violence Erupts During Rallies Across Egypt
text: CAIRO — At least 13 people were killed as violence broke out during Muslim Brotherhood marches in several Egyptian cities on Friday, health officials said, in the deadliest day of clashes in months.

headline: Councilwoman Bruised Feelings in Zoning Fight
text: If she becomes, as appears likely, the next speaker of the New York City Council, Councilwoman Melissa Mark-Viverito of East Harlem has vowed to listen to all groups, treat everyone fairly and be a paragon of transparency.

headline: Knicks’ Shumpert Rediscovers His Shot, and His Smile
text: HOUSTON — Even as Iman Shumpert was going scoreless against teams like the Toronto Raptors and the Boston Celtics in recent weeks, he tried to insulate himself from the noise.

headline: Turning Point for Nets? Victory Over Oklahoma City Did Trick Last Season
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — It was hard to ignore the coincidence.

headline: Gunman Fires at Moving S.U.V. in Queens, Killing One and Wounding Three Others
text: A gunman opened fire on an S.U.V. in Springfield Gardens in Queens on Friday afternoon, killing a longtime friend of the rapper 50 Cent and wounding three other people inside, according to the police and witnesses.

headline: Mental Lapse at Finish Wastes 47 Good Minutes From the Knicks
text: HOUSTON — The Knicks had done what they could to survive against the Rockets for more than 47 minutes at the Toyota Center on Friday night. They had hustled. They had rebounded. They had defended, at least for stretches.

headline: Juanita Moore, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 99
text: Juanita Moore, who earned an Academy Award nomination in 1960 for the single major film role she ever landed, then fell through the cracks of a Hollywood system that had little to offer a black actress besides small parts as maids and nannies, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 99.

headline: Dr. W.V. Cordice Jr., 94, a Surgeon Who Helped Save Dr. King, Dies
text: On Sept. 20, 1958, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., then emerging as the leader of the civil rights movement, was autographing copies of his new book in a Harlem department store when a woman approached to greet him. He nodded without looking up. Then she stabbed him in the chest with a razor-sharp seven-inch letter opener.

headline: Winter Wallop
text: Scenes from across New York City on Friday after a powerful storm brought snow, bitterly cold temperatures and heavy winds.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in December
text: How the auto industry fared in December 2013.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey (above, seated) portrays Portia Nathan, a Princeton admissions officer who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of applicants aspiring to the university’s ivy-covered halls. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princeton’s place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. “How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. “And I must confess that I don’t know whether to be relieved or disappointed that ‘Admission,’ which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment. Mr. Weitz lines up a target placed at the explosive intersection of class, race, region and every other source of societal anguish, and then does not so much miss as aim in another direction — or several — letting fly a volley of darts that land as lightly as badminton birdies.” Still, Ms. Fey and Mr. Rudd “are fun to watch, though not as much fun as they might have been in a riskier, crazier movie,” he said, adding that “the best scenes belong to Lily Tomlin, brilliantly cast as Portia’s mother, an unbowed second-wave woman warrior with a pair of borzois and a Bella Abzug tattoo.”

headline: Cambodia Cracks Down on Protest With Evictions and Ban on Assembly
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Seeking to quash one of the most serious challenges to the nearly 30-year rule of the country’s authoritarian leader, Cambodian authorities evicted antigovernment protesters on Saturday from a public square and banned all public gatherings as a court summoned two opposition leaders for police questioning.

headline: Obama Urges Congress to Restore Unemployment Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking the upper hand with Congress as he heads back from his Hawaiian vacation, insisted on Saturday that lawmakers make restoring unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans who are out of work their “first order of business” in the new year.

headline: Do Animals Have a Sweet Tooth?
text: No preference is so quick to form, and none so hard to lose, as a baby’s love for sweets. Give a newborn a drop of sugar water when he’s hours old, and he’ll suckle. At a dental school in Jerusalem in the early 1970s, a scientist named Jacob E. Steiner doled out sucrose to 175 infants before they’d had a drop of mother’s milk and saw clear signs of satisfaction: The babies showed “a marked relaxation of the facial muscle,” he wrote, and “a retraction of the mouth’s angles resembling a ‘smile.’ ” Then he tried the same experiment on several babies born without a cerebral cortex and found the same result. The joy of sugar needs no cogitation; it scarcely needs a brain.

headline: In Fervent Support of the ‘Gap Year’
text: I wasn’t enthusiastic when my daughter first floated her plan to take a “gap year” before college. As someone who couldn’t wait to matriculate, I didn’t see the point of delaying that great intellectual awakening. I felt vaguely disappointed that she wasn’t more eager to embrace all those books and ideas and late-night conversations about the cosmos. And what if her gap year turned into a permanent crevasse and she never earned a degree?

headline: Putin Eases Protest Ban in Sochi for the Olympics
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Saturday eased a sweeping ban on public protests in Sochi, Russia, starting on Tuesday and continuing through the Olympic Games next month and the Paralympic Games in March. However, any demonstrations will require approval in advance from the authorities.

headline: Phil Everly, Half of a Pioneer Rock Duo That Inspired Generations, Dies at 74
text: Phil Everly, whose hits with his older brother, Don, as the Everly Brothers carried the close fraternal harmonies of country tradition into pioneering rock ‘n’ roll, died on Friday in Burbank, Calif. He was 74.

headline: TabTale Cranks Up Its Game-Making Machine
text: You’ve probably never heard of a company called TabTale. But if you’ve ever used an iPad or smartphone to entertain young children (as many parents do), you may very well have downloaded one of its hundreds of animated games or interactive books on topics like virtual cupcake baking and doctors who heal zombies. (I personally wasted an enjoyable hour this week playing Santa Rescue Challenge, one of the company’s recently released holiday titles.)

headline: Boeing Workers Approve 8-Year Contract Extension
text: Boeing workers narrowly approved an eight-year contract extension, their union announced late Friday, in a move that will assure production of Boeing’s new 777X aircraft in the Puget Sound area.

headline: Happy New Year?
text: There’s an alarming amount of optimism out there about US economic prospects for 2014. Let me make the situation even more alarming by saying that I basically share that optimism.

headline: 1914: Amazingly Popular Dance Causes Widespread Social Controversy
text: Never has a dance been so much discussed, defended and denounced as has the tango, the extraordinary terpsichorean craze which has swept over the whole of Europe and the United States. Society leaders have condemned unsparingly, bishops have shuddered, royalty has expressed uncompromising disapproval, and the tango is still danced with fervor by tens of thousands. It cannot be denied that the tango in its original form would have shocked the most Bohemian society. The very name — tango, “I touch”— has a significance which needs no comment. But it is a far cry from the original as it was danced in the most undesirable cafés of the Argentine to the severely Bowdlerized version tolerated in the modern ballroom. It is believed that the tango is of Spanish origin, and was taken to South America by Spanish settlers.

headline: Spate of Injuries in N.H.L. Keeps Olympic Rosters in Flux Worldwide
text: Picking an Olympic roster is tricky enough, but a rash of injuries in the N.H.L. this season is making it harder than ever. Toronto Coach Randy Carlyle noted at the end of December that 108 players were out, 15 percent of the league. That number includes some of the biggest stars among the medal contenders for the Sochi Games, players like Canada’s Steven Stamkos, Slovakia’s Marian Gaborik, Sweden’s Alex Steen and Russia’s Evgeni Malkin.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What A Good Year Won’t Prove
text: A brief addendum to my last post. If 2014 is a year of relatively good growth, you know that many people will take that as somehow refuting Keynesianism — hey, didn’t you guys predict that the economy would never recover without fiscal stimulus?

headline: For Nets and Knicks Fans, a Midwinter Night’s Dream
text: The Knicks fan and the Nets fan settled on the couch, in front of the television, on a snowy, frigid Thursday night. Each held a bottle of Pepto-Bismol, bracing for more stomach pain in a furiously retching season.

headline: Afghanistan’s Worsening, and Baffling, Hunger Crisis
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — In the Bost Hospital here, a teenage mother named Bibi Sherina sits on a bed in the severe acute malnutrition ward with her two children. Ahmed, at just 3 months old, looks bigger than his emaciated brother Mohammad, who is a year and a half and weighs 10 pounds.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 5
text: “C.E.O.’s can look forward and say, ‘I don’t see any near-term economic bumps.’  ”

headline: How a First Career Enhanced a Second
text: What happens when the career you were born to pursue becomes the wrong career when you reach your mid-30s?

headline: Variety: A Lost Diagramless
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I have a love/oh-no-not-again relationship with diagramless puzzles. They’re good for the ego in the sense that the clues are exceptionally easy, and the clues are easy because the main point is to figure out where the entries go. That’s the part that’s not so much fun for me.

headline: You Can’t Take It With You, but You Still Want More
text: All work and no play may just be a result of “mindless accumulation.”

headline: Ice Dancing, Adored and Mocked, Could Give Americans a Lone Gold
text: CANTON, Mich. — Olympic ice dancing is widely appealing to audiences, but it has been frequently mocked as a dubious competition, fraught with predetermined outcomes, almost impossible to judge objectively. An existential question lurks: Is rumba really a sport?

headline: Afghanistan’s Child Hunger Crisis
text: Hospitals around the country have been swamped by a wave of malnourished children in the past year, but the causes are unclear.

headline: Listen to Pandora, and It Listens Back
text: Pandora, the Internet radio service, is plying a new tune.

headline: Afghanistan’s Unexplained Hunger Crisis
text: Throughout Afghanistan, there is what doctors call acute severe malnutrition. Most of the cases are seen in children under the age of 5.

headline: Please, There’s No Need to Shout
text: The Haggler has been described by more than a few people as a congenital grump, and this is often framed in negative terms. The Haggler, though, believes that his congenital grumpiness is among his more appealing characteristics, right up there with this fondness for the word “congenital.”

headline: Help the Working Poor, but Share the Burden
text: In a speech last month, President Obama brought renewed attention to economic disparities in the United States. The gap between rich and poor is indeed substantial — much larger than in most developed nations and much larger than it was 40 years ago. So what is the best way to help those struggling at the bottom of the economic ladder?

headline: A Roadblock to Brawny Bank Reform
text: Regulators made some real progress last year attacking the risks of too-big-to-fail banks. The Volcker Rule and other Dodd-Frank reforms were completed, and, perhaps even more important, three big regulators devised a proposal for tougher capital rules intended to ensure that banks would never require a government bailout when their risky bets went bad.

headline: Karen Abramson, on Going to the Front Lines
text: This interview with  Karen Abramson, chief executive of Wolters Kluwer Tax & Accounting, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Finding Her Teaching Voice
A Backward Rule and a Baseball Hall Backlog
text: It happens every winter. An overstuffed, unwieldy collection of voters, some much more qualified and conscientious than others, holds an election to bestow the highest honor of a cherished American institution. It is a secretive process in a world that, more and more, craves transparency.

headline: Denver’s McGee Not Just Any Tall Drink of Water
text: Explaining JaVale McGee to the uninitiated can be difficult.

headline: A Marriott for the Hip Crowd
text: To lure a younger consumer Marriott International is making a turn toward flash, partly by offering new hotel brands.

headline: Militant Tied to Bombings in Lebanon Dies in Jail
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of a Lebanon-based affiliate of Al Qaeda who was arrested recently died Saturday while in custody in Lebanon, officials said.

headline: Packers Fever Cools a Bit, and the Explanation Is Complex
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The Stadium View Bar & Grille, as the name implies, stands one long block from Lambeau Field, at the corner of Holmgren Way and Brett Favre Pass. Through large windows and behind a 20-foot-tall replica of the Lombardi Trophy, the brick facade of Lambeau rises in the distance down Armed Forces Drive, a sort of Champs-Élysées for cheeseheads.

headline: Qaeda-Linked Militants in Iraq Secure Nearly Full Control of Falluja
text: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants fighting under the banner of Al Qaeda appeared to make gains across Anbar Province on Saturday, using snipers and rocket-propelled grenades in heavy street fighting as they secured nearly full control of Falluja and captured the strategic town Karma. Government forces and the tribal militias fighting with them seemed unable to resist the militants’ advances.

headline: But It Doesn’t Look Like a Marriott
text: J.W. Marriott Jr., the 81-year-old chairman of Marriott International, flew to London in September to inspect his company’s new jewel: Edition, a sumptuous boutique hotel intended to anchor a new 100-city chain — the next W, if Marriott has its way. But Mr. Marriott did not stay overnight at the London Edition, as the new property is known, with its laser-lighted nightclub and guest-room paintings of women wearing toilet-paper turbans. He bedded down at Grosvenor House, one of the company’s more traditional luxury hotels.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Treating Mental Illness
text: Readers react to a call for better coverage for psychiatric care.

headline: Making a Living (and a Life) Abroad
text: Some Americans have taken advantage of technology and a globalized economy to work and live in other countries.

headline: The Roots Stay Strong at Auburn
text: AUBURN, Ala. — There is a tree sculpture inside the Auburn Art store, a replica of an oak that towered over the entrance to Auburn University for decades.

headline: A College Football Fan Is Born a Weekend at a Time
text: NEW ORLEANS — When my wife, Betsy, and I walked out of our Canal Street hotel here Thursday night to head to the Sugar Bowl, we ran into a colleague of hers who happened to be in town for a wedding.

headline: For Obama, a Real and Rare Vacation in Hawaii
text: KAILUA, Hawaii — After a two-week vacation on the windward side of Oahu, ensconced with his family in a private beachfront rental, President Obama prepared on Saturday to return to the chillier clime — both politically and weather-wise — of the nation’s capital.

headline: Management Be Nimble
text: “We aspire to be the largest small company in our space.”

headline: The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Reader
text: “TO read a novel is a difficult and complex art,” Virginia Woolf wrote in a 1925 essay, “How to Read a Book.” Today, with our powers of concentration atrophied by the staccato communication of the Internet and attention easily diverted to addictive entertainment on our phones and tablets, book-length reading is harder still.

headline: Banished for Questioning the Gospel of Guns
text: BARRY, Ill. — The byline of Dick Metcalf, one of the country’s pre-eminent gun journalists, has gone missing. It has been removed from Guns & Ammo magazine, where his widely-read column once ran on the back page. He no longer stars on a popular television show about firearms. Gun companies have stopped flying him around the world and sending him the latest weapons to review.

headline: Bracing for Carp in Great Lakes, but Debating Their Presence
text: After decades of increasingly dire warnings, countless studies and countermeasures, scientists are beginning to mull over hints of something that few of them wish to contemplate: The despised Asian carp may have finally arrived in the Great Lakes.

headline: Moves to Curb Spying Help Drive the Clemency Argument for Snowden
text: WASHINGTON — To the prosecutors pursuing him, Edward J. Snowden has committed espionage by divulging national secrets. But the growing backlash against government surveillance has spurred a spirited debate about whether he should be forgiven.

headline: Blast Hits Kabul Military Base, and Eastern Afghanistan Bombing Kills American
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An explosion hit one of the entrances to a predominantly American military base in the heart of Kabul on Saturday, hours after a separate suicide bombing in eastern Afghanistan killed an American service member — the first combat casualty of the year.

headline: The Invisible Hand Award
text: One last Jerry Goodman post. My friend, classmate, and fellow joke-writer Irwin Collier of the Free University of Berlin sends me the program of the 1976 Adam Smith dinner and Jerry’s writeup of his experience (both pdf).

headline: De Blasio’s Long Odds
text: THIS much can be said for Bill de Blasio’s inauguration, which featured a concentration of left-wing agitprop unseen since the last time Pete Seeger occupied a stage alone: If the waning years of Barack Obama’s presidency are going to be defined by a liberal crusade against income inequality, there’s no more fitting place to kick it off than New York City.

headline: Need-Blind Justice
text: WASHINGTON — FIFTY years ago, in Gideon v. Wainwright, the Supreme Court ruled that poor people accused of serious crimes were entitled to lawyers paid for by the government. But the court did not say how the lawyers should be chosen, how much they should be paid or how to make sure they defended their clients with vigor and care.

headline: How Insecure Is Your Password?
Compromise: Not a 4-Letter Word
text: FORMER SENATOR ALAN SIMPSON likes to say that if you can’t learn to compromise on issues without compromising yourself, you should not be in Congress, be in business or get married. It is amazing how many people violate that rule, but especially in Congress and especially among the Tea Party types, where calling someone a “deal maker” is now the ultimate put down. What makes it crazier is that in American education, innovation and commerce today, “collaboration” is being taught and rewarded as the best way to do anything big, important and complex. Indeed, in Silicon Valley, a “collaborator” means someone with whom you’re building something great. In D.C., it means someone committing political treason by working with the other party. And that is why Silicon Valley is now the turbo-engine of our economy and D.C. is the dead hand.

headline: First Up, Mental Illness. Next Topic Is Up to You.
text: THOSE of us in the pundit world tend to blather on about what happened yesterday, while often ignoring what happens every day. We stir up topics already on the agenda, but we falter at calling attention to crucial-but-neglected issues.

headline: Stephen Kellert
text: Stephen Kellert is a social ecologist and senior research scholar at Yale University’s School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. He has written several books and produced a documentary about so-called biophilic design, which goes beyond sustainability to integrate and connect people with the natural world.

headline: One Marine’s Dying Wish
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — WE don’t get any say about the kind of world we’re born into — about whether it’s prepared for the likes of us, whether it will open its arms. Hal Faulkner certainly didn’t get the world he deserved. It was needlessly cruel to him, senselessly judgmental. For the most part, he made peace with that.

headline: The Commish, the 2nd Time Around
text: BILL BRATTON’S biggest problem right now might not be stop-and-frisk.

headline: Can Upward Mobility Cost You Your Health?
text: Americans love a good rags-to-riches story. Even in an age of soaring inequality, we like to think that people can still make it big here if they work hard and stay out of trouble. The socioeconomic reality of most of the last four decades — stagnant wages, soaring income and wealth inequality, and reduced equality of opportunity — have dented, but not destroyed, the appeal of the American dream.

headline: 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag
text: WASHINGTON — To many Americans, the war on poverty declared 50 years ago by President Lyndon B. Johnson has largely failed. The poverty rate has fallen only to 15 percent from 19 percent in two generations, and 46 million Americans live in households where the government considers their income scarcely adequate.

headline: Path to Casinos Turns Messy in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON — When Massachusetts finally gave in after decades of resistance and decided two years ago to legalize casino gambling, it seemed a relatively easy way to fill the state’s recession-battered coffers.

headline: A Lonely Quest for Facts on Genetically Modified Crops
text: KONA, Hawaii — From the moment the bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced in May 2013, it garnered more vocal support than any the County Council here had ever considered, even the perennially popular bids to decriminalize marijuana.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 5
text: As lawmakers return to Capitol Hill this week, President Obama urged them to restore unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans who are without work. The program was cut in the two-year budget passed before the holidays.

headline: Why Everyone Seems to Have Cancer
text: EVERY New Year when the government publishes its Report to the Nation on the Status of Cancer, it is followed by a familiar lament. We are losing the war against cancer.

headline: Declining Lethality
text: Since 1958, the death rates from heart disease and stroke have declined more than those from cancer.

headline: Warming Up for Australian Open, Williams Beats Azarenka in Brisbane
text: BRISBANE, Australia — Serena Williams began this season in the same pose she ended the last, her right heel lifted slightly off the ground, her arms high over her head, her hands grasping yet another trophy.

headline: Why Do We Fear the Blind?
text: BRISTOL, R.I. — A FEW years ago, when I mentioned to a woman I met at a party that I was teaching in a school for the blind, she seemed confused. “Can I just ask you one question?” she said. “How do you talk to your students?”

headline: Happy New Year, Politicians. Seriously.
text: GAIL COLLINS: Happy New Year, David! I’m glad you’re back and that we’re going to start conversing again. What are you expecting, politically speaking, for 2014? It doesn’t really seem possible that things could get much worse.

headline: Small Plane Makes an Emergency Landing on a Highway in the Bronx
text: A single-engine plane made an emergency landing on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon, officials said. No one was seriously injured.

headline: Rampant Prosecutorial Misconduct
text: In the justice system, prosecutors have the power to decide what criminal charges to bring, and since 97 percent of cases are resolved without a trial, those decisions are almost always the most important factor in the outcome. That is why it is so important for prosecutors to play fair, not just to win. This obligation is embodied in the Supreme Court’s 1963 holding in Brady v. Maryland, which required prosecutors to provide the defense with any exculpatory evidence that could materially affect a verdict or sentence.

headline: Putting Drones to the Test
text: Drones will soon take to the skies across the United States in federally approved tests that are meant to clear the way for the commercial use of unmanned aircraft. But before that happens, lawmakers and regulators need to deal with a host of unresolved privacy and safety concerns.

headline: The Marijuana Experiment
text: On New Year’s Day, government-licensed recreational marijuana shops opened in Colorado, the first place in the world to regulate the drug “from seed to sale.” Later in 2014, marijuana retailers will open in Washington State. As public opinion shifts away from prohibition, these two states will serve as test cases for full-on legalization. Here’s what to watch for in the early stages of this experiment:

headline: Health Care in America
text: Michael Moore called Obamacare both ‘awful’ and a ‘godsend.’ Readers offer their opinions.

headline: 50 Years of Poverty
text: While government programs have kept millions of people, especially the elderly, from falling into poverty, rates remain high for many groups of Americans, including children, blacks and Hispanics.

headline: 'Tony Bargains' Helps Bronx's Needy
text: Anthony Cody, a former inmate and homeless drug addict known as Tony Bargains, has turned a crack house on Boston Road into a thrift store for the needy.

headline: New York State Is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws
text: ALBANY — Joining a growing group of states that have loosened restrictions on marijuana, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York plans this week to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of the drug by those with serious illnesses, state officials say.

headline: ‘Inside Llewyn Davis’ Gets Critics Society’s Vote
text: Updated, 1:10 p.m. | The National Society of Film Critics crowned “Inside Llewyn Davis” as its best picture on Saturday, with the “Davis” filmmakers, Joel and Ethan Coen, taking the director prize.

headline: Your Submissions for “Most Neglected Topic”
text: My Sunday column invites readers to submit the issues they believe are most neglected by the news media and that deserve more coverage in 2014. My own suggestion, which my column focuses on, is mental health. So if you have a suggestion for an issue that you think is of national or global importance but isn’t getting adequate coverage, please post below and explain why. I hope to stitch together a column based on some of your best entries.

headline: N.F.L. Wild Card Saturday
text: Highlights from Saturday’s N.F.L. playoff games.

headline: Clued In
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow. Look at that grid. Are you intimidated by that grid?

headline: Harvey K. Littleton, a Pioneer in the Art of Glass, Dies at 91
text: Harvey K. Littleton, an artist who helped found the so-called studio glass movement in the United States, developing and teaching do-it-yourself techniques that freed glassblowing from the cumbersome protocols of factory production and made molten glass almost as easy to work with in the studio as wet clay, died on Dec. 13 in Spruce Pine, N.C. He was 91.

headline: Ecuadorean Navy Delivers for Amazon Chief
text: The Ecuadorean Navy offered Jeff Bezos same-day shipping on an Amazon Prime package: Mr. Bezos himself.

headline: Saul Zaentz, Producer of Oscar-Winning Movies, Dies at 92
text: Saul Zaentz, an acclaimed independent film producer who adapted literary works for the screen and won best-picture Academy Awards for “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” “Amadeus” and “The English Patient,” died on Friday at his apartment in San Francisco. He was 92.

headline: Opposition Party Boycotting Bangladesh Election
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — As Bangladesh prepared for general elections on Sunday, a truck driver named Nur Islam was trying to haul a load of potatoes to Dhaka, the capital, along a route he knew would be targeted by protesters allied with the opposition.

headline: Home From Tour and Back on Ballot, Singer Finds a Reason to Campaign
text: MEDINA, Tex. — Kinky Friedman practiced his smile as he sat on the front porch of his cabin on a secluded Hill Country ranch in December, three dogs scampering around his legs. He said he had gotten an instructive tip from a former Miss Mississippi.

headline: Tunes for the New Year From the Home Team
text: Less than a month ago, a guide to prominent 2014 releases from Texas artists would have begun with a long-rumored Beyoncé album. Although she took that off the plate with her headline-grabbing stealth release on Dec. 13, a robust selection remains of Texans planning on ringing in the first part of the year with new albums. Our roundup — which ranges from a pair of Houston-based alternative rock acts to celebrated veterans branching out in new directions — hints at what the year may bring. And sets from Don Henley, the Austin rock band Spoon and the Old 97s, although still unscheduled, are on the horizon.

headline: Texas Right to Life Criticized for Playing Politics With Ratings
text: A rift on how to regulate end-of-life care that broke out during last year’s legislative session has carried over into this year’s election cycle.

headline: As Perry Exits, His Appointees Look for Havens
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Saying Farewell to a Rock Icon
text: Phil Everly, as half of the Everly Brothers, inspired the Beatles, Linda Ronstadt, Simon and Garfunkel and many others who recorded their songs and tried to emulate their ringing vocal alchemy.

headline: A League Less Nimble as Point Guards Go Down
text: When the Los Angeles Clippers’ Chris Paul came careening off a screen — as he does so often during a game — and crashed to the floor Friday night in Dallas, separating his right shoulder, he joined what has become a distinguished list: ailing N.B.A. point guards.

headline: Donald H. Forst, Feisty Newspaper Editor, Dies at 81
text: Donald H. Forst, the feisty former top editor of New York Newsday, The Village Voice and The Boston Herald, died on Saturday in Albany. He was 81.

headline: Overwhelmed Early, Colts Overcome Chiefs With Huge Comeback
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The ball flew from the arms of Indianapolis running back Donald Brown, and with it, perhaps, went the Colts’ season. The ball bounced, though, off the back of an offensive lineman and then, like a trained dog, returned to the feet of quarterback Andrew Luck. He scooped it up, hopped and lunged, arms outstretched, into the end zone for a fourth-quarter touchdown.

headline: Webster Strengthens Grip on the Collegiate Game
text: The Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship highlighted Webster University’s unchallenged dominance of collegiate chess.

headline: After Decades of Unexplained Mood Swings, a Quiet Place to Call Home
text: For the first 54 years of her life, Cheryl McCray did not understand why she flew off the handle and suffered such violent mood swings.

headline: Charred Body of Kidnapped Man Is Found on Long Island
text: The charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer who was kidnapped Thursday near his Brooklyn office has been found in a smoldering trash bin outside a Long Island gas station, the police said on Saturday.

headline: South Sudan and Rebels Open Peace Talks
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The South Sudanese government and representatives of rebel forces met for the formal opening of peace talks Saturday evening in Ethiopia, part of the diplomatic effort to halt weeks of fighting in the young nation.

headline: Power Vacuum in Middle East Lifts Militants
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The images of recent days have an eerie familiarity, as if the horrors of the past decade were being played back: masked gunmen recapturing the Iraqi cities of Falluja and Ramadi, where so many American soldiers died fighting them. Car bombs exploding amid the elegance of downtown Beirut. The charnel house of Syria’s worsening civil war.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 4, 2014
Plane Uses Bronx Highway for Runway
text: Bystanders described the scene after the pilot of a small plane pulled off a successful emergency landing on the northbound lane of the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon.

headline: A Struggle Over the Jordan Valley
text: As a strategic corridor along the West Bank border with Jordan, the Jordan Valley holds deep meaning for many.

headline: Strategic Corridor in West Bank Remains a Stumbling Block in Mideast Talks
text: BARDALA, West Bank — The residents of this neglected Palestinian farming village in the northern Jordan Valley area of the West Bank say they get running water once every three days, which they store in bottles and cisterns.

headline: New Year, New Nets With Back-to-Back Wins
text: After beating Oklahoma City on the road Thursday, the Nets returned home Saturday feeling about as pleased with themselves as they had since — well, let’s say October, before the season, when hope and hype for the team were at an apex.

headline: Elizabeth Goff and Russel Santillanes
text: Elizabeth Jeanne Goff and Russel Edward Santillanes were married Saturday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: AnnaRose King and Michael Telis
text: AnnaRose McLaughlin King, a daughter of the Rev. Alison T. Moore of Brookline, Mass., and the late Roger M. King, was married Saturday to Michael Charles Telis, a son of Karen A. Telis and Dr. Sherman H. Telis of Washington. The bride’s mother, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Weylin B. Seymour’s, an event space in Brooklyn, with Rabbi Richard Davis assisting.

headline: Rochelle Behrens and Sacha Litman
text: Rochelle Alexis Behrens and Sacha Frédéric Litman were married Saturday evening at the Rancho Bernardo Inn and Resort in San Diego. Rabbi Deborah R. Prinz officiated, with Rabbi Marc Baker assisting.

headline: Amira Ibrahim and Nathan Bliss
text: Amira Tumbaga Ibrahim and Nathan Joseph Bliss were married Saturday at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn. The Rev. Constance Hulla, the pastor at the Coney Island Gospel Assembly Church, officiated.

headline: Teammates, On Court and Off
text: Rachel Esther Rosenberg and Evan Stuart Levine were married Saturday evening at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Getzel Davis, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

headline: Alexandra Andrews, Christopher Beha
text: Alexandra Drury Andrews and Christopher R. Beha were married Saturday at the James Burden Mansion in New York. Sarah Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the ceremony; James J. Beha II, the groom’s twin brother, led the couple in their vows and exchange of rings.

headline: Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Spiegel
text: Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Jay Spiegel were married on the evening of Jan. 4 in what the guests had been told was going to be the couple’s engagement party. Rabbi Esther Lederman led the surprise wedding ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

headline: Angelique Velez and Jeremy Sina
text: Angelique Velez and Jeremy Daniel Sina were married Saturday at the Rincon Beach Resort in Añasco, Puerto Rico. Judge Rafael A. Ramos Sáenz of the municipal court in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, officiated.

headline: Teresa LaBarbera, Brandon Dufour
text: Teresa Anne LaBarbera and Brandon John Dufour were married Wednesday at the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception in Waterbury, Conn. The Very Rev. John J. Bevins, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Daniella Rohr, Samuel Adelsberg
text: Daniella Esther Rohr, a daughter of Pamela L. Rohr and George Rohr of Manhattan, was married Tuesday to Samuel S. Adelsberg, a son of Renée Adelsberg and Steven Adelsberg of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ruben C. Gober officiated at Spring Studios, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: A Romance Goes From Head to Heart
text: Barbara Catherine Galletly and Grant Olney Passmore were married Saturday by the Rev. Davis Bailey, a Presbyterian minister, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: After Long Wait, Good Things Come to Visiting Saints
text: PHILADELPHIA — The New Orleans Saints joined the N.F.L. in 1967 and did not make the playoffs for 20 years. It took the Saints another 13 years to win a playoff game. And Saturday night, 46 seasons after their debut in the N.F.L., they finally won a road playoff game.

headline: Low on Funds, ‘Spider-Man’ Dims Its Last Lights
text: It wouldn’t have been a fitting final performance of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” if something hadn’t gone wrong.

headline: Corrections: January 5, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: On Tour of Mideast, Kerry Says Iran Might Play Role in Syria Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday that Iran might play a role at the peace talks on Syria in Switzerland this month.

headline: Michelle Obama Extends Her Hawaii Vacation
text: HONOLULU — When President Obama departed Hawaii Saturday evening he left behind one notable thing — his wife, Michelle.

headline: My Year of Mom Rage
text: It’s time to put on pants, and my daughter is sprawled on the floor sobbing. “I don’t want them!” she cries. “I don’t wike dem!” My daughter is 2, and she refuses to wear anything except fancy dresses. Today she is wearing a white Easter dress with a green sash and a big pink flower. Never mind that it’s winter and we live in Iowa, where it’s 20 degrees outside. I’ve tried reasoning and pleading with her, and finally we reach a compromise. She can wear the dress as long as she wears pants underneath and a sweater. I get the sweater on her. It’s pink, so that helps. But not the pants.

headline: American Dialect Society Chooses ‘Because’ as Word of the Year
text: After a year dominated by upstarts like “selfie,” “bitcoin” and “twerk,” the American Dialect Society’s Word of the Year honor for 2013 has gone to a seemingly old-hat vocabulary item: “because.”

headline: Urban Dictionary’s Next Phase: Global and Mobile
text: Urban Dictionary, the crowdsourced online dictionary, has slowly gained a cult following over the last decade and a half that has turned the bootstrapped site into the default dictionary for the Internet.

headline: Jet Skids Into Snowbank at J.F.K. Airport
text: A plane skidded off a taxiway and into a snowbank at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Sunday morning, causing all domestic and international flights to be suspended for two hours while workers salted and sanded taxiways and runways, transportation officials said.

headline: In Our Pages: January 6
text: 1914: Hotel Jewelry Thieves Arrested In Paris

headline: Founder of Avant-Garde Theater Tackles a New Scene
text: “I couldn’t pay the rent,” said Judith Malina, 87, the artistic director and co-founder of The Living Theater, explaining why a year ago she lost the site of her Lower East Side theater company and the commercial space above it, where she had lived for six years.

headline: Low Turnout in Bangladesh Elections Amid Boycott and Violence
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Amid a deepening conflict between Bangladesh’s two main political parties, the scene here in the capital as polls opened for the general elections on Sunday was ominous, with black-clad special forces units and soldiers in combat gear patrolling nearly empty boulevards.

headline: U.S. Vessel to Aid Ships Stuck in Antarctica
text: TAISHAN, China — Australian officials have asked an American icebreaker to help with the rescue of Chinese and Russian vessels that are surrounded by ice floes off Antarctica, according to an announcement on Sunday by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY A fourth round of the writer Julian Fellowes’s sudsy British hit about aristocrats and their servants begins as Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery) mourns the death of her husband, Matthew, who was killed on the day of the birth of their baby, George, at the end of last season. But Mary finds motherhood to be scant solace, and Matthew’s death has left the estate’s financial future shaky, since he apparently did not leave a will. Meanwhile, Lady Edith (Laura Carmichael) appears to have at long last found love with the editor Michael Gregson (Charles Edwards); Lady Rose (Lily James), the niece of the Earl of Grantham (Hugh Bonneville), stirs things up with her newfound fondness for jazz and her particular appreciation for the singer Jack Ross (Gary Carr); and Isobel Crawley (Penelope Wilton) struggles with her place in the family, now that her son Matthew is no longer in the picture. (Sophie McShera, as Daisy, is above.) “The narrative this time around is even more stretched, derivative and repetitive than Season 3’s, but almost ingeniously so: It is both utterly predictable and surprisingly addictive,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Downton Abbey’ is long past its sell-by date, yet is still remarkably palatable.”

headline: Eusebio, Who Represented the Best of Soccer and of Portugal, Dies at 71
text: Soccer fans called him the Black Panther, in the manner of the day, because he was from Mozambique, playing for Portugal, but there was little feline about Eusebio. He was big in the beams and solid around the middle even when he was 24 and, for a few magical weeks, the most captivating player of the 1966 World Cup.

headline: As Deep Freeze Hits, Moviegoers Return ‘Frozen’ to Box-Office Top Spot
text: “Frozen” became the rarest of hits over the weekend: Instead of shuffling off toward DVD, as most movies playing in wide release do after about a month, the Disney musical surged back to the top spot at the North American box office by selling an astounding $20.7 million in tickets. “Frozen” — benefiting from top-notch reviews, a shortage of family-friendly movies and, perhaps, the thematically appropriate extreme winter weather in much of the United States — has now taken in roughly $297.8 million over its six-week domestic run, for a global total of $639.9 million.

headline: Senators Differ Sharply on Penalty for Snowden
text: WASHINGTON — A debate over whether Edward J. Snowden deserves lenience or the strict treatment the Obama administration has demanded for divulging a vast array of national secrets drew sharply opposing views on Sunday from two prominent senators.

headline: Fire in Luxury High-Rise Kills One and Displaces Dozens in Hell’s Kitchen
text: A 27-year-old man was killed and dozens of residents were displaced Sunday in a three-alarm fire at a luxury high-rise building in Hell’s Kitchen, officials said.

headline: Co-Pilot Killed in Plane Crash at Aspen Airport
text: A co-pilot was killed and two other people were injured after a private plane crashed as it tried to land at the Aspen airport in Colorado on Sunday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Fresh Fare Is Served Well Chilled
text: Fourteen performers assembled on the old coffee barge under the Brooklyn Bridge during Thursday evening’s blizzard for Bargemusic’s Here and Now winter festival of contemporary fare. With 14 pieces by 13 composers, the program felt somewhat like a potluck dinner where the few tantalizingly accomplished dishes are finished all too soon, leaving you to pick at multiple versions of baked macaroni.

headline: U.S. Ambassador Renews Ties to His Ancestral Village
text: A light drizzle was falling on the village of Jilong on the afternoon of Dec. 17 when a large black sport utility vehicle pulled up to a parking area next to the pond. Out of it stepped Gary Locke, the American ambassador, who this month is expected to leave his post and return to his hometown of Seattle. This was Mr. Locke’s fifth visit to his ancestral village in the Taishan region of Guangdong Province, and his third and possibly final one as ambassador to China.

headline: In Love and Traffic
text: Teresa LaBarbera was the local traffic reporter at WTNH in Connecticut. Brandon Dufour was a driving instructor. When they met on-air during a news segment, the connection was immediate.

headline: N.F.L. Wild-Card Sunday
text: Highlights from Sunday’s N.F.L. playoff games.

headline: In Palm Springs, 2 Bonos and Many Hopefuls
text: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — You know it’s not a standard Oscar whistle-stop when Bono (BAHN-oh) is the less revered Bono (BONE-oh), Julia Roberts does her best to disprove the orchestra’s “Oh, Pretty Woman” introduction music, and your silver-haired table mate introduces himself like this: “Hello. I have really bad sinuses.”

headline: De Blasio Holds Open House at Gracie Mansion, His New Home
text: Gracie Mansion, the buttercream-hued mayoral residence on a bluff overlooking the East River, has stood stately but mostly silent for more than 12 years, its elegant interiors reserved for the formal functions of a mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, who chose to live elsewhere.

headline: Bengals Seek Respect, but Chargers Earn It
text: CINCINNATI — Here along the banks of the murky Ohio River, where a generation has wallowed in the futility of the beloved Bengals, the paradigm has shifted: Respect is gained not by reaching the postseason but by winning there.

headline: Democrats Press Revival of Jobless Aid That Expired
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats continued on Sunday to argue for restoring long-term unemployment insurance for more than a million Americans who are out of work, days after the benefits lapsed, as lawmakers prepared to return from their recess.

headline: A Double Dose of Chekhov
text: A century and a half ago, Anton Chekhov wrote a play while still a medical student. Never performed or published in his lifetime, it was discovered in a locked box years after his death. This sprawling 20-character work, left untitled, has subsequently appeared as “Play Without Title,” “Without Fathers,” “A Country Scandal,” “Don Juan in the Russian Manner” and as the film “Unfinished Piece for the Player Piano.”

headline: Make It One for My Baby and One More for the Books
text: In “The Sutton Place Story,” John Cheever describes Deborah, “not quite 3 years old,” who, because of her home environment, “had naturally come to assume that cocktails were the axis of the adult world. She made Martinis in the sand pile and thought all the illustrations of cups, goblets, and glasses in her nursery books were filled with old-fashioneds.” Cheever and five other writers who had alcohol much on their minds (and in their livers) are brought together in Olivia Laing’s “The Trip to Echo Spring,” a combination of literary analysis, memoir and travelogue that is most beguiling and incisive when rambling through the work and lives of Cheever, Raymond Carver, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, Tennessee Williams and John Berryman.

headline: Waltzing Right Past History in Austria
text: VIENNA — A year ago, in the days surrounding the Vienna Philharmonic’s internationally televised New Year’s concerts, the orchestra was surrounded by turmoil. This year, not so much.

headline: Broken Bow Hairs, Puns and Idiosyncratic Style
text: It is increasingly common for adventurous musicians like Chris Thile to take a mix-and-match approach to programming. Instead of performing a Bach partita or complete sonata in reverential entirety, he might juxtapose movements with eclectic repertory to highlight unlikely connections.

headline: A Satire With Targets Not So Well Remembered
text: If New York City did not have its very own Albert Bergeret, we would need to invent — or at least import — him. Since 1974, Mr. Bergeret, the artistic director of the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, has done yeoman’s work guarding and promoting the peerless operettas and traditions of the English duo for which his company is named. A life without opportunities to hear those witty, wise pieces performed faithfully is not something I care to think about.

headline: An Actor Dons His Singer-Songwriter Hat
text: Jeff Daniels’s folksy monologue “Recreational Vehicle” is only half as long as its prototype, Arlo Guthrie’s “Alice’s Restaurant.” But this rambling true story of a family road trip to the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., in a 28-foot “Jayco Winnebago” driven by Mr. Daniels has a similar thread of absurdist, self-deprecating humor and is almost as funny.

headline: Seeking Loved Ones, Including Themselves
text: The actresses Nora Woolley and Kim Katzberg bear a mild resemblance to each other, and that — along with a gift for writing their own material and quick-changing into an array of characters — make them suitable partners for “Hip” and “Darkling,” two audacious solo shows paired at the IRT Theater.

headline: Strip-Squeezing at the Truscott Board-a-Match Teams
text: The Truscott Board-a-Match Teams competition was held on Dec. 29 and 30, the last two days of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan.

headline: Eusébio, 71, Legend of Portuguese Soccer, Dies
text: London — Eusébio, the wonderful soccer player of the 1960s and 1970s, died on Sunday at the age of 71.

headline: Bit of Cheesecake
text: Administrivial Cool Article Alert! Constructor extraordinaire Ian Livengood and his J.A.S.A. class were interviewed for “DNAinfo New York”. You can read more about the class and its members here.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 6
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: America and India
text: Reciprocity on diplomats’ rights just went out the window.

headline: The Children of ThinkFilm
text: ThinkFilm was founded in 2001 as an independent art-house distributor by several former executives at Lionsgate. The company became known for award-winning films like “Born Into Brothels” and “Half Nelson.” After the company closed in 2008, many former ThinkFilm employees went on to lead new film businesses.

text: I.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Freed Russian Oligarch Leaves Germany for Switzerland With Family
text: BERLIN — Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon recently freed after a decade in prison in Russia, has left Berlin and arrived by train in Switzerland, where he and his wife will oversee their teenage sons’ return to school, according to a statement from Mr. Khodorkovsky’s aides, who called the trip “a family matter.”

headline: Hawaii Makes Its Case for Obama’s Library: Why Not Bring It to the Beach?
text: HONOLULU — When Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii was asked to appear in a video urging President Obama to make the state the home of his presidential library, the governor’s appeal was simple and, he said, reflective of the state’s “Aloha spirit.”

headline: Federer Falls to Hewitt, but Australian Open Awaits
text: BRISBANE, Australia — This stage of Roger Federer’s career will primarily be measured by his success in fending off younger players, but he finished the first week of his 2014 season with a rare loss to an older foe.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 6
text: SAMSUNG EARNINGS 2014 will be a tough year for Samsung Electronics, the largest cellphone and television maker in the world. Its stock recently took a beating amid concerns of slowing profit growth from smartphone sales, and the company is under pressure to continue releasing innovative new products to compete with Apple and a crop of handset makers in China. On Tuesday, when the South Korean giant is expected to report earnings estimates for the fourth quarter, investors will keep a close eye on the company’s sales of cellphones, televisions and other items during the holiday shopping season, the most lucrative time of year for electronics manufacturers.

headline: Abolish the Corporate Income Tax
text: BOSTON — JOBS don’t grow out of thin air, especially well-paying ones. They require, among other things, companies that are willing to operate where you live. Just ask the Seattle-based District 751 of the machinists’ union, which was worried that Boeing will build its new 777X airliner someplace far away where it is cheaper to produce. Last month the union offered contract concessions, as its president explained, to ensure “the long-term success” of Boeing in Washington State. And on Friday, Boeing machinists approved a contract with concessions to keep assembly of the plane in the area.

headline: Spain’s Solar Pullback Threatens Pocketbooks
text: ÁGUILAS, Spain — Six years ago, Justo Cruz Rodríguez, who runs a small business here designing signs, was looking for a way to generate a steady, if modest, pension for himself and his father.

headline: Give Rose a Shot at the Hall
text: THE Baseball Hall of Fame will announce its new inductees on Wednesday — a burst of warmth in the cold, diamond-less winter — and the crop of potential inductees includes, for the second straight year, Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens.

headline: The Bubble Is Back
text: WASHINGTON — IN November, housing starts were up 23 percent, and there was cheering all around. But the crowd would quiet down if it realized that another housing bubble had begun to grow.

headline: Two Decades of Change Have Boston Sparkling
text: BOSTON — During the 1988 presidential campaign, Vice President George Bush famously shined a spotlight on the “open sewer” that was Boston Harbor. He blamed his opponent, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, for failing to clean it up and called the harbor, which was choked with sludge and contaminated with chemicals, the dirtiest body of water in the country.

headline: Crack Cocaine Limbo
text: President Obama earned a rare moment of bipartisan acclaim last month when he commuted the sentences of eight long-serving federal prisoners. Their crack cocaine offenses had resulted in the harsh penalties mandated by a sentencing formula that Congress repudiated when it passed the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010. The old formula, under which possession of a quantity of crack earned the same sentence as possession of 100 times that quantity of powdered cocaine, was “now recognized as unjust,” the president said.

headline: In Bid to Be Council Speaker, a Tenants’ Champion Fights an Uphill Battle
text: In eight years on the City Council, Daniel R. Garodnick has pushed for police reform, rallied with labor leaders in support of paid sick days and fought to preserve middle-class housing in his district.

headline: Acing the Course at Chapel Hill
text: Another shameful lesson in the multibillion-dollar entertainment industry euphemistically referred to as collegiate sports is playing out at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. A former professor was indicted on fraud charges last month after running dozens of bogus and no-show courses heavily enrolled with student athletes looking for easy academic credits.

headline: Republican Disdain for the Jobless
text: One of the first votes the Senate plans to take when it returns Monday is on restoring unemployment benefits to 1.3 million people who lost them on Dec. 28. It’s hard to imagine a more important action for those who have been out of work the longest and for the economy.

headline: Iraqis Make Gains Against Militants in Key City
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi security forces and their tribal allies made gains in heavy fighting on Sunday in Ramadi, reclaiming parts of the city from Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda, security officials and tribal leaders said.

headline: Seminoles Tight End’s Competitive Drive Recalls His Grandfather Nicklaus
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Nancy O’Leary named her second son Nicklaus, her maiden name. She figured he could go by Nick but wanted to honor her parents, Jack and Barbara Nicklaus.

headline: Another Step Forward on Okinawa
text: For nearly two decades, Japan and the United States have been mired in a dispute over the American military presence on Okinawa. Late last month,  the two sides took an important step toward resolving the issue when the Okinawa governor, Hirokazu Nakaima, approved a landfill permit clearing the way for construction of a new base on a remote coast of the island. There are still hurdles, but the permit was a significant breakthrough.

headline: NBC Begins Swarm of Ads to Lift ‘Today’ Back to Top
text: The “Today” show, so accustomed to winning, has grown impatient with losing.

headline: $1 Billion as Milestone and Omen
text: Fab.com, an online retailer selling affordable high design, last year seemed as if it could be the next Amazon.

headline: Before Signing a Strong Arm, Teams Should Heed Vick’s Dark Past
text: PHILADELPHIA — Michael Vick, the quarterback known as much for his rap sheet as his athletic skill, watched the football tumble through the uprights not long before midnight on Saturday and knew his time was up.

headline: ThinkFilm, a Short-Lived but Wily Distributor, Still Influences Industry
text: LOS ANGELES — In two weeks, the feisty operatives of an ever tighter, tougher independent film business will gather at the annual Sundance Film Festival.

headline: A Developer Is Mourned and Vilified in Brooklyn
text: A day after the charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer was identified in a smoking trash bin on Long Island, more than a thousand mourners gathered for his funeral in the heart of Hasidic Williamsburg. They grieved for the man they called a pillar of his synagogue and his community, a father of eight who had been quick to donate and quick to lend.

headline: Does the U.S. Need Another War on Poverty?
text: Fifty years after President Lyndon B. Johnson's declaration, much has changed, but much remains the same. Or does it?

headline: Print Starts to Settle Into Its Niches
text: Kevin Kelly is not a dumb guy — far from it actually. As the founding executive editor of Wired and one of the people who helped build The Well, among the earliest online communities, he has done a good job of seeing what is coming next for decades.

headline: House G.O.P. Trims Agenda, Looking to Avert Election-Year Trouble
text: WASHINGTON — The “do nothing” Congress is preparing to do even less.

headline: Zero Tolerance, Reconsidered
text: Schools across the country are rethinking “zero tolerance” discipline policies under which children have been suspended, even arrested, for minor offenses like cursing, getting into shoving matches and other garden-variety misbehavior that in years past would have been resolved with detention or meetings with a child’s parents.

headline: 49ers Feel Joy, if Not Their Toes
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The bitterly cold forecast for Sunday’s N.F.C. wild-card game at Lambeau Field concerned San Francisco 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh. So twice, on Saturday and again before kickoff, he asked his quarterback, Colin Kaepernick, to reconsider his plan to play in short sleeves and without gloves.

headline: The Muslim Brotherhood, Back in a Fight to Survive
text: FAYOUM, Egypt — They hide in safe houses on the outskirts of this city, talk only fleetingly on cellphones and avoid the cafes where they used to meet. Heavy scarves obscure their identities when they venture out to join protests.

headline: New Campaign Markets Activia to Wider Audience
text: A MUCH-NOTICED, much-parodied relationship between a star and a brand is ending as a campaign for Activia probiotic yogurt, scheduled to begin on Monday, replaces the actress Jamie Lee Curtis with three endorsers.

headline: Wild-Card Weather Balmy, Compared With the ‘Freezer Bowl’
text: CINCINNATI — The Cincinnati Bengals commemorated the franchise’s 1981 team before the current squad’s 27-10 loss Sunday in an A.F.C. wild-card game against the San Diego Chargers.

headline: Latin Jazz Stalwart Struggles to Make Sweet Sounds Again
text: The autographed posters and concert photos in Dave Valentin’s living room attest to his status as one of the pre-eminent flutists in Latin jazz. Tucked among 78s tacked to the wall, they show Mr. Valentin smiling alongside performers like Tito Puente and aficionados like Bill Cosby. Nearby, a bunch of “All Access” stage passes from concerts dangle from a nail like a good-luck charm.

headline: Fog-Wreathed Paradise, Built by a Billionaire Under a Cloud
text: JIUZHAIGOU, China — Inside the hotel’s front entrance, a white mechanical yak nods and says “Moo.” Beyond it is the centerpiece of the compound: a vast glass atrium with a replica of a Tibetan and ethnic Qiang village filled with three-story stone and wood buildings, each housing a restaurant or bar. Corn husks sit atop the roofs.

headline: Southwest’s Dwindling Water Supply
text: If Lake Mead drops below 1,000 feet above sea level, millions of people will lose their source of water.

headline: Colorado River Drought Forces a Painful Reckoning for States
text: LAKE MEAD, Nev. — The sinuous Colorado River and its slew of man-made reservoirs from the Rockies to southern Arizona are being sapped by 14 years of drought nearly unrivaled in 1,250 years.

headline: 16-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot on His Way Home From a Party in Brownsville
text: Iquan Williams’s parents said they kept him close: an early curfew and no hanging out late at house parties. They knew what trouble could come to a 16-year-old boy at certain times in certain corners of the city. Days earlier a young gunman had fired into a group of teenagers in the lobby of a housing project in Brownsville, Brooklyn, wounding five, as a party thumped upstairs.

headline: Democrats Quote the Pope
text: Democrats are using the words of Pope Francis in their speeches about poverty, income inequality and social justice.

headline: O.J. Who? Rogues Vanish From Annals of Sport
text: Among college football’s many rituals, the annual Heisman Trophy presentation remains one of the highlights. Fans and coaches and former stars gather in Manhattan each December to honor the season’s outstanding player. This season, about two dozen former winners stood on the stage as another member was added to their exclusive club.

headline: Popular Voice in the Capitol? It’s the Pope’s
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly before leaving the Capitol for the holiday recess, Senate Democrats gathered behind closed doors to lay out an agenda for 2014. When the majority leader, Harry Reid, exhorted colleagues to “deal with the issue of income inequality,” the talk took a spiritual turn.

headline: Sudan’s Lost Boys Are Drawn Into War at Home
text: AWERIAL, South Sudan — When Jacob Atem was just a young boy, his parents were killed during the long war for independence from Sudan, and he found himself among the legions of orphaned children known as the Lost Boys wandering hundreds of miles across this part of Africa.

headline: Ireland Stirs Homegrown Flavor Into Tech Scene
text: DUBLIN — The Grand Canal Docks, an upscale business district here in the center of town, is a kind of home away from home for the big Silicon Valley companies like Google and Facebook. These international behemoths, in large part attracted by the low Irish corporate tax rates, have big presences here. And with their thousands of workers and bustling offices, they have long overshadowed the local start-up scene.

headline: Study Suggests Recovery in U.S. Is Relatively Vital
text: PHILADELPHIA — Academic heavyweights have been debating whether the current United States economy is so sluggish because of too much government stimulus or not enough, or because slower growth had become the norm even before the recession.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Nears a $2 Billion Deal in a Case Tied to Madoff
text: Working through a long list of legal problems, JPMorgan Chase is starting the new year with another steep payout to the government.

headline: From Petraeus Scandal, an Apostle for Privacy
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Jill Kelley still glances around for cameras before she leaves her large, six-columned house on Hillsborough Bay, and she rarely goes to the grocery store. Since November 2012, when the government released her name in connection with a scandal that brought down the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, Ms. Kelley has yet to return to her children’s schools, she said, and could not even summon the courage to go to their holiday plays.

headline: Seeking Independence, Three Men Start in the Kitchen
text: Five men were playing pool recently in the sunny, airy lobby of the Next Generation Center in the South Bronx. One of the men offered pool tips to the others. Later, two men greeted each other with a tight hug.

headline: With Marijuana Access on the Horizon, Patients Fear Potential Restrictions
text: Nancy Rivera, a cancer survivor, has a bag of pills in her night stand — white, gold and rust, big and little, antidepressants, antiemetics and tranquilizers — given to her by doctors. So it always seemed hypocritical to her that while she could possess such powerful mind-altering pharmaceuticals in fairly generous quantities, she was not allowed to legally smoke marijuana to relieve the nausea and pain of her cancer and chemotherapy.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Jan. 5, 2014
Out of the Wilderness and Into the Olympic Spotlight
text: Ask Carey Price how his hockey journey started, and he says, “I grew up in a small town, like most Canadians,” and laughs.

headline: 14 Killed in Stampede in Northwest China
text: HONG KONG — Fourteen people were trampled to death in northwest China on Sunday as a crowd rushed to take offerings of traditional fried flat bread, the official news agency Xinhua reported Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 6, 2014
text: “I don’t want to see another generation of children go through what I’ve gone through and what other children of my generation went through.”

headline: A Frozen, Fertile Ground for Developing Tennis Players
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Following tennis usually means chasing summer, with players training on sunbaked courts in Florida and California and traveling the globe in search of sunshine.
