headline: Knicks Display Their Newfound Resolve by Dispatching Mavericks
text: DALLAS — The Knicks arrived in Texas last week as a fragile, broken team. Two of their rotation players did not even make the trip because of injuries. Their starting point guard spent all three games in street clothes as he recovered from a strained groin.

headline: The Road to the National Championship
text: Even by college football’s standards, this season was turbulent, taking more turns than a board game. Auburn was unranked when the season started; Florida State was 11th. The expected contenders Alabama, Oregon and Ohio State fell by the wayside. The Tigers survived on last-second victories, while the Seminoles won every game by at least 14 points. On Monday night, they meet in the national championship game, competing for the sport’s biggest prize.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Advertising pages for weekly magazines fell 2 percent from 2012 to 2013, and biweeklies saw a 5.3 percent decline.

headline: ‘Smart TVs’ Are Next Bet for Makers as Sales Languish
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Big, bright, sharp and sophisticated, television sets have never looked better. But that’s a problem. The TV industry has innovated itself into a corner.

headline: Symptoms of Torn Artery Are Easy to Miss
text: Karin Satrom, a 35-year-old Brooklynite, had been feeling fine through 23 weeks of pregnancy when one night she said she became “very, very dizzy, as if I were drunk.” Her husband suggested that she lie down, but even with her eyes closed, the room continued to spin.

headline: Word of the Day | ruffian
text: ruffian •\ˈrə-fe-ən\• noun

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: A Rising Team Faces a Top One
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: What Kind of Boomer Are You?
text: The baby boom generation can be seen as having two distinct halves. Where do you fall?

headline: I May Be 50, but Don’t Call Me a Boomer
text: There is no baby boom generation.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: ROBERT OSBORNE After 20 years as the network’s host and interviewer, Mr. Osborne slides into the guest’s chair for a conversation with Alec Baldwin. Four of Mr. Osborne’s favorite movies follow: “The Third Man” (1949), Carol Reed’s thriller about a penniless American writer (Joseph Cotten) whose investigation into the death of a friend (Orson Welles, above) uncovers corruption in post-World War II Vienna, at 9:30; “Libeled Lady” (1936), Jack Conway’s screwball comedy in which a newspaper editor (Spencer Tracy), his fiancée (Jean Harlow) and a former reporter (William Powell) try to compromise an heiress (Myrna Loy) before she can sue for libel, at 1 a.m.; William Dieterle’s “Love Letters” (1945), about a soldier (Cotten, again) who falls for the woman (Jennifer Jones) who may have killed his best friend, at 3 a.m.; and “The Band Wagon” (1953), Vincente Minnelli’s MGM musical with Fred Astaire as an aging star whose Broadway comeback is sabotaged by an overzealous director (Jack Buchanan) and his prima ballerina colleague (Cyd Charisse), at 5 a.m. Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz wrote the songs, which include “That’s Entertainment!”

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Often, fans will use head coverings to vividly declare their loyalties. At other times they merely serve as protection from the elements.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey':  Season 4 Begins
text: A year is a long time to spend in mourning. It is a period expansive enough to leave the dead in the past, and to forge new and renewed relationships with those still living.

headline: For Cheney, Realities of a Race Outweighed Family Edge
text: WASHINGTON — Liz Cheney’s short-lived Wyoming Senate campaign shows the perils of personal ambition outpacing a rationale for candidacy.

headline: A.T.M. Makers See Opportunity in Long Lines at Rural Branches of Banks
text: MANGALI, Haryana — In Indian cities, getting cash from a bank is as easy as going to an A.T.M. around the corner. In the rural areas, however, those who have bank accounts have to withdraw money by visiting the bank, which could be miles away from where they live. Serpentine lines at the tiny bank of a village or district make the simple task of withdrawing money an ordeal.

headline: South Korea Proposes Resuming Reunions of War-Divided Families
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s president proposed Monday that the two Koreas improve their tense relations by resuming the reunions of families separated since the Korean War, a humanitarian program that seemed close to being renewed last year but was scuttled as negotiations soured.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Jan. 6, 2014
text: What four words fill in the blanks from this article about a Mexican holiday tradition?

headline: Vegetable Shopping for a New York Kitchen
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Curious, and Continuing, Appeal of Mark Twain in China
text: There are few authors regarded as quintessentially American as Mark Twain. With his preternatural gift for capturing vernacular expression and his roguish wit, Twain is still widely seen as the founder of the American voice. More than a century after his death, “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,” Twain’s most celebrated work, remains a mainstay of middle school and high school English classes. Ernest Hemingway famously declared it the book from which “all modern American literature comes.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Challenges of Ending Poverty
text: In “50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag,” Annie Lowrey writes about the poverty rate in the United States, and how it has changed over time.

headline: Photographing Spiritual Experience
text: When the Lens blog made its debut in 2009, the newspaper industry was in free fall, the outlets for serious photojournalism rapidly disappearing. “There was a need to help promote photographers and photography in whatever way possible,” said James Estrin, the blog’s co-founder. “We wanted to write about the photographers; photos don’t happen by themselves.”

headline: When Do You Choose Making a Phone Call Over Sending a Text?
text: That device in your pocket used to text, access the Internet, play games and take pictures is called a phone. But how often do you use it to make and answer calls?

text: Also on the Minute, airbrushing sports history and the future of television.

headline: Sudan’s Leader Flies to South for Crisis Talks
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan flew to South Sudan on Monday to discuss the crisis unfolding there with President Salva Kiir after the start of peace talks in Ethiopia failed to bring a halt to fighting.

headline: Democracy in Peril in Asia
text: Street protests in three Asian countries — Cambodia, Bangladesh and Thailand — are a vivid reminder of the fragile state of democracy in many developing countries, particularly those that do not have independent judiciaries and professional police forces and militaries.

headline: In a Hostile Bid, Men’s Wearhouse Raises Offer for Jos. A. Bank
text: Updated, 8:14 p.m. |

headline: German Leader Injured in Skiing Accident
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel has canceled most of her meetings for the next three weeks after doctors ordered her to rest in bed following a fall while cross-country skiing in Switzerland over the Christmas holiday, her spokesman said Monday.

headline: China Destroys 6 Tons of Ivory
text: Over the past five years or so, as the poaching of elephants has swelled to record numbers, environmentalists and researchers have pointed a finger firmly at China’s ravenous appetite for ivory as the main cause for what is now widely described as a crisis.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 6, 2014
text: Update: Jan. 7, 2013

headline: Behind the Cover: Paul Tough on a Tale of Strategic Survival
text: Paul Tough, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about a fisherman named John Aldridge, who fell overboard 40 miles off the eastern end of Long Island last summer and survived nearly 12 hours in the water before being rescued by the Coast Guard. Tough’s most recent book is “How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity, and the Hidden Power of Character.”How did you first hear about this extraordinary survival story?

headline: The Information We Still Need to Manage Our Health Care
text: After writing eight posts on my search for health insurance, which generated more than 275 comment from readers, I was more than ready to move on. After all, I do have a day job — running my little factory — and I have other projects and problems to address. But my mind keeps returning to a scene I witnessed the week before Christmas.

headline: YP, a Mobile Search Firm, Buys Sense Networks
text: YP, the local search and advertising company owned by Cerberus Capital Management and AT&T, said on Monday that it had acquired Sense Networks, a mobile ad company.

headline: The Man Who Forgot He Was Prime Minister
text: NEW DELHI — In political life, perhaps there is no public reaction more denigrating than ridicule. Criticism is part of the terrain, but ridicule entails a deeper kind of humiliation, where the right to even be heard seriously has been taken away.

headline: ‘Polar Vortex’ Sends Shivers Across U.S.
text: Updated, 1:45 p.m. Wake up in Madison, Wis.? Monday’s temperature was 18 degrees below zero. In Minneapolis, and Chicago, it was minus 15. And in Fargo, N.D., it was 23 degrees below zero.

headline: Daily Report: ‘Smart TVs’ in the Spotlight at Consumer Electronics Show
text: The TV industry has innovated itself into a corner, Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report. Crisp, high-definition TVs as big as 50 diagonal inches can be had for a few hundred dollars. Why bother upgrading or paying more for a fancy new one? Many people don’t.

headline: $20 Million Donation for Jazz at Lincoln Center
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center has announced that Robert J. Appel, a financier and philanthropist, has pledged $20 million to benefit the organization’s performance, education and broadcasting efforts. The gift, one of the largest single private contributions to date in support of jazz music,  will also be used to help promote the center’s global initiatives of audience development and jazz advocacy. Mr. Appel joined the Jazz at Lincoln Center board in 2008 and was appointed chairman in 2012.

headline: At CES 2014, a Battle for the Next Generation of Computing
text: The International CES in Las Vegas, one of the largest technology trade shows in the world, is a reflection of the rapidly changing electronics industry.

headline: G.E. to Buy Health Care Units From Thermo Fisher Scientific
text: General Electric said on Monday that it would acquire a gene modulation and magnetic beads business from Thermo Fisher Scientific for about $1.06 billion.

headline: China Follows U.S., Crushing Tons of Confiscated Ivory
text: China on Monday used a loud, much-hailed ivory-crushing event to send a signal to consumers and criminals about the country’s intention to crack down on the smuggling and poaching that has devastated elephant populations. Bettina Wassener has the details in a post on The New York Times blog Sinosphere. Here’s an excerpt and link:

headline: Woody Allen and His ‘Kin'; Alfonso Cuarón and His ‘Bad Movie’
text: Sure, by now you’ve probably taken the Youse, Y’all and Yinz dialect quiz, but have you ever considered the connections between, say, Louis Armstrong, Richard Pryor and Noah Baumbach? A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis investigate the genealogy of Woody Allen, linking him to filmmakers, comedians, writers, even a fictional character or two, in this neat, graphic imagining of his family tree, part of the special Arts & Leisure Oscars issue.

headline: Carlyle Hires Former F.C.C. Chairman for Buyout Group
text: Updated, 5:10 p.m. |

headline: JPMorgan Near a Settlement in Madoff Case
text: JPMorgan Chase is starting the year the same way it ended the last one: by whipping out its wallet, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The bank is preparing to reach roughly $2 billion in criminal and civil settlements with federal authorities who claim that it ignored signs of Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme, bringing its settlement total to nearly $20 billion over the last year. The settlements come on the heels of a record $13 billion deal with the Justice Department in November related to the bank’s questionable mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis.

headline: Nestlé to Sell Frozen Pasta Business to Brynwood Partners
text: LONDON – The food giant Nestlé is selling Joseph’s Pasta, a Massachusetts maker of frozen pastas, to the buyout firm Brynwood Partners.

headline: Human Rights Chairman Said to Resign Over Harassment Accusation
text: NEW DELHI — A former Supreme Court justice resigned as chairman of the West Bengal Human Rights Commission on Monday over accusations that he sexually harassed a law intern, according to local news reports.

headline: In One Image: Cold Snaps In Global Context
text: A useful image from Twitter conveys why debates over regional cold blasts have little relevance to discussions of human-driven climate change:

headline: Last Night in Carroll Gardens
text: Photo: fog shrouded a man, and a street.

headline: A Folkie Takes Issue With ‘Llewyn Davis’
text: Even before the Oscar nominations are announced next week, this has been a season rife with controversy, from the moral stance of “Wolf of Wall Street” to the religious one of “Philomena.” Incidentally, these brouhahas don’t happen to hurt the marketing of the movies in question, since “come see for yourself” has been an irresistible tagline since the dawn of Hollywood, scandal or no.

headline: In Our Pages: January 7
text: 1914: Telephones Used for Blackmail

headline: The War on Poverty at 50
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Justices’ Halt to Gay Marriage Leaves Utah Couples in Limbo
text: SALT LAKE CITY — In a move that cast doubt over the marriages of roughly 1,000 same-sex couples in Utah, the United States Supreme Court on Monday blocked further same-sex marriages there while state officials appeal a decision allowing such unions.

headline: Verso Paper to Buy NewPage Holdings
text: The Verso Paper Corporation announced on Monday that it would acquire NewPage Holdings, a specialty paper company that emerged from bankruptcy in 2012, in a deal valued at $1.4 billion.

headline: BMW Is Recalling 51,000 Motorcycles for Fuel Leak
text: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, BMW says it isrecalling almost 51,000 motorcycles because of a possible fuel leak, according to a report the automaker posted on the agency’s website. Most of the recalled motorcycles are 2005-11 R and K series models.

headline: Image of the Day: January 6
text: Children on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, walking on a snow-covered road.

headline: A Page of Beethoven May Fetch More Than $200,000
text: A rare Beethoven manuscript — actually, a leaf from a late-period sketchbook that the composer apparently tore out and carried in his pocket while composing the “Missa Solemnis” — will be auctioned on Jan. 15 at RR Auctions in Amherst, N.H. The leaf was unknown until 1996, when it was discovered among the papers of Anton Schindler, Beethoven’s friend and early biographer. It was authenticated and auctioned at Sotheby’s in London that year for $110,000.

headline: New Rules for Workers From Europe’s East Prompt Xenophobia in the West
text: The European Union’s easing of work restrictions for Romanians and Bulgarians on New Year’s Day has revived a continent-wide debate on immigration, spurring both irrational alarmism and a caustic backlash against the perceived anti-immigration mania.

headline: London Fashion Week: Lou Dalton Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: A Little Help With the Luggage
text: Soon, passengers won’t have to rely solely on the airline to track their luggage. Find’Em Tracking, a thin Bluetooth tracking device that will be available in February, conveys location information when synched to a smartphone.

headline: Jonathan Saunders: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: London

headline: Knowing a Brain, Saving Sheep and Avoiding Laser Burns
text: We begin a new series that will dive deep into the human mind; helicopters with bags of bighorns — that’s all we will say; the next time you go for laser hair-removal, here are some things to think about.

headline: Solomon Northup’s Legacy, on Film and in Life
text: Chiwetel Ejiofor, the star of “12 Years a Slave,” initially feared that he would not be able to do justice to the life of Solomon Northup, on whose memoir the film is based.

headline: A Symbol of the Range Returns Home
text: BOULDER CITY, Nev. — The two-way radio crackled to life: “We’re coming in with three ewes and a young ram.”

headline: The Read Around: Nikki Giovanni
text: “Poetry prevents everybody from feeling lonely,” says Nikki Giovanni. Her latest book, “Chasing Utopia,” is a collection of poetry, recipes and short stories.

headline: Times Minute | ‘Polar Vortex’ at Work
text: Also in the Minute, Liz Cheney quits the Wyoming Senate Race and “Spider-Man” closes on Broadway.

headline: Times Minute | ‘Polar Vortex’ at Work
text: In the Video

headline: AT&T Allows Advertisers to Sponsor Mobile Data
text: Say you want to watch a trailer for “The Wolf of Wall Street” on your smartphone. Why should you pay for the data required to display it when you are essentially viewing an advertisement?

headline: Daniel Finkel’s Stained Glass Window Problem
text: In this week’s puzzle by Daniel Finkel we continue to follow an itinerant nun who most recently made her way to a shrine in the holy town of Duona. We now join her in some construction work.

headline: Numberplay 2013: A Year in Review
text: Happy New Year! We had quite an adventure in 2013, and I’m looking forward to continuing the quantitative fun this coming year (check out this week’s challenge below). Before we get too far — a short reflection on our recent travels. Numberplay in 2013 featured original problems from many prominent and emerging mathematicians — problems that served as terrific platforms for our weekly explorations. A connection to an original creator is a powerful experience, and we were fortunate to have had many, including understanding fundamental origami concepts with Barry Hayes; discovering combinatorics with Joel Spencer, Ron Graham and Béla Bollobás; exploring primes with Bernardo Recamán.

headline: Yellen Wins Backing of Senators to Lead Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed Janet L. Yellen as the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve on Monday, marking the first time that a woman will lead the country’s central bank in its 100-year history.

headline: British Regulators Open Investigations Into Co-operative Bank
text: LONDON – British regulators said on Monday that they were starting formal investigations into Co-operative Bank after recent revelations about its former chairman and continuing questions about a capital shortfall of 1.5 billion pounds last year.

headline: Eurythmics to Reunite for Beatles Tribute
text: When you think of the Beatles, you think of classic pop harmonies delivered in a British accent and imaginative lyrics that have stood up for half a century. And when you think of these attributes, surely you also think of Eurythmics, John Mayer, Keith Urban and Maroon 5. Or, at least, CBS is hoping that you will, as those are some of the first artists they’ve lined up to perform in a television tribute to the Beatles that will be broadcast on the network next month.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Nikki Giovanni
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Nikki Giovanni discusses her latest book, “Chasing Utopia,” the beer that inspired its title and why poetry keeps people from feeling lonely.

headline: Broad Strokes vs. Pinpoint in Martoma Trial
text: The trial of Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, is the big kahuna for federal prosecutors. While they have won convictions in a number of insider trading trials, this is among the most significant cases because of the dollar amount of the trading, approximately $276 million, and the involvement of Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s founder and owner.

headline: Prepping Food and Their Future
text: Next Generation Caterers in the Bronx helps prepare youth for careers in gastronomy. The Neediest Cases Fund paid the fees for its three interns to take the New York State food protection exam.

headline: MAN: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: London

headline: Topman Lets the London Rains Pour Down
text: LONDON — The coat was a sheer sheet of plastic, revealing a bright red sweater underneath. This shoulders-to-ankles cover-up was just the thing to offset the water that stood in pools on the runway or had been streaming from above — although London’s drenching rains had stopped for a bit.

headline: Mutant Petunias Sing the Blues
text: Blue petunias are a rarity in nature and a favorite among gardeners. Now, researchers say they have discovered the genetic glitch that produces the colored flowers.

headline: Rose Petal and Vanilla Tea
text: This is a sweet infusion with nothing more than dried rose petals, a vanilla bean and honey. You can find dried rose petals in Middle Eastern markets.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 3-5, 2014
text: A week after we began the Gun Report, we decided to end each post with Slate’s gun death tally, an interactive feature which tracked shootings in the news since the Newtown massacre on Dec. 14, 2012. Slate partnered with a Twitter user, @gundeaths, who had been linking to news stories about people killed by guns. No one else in the media was sounding the daily drumbeat of gun violence, and Slate invited readers to contribute details about the shootings it featured every day, giving us a sense of exactly who was getting shot in America.

headline: Teodoro Zamora’s Commission
text: On a humid November day in 1863, Teodoro Zamora and his two brothers rode to the mouth of the Rio Grande. After tying their horses to a lone tree, they walked to where Col. Edmund Davis of the First Texas Cavalry Regiment stood, waiting.

headline: These Females Prefer a Familiar (Fish) Face
text: Female fish are quicker to mate with a male they’ve seen before, thanks in part to a neuron that springs to life in the presence of familiar males, researchers say.

headline: Today in Small Business: Running Out of Marijuana
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Dakar Rally Underway in Argentina
text: Carlos Sousa of Portugal, driving a Chinese-made Haval H8, which looks something like a BMW X3, took the victory Sunday in the first stage of the 2014 Dakar Rally, which ran from Rosario to San Luis, Argentina. He was closely trailed by three entrants in all-wheel-drive Minis.

headline: Iran Urged to Use Influence With Syrian Leader
text: BRUSSELS — Iran could improve its chances of playing at least a limited role in the upcoming peace conference on Syria if it persuaded President Bashar al-Assad to stop the bombardment of Aleppo and allow the delivery of humanitarian aid to besieged towns and cities, senior State Department officials said on Monday.

headline: Lea Seydoux’s Luxe Combo of Florals, Crystals and Satin
text: The Girl: The French actress and model, who earned raves for her performance in “Blue Is the Warmest Color” last year, was in London today, where she accepted a nomination for the EE Rising Star Award, to be presented next month at the British Academy Film Awards.

headline: Trial on Detroit Swaps Deal Is Delayed
text: A trial over how Detroit should end costly financial contracts with two big banks was suspended Monday after more than a foot of snow fell, paralyzing much of the city and closing the federal courthouse there.

headline: U.S. and Iran Face Common Enemies in Mideast Strife
text: TEHRAN — Even as the United States and Iran pursue negotiations on Tehran’s nuclear program, they find themselves on the same side of a range of regional issues surrounding an insurgency raging across the Middle East.

headline: Anna E. Crouse, 97, Dies; Championed Discount Tickets for Broadway
text: Anna E. Crouse, a onetime actress whose fondest Broadway dream — a healthy Manhattan theater district and affordable tickets for young people — was realized when she helped establish the TKTS booth in Duffy Square, died on Dec. 29 in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: 10 Years for Plot to Murder Cartoonist
text: PHILADELPHIA — A federal judge on Monday sentenced a Pennsylvania woman to 10 years in prison for her part in a plan to murder a Swedish cartoonist whose images of the Prophet Muhammad offended Muslims.

headline: Jerry Coleman, 89, Yankee Infielder, Fighter Pilot and Voice of the Padres
text: Jerry Coleman, a former fighter pilot who played in six World Series as an infielder for the Yankees but who made his most lasting mark as a broadcaster, first for the Yankees and then more indelibly for the San Diego Padres, died Sunday near his home in San Diego. He was 89.

headline: What Your Cat Is Thinking
text: Cat owners speak to their cats, attribute many complex emotions to them and chide them when they bring small dead rodents into the house. People don’t pause to ask what is going on in the mind of the cat during these interactions, and perhaps that’s just as well. The role of a pet is to be relentlessly anthropomorphized.

headline: Inside the Cat Brain
text: Excerpt from the preface of “Cat Sense: How the New Feline Science Can Make You a Better Friend to Your Pet” by John Bradshaw.

headline: When Doctors ‘Google’ Their Patients
text: I remember when I first looked up a patient on Google. It was my last day on the bone marrow transplant unit, back when I was an intern. As I stood before the patient, taking her history, she told me she had been a painter and suggested I look up her work on the Internet. I did, and I found her paintings fascinating. Even though our paths crossed fleetingly, she is one of the few patients I vividly remember from that time.

headline: ‘Tis the Season to Compensate College Athletes
text: The N.C.A.A. classifies Division I football players as amateurs, not professionals, student-athletes, not employees, which is how colleges get away with paying them nothing.

headline: The Disappearing Accent in Pop Music
text: Q. Why do pop music vocalists generally seem to sing without an accent?

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Dec. 31, 2013-Jan. 6, 2014
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Gerlach Retirement Opens Up Swing District in Pennsylvania
text: Representative Jim Gerlach of Pennsylvania, a perennial target for Democrats who covet his suburban district, announced on Monday that he will retire from the House after six terms.

headline: In Video and on Twitter, Glimpses of Rodman’s North Korea Trip
text: Dodging tough questions about politics, Dennis Rodman is back in North Korea to play basketball, this time accompanied by former National Basketball Association players who will star in an exhibition game with a local team as part of celebrations Wednesday on the birthday of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: In Sirius Offer, John Malone Is Up to His Old Tricks
text: John C. Malone is up to his same old tricks against Sirius XM.

headline: Czech Parties Agree to Form Center-Left Coalition
text: PARIS — A leftist former finance minister was expected to become prime minister of the Czech Republic after three political parties signed an agreement on Monday to form a center-left coalition government. The deal helped to bring to a close one of the most acrimonious periods of political crisis in the country’s recent memory.

headline: Advertising Age to Reduce Its Print Frequency
text: Advertising Age, the trade publication introduced in 1930, said Monday that it would publish its print edition 25 times a year rather than weekly.

headline: British Economic Debate Opens Ahead of 2015 Vote
text: LONDON — With elections 16 months away, British politicians have headed into battle over the economy.

headline: As New York Region Braces for Chill, Cuomo Declares Emergency
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday declared a state of emergency in 14 counties in western New York and announced that parts of the New York Thruway would be closed, as the Buffalo area braced itself for as much as three feet of snow and wind chills of 30 degrees below zero.

headline: Jared Leto, in Heels
text: Jared Leto is receiving the first of what may be many honors this season, from the New York Film Critics Circle on Monday night, for his performance as the transgender AIDS patient Rayon in “Dallas Buyers Club.” Mr. Leto lost nearly 30 pounds for the role and shaved off his eyebrows, among other make-unders. And of course, he was put in women’s clothing and makeup, as well as being made to look ill and impoverished.

headline: Czech Officials Demand Explanation for Weapons at Palestinian Mission
text: PRAGUE — The Czech authorities, investigating an explosion that killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic at his residence in Prague on Wednesday, now say that they found 12 illegal weapons at the Palestinian Mission next door.

headline: The Confidence of Jerry Coyne
text: One of the problems with belonging to a faction that’s convinced it’s on the winning side of intellectual history is that it becomes easy to persuade oneself that one’s own worldview has no weak points whatsoever, no internal contradictions or ragged edges, no cracks through which a critic’s wedge could end up driven. This kind of overconfidence has been displayed, at various points in the human story, by everyone from millenarians to Marxists, inquisitors to eugenicists. But right now its vices are often found in a certain type of atheistic polemicist, and in a style of anti-religious argument that’s characterized by a peculiar, almost-willed ignorance of why reasonable people might doubt the scientific-materialist worldview.

headline: Deadly Hell’s Kitchen Blaze Traced to Electrical Wire, Fire Dept. Says
text: The fire that left one man dead and other residents displaced from a high-rise building in Midtown Manhattan over the weekend was traced to an electrical power strip, the Fire Department said on Monday.

headline: Never Mind the Predictions: What Did We Learn?
text: I’m not big on market predictions. In fact, if anyone asks, I’m pretty quick to say that I don’t know what the markets will do in 2014. If you absolutely must have predictions for the next year, then I recommend you check out Barry Ritholtz’s annual list. But if you are interested in something more useful than predictions, I suggest taking a look at what we learned (or had confirmed — again) in 2013.

headline: A Long, Frozen Rescue and Sharks on Twitter
text: Nobody had a longer week than the 52 scientists, journalists and tourists waiting to be rescued from a vessel trapped in the frozen waters of East Antarctica. But for fishermen in Maine, where the shrimping season has been canceled because of a dearth of the crustaceans, it will be an even longer winter.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ and Peter Bogdanovich’s Surprise Cameo
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sunday’s episode of “The Good Wife.”

headline: Palo Alto Networks Acquires  Start-Up Morta Security
text: Palo Alto Networks has acquired Morta Security, a two-year-old Silicon Valley security start-up run by former employees of the National Security Agency and the United States Air Force.

headline: Study Ties Diabetic Crises to Dip in Food Budgets
text: Poor people with diabetes are significantly more likely to go to the hospital for dangerously low blood sugar at the end of the month when food budgets are tight than at the beginning of the month, a new study has found.

headline: The Forecast on GJ 1214b: Extremely Cloudy
text: Astronomers from the University of Chicago have used the Hubble Space Telescope to observe the weather on a “super-Earth” planet orbiting a distant star for the first time. Conditions on GJ 1214b are cloudy, with an atmosphere so thick with water vapor or some other heavy molecule that observations of the planet’s surface are nearly impossible, they report in the journal Nature. Super-Earth planets, which are larger than Earth but smaller than Neptune, are among the most common planets in the Milky Way. To compile their forecast, the team analyzed 96 hours of telescope time over 11 months.

headline: Walkabout: Winter Storms Freeze U.S. Flights; How to Rebook if You’re Stranded
text: On Monday, winter storms continued to hobble travel plans across the United States, as thousands of flights have been either canceled or delayed. There have also been flight snafus at  Kennedy International Airport, the Bronx and, sadly, Aspen. (USA Today, The New York Times)

headline: Laser Hair Removal’s Risks
text: Her first two laser hair-removal sessions went smoothly, but the third ended with burning pain that persisted for weeks, a 26-year-old Brooklyn woman recalled. Then the marks appeared: long red stripes along the backs of her legs. Over the next few months, the stripes turned dark brown.

headline: Departing Broadway Shows Leave on a Box-Office High
text: Numerous Broadway shows started 2014 with million-dollar high notes at the box office, even as some of them ended their runs.

headline: After Agreement in N.F.L. Concussion Case, Retirees Will Look at Details
text: The N.F.L. and lawyers for the more than 4,000 former players who said the league hid from them the dangers of repeated hits to the head have agreed on the details of a $760 million settlement that could determine how retirees with head trauma are compensated.

headline: 20 Winter Wines for $20
text: Eric Asimov selects 20 fantastic winter wines, all at the price point of $20, presented here in no particular order.

headline: When a (Partial) Tweet Becomes an Ad, What Are the Rules?
text: The media world gets weirder every day, but this moment still stands out as something of a stunner – the kind of thing that merits a place on the eternal timeline of “How the Internet Flipped the Media World on Its Head.”

headline: Slow Growth in Health Spending
text: Experts at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services said in a report that national spending on health care continued to be modest in 2012.

headline: A New Test for Malaria, No Blood Required
text: Rice University researchers have developed a rapid malaria test that uses a laser pulse, eliminating the need to draw blood.

headline: Your 2014 Resolution: Drink Adventurously
text: Here’s my resolution for 2014: Drink adventurously.

headline: Another Modest Rise for Health Costs
text: WASHINGTON — National health spending grew slowly for the fourth consecutive year, increasing 3.7 percent in 2012 to $2.8 trillion, the federal government said Monday. But officials disagreed over whether the Affordable Care Act or lingering effects of the recession were primarily responsible for the remarkable trend.

headline: Welcome to America. Enjoy the Free Napkins and Straws.
text: Of the many enormously gifted authors now writing about the immigrant experience — including Jhumpa Lahiri, Edwidge Danticat, Dinaw Mengestu, Chang-rae Lee, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Gish Jen — Gary Shteyngart is undoubtedly the funniest (with Junot Díaz a close runner-up).

headline: Adoption and All That Comes With It
text: Three families who have gone through the process of international adoption and know how difficult the adjustment can be.

headline: Energy Bars That Put a Chirp in Your Step
text: How do you make ground-up crickets taste good?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Britain and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Wales, Illinois, Bangladesh and Indonesia.

headline: Giving Voice, and Finding Her Own
text: The writer Sue Monk Kidd found the voice that her new book needed when she became smitten with an enslaved girl who is only a footnote to history. “I could hear Hetty in my head quite clearly,” Ms. Kidd said. “She would talk and talk and talk and talk to me.”

headline: Join Us on an Instagram Tour of Our Printing Plant
text: Updated | January 10, 2014

headline: Translating a Fellow Passenger’s Vision of Doom
text: I THINK I have flown on every airline existing on the planet at least once. Family members and people I work with call me a “risk” because I too often barely make it to flights on time. I like to maximize the time I have, so I do cut it close. On two occasions I had to get out of a taxi and walk along the highway, roller dragging behind me, briefcase tightly tucked under my arm and cellphone blasting calls for help, just to be sure I made my flight.

headline: Samsung Electronics Goes Big on Tablets
text: Samsung Electronics, the No. 1 handset maker, beat Apple to making smartphones with larger screens. Now the company wants to make an aggressive play in the tablet market with extra-large tablets.

headline: Rebel Infighting Spreads to an Eastern Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An internal war between Syrian insurgents and their onetime allies, members of a transnational jihadist group that even some fighters affiliated with Al Qaeda reject as too extreme, widened on Monday from parts of northern Syria into Raqqa, the largest city in eastern Syria that had been under the group’s control, antigovernment activists and fighters said.

headline: Asking Siri About ‘Her’
text: Updated, 7:08 p.m. | Spike Jonze wrote his near-future love story “Her” before Apple introduced Siri, but comparisons are inevitable between Samantha, the computer operating system in the movie (voiced by Scarlett Johansson), and Siri, Apple’s digital assistant, originally voiced by Susan Bennett, a suburban Atlanta voiceover actor.

headline: Growth Returns to Tech, but Profits Will Not Be So Easy
text: The good news for the information technology business is that in 2014 it should start growing at a significant rate again. The bad news? It may be less profitable.

headline: Bone-Chilling Cold a Crippling Blow to Air Travel
text: The chaos in the nation’s air travel system worsened on Monday as a wave of frigid weather forced airlines to cancel thousands more flights, stranding passengers from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Los Angeles.

headline: A Mixed Bag in H.I.V. Prevention (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: In Defense of DNA Testing (2 Letters)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: An Army of One, Enhanced by a Chip
text: Gabriel Vaughn, the commando turned human computer at the center of CBS’s melodramatic new action series “Intelligence,” has multiple operating modes. The microchip in his brain makes him a walking Google as well as a one-man surveillance state, able to distract terrorists by reciting their emails to them. He’s also his own wireless hot spot — in Tuesday’s pilot, he works the digital lock of a Pakistani interrogation cell from across the room. Where was this guy when it was taking 10 years to find Osama bin Laden?

headline: Study Raises Questions for Employer Wellness Programs
text: If you work for a big employer — or even a small one — you probably have encountered some sort of workplace wellness program. You most likely filled out a health questionnaire, which may have led to a recommendation that you attend exercise classes, quit smoking or participate in telephone coaching to help you control diabetes or asthma.

headline: A Woman Chasing Disasters, on and Off the News
text: All day long, Mary Jane Paul puts out fires: saving a friend from a possible suicide attempt, tough-talking a niece who wants to do pornography, squaring off against unscrupulous co-workers who want to damage her reputation, talking in depth about her sex life with the wife of the man she’s sleeping with.

headline: London Fashion Week: Jonathan Saunders Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Hires Black Female Cast Member
text: “Saturday Night Live” concluded its search for a black female cast member on Monday when it hired Sasheer Zamata, a young sketch comedian who has been performing in the New York area for the last four years.

headline: A Case of Bad Cop, Good-Looking Cop
text: On second thought, maybe it should be a man’s world.

headline: In Nod to History, Two Ballet Rivals Spring to Life
text: PARIS — Story ballets. Three acts, characters, costumes, scenery, melodious music. Beloved by mass audiences, they’ve been unfashionable with current, forward-thinking choreographers for years.

headline: Times Minute | Gay Marriage Blocked
text: Also on the Minute, a key step in a long-running N.F.L. concussion lawsuit and a Beethoven manuscript goes on sale.

headline: Times Minute | Gay Marriage Blocked

headline: Loft Life in a Building Once Evacuated Over Matzos

headline: Still Stuck in a Climate Argument
text: When a ship carrying scientists and adventure tourists became stuck in ice in the Antarctic late last month, climate change skeptics had a field day. On Twitter and other social media sites, they pointed out that a group whose journey was meant to highlight the effects of global warming was trapped by a substance that was supposed to be melting.

headline: The Brain, in Exquisite Detail
text: ST. LOUIS — Deanna Barch talks fast, as if she doesn’t want to waste any time getting to the task at hand, which is substantial. She is one of the researchers here at Washington University working on the first interactive wiring diagram of the living, working human brain.

headline: Israeli Official Points to ‘Incitement’ by Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — Adolf Hitler is quoted on the Facebook pages  of Palestinian Authority schools. A young girl appears on Palestinian television, describing Jews as “barbaric monkeys, wretched pigs” and the “murderers of Muhammad,” the Islamic prophet. Maps on the Facebook page of the Palestinian presidential guards do not show Israel. President Mahmoud Abbas himself embraced as “heroes” released Palestinian prisoners who killed Israelis.

text: Bookish, a struggling website started by three large book publishers less than a year ago, has been sold to Zola Books, a start-up e-book retailer, the parties announced Monday. The purchase price was undisclosed.

text: A prominent bond trader who was hired to revitalize Morgan Stanley’s trading business but whose division racked up sizable losses has left the Wall Street firm.

headline: Going Shopping, Honey? Be a Dear and Pick Up My Arsenic
text: Ah, for the days when you could stop by the local pharmacy and pick up some Radium Spray, advertised as “the new combination bug killer, disinfectant and furniture polish.” The days when you didn’t have to worry about your complexion because, as another product proclaimed, “a clear, white skin may positively be obtained by using LeFevre’s Arsenic Wafers.”

headline: A Device to Put You Into a Video Game

headline: No Barbarians at the Gate; Instead, a Force for Change

headline: The Cult Filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky on Mandalas, the Aztec Calendar and Papa Freud
text: The cult Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky practically invented the midnight movie in the early 1970s. His seminal films “El Topo” and “The Holy Mountain,” both shot in Mexico (the latter was financed by John Lennon to the tune of $1 million), were spiritual, strange and visually spectacular. Offering decadent visions of alternate realities and mystic rituals, the films became a favorite with audiences of that era, as well as with generations of (often stoned) college students ever since. The 84-year-old director, who lives in Paris, recently returned to his hometown of Tocopilla, Chile, to make “The Dance of Reality,” an autobiographical film that also manages to be a hypnotic surrealist fantasia. The film, which hits American theaters in May, received a standing ovation when it premiered at the Cannes Film Festival last year.

headline: New York, the Silicon City
text: FOR all the talk of New York’s “tale of two cities” economic divide, last week Mayor Bill de Blasio took charge of a local economy that has far outperformed the rest of the country since the financial collapse — and not just in a small corner of Manhattan, but across the city. Driven by the expansion of the technology and information sector, New York City today has more private-sector jobs than during the 2007-8 peak of the finance-driven boom years.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Returns and Sets Ratings Record
text: By any standard, public television has a major hit in “Downton Abbey,” which returned for its fourth season Sunday night in triumph, setting a record for a season premiere with 10.2 million viewers, and dwarfing most of the shows across commercial television.

headline: In Hong Kong, a Glittering Exhibition
text: Newly minted Chinese millionaires may be rushing to buy Chinese art, but the Mengdiexuan family of Hong Kong has already assembled a brilliant collection all its own: hundreds of astonishing pieces from 1500 B.C. to the 18th century.

headline: Pitching the Yankees to Fans on Broadway

text: After trailing for most of the game, Florida State stunned Auburn with a late touchdown to win its first national championship since 1999, 34-31.

headline: When Airlines Are Quick to Hit the ‘Cancel’ Button
text: THERE is reason to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the first scheduled airplane passenger flight in the United States. That flight was right on schedule. After a week like the last one, you might wonder if things have gone downhill since.

headline: On a Changing East Village Street, a Source of Continuity Fights for His Job
text: The changes unfolded over decades on Astor Place, slowly transforming the three-block stretch that has long separated the raffish expanse of the East Village and the more proper precincts to the west.

headline: High Stakes for Sudan in the South’s Conflict
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The United States has demanded negotiations. Uganda has threatened to intervene. China has called for an immediate cease-fire.

headline: Cuomo Proposes $2 Billion in Tax Cuts

headline: Howard Permut, Metro-North President, Is Stepping Down
text: After a year marred by a train collision, a worker’s death and the first passenger fatalities in Metro-North Railroad’s three-decade history, the agency’s president, Howard R. Permut, is stepping down, according to several sources with knowledge of the move.

headline: SAC Trader’s Co-Workers Were Deposed
text: The criminal insider trading case against Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, was built in part on interviews and depositions by federal authorities with several of his former colleagues at the hedge fund, according to a recent court filing.

headline: A Makeover for Maps
text: Like many designers, Eric Rodenbeck has had a long relationship with bar graphs and pie charts. He just thinks they are a little old school for today’s data-filled world.

headline: Africans Continue to Protest in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — After years of living on the margins of Israeli society, thousands of African asylum seekers flooded the streets of central Tel Aviv for a second day on Monday to protest their treatment by the Israeli authorities and to demand recognition as refugees.

headline: A Delicate Balance for the Turnaround Chief of ThyssenKrupp
text: Heinrich Hiesinger was hired as chief executive of Thyssen-Krupp in 2011 to clean up and modernize the storied German industrial giant after its disastrous attempt to go global during the financial crisis. Since then, he has been pushing through an overhaul plan that includes cutting the losses in steel while beefing up what he considers more promising businesses like elevators and factory design and construction.

headline: Jordan to Renew Appeal on Syrian Refugees
text: The ambassador to the United Nations from Jordan, the nation thrust into the rotating presidency of a polarized Security Council, said Monday that he would renew his appeal to the 15-member governing body to visit countries that shelter millions of Syrian refugees, including his own, which hosts more than 500,000 Syrians. The ambassador, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein, said he had made the request before to draw attention to the humanitarian crisis facing Syria’s neighbors, but received no response. The Council has been deadlocked on Syria, but he declined to ascribe blame. “Being on the Council hopefully will make a difference,” he said. Jordan took the rotating two-year seat after Saudi Arabia rejected it to protest what it saw as the weak stance of Western powers toward Syria and Iran, the Saudis’ chief regional rivals.

headline: Bodies of 2 American Climbers Found in Argentina
text: BUENOS AIRES — Two bodies discovered at the bottom of a 650-foot ravine on a mountain in Argentina are believed to be those of two missing American climbers, a local government official said Monday.

headline: Germany Adds Lessons in Islam to Better Blend Its Melting Pot

headline: Bangladesh’s Governing Party Wins Vote Amid Unrest
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladesh’s governing party celebrated its victory in general elections on Monday, dismissing critics who said the vote’s legitimacy was undercut by violence, low turnout and the absence of the country’s main opposition force from the ballots.

headline: Medical Marijuana in New York
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York is set to use his executive powers to loosen restrictions on the use of marijuana for medical purposes. The Legislature, where medical marijuana bills have stalled repeatedly in the State Senate, ought to expand and strengthen the governor’s effort through appropriate legislation.

headline: Rumors Fly Among Hasidim About Abducted Man’s Death
text: The mourning for Menachem Stark, a Hasidic real estate developer from Brooklyn who was kidnapped and killed last week, was not a quiet affair. As family and friends ascended the steps of his red brick rowhouse on Monday to pay their respects, they were abuzz with a single question: Why had he been killed?

headline: Unfair Phone Charges for Inmates
text: The Federal Communications Commission ended a grave injustice last fall when it prohibited price-gouging by the private companies that provide interstate telephone service for prison and jail inmates. Thanks to the F.C.C. order, which takes effect next month, poor families no longer have to choose between paying for basic essentials and speaking to a relative behind bars. The commission now needs to be on the lookout for — and crack down on, if necessary — similar abuses involving newer communication technologies like person-to-person video chat, email and voice mail.

headline: Clash of Priorities Sets Up Cuomo-de Blasio Showdown on Pre-K Push

headline: Arctic Cold Blankets Midwest, Freezing Routines
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Hildagard Omete, 36, a mother of three who has been unemployed for a year and a half, went job hunting on Monday.

headline: Will Digital Networks Ruin Us?
text: The most important book I read in 2013 was Jaron Lanier’s “Who Owns the Future?” Though it was published in May, I came to it late in the year. But this turned out to be fortuitous timing. With unemployment seemingly stalled out at around 7 percent in the aftermath of the Great Recession, with the leak of thousands of National Security Agency documents making news almost daily, with the continuing stories about the erosion of privacy in the digital economy, “Who Owns the Future?” puts forth a kind of universal theory that ties all these things together. It also puts forth some provocative, unconventional ideas for ensuring that the inevitable dominance of software in every corner of society will be healthy instead of harmful.

headline: High-Speed Train in California Is Caught in a Political Storm
text: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown of California is riding into an election year on a wave of popularity and an upturn in the state’s fortunes. But a project that has become a personal crusade for him over the past two years — a 520-mile high-speed train line from Los Angeles to San Francisco — is in trouble, reeling from a court ruling that undermined its financing, and from slipping public support and opponents’ rising calls to shut it down.

headline: Polar Vortex: Temperatures Fall Far, Fast
text: Meteorologists called it “weather whiplash” — a drop of roughly 50 degrees in a matter of hours that took temperatures from 55 in Central Park on Monday morning to a record low of 5 overnight and an expected high on Tuesday of only 10. The last time temperatures in New York fell that much in such a short time, Warren G. Harding was in the White House.

headline: $18 Billion Price Put on Effort to Block Carp
text: The most effective methods of keeping Asian carp from invading the Great Lakes via Chicago’s web of waterways could cost up to $18.4 billion and take 25 years to put in place, the federal Army Corps of Engineers concluded in a study released Monday.

headline: Jagr Receives Olympic Spot As Roster Questions Swirl

But the selections were not without controversy, and more controversy is sure to follow Tuesday, the deadline to submit Olympic rosters.

headline: Question Posed
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people have signature words. Mine is “awesome.” If I like something, it is awesome. It’s convenient to have a signature word like this, because then you don’t have to remember all the other words that mean exactly the same thing and I can then use the extra space in my brain to figure out what I’m going to eat next. That’s a far more efficient use of space, in my opinion.

headline: Test Scandal in Atlanta Brings More Guilty Pleas

Their pleas bring to 17 the number of educators who have already pleaded guilty, with a handful more in active negotiations.

headline: Run Run Shaw, Chinese-Movie Giant of the Kung Fu Genre, Dies at 106
text: Run Run Shaw, the colorful Hong Kong media mogul whose name was synonymous with low-budget Chinese action and horror films — and especially with the wildly successful kung fu genre, which he is largely credited with inventing — died on Tuesday at his home in Hong Kong. He was 106.

headline: Judge Rejects Chicago’s Ban on Gun Shops
text: CHICAGO — This city’s ban on gun shops violates the Constitution, a federal judge ruled on Monday, dealing the latest setback to politicians here who had put in place some of the nation’s strictest limits on firearms.

headline: Saying Police Fed ‘Lies,’ Witness to ’94 Murder Recants

text: Pistol Robinson, who tours on the Professional Bull Riders circuit, returned to Madison Square Garden Friday after he broke his legs in an accident in 2012.

headline: Yale Professor Died of Overdose, Official Says

headline: Halton Arp, 86, Dies; Astronomer Challenged Big Bang Theory
text: Halton C. Arp, a provocative son of American astronomy whose dogged insistence that astronomers had misread the distances to quasars cast doubt on the Big Bang theory of the universe and led to his exile from his peers and the telescopes he loved, died on Dec. 28 in Munich. He was 86.

headline: Nash Stars, but Rangers Fall to His Old Team

headline: Bronson Binger, 83, Who Saved New York Parks and Buildings, Dies
text: Bronson Binger, a New York architect and preservationist who helped wrest Union Square Park in Manhattan from drug dealers but was stymied in an effort to rebuild Wollman Rink in Central Park, died on Dec. 23 in Housatonic, Mass. He was 83.

headline: Nuclear Fuel Storage Remains Safe, Panel Members Say
text: WASHINGTON — Most members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission indicated on Monday that they considered it safe to continue storing most spent nuclear fuel in pools, even though concerns remain about potential accidents and terrorist attacks.

text: Richard N. Cohen, a member of The New York Times Company’s board throughout the 1960s, died on Thursday in Stamford, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Lineup Set for Tribute to Music of Paul Simon
text: For the last nine years Michael Dorf, the owner of City Winery, has made an annual trip uptown to raise money for music education programs by way of a tribute concert at Carnegie Hall. This year’s installment, on March 31, the 10th in Mr. Dorf’s series, honors the music of Paul Simon. The preliminary lineup for the concert, which Mr. Dorf is expected to announce on Tuesday, includes Joy Williams (of the Civil Wars), the soul singer Bettye LaVette, the singer-songwriters Bob Mould, Dan Wilson and Ben Sollee, the composer Allen Toussaint and a collaboration between the jazz singer Madeleine Peyroux and Jon Herington, the lead guitarist of Steely Dan.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 7, 2014
text: “It is clear we are increasingly reaching common ground with the Americans. No country should have an eternal enemy, neither we nor the United States.”

headline: Stealing J. Edgar Hoover’s Secrets
text: One night in 1971, files were stolen from an F.B.I. office near Philadelphia. They proved that the bureau was spying on thousands of Americans. The case was unsolved, until now.

headline: Burglars Who Took On F.B.I. Abandon Shadows
text: PHILADELPHIA — The perfect crime is far easier to pull off when nobody is watching.

headline: Payout May Come for an A.B.A. Team That Is Long Gone
text: The N.B.A. has long hoped to be released from its financial obligation to Ozzie and Daniel Silna, brothers who owned the Spirits of St. Louis in the defunct American Basketball Association.

headline: Faulty Websites Confront Needy in Search of Aid
text: MIAMI — Three months after the disastrous rollout of a new $63 million website for unemployment claims, Florida is hiring hundreds of employees to deal with technical problems that left tens of thousands of people without their checks while penalties mount against the vendor who set up the site.

headline: Detroit Pensions Are Frozen, Then Thawed
text: DETROIT — The city’s emergency manager, Kevyn D. Orr, in an unpublicized move last week, ordered that pension benefits for thousands of public employees be frozen, but said on Monday that he would delay the move to allow for a possible compromise in federally mediated talks.

headline: Charges Filed in Attack on Chinese Consulate in San Francisco
text: A Chinese citizen has been arrested in connection with the Jan. 1 arson attack at the Chinese Consulate in San Francisco, the F.B.I. said. According to a statement released by the F.B.I. in San Francisco, Yan Feng, 39, of Daly City, Calif., turned himself in to police officers on Jan. 3 and was arrested “without incident.” Mr. Feng made his first court appearance on Monday to face two federal charges, arson and damaging the property of a foreign government.

headline: Florida State Wins With Auburn-Like Comeback
text: PASADENA, Calif. — A furious second-half comeback. A 100-yard kickoff return. A touchdown drive led by a redshirt freshman quarterback that ended with 13 seconds on the clock.

headline: Senate Postpones Vote on Unemployment Benefits
text: Senate leaders on Monday night abruptly postponed a vote to take up a measure extending expired unemployment benefits. Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, was about to call the vote when the Senate’s No. 2 Republican, John Cornyn of Texas, accused him of manufacturing a political issue by holding a vote with 17 senators absent, mostly because of weather delays. Mr. Reid than gruffly asked for consent to postpone it until Tuesday morning. The measure is expected to fall to a Republican filibuster.

headline: Jameis Winston Smiles All the Way Into Seminole Lore
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Late Monday, the celebration continued in the Florida State locker room. Championship hats and T-shirts were everywhere. The room was loud and the mood light.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 5:45 P.M. (Sundance) AN EDUCATION (2009) Carey Mulligan stars as Jenny, a willful, Oxford-bound 16-year-old suffering from ennui in the London suburb of Twickenham in 1961. Peter Sarsgaard is David, the older man who introduces her to a world of art auctions and Champagne while appealing to the pretensions of her proper parents (Cara Seymour and Alfred Molina). But soon it’s apparent that David and his fabulous life aren’t quite what they seem, though that doesn’t stop Jenny from playing along. “The filmmakers themselves seem too intoxicated by the mystique of the period to take full account of the sad, bleak aspects of the story they have to tell,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama directed by Lone Scherfig, written by Nick Hornby and based on a memoir by Lynn Barber. Still, he added, in the end the film is “a pleasure — which I don’t mean entirely as a compliment.”

headline: California: Girl Declared Dead Is Transferred
text: The family of Jahi McMath, 13, who was declared brain-dead after complications from surgery last month at Children’s Hospital Oakland, said on Monday that she had been transferred to a facility that will provide her with care. The family and their lawyer declined to identify the facility, citing privacy concerns.

headline: As Donations Pour In, Aam Aadmi Party Tries to Transform Campaign Finance
text: MUMBAI — The Aam Aadmi Party, having shaken up the political order in India by its surprisingly strong showing in the Delhi state assembly elections last month, is also making an attempt to change the way the country’s political campaigns are financed.

headline: A Once-Troubled Museum Frames a Future in Los Angeles
text: After three years of tumultuous leadership, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles said it was nearing the end of a search for a new director and announced on Monday that it had reached a fund-raising milestone that would ensure it does not have to merge with another institution or face dissolution.

headline: Emerging Markets Expected to Drive Device Sales
text: LONDON – Consumers in developing countries like Brazil and China are set to continue as the main engine for sales growth for devices like smartphones and tablets in 2014, according to a research report published Tuesday.

text: In “A Lexicon of Instant Argot,” Jenna Wortham writes about Urban Dictionary, the crowdsourced online dictionary that lets anyone contribute words and definitions.

headline: Palestinian Pleasures
text: Since the mid-1980s, the visual narrative of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza has been predictable: photographs of stone-throwing teenagers confronting Israeli soldiers, refugee camps, mothers mourning children killed in conflicts, and long lines at border crossing points. Particularly dramatic variations on these visual tropes make the front pages and win awards.

headline: Should College Football Players Get Paid?
text: The 2013-14 college football bowl season ended Monday night, and even if you missed the Little Caesars Pizza Bowl or the Sheraton Hawaii Bowl, it’s hard to miss the fact that college football is big business — a multibillion-dollar industry. Top coaches receive sky-high salaries, and many college athletic departments rake in huge sums. But college football players? Zero. N.C.A.A. rules bar college athletes from earning any compensation. Is this fair?

headline: Times Minute | Rodman in North Korea
text: Also on the Minute, teaching Islam in Germany and ABC's 'Killer Women' premieres.

headline: New York Today: ‘Life-Threatening Wind Chill’
Familiar Yet Distant, With Songs and an Edge
text: Neil Young was just a few bars into an indignant old song at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, chugging a terse intro on an acoustic guitar, when he abruptly threw the emergency brake.

headline: Maersk to Sell Stake in Denmark’s Largest Retailer
text: LONDON – The Danish shipping conglomerate A.P. Moller-Maersk Group said on Tuesday that it planned to sell most of its stake in Denmark’s largest retailer for about $3 billion.

headline: Purge of Police Said to Be Move by Turkey to Disrupt Graft Inquiry
text: PARIS — About 350 police officers in Ankara, the Turkish capital, were removed from their posts overnight, Turkish news outlets reported on Tuesday, the largest single purge of the police force since a corruption investigation plunged the government into crisis last month.

headline: A Conversation With: Author Rana Dasgupta
text: The British-Indian writer Rana Dasgupta’s new book “Capital: A Portrait of Twenty-First Century Delhi” is a lyrical and haunting nonfiction account of a city that’s gripped by an intoxicating mix of ambition, money, power and rage.

headline: Carole King’s ‘You Make Me Feel’ by Emeli Sande
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Judge Accuses Spanish Princess of Money Laundering and Tax Fraud
text: PARIS — Princess Cristina, the younger daughter of King Juan Carlos of Spain, was formally accused of money laundering and tax fraud by a magistrate on Tuesday and was summoned to appear in court on March 8. She is the first close relative of a Spanish monarch in modern history to face the prospect of a criminal trial.

headline: For a Former Pizzeria Owner, It’s All Gravy
text: Last week, we published a case study about a New Jersey pizzeria owner who recently debated two different paths in the food industry: Should he enlarge his tiny restaurant to boost stagnant revenues? Or should he sell the business and start another one to manufacture his restaurant’s red sauce, which he had been selling over the counter as Jersey Italian Gravy?

headline: Intersection: Brooklyn Heights Vintage
text: Irwin Susskind, a Brooklyn Heights resident for 42 years, says he likes antique clothing and gets a lot of his clothes at thrift shops and street sales.

headline: How the Obama Administration Can Get Bluefin Tuna Off the (Wrong) Hook
text: Lee Crockett, who directs the U.S. Oceans program of The Pew Charitable Trusts, sent a compelling “Your Dot” piece on addressable problems with United States fishing regulations that are perpetuating wasteful catches of bluefin tuna on longlines set for other species. He notes that you can weigh in with a comment to the relevant agency until Friday. Here’s his post:

headline: European Cable Operator Altice Plans $1 Billion I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The European cable and cellphone operator Altice announced on Tuesday that it planned to raise up to 750 million euros, or $1 billion, through an initial public offering on the NYSE Euronext stock exchange in Amsterdam.

headline: Danglers Ahead
text: As I’ve noted ad nauseam — here, here and here, for example — danglers in their various forms are one of our most common grammatical lapses. Participle phrases, “like” comparisons, appositives and other modifying constructions generally must be adjacent to the noun or pronoun they refer to. Otherwise, they dangle — and leave a clumsy or confusing sentence.

headline: Must This Lesbian Wear a Dress to an Orthodox Synagogue?
text: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: I am a gay woman who tends to dress and identify on the masculine side. I’ll soon be attending a religious service at my extended family’s Orthodox synagogue, requiring modest attire, which means that women are not allowed to wear pants and can be denied entry. I think that as long as I dress respectfully and in the spirit of the religious mandates I should not have to compromise on my gender identity and expression. My family says that I’m being difficult and that “when in Rome …” Of course, there is no chance my relatives would dress according to a code I prescribed for an event if it conflicted with their religious identity. So why am I considered “difficult” for not compromising in the expression of my gender identity when they would be considered justified in not compromising their religious expression? — Name withheld

headline: Labor Tactic Raises Fear for France
text: PARIS — Negotiations broke down last weekend at a Goodyear tire factory scheduled for closing in northern France, so employees resorted to a brazen tactic: They kidnapped the bosses.

headline: Daily Report: Soft Smartphone Sales Lead to Decline in Samsung’s Profit
text: The world’s largest smartphone maker is facing unanticipated challenges, Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: Will Forte Is Just as Surprised as You Are
text: Will Forte was an unexpected winner with the National Board of Review; he’ll pick up his prize for best supporting actor, for his turn as a son on a road trip with his cantankerous father (Bruce Dern) in “Nebraska,” at the group’s ceremony Tuesday night.

headline: Trial Begins for Former SAC Trader
text: Prosecutors had long hoped Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, would provide the missing link in their pursuit of the hedge fund’s owner, Steven A. Cohen. Instead, the insider trading case prosecutors never thought would happen is going to trial, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Prosecutors first confronted Mr. Martoma in November 2011, asking him to cooperate in their long-running investigation of Mr. Cohen, and they have continued to press him in a number of meetings since. But Mr. Martoma has baffled officials by refusing to cooperate against the boss who fired him in 2010.

headline: Christopher Kane’s Vision for His First Store
text: LONDON — Christopher Kane is getting ready to open his first store this summer on London’s Mount Street, a shopping area that already has drawn the fashion houses of Balenciaga, Lanvin, Marc Jacobs and Christian Louboutin, as well as Nicholas Kirkwood shoes and Stephen Webster jewelry.

headline: New Yorkers Struggle to Shrug Off the Icicles
text: It was 8 degrees at 4:30 a.m., but it felt like minus 12, a fact of which Mike Peters was grimly aware. Mr. Peters, a utility worker, stood neck deep in a two-foot-by-two-foot pit hacked into the pavement of Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, the sidewalk around him slicked with ice that fringed the hole he was in with filthy icicles.

headline: Greek Police Hunt for Convicted Terrorist Who Disappeared on Furlough
text: ATHENS — The Greek authorities on Tuesday began a nationwide search for a convicted member of the dismantled November 17 group, once the country’s deadliest guerrilla organization, after he failed to report to the police during a prison furlough, fueling fears of a resurgence of political violence.

headline: Low Inflation Worries the Euro Zone
text: PARIS — Consumer prices in the euro zone barely increased last month, raising fears of deflation and putting pressure on the European Central Bank to take further action.

headline: Charges for 106 in Huge Fraud Over Disability
text: The retired New York City police officers and firefighters showed up for their psychiatric exams disheveled and disoriented, most following a nearly identical script.

headline: Image of the Day: January 7
text: The royal couple of Bhutan is on an official visit to India.

headline: JPMorgan Is Penalized $2 Billion Over Madoff
text: Updated, 9:37 p.m. | Two men who occupy coveted roles in Manhattan’s power elite, one the city’s top federal prosecutor and the other its top banker, sat down in early November to discuss a case that was weighing on them both.

text: London

headline: Lindsey Vonn’s Injured Knee Will Keep Her Out of Sochi Games
text: Lindsey Vonn sat on a stone wall at the United States Open in June, waiting for her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, to finish his second round. Four months after major knee surgery, Vonn, the defending Olympic champion in the women’s downhill, was already looking eight months ahead.

headline: Citizens Financial to Sell Chicago-Area Branches to U.S. Bancorp
text: LONDON — Citizens Financial Group, a unit of the Royal Bank of Scotland, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell 94 retail branches, as well as its small business operations in the Chicago area, to U.S. Bancorp.

headline: In Performance: Bobby Moreno of ‘Year of the Rooster’
text: In Eric Dufault’s cockfighting comedy “Year of the Rooster,” Bobby Moreno plays a menacing bird with issues named Odysseus Rex. In this scene the rooster challenges the sun to a fight. Directed by John Giampietro, the show begins performances on Jan. 9 at the Ensemble Studio Theater, where it had a well-received run last year.

headline: Karen Carpenter: Voice of a Lifetime
text: As a sidebar to the Riff column I wrote for this past weekend’s issue, which drew from the book I’m writing about my appreciation of the Carpenters’ music and the life events of mine it surrounded, here are six takes on Karen Carpenter’s voice. They include early reviews of Carpenters albums and posthumous nods from the likes of the film director Todd Haynes and the novelist Mary Gaitskill. Their range is a testament to hers.

headline: Today in Small Business: Close the S.B.A.?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Oracle Agrees to Buy Cloud-Based Service
text: Oracle announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to purchase Corente, a cloud-based services company, in a move that pushes the once web-shy technology giant further into the Internet age.

headline: In Our Pages: January 8
text: 1889: Is Waltzing Immoral?

headline: Bloomberg Failed to Meet 51% of Goals in His Last Fiscal Year in Office
text: Michael R. Bloomberg was elected mayor in 2001 in part because he promised to run the city as efficiently as he had his business. Eight years later, a federal judge let him run for a third term because, as a businessman, Mr. Bloomberg said he was best suited to steer the city through tough economic times. But by the mayor’s own measure – admittedly a high standard – his record at delivering city services by the end of his tenure seems middling.

headline: Mussina Deserves More Than ‘Almost’ From Hall
text: Scrawled on the dry-erase board by Mike Mussina’s locker one spring morning in Tampa, Fla., was this message: “Huey Bong Says Chicago Is Dusty.” The words made no sense. There had to be a story behind them.

headline: Vote in Senate Starts Talks on Extending Unemployment Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s unexpected vote on Tuesday to advance legislation extending expired unemployment benefits touched off delicate negotiations to secure final passage in the chamber, even as Republicans and Democrats warily eyed the political motives behind the efforts.

headline: Through Nearly Third of Ballots, 4 Players Are on Track for Election
text: One year after writers failed to elect any players to the Baseball Hall of Fame, four candidates are polling strongly as voters make their selections public.

headline: Bounced From Hospice
text: It didn’t come as a complete surprise when a Pennsylvania hospice told Phyllis Fine’s family last year that she was no longer eligible to receive care.

headline: Amid Accusations of Department Misconduct, Los Angeles Sheriff Will Step Down
text: LOS ANGELES — The embattled sheriff of Los Angeles, Lee Baca, announced Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the month and not seek re-election. His announcement ended weeks of speculation about his future amid federal investigations and accusations of widespread misconduct in his department.

headline: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Chevrolet Introduces Corvette Performance Data Recorder at C.E.S.
text: For this year’s Consumer Electronics Show, Chevrolet is installing technology that sounds like it belongs in a commercial airliner into the Corvette Stingray.

headline: On McQueen’s Night, Belafonte Steals the Show
text: It was an awards ceremony as glitzy and clubby as anyone could hope: Cate Blanchett regal and resplendent in a sweeping silver gown; Adèle Exarchopoulos, the winsome young French star of “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” shyly flashing her slightly buck-toothed smile; Robert Redford accepting the best actor award with avuncular ease — all rubbing shoulders with the film critics who had bestowed upon them the latest in this season’s round of awards.

headline: Pay-Per-Like
text: It turns out you can buy love, after all. Well, at least affection on social media sites. For a price as low as half a cent per click, companies, government agencies and entrepreneurs can get a small army of people in developing countries to “like” their Facebook page, endorse them on LinkedIn or follow them on Twitter, according to a recent Associated Press story.

headline: James Bond, Sherlock Holmes, Hercule Poirot: Why Do We Keep Resurrecting the Same Literary Characters?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Pankaj Mishra discuss why certain literary characters never seem to die.

headline: Lang Lang and Metallica Join an Offbeat List of Grammy Collaborators
text: When Lang Lang joined forces with Herbie Hancock at the Grammy Awards in 2008, there may have been a few raised eyebrows, but it was not really much of a stretch: Mr. Hancock’s musical language is jazz and Mr. Lang’s is classical, but both are virtuoso pianists who easily found common ground in an arrangement of Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue.”

headline: When Good Things Like the Playoffs Happen to Bad Teams Like the Knicks
text: The 11-22 Knicks, a team with Metta World Peace on its roster, might look to a team once led by World B. Free for inspiration to make the N.B.A. playoffs.

headline: Jane Campion to Lead Cannes Film Festival Jury
text: The New Zealand director Jane Campion will lead the feature film jury at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, the festival announced on Tuesday. In a statement, the organizers noted that Ms. Campion is the only female director to have won the festival’s highest honor, the Palme d’Or, for her 1993 film “The Piano,” starring Holly Hunter and Harvey Keitel.
