headline: House Financial Services Chairman to Seek Volcker Rule Change
text: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | When Zions Bank announced last month that it expected to take a big loss because of the Volcker Rule, it set off alarms all over Washington. Regulators scrambled to say they were considering changing the rule, but that was evidently not enough for some legislators.

headline: First Batch of Deadly Chemicals Exported From Syria
text: The first batch of the most dangerous materials in Syria’s banned chemical weapons stockpile was exported from the country on Tuesday, loaded onto a Danish commercial vessel in the Syrian port of Latakia in an operation overseen jointly by the United Nations and the group responsible for ensuring the arsenal’s destruction.

headline: The Pirate Bay Has a Plan to Avoid Blockades
text: The Pirate Bay’s website, which is used to download copyrighted movies, music and television shows, is often taken offline by authorities. Last year, the site changed its domain name six times, shuffling among .se, .sx, and .ac domains, after court orders to block the site.

headline: Soft Forecast by Samsung Points Out Challenges
text: TOKYO — No wonder Samsung Electronics is so busy looking for a new hit product. Its signature device, the high-end smartphone, seems to be facing unanticipated challenges.

headline: Crossing Gender Boundaries Again
text: LONDON — Noble, strong, a proud label with a feminist stance — the powerful J.W. Anderson show on Tuesday ignited the London Collections: Men and rekindled the masculine-feminine debate in 21st-century fashion.

text: Acrostic answer for January 12, 2014

headline: 200 Years of American Financial Crises
text: Shaila Dewan and I had an article on Monday about a study suggesting the American economy was doing reasonably well — at least compared with the aftermath of previous systemic financial crises. Some readers wrote me asking about what the previous crises were and how they’re defined, so here’s some more detail.

headline: The Gun Report: January 7, 2014
text: If more citizens were armed, criminals would think twice about attacking them, Detroit Police Chief James Craig said in a press conference last week. Craig, who served in the L.A.P.D. for 28 years, attributes a lack of confidence in his police department to the likelihood that someone with a concealed weapons permit will open fire, The Detroit News reported.

headline: Wolfram Wants to Connect the Internet of Things
text: If all our gadgets and gizmos are going to be connected to the Internet, and in turn one another, they’ll need to speak the same language.

headline: Obama Speaks of Better Days for Economy, With Asterisk
text: WASHINGTON — Only moments after the Senate advanced an emergency extension of unemployment insurance benefits on Tuesday, President Obama stood on an East Room stage full of people without jobs and defied the traditional logic of White House strategy that normally emphasizes good news over bad.

headline: Lamb Tagine Demands a Red
text: The sweet and savory bursts of flavor in this tagine call for a red wine that is fruity yet dry and perhaps slightly bitter. The fruitiness will echo and amplify the sweet spiciness of the dates, pomegranate seeds, cinnamon and ginger, while the dry, bitter flavors will serve to underline the savory elements and refresh the mouth between bites. Italian reds like dolcetto, Valpolicella and Montepulciano d’Abruzzo specialize in the tension between fruity and bitter flavors.

headline: Directors Guild Names Its Top 5
text: The Directors Guild of America released its nominations for best feature director today, a list notable for the inclusion of “Captain Phillips” and the omission of “Inside Llewyn Davis,” continuing that film’s guild shutout. Stay tuned for the Bagger’s analysis. For now, here’s the list:

headline: Qaeda Group Leader in Syria Suggests Islamic Court to End Rebel Infighting
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of the Nusra Front, an affiliate of Al Qaeda in Syria, on Tuesday proposed an initiative aimed at halting the worst infighting yet between the armed opponents of President Bashar al-Assad since the start of the conflict nearly three years ago.

headline: Loaded With Centers, Team Canada Passes on Some Notables
text: The pool of candidates from which the Canadian Olympic men’s hockey team was picked was like a Tim Hortons strawberry jelly filled doughnut. It was bursting with goodness at center. Given Hockey Canada’s formidable depth at the position, it was inevitable a worthy player would be squeezed out.

headline: Weight-Loss Companies Charged With Fraud
text: WASHINGTON — “Get a gym body without going to the gym” by sprinkling a powder on your food. “Significantly slim your thighs and buttocks” using an almond-scented cream. Lose up to one pound a day with just two drops under the tongue.

headline: The Real Belfort Story Missing From ‘Wolf’ Movie
text: Joel M. Cohen, a former federal prosecutor, is a partner in the New York office of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher.

headline: Bipartisan Critic Turns His Gaze Toward Obama
text: WASHINGTON — After ordering a troop increase in Afghanistan, President Obama eventually lost faith in the strategy, his doubts fed by White House advisers who continually brought him negative news reports suggesting it was failing, according to his former defense secretary Robert M. Gates.

headline: JPMorgan Settlement Documents in Madoff Case
text: Under a settlement between JPMorgan and federal prosecutors, the bank will pay $1.7 billion to victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: Turning Cheese Into a Cook’s Assistant
text: The following confession may come as a surprise from someone who makes her living as a food stylist and writer: I’m slightly intimidated by the cheese counter.

headline: Sum of Batista Parts Still Doesn’t Add Up
text: It’s hard to find a phoenix in the ashes of Eike Batista’s empire. There are real assets buried under the tycoon’s collapsed EBX Group. Even so, the group’s onetime flagship energy explorer will emerge with poor growth prospects. Investors have already priced in big things for the port and electricity arms. And too much depends on a resurgent Brazilian economy.

headline: Sandvik to Buy Texas Oil Drilling Equipment Company for $740 Million
text: LONDON — The Swedish engineering company Sandvik said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Texas oil drilling equipment company Varel International Energy Services for about $740 million.

headline: A Rare Visit With a Jailed Journalist in Egypt
text: A first-person account of a visit with Mohamed Fahmy, part of a team of journalists from Al Jazeera English who were arrested 10 days ago on accusations that their coverage of the Muslim Brotherhood constituted “false news” and “incitement,” has provided a rare glimpse into prison conditions in Egypt as the government cracks down on the Brotherhood and anyone suspected of supporting it.

headline: Republicans Respond to the Pope
text: Pope Francis has reportedly struck a chord in Washington with his critique of today’s “impersonal economy.”

headline: Tips for Travel Savings in 2014
text: Break a resolution yet? If any were travel-related, here’s some good news: In 2014, you can save while staying the traveler that you are.

headline: Travel Trends and the Year Ahead
text: Where do you plan to go in 2014? That’s a question advertisers in the travel industry are eager to find the answer to. And for a pretty good idea of that answer — and some insight into when and how to pitch you — they turn to data-marketing companies like Sojern.

headline: Obama Calls for Action on Unemployment
text: The president said Congress should pass legislation that would restore benefits to millions of people who are struggling to find work in an economy that is still recovering from a deep recession.

headline: Still Not Serious About Jobless Benefits
text: The Senate agreed on Tuesday to hold a debate on extending unemployment benefits to more than a million of the long-term jobless, clearing the first filibuster hurdle. But those benefit checks are still a long way from getting into the mailboxes of the people who desperately need them, thanks to the callousness of Republican lawmakers in both the House and Senate.

headline: The Big Chill
text: The London’s men’s collections mark the beginning of the fall 2014 shows. A look at James Long, J.W. Anderson, Jonathan Saunders and others.

headline: Idaho Ballet Troupe to Shift Directions
text: The Trey McIntyre Project, a contemporary ballet troupe based in Boise, Idaho, will mount a tour this spring that ends with six performances at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, June 25 to 29, and will then cease operating as a full-time dance troupe and will instead be a project-driven company.

headline: The Top Twelve Motherlode Posts of 2013
text: If you read that headline aloud, it’s nice and alliterative. These 12 posts represent Motherlode’s “tops” of last year — the most read, most commented-upon, most-shared, and in general, the most “Motherlode.” They’re conversation starters: Entertaining, interesting and in some cases provocative.

headline: A Backup Drive Worth Staring At
text: Backup drives are usually characterless bricks, far more function than form. But the drive maker LaCie has teamed with the French silversmith Christofle to make a drive that is pleasing to the eyes and has plenty of function to boot.

headline: The Lives They Lived: André Cassagnes
text: The creator of the Etch A Sketch gets his own treatment in the magazine’s Lives They Lived issue, which celebrates a selection of people who died in 2013.

headline: Listen Up | The Cinematic Sounds of Nashville’s Newest Indie-Pop Quintet
text: “I’m getting my world together at the moment,” says Keegan DeWitt, the 31-year-old frontman of the Nashville-based electro-pop quintet Wild Cub. Over the next two months, Wild Cub will play 23 shows across Britain and the United States, and release an expanded version of its debut album (the infectious “Youth,” streaming below) on Jan 21. Meanwhile, DeWitt — the band’s tireless songwriter — will squeeze in a trip to the Sundance Film Festival, where he scored two films in this year’s program. It’s a whirlwind start to 2014 for a band that formed less than two years ago, but DeWitt, who moved to Nashville from Brooklyn in 2008, has never been one to keep a light schedule.

headline: Entrepreneurial Lessons From ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’
text: I went to see “The Wolf of Wall Street,” and I think Martin Scorsese, the famed director, just nailed how business cultures are created in fast-growth companies. He took it over the top with the Hollywood glamour, vulgarity and corruption, but he got a lot of it right — I just wish he could have left out the corruption.

headline: Will Hermes to Write Lou Reed Biography
text: Farrar, Straus and Giroux has signed the Rolling Stone writer Will Hermes to write “Lou: A New York Life,” a biography of Lou Reed.

headline: Airline and Rail Travelers Stranded During Severe Cold Weather
text: As the bitter cold moved east and continued to keep much of the center of the country in a deep freeze, travelers found themselves stranded at airports, on Amtrak trains and in their driveways.

headline: Revival for a Sauce That Never Left
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Comeback sauce, a spicy, versatile remnant of a bygone South, is making something of, well, a comeback. And it is reminding Southerners of an old connection to Hellenic culture.

headline: Samuel McCoy to Be Chelsea Opera’s Music Director
text: Chelsea Opera — a small Manhattan opera company that calls itself “the little opera company that could” — has appointed Samuel McCoy as its new music director and principal conductor. For his first outing in the position, Mr. McCoy, who has worked on contemporary operas and classics, will conduct a production of Aaron Copland’s “The Tender Land” at Chelsea Opera in June, said Lynne Hayden­-Findlay, who formed the company in 2004 with Leonarda Priore.

headline: Make Music New York to Host Monthly Talks
text: Make Music New York continues to expand. It began in 1989, as a one-day event, held every year on June 21, the summer solstice, with performances by musicians and ensembles of every stylistic stripe at parks, atriums, street corners and concert halls all over New York City, from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.  Then, in 2011, inspired by Phil Kline’s annual “Unsilent Night” boombox parade, a winter solstice (Dec. 21) event was added, with composers and performers parading through the streets making music.

headline: Twitter Co-Founder Unwraps Jelly, a Visual Social Query App
text: Updated, 6:26 p.m. | Added comments from an interview with Biz Stone, Jelly’s chief executive.

headline: Broadway’s ‘Glass Menagerie’ Recoups Investment
text: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of “The Glass Menagerie” has recouped its $2.6-million capitalization, the play’s producers announced on Tuesday. Only about 25 percent of Broadway shows turn a profit for their investors, and when plays do so, they usually feature Hollywood celebrities in the cast. While “The Glass Menagerie” has one such star, Zachary Quinto (the recent “Star Trek” movies) as Tom, the play’s box office has also benefited from strong buzz about the quality of the production and the performances of its four actors, particularly two-time Tony Award winner Cherry Jones as the mother, Amanda Wingfield. Directed by Tony winner John Tiffany (“Once”), “The Glass Menagerie” began performances at the Booth Theater in September and is scheduled to end its run on Feb. 23.

headline: 308 Thai Officials Face Anticorruption Inquiry
text: BANGKOK — The anticorruption authorities in Thailand announced Tuesday that they were opening investigations of 308 lawmakers, most of them from the governing party, on suspicion of “malfeasance in office,” in connection with a constitutional amendment that was later ruled by a court to have been enacted illegally.

headline: Gluten-Free Ramen, Pullet Eggs and More
text: To Indulge: Sweet Canelés for All Tastes

headline: A Case for the iPhone Attracts Some Unwanted Attention
text: Typo is one of a vast array of iPhone cases introduced this week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Despite its name, it is intended to improve typing accuracy by providing users with a physical keyboard.

headline: Making the Restaurant Part of the Family
text: ROUEN, France — At first glance, Benjamin Lechevallier would seem to be the very soul of the ambitious, tireless French chef.

headline: In Westchester, Picturesque Prosperity
text: When Hatsy and Scott Vallar were living in Manhattan with toddler sons overtaking their three-bedroom Upper East apartment, they knew it was time to move to a place where the children could spend more time outdoors. So in 1997, they moved to Bedford, a rural community of narrow winding two-lane highways and many unpaved side roads, paying $1 million for a four-bedroom six-and-a-half-bath colonial on 4.25 acres near several horse farms.

headline: The Contradictions of Liberal Populism
text: My Sunday column, on Bill De Blasio and the new liberal crusade against inequality, took note of one of the internal tensions facing 21st century liberal populism: The movement tends to succeed politically when it mobilizes the upper middle class against the super-rich, but then its dependence on those same upper middle class votes significantly limits its ability to raise taxes and expand transfers to the extent that a true war on after-tax inequality would probably require.

headline: Economic Inequality in America: Developing a New War on Poverty
text: Overview |  How big of an issue is poverty in America today, and what are the most effective ways to address it? Is America still the great land of opportunity — where if you work hard and play by the rules, you can make it?

headline: Empire Diner Opens in Chelsea
text: Headliner

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, South Sudan, Indonesia and New York.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o’s Bonding Moment and Steve McQueen’s Union Roots
text: New York was shivering on the outside, but all was warm and cozy at midday Tuesday inside the plush 21 Club, where a lunch was held to honor the female stars of “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Overhaul of Israel’s Economy Offers Lessons for United States
text: Americans may talk about income inequality, but Israel has done something about it.

headline: New York Critics’ Group Apologizes for Heckling, but Armond White Says He Didn’t Yell Anything
text: Updated, 6:42 p.m. |  New York film circles were abuzz early Tuesday with the spectacle that threatened to overshadow the awards ceremony held the previous night: an outburst at the New York Film Critics Circle awards.

headline: Tax Break as a Not-So-Secret Weapon
text: The tax break wars are heating up again, as New Jersey aggressively pushes a revamped program to encourage businesses to stay or move within its borders.

headline: L.A. Sheriff to Retire
text: In an emotional statement, the embattled Los Angeles County sheriff, Lee Baca, said that he would not seek re-election to a fifth term and that he planned to retire at the end of the month.

headline: Tosca Cafe
text: Inside the meticulously restored restaurant in San Francisco.

headline: Revenge Takes on Life of Its Own
text: James Scott’s debut novel, “The Kept,” opens on a scene of massacred children. It’s daring and bleak in a novel whose daring is found in its bleakness. Elspeth Howell, a midwife, returns to her family’s remote homestead in far upstate New York in a snowstorm to find four of her five children and her husband shot dead and left where they fell. Her fifth child, Caleb, has been hiding in a closet since three men came and gunned down the Howells. Thinking his mother is one of the gunmen returning to finish him off, Caleb shoots her, wounding her badly. If you’re expecting things to look up, read no further. What follows is an unrelentingly somber story of revenge played out across an austere landscape.

headline: Oldies Done in New Palettes
text: Given the plentitude of chamber music series in New York, it is easy to take low-visibility offerings for granted, despite the consistency, excellence and affordability of their programs. I had not been to a concert by the Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players in a long while when I attended Monday afternoon’s program at Good Shepherd Church. I will not let so much time slip by again.

headline: A Rite of Sexual Submission: Bed to Book to Off Broadway
text: Rehearsal rooms are not places of great sensuality, unless your tastes run toward fluorescent lighting, groaning heating pipes and bathroom cubicles with cracked toilets.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Returns to a Record Audience
text: “Downton Abbey” has become event television.

headline: A Dream Fight Made Real Onstage
text: The sweat, the combativeness and even the body blows feel mighty real, but the fight itself is pure fantasy in “Tyson vs. Ali,” a sleek mixed-media meditation on a boxing bout that never was, and never could have been. Currently bobbing and weaving around a simulated ring at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, the production is conceived and directed by Reid Farrington, who deftly splices together video footage and live performance to offer a prismatic take on a theoretical matchup of Mike Tyson and Muhammad Ali, two of the great names in boxing history.

headline: This Place Looks Familiar
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the man swayed into Tosca Cafe with the distant yet determined expression of a bar-stool poet 50 years late for a drink with Jack Kerouac, I thought he had to be a ringer. When he listed past the gleaming, monumental espresso machine and produced a bottle of off-brand tequila from his jacket, I was sure of it. Ken Friedman and April Bloomfield, the New York restaurateurs who converted this landmark dive bar into an Italian restaurant last year, had clearly put him on the payroll to keep up Tosca’s reputation as a haven where unmoored eccentrics raise glasses with actors, go-go dancers, politicians, heavy-metal drummers, cops and Russian ballerinas.

headline: Boston Globe Hires Journalist to Focus on Catholicism
text: The Boston Globe announced on Tuesday that it would hire John L. Allen Jr., a journalist for The National Catholic Reporter, and explore starting a free-standing publication dedicated to Catholicism.

headline: A Cash Prize as Elusive as ...
text: It’s time once again to ponder that age-old philosophical question: Do sasquatches have access to televisions? Because if they do, and they channel surf their way to a new Discovery show called “Lone Target,” no one is going to win the $10 million.

headline: Andrea L. Olshan
text: Ms. Olshan, 33, is the chief executive of Olshan Properties, formerly known as Mall Properties, or M.P.I., a private real estate company that owns and manages retail, residential, office and hotel properties in 11 states, among them the mixed-use Parkchester development in the Bronx.

headline: Taking Along iCloud Calendars
text: Q. Our family life depends on Apple shared calendars. If I go AWOL and get a non-Apple portable device, can I get access to the calendar? For that matter, can I get access to the calendar on a Windows laptop?

headline: The Point Men for Public School
text: The Public School design duo was at Barclays Center in Brooklyn last month for an N.B.A. game between the Knicks and Nets. It was the first quarter, and they were drinking beer and eating hot dogs.

headline: London Fashion Week: James Long Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: With Vonn Out, Other Olympians May Shine Brighter
text: Admit it: You were dying to watch that 17-day made-for-TV “Lindsey & Tiger” special otherwise known as the Sochi Winter Olympics. Just think of NBC’s full-sepia treatment as Lindsey Vonn zoomed past the finish line and into the arms of her ear-muffed boyfriend, Tiger Woods.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg to Leave Lincoln Center
text: Diane von Furstenberg, the president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, puts on one of the splashiest shows in the tents at Lincoln Center, with a front row of media stars and celebrity friends. So her decision to leave the space amid complaints about its atmosphere suggested the leader might be abandoning ship.

headline: The End of the Much-Debated B.C.S.
text: PASADENA, Calif. — The Bowl Championship Series, a postseason system that drew the ire of college football coaches, players and fans while enriching bowl directors and the establishment that profited from it, died Monday night after Florida State topped Auburn, 34-31, in the final championship game.

headline: The Missing Piece in the War on AIDS
text: One afternoon last spring I met a farmer named Salomão in a rural community in Southern Mozambique.  Salomão was in his late 30s, living with both HIV and tuberculosis, and very poor, with few possessions aside from the clothing on his back, some cooking pots, and his hoe.   In late March, he walked without shoes for eight hours in the pouring rain so that he could pick up his month’s supply of drugs.  When he got to the health center, he was tired and weak.  He was then humiliated and turned away because his health card was wet.  And in the process, Salomão’s HIV status – something that should be held in complete confidentiality – was disclosed to everyone who happened to be in the crowded waiting area at the outpatient clinic.   Upon returning to his village, Salomão was shunned by his family and many of his neighbors.  Without his medicine, his health deteriorated rapidly.  By May, he had developed several abscesses on his leg.  He resisted returning to the health facility.  Within a few weeks Salomão died at home, alone, and in silence.

headline: What the JPMorgan Settlement Means
text: JPMorgan Chase’s latest criminal settlement shows that prosecutors are becoming more creative about getting money to victims of a fraud rather than just putting it into federal coffers.

headline: Who’s Helped — and Hurt — by the Directors’ Nods
text: The Directors Guild of America has historically been a fairly good predictor of both the eventual best director Oscar nominees, and a harbinger of the best picture field – that is, until the last few years. Generally, the guild matches up with the Oscar directing category in four of its five slots; last year, however, when the directors branch of the Academy threw a loop by not nominating Ben Affleck or Kathryn Bigelow, both guild honorees, that stat went out the window.

headline: That Uncertain Muse and Witness, Memory
text: “Blow out your candles, Laura,” Tom says. But she doesn’t.

headline: Goldman Reshuffles an Investment Banking Group
text: Goldman Sachs is shaking up its technology, media and telecommunications investment banking group, according to internal memos.

headline: The Flu Hits, and Anna Netrebko Withdraws
text: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko has withdrawn from the first two performances of Donizetti’s “L’Elisir d’Amore” at the Metropolitan Opera this month because she is suffering from the flu, the opera house announced Tuesday.

headline: Scene City: ‘Girls’ Grows Up in Season 3
text: Lena Dunham and the rest of the “Girls” cast celebrate the new season with family and fashionable friends.

headline: Recalling a Disaster Without Uttering a Word
text: This probably isn’t the kind of compliment the filmmakers want to hear in the week of its theatrical release, but “The Great Flood,” a beautiful exploration of the Mississippi River flood of 1927, almost demands to be enjoyed using high-quality headphones. Its soundtrack is an artwork in its own right, one worth savoring as you would a fine recording.

headline: An Artist Who Turns Music and Movies Into Soundless Works
text: On Thursday, the Berlin-based artist Gregor Hildebrandt will fill both floors of the Galerie Perrotin on the Upper East Side with his first solo show in New York, “Die Geschichte lauft uber uns” (“The Story Runs Across Us”). Music and film weave through his installations, sculptures and works on canvas, but the experience of the exhibition is completely visual: there is no sound.

headline: Sale of Tear Gas to Bahrain Blocked Over Concerns Raised by Rights Groups
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 8:43 a.m. | Citing concerns raised by rights groups about the misuse of tear gas by the riot police in Bahrain, South Korea’s government has decided to block the export of millions of canisters of the gas to the kingdom, The Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

headline: Slowly, Asia’s Factories Begin to Turn Green
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — When Intel went about setting up its chip factory in Vietnam, it found an oddity: Local laws did not govern every aspect of the building.

headline: Drawing Conclusions From Sony’s Early Lead in the Console Race
text: Sony’s new video game console outsold Microsoft’s by a healthy margin last year. But why?

headline: Sudan Denies Talking to South About Creating a Joint Force
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudan on Tuesday backed away from its assertion that it had held discussions with South Sudan about creating a joint force to safeguard oil fields in the South, the economic lifeblood for both countries that is being threatened by the fighting in South Sudan.

headline: Responding to Readers on ‘The House Edge’
text: In response to an invitation to readers, David Kocieniewski, a business reporter for The New York Times, and Gretchen Morgenson, an assistant business editor and columnist, are answering questions about their four-part series, The House Edge, which examined the challenges posed by Wall Street’s influence over markets and the prices consumers pay.

headline: Yahoo Unveils New Digital Magazines and Ad Products
text: At the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, long lines of people swerved around the blackjack tables, skirting the slot machines and doubling back around. No, people were not waiting to see the latest drones or curvy televisions. They were waiting to hear Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, speak about updates for a company that was once left for dead.

headline: The Bitter Debate Over Gun Laws
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Agency, a Spinoff, Will Aim Its Message at a Hispanic Audience
text: IT is hard to overstate the increasing influence of the growing Hispanic population upon Madison Avenue. Examples just so far this week include a ratings spurt on Monday night for “The Bachelor,” with its first Latin lead, Juan Pablo Galavis; special programming on Tuesday on ESPN Deportes, the Spanish-language version of ESPN, to celebrate its 10th anniversary; an announcement of a contest for youngsters to win a trip to the Copa Coca-Cola Soccer Camp during the 2014 World Cup in Brazil; and the debut on ABC on Tuesday night of a series, “Killer Women,” that is based on a drama from Argentina and includes Sofia Vergara among its executive producers.

headline: First Witness in Martoma Trial Took Detour to Waffle Business
text: When Timothy W. Jandovitz left SAC Capital Advisors after five years of grinding out financial numbers and analyzing companies, he decided to try his hand at pork belly and burrata-filled Belgian waffles.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Maine: Man Pleads Guilty in Tusk Smuggling Case
text: A Tennessee collector of wildlife curios has pleaded guilty to three federal charges for his role in illegally bringing more than 100 narwhal tusks into the United States. According to documents filed in Federal District Court on Tuesday, the collector, Jay G. Conrad, 67, admitted to one count each of conspiracy to smuggle goods, conspiracy to launder monetary instruments and smuggling. He was accused of working with co-defendants including Andrew J. Zarauskas of New Jersey and Gregory Robert Logan of Canada on a decade-long smuggling operation that brought the ivory tusks from Canada into the United States through Maine, in violation of the Marine Mammal Protection Act. No sentencing date has been set. Mr. Zarauskas is to be tried next month. Mr. Logan was arrested last month in Canada.

headline: Michigan: New Mayor Detroit Asks Detroit Residents To Stay
text: Mike Duggan delivered his first public address as the new mayor of Detroit on Tuesday, asking frustrated residents not to move out of the bankrupt city before giving his fledgling administration time to improve neighborhood services. “Give us six months to prove that we can turn things around,” said Mr. Duggan, who took office on Jan. 1. “Just push the pause button and don’t leave that house yet.” He said the success of his tenure as mayor would be determined by whether Detroit’s population — which has dropped by more than a million since 1950 — increases over the next four years.

headline: How Many Cheers for Cheerios?
text: Well, a major and venerable American brand has gone and announced that it contains no genetically modified organisms (G.M.O.'s). Cheerios is G.M.O.-free! And will soon be labeled “Not Made With Genetically Modified Ingredients.”

headline: In Iraqi City Under Siege, More Support for Militants Than Officials
text: BAGHDAD — On a good day, the drive from Falluja to Baghdad takes less than an hour. On Sunday morning, with his city under siege, its morgue filled with bodies and people running low on food, water and generator fuel, Osama al-Ani packed his family of seven into his car and set off for the capital. The trip, with its constant checkpoints and vehicle searches, took more than 12 hours, he said.

headline: What’s the Matter With Kansas’ Schools?
text: KANSAS, like every state, explicitly guarantees a free public education in its Constitution, affirming America’s founding belief that only an educated citizenry can preserve democracy and safeguard individual liberty and freedom.

headline: Ford Chief Out of Running to Lead Microsoft
text: SEATTLE — Alan Mulally, the chief executive of Ford, said on Tuesday that he would not leave the automaker for Microsoft, ending months of speculation that he was a leading candidate to run the tech giant.

headline: Ethiopian Migrants Expelled by Saudis Remain in Limbo Back Home
text: LEGUAMA, Ethiopia — Mohammed Jemal left Ethiopia two years ago. He wanted to be independent, to support his family — and to escape the mockery of having squandered a big chance for a better life.

headline: Franky Cam
text: Franky, an easygoing 17-year-old tortoise, sauntered down an aisle of Lou's Pet Shop in Grosse Pointe, Mich., while broadcasting his movements online via Dropcam.

headline: Webcams See All (Tortoise, Watch Your Back)
text: In the Sahara, the African spurred tortoise lives for about a century. Thanks to modern technology, one named Franky has a shot at immortality.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,288 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Additional U.S. Battalion Going to South Korea
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon announced Tuesday that 800 soldiers, about 40 Abrams battle tanks and 40 armored infantry fighting vehicles would be deployed to South Korea next month as part of the Defense Department’s “rebalance” of forces across Asia and the Pacific.

headline: Mass Arrests During ’04 Convention Leave Big Bill and Lingering Mystery
text: The final costs of settling civil rights lawsuits brought by hundreds of people who were swept up in mass arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention — many of whom were breaking no laws whatsoever — are likely to be well over $35 million.

headline: What Happened to Transparency?
text: When President Obama took office in 2009, he promised an “unprecedented level of openness in government.” In a memo issued the day after his inauguration, he wrote, “The government should not keep information confidential merely because public officials might be embarrassed by disclosure, because errors and failures might be revealed, or because of speculative or abstract fears.”

headline: U.S. Military Helicopter Crashes on Coast of England
text: LONDON — An American military helicopter crashed on the coast of eastern England on Tuesday, and all four people aboard were believed to have been killed, the authorities said.

headline: New Leader at Billboard Sees Future in Visuals
text: Janice Min, who gave The Hollywood Reporter a renewed relevance by transforming the daily trade paper into a much-read weekly magazine and website, is about to see if that formula can put Billboard, the embattled music industry trade publication, back on the charts.

headline: Stuck Ships Break Free Near Antarctica
text: Two ships immobilized by ice floes near Antarctica broke free on Tuesday, news agencies reported. The Chinese icebreaker Xue Long was trapped Friday after its helicopter evacuated 52 passengers from a Russian research ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, that had been icebound since mid-December. The BBC reported Tuesday that shifting winds had opened a path for the research ship to free itself. Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency, reported Tuesday evening that the Xue Long was also working its way out of the pack ice a short distance away. At the request of Australian maritime authorities last week, a United States Coast Guard icebreaker has been making its way toward the two ships, but was still several days away.

headline: Steep Penalties Taken in Stride by JPMorgan Chase
text: To settle a barrage of government legal actions over the last year, JPMorgan Chase has agreed to penalties that now total $20 billion, a sum that could cover the annual education budget of New York City or finance the Yankees’ payroll for 100 years.

headline: Biography Casts Critical Light on Fox News Chief
text: Roger Ailes was so eager to influence national politics that in the run-up to the 2012 presidential election, he told fellow Fox News executives point-blank: “I want to elect the next president.”

headline: Pakistani Court Panel Weighs if Musharraf Is Fit for Trial
text: ISLAMABAD — A special court panel was shown on Tuesday a medical report on the former Pakistani military ruler Pervez Musharraf and began to determine whether he could be excused from attending treason proceedings against him. He was rushed to a military hospital for what was described as a sudden heart problem five days ago.

headline: Not Just About Us
text: Every day the headlines from the Arab world get worse: An Al Qaeda affiliate group, aided by foreign fighters, battles with seven different homegrown Syrian rebel groups for control of the region around Aleppo, Syria. The Iranian Embassy in Beirut is bombed. Mohamad Chatah, an enormously decent former Lebanese finance minister, is blown up after criticizing Hezbollah’s brutish tactics. Another pro-Al Qaeda group takes control of Fallujah, Iraq. Explosions rock Egypt, where the army is now jailing Islamists and secular activists. Libya is a mess of competing militias.

headline: Palestinians Corner Jewish Settlers During Clash in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — A confrontation between a group of Jewish settlers and Palestinian villagers in the West Bank on Tuesday ended when Palestinian officials handed the settlers, who had been surrounded by other Palestinians, over to Israeli forces.

headline: Arctic Blast Proves Unwelcome Novelty, Especially Across South
text: ATLANTA — The fountains turned into crystal still-lifes in Savannah, Ga. Ducks walked forlornly on iced-over swimming holes in southern Arkansas. School bus doors froze open in Beaufort, S.C. And pipes froze all over as Southerners, who are not born or made for temperatures in the Minnesota digits, had to consider things they typically take for granted.

headline: China’s Shadow Banking Problem
text: China’s top officials appear to be moving to address the risks posed by a fast-growing-but-shadowy part of the country’s financial system. The Chinese cabinet is seeking to increase government oversight of lending by companies that currently face little or no supervision, according to news reports based on an official document that was written last month.

headline: Temperatures Plunge in the East and South
text: The record-breaking polar air that has frozen the Midwest spread to cities from Boston to Nashville.

headline: Germany: $8.2 Million in Drugs Found Among Fruit
text: Supermarket employees in Berlin and Brandenburg State were stunned when they started unpacking banana boxes and found hundreds of pounds of cocaine, worth about $8.2 million, the police said Tuesday. Seven crates unloaded on Monday contained an estimated 309 pounds of cocaine, the second-largest drug find in Berlin in 35 years, the police said. The crates were part of a shipment of more than 1,100 boxes from Colombia to a fruit wholesaler in Berlin. Olaf Schremm, a senior police officer, told reporters that drug smugglers had probably made a “logistical error.”

headline: Doubts Linger Over N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
text: The ink on the N.F.L.’s proposed $760 million settlement had barely dried Monday before ex-players and their lawyers started sifting through hundreds of pages for clues about how the payouts and medical benefits will be distributed and whether there will be enough money for the claims brought by some of the 18,000 retirees.

headline: Venezuela: Death of Beauty Queen in Robbery Rattles Country
text: A soap opera actress and former Miss Venezuela, Mónica Spear, was shot to death by robbers after her car broke down on a highway, the authorities said Tuesday. Her ex-husband was also killed, and their 5-year-old daughter was wounded. Venezuela has one of the highest rates of violent crime in the region, but the killing of Ms. Spear, 29, provoked a particularly sharp outcry. President Nicolás Maduro called it “a massacre.” Ms. Spear was crowned Miss Venezuela in 2004 and was a soap opera star on the Spanish-language channel Telemundo. A United States citizen, she was in Venezuela on vacation, local media reported. A police official said five suspects had been arrested.

headline: Bridging the Compassion Gap
text: What’s going on with John Boehner, the speaker of the House?

headline: Iran: In Thaw, British Lawmakers Visit
text: A delegation of British lawmakers led by former Foreign Minister Jack Straw visited Iran on Tuesday, the first such trip in years and a reflection of the slowly improving ties between the two countries. Relations plunged near the breaking point in 2011 after Iranian protesters stormed the British Embassy. Mr. Straw was scheduled to meet with Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, during the four-day visit. It comes a month after Britain’s new envoy to Iran, Ajay Sharma, traveled to Iran, the first diplomatic visit by a British official since 2011.

headline: Judge Blocks Part of N.Y.U.’s Plan for Four Towers in Greenwich Village
text: A state judge on Tuesday unexpectedly blocked about half of New York University’s large and hotly debated expansion plan to build four towers in the school’s leafy and largely low-scale Greenwich Village neighborhood.

headline: The Lessons of Physical Therapy
text: TODAY, the anniversary of the shooting in Tucson that put a bullet through my head and killed six of my constituents, is when I make my annual resolutions.

headline: New York State Supreme Court Ruling on N.Y.U. Proposed Expansion
text: Read the full ruling from the New York State Supreme Court.

headline: Beautifying Abbey Road
text: In real life, Americans may keen about income inequality. But on TV, they’re keen for it.

headline: Pregnant, and Forced to Stay on Life Support
text: FORT WORTH — The diagnosis was crushing and irrevocable. At 33, Marlise Munoz was brain-dead after collapsing on her kitchen floor in November from what appeared to be a blood clot in her lungs.

headline: Saudis Back Syrian Rebels Despite Risks
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — On his eighth trip to fight with the rebels in Syria, in August, Abu Khattab saw something that troubled him: two dead children, their blood-soaked bodies sprawled on the street of a rural village near the Mediterranean coast. He knew right away that his fellow rebels had killed them.

headline: The Cold This Time
text: By now, we all know that a polar vortex is a cyclone of frigid air centered on the Arctic. A rogue sweep of that air moved south and pushed the temperature in Central Park in New York City to a 118-year low of 5 degrees on Tuesday morning; records were similarly broken in scores of other American and Canadian cities; and flights were canceled across North America. Yet winter has barely begun, and, even before the icy cold of this week, it had already treated the eastern United States to snowstorms, southwest Britain to monster waves and northern Europe to unusually nasty weather.

headline: Uncertainty in Utah as Appeals Process Plays Out Over Gay Marriage
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Ever since it was a distant Western territory straining for statehood, Utah has been entwined in battles over what makes a marriage.

headline: For Some Tenants, Only Thing Heating Up Is a Temper
text: In her chilly living room in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn, Vernaline McFarlane on Tuesday read the most recent dates from a spiral notebook she has kept since October.

headline: Adult Beverages Not Supplied
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Sam Ezersky is one of our younger constructors and, according to his notes below, today’s puzzle was his first-ever submission to The New York Times. You can kind of tell from the theme, but since I happen to like the show that is highlighted in his theme, I’ll give that a pass.

headline: Preventing Civil War in South Sudan
text: Given the critical role the U.S. and other foreign entities played in the creation of South Sudan, what is their responsibility as the region faces another civil war?

headline: Cuomo, Joined by Biden, Details Disaster Aid Plans
text: ALBANY — Drawing on lessons from Hurricane Sandy, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo outlined on Tuesday how New York would spend more than $16 billion in federal disaster aid on items like high-tech weather stations and seals for entrances to subway stations.

headline: Bothersome Ankles Sideline Nets’ Deron Williams
text: Even while riding a three-game winning streak, the Nets seem unable to avoid injuries that have undercut their recent success.

headline: Body of a Brooklyn Landlord Is Discovered in a Basement
text: The nearly decapitated body of a Brooklyn businessman was discovered early on Tuesday in the basement of a building he owned, police officials said.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 8, 2014
text: “I get angry with the state. What business did they have delving into these areas? Why are they practicing medicine up in Austin?”

headline: Long Island Man Gets $3.4 Million for 17 Years in Jail
text: Martin H. Tankleff, a Long Island man who served 17 years in prison for murdering his parents before a state appeals court vacated his conviction, will receive more than $3 million under a settlement of his wrongful imprisonment lawsuit.

headline: Seeking Clues to Gangs and Crime, Detectives Monitor Internet Rap Videos
text: In the streets of Brownsville, Brooklyn, a local rap artist named Cuame Nelson was recording a new music video when someone called out his stage name.

headline: Corruption Trial Begins for a Bronx Assemblyman
text: At some point during his first term as an assemblyman, Eric A. Stevenson made a portentous decision: He decided “to sell official actions in exchange for thousands of dollars in cash,” a federal prosecutor told a Manhattan jury on Tuesday.

headline: Felton Returns, and Suddenly Surging Knicks Win Again
text: The Knicks found a winning formula in Texas, and brought it home to New York — barely. After leading by 17 points late in the third quarter at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks nearly blew it Tuesday night. The Detroit Pistons almost stole a game that would have meant another night of misery for Knicks fans.

headline: De Blasio Fills Press Positions With Past Campaign Officials
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who rose to prominence as a behind-the-scenes caretaker of other politicians’ images, unveiled the new guardians of his own public persona on Tuesday, appointing a fleet of City Hall press aides.

headline: More Charges in Scheme to Defraud a Charity
text: Two additional former executives of one of the largest and most respected nonprofit social service agencies in the region were charged on Tuesday in connection with what prosecutors describe as a long-running scheme to defraud the organization of more than $7 million.

headline: Late Lobbying for Support as Speaker Election Nears
text: With little time left in the contest to choose a new speaker of the New York City Council, the forces allied with Mayor Bill de Blasio were working furiously into the night on Tuesday to squelch any remaining chance that his handpicked candidate, Melissa Mark-Viverito, could be defeated.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 7, 2014
Record-Low Belt
text: Records were set across the East and South on Tuesday.

headline: When the Loss of a Job Feels Like the End of Life
text: Neighborhood streets were once impromptu meeting places where Gail Dubins took immense pleasure conversing with the many students and parents she encountered. These days, those streets seem off-limits. Ms. Dubins, 53, has no desire to be seen, much less to fraternize in her Brooklyn neighborhood. Her social instincts have been stifled by her shame.

headline: On-Court Levity Puts J. R. Smith Back on the Defensive
text: J. R. Smith had no reason to do it, but that had never stopped him before.

headline: Jaromir Jagr a Last Link to a Golden Generation of Czech Hockey
text: NEWARK — Jaromir Jagr, who will turn 42 during his fifth Winter Olympics next month, is part of a golden generation of Czech hockey that is slowly passing into history. Yet the fact that Jagr is still being looked to as one of his country’s top players headed to Sochi says a lot about the state of the game in his country.

headline: Elizabeth Jane Howard, Novelist of Mid-Century British Life, Dies at 90
text: Elizabeth Jane Howard, a novelist known for her multivolume saga of a 20th-century English family and for her amorous entanglements with some of the 20th century’s foremost literary men, died on Thursday at her home in Bungay, England. She was 90.

headline: Report Finds More Flaws in Digitizing Patient Files
text: Although the federal government is spending more than $22 billion to encourage hospitals and doctors to adopt electronic health records, it has failed to put safeguards in place to prevent the technology from being used for inflating costs and overbilling, according to a new report by a federal oversight agency.

headline: How Being Heavy or Lean Shapes Our View of Exercise
text: Overweight women’s brains respond differently to images of exercise than do the brains of leaner women, a sophisticated new neurological study finds, suggesting that our attitudes toward physical activity may be more influenced by our body size than has previously been understood.

headline: Policies That Discourage Full-Time Work

headline: Anbar’s Tribes Want to Join Other Provinces Against ‘Iranian Occupation’
text: As my colleagues Yasir Ghazi and Tim Arango reported, the fighting in Anbar province has exacerbated the animosity among Sunni civilians and tribal militias toward the Shiite dominated government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: Sneaky Judges Find Their Pianist
text: The Polish pianist Rafal Blechacz suspected nothing when, while preparing for three concerts in Switzerland in late 2012, he was bombarded with questions by the artistic director of the Lucerne Symphony Orchestra. He had no clue that a recital he gave that year in Schenectady, N.Y., was closely scrutinized and discussed and debated by a select few listeners.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay) must reveal details about the attack on her by the psychopath William Lewis (Pablo Schreiber, above with Ms. Hargitay) — and cope with post-traumatic stress disorder — when he maneuvers to continue his winning streak at trial. In “Chicago P.D.,” a spinoff of “Chicago Fire,” created by Dick Wolf and Matt Olmstead, at 10, Jason Beghe stars as Hank Voight, the ruthless leader of the Chicago Police Department’s elite Intelligence Unit, created to deal with organized crime, drug trafficking and high-profile murders. His mantra: “You tell me the truth so I can lie for you.” Jon Seda, Jesse Lee Soffer, Sophia Bush, Elias Koteas, Amy Morton and Patrick John Flueger round out the cast. “ ‘Chicago P.D.’ is in many ways a throwback to an earlier, male-dominated era of crime shows,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, “yet it carves out room for strong female characters who are good at their jobs and taken seriously by their colleagues — and the writers.”

headline: To Lower Maternal Deaths, India Urged to Reconsider Role of Midwives
text: PATRA, West Bengal — In this village 30 miles south of Kolkata, three generations of women have depended on Saira Bewa to deliver their babies.

headline: Turkish Government, Shaking Up Police, Now Seeks More Power Over Judiciary
text: The Turkish government reshuffled the police force yet again overnight, the police said on Wednesday, and sought to expand its power over the judiciary in a move that one former justice minister likened to a coup.

headline: How Do You Handle the Cold?
text: Temperatures that were 20 to 40 degrees below average were reported in the central parts of the country on Monday, and on the East Coast on Tuesday. How cold has it been where you live? How have you been handling it?

headline: Reprising the Storefront Gallery of the Greats
text: There weren’t too many spaces in New York devoted to exhibiting photography when Larry Siegel was coming up as a young street photographer, apart from the Museum of Modern Art and the Limelight Gallery (and coffeehouse). But the sight of MoMA’s “The Family of Man” exhibit was enough to compel Mr. Siegel to do something drastic.

headline: Nature Enthusiasts Help Foster an Economic Revival in Portugal

headline: Unemployment in Europe Stays High Amid Signs of Recovery

headline: ‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’ Coming to Broadway in the Fall
text: The hit London play “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” will open on Broadway this fall at the Barrymore Theater in a new production, executives at the National Theater of Great Britain said on Wednesday. Based on Mark Haddon’s best-selling novel, the drama follows Christopher — a 15-year-old mathematics savant with an often crippling antisocial disorder — as he pieces together clues to solve a neighborhood mystery and comes to a greater understanding of his own family. Last year, “Curious Incident” received seven Olivier Awards (London’s equivalent of the Tony Awards), the most ever earned by a play, winning for best new play (adapted by Simon Stephens), best director (Marianne Elliott) and best actor (Luke Treadaway as Christopher) among other categories.

headline: New York Today: Frozen Commute
text: Updated 12:17 p.m.

headline: Terrorism’s Fertile Ground
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Terrorism is a global reality, and for me as a Kenyan, this struck close to home in September with the siege of the Westgate mall. Yet in many ways, growing up in Nairobi I was always in the midst of terror. As a boy living in extreme poverty in Kibera, one of Africa’s largest slums, I learned early on that I was disposable, that human life is not equally valued. Life expectancy in Kibera is estimated at 30 years, compared with 64 in the rest of Kenya and 70 worldwide. In Kibera, people are desensitized to death. Living is understood to be the exception.

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 3: The Office Bully
text: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Why I Didn’t Give End-of-the-Year Bonuses
text: A couple of weeks ago, my production manager asked me a question that I have not looked forward to answering for several years now. “Are we going to be giving any bonuses this year?” asked Dale, who oversees 38 people in my picture-framing business.

headline: Citing Bad Weather, Egypt Postpones Morsi’s Trial
text: CAIRO — The trial of Egypt’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, on charges of inciting murder was postponed on Wednesday after the authorities said that bad weather had prevented them from flying Mr. Morsi to the courthouse in Cairo from prison near the port city of Alexandria.

headline: Daily Report: Webcams Become Small, Cheap and All-Seeing
text: In the Sahara, the African spurred tortoise lives for about a century. Thanks to modern technology, one named Franky has a shot at immortality, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: India and U.S. Continue Fight Over Diplomacy
text: NEW DELHI — Stepping up the pressure in an escalating diplomatic fight, India asked the American Embassy in New Delhi on Wednesday to stop selling liquor and other duty-free goods to nondiplomats by Jan. 16, acting before the American authorities are to decide whether to prosecute an Indian diplomat in New York who was arrested in a visa fraud case.

headline: A Growing Taste for U.S. Fast Food in India
text: MUMBAI — India has long had a reputation as being unfriendly to foreign businesses, but when it comes to fast food, international chains are being warmly welcomed by a young, upwardly mobile population.

headline: Carmignac Gestion Hires Former SAC Investing Team in London
text: LONDON — A group of former employees at the SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund in London has found a new home.

headline: Don’t Ask. Please Don’t Tell.
text: I turned 66 last week and started worrying that maybe I really was getting older, but whenever that sort of thing happens I hold my head erect and whistle a happy tune.

headline: China Cracks Open the Door for Video Game Consoles, but Doubts Abound
text: TOKYO — For years, the Big Three makers of video game consoles — Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo — have coveted access to China, a potentially huge but mostly closed market. Finally, China has cracked open the door, but industry experts say console makers may still struggle to break through to the next level.

headline: A Nigerian Connection at Bloomingdale’s
text: Dear Diary:

headline: From Denmark, a Hopeful Contends With His Own Legacy
text: The Danish director Thomas Vinterberg remembers the exact moment the idea for “The Hunt,” one of the nine films shortlisted in the Oscar competition for best foreign-language film, began percolating in his head. A psychological drama in which Mads Mikkelsen is cast as a timid kindergarten teacher unjustly dragged into scandal, “The Hunt” grew directly out of one of Mr. Vinterberg’s earlier films, “The Celebration,” a 1998 prizewinner at Cannes about a family rocked by allegations of sexual abuse.

headline: JPMorgan Settles Madoff Charges
text: JPMORGAN SETTLES MADOFF CHARGES  |  Over the last year, JPMorgan Chase has agreed to legal penalties now totaling $20 billion, but the settlements have not taken as large a toll on the bank as the numbers might suggest, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. On Tuesday, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, imposed a record $1.7 billion fine for felony violations of the Bank Secrecy Act for failing to report Bernard L. Madoff’s suspicious activities. On top of that, the bank agreed to pay $350 million to the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, bringing the total settlement to $2 billion.

headline: Speed Minimized as Factor in Schumacher Ski Accident
text: LONDON — French police officials said on Wednesday that speed was “not an important element” of their investigation into the Dec. 29 skiing accident in which Michael Schumacher, the most successful driver in the history of grand prix racing, sustained serious head injuries.

text: The latest men’s collection from Burberry at London fashion week.

headline: Chinese E-Commerce Giant Alibaba to Ban Bitcoins on Its Sites
text: LONDON — The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group said on Wednesday that it would not allow the sale of Bitcoins on its website.

headline: For Carlyle, Private Equity Business Is a Standout
text: The Carlyle Group manages a range of different investments, including private equity, hedge funds and real estate. But its bread-and-butter business of private equity was a standout last year.

headline: Administration Urges Restraint in Using Arrest or Expulsion to Discipline Students
text: The Obama administration issued guidelines on Wednesday that recommended public school officials use law enforcement only as a last resort for disciplining students, a response to a rise in zero-tolerance policies that have disproportionately increased the number of arrests, suspensions and expulsions of minority students for even minor, nonviolent offenses.

headline: Christie Faces Scandal on Traffic Jam Aides Ordered
text: The mystery of who closed two lanes onto the George Washington Bridge — turning the borough of Fort Lee, N.J., into a parking lot for four days in September — exploded into a full-bore political scandal for Gov. Chris Christie on Wednesday. Emails and texts revealed that a top aide had ordered the closings to punish the town’s mayor after he did not endorse the governor for re-election.

headline: Official Suggests 2022 Cup Won’t Be in Summer
text: Speculation about a potential winter World Cup has percolated ever since the 2022 tournament was awarded to Qatar, the tiny, gas-rich nation in the Middle East, four years ago. On Wednesday, however, a top official with global soccer’s governing body indicated that the expected scheduling switch is all but inevitable.

headline: Nations With Fuel for Atomic Bombs
text: The number of countries with fuel for nuclear weapons has dropped since 1991.

headline: Nuclear Materials Report Shows Better Safekeeping
text: A report issued Wednesday on the security of deadly nuclear materials found steady improvement, with seven countries in the last two years giving up most of their uranium and plutonium that could be readily turned into weapons. Their actions lowered the number of nations with appreciable fuel for atomic bombs to 25 from 32.

headline: Forest Labs to Buy Specialty Drug Maker for $2.9 Billion
text: Forest Laboratories said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Aptalis, a privately held drug maker, for $2.9 billion in cash.

headline: Syrian Rebels Deal Qaeda-Linked Group a Reversal
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For months, the patchwork of rebel brigades spread across northern Syria watched with foreboding as a new group gradually expanded its control, filling a vacuum left by nearly three years of war.

headline: 2 Parties Place Political Focus on Inequality
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Kay Hagan, a North Carolina Democrat who is up for re-election, is admonishing Republicans back home as “irresponsible and cold-hearted” for slashing unemployment benefits. Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, says that her party’s thinking is “stale and old and doesn’t really address the magnitude of the problem.”

headline: The Meryl Streep-Emma Thompson Show
text: There is everyone else making introductions at awards shows, and then there is Meryl Streep. At the National Board of Review awards gala on Tuesday night, Ms. Streep was to introduce her friend Emma Thompson, the group’s best-actress honoree for her star turn in “Saving Mr. Banks.” And from the moment Ms. Streep took the stage, wearing a baseball cap that read “Prize Winner” (swag related to “Nebraska,” which features a similar one), she stole the show.

headline: Emails Between Top Christie Aides and Port Authority Officials
text: Documents were released Wednesday in connection with an investigation into lane closings ordered at the George Washington Bridge by top aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: L.P.G.A. Adds Points Race and a $1 Million Bonus
text: The drama at the L.P.G.A. Tour’s season finale in Naples, Fla., in November was thick as a Broadway curtain, with Stacy Lewis and Suzann Pettersen battling for the Vare Trophy, given to the player with the lowest scoring average of the season, and with Shanshan Feng holding off Gerina Piller for a one-stroke victory.

headline: Insane Clown Posse Defends Fans, With F.B.I. Lawsuit
text: The Michigan rap group Insane Clown Posse filed suit on Wednesday against the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, saying that the United States government had made the “unwarranted and unlawful decision” to classify fans of the band as criminal gang members, leading to their harassment by law enforcement and causing them “significant harm.”

headline: A Closer Look at Cold Snaps and Global Warming
text: Updated, 2:09 p.m. | I spent a couple of hours this morning discussing the Northern Hemisphere cold snap in the context of global warming on CBC radio shows across Canada. You can hear one at the bottom of this post.

headline: Part of Something Big
text: There are many books about Martin Luther King Jr. for reading aloud with children in celebration of his birthday on Jan. 15, including picture-book biographies like “Martin’s Big Words: The Life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.,” by Doreen Rappaport, with illustrations by Bryan Collier, published in 2001. But the trend for looking at big events through the prism of small things (“The Civil War in 50 Objects,” “A History of the World in 100 Objects”) is particularly attractive for children, who may have an easier time understanding the parts than the whole.

headline: Rodman Serenades Kim With a Chorus of ‘Happy Birthday, Dear Marshal’
text: One day after he seemed to suggest that an American citizen detained in North Korea might deserve his fate, the retired basketball star Dennis Rodman serenaded North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, with a chorus of “Happy Birthday, Dear Marshal,” before an exhibition game in Pyongyang on Wednesday.

headline: Barnes & Noble Promotes Nook Boss to Chief Executive
text: Barnes & Noble appointed one of its top executives on Wednesday to fill the post of chief executive, a job that has been vacant since William Lynch Jr. abruptly resigned from the company in July.

headline: Two Researchers Nominated to Investigate Trove of Nazi-Looted Art
text: Two longtime provenance researchers have been nominated to join a task force created to investigate the history of more than 1,400 works of art stashed in a Munich apartment. The researchers, Sophie Lillie and Agnes Peresztegi, were recommended by the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany and will serve on a panel led by Dr. Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, Germany’s former deputy state minister for culture, who welcomed the nominations.

text: Did the recent recession make people feel physically ill? A study of Google queries suggests it did.

headline: Bronx Landmark, Under City’s Care, Is on Brink of Demolition

headline: Despite Stock Market Exuberance, a Tempered Reaction
text: What a spectacular year was 2013.

headline: Omaha Theater to Produce a Stage Adaptation of ‘The Shining’
text: If you’ve always wanted to unleash your inner Jack Nicholson, and will be in Nebraska this winter, then here’s an opportunity. The Benson Theater, an enterprising Omaha company, is hoping to raise the money to buy and renovate a 1923 theater to call home, and among its fund-raising projects is a new theatrical version of “The Shining,” Stephen King’s tale of a substance-abusing and increasingly crazed hotel overseer stuck with his family at a resort during the snowy off-season – the role Mr. Nicholson played to magnificently creepy excess in the 1980 Stanley Kubrick film. The company is holding auditions this week.
