headline: Blast in Pakistan Kills Senior Police Official
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A senior Pakistani police investigator at the forefront of operations against the Taliban and other criminals in the sprawling, seaside city of Karachi was killed in a huge bomb blast there on Thursday, police officials said. His driver and a security officer were also killed in the attack, and at least 11 people were reported wounded.

headline: Vanya and Sonia and Abs and Pecs
text: Jefferson McDonald isn’t shedding tears for friends who made New Year’s resolutions to get in shape. This 26-year-old actor has committed to a routine that includes near-daily workouts, yoga several times a week and basketball in his free time. Say “pizza and beer,” and machetes shoot from his eyes.

headline: Critics Voice Objections to MoMA’s Plan to Take Down Folk Art Museum
text: Updated, 6:09 p.m. | To the surprise of perhaps no one, including the Museum of Modern Art, the decision to take down the former home of the American Folk Art Museum as part of a redesign of MoMA’s Midtown Manhattan building provoked strong reactions on Thursday from architects and critics.

headline: Wheelies: The Vice Presidential Auto Show Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: An Artist Who’s Truly Wired
text: For R. Luke DuBois, art has its basis in mounds of data.

headline: How British Members of the Academy May Be Leaning
text: Voting for the Oscar nominations has officially closed — the final clicks and ballots had to be accounted for by 5 p.m. Pacific Standard Time on Wednesday — which means that other groups’ prize choices will not have an effect. But they could still indicate which way the breeze is blowing at the Academy.

headline: Should Governor Christie Step Down?
text: The governor's aides retaliated against a foe by causing traffic tie-ups at the George Washington Bridge. Should Christie's involvement, or lack of involvement, end his career?

headline: A Way to Carrying Multiple Concealed Devices
text: How would James Bond carry his electronic tablet – assuming he carried a tablet and wasn’t so cool?

headline: As Iran Nuclear Talks Resume, Ayatollah Criticizes U.S.
text: Iran’s supreme leader harshly denounced the United States on Thursday as negotiations to conclude an interim agreement in the Iranian nuclear dispute resumed, saying those talks illustrated what he called the hostility of Americans toward Iran and the Muslim world.

headline: The Gun Report: January 9, 2014
text: First it was Instagram. Now, Reddit, the so-called “front page of the Internet,” has been exposed as an active marketplace for assault rifles, high-capacity magazines and other powerful firearms, according to an investigation by Mother Jones. The Guns for Sale page, which counts more than 7,200 subscribers, offers buyers and sellers a forum on the site, which boasts tens of millions of users and drives major traffic to other websites.

headline: How Did You Motivate Your Hibernating Teenager to Stay Healthy in Winter?
text: It’s winter. In much of the country, it’s cold, often bleak, snowy, icy, rainy. It’s not appealing weather for getting outside and getting moving. Younger children see that differently: They see snow for sledding and ice for sliding, and really, why wouldn’t you want to go out? And teenagers who are already active in sports, dance, or enjoy a regular workout routine just keep going. But for teenagers who are even more inclined to hibernate in winter, how can you keep them moving and healthy?

headline: A Chunky, Cheerful Tracking Device to Keep Tabs on Your Child
text: Tracking devices make me uneasy, but I have to defer to parental paranoia, which requires knowing where your children are. A watch/tracker/phone, Filip, may help.

headline: In Harlem, an African Tasting Plate
text: First, respect: Bebop was born here, on West 118th Street at St. Nicholas Avenue, where in the early 1940s Minton’s Playhouse hired as house pianist an unknown named Thelonious Monk, who played the instrument as if nobody knew how before.

headline: Ex-SAC Trader Was Expelled From Harvard Law School
text: A federal jury will decide whether Mathew Martoma, the former hedge fund manager, cheated when he worked at SAC Capital Advisors, but there’s no denying he cheated when he falsified his grades at Harvard Law School some 15 years ago.

headline: Mercedes-Benz to Reveal AMG-Tuned GLA45 and Concept S-Class Coupe in Detroit
text: Mercedes-Benz will show several new models at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next week, among them the 2015 GLA45 AMG, the 2015 Concept S-Class Coupe and the 2015 C-Class.

headline: After Apparent Food Stamp Deal, Dairy Rift Moves to Fore in Farm Bill Talks
text: WASHINGTON — Disagreements over a program to help dairy producers when milk prices drop have emerged as a major sticking point in negotiations on a new farm bill, which had been expected to be wrapped up this week. But lawmakers appear to have reached an agreement on cuts to the food stamp program, which is part of the farm bill and had been the most contentious issue in efforts to pass the legislation.

headline: Today in Small Business: Disloyalty Cards
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Letters to the Doctor
text: When I entered the exam room to see my first patient of the day, a doctor from another department at my hospital, I found her sitting in the chair I usually occupy, typing away at the computer on the tiny desk.

headline: Tempered Optimism for the Economy
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

headline: E.U. Panel Invites Snowden to Testify on Privacy Breaches
text: PARIS — A European Parliament committee has invited Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has leaked classified government documents and is now in hiding in Russia, to testify via video link as part of an investigation into how to protect the privacy of European citizens.

headline: Making Oprah’s Gift Count
text: I’ll never forget when Oprah Winfrey turned to me and said, “We are going to build a school!” This was my second time on her show, and Oprah had just named me her “all-time favorite guest” in 25 years of the show. As if that wasn’t enough, she had just informed me that she was donating $1.5 million to build a school in my home village in Zimbabwe!  When Oprah gave me the incredible news, my response – in the midst of overwhelming gratitude – was “It is achievable!”  (Tinogona means “it is achievable.”) With that, Tinogona Foundation was born.

headline: Skiing the Giant Slalom at Age 7
text: “She was a happy little kid,” Rika Moore, a youth coach at Vail, said of Shiffrin, “but she was unbelievably focused on making perfect turns, one after another.”

headline: Signs of Future Slalom Success
text: Youth coaches saw an evolving star in Mikaela, but the Shiffrins still strived for normalcy.

headline: Early Olympic Dreams
text: From unicycles to inline skates, Mikaela Shiffrin spent plenty of time off skis, as when she played in the garage with her brother at age 6.

headline: Travel Site Will Emphasize Personal Advice
text: Virtuoso, the luxury travel network with close to a 1,000 hotels and 335 affiliated agencies globally, introduced a site this week that aims to marry technology with the human touch.

headline: Christie’s Confrontational Style
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has been accused of bullying political opponents. On YouTube, there are clips of his confrontations with critics.

headline: Director of Britain’s National Theater to Form New Company
text: LONDON — Nicholas Hytner, the director of Britain’s National Theater, has announced plans to form a theatrical production company when he leaves his current position in 2015. (His successor is Rupert Norris, an associate director at the National Theater.)

headline: Discovery of Bombs and Corpses Rattles Tense Caucasus Region
text: MOSCOW — The discovery of several improvised explosive devices and the bodies of six men shot dead put security forces on higher alert in the North Caucasus region of Russia on Thursday and added new concerns about violence ahead of the Olympic Games planned for the nearby resort city of Sochi next month.

headline: Bankers’ Bonus Blues
text: Investment bankers will have to look backward, not forward, for joy this bonus season. A mediocre fourth quarter means Wall Street and City practitioners are unlikely to improve on their total compensation from 2012. With industrywide revenue growth expected to be tepid at best for the next couple of years, the trend could persist. Bank share price performance, though, should help make up some of the difference.

headline: Analyst Suggests UBS Spin Off Investment Bank and Revive Warburg Name
text: LONDON — As Swiss banks faces more pressure from regulators to wall off their riskier activities, UBS should consider spinning off its investment bank, an analyst at Mediobanca said on Thursday.

headline: Bomber in Iraq Kills 22 Recruits Seeking to Fight Al Qaeda
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber detonated explosives on Thursday among a group of recruits who were joining the Iraqi Army to fight Al Qaeda in Anbar Province, the police said. Twenty-two recruits were killed, and 31 were wounded, officials said.

headline: The Memi Smart Bracelet: Wearable Tech That Lets You Disconnect
text: If one of your resolutions this year was to put down your gadgets more often when you’re with family, then the Memi smart bracelet, oddly enough, is a gadget that might make it easier to do just that.

headline: Darkness On the Edge of Trenton
text: I’m not sure how much there is to add to what’s already being said about Chris Christie’s ongoing “traffic study” scandal, but now that his press conference has (I think) finally ended here are a few thoughts.

headline: ‘Lady and the Unicorn’ Tapestries Return to View in France
text: PARIS — After a nearly two-year absence and a thorough cleaning, “The Lady and the Unicorn” tapestries have gone back on view at the Musée National du Moyen Age here, their rich colors more vivid than ever.

headline: Woman Says Lane Closings Were Not to Blame for Her Mother’s Death
text: FORT LEE, N.J. — The daughter of a 91-year-old woman from Fort Lee, N.J., who died on the day of a major traffic jam precipitated by top aides to Gov. Chris Christie said on Thursday that she did not believe the inability of an ambulance to reach her mother’s house was a factor in her death.

headline: Claim Against Indian Diplomat Has Echoes of Previous Cases
text: Sangeeta Richard, the housekeeper whose accusations of employer mistreatment led to the arrest of India’s deputy consul general in New York and an international furor, is not the first domestic worker to take issue with a diplomat who hired her.

headline: Questions for Christie
text: Gov. Chris Christie’s press conference on the manmade-traffic-jam lasted for almost two hours. He beat up on himself — he feels “embarrassed and humiliated” — and his staff — he called Bridget Anne Kelly “stupid and deceitful” — and did a pretty decent job of exhausting reporters, if not public interest in the story. A few questions remain that will likely play a part in the controversy going forward:

headline: Tunisia’s Premier Resigns, Formally Ending His Party’s Rule
text: TUNIS — Tunisia’s Islamist prime minister resigned Thursday, ending the two-year-old rule of his party, which has dominated the political scene since the popular uprising here that initiated the Arab Spring.

headline: Apple and Samsung Chiefs to Meet a Mediator Ahead of Next Patent Suit
text: In March, Apple and Samsung Electronics are scheduled to go to trial again to fight over smartphone patents. But after discussing settlement opportunities earlier this week, the companies have agreed to meet with a mediator.

headline: Blackstone Hires UBS Banker to Lead Energy Advisory Group
text: The investment banking arm of the Blackstone Group has hired a UBS executive to lead its energy and power advisory practice.

headline: Chrysler Announces Mopar Custom Shop Display for Detroit
text: Although Mopar has been Chrysler’s parts and service moniker since before World War II, it was during muscle-car craze of the 1960s that it came to be identified with performance aftermarket parts. At the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next week, Chrysler will have a sizable Mopar display as part of its 5,500-square-foot spread, showing off several vehicles laden with aftermarket parts.

headline: With Release of Prisoners, Afghan Leader Again Defies U.S. Wishes
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Thursday ordered the release of dozens of prisoners accused of having American blood on their hands, saying there was not enough evidence to hold them and intensifying his showdown with Obama administration officials after weeks of warnings that he risked losing American troop support.

headline: Jon Favreau’s ‘Chef’ to Open South by Southwest Film Festival
text: One more food truck will roll into Austin when “Chef,” a comedy written, directed by and starring Jon Favreau, has its premiere on opening night of the South by Southwest Film festival, organizers announced Thursday.

headline: A Comic Book Team Gets the Green Light
text: The life of a freelance comic book creator is all about pitching and survival: looking for a publisher and hoping an audience will be there to sustain a series. For the writer-artist team Ed Brubaker and Sean Phillips, things are about to get a little easier. Mr. Brubaker and Mr. Phillips have made a five-year publishing deal with Image Comics, the home of their most recent collaboration, the supernatural noir series Fatale. Image will publish whatever the team can dream up and Mr. Brubaker and Mr. Phillips will retain ownership of the property, a hallmark of the company.

headline: JPMorgan Lost Madoff in a Blizzard of Paper
text: Did JPMorgan Chase deliberately cover up Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud?

headline: Old Breakfast Buddies, From Tarzan to Snoopy
text: ONE of the simple yet durable cultural traditions of the 20th century — a modest rite that transcended barriers of race and class — was the Sunday morning or afternoon spent lost in the newspaper funnies. There was always something for everyone: “Flash Gordon,” “Prince Valiant” and “Terry and the Pirates” for those craving pulpy adventure; “Archie” and “Peanuts” for laughs and chuckles; “Gasoline Alley” and “Blondie” for family life; and “Krazy Kat” and “Pogo” for the comic-strip intelligentsia.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: New York Transportation Etiquette

headline: A Sweet History: Doughnuts in New York City
text: The Miser grew up just a few towns south of the birthplace of that symbol of American low cuisine, Krispy Kreme. So captivating were those confections’ sugary spell that it wasn’t until adolescence that he was even aware of the existence of other doughnuts. Doughnuts, for all he knew, simply were Krispy Kremes, and vice versa. Dunkin’ Donuts, he assumed, was merely a figure of speech, not a rival purveyor.

headline: National Park Proves a Hard Gift to Give
text: PATTEN, Me. — Lucas St. Clair pulled up to an overlook in Maine’s North Woods to a stunning vista of Mount Katahdin, the state’s highest peak and the endpoint of the Appalachian Trail. Stretched out below was a vast green carpet of pine and spruce flecked with golden aspens and blazing red maples; Millinocket Lake glistened in the distance.

headline: Portraits From Clips and Bytes
text: When the visual artist and composer R. Luke DuBois was commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery in Washington to make a portrait of Google’s founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, he elegantly co-opted Google’s own technology for the job.

headline: Early Chekhov, Framed Anew
text: The experimental designer and director Jay Scheib is offering audiences two ways to view his raucous contemporary rewrite of an unfinished early Chekhov play. You can see a live performance at the Kitchen in Chelsea, where it is called “Platonov,” the play’s traditional title, or you can watch a live simulcast of the performance at one of several theaters in New York and elsewhere, where it goes by another name, “The Disinherited.”

headline: ‘Captain Phillips’ Gets Another Vote of Confidence
text: Is this another indicator that “Captain Phillips” is going to go far? The USC Libraries Scripter Award, a screenplay prize that includes the original material that adapted movies come from, announced finalists on Thursday, and the real-life captain’s memoir, along with the film version, made the list.

headline: After Being Indicted, Diplomat Is Allowed to Leave the Country
text: The legal battle over an Indian diplomat whose recent arrest in New York caused an uproar in her home country took an unusual turn on Thursday when she was indicted by a federal grand jury in Manhattan but was then allowed to leave the United States.

headline: Dish Shares Drop After It Withdraws Bid for LightSquared
text: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | For years, Charles W. Ergen had ambitions to buy LightSquared, the bankrupt broadband wireless company, to bolster his dream of creating a huge data services provider.

headline: National Board of Review Gala Red Carpet
text: Celebrities like Adèle Exarchopoulos and Leonardo DiCaprio attended the event.

headline: Teju Cole Puts Story-Telling to the Twitter Test
text: 6:50 p.m. | Update: Teju Cole, who is in India, responded to my email after this post originally went live. His comments were added later.

headline: Civil War Archive to Go on Sale

headline: Rubio Demands States’ Right to Ignore the Poor
text: For a senator who likes to hold himself out as the future of the Republican brand, Marco Rubio has come up with a remarkably retrograde contribution to the party’s chorus of phony empathy for the poor: Let the states do it.

headline: As Seals Return to Long Island, So Do Watchers
text: In 2000, when the Riverhead Foundation for Marine Research and Preservation began running seal-watching cruises on Hempstead Bay, passengers would typically see one or two seals, according to Robert A. DiGiovanni Jr., a biologist and the group’s executive director.

headline: Philadelphia Museum Lands a Major Gift
text: Since the 1970s, Keith L. Sachs, the former chief executive of Saxco International, a packaging distribution company, and his wife, Katherine, have been major supporters of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, he as a longtime trustee and she in a number of roles, including adjunct curator.

headline: Going Driverless at CES
text: Roy Furchgott explores the buzz around autonomous vehicles at this year’s International CES.

headline: Survey of a Modern Form and a Friendship
text: You can tell by the primary colors and rectilinear grids in Harry Holtzman’s paintings and sculptures that the artist was a disciple of Piet Mondrian, the Dutch founder of Neoplasticism, an aesthetic philosophy that sought spiritual balance through simplified formal structure. Mondrian’s legacy in the United States is even owed in large part to Holtzman, who was 40 years younger and became the sole heir to and executor of his estate. The story of Holtzman’s work and their relationship, however, has been largely left untold. “Harry Holtzman and American Abstraction” at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Conn., offers a thorough and thoughtful recounting of that history.

headline: A Conductor Wields a Baton Across Cultures
text: The conductor Rossen Milanov balances two approaches when leading an orchestra.

headline: The Mind’s Jailer
text: “I’ve always responded to the history of my times,” says the beleaguered narrator of “Andrew’s Brain,” almost ruefully, as if he wished it weren’t so. He has no choice, though: Responding to the history of one’s times is the sworn duty of a character in a novel by E. L. Doctorow, who has in his half-century of writing fiction placed a remarkable number of people, both real and imagined, in their history just to watch them respond. At first Andrew, whose time is the bewilderingly eventful opening decade of this century, doesn’t sound like much of a witness: A self-­described “freakishly depressive cognitive scientist klutz,” he seems far more interested in the workings of his own mind than those of the world outside, and for a long time speaks — to someone he calls Doc — only of his messy private life and his largely fruitless research into the mysteries of the human brain. He cracks cynical jokes, tells parts of his life story in the third person, indulges in a fair bit of glib self-analysis (“I am finally, terribly, unfeeling”) and generally plays the fool. “Andrew’s Brain” is cunning. It isn’t hard to figure out that Andrew is an unreliable narrator, but by the end of this sly book Doctorow has you wondering if there’s any other kind.

headline: I Read You Loud and Clear
text: I love book clubs. I love reading for them, I love talking to them, and if I had my choice I’d probably do nothing but visit them to promote my books. Where else do you find people who have already made a commitment to read your book, and to read it closely enough to discuss it in a knowledgeable fashion with their friends? The best insights I’ve ever been offered about my work have come from book club members. In a world full of readings attended by the inevitable, random 5-to-10 bookstore browsers and 20-year-old assistant night managers who consistently mangle the title of your work, book clubs are an oasis of intelligent thought and discussion.

headline: Marvin Bileck: ‘Thimbledon Bridge’ and Emily Nelligan: ‘Drawings’
text: Alexandre Gallery

headline: Jury of 7 Women and 5 Men Chosen for Martoma Trial
text: A jury of seven women and five men was selected on Thursday to determine whether Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, is guilty of engaging in what the government has called the biggest insider trading scheme in history.

headline: Panel Recommends Transferring Yemeni From Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — In the first results of a long-delayed Obama administration initiative to hold parole-like hearings at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a military panel has recommended transferring a Yemeni detainee who had been ordered held indefinitely without trial, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Para-Real’
text: 601Artspace

headline: A Chef in the Field | Olive Oil
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

text: David Lewis Gallery

headline: The Feel, and Taste, of France
text: Saint George, a youthful new bistro that has taken the place of the beloved Buffet de la Gare, in Hastings-on-Hudson, is giving nervous loyal Gare patrons all kinds of reasons to take heart.

headline: Attorney General Vows to Crack Down on ‘Insider Trading 2.0’

text: Canada

headline: Looking Again at That Mars-Venus Thing
text: On HBO, it’s the guys who are airbrushed and Photoshopped, and the “Girls” who let their blemishes show.

headline: At the End of a Strip Mall, a Surprise
text: Verona Restaurant is one of those proverbial gems, a first-rate traditional Italian restaurant in an unremarkable setting. Here, at the end of a strip mall that houses a Subway sandwich shop and a dry cleaner, ordinary dishes like eggplant rollatini and fried zucchini dominate. Prepared with skill and flair, they remind you why these standard items are beloved by so many diners.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: sleep apnea, torn arteries and Google searches. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Brazil and Turkey.

headline: Beyond Beefcake in the Work of a Gay Pioneer
text: In 1951, Bob Mizer began Physique Pictorial, a magazine loaded with photographs of muscular young men wearing little more than posing straps — G-strings for men. Its imagery ostensibly illustrated health and fitness, but was really aimed at what was then an underground gay market. Mizer (1922-92) was a pioneer in making explicit the genre’s erotic appeal, enough so to attract attention from legal authorities. In 1947, he was convicted of contributing to the delinquency of a minor by taking nude pictures of a 17-year-old, and he spent a year in prison. In 1954, he was convicted of distributing obscene material through the mail. (That conviction was reversed on appeal a couple of years later.) Those speed bumps didn’t stop Mizer’s enterprise as a commercial photographer and publisher from growing to the point at which it occupied four lots near downtown Los Angeles, like a Hollywood movie studio, earning him the nickname “the Hugh Hefner of gay publishing.” Mizer, evidently, was blessedly free of high-art pretension, but Physique Pictorial was nevertheless an inspiration for artists like David Hockney and Robert Mapplethorpe.

headline: At Issue in 2 Wrenching Cases: What to Do After the Brain Dies
text: In one way, the cases are polar opposites: the parents of Jahi McMath in Oakland, Calif., have fought to keep their daughter connected to a ventilator, while the parents and husband of Marlise Muñoz in Fort Worth, Tex., want desperately to turn the machine off. In another way, the cases are identical: both families have been shocked to learn that a loved one was declared brain-dead — and that hospital officials defied the family’s wishes for treatment.

headline: Hiding in Plain Sight
text: InThai Restaurant is handy for workers in several high-rise office buildings along Route 7 in Norwalk near the Wilton line, many of whom cross the road for a quick lunch or a takeout dinner. But even after three years in business, the restaurant is still something of a secret beyond that area, and those acquainted with its extremely low prices and good spicy Thai food may want it to retain its sleeper status a while longer.

headline: Amiri Baraka, Polarizing Poet and Playwright, Dies at 79
text: Amiri Baraka, a poet and playwright of pulsating rage, whose long illumination of the black experience in America was called incandescent in some quarters and incendiary in others, died on Thursday in Newark. He was 79.

headline: Christie and the Bridge Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gary Shteyngart Offers Some Jokes, Some Self-Analysis
text: Gary Shteyngart was speaking on Wednesday night about the difficulties of recapturing his past on the page. “There was one acid trip I wanted to write about,” he said, “and in interviewing five people, I realized it never happened.”

headline: Punk, Skirts, Balaclavas: A Russian Revolution
text: The problem with staging a show trial is that the main actor has little incentive to follow the script. Yet that’s never tempered Russia’s thirst for judicial theater. In 1964, a Soviet court demanded to know who had given Joseph Brodsky permission to write poetry. That future Nobel laureate’s retort: “I think that it ... comes from God,” became a classic of artistic defiance.

headline: Obama Announces ‘Promise Zones’ in 5 Poor Areas
text: WASHINGTON — A year after promising to direct federal attention and support to needy areas across the country, President Obama said Thursday that the government would begin helping five economically hard-hit communities fight poverty and assist children.

headline: She’s Hard as Nails, He’s Noir and Nasty
text: There’s more mystery in the grammatically anguished title of “Cold Comes the Night” than in this low-voltage thriller, which asks you to guess, if not for long or terribly hard, which is the tougher of two combatants: a young and lovely single mother or a Polish criminal. In one corner is Chloe (Alice Eve), a hardworking, hard-bitten beauty who runs and lives in one of those motels that rent rooms by the hour. In the other corner is Topo (Bryan Cranston), a very bad man who stops at the motel one evening — the presumably cold night of the title (she puts on a parka) — a stopover that leads to a face-off that ends pretty much how you might guess.

headline: A Spot for Theatrics, or Serenity
text: The first thing to know about K60 Japanese Steak House is that this sprawling, neon-trimmed restaurant in a Lake Grove strip mall offers two entirely different dining experiences. The most popular, by far, is the raucous hibachi room, where flames leap, diners cheer (or cringe), servers scurry and impassioned chefs jump, juggle, chop and grill, all beneath the nonstop whoosh of overhead exhaust fans. And there is the adjacent, far quieter “sushi room,” as a hostess called it on a recent evening, with its sleek, sparsely populated tables and booths, serene sushi bar and attentive servers.

headline: When There Was a Mock Plantation in Brooklyn
text: All up and down de whole creationSadly I roam,Still longing for de old plantation,And for de old folks at home.

headline: I Remember Mama, the Pot Smuggler
text: In the opening moments of “Free Ride,” Christina (Anna Paquin), a young mother, impulsively flees her abusive boyfriend and dead-end factory job in an Akron, Ohio, suburb, to begin a new life in Florida. It is 1977, and the state, still in the throes of the blasé anything-goes spirit of the post-hippie era, is awash in imported drugs.

headline: Looking for the Hands-Free Driving Experience
text: At this year’s International CES, several automakers are showing off the latest and greatest technology in their vehicles, and much of the focus was on autonomous technology. Audi introduced a car that took steps toward self-driving, as did BMW and Bosch.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the ‘Ugly Betty’
text: When Michael Urie was cast in 2006 as Vanessa Williams’s slavishly devoted assistant on the television series “Ugly Betty,” it meant a move to Los Angeles. Relocating is an actor’s lot, of course, but Mr. Urie desperately missed New York. Clever guy, he came up with an effective treatment for homesickness: the purchase of an apartment in a very tall building. “Anytime friends came over,” he recalled, “they said, ‘This is just like home.’ ”

headline: What I Love | Michael Urie
text: The Midtown West home of Michael Urie and his partner Ryan Spahn.

headline: Gillespie, Former Republican Chairman, Readies to Run for Senate in Virginia
text: WASHINGTON — Ed Gillespie, a former Republican National Committee chairman, has told senior members of his party that he will challenge Senator Mark R. Warner of Virginia and announce his candidacy as early as next week, giving Republicans a top-tier candidate in what has become one of the nation’s most competitive swing states.

headline: Designing the Next Wave of Computer Chips
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Not long after Gordon E. Moore proposed in 1965 that the number of transistors that could be etched on a silicon chip would continue to double approximately every 18 months, critics began predicting that the era of “Moore’s Law” would draw to a close.

headline: No Barbershops Here, Nor Violins or Cellos
text: At the start of Heather Kravas’s “a quartet,” the work’s four dancers stand in line like serious kids pretending to be a train. As they repeatedly bend forward and arch back, their collective motion — switching between unison, relay and counterpoint — takes on the aspect of a stationary machine. Then, as their pelvises rock, they add a word — “want” — which becomes a mantra. Accelerating, the sequence approaches the edge of comedy.

headline: Coming-of-Age in Wartime
text: Eka and Natia , the 14-year-old best friends at the heart of “In Bloom,” live in a place that seems to be crumbling at the edges. It’s 1992, and their homeland, the former Soviet republic of Georgia, is at war. The fighting, in the northern Abkhazia region, is far from the capital, Tbilisi, where the girls live, but the conflict pops up frequently in the adult conversations, at least when the grown-ups are not screaming and cursing about other things.

headline: Shifting His Tectonic Plates
text: At the end of December, the PBS host Charlie Rose conducted a curious interview with Richard Serra about his new show in two locations of the Gagosian Gallery in New York, and it quickly became popular on the Internet. The conversation was notable mostly because it reached an uncomfortable deadlock over how to talk about Mr. Serra’s sculpture. (Mr. Rose thought one work in Mr. Serra’s new show looked like a cemetery; Mr. Serra disagreed. Repeat.)

headline: Celebrating Age as Well as Attitude at a Record Label’s Anniversary Party
text: An anniversary concert for a record label, like an anniversary edition of a music festival, always comes preloaded with a burden of intention. What’s implicit is some form of brand reinforcement — but an album catalog contains its own narrative, and an artist roster has its own identity, and the two may not naturally converge. So one question for any label at a milestone is what to celebrate most: a corpus or an ethos?

headline: Ford Looks to Fiesta to Increase Sales in Japanese Market
text: TOKYO — Ford might be an auto giant in America, but odds are you will not spot one of its cars on Japan’s busy roads. Last year, the Detroit automaker sold all of 3,896 cars in Japan.

headline: A Band of Brothers and Oddballs
text: Any man who was of a devil-may-care age in 1981 will, if interrogated long enough, eventually drop his intellectual facade and affirm that the greatest movie of all time is not “Citizen Kane” but “Stripes,” the boot-camp comedy from that year starring Bill Murray and Harold Ramis. “Enlisted,” a Fox sitcom that begins on Friday night, really, really wants to be “Stripes,” but it has none of its panache. Where “Stripes” was full of memorable misfits, “Enlisted” is full of mismatched ones.

headline: E-Cigarette Shops Open Even as City Cracks Down
text: A half-dozen people were gathered around the tasting bar at the Henley Vaporium in SoHo on a recent Friday evening. Behind the bar, two vapologists in white lab coats stood before a selection of dozens of tiny bottles, each containing liquid nicotine. The customers, all students or young professionals, leisurely inhaled on their so-called vape pens. Clouds of mist curled upward and vanished. A slightly sweet smell lingered in the air.

headline: Charting the Decline in Service at the I.R.S.
text: The national taxpayer advocate, the ombudswoman for the Internal Revenue Service, has released her annual report about the biggest issues facing the agency. One major concern that the advocate, Nina E. Olson, emphasized was declining customer service at the agency, driven by budget cuts.

headline: No Heavy Lifting for These Gym Rats
text: Because the time is long overdue for a gross-out comedy about the absurdities of gym culture, the first few minutes of “Dumbbells,” set at a Los Angeles fitness center, raised my hopes that here at last was the satirical takedown this subject deserves.

headline: Unfinished Works
text: The Metropolitan Museum is dotted with paintings that have been left incomplete.

headline: The Fascination of the Unfinished
text: Unfinished paintings are enticing cracks in the facade of art history, lures along the path to a deeper understanding of artistic processes and impulses. For all the paintings that artists complete, countless others are left incomplete for any number of reasons — poverty or war, a change of plan or vision, the illness or death of the artist. While many of these works have been destroyed, and others forgotten, some are now recognized as significant works of art, accorded a special place in history and in an artist’s body of work, in part because they can bring us closer to understanding the mysterious process of painting, and, indeed, to painting’s future. After all, nothing inspires a young artist like a close look at how an earlier one worked.

text: Leon D. Black, the head of Apollo Global Management, said last year that his firm was “selling everything that’s not nailed down.”

headline: The Very Model of a University
text: In designing his 1907 campus for the City College of New York at Amsterdam Avenue and 138th Street, George B. Post must have felt like the ham in a sandwich. He was working between McKim, Mead & White’s lofty, imperial Roman-style Columbia College and their demure Renaissance-style campus for New York University’s Bronx branch, now Bronx Community College.

Action!” But such a phrase might be heard during the 2014 Sundance Film Festival as the Sundance Institute teams with a giant public relations agency to stream a daily, hourlong show on the institute’s channel on YouTube, at youtube.com/sff.

text: WASHINGTON — It is hardly the kind of news that lawmakers in Congress would want to highlight during a week when unemployment benefits expired for more than a million Americans. But Congress has achieved something of a milestone.

headline: Tech vs. Tyke
text: Unlike almost everyone we know, my husband and I do not allow our 3-year-old to watch TV or movies, or use smartphones, tablets or other devices. We feel that “screen time” is unhealthy, and so far, the policy has worked for our family. I avoid this topic with other parents because our choice implies a negative judgment about their choices. If the TV comes on at someone else’s house, we quietly excuse ourselves. But what should I say when another parent asks me about this directly?

headline: A Third Ring, Bearing the Most Important Truth
text: My first engagement ring, a diamond, was given to me by Glenn on my 27th birthday. Although we had been dating only 10 months, I suspected a proposal was coming. Little clues tipped me off: a cut-short phone call, his nervousness at the restaurant.

headline: If Bad Things Happen, Blame the 10-Year-Old
text: A pretty, somewhat sleepy and finally strange once-upon-a-time tale, “The Rocket” is the story of a Laotian boy who transcends adversity, partly because, if we’re being honest, few moviegoers would probably want to watch a film about a boy who doesn’t (unless it is a documentary). It opens with a villager, Mali (Alice Keohavong), giving birth to twins, one dead. An older relative, Taitok (Bunsri Yindi), wants to kill the surviving child because, she insists, twins are bad luck. Mali successfully begs for the boy’s life, and, after the dead newborn is clandestinely buried, the surviving child grows up to become the movie’s plucky 10-year-old hero, Ahlo (Sitthiphon Disamoe).

text: In recent years, it has become increasingly clear that no prominent banker would be prosecuted for fraud in the run-up to the financial crisis. In the current issue of The New York Review of Books, Judge Jed Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan asks why.

headline: Polio Vaccination Effort in Syria Appears to Have Some Effect
text: The first polio outbreak in Syria in 14 years, which caused alarm when detected last September in the war-ravaged country, appears to have been contained halfway through an emergency vaccination effort for millions of children in the Middle East, two top World Health Organization officials said Thursday.

headline: Fitful Progress in the Antismoking Wars
text: Fifty years ago this Saturday, on Jan. 11, 1964, a myth-shattering surgeon general’s report on smoking and health brushed aside years of obfuscation by tobacco companies and asserted, based on 7,000 scientific articles, that smoking caused lung cancer and was linked to other serious diseases. Those findings expanded as more data was gathered.

headline: After Chris Christie’s Performance
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey issued repeated apologies Thursday for the abuse of office that now threatens to undermine his political future. Though he sounded remorseful — and clearly sorry that this scandal might sink his ambitions for national office — he blamed his staff for making him a victim. Unbeknown to him, he said, they shut down lanes to the George Washington Bridge to create a four-day traffic jam to punish a local mayor who failed to endorse him in last year’s election.

headline: Sexual Assault Case Yields a Plea Deal in Missouri
text: MARYVILLE, Mo. — A former high school football player, under an agreement with a special prosecutor, pleaded guilty here on Thursday to a misdemeanor and was sentenced to two years’ probation in a sexual assault case that drew national outrage when an initial investigation two years ago ended with the sexual assault charges being dropped.

headline: Pretty, Yes, but for Boats, Ice Can Be a Menace
text: It may not be the Akademik Shokalskiy, the Russian boat recently trapped by ice in Antarctica, but the Brooklyn, a 280-ton tour boat operated by the Circle Line, has had its own troubles with frozen water this week.

headline: Reid’s Uncompromising Power Play in Senate Rankles Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — With his strong-armed change to the filibuster rule and an iron-fisted control of the Senate floor, Senator Harry Reid has engaged in the greatest consolidation of congressional power since Newt Gingrich ruled the House, unleashing a bitterness that may derail efforts to extend unemployment insurance.

headline: U.S. Considers Resuming Nonlethal Aid to Syrian Opposition
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is considering the resumption of nonlethal military aid to Syria’s moderate opposition, senior administration officials said on Thursday, even if some of it ends up going to the Islamist groups that are allied with the moderates.

headline: Christie’s Apology for the Sins of His Aides and Appointees Leaves Out His Own
text: Another 900 pages of documents on the George Washington Bridge Tollgate-Gate are due to be published as soon as Friday, and early word is what they lack in punchiness — after all, what could top “time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee”? — they make up for in venom.

headline: A Chilean Dictator’s Secret Book Collection: Heavy on Napoleon, Light on Fiction
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — The Augusto Pinochet Ugarte Library, on the manicured grounds of the military academy here, welcomes visitors with an oil portrait of the Chilean dictator himself in military regalia. The painting of General Pinochet, whose government killed or disappeared more than 3,000 people and tortured nearly 40,000 others, hangs above the librarian’s desk.

headline: Deals Show M.L.S. Is No Longer an Afterthought
text: CARSON, Calif. — When Omar Gonzalez left the University of Maryland and was taken by the Los Angeles Galaxy as the third pick in the 2009 Major League Soccer draft, he had a plan: Learn the ropes of being a professional, develop his craft and, when his contract was up, head to Europe, where a bigger stage and payday awaited.

headline: The Danish Prince and His Family Drama
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Falluja’s Fall Stuns Marines Who Fought There
text: Adam Banotai was a 21-year-old sergeant and squad leader in the Marine Corps during the 2004 invasion of Falluja, a restive insurgent-held city in Iraq. His unit — which had seven of 17 men wounded by shrapnel or bullets in the first days of the invasion — seized control of the government center early in the campaign.

headline: In a Rare Video, Fidel Castro Surfaces
text: Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, made his first public appearance in nine months on Wednesday night at the opening of a nonprofit art studio in the Romerillo neighborhood of Havana.

headline: Promising Drug Trial Lifts Stock of Intercept
text: Shares of a small biotechnology company nearly quadrupled Thursday after a clinical trial suggested the firm might have the first effective treatment for a fatty liver disease associated with the nation’s epidemic of obesity.

headline: If Opportunity Doesn’t Knock
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLES — Ah, a grid with lots of white space. There’s nothing better than a grid with lots of room to stretch out, except possibly a Patrick Berry grid with lots of room to stretch out.

headline: Wall Street Predicts $50 Billion Bill to Settle U.S. Mortgage Suits
text: Wall Street could pay nearly $50 billion to buy peace from federal authorities who are taking aim at the banks over their role in the mortgage crisis, according to interviews and a confidential analysis of the industry’s potential legal exposure.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Wants Six Months to Revise Rules on Gun Sales
text: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said Thursday that he would ask a federal judge who declared the city’s ban on firearms sales unconstitutional to give lawmakers six months to adopt a new ordinance regulating gun shops. The judge, Edmond E. Chang of the Northern District of Illinois, signaled in his decision on Monday that Chicago could still restrict gun transactions as long as they stopped short of a complete ban. “Though I fully disagree, the city has little option but to follow the ruling of the court,” Mr. Emanuel, who will not file an appeal, said in a statement. A status hearing is scheduled for next week.

headline: Christie Brings His Remorse to an Inconvenienced Borough
text: FORT LEE, N.J. — Nobody had ever claimed that Mark Sokolich was one of the most powerful mayors in America. But on Thursday afternoon, Chris Christie, one of the most powerful governors in the country, flew to Mr. Sokolich’s borough to deliver a personal apology.

headline: Gmail Plans to Allow Google Plus Users to Send Anyone an Email
text: Google will soon allow people to send anyone an email, even if they do not have the person’s email address, as long as both people have a Gmail and Google Plus account.

headline: Andrew Luck Is a Fan of Two Types of Football
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Andrew Luck has been preparing all week for Saturday’s A.F.C. divisional playoff game at New England against the Patriots. There have been game plans to dissect, film to study and practices to participate in to prepare for the wrinkles of a Bill Belichick defense. Then there was the football that had nothing to do with Tom Brady, Luck’s Indianapolis Colts or the game at all.

headline: More Naked Heathen Romps
text: You just can’t keep a good pagan cult down, although sometimes it seems as if everything colludes to do so. Take Robin Hardy’s 1973 horror classic “The Wicker Man,” now having its Blu-ray debut in a Lionsgate “Final Cut” edition. The film — about a prudish policeman’s encounters with pre-Christian Celtic practices in a remote Scottish community — has weathered numerous twists and turns in its 40-year existence, including a remake, a quasi-remake and at least three versions of varying length. But its journey concludes on a positive note, even if the film itself does not. On second thought, the film can be a little ambivalent in that department.

headline: Chemical Spill Fouls Water in West Virginia
text: More than 100,000 customers were without safe tap water on Thursday after a chemical used to clean coal leaked into the Elk River in Charleston, W.Va., officials said.

headline: Christie’s Apology, Done His Way
text: He was, he said, heartbroken. Embarrassed. Sad. Disappointed. Humiliated.

headline: Police Scrutinize Pensions; 6 More Arraigned in Fraud
text: As six more New York police officers were arraigned in state court on Thursday on charges that they feigned mental illnesses to bilk Social Security out of disability benefits, a police commander said the Police Department was scrutinizing the city pensions being paid to scores of retired officers accused in the scheme.

headline: Delays in Bidding Help Put Focus on Masahiro Tanaka
text: It is not just that Major League Baseball changed its rules governing how Japanese players could join North American clubs. Masahiro Tanaka and his agent will be the beneficiaries of what is set to become an unprecedented bidding war because of delays, confusion, infighting, counterproposals and more delays.

headline: Among Cuomo’s Proposals, a Tax Break for Renters
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan to create a tax credit for New York renters would only begin to address an imbalance in tax policy that historically has favored homeowners over tenants in the state, housing experts said.

headline: Taking Responsibility for a Child, Then Raising Five More

But their fame may have faded with time. Lisa W. Foderaro of The Times has written a guide to some of the more obscure historical markers that dot the city.

headline: Signs of Abuse in Toddler’s Death, but Few Warnings
text: By age 4, Myls Dobson knew the dislocation of family court hearings and custody fights. He also knew the love of grandparents and aunts. His smiling face beamed from Facebook, a healthy toddler full of promise, dressed up in ties or posing by a courthouse in Manhattan.

headline: Prokhorov Will See Different Nets Team in London Than in Brooklyn
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets’ owner, is planning to attend the team’s game against the Atlanta Hawks next Thursday at O2 Arena in London, a club spokesman said. It will be the first time Prokhorov has attended a Nets game since Nov. 1, when he watched his team’s home opener against the Miami Heat at Barclays Center. The Nets won that game, a misleading prelude given how the season has played out.

headline: Michael Price to Retire From Goodspeed Musicals

headline: A Race in One District Draws Focus to Asian Voters

The contest underscores the diversity of the Houston district in a state where Asian-Americans are the fastest-growing race or ethnic group.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) RICHARD TUCKER AT 100: AN OPERA CELEBRATION Isabel Leonard, above, the winner of the 2013 Richard Tucker Award, and a roster including Stephanie Blythe, Stephen Costello, Joyce DiDonato, Renée Fleming, Susan Graham and Eric Owens perform works by Verdi, Rossini, Donizetti, Puccini and Offenbach, accompanied by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and the New York Choral Society. Writing in The New York Times about this gala, held Nov. 17 at Avery Fisher Hall and presented here by “Live From Lincoln Center,” Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim commended the “stellar lineup,” including the “exquisite” Ms. Leonard and the “silken soprano” of Ms. Fleming. She added, “It was perhaps revealing of the confidence of both these artists — at very different stages of their career — that their repertory choices lay outside the operatic mainstream.”

headline: As Indian Diplomat Exits After Arrest, a Culture Clash Lingers
text: NEW DELHI — Two dozen revved-up television crews were clustered outside a V.I.P. exit at Indira Gandhi International Airport on Friday, waiting for the flight from New York. They had been in place for two hours, and every time a trickle of passengers came into view, they all jumped up and pressed their cameras against the glass.

headline: Illiterate, but in Love With Books
text: On the banks of picturesque Dal Lake in Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, sits the only library in the neighborhood, run by a man who loves books but cannot read.

headline: What Snail Snot Can Do For You
text: Batali gets salty; Shinzo Abe or Abe Vigoda?

headline: Who Made That Dial Tone?
text: “Remove the Receiver from the hook,” read a notice in The Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch in 1919, “and listen for a steady humming sound, known as the ‘Dial Tone.’ If you hear the dial tone, place your finger in the hole containing the first figure of the number to be called and pull the dial as far as it will go. . . .” (An accompanying article described the noise as being “like the buzzing of a bumble bee or other large insect.”)

headline: Jared Diamond: ‘New Guinean Kids Are Not Brats’
text: Your latest book, “The World Until Yesterday,” is about traditional societies and your research in New Guinea. Why is the acronym Weird central to the book?  In Weird — Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich and Democratic — societies we take these things for granted that just didn’t exist anywhere in the world until a few thousand years ago. We encounter strangers, and it’s normal, and we don’t freak out and try to kill them. We eat food that somebody else grew for us. We have a government with police and lawyers to settle disputes.

headline: Is Uber’s Surge-Pricing an Example of High-Tech Gouging?
text: At 10 p.m. on New Year’s Eve, I hailed a taxi outside my apartment in Adams Morgan and directed it to a friend’s apartment in Shaw, a nearby neighborhood, also in Northwest Washington. It took a mere minute to find an open car, and the traffic-clogged two-mile trip cost $13, including tip.

headline: The Flying Tomato Would Rather You Not Call Him That Anymore
text: Shaun White sat in a lawn chair on the side of the mountain at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe, trying to think of a nice way to ask one of the young men grooming the hill to shovel some snow up onto the air bag, please. White was there in April to learn a triple cork 1440, a snowboarding trick that requires flipping three times in the air while moving through three different planes — horizontal, lateral and vertical — all while doing four 360-degree spins. Landing a triple cork is considered essential to winning slopestyle, a snowboarding event that will debut in the Olympic Games next month and that involves riding down a course filled with jumps and rails, sort of like those in a skateboard park. Because White had not yet mastered the triple cork, he needed to practice the trick by crash-landing into a giant yellow air bag. Judging from his emphatic cursing, the impact felt horrible.

headline: Care of: My Wife’s Lover’s Neighbor
text: I received an envelope that was addressed to my home but did not include a name. I recognized the last name on the return-address label. I opened the envelope and realized it was intended for my neighbor, a woman I have known, along with her husband, for many years. The letter chronicled the dates and locations of an affair the sender claimed his wife was having with my neighbor’s husband. I regret reading the letter. Upon looking more closely at the envelope, I was able to discern my neighbor’s name (the wife) and the words “private and confidential,” but these were obscured by the postmark. It seems the sender intentionally sent the letter to my home to keep the husband from intercepting it, counting on me to deliver it to the wife. Now that the envelope is open, the neighbors will know that I have read the allegations. What is my obligation: To deliver the letter or to inform the sender that this plan didn’t go as intended? NAME WITHHELD

headline: We Didn’t Eat the Marshmallow. The Marshmallow Ate Us.
text: In a series of famous experiments in the 1960s and ’70s conducted by the Stanford psychologist Walter Mischel, preschoolers were invited to sit alone in a room furnished only with a small desk. On the desk sat two marshmallows (or equivalently tempting treats) and a bell. The researcher told each child that he had to leave, but that when he returned, she could eat both marshmallows. If she wanted one marshmallow before then, however, she could ring the bell and eat one, but not both. Then the researcher shut the door, leaving the child alone with the forbidden marshmallows.

headline: No Puff Piece
text: A friend who almost never cooks recently made gougères — baked puff pastries with cheese. “I could not believe how easy that was,” he told me. In fact, I can’t think of anything as impressive that needs so little work.

headline: The Murderer and the Manuscript
text: Just before Labor Day in 2011, Toni Kirkpatrick, an editor at Thomas Dunne Books, an imprint of St. Martin’s Press, picked up her phone and called an unfamiliar number with a Southern California area code. She was hoping to deliver good news to a man named Alaric Hunt, the newest winner of a debut-detective-novel writing contest, jointly sponsored by Minotaur Books (another St. Martin’s imprint) and the Private Eye Writers of America. The contest has a good track record — a past winner, Michael Koryta, a 21-year-old phenom, has since published 10 successful thrillers — and it also comes with a substantial prize: a $10,000 advance and a guaranteed publishing contract for the book that has been submitted.

headline: Fruits of the Loom
text: In 1776, America didn’t have a single textile mill. There were no spinning mules, no water-powered looms. There were only rumors of what such things might look like and a few nonfunctioning models built from those rumors. Nearly every American woman, except the wealthiest, knew how to spin her own yarn and weave her own cloth, even as across the Atlantic women were moving out of the home and into millwork as England — bent on protecting its export market by safeguarding its trade secrets — industrialized the manufacturing of textiles.

headline: Rosanne Cash Goes Home
text: On an icy December morning, Rosanne Cash was making tea in the kitchen of the Chelsea brownstone she shares with her husband, the producer-songwriter-guitarist John Leventhal, and their 14-year-old son, Jakob. Her 25-year-old daughter Carrie, also a singer and the youngest of three children that Cash had with her ex-husband, the singer-songwriter Rodney Crowell, was also staying there for a while. It was a full house, and Cash seemed to like it that way. Carrie appeared from a downstairs bedroom to ask Cash to help her find the “save the date” cards she wanted to get in the mail for her May wedding to Dan Knobler, a guitarist and producer. Mother and daughter moved around a partly finished jigsaw puzzle on a nearby table, and Cash began looking through a cabinet, pausing to answer a phone call from a close friend, the former New Yorker TV critic Nancy Franklin. Soon the cards were found, and Carrie was off to address them.

headline: Big in Japan
text: You might not know me, but I’m famous. Don’t feel bad. Until recently, I didn’t know I was famous either, and most days, even now, it’s hard to tell.

headline: Pictures of Men, Friends or Lovers
text: Trent Kelley wondered how he could study the history of African-American gay men when so many of them had lived their lives in relative secrecy. He found his answer in vintage photographs — which he began to collect on eBay, at flea markets and at estate sales — which depict everything from urban dandies and workers to athletes and soldiers.

text: The website of People’s Daily, the mouthpiece of China’s Communist Party, has released “Beat Corruption,” an online game that allows players to fight graft by zapping greedy officials. Players win points by using their mouse to blast bad guys with a Taser and lose points by targeting virtuous police officers.

text: HONG KONG — Fosun International aspires to be China’s answer to Warren E. Buffett’s investment firm, Berkshire Hathaway, and it wants to be sure everyone knows it.

headline: Ireland's Rebound Is European Blarney
text: DUBLIN — I was talking just before Christmas to a young man who sells shoes in a department store in Dublin. He told me that a television news crew had filmed interviews in the store the previous day. They wanted to know if sales were picking up during the vital holiday period, indicating that the battered Irish economy was, after five grim years, on the rise at last.

headline: Daily Report: Seeking New Ways to Make Computer Chips
text: More than ever recently, industry pundits have been warning that the progress of the semiconductor industry is grinding to a halt — and that the theory of Gordon E. Moore, an Intel co-founder, has run its course, John Markoff reports.

headline: IPad Is an Artist’s Canvas for David Hockney
text: Stand before a huge image of Yosemite by David Hockney and see the artist’s rendition of wispy clouds hovering over midnight blue mountains. Look closer and see strokes drawn by a stylus on an iPad, and pixels from an inkjet printer.

headline: British Regulators Said to Prepare Charges Against Ex-Trader
text: LONDON — British regulators are preparing to bring criminal charges against Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested nearly four years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: New Detail Emerges About Bo Xilai’s Downfall
text: Ever since Bo Xilai, the Communist Party aristocrat, was given a sentence of life in prison last September on charges of corruption, very little in the way of new details about his downfall have emerged. But this week, a Chinese magazine, Sanlian Life, published a 31­-page cover story on Mr. Bo’s youngest son, Bo Guagua, a favorite focus of gossip in China. He is currently a first-year student at Columbia Law School and has been spotted at social gatherings in Manhattan.

text: OK, and I’m more or less back on duty, although next week I’ll be busy in Ireland. But time to weigh in again on a few things.

headline: Mumbai’s International Airport Gets Modern Makeover
text: MUMBAI — For anyone who has traveled through the shiny airport hubs of Asia like Hong Kong and Singapore, flying into Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai can deliver quite a shock.

headline: An Affair? France Shrugs, but Its Leader Calls for Privacy
text: PARIS — The photographs show a stout man of middling height striding out of an ordinary-looking Parisian apartment house, a helmet and a dark visor obscuring his face. He gets on a motorized scooter and zooms away into the Eighth Arrondissement.

headline: The Medicaid Cure
text: Something really interesting is happening on the health-care front: costs are rising much less rapidly than anyone expected. This is good news for the budget; it’s also good news for Obamacare. There was much skepticism about promises that health reform would “bend the curve”, reducing cost growth; well, the curve is bending, and it’s likely that the cost control measures that are part of Obamacare (and have been in effect for several years) are part of the reason.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Wong Kar-wai on ‘The Grandmaster’
text: The Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai is a global art-house favorite, best known for lushly photographed dramas about romantic loss or frustration, like “In the Mood for Love.” So there some oddity in the fact that when he finally made it onto the shortlist for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, it should be with a kung fu biopic called “The Grandmaster.”

headline: Growth in Jobs Slows Sharply to 3-Year Low
text: Just when it seemed as if the economy was finally accelerating, the latest employment figures once again confounded expectations of better days ahead.

headline: Banks Brace for Reckoning
text: When the dust has settled on investigations into the role of banks in the mortgage crisis, fines could total nearly $50 billion, and that does not include the $13 billion that JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. Put into context, the $50 billion would equal roughly half the total annual profit of large American banks in 2012.

headline: The Making Of | Folkert de Jong’s Synthetic, Sculptural Costumes for the Wooster Group
text: For the past decade, the Dutch artist Folkert de Jong has gained international recognition for eerily beautiful figurative sculptures made from materials like plastic, polyurethane and bronze. He’s shown at biennales in Sydney and Kiev, is in the permanent collection at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, has a show through early April at Antwerp’s Middelheim Museum and will have his work on exhibit this year at the Armory Show and at James Cohan Gallery. He also has upcoming solo shows in Paris, Milan and Wakefield, England.

headline: Thousands Without Water After Spill in West Virginia
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — As 300,000 people awoke on Friday to learn that their tap water was unsafe for brushing teeth, brewing coffee or showering, residents and businesses expressed a mix of anger and anxiety in coping with an industrial accident with no clear end in sight.

headline: In Blow to Peace Effort, Israel Publishes Plans for New Housing in Settlements
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Friday published plans to build 1,400 housing units in Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem and the West Bank, a move the chief Palestinian negotiator condemned as a “slap” to Secretary of State John Kerry’s intense push for a Middle East peace deal.

headline: For Target, the Breach Numbers Grow
text: Target on Friday revised the number of customers whose personal information was stolen in a widespread data breach during the holiday season, now reporting a range of 70 million to 110 million people.

headline: Carlyle Hires UBS Executive for Market Strategies Group
text: The Carlyle Group, the big alternative investment firm based in Washington, has hired a UBS executive to bolster its capital markets expertise.

headline: How Do You Motivate Your Teenager to Get Moving in the Cold?
text: If the polar vortex had you hibernating, how has it affected your teenager? The open discussion on the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming is how to get a teen who is disinclined toward activity to get moving, especially in the winter when outdoor fun may be less appealing. I asked parents who have successfully nudged a less-than-enthusiastic teenager out of the house and into exercise to weigh in.

headline: The Employment Rate’s New Normal
text: The share of Americans with jobs did not increase in 2013. The economy added about 182,000 jobs a month, just enough to keep pace with population growth.

headline: Suzanne Vega Has Her Own Issues With ‘Llewyn Davis’
text: The irate folkies – a group that actually exists – will be paying close attention to how “Inside Llewyn Davis” fares at the Golden Globes on Sunday, and on the awards circuit beyond. “My hunch is that if the film gets a bunch of Oscar noms — especially if it gets a nom for best picture — the dust-up won’t go away,” wrote Christine Lavin, the singer-songwriter who has been on a mission to clarify some things about what she believes the Coen brothers’ portrait of the 1960s Greenwich Village folk scene got wrong. “Maybe it will become a haboob?” she added. “Love that word.”

headline: In Our Pages: January 11
text: 1914: Bleak Week for Fleet Street

headline: New York Times Features Every Teacher Should Know About
text: One example of the new Science Take video series.

headline: In Life and Business, Learning to Be Ethical
text: LOTS of New Year’s resolutions are being made — and no doubt ignored — at this time of year. But there’s one that’s probably not even on many lists and should be: Act more ethically.

headline: ‘Paranoia Is the Mother-in-Law of Invention,’ Puppet Accused of Terror in Egypt Tells BBC
text: In an English-language interview with the BBC on Friday, the Egyptian puppet recently accused of acting as a terrorist mouthpiece protested her innocence. The puppet, Abla Fahita, rejected allegations from a pro-military blogger that unseen hands had manipulated her into sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists during an ad for a phone company.

headline: Debating Why the Work Force Is Shrinking
text: People keep leaving the labor force. The share of Americans either working or looking for work sank to 62.8 percent in December, tying October for the lowest level since 1977 – an era when women were much less likely to work.

headline: Paperback Row
text: KURT VONNEGUT: Letters,  edited by Dan Wakefield. (Dial, $20.) Written over a 60-year period, these letters display all the hallmarks of Vonnegut’s fiction — smart, hilarious and heartbreaking. It includes chilling descriptions of the Allied firebombing of Dresden and Vonnegut’s time as a P.O.W.; wry dispatches from his years as a struggling writer; and words of commiseration and encouragement to contemporaries like Norman Mailer and Bernard Malamud.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ON SUCH A FULL SEA,  by Chang-rae Lee. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Lee abandons realist fiction in this marvelous dystopian fantasy, set in an almost familiar future world. But he continues to grapple with themes of hope and betrayal.

headline: Image of the Day: January 10
text: The International Kite Festival in Dhordo, Gujarat.

headline: Hitting the Road
text: In Len Vlahos’s debut novel, the Scar Boys are a punk band from Yonkers that hits the road riding a rusty van and working out personal problems while playing gigs in college towns as far south as Georgia. “Music to the rescue,” muses Harry, the book’s narrator. Playing and touring demand creativity and commitment, forcing the Scar Boys — actually three guys and a girl — to come of age in this wry, stylish tale.

headline: The Making of the Presidents
text: “Away back in my childhood, the earliest days of my being able to read,” Abraham Lincoln nostalgically remembered on the eve of his first inauguration, “I got hold of a small book. . . . Weems’ ‘Life of Washington.’ ” The future president never forgot its vivid accounts of the battles and heroes of the Revolutionary War, not to mention the causes for which the founders fought. “I recollect thinking then, boy even though I was,” he reminisced, “that there must have been something more than common that those men struggled for.” The book’s stories “fixed themselves on my memory,” he proudly added, acknowledging that “these early impressions last longer than any others.”

headline: Unbridled
text: The cherished bond between humans and horses is celebrated in many beloved children’s books, from “National Velvet” to “War Horse.” But when the real connection is already palpable, why do writers take their horse stories deeply into the realm of the imaginary? Two new books for middle-grade readers use different approaches to the equestrian genre to explore these fantasies.

headline: Line of Fire
text: Beginning with the publication of her award-winning young adult novel “Speak” in 1999, Laurie Halse Anderson has written with honesty and grit, bravely shedding light on such once-taboo topics as rape, eating disorders, suicide and addiction. In doing so, she has helped build the current landscape of contemporary young adult literature. Anderson writes the hard truth, stirring debate and discussion among both fans and objectors, and ultimately creating long overdue conversations about the real issues teenagers face every day.

headline: Poems, Protests and Prayers
text: Over the next few weeks, we welcome three new writers to our roster of Bookends contributors: James Parker, Thomas Mallon and Leslie Jamison. Parker, who makes his initial appearance this week, is a contributing editor at The Atlantic, where he has written about everyone from Norman Rockwell and Martin Amis to Charlie Sheen and the lead singer of the 1980s hair-metal band Ratt. He was a staff writer at The Boston Phoenix and in 2008 won a Deems Taylor Award for music criticism from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

headline: The ‘Wolf’ Is Still Bending the Truth, Prosecutors Say
text: Jordan Belfort, the author of two books about his life as the rapacious “Wolf of Wall Street” and now a prominent motivational speaker, is sending mixed messages, federal prosecutors say.

headline: Global Warming
text: THE CLIMATE CASINORisk, Uncertainty, and Economics for a Warming WorldBy William NordhausYale University, $30.

headline: A Southern Landscape
text: Elizabeth Spencer published her first novel in 1948. Seven more followed, along with five volumes of short stories and the novella “The Light in the Piazza.” There would also be a play and an exquisite memoir. Now there is a new book of stories, “Starting Over.” Given that Spencer is 92, it’s tempting to call the title audacious, but since there seems to be nothing this extraordinary writer can’t do, maybe she’s just being realistic.

headline: The Music Gene
text: Is it premature to talk of the “Powers Problem”? For the last three decades, Richard Powers has been bringing out hefty novels at the rate of one every 2.5 years: 11 in all. At his current age of 56, he is, as a novelist, midway on life’s path; presumably he has another 11 or so novels still in him. Powers has won a National Book Award and has been a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize; he has been the recipient of a MacArthur “genius grant”; he has elicited lavish praise from the critics — most of them, anyway. Two of the words most frequently employed in connection with his literary output are “cerebral” and “ambitious.” “Cerebral” refers to his tendency to lace his novels with scientific and scholarly themes, like artificial intelligence in “Galatea 2.2,” game theory in “Prisoner’s Dilemma” and musicology cum genetic recombination in “The Gold Bug Variations.” “Ambitious” refers to his penchant for fashioning narrative structures and symbolic networks on a heroic scale.

headline: The There There
text: As a diminutive child growing up in the “landlocked Illinois” town of Moline, where John Deere built his plow-and-­tractor empire, Diane Johnson (author of the popular novel “Le Divorce,” among other books about Americans abroad) dreamed of a life of adventure, “preferably at sea, before the mast.” She fled the Flyover (as coastal sophisticates call the Midwest), first to New York, where she was part of the same cohort of aspiring college students at Mademoiselle magazine that Sylvia Plath recorded in “The Bell Jar,” then to her first marriage to a doctor in California and finally to France, where she now spends much of her time. “The one thing you, we, Americans, are not allowed to say is that there is somewhere better than America to live,” she writes, confidently having found “one of the better places.”

headline: Flying Through the Air
text: The snowboarder Shaun White practices at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe in preparation for the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia in February.

headline: Life in Transit
text: Elisabeth de Waal’s posthumously published novel takes place in the aftermath of some of the 20th century’s greatest calamities, as it follows Austrian exiles returning to their homeland to encounter a dramatically altered physical and psychological landscape. By 1954, when the action of the novel begins, Vienna has witnessed not only the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire but the Anschluss and Hitler’s reign of terror against the Jewish population, as well as repeated bombings during World War II and simultaneous occupation by four victorious foreign powers. Written during the late 1950s, “The Exiles Return” has an immediacy that makes de Waal’s readers feel the experiences of its characters in a visceral way.

headline: Islanders
text: If there were a prize for ornery old men, the ornithologist Jim Kennoway in Alice Greenway’s novel “The Bird Skinner” would trounce every recluse in New England. Refusing help from his remarkably well-­adjusted son and incredibly patient neighbors, he’s drinking and smoking himself to death on an island in Maine. Trudging along in this Lear-like existence — “Wintertime, Jesus Christ, he lived like a bear” — he’s taken by surprise by the ebullient Cadillac, a remarkable young woman from the Solomon Islands who comes to stay with him before studying medicine at Yale. (Thirty years prior, stationed in the Solomons during the Second World War, Jim befriended Cadillac’s father, with whom he has since lost all contact.) If this premise sounds familiar — striking young woman brings hope to forsaken old man — the style with which Greenway weaves her tale of memory and loss is bracing in its restraint.

headline: A Vengeful Fury
text: Between the early 16th century and the middle of the 19th, more than 12 million human beings were shipped against their will from Africa to the New World and sold into slavery. An untold number died at different stages of the journey — overland in Africa, during the “middle passage” at sea or soon after arrival. Among those who perished, most died of disease, some by suicide and still others from wounds or execution following failed revolts.

headline: Mystical Pizza
text: In a not-too-distant future, in a world much like our own, a young man sits in a white room, answering a white phone, listening. In his world, fast-food chains and political philosophies are one. Jack-o-Bites chefs and Whiggery Piggery employees brawl with kebab sticks in the public square, and neo-Baconians keep safe houses to protect themselves from the Cathars at the Strawberry Parfait. At the center of it all, Leonard, a customer-service rep for a Pythagorean pizza company, must save the world by time traveling and speaking to historical figures through the Neetsa Pizza support line.

headline: Dear Sasha, Dear Volodya
text: Contemporary Russia is short on pleasant surprises, but one is its formidable audience not only for the trashy novels prohibited by the Soviets but also for aggressively untraditional work. In the West, the phrase “Russian literature” typically conjures standard-bearers of ­realism — Tolstoy, Chekhov — but perhaps modern Russia is too real for realism. Imagine the madcap American fabulist Barry Yourgrau as an Oprah pick, and you have an inkling of the situation in Moscow, where bookstores are thick with nihilistic postmodern hallucinations by the likes of Vladimir Sorokin, perhaps best known for a sodomy scene between clones of Khrushchev and Stalin.

headline: Campfire Girl
text: In her first published story for The New Yorker, “Love Lessons Mondays, 9 A.M.,” Lara Vapnyar wrote about a painfully shy 18-year-old in Moscow, teaching sex ed to 10th-grade girls who have more experience than she does. By the end the young narrator is dating the school ­Lothario and laughing uncontrollably when one of her students asks why it’s just as arousing to kiss a boy she doesn’t like as one she does. The narrator’s answer: “I don’t know!”

headline: How Arbitration Worked, and What Happens Next
text: Questions and answers in connection with Alex Rodriguez’s arbitration case and the ruling, announced Saturday, that he would be suspended for the entire 2014 season.

headline: Inside the List
text: Order Now: For the first time in three weeks, there are new names on the hardcover lists — although “new” may not be the best word to describe the thriller writers W. E. B. Griffin (“Hazardous Duty,” No. 3) and Jack Higgins (“The Death Trade,” No. 11). Higgins is well known for his audacious story lines: His 1975 breakthrough, “The Eagle Has Landed,” concerned a Nazi plot to kidnap Churchill, while his 1989 best seller “A Season in Hell” imagined smugglers transporting heroin in the corpses of drowning victims. By those lights, “The Death Trade” — about a nuclear scientist forced to work for the Iranian government — seems almost workaday. Higgins’s eating habits are less colorful. “I’m notorious for liking very simple food,” he told Virgin Media in 2000. “You can take me to some of the world’s top restaurants and I’ll leave half of it on the plate. Food is not hugely important to me.” That’s not to say Higgins never dines out — a restaurant near his home in the Channel Islands doubles as his office, he explained in the same interview. “I go in at lunchtime, do two hours’ work, and then I eat,” he said. “And then in the evening I’ll go in and do three hours and then I’ll eat. I’ll write by hand and I get so absorbed it doesn’t bother me if the place is full or the music’s playing.
