It’s very common, particularly at night, for the waiters to come up and say, ‘Look, it’s 10 o’clock and you haven’t had anything to eat yet.’ ”

headline: Teller on Penn’s Idea, Tim’s Hypothesis and Vermeer’s Painting
text: The “Tim” in “Tim’s Vermeer,” shortlisted for the Oscar for best feature documentary, is Tim Jenison, an inventor and friend of the illusionists Penn and Teller. The movie grew out of a conversation Mr. Jenison had with Penn Jillette in which he casually remarked that he thought he had figured out how the 17th-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer was able to produce canvases so lifelike that they still mystify painters and art historians alike.

headline: The Execution of David O. Dodd
text: On the afternoon of Jan. 8, 1864, a crowd of 6,000 soldiers and civilians gathered on the parade grounds in front of St. John’s Masonic College in Union-occupied Little Rock, Ark. Some of the onlookers perched in trees hoping for a better view of the day’s events: the public hanging of 17-year-old David O. Dodd, a convicted Confederate spy.

headline: Chrysler to Recall Fire-Prone Jeeps to Add Trailer Hitches
text: After announcing a recall last June over a rear-impact collision fire hazard, Chrysler is finally preparing to recall nearly 1.6 million 1993-98 Jeep Grand Cherokees and 2002-7 Jeep Liberty S.U.V.'s. The fix the automaker is using to correct the problem – the vehicles’ fuel tanks are exposed to rear impacts – is controversial: Chrysler will install trailer hitches to protect the fuel tanks and reduce the chance of fires caused by rear-impact collisions.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Austria; California; Amsterdam
text: Mozart Week, Salzburg

headline: A Desperate Plot to Boost Google Plus
text: When Google launched Gmail, Internet users quickly began using the service. Same with Google Maps. But the company has struggled to get people to try Google Plus, its answer to Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Bookshelf: Friends in Fur
text: New picture books about bears include “Cub’s Big World,” by Sarah L. Thomson.

headline: Obama to Nominate 3 to the Board of the Fed
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate three people to the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors, including Stanley Fischer, former head of the Bank of Israel, as the Fed’s next vice chairman, the White House said on Friday.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Empire of Necessity’
text: This week, Greg Grandin talks about “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Coral Davenport discusses new books about global warming; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: When Tourists Rescue Scientists in Antarctica
text: After I covered efforts to evacuate the participants in the ice-trapped Antarctic “Spirit of Mawson” expedition, an interesting comment was posted by Ted Cheeseman, the co-owner of Cheesemans’ Ecology Safaris, which runs frequent Antarctic tourist trips. He noted that tourist ships have come to the aid of scientists on occasion, and expressed concern that I was implying that tourists have no right to visit the region. I invited him to send a “Your Dot” piece building on his comment. Here it is (I added some contextual links):

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Empire of Necessity’
text: This week, Greg Grandin and Coral Davenport.

headline: Times Minute | Unfinished Art
text: Also on the Minute, a disappointing jobs report and Shaun White gets a makeover for Sochi.

headline: Times Minute | Unfinished Art
text: In the Video

headline: Detecting a New Season
text: The winter television season brings more significant new shows than ever this year, starting this weekend with HBO’s “True Detective” and including that network’s “Looking”; Fox’s Greg Kinnear vehicle, “Rake”; Sundance’s “Red Road”; and USA’s “Sirens,” from Denis Leary. But the big news is likely to be made by the shows that are coming back: “The Following” on Fox, “The Americans” on FX, Netflix’s “House of Cards” and, perhaps best of all, the long-awaited third season of “Sherlock” on PBS.

headline: U.S. to Recognize 1,300 Marriages Disputed by Utah
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday made the latest contribution to a fast-moving legal battle over same-sex marriage rights as the Justice Department said that the federal government would recognize as lawful the marriages of some 1,300 same-sex couples in Utah even though the state government is largely refusing to do so.

headline: Now Starring as the Jerk You Can Feel For
text: CULVER CITY, Calif — In an early episode of the new Fox series “Rake,” the down-and-out defense lawyer Keegan Deane, a middle-aged mess of a human being played by Greg Kinnear, is asked by his ex-wife how the man she once loved, a brilliant advocate and caring father, ended up this way.

headline: Air Rights: A Cash Bonanza?
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Hangover: Cantilevered Buildings of New York
text: Casting a glance skyward in Manhattan these days may include the risk of beholding not sky but horizontal appendages that curve and jut outward from the sides of residential towers and hover like geometric mutants above the roofs of vertically challenged neighbors, inhabiting space once occupied by open air.

headline: An Odd Couple, Separated by 55 Years, but Not by Much Else
text: It was after midnight on a recent night at Sevilla, a Spanish restaurant in the West Village, and waiters wandered the aisles, watching the last two diners finish their second pitcher of sangria.

headline: ‘Idol’ Tries to Clean Up Its Act
text: Another season of “American Idol” begins Wednesday; perhaps you haven’t noticed.

headline: Weill Named Chairman of Hamilton Insurance
text: Sandford I. Weill, the former head of Citigroup, is preparing for his third act in the insurance industry.

headline: Ears for Opera, Eyes on the Future
text: On a bulletin board in her tiny, tidy Upper East Side apartment, Beth Morrison has displayed a quotation by the librettist and theatrical producer Oscar Hammerstein II since she first moved to New York City in 2005. Printed on a rumpled, coffee-stained scrap of paper, the note enumerates qualities that in Hammerstein’s view characterize the mysterious job of a theater producer: “a hopeful innocent in fair weather, a stern pilot in stormy weather, a mathematician who prefers to ignore the laws of mathematics and trust intuition, a realist, a practical dreamer, a sophisticated gambler, a stage-struck child.”

headline: Playing With Tracks
text: The song “When the Night Time Comes” by NightBus is recorded in an unusual way — with two completely different, complementary versions of the song on the left and right channels.

headline: A Window to Bone Disease in a ‘Shark’s’ Skeleton
text: An elephant shark’s skeleton is made up largely of cartilage, not bone. Now, researchers have found a possible explanation that could help in the development of treatments for bone diseases like osteoporosis.

headline: Negotiators Move Closer on Iran Nuclear Pact
text: Iran and a group of six world powers moved closer on Friday to carrying out the nuclear agreement reached in November, with the Iranian side saying all outstanding issues have been resolved.

headline: Corporate Takeover? In 2013, a Lawsuit Almost Always Followed
text: These days, you can be sure that when a company announces it is being acquired, it will also be sued by a bevy of plaintiffs’ lawyers.

headline: Husband-and-Wife Architecture Firms Compete for Vancouver Commission
text: As they find themselves at odds over the Museum of Modern Art’s renovation announced this week, the architecture firms Diller Scofidio + Renfro and Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects now also find themselves competing over a new commission. (Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio are married to each other, as are Mr. Williams and Ms. Tsien.)

headline: On French TV, No Twerking Before 10
text: Those French – they can be such prudes. The Conseil Superieur de l’Audiovisuel, the body that oversees French broadcasting standards, has decided that the promotional video clips for Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball” and Britney Spears’s “Work Bitch” should be effectively banished from daytime and early evening television in France.

headline: John Zorn to Present Latest Installment in His Masada Project
text: John Zorn, the tirelessly prolific composer, organizer and genre-scrambler, will throw open the doors to yet another wing of his rambling musical estate this spring, with the premiere of “John Zorn’s Masada Book Three: The Book Beriah.” The work will be presented on March 19 at the Town Hall, in a concert involving roughly 20 ensembles, including the Masada String Trio, the Jamie Saft Trio, Fieldwork and Secret Chiefs 3. Mr. Zorn is scheduled to perform on alto saxophone with Aleph Trio, which includes Shanir Blumenkranz on bass and Ches Smith on drums. Tickets will be available on Monday through Ticketmaster and the Town Hall box office.

headline: Lobster Stirs Up the Sauce
text: In Rome several years ago, at the all-fish restaurant Quinzi & Gabrieli, I was served a lobster pasta as a first course that haunts me still. Somehow the dish was simultaneously delicate and robust — wide, silky pappardelle noodles napped with a creamy yet intensely piquant sauce.

headline: Utah Gay Marriages to be Honored by U.S.
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. says the United States will recognize same-sex marriages officiated in Utah, despite a decision by the state not to do so.

headline: The Churchill War Rooms Greet Savile Row
text: Suzy Menkes visits the historic landmark where London's bespoke tailors displayed their finest.

headline: Shimmery Orchestrations, With a Tinge of Philip Glass
text: Jherek Bischoff, a songwriter and arranger from Seattle, made his 2012 debut album, “Composed” (Brassland), with low-budget digital diligence. He built the album’s orchestral arrangements by recording one instrument at a time on his laptop. He then drew on some impressive contacts to add vocals, among them David Byrne, Caetano Veloso, Nika Danilova (better known as Zola Jesus), Zac Pennington of Parenthetical Girls and the indie-pop songwriter Mirah Zeitlyn, along with drumming from Greg Saunier of Deerhoof. They recognized a fellow pop experimenter.

headline: More Snow Days, Fewer Sick Days
text: The nonfarm payroll numbers for December came in much worse than expected. One possible reason, economists speculate, could have to do with unusually bad winter weather.

headline: Google+ Hangout on Human Trafficking
text: Nick Kristof is doing a Google+ Hangout with leaders in the global fight against modern slavery. He will be talking with Rachel Lloyd, of Girls Educational & Mentoring Services, Gary Haugen, of the International Justice Mission, Dave Batstone, of Not For Sale, and Susan Bissell, of UNICEF about what 2014 holds for efforts to combat human trafficking worldwide. Tune in below, to what promises to be a thought provoking conversation.

headline: Hold Up, We’re Not Through With 2013
text: Let’s postpone 2014 for the length of a Playlist — a handful of deserving 2013 albums that almost got away.

headline: Money Flows to the Biggest Buyout Funds
text: In the world of private equity, it may help to be big.

headline: All That Craft, and Now Some Abandon
text: Almost three years ago, Michele Wiles performed her final “Swan Lake” with American Ballet Theater. She kept the occasion so private that her partner didn’t even realize what was going on. Driven by an urge to experience ballet in a new way, Ms. Wiles didn’t so much retire from the company as slip away.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Empire of Necessity’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Delbanco reviews Greg Grandin’s “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World.” Mr. Delbanco writes:

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in London
text: The first round of men’s fashion shows this year, London Collections: Men, have come to an end. From street-wear-inspired looks to the more refined and elegant clothing we expect from England’s capital, here are the five best shows from the Fall/Winter 2014 runways so far.

headline: Role Reversals Emerge in Dispute Over Obama’s Recess Appointments
text: WASHINGTON — C. Boyden Gray, the former White House counsel and ambassador, is among the conservative lawyers urging the Supreme Court to severely constrain the Obama administration’s ability to fill executive branch vacancies during a Senate recess. Mr. Gray is exceptionally well versed in the subject, having received his own recess appointment in 2006.

headline: Jobs Data Gives Hope for Benefits Extension
text: WASHINGTON — The surprisingly weak December jobs report might have strengthened Democrats’ hand in the current fight over emergency jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed even as it weakened the party in the larger midterm election battle.

headline: House Votes to Increase Security Measures on Health Care Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Friday to strengthen security protections on the HealthCare.gov website, requiring all security breaches of the health insurance exchanges to be reported in a timely fashion.

headline: W.V. Governor Issues Warning on Water
text: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin urged affected residents to avoid using tap water after a chemical spill in West Virginia.

headline: Robert Gates Skewers the Ugliest Branch of Government
text: What are all those congressional hearing witnesses privately thinking as they face pompous inquisition from phalanxes of ambitious lawmakers tossing gotcha questions like grenades? “Congress is best viewed from a distance — the farther the better — because up close, it is truly ugly,” advises former Defense Secretary Robert Gates, in his new Washington tell-all, “Duty: Memoirs of a Secretary at War.”

headline: Tonics and Teas
text: Last week, in the course of cleaning out my office and downsizing my cookbook library, I came across an interesting book called “Tonics” by Robert A. Barnett. The book is a collection of recipes, not just for liquid tonics, but for all sorts of dishes made with foods and herbs thought to improve well being.

headline: ‘12 Years’ Will Win, No, ‘Gravity,’ No ...
text: The Academy Award nominations will be announced Thursday, but Oscar pundits don’t like to wait until the field is narrowed down to make their predictions. In fact, they often don’t like to wait till the films have even been released. Nearly six months before the actual ceremony on March 2, predictions were already being made and second-guessed. Here’s a look at how the best picture race has already been won and lost several times over, following the fortunes of “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: A Collector’s Paradise
text: Rudy’s Hobby & Art in Astoria, Queens, has became a repository for many hard-to-find items, not just in Astoria but the entire city.

headline: A Hobby Shop Endures Despite Changes Around It
text: Planes, trains and automobiles — and a colorful assortment of rosary beads.

headline: Horror Thriller Has Major Bite in Israel
text: During a screening of “Piranha 3D” last year in Tel Aviv, the filmmaker Navot Papushado found himself near two girls who were clearly under-age and squirming at the graphic imagery. He escorted them from the room.

headline: Big Ticket | A Photographer’s Refuge for $28.5 Million
text: The quaint collage of ivy-covered brick townhouses that the celebrity photographer Annie Leibovitz assembled in the West Village a decade ago and eventually transformed into a leafy compound where she lived, worked and entertained guests, sold for $28.5 million in two separate deals to the same buyer and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Blood Ties and Crossed Wires
text: Years after the fact, two children are found to have gone home from the maternity ward with the wrong parents. They have grown up in very different circumstances, and their biological parents now face difficult choices. The premise for the ABC Family drama “Switched at Birth”? Yes, but it also describes “Like Father, Like Son,” an affecting film from the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda. In this story, the children are 6. One, Keita, has been raised in overprotective affluence, an only child. The other, Ryusei, grew up in humbler circumstances, with siblings and amid carefree chaos.

headline: Reaction to Resignation of Central African Republic President
text: Residents in the Central African Republic celebrated the resignation of their president, Michel Djotodia, as a potential turning point in the recent fighting in their country. Many hoped it would signal an end to the violence between Mr. Djotodia’s Muslim rebel group, Seleka, and the Christian militia groups who oppose it.

headline: Leaps and Bounds and Discoveries
text: The American Realness Festival is the kind of event that has descriptions of performances that say things like “Taking inspiration from ballet, psychoanalysis, queer theory and Marxism ... ” (Jillian Peña’s “Polly Pocket”) or, “At a small-town tap studio, four dancers prepare for a competition” (Tina Satter’s “House of Dance”). You never know what you’re going to get at American Realness, running through next Sunday, which Ben Pryor started five years ago. If you are curious about the latest in contemporary dance, then wander through the scheduling madness of American Realness, dipping in and out at will. There are established names like Miguel Gutierrez, Ishmael Houston-Jones and Neal Medlyn; there are names less known to American audiences, like Marten Spangberg and Eszter Salamon; there are exhibitions (Sarah Maxfield, Ian Douglas, Mr. Medlyn and Fawn Krieger, Ann Liv Young); there are parties; there will be discoveries. (At the Abrons Arts Center and other New York City locations; americanrealness.com.)

headline: The Gun Report: January 10, 2014
text: A federal judge has ruled that it is unconstitutional to prohibit licensed gun stores from operating in Chicago, the epicenter of the nation’s gun violence. The ruling would also make it legal for adults to transfer ownership of a firearm through a private sale as long as the recipient has a firearm owner’s identification card.

headline: Off the Charts: Japanese Economy Shows Life
text: In 2013, the Japanese stock market rose at the fastest rate since 1972 as deflation appeared to end.

headline: Back in the Pulpit After Losing His Church, and Still Supporting Gay Marriage
text: SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn. — Three below zero on a Minnesota morning, and the Rev. Oliver White stomps the snow off his boots as he enters the stucco edifice of Clark Memorial United Church of Christ to lead worship. He peels off an overcoat to reveal the kente-cloth vestments his wife made for him, which match the kufi hat he wears.

headline: Bulls to Angels in Spanish Drawing
text: The Morgan Library & Museum has long been known for its extraordinary collection of drawings — nearly 12,000 of them from the 14th through the 21st centuries — especially examples of Italian, Dutch and French old masters. Less known and rarely shown, however, is a small but outstanding group of Spanish drawings.

headline: High Culture, In the Basement
text: In town for concerts as part of his New York Philharmonic residency, the pianist Yefim Bronfman devotes Monday evening to Contact!, the orchestra’s new-music series. At the lower-level Greenwich Village space SubCulture, he will give the premiere of “Passions, Reflected,” a Schumann-influenced work for solo piano by Marc Neikrug, who has a long relationship with the Philharmonic. Joined by two of the orchestra’s string players, Mr. Bronfman will also perform Marc-André Dalbavie’s Piano Trio No. 1 (2008); others in the string section will play Poul Ruders’s String Quartet No. 4 (2012). (7:30 p.m., 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, 212-875-5030, nyphil.org.)

headline: Government Stimulus Lifts Japan
text: HAS Japan turned the economic corner?

headline: Exclusive | 995 Fifth Avenue
text: An eight-room simplex on the 6th-floor is about to enter the market at $13.5 million. The building occupies a prime spot opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Museum Mile Elegance
text: A svelte eight-room simplex that blends classic Museum Mile elegance, European élan and the open-ended entertainment flow of a luxury downtown loft is poised to enter the market at $13.5 million.

headline: Top Editor at People Magazine Leaving Time Inc.
text: Time Inc. shook up its management on Friday as it prepared itself to be spun off from the media conglomerate Time Warner into an independent company.

headline: Shakespeare Double-Bill to Be Treated as Two Shows for Tony Eligibility
text: Contrary to the producers’ wishes, the Broadway double-bill of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III” will be treated as two separate shows for the purposes of the Tony Awards, and not as a joint production, the committee that oversees Tony award eligibility ruled on Thursday.

headline: The Racecar Driver at Rest
text: When Lucas Bize is not reading J. D. Salinger for his high school literature class, he is speeding around racetracks in his Mustang at up to 170 miles per hour. Mr. Bize, who lives on the Upper West Side, is a senior at the Professional Children’s School, also called P.C.S., and a professional racecar driver. At 18, he is the youngest driver on the Racers Edge Motorsports team. On Sundays before a race, besides sleeping in and then hanging out with friends, he will study as much as he can about a track. Occasionally he will go with his parents, Alex, 56, and Evelyne, 45, to their home in Montauk, N.Y., where he can practice using a racing simulator, a computer with a large monitor and a wheel attached. Mr. Bize learned to race by tagging along to tracks with his father, a former business partner of Jay Z in the clothing line Rocawear, and his brother, Dennis, 22; both race only for fun now. Mr. Bize’s mother works as his manager. His sister, Natasha, 20, recently moved to Charlotte, N.C., for college.

headline: 52 Places to Go in 2014
text: From No. 1 Cape Town all the way to No. 52 Niagara Falls, N.Y., explore the vibrant cities and spectacular coastlines, unexpected spots and new attractions that made our list this year.

headline: Symphony Space Artistic Director Resigns
text: Laura Kaminsky, the artistic director of Symphony Space since 2010, and the overseer of its music programming since 2006, said on Friday that she had resigned her position. In a telephone interview, she described her departure as amicable, and said that she would stay on until March 30. But both she and a spokesman for the hall also said that they were parting ways because of “differences in artistic vision for the future” of the space. A press announcement said that the space would begin a search for Ms. Kaminsky’s successor immediately.

headline: Deft Hands Keep Figure Skaters Looking Sharp
text: BOSTON — The United States figure skating championships had not yet opened Thursday when a skater had a wardrobe malfunction at ice dance practice. Not to worry.

headline: American Man, After Jail Term in U.A.E., Says He Was Tried by ‘Kangaroo Court’
text: An American man who was accused of endangering national security in the United Arab Emirates — after making a satirical video about a fictitious combat school — said on his return to the United States on Friday that he was given the one-year jail term by a “kangaroo court.”

headline: Pint-Size Players, Texas-Size Fervor
text: There’s no quitting in football. But there’s plenty of blood, sweat and tears when you’re a baby linebacker exhausted in 99-degree heat, and the coach orders you to bear-crawl across the field. “I don’t care how much pain you’re in,” bellows Charles Chavarria, a former Marine, at his team, the Junior Broncos. “You don’t quit.”

headline: Harking Back to Country’s Roots
text: For 10 days in the summer of 1927, the Victor Talking Machine Company set up shop in Bristol, Tenn., recording a hodgepodge of hopefuls for possible release. The Bristol Sessions, as we now know them, included the first commercial recordings of Jimmie Rodgers and the Carter Family, which is one reason the sessions are often described as the big bang of country music.

headline: Can I Just Pick Your Brain?
text: This week in SundayBusiness, the Workologist — a column by Rob Walker that addresses workplace conundrums — tackles a topic that many business owners will find familiar. How do you handle requests for advice from aspiring entrepreneurs?

headline: For the Couple That Loves Joe and Chai
text: Gifts for coffee and tea lovers.

headline: Fighting ‘Observation’ Status
text: Every year, thousands of Medicare patients who spend time in the hospital for observation but are not officially admitted find they are not eligible for nursing home coverage after discharge.

headline: Your Comments on Places to Go in 2014
text: Each year we compile a list of places to go in the coming year. And each year we hear from readers: agreements, disagreements, celebration, anger, bewilderment.

headline: How We Chose Our List of Places to Go in 2014
text: Each January, the editors of the Travel section publish our Places to Go issue. And each year after it runs, readers wonder why their favorite destination was overlooked or why their least favorite made the top 10. In order to add some clarity to the process, we’ve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our list of 52 Places to Go in 2014.

headline: Bridge Scandal Papers Point to Cover-Up by Chris Christie Allies
text: Officials loyal to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey went to elaborate lengths to make it appear that the September closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge was part of a traffic study, even though their private communications suggest the move was purely political, according to documents released on Friday.

headline: Wheelies: The Ford Is Watching Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: From Tweet to Ad to Mini Modern Scandal
text: If you’ve seen “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the latest movie by Joel and Ethan Coen, you know that it has an unusual narrative structure: The story unwinds along a loose, rambling path and then loops back on itself, catching hold of (if not quite swallowing) its own tail. The story I’m about to tell has a similar shape. It’s hard to say where it begins or ends and even more difficult to say what it all means.

headline: An Anxious Sally Hawkins, Onstage and in Auditions
text: Sally Hawkins was visibly and audibly nervous presenting an award to her “Blue Jasmine” co-star Cate Blanchett at the New York Film Critics Circle ceremony on Monday – her hands were shaking as she turned the pages of her speech, which praised Ms. Blanchett for operating “at a much higher vibration.” So just imagine how terrified she was auditioning for Woody Allen.

headline: A Scarcity of New One-Bedrooms
text: For decades, one-bedroom apartments have been a fixture of New York. But finding one going forward, at least in new developments, may become as hard as hailing a cab in a downpour.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Shows in Search of Direction
text: I SORT OF LOST INTEREST in the London men’s collections once I had clicked through the first day or two of shows.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Jackson
text: Yes, I know it’s only Friday afternoon in New York. But I’m in Stockholm, where it’s 11 degrees and dropping fast, and I wanted something to make me think of warmer climes. And Rhiannon Giddens is always a good thing, especially when she fiddles as well as sings:

headline: New York City F.C. Introduces a Philosophy Along With Its Coach
text: There was much talk about soccer philosophy and very little about actual soccer players when New York City F.C. introduced Jason Kreis as its first head coach on Friday. But it will have to be that way for a while.

headline: Justices Take Case on Free TV Streaming
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to resolve a dispute between television broadcasters and Aereo, an Internet start-up that the networks say threatens the economic viability of their businesses.

headline: Remembrance of News Past
text: WITHIN just over a year we’ve seen the Newtown shootings, the bombing at the Boston Marathon and the rescue of the kidnapped women in Cleveland. But which details of these events will you remember in a year? In five years? Will you remember the names of the perpetrators or the victims, the places where they happened, or the month and the year?

headline: Women of a Higher Calling
text: More women are becoming pastors as denominations proliferate and churches form in nontraditional spaces, such as storefronts.

headline: All December Job Gains Went to Women
text: American employers added 74,000 jobs in December on net. All of that employment increase was a result of new jobs filled by women.

headline: Underlining the Recovery’s Shortfall
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: In Brooklyn, Female Pastors on the Rise
text: Storefronts of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick have given rise to many Christian congregations. Over the years, these nontraditional church spaces have been a launch pad for female pastors.

headline: Video reviews of ‘The Rocket,’ ‘Cold Comes the Night’ and ‘In Bloom’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “The Rocket,” “Cold Comes the Night” and “In Bloom.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: For Alex Prager, It’s Lonely in a Crowd
text: The photographer Alex Prager’s new solo exhibition, “A Face in the Crowd,” opened at the Chelsea and Lower East Side galleries of Lehmann Maupin last night. Using both still and moving images, the Los Angeles native riffs on the way individuals function in a large group: Physical proximity does not necessarily equate closeness, but there are a million stories in an anonymous mass.

headline: Something to Really Talk About
text: Before they became lovers, Stephanie Segura and Becca Sicairos were nearly inseparable, friends with opposite outlooks and personalities, like Bert and Ernie from “Sesame Street,” Ms. Segura laughs, “but without the thick eyebrows.”

headline: Movie Review: 'The Rocket'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Rocket."

headline: Newly Released Files in the New Jersey Bridge Scandal
text: Hundreds of pages of communications related to the scheme to close several lanes leading onto the George Washington Bridge in September were released Friday.

headline: Hugo Lindgren Named Acting Editor of Hollywood Reporter
text: Hugo Lindgren, who stepped down as editor of The New York Times Magazine in November, will become acting editor of The Hollywood Reporter for the next three months, according to a Twitter post by Janice Min, who held that job before being promoted.

headline: Chicken Stew With Sweet Plantains
text: Melissa Clark transforms a traditional chicken stew into a dish hinting at the tropical with the addition of sweet plantains and citrus juices.

headline: It’s Bitesize Captain Kirk
text: William Shatner managed to fit a lot more than just “Star Trek” anecdotes into his did-that-actually-happen? Broadway solo show in 2012. But the epistemological underpinnings of art, science and contemporary civilization were somehow left underdeveloped amid the talk of Ben Folds and “T. J. Hooker.”

headline: Women at the Pulpit
text: Nearly 20 years ago, when the Rev. Susie Elliott, 83, preached her first sermon at Mt. Paran Baptist Church on the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick, she was an anomaly in Brooklyn’s male-dominated world of Christian pastors.

headline: Movie Review: 'In Bloom'
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "In Bloom."

headline: This Bird’s Gone South
text: A bubbling pot of chicken stew with potatoes is a hearty, comforting thing. But substitute sweet plantains for the tubers, and suddenly your dinner leaps from familiar and predictable to unexpected and a whole lot more interesting — at least for someone who doesn’t eat plantains very regularly.

headline: Movie Review: 'Cold Comes the Night'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis "Cold Comes the Night."

headline: BlackBerry Chief Drops ‘Interim’ Label
text: OTTAWA — With little fanfare, John S. Chen has dropped “interim” from his title as chief executive of BlackBerry, the struggling smartphone maker .

headline: A Musical and House of Scandal
text: There’s nothing like a scandal to attract an audience. That’s good news for Andrew Lloyd Webber, whose latest musical, “Stephen Ward,” is based on a British scandal so licentious that it resulted in the resignation of two government officials and the suicide of the show’s title character.

headline: Premier Urges Award for Boy Who Halted Pakistan Attack
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Friday recommended that a high civil award for bravery be bestowed on a teenager who was killed this week while stopping a suicide bomber from attacking his school in northwestern Pakistan.

headline: SodaStream to Bring Some Heat to Super Bowl Ad With Scarlett Johansson
text: In the movie “Her,” Scarlett Johansson personifies new technology by providing the voice of an operating system. In a Super Bowl commercial, she will try something similar by providing a demonstration of a SodaStream home soda-making system.

headline: Actors’ Union to Discuss Pay for Touring Musicals
text: In response to growing frustrations among some members, the Actors’ Equity union will hold a town hall meeting on Jan. 27 to discuss salaries and contracts for touring productions of musicals, an issue that also drew scores of actors to a regional Equity meeting in New York on Friday afternoon.

headline: Luke Steyn Gives Zimbabwe Someone to Cheer for in Winter Olympics
text: In this week’s One-Page Magazine, I make note of Luke Steyn, an Alpine skier who will become the first athlete ever to represent the tropical African nation of Zimbabwe in the Winter Olympics next month in Sochi, Russia. In an email exchange over the holidays, Steyn said he knew that his nationality will make him something of a curiosity among competitors and the media.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Chelsea condo with full-time doormen; an Inwood postwar co-op; and a South Slope penthouse.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: In Cranbury Village, a 1861 Victorian; and a Westchester contemporary on one acre.

headline: Fleeing a Backwater to Lunge at Happiness
text: There is something not quite normal about Paul, the teenager at the center of Willa Cather’s 1905 short story “Paul’s Case,” and everyone around him knows it. Cather memorably illuminates the outward manifestations of the boy’s dandyish disaffection: “His eyes were remarkable for a certain hysterical brilliancy, and he continually used them in a conscious, theatrical sort of way, peculiarly offensive in a boy.” Among his trespasses: a red carnation in his threadbare lapel.

headline: Yo, What’s Shaking? Not These Movers
text: The main characters of “Lucas Bros. Moving Co.,” a new addition to Fox’s late-Saturday-night collection of 15-minute animated series, have a lot in common with their creators. Kenny and Keef, like Keith and Kenny Lucas (who are also the show’s main writers and voice actors), are young black twins who live in a mythical place called Brooklyn.

headline: A Central Park Ice Hockey Referee Shares Some Secrets
text: By the third period, Bill Marshall really regretted not putting those heat packets in his skates.

headline: Is The Times Giving Proper Credit on the Christie-Bridge Story?
text: The explosive story surrounding Gov. Chris Christie this week is bringing well-deserved praise to The Record, the newspaper in northern New Jersey that has been chipping away at it for months.

headline: A Hybrid Pioneer Is Back in the Hunt
text: You might assume that Honda and hybrids go together like Bordeaux and a juicy steak. But despite a reputation for practical and fuel-efficient cars, Honda has largely whiffed on the hybrid front. That has to be vexing for a company that pioneered the hybrid in America, with the two-seat, podlike Insight that beat the Toyota Prius to market in 1999.

headline: Immigrants and Red Scare Case Studies
text: Some years ago, Dr. Gabor Nagy, chairman of the Budapest City Council’s Committee on Human Rights and Minorities (the largest minority in his city was Gypsies), was shocked by what he viewed as the Balkanization of the New York City Council.

headline: White House, in Gates’s Telling, Restrained Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — In the early scorekeeping of winners and losers in “Duty,” Robert M. Gates’s unsparing account of his days as defense secretary, Hillary Rodham Clinton has fared better than either President Obama or Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Sudan, the West Bank, Bangladesh and Jordan.

headline: Tea Party Delays Spending, Beats Dead Horse
text: It will only cover three days, but once again next week Congress will have to pass a continuing resolution to keep the government open. The current resolution expires on Wednesday, and even though a budget agreement was reached last month, appropriators in both chambers still haven’t nailed down a plan to tell various agencies what they can spend.

headline: Honda’s Hybrid Do-Over
text: Honda has returned to the hybrid front with better technology that is fitted to the latest, acclaimed redesign of the Accord sedan.

headline: Court Returns Stolen Renoir Painting to Baltimore Museum of Art
text: A Renoir painting said to have been bought at a Virginia flea market will be returned to the Baltimore Museum of Art, from where it was stolen more than 60 years ago, a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: Review: 2014 Chevrolet Traverse
text: Need practical wheels with room for the family? The spacious three-row Chevrolet Traverse is practically a family room on wheels.

headline: A Fork? De Blasio’s Way of Eating Pizza Is Mocked
text: The pizza arrived, steaming and delectable, a smoked-mozzarella-and-sausage pie presented to Mayor Bill de Blasio like a gilded offering to a visiting caliph.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Miley Cyrus’s Latest Drama, The Row’s Seasoned Models and DVF’s 40th Anniversary
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 4 – 10

headline: Prada to Aid Restoration of Vasari’s ‘Last Supper’
text: Giorgio Vasari’s “The Last Supper,” an imposing wood-panel painting that was almost destroyed in a 1966 flood in Florence and has been undergoing restoration for more than four years, will be the beneficiary of a grant by the Prada company that conservators hope will allow them to bring the work back to public view.

headline: As Shop Owner, Woman Sees Troubling Sides of Herself
text: Living in New York can curiously and frequently feel like an exercise played out on a narrow emotional field, a continual toggle between envy and guilt. You wish for more; so many others seem to have it, after all — more space, nicer furniture, a greater number of things from Lululemon. But you also harbor a discomfort at possessing plenty while legions haven’t nearly enough. In any given hour you might veer from feeling unduly blessed to woefully disadvantaged. It is not the job of politics to solve the problem of this kind of split perspective, but it remains one of the chief psychological byproducts of inequality for those who occupy a place in the city’s vast and steeply tiered middle class.

headline: American Freed From Prison in United Arab Emirates
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An American who was detained and sentenced to a year in prison in the United Arab Emirates after posting a video online that satirized Dubai youth culture has returned to the United States after being released.

headline: Long-Eared Owls, Built for Stealth, Often Go Unnoticed
text: The long-eared owl’s plumage is a tapestry of warm and cool grays, tawny browns and chestnut highlights. Some of nature’s most lavish camouflage, it is as close to bark as a bird can produce.

headline: A New Cultural Venue, Southampton Center, Hires Its First Director
text: The Southampton Center, a new cultural organization at the Parrish Art Museum’s former site, on Jobs Lane in Southampton Village, N.Y., has hired Michele Thompson as its first director.

headline: Twitter Gears Up for Second Fiction Festival
text: Get ready for some #seriouslyshortstories. The second annual Twitter Fiction Festival is slated for March 12-16.

headline: A Mix That, Unabashedly, Doesn’t Really Mesh at All
text: Listeners can discern links between eclectic works on a program in various ways, often by style or nationality, or perhaps the way one composer influences another. But no obvious aesthetic threads wove through the polyglot lineup on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. In the New York Philharmonic’s program book, the music director, Alan Gilbert, described the offerings as a “bouquet of varied masterpieces.”

headline: Determining New York City’s Record Wind Chill
text: Q. Tuesday’s freeze was hideous. What was the lowest wind-chill temperature ever recorded in New York City?

headline: Rethinking How Baseball's 'Greats' Are Chosen
text: Does the voting process for the Baseball Hall of Fame need to be changed?

headline: A Coupling as Bizarre as the Murder
text: The success of HBO’s new Sunday night crime drama, “True Detective,” depends on two pairs of men, a couple of veterans and a couple of relative rookies. Upfront, and drawing all the attention, are the movie stars Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, playing a mismatched team of Louisiana state cops.

headline: Actor-Doctor
text: Clancy O'Connor, the understudy for the play "Buyer & Cellar," talks about the demands of his job.

headline: The Power of Imagination
text: Clancy O’Connor on his strategy for perfecting comedic timing while rehearsing on stage in front of an empty house.

headline: Americans Traveling to Winter Games Cautioned
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department issued a travel advisory on Friday cautioning Americans planning to attend the Winter Olympics next month in Sochi, Russia, that terrorists have threatened to attack the Games. The advisory also expressed concern about the quality of medical care in the region, noting that it could “differ substantially from Western standards.”

headline: Even Cheap Wine Can Work a Little Magic
text: It’s unusual for a tragedy-obsessed art form, but for the last month or so, the fare at the Metropolitan Opera has been dominated by works that end happily and without too many bodies piled up. There have been runs of Strauss’s elegant “Der Rosenkavalier” and Mozart’s sublime “The Magic Flute,” as well as new productions of Verdi’s merry “Falstaff” and Johann Strauss Jr.’s frothy “Die Fledermaus.” (If you really needed death, “Tosca” and “Eugene Onegin” were there, too.)

headline: Hope Under the Grip of Oppression
text: Paulo Bruscky’s career as an artist began in a difficult time and place: Recife, Brazil, a few years after the 1964 coup that led to a dictatorship lasting nearly 20 years. Like other artists — and anyone who came under government suspicion — Mr. Bruscky was arrested (more than once), interrogated and tortured. But focusing only on the violent context of his work undermines what it set out to prove, which is that radical art can flourish even in repressive circumstances, and that it can be a form of communication, liberation and optimism, as the title “Paulo Bruscky: Art Is Our Last Hope” suggests. Installed at the Bronx Museum, the exhibition includes 140 works of sculpture, performance documentation, mail art and photography made between 1971 and 2011.

headline: Ethnic Segregation at a U.N. Camp in South Sudan
text: Reporting from South Sudan on Friday, the BBC correspondent Alastair Leithead discovered that civilians taking refuge from fighting at a United Nations base outside the town of Bentiu were being segregated along ethnic lines by the peacekeepers.

headline: A Rising Tide of Record Sales May Not Lift All Boats
text: The cluster of six collector-car auctions that get underway in the Phoenix area this week — and a 3,000-car sale by Mecum Auctions a week later in Florida — come five years after a major market correction, possibly providing clarity and insight on the state of the recovery.

headline: Measures of the Collectible-Car Market
text: Rob Sass looks at some of the cars to be offered in the Arizona auctions this week that may provide a gauge of value trends.

headline: Tech Companies and White House Discuss Surveillance Reform
text: Representatives from tech companies including Google, Twitter, Yahoo and Microsoft met on Friday with White House staff members to discuss Internet surveillance reforms.

headline: The F-150’s Aluminum Diet
text: DETROIT — When Ford rolls out its redesigned F-150 pickup truck here on Monday morning to kick off two days of press previews for the 2014 North American International Auto Show, the automaker will be making one of the boldest product gambles in its 111-year history.

headline: Ice Truck Starts, Moves and Melts, but No Heated Seats
text: OTTAWA — With no inkling that the polar vortex would freeze much of North America in January, executives at Canadian Tire, the country’s leading retailer of automotive and household goods, managed to hit on what proved a timely topic — ice — when they developed a winter advertising campaign for a new product.

headline: At CES, Wired Cars Reach Out
text: LAS VEGAS — Not that long ago, a telephone meant a black two-piece unit with a handset and a rotary dial. Nowadays, the telephone has been completely redefined as a smartphone capable of performing an exponentially expanding array of tasks.

headline: Magical Crockery, Pop Music Parody, a Hula Hoop and Other Experiments
text: American Realness, a small-scale annual performance festival of the Abrons Arts Center, began just after 7 on Thursday evening with the audience seated onstage at the center’s playhouse. In a 45-minute solo show titled “Wonder,” a naked woman, Michelle Boulé, briskly paced a figure-eight pattern around the space with a fixed smile for several minutes, to some mild rock music. Later she donned dancewear and, at one point, a full-length blue gown and matching wig.

headline: Times Minute | Recognizing Gay Marriages
text: Also on the Minute, tabloid trouble in Paris for President Francois Hollande and monuments of the forgotten in New York City.

headline: Times Minute | Recognizing Gay Marriages
text: In the Video

headline: In Insider Case, Harvard Classmates on Different Sides of the Court
text: In May 1999, on the stately campus of Harvard Law School, Mathew Martoma was facing expulsion for doctoring his grades in the hopes of securing a coveted judicial clerkship.

headline: Playing Bridge Onboard the Silver Whisper
text: Slow down, you play too fast. You got to make the winners last. Just kickin’ down the trump tricks. Looking for fun and feelin’ groovy.

headline: In This Dance Performance, Love Takes a New Shape
text: The vibrant, convivial and unfussy American Realness performance festival, now in its fifth year, is at Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side through January 19. Debuting last night was “13 Love Songs: dot dot dot”, the first evening-length collaboration between friends Ishmael Houston-Jones, a downtown dance pillar in his 60s who still fearlessly puts his body through brutal and manic paces, and Emily Wexler, a big-boned, flame-haired 30-something who matches his self-flagellating bravado.

headline: Moelis Is Said to Ready a Potential Public Offering
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank founded by Kenneth D. Moelis, has begun working with advisers on a potential initial public offering, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Stop Asking Me for My Email Address
text: It’s hard out there for a paranoid cybersecurity reporter.

headline: Contractor for Health Portal Replaced, but Says ‘We Were Not Fired’
text: OTTAWA — The contractor hired to build the computer enrollment system for President Obama’s health care law said Friday that it would stop working on the troubled insurance exchange when its contract expires at the end of February.

headline: Two Plays, Four Actors and One Company
text: The French military captain (who will shortly thereafter become an English earl) is at a loss as to why everybody is so smitten with this peasant girl who’s suddenly shown up in their midst. It’s not as if she were particularly pretty or intelligent or, heaven forbid, sexy.

headline: Gender Politics Wiggles Into a World Guys Staked Out
text: Laura Jane Grace, the frontwoman of the punk band Against Me!, introduced all the new songs by name on Thursday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, as the singer of a band with a new album generally does, and should do.

headline: The Next Data Privacy Battle May Be Waged Inside Your Car
text: Cars are becoming smarter than ever, with global positioning systems, Internet connections, data recorders and high-definition cameras. Drivers can barely make a left turn, put on their seatbelts or push 80 miles an hour without their actions somehow, somewhere being tracked or recorded.

headline: An Invitation to Geneva Two
text: An international summit to address the conflict in Syria, called Geneva Two, is scheduled to begin on Jan. 22 in Montreux, Switzerland. (Hotels in Geneva were fully booked by attendees to a watch convention.) The United Nations this week began sending out invitations, and Ayman Abdel Nour, a dissident Syrian exile who was once a friend of President Bashar al-Assad’s, posted one Thursday on his popular Arabic-language blog, All4Syria.

headline: Wrestlers in Leather: What More Is Required?
text: “The Legend of Hercules,” a new 3-D work of Classical beefcake scholarship, directed by Renny Harlin, is likely to be met with ridicule. At the crowded preview screening I attended on Thursday night in Manhattan, there were audible hoots of derision, which were, for the most part, well earned. But really, this movie, with its relatively modest running time and not-quite-household-name cast, is no more ridiculous than, let’s say, the “Thor” movies, and a lot less pretentious. It delivers what it promises, which is muscular guys in skimpy clothes fighting and howling, as well as some large-scale digitally enhanced battle sequences.

headline: Big Break? Well, Eyes Will Be on Him
text: The Off Broadway hit “Buyer & Cellar” has delivered a 200 percent return to its investors in just six months, and everyone involved knows the main reason: The star, Michael Urie (television’s “Ugly Betty”), who has received phenomenal reviews in the one-man play. But with Mr. Urie on vacation this weekend, a perennial dream of New York actors is coming true. The understudy is going on.

headline: Video: An Updated Chevy Traverse That Can Fit the Family
text: Recently, I discovered that my older brother and his wife were interested in a Chevrolet Tahoe. Their reasoning was simple – its three rows of seating would be handy when chauffeuring my niece’s soccer teammates and gear. And they love the S.U.V. look.

headline: Two Power Options in One Small Package
text: LAS VEGAS — Ventev, a company that makes battery and charger products, has an extra-compact car charger that manages to squeeze in an auxiliary battery.

headline: Searching for Philomena’s Real Son
text: In the early-to-mid 1980s, if you were a gay man in Washington working in politics, chances are you ended up on L Street near Capitol Hill, at a bar called Lost & Found.

headline: After Accidents, North Dakota Senators Want Stiffer Rail Safety Rules
text: After train accidents involving North Dakotan crude oil, the state’s political leaders are putting pressure on the Obama administration to improve railroad safety regulations, with some even urging a slowdown in drilling until safety solutions are found.

headline: At a Bay Area Club, Exclusivity Is Tested
text: The game was called “describe your superpower.” Five men and women, who had met two hours earlier, lounged on shiny gold couches and boasted about their hidden talents.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Thrills and Chills
text: As the temperature bounced around zero last week, people in need of cheering up could have viewed an array of exotic orchid blooms in markets.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Thrills and Chills
text: Last Tuesday and Wednesday, some women and men paraded in fur coats from an earlier era. Others protected their faces by wrapping them in scarves. One woman, taking her cues from the early 1960s, stood out with bare legs as she walked to work.

headline: A Strong Sense of Fashion
text: WHO Tina Fey

headline: They Want Her on Their Side
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2007, Brandee Barker and a colleague drove to a Nordstrom in Palo Alto, Calif., and bought Mark Zuckerberg a black suit. Mr. Zuckerberg, a founder of Facebook, was embarking on his first trip to Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, and Ms. Barker, then the head of public relations for his growing company, thought the occasion called for something more formal than his signature hooded sweatshirt.

headline: Christie’s Efforts at Damage Control
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evening Hours | Memorable Lanes
text: Bill Cunningham’s 2013 in parties.

headline: Obama Counts on Power of Convening People for Change
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama may have lost the power of persuasion with Congress, but he still has the underrated power of invitation to the White House. Since congressional Republicans remain hostile as ever to his agenda, next week Mr. Obama will begin hosting influential groups in the West Wing to try to spur specific action on national problems short of changes to federal law.

headline: Violence in Football: Why Do We Tolerate It?
A Decision to Go to Trial
text: To the Editor:

headline: Views of the Blind
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Power of One
text: “I love your dress tonight,” gushed Ashlan Gorse, a correspondent for the E! network, thrusting a microphone toward Julianne Moore as the actress walked the red carpet to a Golden Globes after-party last year. “How many did you have to try on?”

headline: Sexual Assault Charges Dropped at Annapolis
text: WASHINGTON — Charges in a sexual assault case have been dropped against a Naval Academy midshipman after his statements about the encounter were determined to be inadmissible because he had not been read his rights before questioning and, as a result, there were “no reasonable grounds” to prove a crime was committed, the Navy announced Friday.

headline: The Rwandan Genocide
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toiling to Bring Rwanda Genocide Suspects to Justice
text: REIMS, France — ABOVE his desk in a peaceful and tidy townhouse with pots of geraniums hanging from the windowsills and walls covered with photos of his children, Alain Gauthier keeps 24 files labeled with the names of some of the men and women accused in one of the most appalling crimes of the 20th century.

headline: Federal Consumer Agency Ponders Its Next Crusades
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which has already overcome considerable political resistance, has managed to pack some punches in the last few months on behalf of the purchasing public it represents.

headline: Fury in Sri Lanka at U.S. Embassy Tweet on Killing of Tamils
text: The Sri Lankan Ministry of Defense expressed shock and anger on Friday at what it called a “baseless allegation” against the nation’s military in a photo caption posted on the official Twitter feed of the United States Embassy the day before.

headline: SAC Trader ‘Corrupted’ Doctors, Prosecutor Says
text: Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, “corrupted” doctors to get an “illegal edge” that helped him perpetrate the most lucrative insider trading scheme in history, a federal prosecutor said on Friday.

headline: In Rhino Horn Case, Judge Sees a Criminal Instead of a ‘Naïve Kid’
text: Michael Slattery Jr. stood in court with his hands clenched behind him as if they were still in the shackles that had just been removed. It was time for his sentencing on Friday, in federal court in Brooklyn, an often surreal setting in which very different versions of the same human are described for the judge’s careful consideration.

headline: Thai Beer Loses Esteem After Heiress’s Remarks
text: UDON THANI, Thailand — It was probably inevitable in a country so obsessed with food and drink that Thailand’s political turmoil would spill over into beer.

headline: Despite Bumps, the Knicks’ Bandwagon Starts to Roll
text: Without introduction, here are a few events — Episodes? Tragicomedies? Calamities? — that have befallen the Knicks over the past five games.

headline: Street Style Photos at Pitti Uomo in Florence, Italy
text: The men’s collections were shown this week at Pitti Uomo in Florence, Italy. Here are some from our Instagram feed, for more.

headline: Lane Closings Scandal Shows Port Authority’s Status as 2 Warring Fiefs
text: After a top New Jersey official at the Port Authority, David Wildstein, ordered the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge that clogged Fort Lee, N.J., for four days in September, the authority’s New York-appointed executive director, Patrick J. Foye, exploded with anger and ordered the lanes reopened. But then the authority’s New Jersey-appointed chairman, David Samson, expressed outrage over Mr. Foye’s outrage, accusing him of leaking the story of the lane closings.

headline: It’s Time to Update Overtime
text: WASHINGTON — PRESIDENT OBAMA has assured American workers that he won’t let Congress keep him from lending a hand during these tough economic times. “I will not allow gridlock, inaction or willful indifference to get in our way,” he said in a speech last year. “Whatever executive authority I have to help the middle class, I’ll use it.”

headline: To Regain Trust, Target Must Do More, Crisis Experts Say
text: With clients over the years like Michael R. Milken (securities fraud), Dominique Strauss-Kahn (rape allegations), Jack Abramoff (bribery) and the Sizzler restaurant chain (salmonella), Marina Ein is well versed in the art and science of crisis public relations.

headline: Nelson Ned, Florid Brazilian Balladeer, Dies at 66
text: Nelson Ned, a Brazilian singer of small stature and large voice who was hailed throughout Latin America as the “Little Giant of Song,” died on Sunday in São Paolo. He was 66.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside Bell Labs’ Carcass, and Encouraging Women Programmers
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Larry Speakes, Public Face of Reagan Era, Dies at 74
text: WASHINGTON — Larry Speakes, who became the public face of Ronald Reagan’s presidency when a would-be assassin’s bullet gravely wounded his boss, press secretary James Brady, died Friday in his native Mississippi. He was 74.

headline: Imagining President Christie
text: Let us count the ways that this week’s traffic-jam scandal is actually good for Chris Christie’s presidential prospects.

headline: U.S. Says Iran Won’t Attend Peace Talks on Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Iran will not participate in peace talks on Syria that are to be held this month in Switzerland, a senior State Department official said Friday.

headline: Dale T. Mortensen, Labor Economist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 74
text: Dale T. Mortensen, an economist whose pioneering work on labor markets won a Nobel and helped governments and policy makers better understand the stubborn complexities of unemployment, died on Thursday at his home in Wilmette, Ill. He was 74.

headline: Sex Is Not Our Problem
text: There is often a simplistic, black-or-white, conservative vs. progressive discussion around the dissolution of the traditional family and high single-parent birthrates in America and what these trends may portend for us as a country.

headline: Enrollees at Health Exchanges Face Struggle to Prove Coverage
text: FORT WORTH — Paul D. Donahue and his wife, Angela, are among more than a million Americans who have signed up for health coverage through the federal insurance exchange. Mr. Donahue has a card in his wallet from his insurer to prove it. But when he tried to use it to get a flu shot and fill prescriptions this week, local pharmacies could not confirm his coverage, so he left without his medications.

headline: Down to the Last Cigarette?
text: This is certainly turning out to be quite the year for 50th anniversaries. Fifty years ago next month, the Beatles made their U.S. debut on “The Ed Sullivan Show.” In 1964, President Lyndon Johnson started the War on Poverty. And 50 years ago Saturday, the surgeon general of the United States issued the single most important report that would ever come out of that office. It linked cigarette smoking to illness and death.

headline: Seeking Redemption, Sometimes With a Familiar Ring
text: See the ultimate political apology, culled from notable speeches and statements made in the aftermath of wrongdoing or other officeholder embarrassments.

headline: Florida’s Site Said to Delay Millions in Aid to Jobless
text: MIAMI — The botched rollout of Florida’s online system for unemployment claims may have kept jobless Floridians from receiving $20 million in benefits in October and November, according to an informal analysis by a workers’ rights group.

headline: Seahawks’ Punt Team Is Flashy With Play, Not Name
text: RENTON, Wash. — In a locker room populated by the “Legion of Boom” and “Beast Mode” and even a “Fat Rabbit,” the most dominant unit on the most dominant team in the N.F.C. lacks a catchy nickname of its own. For this, Jeremy Lane, an integral member of that squad, apologizes.

headline: Booze, Revisited
text: Dear Readers: Some of you had trouble finding my most recent column, on alcoholism. Since the latest entries are no longer part of Opinionator, the best way to locate my pieces is simply to search for my name in the Times’s search engine or go directly to my columnist page. I’ve always looked forward to reading your comments, even though the queue sometimes got so busy they had to be turned off — particularly unfortunate in this case since the 100 that were allowed were erudite and touching. Please keep your notes coming, as much as you can! I have a very busy year ahead, but I will be back to you as often as possible, even though it won’t be on a regular schedule. You can think of me as a little occasional surprise. Here’s to a productive and healthy 2014. — Dick

headline: Wall St. Shock: Take a Day Off, Even a Sunday
text: For the ambitious college graduates who flock to Wall Street, working into the wee hours or even pulling all-nighters is an unwritten expectation of the job. Spending both Saturdays and Sundays at the office is the norm.

headline: World Bank Is Criticized for Honduran Loan
text: MEXICO CITY — The World Bank ombudsman issued a stinging critique Friday of the bank’s private-sector arm over a loan to a Honduran palm-oil company engaged in a violent conflict with farm workers over land tenure.

headline: Arkansas: Lieutenant Governor Quitting Under Pressure
text: Lt. Gov. Mark Darr, who was facing the threat of impeachment proceedings in the aftermath of a settlement with the state’s Ethics Commission, said on Friday that he would resign on Feb. 1. Although Mr. Darr, a Republican elected in 2010, had resisted bipartisan demands for his resignation, he agreed to quit as lawmakers openly discussed removing him from office. State investigators determined last month that Mr. Darr had repeatedly broken state law by using more than $31,000 in campaign money for personal reasons, accepting improper contributions and maintaining faulty records. Mr. Darr, who abandoned a bid for Congress after an Arkansas political blogger accused him of the misconduct, said his errors were unintentional but agreed to pay $11,000 in fines.

headline: U.S. Advisers Sent to Help Somalia Fight the Shabab
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has sent a small team of uniformed military advisers to Somalia, the first American troops assigned there since 1993, when 18 Americans were killed in the failed “Black Hawk Down” mission.

headline: An Assembly of Quietly Moving Parts
text: The stars of “The Record” — all 45 of them — do not really do much. They stand stock still on a bare stage, strike some funny poses then walk around a bit. They do a little running, too, and assemble in groups and sometimes stretch out on the floor. Just now and then, one will extend a hand to touch another, or a young woman will fall backward into a man’s arms, in a moment of connection that registers with soft surprise.

headline: No Jobs, No Benefits, and Lousy Pay
text: There is nothing good to say about the December employment report, which showed that only 74,000 jobs were added last month. But dismal as it was, the report came at an opportune political moment. The new numbers rebut the Republican arguments that jobless benefits need not be renewed, and that the current minimum wage is adequate. At the same time, they underscore the need, only recently raised to the top of the political agenda, to combat poverty and inequality.

headline: Bill Conlin, Sportswriter Who Quit After Molestation Claims, Dies at 79
text: Bill Conlin, a sports columnist for The Daily News in Philadelphia who was honored by the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2011 but who left his job later that year amid a storm of publicity over child-molestation accusations, died on Thursday in Largo, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Haiti, Unfinished and Forsaken
text: Four years after the earthquake, Haiti is a fragile, largely forgotten country. It’s possible that some natural or man-made crisis this year could push it back into the headlines. But sustained attention, with the kind of support from outside that Haiti still needs to rebuild and become more self-sufficient, is mostly gone.

headline: Weigh-In Section
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh boy. I like Martin Ashwood-Smith’s puzzles, but this one really wasn’t in my wheelhouse. That doesn’t make it a bad puzzle, I just had a tough time solving it because I didn’t know much about the things in it. You know you’re in trouble when the clue at 1 Across — “It has a close ‘Kentucky’ cousin” — has you thinking about bourbon instead of flora.

headline: Increased Security for Nuclear Materials
text: There is some rare good news on the issue of securing and containing deadly nuclear materials. In the last two years, seven countries have forsaken their uranium and plutonium stockpiles, bringing the number of nations still possessing appreciable quantities of nuclear fuel usable for bomb-making down to 25. In 1991, the number was 52.

headline: Yankees Sign Reliever (Matt Thornton) and Cut Outfielder (Vernon Wells)
text: With a glut of outfielders and a shortage of left-handed relief pitchers, the Yankees swapped out one for the other Friday, cutting Vernon Wells and signing Matt Thornton.

headline: A Mr. Feder, Once of Fort Lee, Chimes In
text: A Mr. Richard Feder, famously from Fort Lee, N.J., has a question about the rather infamous closings of lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: A Guillotine in Storage Bears Signs of a Role in Silencing Nazis’ Critics
text: BERLIN — A guillotine used to execute thousands of people during the Nazi era, including a brother and sister who led a group of Munich students known as the White Rose in resistance to Hitler, has been provisionally identified in a storage area belonging to the Bavarian National Museum, museum officials said Friday.

headline: Franklin McCain, Who Fought for Rights at All-White Lunch Counter, Dies at 73
text: Franklin McCain, who helped fuel the civil rights movement in 1960 when he and three friends from their all-black college requested, and were refused, coffee and doughnuts at a whites-only lunch counter in Greensboro, N.C., died on Thursday in Greensboro. He was 73.

headline: Colts vs. Patriots: A Great Rivalry, Now Revised
text: Since Tom Brady’s first career start more than a dozen years ago, the rivalry between the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts has been must-watch football. For years, Brady faced Peyton Manning in a duel of the top two quarterbacks in the N.F.L. With Manning playing in Denver for the Broncos, a second chapter of the rivalry is being established. Now it is Brady versus Andrew Luck, the Colts’ second-year quarterback and an emerging star.

headline: Dropbox Says Site Down After Maintenance Error, Not From Hackers
text: Updated January 11, 9:46 a.m. | A hacker claiming to be a member of the loose hacking collective Anonymous took credit for knocking offline the website of the cloud storage provider Dropbox late Friday. Attempts to reach the site were met with an error message.

headline: New Reality for Heat: From Rolling to Resting
text: The Miami Heat appear to be learning from one of their few mistakes.

headline: Neiman Marcus Investigates Breach Involving Credit Card Data
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Neiman Marcus is investigating a security breach involving credit card information stolen from its customers.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 11, 2014
text: “We’re going to continue to file and act as if we’re married. Some people have said that’s an act of civil disobedience. If it is, so be it.”

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: A disappointing jobs report, thousands of airline flight cancellations and an aggressive move to attract cellphone customers.

headline: South Sudan: Army Says Its Soldiers Have Regained Control of Northern City
text: South Sudan’s military on Friday retook Bentiu, the capital of an oil-producing state, from rebels loyal to the former vice president, said a military spokesman, Col. Philip Aguer. Fighting in South Sudan began last month in the national capital, Juba, after President Salva Kiir, left, said that his former vice president, Riek Machar, had attempted a coup. Thousands are believed to have been killed and 200,000 displaced by the fighting, which has involved the country’s largest two ethnic groups, the Dinka and the Nuer. Peace talks are underway in Ethiopia. The military’s claim that it had regained control of Bentiu in the north could not immediately be confirmed. Colonel Aguer accused the rebels of looting the city and burning buildings. The medical aid group Doctors Without Borders also said that its facilities in Bentiu had been looted. “It is unacceptable that one of the only humanitarian organizations still providing assistance to the population in Bentiu has been looted,” said the group’s general director, Arjan Hehenkamp. The United Nations Security Council on Friday urged the warring parties to stop the fighting, continue negotiations and ensure the protection of the country’s oil fields. The Council also asked Mr. Kiir to release political prisoners and urged Mr. Machar to agree to a cessation of hostilities “without precondition.”

headline: St. John’s Pulls Together While Playing Through Grief
text: Steve Lavin, a son of an English professor, is philosophical about life and, in particular, his St. John’s men’s basketball team. He searches for themes, uses analogies as often as gestures and, as his father did, takes time to find the exact words to express his thoughts.

headline: Corrections: January 11, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Dreaming a Dream for a Daughter Talented in Art
text: So far, Alicia Guillén’s dreams have come true.

headline: For Fund Investors, the Dangers of Rarefied Air
text: THE stock market ended 2013 at record highs and with indicators of investor optimism near best-ever levels. The enthusiasm is understandable after a year that was the strongest for stocks in well over a decade — but whether it is wise is another matter.

headline: From Ice Level, Rick Nash Helps Rangers Take Season to New Heights
text: Coming off perhaps their most satisfying win of the season — in Chicago, over the defending Stanley Cup champions, the Blackhawks — the Rangers generated the same kind of success Friday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Guru Funds, Mimicking the Smart Money
text: SUCCESS breeds imitation, whether acknowledged or not. Now, two exchange-traded funds and a mutual fund are being open about their copying: They aim to replicate the investments of the most successful hedge funds and business people.

headline: In Search of Europe’s Growth Stories
text: ALTHOUGH mutual and exchange-traded funds that invest in Europe recently posted strong results for the second consecutive year, the rally has largely been two-dimensional.

headline: A Surprising Surge for Industrial Stocks
text: IT may come as a surprise to those who have fretted over the hollowing of American industry, but in a year of big market gains, industrial stocks were among the strongest performers.

headline: In Fund Expenses, Tenths of a Point Mean a Lot
text: HOW much a fund costs to run may seem inconsequential, especially now. With the backdrop of a “go big or go home” stock market that frightens many small investors but can enrich those who take a chance, how could several tenths of a percentage point in operating expenses, one way or the other, really matter?

headline: Making the Most of Financial Resources at Hand
text: IF improving your net worth made your list of New Year’s resolutions, two books — one about the personal investment ideas of John Maynard Keynes and the other from the creator of a relatively new financial website — could help.

headline: In a Stellar Quarter, Three Funds That Went Over the Top
text: NEARLY every style of stock fund rose in the fourth quarter of 2013, and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index continued its long sprint, returning 9.9 percent. But the stewards of three of the top-performing mutual funds beat even that heady return, finding gains in sectors as diverse as trucking, technology and automotive paint shops.

headline: In the Bond Market, Lower Expectations Became the Reality
text: BONDS lived down to expectations last year. The threat of rising interest rates, which had lurked in the ether for five years, finally materialized, pushing prices lower.

headline: Before His Death, Boy Faced Weeks of Abuse, Officials Say
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio ordered an investigation on Friday into the death of a 4-year-old boy who was beaten, tortured and starved for three weeks by his caregiver, as new details of the boy’s horrific ordeal emerged in court.

headline: In Performance: Eric Tucker
text: Eric Tucker plays the title character in Bedlam Theater’s production of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet.”

headline: New Clashes Erupt in Ukraine After Trial
text: At least a dozen protesters were injured in clashes with riot police in Kiev after a Ukrainian court on Friday convicted three men of plotting to topple a statue of Vladimir Lenin in 2011 in Boryspil, a city southeast of the capital. The protesters had denounced the prosecution of the three men as politically motivated and a “show trial” and pointed to evidence showing that the Boryspil City Council had voted to remove the Lenin statue even before the alleged plot was discovered. About 100 protesters had gathered at the courthouse in Kiev for the verdict. The clashes began after the three defendants were sentenced to six years in prison. Among the injured was Yuri V. Lutsenko, a former interior minister and an outspoken opposition leader who helped coordinate the recent mass demonstrations in central Kiev against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich. Local news agencies reported that Mr. Lutsenko had been knocked unconscious. Mr. Lutsenko, who was also an organizer of the 2004 Orange Revolution, is the leader of an opposition party called the Third Ukrainian Republic.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 10, 2014
Week in Pictures for Jan. 10
text: Subjects include: Cold weather, visitors to Gracie Mansion and an emergency landing in the Bronx.

headline: If Couples Could Be Corporations
text: JUST before New Year’s, I attended a lovely wedding back in Texas, my home state. It couldn’t have been nicer: The couple exchanged vows out on a ranch under a perfect sky, and the barbecue and buffalo burgers served in the barn after the ceremony were mighty tasty.

headline: Retired Correction Officer’s Death May Have Stemmed From a Romantic Quarrel
text: In what may have been a romantic quarrel involving one former and two current New York City correction officers, a man was shot and killed early on Friday morning on a Queens street, officials said.

headline: LeBron James Seethes, and Nets Are Hotter, Winning 5th in Row
text: LeBron James spent much of Friday night fuming. Almost as soon as he stepped on the court, he was jawing at the referees, shooting them incredulous glares. He slammed the ball to the floor early in the fourth quarter when his teammate Michael Beasley committed an offensive foul. He told a heckler along the baseline to sit down.

headline: For Once, Every Player Makes Name for Himself
text: There was never any doubt that two of the N.B.A.’s new nickname jerseys would read Big Ticket and Truth, the monikers of Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce of the Nets, but it is doubtful that anyone in the United States would have expected Andrei Kirilenko to go with Кириленко.

headline: In Bridge Scandal, a Slight Heard Around the World
text: Amid the rivers of invective that Gov. Chris Christie’s allies spilled as they plotted to cripple traffic in Fort Lee, N.J., was one bitter drop of bile: The city’s mayor was referred to as a “little Serbian.”

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE PLACE BEYOND THE PINES  (2013) An itinerant motorcycle stunt rider (Ryan Gosling) tries to support a former lover (Eva Mendes, above with Mr. Gosling) and their son by robbing banks, leading to an encounter with a rookie cop (Bradley Cooper) that will have consequences neither can fathom at the time. “The most radical aspect of ‘The Place Beyond the Pines’ is its relentless linearity, the way it tells its story without foreshadowing or flashing back or resorting to other conventional shortcuts,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this three-part drama, directed by Derek Cianfrance (“Blue Valentine”). “Watching it is refreshing and absorbing partly because it is rare for a film to show this kind of confidence in its own narrative momentum, which is also a gesture of faith in the audience’s willingness to pay attention.” He added, “Your attention is especially rewarded by the work of Mr. Gosling and Mr. Cooper, who offer contrasting studies in tragic, shortsighted masculine intensity.”

headline: Cuomo Blocks Liquor License for Caterer in Upper East Side Church
