text: An Upper East Side catering hall that has waged a long-running campaign for a liquor license was dealt a major setback on Friday when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed legislation tailor-made for the hall.

headline: Boy and Elderly Man Killed in Separate Traffic Accidents
text: A boy and an elderly man were struck and killed on Friday in separate traffic accidents on the Upper West Side.

headline: Fire Ravages China District Said to Inspire Shangri-La
text: HONG KONG — Fire blazed through an ancient Tibetan neighborhood in southwest China on Saturday, destroying hundreds of wooden homes and shops that have drawn tourists to an area casting itself as the inspiration for mythic Shangri-La.

headline: A Hammock In Kentucky?
text: National Review has an actually interesting report by Kevin Williamson on the state of Appalachia, providing a valuable portrait of the region’s woes — plus an account of how people turn food stamps fungible by converting them into soda. But the piece also has a moral: the big problem, it argues, is the way government aid creates dependency. It’s the Paul Ryan notion of the safety net as a “hammock” that makes life too easy for the poor.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Whale Washes Up on a Florida Beach
text: A male sperm whale, said to weigh as much as 15 tons, came ashore on Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. Wildlife officials were unsure of the cause of death and said that a necropsy would be performed. Sperm whales are considered an endangered species.

headline: Ermenegildo Zegna: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Ariel Sharon, Israeli Hawk Who Sought Peace on His Terms, Dies at 85
text: Ariel Sharon, one of the most influential figures in Israel’s history, a military commander and political leader who at the height of his power redrew the country’s electoral map, only to suffer a severe stroke from which he never recovered, died on Saturday in a hospital near Tel Aviv. He was 85.

headline: Algorithm for Your Personal Rhythm
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Jimmy Iovine, whose career as a recording engineer, producer and music executive stretches from John Lennon to Lady Gaga, was proudly showing off some of his hits one afternoon last month at a boutique recording studio here.

headline: Consumer Preferences vs. Tax Breaks
text: In a recent column, George F. Will suggests that consumer preferences are always going to win out over big government’s finger-wagging and incentives to do whatever it is liberals claim is the right thing. Prognosticating about the future of the Affordable Care Act, universal preschool and a possible minimum wage hike, he extrapolates from the auto market:

headline: Sharon, Through the Years
text: As a warrior and political leader whose reputation rose and fell with the times, Ariel Sharon left a profound imprint on Israel.

headline: Ariel Sharon, 1928-2014
text: A cunning general who went on to hold nearly every top Israeli government post, Mr. Sharon suffered a stroke in 2006 and fell into a coma from which he never awoke.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 10, 2014
text: Janet Yellen will be the first woman to head the the Federal Reserve when she takes over for Ben Bernanke at the end of January. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar from Time magazine discuss the woman who will soon steer the world’s largest economy. Ms. Foroohar said Yellen will focus on how to help ordinary families get back on their feet, while Joe said Yellen is an expert on unemployment who will apply her skills to the nation’s stubborn unemployment problem.

headline: The Raleigh Experiment
text: North Carolina is an interesting place these days, and I mean that in the worst possible way. It’s a southern state, but one with a major technology complex, growing foreign investment, and what seemed until recently to be a moderating, increasingly sophisticated political culture. But then came the Republican wave of 2010, and NC was taken over by right-wing radicals, who have — among other things — taken the nation’s hardest line in cutting benefits to the unemployed.

headline: A Last Look at the Media and the Dreaded Polar Vortex
text: I was invited to explore the feeding frenzy surrounding the dreaded polar vortex on the NPR show On The Media. The segment, “Sucked Into the Polar Vortex,” is fun and brief. Give a listen here (I’ll add a transcript link when there is one):

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 12
text: “The fines have been manageable in the context of the bank’s earnings capacity.”

headline: The Minimum Wage: Whose Burden?
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: That Thirst to Earn
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Sharing Your Wisdom, Within Limits
text: I am the C.E.O. of a technology start-up with a pretty major presence, especially in our home city. Every day I get a request for a meeting from an aspiring or early-stage entrepreneur. They all say, “Can I just pick your brain?” If I agreed to even a fraction of these requests, my head would become a colander. I’m already seriously slammed: We’re growing fast, I travel a lot and, most important, I have lots of young team members who need my time.

headline: Don’t Snow on His Parade
An Advantage Vanishes for Money Funds
text: When money market mutual funds were invented back in 1971, they offered something new. Investors could earn higher yields than on bank deposits, with nearly the same liquidity and safety. But that has changed. Currently, a money market deposit at Citibank pays about five times as much interest as an investment in the Fidelity Cash Reserves fund — though, in today’s low-rate environment, the yields are minuscule.

headline: A Market Streak Has Ended, but the Echoes Haven’t
text: After two improbable, gravity-defying years, the streak is over.

headline: The Vicious Circle of Income Inequality
text: Almost every culture has some variation on the saying, “rags to rags in three generations.” Whether it’s “clogs to clogs” or “rice paddy to rice paddy,” the message is essentially the same: Starting with nothing, the first generation builds a successful enterprise, which its profligate offspring then manage poorly, so that by the time the grandchildren take over, little value remains.

headline: Michael Gregoire, on Diversity’s Importance
text: This interview with  Michael P. Gregoire, chief executive of CA Technologies, the software makers based in Islandia, N.Y., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Syria’s Conflict Told Through a Caustic Wit
text: Raed Fares and Razan Ghazzawi are well-known Syrian activists who are wrapping up a speaking tour of North America. Ms. Ghazzawi, a prominent blogger who fled Damascus after facing government persecution and arrest, has traveled across Syria and the Middle East to raise awareness about the human cost of the Syria conflict. Mr. Fares runs an activist media center in the northern village of Kafranbel, which has gained a measure of international attention because of the witty banners and posters, many of them designed by Mr. Fares and his team, that protesters have displayed there.

headline: Ariel Sharon, the Ruthless Warrior Who Could Have Made Peace
text: TEL AVIV — POLITICS, to Ariel Sharon, was like a Ferris wheel. But he didn’t make do with just staying on the wheel; he did all he could to climb to the top and stay there.

headline: Bailout Risk, Far Beyond the Banks
text: Everyone knows that the largest of our nation’s banks would be destined for a taxpayer bailout if they ran into trouble anytime soon. But which nonbank financial institutions — say, asset management companies offering hedge funds or mutual funds — might also pose too-big-to-fail risks because of their size and interconnections?

headline: Light-Bulb Moments for a Nonprofit
text: No baby should die or be disabled because a light bulb can’t be replaced. Yet during visits to hospitals in India and other countries, Krista Donaldson often saw lifesaving phototherapy systems, used to treat infant jaundice, languishing in dusty corners because of burned-out bulbs and other seemingly simple problems.

headline: Eminent Domain: A Long Shot Against Blight
text: You can’t fight city hall, the saying goes. But Gayle McLaughlin, the mayor of Richmond, Calif., a city of 100,000 souls, would tell you that fighting Wall Street is harder. Even for city hall.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: In Scandal’s Wake, McKinsey Seeks Culture Shift
text: Dominic Barton is 51 years old, 6 feet 4 and silver-haired, yet he has the countenance of a choirboy. Born in Uganda, he is the son of a missionary and a nurse, both Canadians. But it could be said that the society to which he really belongs is that of McKinsey & Company.

headline: Panthers Out to Disprove Underdog Label in Rematch
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Captain Munnerlyn has played for the Carolina Panthers long enough to know a bad defense. Remember 2011? Their defense was ranked 28th in the N.F.L.

headline: France Oil Giant Is Expected to Seek Shale Gas in Britain
text: LONDON — The French oil giant Total is on the verge of becoming the first major oil company to explore for natural gas and oil in shale rock in Britain.

headline: Variety: A Physical Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I loved this one. My inner science geek stands right beside that of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon (see their notes below), and today’s acrostic puzzle was right on my wavelength. That’s a lot funnier if you’ve studied physics.

headline: Arbitrator’s Ruling Banishes the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez for a Season
text: Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez was barred for 162 games and the 2014 postseason, the longest suspension for doping in baseball history, after an arbitrator upheld most of the punishment sought by Major League Baseball.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Defying Japan, Rancher Saves Fukushima’s Radioactive Cows
text: NAMIE, Japan — His may be one of the world’s more quixotic protests.

headline: Banks Say No to Marijuana Money, Legal or Not
text: SEATTLE — In his second-floor office above a hair salon in north Seattle, Ryan Kunkel is seated on a couch placing $1,000 bricks of cash — dozens of them — in a rumpled brown paper bag. When he finishes, he stashes the money in the trunk of his BMW and sets off on an adrenalized drive downtown, darting through traffic and nervously checking to see if anyone is following him.

headline: Unearthing Nuggets of Gold for NBC
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — Nothing satisfies NBC’s crew of Olympic researchers more than discovering something unusual about an athlete heading to the Games. A little-known back story or a strange hobby. A name change or a shifted national affiliation. An injury or a medical condition overcome. And if an athlete is not a household name, all the better.

headline: Presidential Run Likely for Egypt’s Top General
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s top military officer on Saturday offered the clearest indication yet that he sees this week’s referendum on a revised Constitution as a prelude to a bid for the presidency, moving to consolidate his power after his ouster of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Raging Fire in Ancient Tibetan Town
text: More than 2,000 firefighters tried over 10 hours to bring a fire under control in Dukezong, an ancient Tibetan town in China’s Yunnan Province.

headline: A-Rod’s Suspension Reduced
text: The suspension of Alex Rodriguez of the New York Yankees was reduced from 211 to 162 games.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 11
text: It was not Gov. Chris Christie’s week. The New Jersey Republican faced mounting criticism after emails and texts linked his office to lane closures on the George Washington Bridge from Fort Lee, N.J., in September. The closures were apparently retribution for the town’s mayor declining to endorse Mr. Christie for re-election. In a two-hour news conference on Thursday, Mr. Christie apologized, saying he was “blindsided” by the news. He fired Bridget Anne Kelly, his deputy chief of staff who wrote in one email, “time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.”

headline: Israel and World Grapple With Sharon’s Mixed Legacy
text: SDEROT, Israel — When the Mark family heard the news about the death of Ariel Sharon on the radio on Saturday afternoon, they immediately turned their car around and headed to his sprawling sheep farm here in the Negev desert, where he is expected to be buried on a hill next to his wife, Lily.

headline: Emma Thompson, Bryan Cranston and Other Party Minglers
text: LOS ANGELES — “I’m going to go tell Bryan Cranston that I worship the ground he walks on,” Emma Thompson said Friday at a luncheon for the American Film Institute. She made a beeline for Mr. Cranston, there as the star of “Breaking Bad,” and began complimenting. That means so much coming from you, Mr. Cranston murmured, as others (Tom Hanks among them) lined up to pay tribute.

headline: The Mixed Marriage
text: Lise Funderburg, a journalist, interviewed Yael Ben-Zion, a photographer raised in Israel, about her new book, “Intermarried,” published by Kehrer, which features families from the Washington Heights neighborhood where she lives with her French husband and 5-year-old twins.

headline: For Yanks, Some Payroll Relief Now but Questions Down the Road
text: For more than two years, the Yankees have considered Alex Rodriguez’s record-setting contract a burden, a mistake and a hindrance to their planning. With so much money invested in a rapidly declining player, Rodriguez’s presence was a reminder of the team’s financial folly.

headline: Thunder Road
text: WASHINGTON — I HAVE learned two things covering politics.

headline: How Can We Help Men? By Helping Women
text: THIS week Maria Shriver brings together a star-studded cast of celebrities, from Hillary Rodham Clinton to Beyoncé, to call attention to the economic plight of American women and demand that women’s needs be put “at the center of policy making.”

headline: A Longer Life for the Space Station
text: The Obama administration’s decision to extend the international space station’s time in orbit by at least four years makes good sense. Some $100 billion has been invested to build the station, which was completed less than three years ago. The plan had been to allow the station to plunge into the ocean in 2020.

headline: Protect the President’s Appointments
text: Under the Constitution, the president nominates federal judges, cabinet members and officials for executive agencies, and the Senate votes on their confirmation. But what if the Senate isn’t in session? The answer has always seemed clear: The Constitution gives the president the power to fill “all vacancies that may happen during the recess of the Senate.”

headline: The Times, From the Top: Looking Ahead
text: THESE days, when Jill Abramson surveys the paper’s masthead, she does so with a certain amount of satisfaction. Half of the 10 top-ranking editors in the newsroom, including herself, are women. That’s a long way from a time when women had no presence on the Times masthead; the first on the news side was Carolyn Lee, in 1990 (though Charlotte Curtis preceded her, as an opinion editor, in 1974).

headline: End the Corporate Tax?
text: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay that said abolition of the tax would benefit workers.

headline: The Civil Rights of Children
text: Most school officials try to apply disciplinary policies fairly and in compliance with federal laws that forbid racial discrimination. Even so, a large and troubling body of data — some if it gathered by the federal government — shows that black and Hispanic students are disproportionately and unjustifiably subjected to suspension, expulsion or even arrest for nonviolent offenses that should be dealt with in the principal’s office.

headline: Anthony Mandler
text: Anthony Mandler is a film director and photographer probably best known for the noir music videos he has created for pop artists such as Rihanna, Jay-Z, Beyoncé, Eminem and Lana Del Rey.

headline: The War on Women
text: THE year is new, but we already have a candidate for the most troubling magazine essay of 2014: Amanda Hess on “Why Women Aren’t Welcome on the Internet,” in the latest issue of Pacific Standard.

headline: If I Had a Hammer
text: MY favorite story in Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee’s fascinating new book, “The Second Machine Age,” is when the Dutch chess grandmaster Jan Hein Donner was asked how he’d prepare for a chess match against a computer, like I.B.M.’s Deep Blue. Donner replied: “I would bring a hammer.”

headline: The ‘I’ in Christie’s Storm
text: POLITICS boils down to three pronouns: I, you, we. The politician who has them in balance goes a long way.

headline: Goodnight. Sleep Clean.
text: SLEEP seems like a perfectly fine waste of time. Why would our bodies evolve to spend close to one-third of our lives completely out of it, when we could instead be doing something useful or exciting? Something that would, as an added bonus, be less likely to get us killed back when we were sleeping on the savanna?

headline: A Week of Victories for Cold Weather and Al Qaeda
text: The first full week of the new year dutifully served up some of the themes likely to command attention in 2014.

headline: In This Rape Case, the Victim Was 4
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — SHE’S a 4-year-old girl named Ida, fragile and shy, and when she was raped by a neighbor boy in September, her family tried to have the attacker arrested.

headline: When a Food Writer Can’t Taste
text: ON that early spring day in San Francisco, I walked out to buy local treats for my birthday party — country bread (sour, with walnuts) from Tartine bakery, tamales from the lady in front of my favorite produce shop, salted caramel ice cream from Bi-Rite and a tub of peanut curry ice cream from Humphry Slocombe’s.

headline: I Crashed the Wrong Shiva
text: YOU get to know all the old people. This is what no one tells you when you live in New York City and decide to work from home, but it’s true. One generation’s “off-peak hours” is another’s “hours.” There they are, walking their rickety dogs at 10, doing their laundry at noon, checking their mail at 3, asking you if you know how to operate a VCR machine at 6.

headline: Matriarchs’ Duel for Power Threatens to Tilt Bangladesh Off Balance
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh —  Two ladies eyed each other from their elegant residences in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital, last week, each waiting to see whether the other would blink.

headline: Sexual Violence and Impunity, from Kenya to America
text: My Sunday column is from Nairobi, Kenya, about how police corruption and indifference create impunity that allows sexual violence to unchecked. This is a global problem, particularly in poor countries with dubious criminal justice systems but also of course in the United States. As you’ll see, I argue that we have to change attitudes but above all we have to end the impunity. The organization that I followed in Kenya, Shining Hope for Communities, is doing a terrific job trying to do just that.

headline: Chargers’ Rivers Wears Country Roots on Sleeve and Around His Neck
text: SAN DIEGO — Gone are the days when a quarterback would stand at his locker after a game, freshly showered with a wet head or sweat soaked, grass stained and half undressed, and answer questions from reporters who crowded around. That ritual is now the domain of the proletariat — linemen, linebackers and the like.

headline: Cruel Bargain for A-Rod and Boys With Baseball Dreams
text: Before Alex Rodriguez was A-Rod, long before he became a symbol of all that’s wrong with baseball, he was simply Alex, a skinny little 8-year-old with dreams of being a pro ballplayer like his father.

headline: Heat Are Fine With Learning From Losses
text: The Miami Heat arrived in New York last week in the midst of another marauding march through the regular season. They limped away with a training room full of banged-up players after losses on consecutive nights to the Knicks and the Nets.

headline: Tough Suspensions in Sports Don’t Always Stick
text: Through the decades, suspensions in sports have come in all sizes and for offenses that include attacking a coach and protesting a war. Often assumed to be career-enders, suspensions have often been shortened or vacated, allowing players to resume doing what they do best, which is to compete on a field, a court or a rink.

headline: With N.F.L. Concussion Deal, Two Tiers of Payouts
text: Court settlements are by nature compromises, and compromises are often messy. The proposed settlement of the lawsuits brought by more than 4,500 former N.F.L. players who contended that the league hid from them the dangers of concussions is no exception.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Ermenegildo Zegna Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Setting a Hockey Team’s Direction Left and Right
text: Kurt Kehl has an unusual memory. Name just about any N.H.L. player in the last 40 years or so, and Kehl knows whether he shot from the left side or the right side.

headline: After Losing Gasol, Grizzlies Find Talent On the Bench
text: Marc Gasol, the Memphis Grizzlies’ starting center, is one of a number of high-profile N.B.A. stars who have missed a large chunk of this season because of an injury. But in the absence of Gasol, the Grizzlies discovered talent sitting on their bench.

headline: Rodriguez Barred From Baseball, but Not From the Public Eye
text: Alex Rodriguez is not going away. An arbitrator has decided that Rodriguez cannot play in 2014, not in the regular season or the postseason, but we will see him again. Rodriguez will make sure of it.

headline: Panel Blocks Gas Pipeline in New Jersey Pinelands
text: The New Jersey agency charged with protecting the Pinelands, a vast and fragile expanse of sand pines, gnarled oaks and river deltas, narrowly defeated a proposal on Friday to run a 22-mile natural gas pipeline through it.

headline: The 1890 Book I Had to Have
text: Four years ago, while browsing in Second Story Books in Washington, D.C., I noticed a plain clothbound volume among the fine leather-bound tomes locked in a glass case. I had no business looking at any rare books, but that did not stop me from asking if I might see it. A moment later I was holding a copy of “How the Other Half Lives,” the 1890 classic on the squalor of New York’s tenements that pricked a nation’s conscience and became a template for generations of investigative reporters like myself.

headline: U.S. Figure Skating Team Awaits Difficult Winnowing
text: BOSTON — Two hours before her long program on Saturday night, Polina Edmunds, 15, took a peek from backstage at the United States figure skating championships. This was her first competition at the senior level. Rarely, if ever, had she skated before an audience this large, with the stakes so high.

headline: Skating’s New Scoring System Adds to Challenge for American Men
text: BOSTON — As the sun set on the cavernous convention center Friday, five boyish-looking ice skaters laced up their footwear and took turns leaping, gliding and spinning their nerves away, making a chorus of satisfying crunches of skate blades on a fresh sheet of ice.

headline: Tennis Tries to Find Balance on Doping
text: Criticized in the past for not being tough enough, tennis’s antidoping program faced criticism in 2013 that it was too harsh as two prominent players, Viktor Troicki and Marin Cilic, received suspensions that were reduced on appeal.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Jil Sander Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Taking the Battle to the States
text: A look at the party splits in the states on different issues.

headline: A National Strategy Funds State Political Monopolies
text: By his third year as chairman of the Alabama Republican organization, Mike Hubbard believed his party had just about everything it needed to win control of the State Legislature.

headline: Six Who Could Challenge the Usual Suspects
text: These six players could challenge the more familiar names at the Australian Open.

headline: Versace: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: It’s Only “A” Game
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, that was A-one. I really enjoyed this puzzle by Andrew Chaikin, not just for the great fill and clever theme, but for the fabulous, cryptic-sounding clues that were not actually written to be cryptic. When I eventually realized what was going on.

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Statement
text: Alex Rodriguez issued the following statement in response to the arbitrator’s decision to suspend him for 162 games.

headline: This Time, Smith Avoids Sideshow and Just Puts On a Show
text: PHILADELPHIA — The benching of J. R. Smith lasted 12 minutes into its second game. Knicks Coach Mike Woodson could not restrain the capricious and impulsive Smith any longer than that.

headline: Harvard-Yale Rivalry Echoes Through the Garden
text: The first Harvard-Yale hockey game was played in 1900 at St. Nicholas Rink off Columbus Avenue in Manhattan. It was so long ago that when the Elis won, 5-4, their fans celebrated with the Yale frog cheer, based on a passage from Aristophanes. “Brek-ek-ek-ex,” it began, mimicking the chorus of frogs on the banks of the River Styx.

headline: Seeking Nuclear-Power Workers of Tomorrow
text: PALACIOS — At first glance, the large, framed photo hanging on a wall at the state’s largest nuclear power plant seems to tell a simple story. About 200 smiling men and women stand in block formation behind a long-stretching banner — shades of a high school class portrait, though one posed in front of the domes of two nuclear reactors.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Dolce & Gabbana Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Blogger’s Incarceration Raises First Amendment Questions
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — For over six years, Roger Shuler has hounded figures of the state legal and political establishment on his blog, Legal Schnauzer, a hothouse of furious but often fuzzily sourced allegations of deep corruption and wide-ranging conspiracy. Some of these allegations he has tested in court, having sued his neighbor, his neighbor’s lawyer, his former employer, the Police Department, the Sheriff’s Department, the Alabama State Bar and two county circuit judges, among others. Mostly, he has lost.

headline: In Scandal, Turkey’s Leaders May Be Losing Their Tight Grip on News Media
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has labeled an investigative reporter who has published a number of leaked documents related to a widening corruption scandal a traitor. Mr. Erdogan’s lawyers have also filed suit against a newspaper columnist, once a reliable supporter of the prime minister, for his critical Twitter messages.

headline: Kiss and Tell: Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley Talk Shop
text: Even if you like the rock band Kiss, and the bratty superhero antics of its founders, Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley, their appearance at the end of John Varvatos’s show in Milan qualified as a cringe moment. With models standing around them, the rock legends fist-pumped the air — Mr. Simmons stuck his tongue out, of course — and Mr. Varvatos looked pleased to be with his new mates. His clothes this season have a sleek toughness, with scaly metallic finishes and feathered fabrics that made you think of animals. Maybe that’s a link to Kiss. Still, the group’s presence seemed out of context, like someone photo-bombing your wedding pictures. Well, someone with clown makeup and a cherry-red tongue.

headline: Keeping Public Buildings Free of Guns Proves Too Costly for Kansas Towns
text: WICHITA, Kan. — Reasoning that more guns mean greater safety, Kansas lawmakers voted last year to require cities and counties to make public buildings accessible to people legally carrying concealed weapons.

headline: A Cheerleader for Others, Virginia Governor Stands on His Own
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton toasted Terry McAuliffe, the incoming governor of Virginia, at a private dinner here Friday evening. Then they walked with him through the State Capitol on Saturday morning on the way to his inauguration and sat on the rain-soaked steps outside, smiling broadly under an umbrella as he took the oath not long after noon.

headline: Prepared for Seattle’s Noise, the Saints Can’t Overcome Seattle’s Players
text: SEATTLE — For their return to that caldron of cacophony called CenturyLink Field, the New Orleans Saints reconstructed the stadium’s atmosphere. Tried to, rather.

headline: Water Ban Continues
text: Residents in Charleston, West Virginia, and nearby communities have been warned to stay away from tap water for drinking and washing.

headline: 9-Year-Old Killed by Taxi Was ‘Spirited’ and ‘Wise’
text: A 9-year-old boy who was one of two people struck and killed by separate vehicles on the Upper West Side on Friday night was described by his family on Saturday as a “spirited third grader” with a fanatical devotion to the New York Knicks.

headline: Wait Continues for Safe Tap Water in West Virginia
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — As hundreds of thousands of residents faced a third day without water because of a chemical spill in a local river, a water company executive said on Saturday that it could be days before it was safe for them to drink tap water again.

headline: Staying Drug-Free, and Providing for His Son the ‘Right Way’
text: It has taken a while, but Justen Henderson, 25, has learned from his mistakes.

headline: Villanova Rediscovers 3-Point Touch, and St. John’s Loses Way
text: Eighth-ranked Villanova found the separation it needed to avoid an upset against St. John’s in the final six and a half minutes of a 74-67 victory Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Rising Tide Is a Mystery That Sinks Island Hopes
text: LAGO ENRIQUILLO, Dominican Republic — Steadily, mysteriously, like in an especially slow science fiction movie, the largest lake in the Caribbean has been rising and rising, devouring tens of thousands of acres of farmland, ranches and whatever else stands in its way.

headline: Delay in Plan to Drug Screen Applicants for Unemployment Aid
text: Texans applying for unemployment benefits will be subject to a new drug screening procedure in a program scheduled to take effect Feb. 1. But the Texas Workforce Commission said it would not be able to start the program on the state’s timetable because the United States Labor Department had not set the required parameters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 11, 2014
Another Academic Group Considers Israel Censure
text: CHICAGO — A movement to pressure and isolate Israel gained further ground among American academics on Saturday, when the Modern Language Association took a step toward approving a resolution calling on the State Department to contest what it characterized as Israel’s discriminatory “denials of entry” to American scholars seeking to visit the West Bank to work at Palestinian universities.

headline: ‘A Coarse Pleasure’ in Stories of Impostors
text: In 1985, when the novelist and playwright James Magnuson first accepted a job teaching creative writing at the University of Texas at Austin, he harbored a fair amount of skepticism toward the academic world. In the past, he had taken what he called “an outsider’s pride” in being able to support himself as a writer without having to teach. He wondered too if both the teachers and the students in creative writing programs were prone to taking themselves too seriously.

headline: Goalie Gets Back on His Game in a Town Full of Tough Critics
text: Over the last two decades, playing in Philadelphia has been a nightmare for Flyers goalies.

headline: Predicting the Future in 13 Races
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Violence Replaces Rejoicing After Central African Leaders Resign
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Sporadic looting, gunfire and a handful of deadly clashes, including some with French soldiers, took the place of celebrations here after the forced resignation of President Michel Djotodia and Prime Minister Nicolas Tiangaye on Friday.

headline: 2 Far-Right Greek Lawmakers Are Accused of Criminal Activity
text: ATHENS — Two lawmakers from Greece’s far-right party, Golden Dawn, were ordered to be taken into custody late on Saturday on charges of joining and directing a criminal organization. The decision was part of a government crackdown on the party, which has been condemned by European authorities as neo-Nazi and violent.

headline: Record-Setting Night for a Patriot (Not Brady) Eliminates the Colts
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The shootout between Tom Brady and Andrew Luck in Saturday night’s divisional playoff game was a riveting duel for three quarters. It had everything a postseason game should have, with Luck cast as the resolute heir apparent who played brilliantly as he tried to knock off Brady, the Patriots longtime king of playoff excellence.

headline: Judy Protas, Writer of Slogan for Levy’s Real Jewish Rye, Dies at 91
text: You don’t have to be Jewish to write an ad for rye bread that has endured in public memory for more than half a century, but in Judy Protas’s case it certainly didn’t hurt.

headline: GMC Canyon Is a Midsize Striver
text: DETROIT — General Motors introduced its step-up entry in the midsize pickup market on Sunday, a day ahead of the opening of press previews for the Detroit auto show. The 2015 GMC Canyon takes its place in the G.M. lineup just a bit upstream of the 2015 Chevrolet Colorado, which was introduced at the Los Angeles auto show in November.

headline: Indonesia Announces Export Ban on Raw Ore
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia, one of the world’s biggest producers of minerals including gold, nickel, copper, tin and thermal coal, implemented a new law Sunday banning the export of unprocessed ore.

headline: Aliisa Rosenthal and Samuel Hodges
text: Aliisa Rachel Rosenthal and Samuel Hazen Hodges were married Saturday evening at Antoine’s Restaurant in New Orleans. Dana F. Worth, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Eve Rudin, Elliott Kleinman
text: Rabbi Eve Sandra Rudin and Rabbi Elliott Adam Kleinman are to be married Sunday at the Woodlands Community Temple in White Plains. Rabbi David Ellenson is to perform the ceremony.

headline: A Surprise for the Holidays
text: Dr. Rebecca Jacqueline Aspden and Larry Demetrious Waddell are to be married Sunday at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington. The Rev. Michael W. Caine, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to officiate.

headline: Meredith Small and Scott Wallace
text: Meredith Ashley Small, a daughter of Neal C. Small and Cherie L. Small of Dallas, was married Saturday at her parents’ vacation home in Victor, Idaho, to Scott Trevor Wallace, a son of Leneta J. Wallace of Sherman, Tex., and the late Don Wallace. Justin A. Small, the brother of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Rachel Hilzinger, Ross Monten
text: Rachel Colleen Hilzinger and Ensign Ross Alan Monten were married Saturday afternoon at Trinity Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Mark E. Asman, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lauren Baer and Emily Meyers
text: Lauren Elizabeth Baer and Emily Margalit Meyers were married in New York Saturday evening by Rabbi Bruce S. Warshal, with Cantor Lori Corrsin taking part. The ceremony was held at Temple Emanu-El, where Ms. Baer’s paternal great-granduncle, the late Dr. Julius Mark, was the senior rabbi from 1948 to 1977.

headline: Adrianna Giuliani and Jim Bevilaqua
text: Adrianna Lara Giuliani and Jim Joseph Bevilaqua were married Saturday at the Bowery Hotel in New York. The Rev. Alma Daniel, an interfaith minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Nina Vertlib and Jared Eisenberg
text: Nina Vertlib, the daughter of Marina and Alexander Vertlib of Walnut Creek, Calif., was married Saturday evening to Jared Eli Eisenberg, a son of Andrea and Mark Eisenberg of Dorchester, Mass. Nicole Berne, a friend of the couple who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, officiated at the Melville Park Bed & Breakfast in Dorchester, which is owned by the groom’s parents.

headline: Caroline Shnay, Samuel Goldberg
text: Caroline Fay Shnay and Samuel Hankin Goldberg were married Saturday evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Dovi Scheiner officiated.

headline: Alexandra Parsons and Mark Andrews IV
text: Alexandra Geddes Parsons, a daughter of Kathryn M. Parsons and J. Geddes Parsons of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Mark Edwin Andrews IV, the son of Elizabeth Quay Andrews and Mr. Andrews III of New York. The Rev. Matthew Heyd, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, where he is the rector.

headline: For TV Fans, Cramming In Sunday’s Best
text: Pity the DVR, destined to be overworked on Sunday night.

headline: New York Times Hires Bloomberg Reporter in China Controversy
text: A Bloomberg News reporter who recently left the news organization over a controversy involving an unpublished article from China has joined The New York Times.

headline: The Glow Stick Fiasco
text: Elliott Klienman had a grand vision involving thousands of glow sticks. Eve Rudin messed it up.

headline: Playing Second Fiddle for a Chance at First Place
text: Serving as a champion’s second can pay off for players seeking to improve their own games.

headline: For Financier, a Final Try to Avoid U.S. Charges
text: A lawyer for Florian Homm, a German financier wanted by United States authorities, says he will appeal to the Italian Ministry of Justice in a last-ditch attempt to prevent the former hedge fund manager from being extradited to Los Angeles to face charges of securities fraud.

headline: Teenager Arrested and Charged in Killing of 16-Year-Old in Brooklyn
text: A teenager was arrested on Saturday in the fatal shooting earlier this month of a 16-year-old boy who was heading home from a birthday party in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

headline: Corrections: January 12, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: After Surgery, Murray Lowers His Sights
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — For years, Andy Murray’s right hand shot so frequently to his back after arduous or even routine points that it sometimes seemed permanently attached. Murray looked, at times, like an old man, or at least a man far older than 26.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: When Divorce Magnifies Adoption’s Losses
text: Last summer, en route to pick up my youngest daughter from a weeklong sleepaway camp in Connecticut designed specifically for adopted children, I was half-certain I would find her wailing about having been miserable, friendless and infected with Lyme’s disease. Would she run into my arms and dissolve into tears? This was her first time alone and away from home. That she might have enjoyed herself, made friends and been tick-free seemed like too much to wish for.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Versace Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 71ST ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Tina Fey and Amy Poehler (above right, with Ms. Fey) host these awards — often considered predictors of the Oscars — sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live. In the motion picture drama division, the nominees are “12 Years a Slave,” “Captain Phillips,” “Gravity,” “Philomena” and “Rush,” for best picture; Cate Blanchett, Sandra Bullock, Judi Dench, Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet, for best actress; and Chiwetel Ejiofor, Idris Elba, Tom Hanks, Matthew McConaughey and Robert Redford, for best actor. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees are “American Hustle,” “Her,” “Inside Llewyn Davis,” “Nebraska” and “The Wolf of Wall Street,” for best picture; Amy Adams, Julie Delpy, Greta Gerwig, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Meryl Streep, for best actress; and Christian Bale, Bruce Dern, Leonardo DiCaprio, Oscar Isaac and Joaquin Phoenix, for best actor. Woody Allen will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award, although he is not expected to attend. Awards will also be handed out for television work. A countdown to the ceremony begins at 4 on E!, which moves to red carpet coverage at 6. NBC will report on arrivals, starting at 7. And E! will visit after-parties at 11.

headline: What to Look for on the Globes Red Carpet
text: This much is clear about this year’s Golden Globes. Whether Lupita Nyong’o wins the award for best supporting actress at Sunday night’s ceremonies (an award for which she is the heavy favorite) or not, the young Kenyan actress will stride the red carpet beforehand as a bona fide star of the fashion world.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Neil Barrett Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Golden Globes Predictions (and Hopes)
text: LOS ANGELES – The Golden Globes are mostly an excuse to drink, laugh and sing off-key along with the hosts Tina Fey and Amy Poehler. But the awards also serve as a warm-up to creaming your officemates in your Oscar pool.

headline: In Our Pages: January 13
text: 1939: Father Kills Son To ‘End Lifetime Suffering’

headline: Disruptions: At CES, a Big Stage for Big Dreams but Fewer Surprises
text: LAS VEGAS — Marissa Mayer and 50 Cent. Budgee the robot and Parrot the drone. Smartwatches and curving TVs, all sprinkled with Hollywood stardust.

headline: Hungry? Buy This Billboard
text: Eric Justusson, a software engineer, was walking to work from Brooklyn across the Manhattan Bridge when he first saw the enigmatic billboard, the words “Easy As” in gigantic letters followed by a 12-foot-high picture of a slice of pie. For BJ Gruber, an actor who lives in Astoria, Queens, it was the words “Cool As A,” followed by a photo of a cucumber slice that he spotted while driving on the Brooklyn Queens Expressway. Soledad Tejada, a high school student from Brooklyn, noticed one with “The Big” and a tremendous hunk of cheese in her home borough.

headline: Live Stream | Prada’s Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
text: The latest men’s collection from Prada at Milan fashion week.

headline: Antigovernment Protesters Try to Shut Down Bangkok
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters seeking to block next month’s elections in Thailand seized control of major roads in Bangkok on Monday as they began their campaign to shut down the city.

headline: ‘Lone Survivor’ a Surprise Hit at Box Office
text: Moviegoers have stubbornly refused to care about war movies set in Afghanistan, contributing to modest prerelease expectations for Peter Berg’s “Lone Survivor.” But ticket buyers, especially those in heartland states, surprised Hollywood over the weekend and powered “Lone Survivor” (Universal Pictures) to an estimated $38.9 million in sales, roughly double the total that most analysts expected and easily enough for first place at the North American box office.

headline: As Usual, Patriots Find Talent Where Others Fear to Tread
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The bearded Julian Edelman wore a flat cap and a trench coat, standing at his dressing stall, when the four-touchdown man of the late-night hour, LeGarrette Blount, walked by, still in his game jersey, No. 29.

headline: Negotiators Put Final Touches on Iran Accord
text: PARIS — Iran and a group of six world powers completed a deal on Sunday that will temporarily freeze much of Tehran’s nuclear program starting next Monday, Jan. 20, in exchange for limited relief from Western economic sanctions.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: John Varvatos Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Praise and Criticism as Sharon’s Body Lies in State
text: JERUSALEM — In life, former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was a polarizing figure, particularly after his turnabout from a builder of Jewish settlements to a man who forced their evacuation.

headline: Charlize Theron’s Influence, Anderson Cooper’s Help
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. – Even to the most hedonistic Hollywood player, the party onslaught leading up the Golden Globes can seem a little, you know, excessive. Enter the Help Haiti Home benefit, now in its third year, which donated money to the J/P Haitian Relief Organization, as well as to typhoon relief efforts in the Philippines.

headline: Wagner on U.S. Team as Officials Choose Reputation Over Result
text: BOSTON — Her free skate was not yet complete, but Gracie Gold, 18, landed a double axel and smiled and pumped her fists.

headline: A Busy Doctor’s Right Hand, Ever Ready to Type
text: DALLAS — Amid the controlled chaos that defines an average afternoon in an urban emergency department, Dr. Marian Bednar, an emergency room physician at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas, entered the exam room of an older woman who had fallen while walking her dog. Like any doctor, she asked questions, conducted an exam and gave a diagnosis — in this case, a fractured hand — while also doing something many physicians in today’s computerized world are no longer free to do: She gave the patient her full attention.

headline: The Anti-Scientific Revolution in Macroeconomics
text: Well, now I’m in Dublin to receive the James Joyce Award; life is interesting, although it does tend to get in the way of blogging.

headline: Christie’s Potential 2016 Rivals Tread Carefully
text: Gov. Chris Christie’s potential rivals for the White House in 2016 stepped gingerly around the scandal involving road closures and political retribution in New Jersey, saying on Sunday that they were waiting for more details to come out.

headline: Senior Libyan Official Assassinated, First Since Qaddafi Era
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A Libyan deputy cabinet minister was killed by gunmen on Saturday evening in the first assassination of a senior government figure in the country since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi more than two years ago.

headline: Prada: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Bottega Veneta Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: In Alex Rodriguez Decision, the Devil Is in a Lack of Detail
text: Since early August, “The Wolf of East 161st Street” has been playing in the Bronx and theaters everywhere, with Alex Rodriguez as the star.

headline: Francis Looks to the Developing World in Appointing New Cardinals
text: ROME — Pope Francis continued reshaping the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church on Sunday by appointing his first group of cardinals with an emphasis on Asia, Africa and Latin America, even as he also made omissions that signal his distaste for the traditional clerical career ladder.

headline: Q. & A.: Wu Wei Reflects on Reform, Now and in the 1980s
text: Wu Wei is a former Chinese official who in the 1980s was heavily involved in developing the Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang’s plans for measured political reform. Mr. Wu also served as a secretary to Bao Tong, the senior aide to Mr. Zhao. Those reforms collapsed in 1989, when the party patriarch, Deng Xiaoping, turned against Mr. Zhao and ordered troops to suppress student protests based in Tiananmen Square in Beijing. Mr. Wu was detained and investigated after the June 4, 1989, crackdown, and later went into publishing and business. He has remained a close observer of Chinese politics, and last year his book “On Stage and Backstage: China’s Political Reform in the 1980s” was published in Hong Kong.

headline: 1924: Thaw Sets in at Chamonix, Keeping Olympic Skaters Off Ice
text: Melting ice caused concern ahead of the first Winter Games in Chamonix in 1924.

headline: Spanish Opera House to Lose Crumbling Facade by Star Architect
text: MADRID — In the latest development in the ongoing travails of Santiago Calatrava, the Spanish architect, construction workers are due to start removing the crumbling mosaic facade of Valencia’s opera house on Monday.

headline: In Tight Game, 49ers’ Experience Conquers Panthers’ Exuberance
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In many ways, the Carolina Panthers and the San Francisco 49ers were mirror images of each other during the regular season, so it was fitting that the two teams shadowed each other for most of their divisional playoff game Sunday.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Missoni Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Visa Trims Slogan to Expand Meaning
text: IN a world where time-pressed people type “u 2” for “you too”; say “because” to introduce a noun or adjective rather than a full clause, as in “because doughnuts;” and use abbreviations like “ftw” (“for the win”), marketing and media phrases are also increasingly being compressed. For instance, commercials for Alka-Seltzer Plus keep the words “Oh, what a relief it is” from their vintage predecessors while eliminating the “Plop, plop, fizz, fizz.” The sequels to “The Fast and the Furious” go by titles like “Fast & Furious 6.” And “Masterpiece Theater” on PBS is now “Masterpiece.”

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave,’ ‘American Hustle’ Take Top Honors at the 2014 Golden Globes
text: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live-blogged the 71st annual Golden Globes on Sunday night, with contributions from Melena Ryzik and others.

headline: A Family Drama, and a Balancing Act
text: Peter Paige gets just a tiny bit agitated when asked about the amount of sex on his television show “The Fosters.” “We’re dealing with two women who are raising five kids!” he exclaims. Sometimes they can sneak away. But mostly they need to make lunches or monitor homework or drive someone to a piano lesson. Who has the time?

headline: If the Fur Doesn’t Drive You Crazy, the Virus Will
text: Syfy has been trying to step up its game lately, and two new shows make respectable additions to its lineup, even if they do work tried-and-true subject matter.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 13
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Not Just Another Ex-Con Hoping for Hip-Hop Glory
text: Animation is best suited for what might not be believable, even if seen. And our era of extreme progressivism notwithstanding, the idea of a gay white hip-hop thug still remains, for many, the stuff of fantasy.

headline: Now You See the Motorcycle, Now You Don’t
text: Some skills aren’t particularly television friendly, and magic, especially the small-scale kind like the card trick, is one of them. If you’re not witnessing it live at fairly close range, you have to take it on faith that something magical happened, and that no camera manipulation was involved.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 13
text: BANK EARNINGS JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, set to report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, will kick off a flurry of bank earnings. The banking giants, analysts say, will most likely face sluggish demand from borrowers whose appetite for refinancing has been sapped by rising rates. For JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest bank, the quarterly report comes after a string of costly government settlements, prompting analysts to predict that high legal costs could hamper profit. All told, JPMorgan will have paid some $20 billion to resolve government investigations in the last 12 months alone.

headline: Talking About Their (Iron-Fisted) Generation
text: Among indicators of an actor’s commitment, here’s an impressive one: sticks with a production despite a parent refusing contact as a result. Such (spoiler alert) has been the consequence for Viviana Hernández in “El Año en Que Nací (The Year I Was Born),” a play by the Argentine director Lola Arias playing at La MaMa as part of the Public Theater’s Under the Radar Festival. It makes sense that Ms. Hernández would stay; she is, after all, telling the story of her life in this production, in which nine Chileans, born between 1976 and 1984, knit together a history both sweeping and deeply intimate.

headline: A Personal Revolution Is Set Amid an Epic One
text: Deborah Samson is 22 and free of indenture, but addicted to adventure. She has left the church, and yet she is a believer of sorts, in independence for the American colonies and for herself. She recoils at orders to serve at table, and yet she yearns to serve in arms.

headline: Playing Composer, of Course, to Impress
text: At a time when opportunities for gifted emerging opera composers blazing all manner of new stylistic trails appear to be proliferating, there’s something to be said for a company willing to go to bat for fresh pieces by veteran creators working in conventional modes. Not long ago, that company likely would have been the Dicapo Opera, which performed an estimable service in championing composers like Thomas Pasatieri, Tobias Picker and Conrad Susa.

headline: In Baraka, Inspiration Came With Provocation
text: I’m not the right age for Amiri Baraka, not exactly. Or rather: I’m not the right age to have seen his changes as they happened. Mr. Baraka, who died last week at 79, passed through so many different phases, from middle-class kid in Newark to aspiring Beat poet to founder of the Black Arts movement to leftist activist to academic. For me, he arrived as an author looking back, already armed with his own self-reflection: He published his memoir, “The Autobiography of LeRoi Jones,” in 1984, when I was in high school, though the book didn’t make its way into my hands or my brain until a few years after that.

headline: Actors Jam Meeting to Seek Higher Pay for Tours
text: More than 350 Actors’ Equity members packed a union hall and overflow room on Friday to demonstrate visibly their concern about lower salaries for musical theater performers on national tours, a source of intensifying frustration that has led Equity leaders to schedule a town hall meeting with members on Jan. 27.

headline: Networker
text: Twenty years ago, my wife and I bought a weekend house in the town of Garrison, N.Y., in the lower Hudson Valley. We love the place for its scenic beauty, its peace and quiet, and its old-fashioned sense of community. For us, it’s a refuge from the pace of city life, a place with an easygoing mix of lifestyles and a widely shared ethos about preserving what makes it special.

headline: Everybody
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the things I like most about solving crossword puzzles is that it’s an ALL-inclusive pastime. Anyone can do it, if they are so inclined. And today, Lynn Lempel starts our solving week by inviting ONE AND ALL to solve her puzzle.

headline: With a Happy Refrain: MGM’s Magic Era
text: Why is it that with few exceptions visionary film producers go largely unrecognized by the public while directors and movie stars become legends? That question informed “Going Hollywood: MGM Musicals,” the ebullient season-opening program of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series on Saturday night, hosted by the director and choreographer Kathleen Marshall.

headline: Forget the Domestic. Try the Imported. It’s Less Fizzy.
text: The narrowed cat eyes that suddenly widen into a maniacal blue-eyed stare, the pleated platinum hair of a ’40s femme fatale, the deployment of a voice that can rise to a furious yowl by an imperious diva sheathed in black satin: No expressionistic detail was overlooked in Ute Lemper’s new show, a kind of best-of concert, which began a run at 54 Below on Wednesday evening.

headline: A Victim Becomes Triumphant
text: “Thumbprint,” an earnest new chamber opera, has going for it an inspiring true story. The work, which had its premiere on Friday at the Baruch Performing Arts Center as part of the festival Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now, is about Mukhtar Mai, a Pakistani woman who was gang-raped in 2002 as payback for an “honor crime” allegedly committed by her brother. While custom called for rape victims to kill themselves to avoid dishonor, Ms. Mukhtar spoke out, bringing her assailants to justice. She went on to become a human-rights activist, opening schools and running an ambulance service and a women’s aid group in her village.

headline: Editorial Cartoon
text: Dennis Rodman helps Kim Jong-un score propaganda points.

headline: Denver Art Museum Gets Impressionist Trove
text: The Denver Art Museum is announcing Monday that it has received the largest gift of paintings in its history, a group of 22 Impressionist works — by artists including van Gogh, Monet, Cézanne, Manet and Renoir — from the collection of Frederic C. Hamilton, an oil and gas magnate who has been the museum’s chief benefactor for several decades. The works include van Gogh’s 1887 “Edge of a Wheat Field With Poppies,” which will be the first van Gogh in the museum’s collection. Besides European works the donation includes pieces by major American Impressionists like Childe Hassam and William Merritt Chase. The gift has “forever changed the museum’s ability to deliver world-class exhibitions and programs,” said Christoph Heinrich, the museum’s director, and it transforms Denver’s holdings of Impressionism into one of the most important in the Western states. The paintings, mostly landscapes and seascapes, will be given a dedicated home in the museum’s newest addition, by the architect Daniel Libeskind, which opened in 2006. Mr. Hamilton, who served as chairman of the museum’s board from 1994 until last year, led the fund-raising effort for that $110 million expansion, and the building now bears his name.

headline: Q. and A. With John Kerry
text: If President Obama is the nation’s highest-ranking recreational basketball player, then Secretary of State John Kerry is probably the top hockey player. Kerry was awarded several medals for his Vietnam War service, served 28 years as a senator from Massachusetts and ran for president in 2004, but sometimes it seems that his proudest moments have taken place on a rink.

headline: U.S. Teams for the World Youth Teams Chosen at Atlanta Trials
text: This year’s World Youth Teams Championships will be in Istanbul from Aug. 13 to 23. The United States Bridge Federation is sending five teams, and it recently organized trials in Atlanta to select them.

headline: Hollande’s Companion Is Hospitalized
text: PARIS — Valérie Trierweiler, the companion of President François Hollande and France’s de facto first lady, was admitted to a hospital on Friday after learning along with the rest of France that Mr. Hollande is apparently having an affair with another woman.

headline: Madeline Arakawa Gins, Visionary Architect, Is Dead at 72
text: Madeline Arakawa Gins, a poet-turned-painter-turned-architect who publicly forswore mortality — and whose buildings, by her own account, were designed to pre-empt death for those living in them — died on Jan. 8 in Manhattan. She was 72.

text: I.

headline: Favorites and Discoveries Among a Superabundance of Jazz
text: Here’s what you could have heard at around 6:45 on Saturday evening, during the earliest shift of that day’s programming for the 10th annual NYC Winter Jazzfest: Extravagantly detailed large-canvas compositions, courtesy of Darcy James Argue’s Secret Society. A deep meld of Afro-Cuban music and modern jazz by Michele Rosewoman’s New Yor-Uba. Acoustic folk singing emulsified into a satiny blend by Tillery. Complex rhythmic calculus refashioned into body blows, by the guitarist Miles Okazaki or by one of two dynamic young drummers, Mark Guiliana and Ted Poor.

headline: Interview: Kevin Spacey
text: The actor discusses "House of Cards" on the red carpet.

headline: Afghan Police, Often Derided, Face Another Drawback: Missing Pay
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Outgunned by the Taliban and often derided by some as little more than uniformed thieves, police officers in Afghanistan do not have an easy job. But in recent months, their lives have gotten even tougher: Afghanistan’s police officers have not been paid since November, and some have not seen a paycheck since October.

Uncovering Racial Disparities in Sleep Health

headline: The Next Frontier in Fertility Treatment
text: ANDY INKSTER, a transgender man, had always wanted biological children. So when he embarked on the transition from female to male at age 18 — changing his name, taking testosterone and eventually undergoing surgery to remove his breasts — he left his female reproductive organs intact.

headline: Interview: Cast of 'Brooklyn Nine-Nine'
text: The cast discusses their sitcom.

headline: Golden Globes Red Carpet Fashion
text: Established stars and newcomers made their entrances at the Golden Globes in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: More Movies at Sundance Are Sidestepping the Big Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — What will be the difference between this year’s Sundance and the Sundance of 2006, when independent film was last riding high?

headline: Steve McQueen & Bianca Stigter
text: A talk with the the director Steve McQueen and his partner Bianca Stigter.

headline: Texas Vote-Buying Case Casts Glare on Tradition of Election Day Goads
text: DONNA, Tex. — In this Rio Grande Valley town of trailer parks and weedy lots eight miles from the Mexico border, people call them runners or politiqueras — the campaign workers who use their network of relatives and friends to deliver votes for their candidates. They travel around town with binders stuffed with the names and addresses of registered voters, driving residents to and from the polls and urging those they bump into at the grocery store to support their candidates.

headline: Enemies of the Poor
text: Suddenly it’s O.K., even mandatory, for politicians with national ambitions to talk about helping the poor. This is easy for Democrats, who can go back to being the party of F.D.R. and L.B.J. It’s much more difficult for Republicans, who are having a hard time shaking their reputation for reverse Robin-Hoodism, for being the party that takes from the poor and gives to the rich.

headline: Dudes and Other Distractions in Milan
text: This morning I visited Antonio De Matteis, the chief executive of Kiton, in the company’s new offices in Milan — the former Palazzo Ferre — and he told me something that warmed my heart: you should be able to sleep in your clothes. When a garment feels good and is well made, as a Kiton suit or coat certainly is, you should be able to wear it without sense of care, even if your natural inclination is to baby a very expensive, handmade jacket. Mr. De Matteis, from years of experience, from generations of being Italian, wouldn’t dream of such fussiness. He removed his jacket and slipped it on backward, showing how he wears it to sleep on a plane.

headline: It’s Brooklyn, Basketball and Branding as Nets Head to London
text: After playing five games in eight days, the Nets find themselves with something of a holiday. They were headed to London on Sunday night, preparing to play the Atlanta Hawks at O2 Arena on Thursday night, the only game they are scheduled to play for the next eight days.

headline: Syria Rebels Turn Against Most Radical Group Tied to Al Qaeda
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As a government warplane soared over the northern Syrian city of Raqqa recently, a fighter from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, the country’s most radical group linked to Al Qaeda, watched from behind an antiaircraft gun mounted on a pickup truck. Fighters and activists from rival insurgent factions urged him to fire. He did not.

headline: Heroic Measures
text: LISA BONCHEK ADAMS has spent the last seven years in a fierce and very public cage fight with death. Since a mammogram detected the first toxic seeds of cancer in her left breast when she was 37, she has blogged and tweeted copiously about her contest with the advancing disease. She has tweeted through morphine haze and radiation burn. Even by contemporary standards of social-media self-disclosure, she is a phenomenon. (Last week she tweeted her 165,000th tweet.) A rapt audience of several thousand follows her unsparing narrative of mastectomy, chemotherapy, radiation, biopsies and scans, pumps and drains and catheters, grueling drug trials and grim side effects, along with her posts on how to tell the children, potshots at the breast cancer lobby, poetry and resolute calls to “persevere.”

headline: Interview: Jemima Kirke
text: The actress discusses “Girls.”

headline: Dance Band Experiments With ‘Three-Way Stereo’
text: Pop musicians have been tinkering with the possibilities of stereo sound for decades. In the 1960s, for example, the Beatles sometimes separated individual instruments between left and right channel, and the Velvet Underground took that to an extreme on songs like “The Murder Mystery.”

headline: As Conjugal Visits Fade, a Lifeline to Inmates’ Spouses Is Lost
text: PARCHMAN, Miss. — To spend time alone with the man she married four months ago, Ebony Fisher, 25, drives nearly three hours through the flat cotton fields of the Mississippi Delta until she pulls into a gravel lot next to the state’s rural penitentiary.

headline: Clashes Between Militants and Army Spread in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — A confrontation between Iraqi insurgents and government forces in the western city of Falluja edged closer to the capital on Sunday, after clashes between militants and the army left at least 14 people dead in the Abu Ghraib district in Baghdad Province, according to security officials.

headline: Are Big Banks Out of Control?
text: Does the lack of legal compliance that have cost banks billions in fines show that some have gotten too big to manage properly?

headline: A Flashback to the Reign of J. Edgar Hoover
text: I was a college sophomore in April 1971, still mourning the death of Jimi Hendrix, when I learned that a campus organization to which I belonged was being spied on by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The news landed in the mailbox of the Black Student Union — at what is now known as Widener University, not far from Philadelphia — in an envelope stuffed with documents that had been stolen from an F.B.I. office in nearby Media, Pa.

headline: Missing Executive Actions
text: President Obama has often issued executive orders to get around recalcitrant Republicans in Congress or to clarify existing policy. Yet there are some areas where the president has been too reticent. The start of a new year is a good moment to point out some matters ripe for executive action.

headline: Where Free Speech Collides With Abortion Rights
text: BOSTON — A couple of mornings a week, Eleanor McCullen stakes out a spot outside the Planned Parenthood clinic here and tries to persuade women on their way in to think twice before having an abortion.

headline: NBC’s News Unit Teams With Video Start-Up NowThis News

headline: The Basketball Player’s Guide to the (European) Galaxy
text: ALICANTE, Spain — You are a star high school basketball player, a whirlwind on the court. You score points, get rebounds and cover the ball on the defensive end. You get a scholarship and enjoy college. The N.B.A. draft is approaching and you can’t wait to cash in.

headline: Treading Water on Syria
text: Nearly three years after the fighting began, many of the most dire predictions about Syria’s civil war have come true. The conflict has not only engulfed the country, killing more than 130,000 people and forcing more than nine million civilians out of their homes. Increasingly, it has metastasized across the region, destabilizing neighboring countries and serving as a magnet for militants, or would-be militants, including some from the United States.

headline: For Manning, Win Brings Big Relief and Bigger Rematch
text: DENVER — For exactly a year, Peyton Manning had lived with the duplicitous burden of being the N.F.L.’s best quarterback and an underachieving one. On Sunday, the anniversary of a stinging home loss to the underdog Baltimore Ravens, Manning and Broncos fans awoke to a full-page photograph of the quarterback under a dark cloud against a towering Denver Post headline: A Legacy Under a Cloud.

headline: Critics Say Spill Highlights Lax West Virginia Regulations
text: Last week’s major chemical spill into West Virginia’s Elk River, which cut off water to more than 300,000 people, came in a state with a long and troubled history of regulating the coal and chemical companies that form the heart of its economy.

headline: Saving Relics, Afghans Defy the Taliban

headline: Roger Ailes’s Permanent Pushback Campaign
text: Roger Ailes, the chairman of Fox News Channel, has little left to accomplish in a remarkable television career. He has made billions for his owners, created an entirely new genre of TV and, in doing so, he has changed the way politics is conducted. His business legacy is secure.

headline: An Unemployed Cook Grasps a Bit of Hope on One of Winter’s Coldest Days
text: The night before his big interview, Gregory Brandon crawled into bed and prayed. “That I get the job,” he said quietly. “That everything will be all right.” Then he tossed and turned until he finally emerged from his blankets at about 6 a.m.

In the private room in back are bigger, shinier versions of the jewels out front.

headline: Quick Exit for Venus Williams at Australian Open

headline: CUNY Hopes to Dismiss Brooklyn College Official Over Financial Inquiry
text: The Graduate Center for Worker Education, a tiny outpost of Brooklyn College in Lower Manhattan, has long been a busy place. For three decades, it has attracted students from across New York, minted hundreds of graduates of its master’s program in urban planning and administration, and housed the noted labor studies journal Working USA.

text: Now that Florida State has been crowned the national champion of college football, the spotlight shifts to basketball and a freshman class that includes the expected top N.B.A. draft picks Andrew Wiggins of Kansas and Jabari Parker of Duke. Here are some games to watch this week.

Hamilton, an oil and gas magnate who has been the museum’s chief benefactor for several decades.

headline: The Empty-Diet-Claim Season
text: I don’t need a calendar to know that a new year has begun. I can tell by the deluge of new diet books that arrive in the office mail — more than two dozen since mid-December. On a whim, I weighed them all: over 25 pounds of mostly bad advice, about as much as many readers hope to lose before they have to shed the concealing garb of winter.

headline: MTV’s ‘16 and Pregnant,’ Derided by Some, May Resonate as a Cautionary Tale
text: WASHINGTON — Kailyn Lowry, at age 17, decided to let MTV film her pregnancy and the birth of her first child in the hope of persuading other young men and women to wait to start a family.

headline: GE Capital to Help Set Up Loyalty Programs for Retailers
text: Its logo may not be prominent in stores, but GE Capital Retail Bank has a hand in the branded credit cards of tens of thousands of retailers, including J.C. Penney, Walmart and the Gap.

headline: Aiming to Push Genomics Forward in New Study
text: Here comes genomics, Take 2.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) AT BERKELEY (2013) Without narration or identifying the people interviewed — from the humblest janitor to the most esteemed professor — Frederick Wiseman chronicles the history and teaching process of the University of California, Berkeley, while mulling the effect of capitalism on state-funded public education. “Mr. Wiseman has made his share of grim documentaries in which people are processed and oppressed by bureaucracy,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this four-hour film, presented here by “Independent Lens.” “ ‘At Berkeley’ is not one. Its cautiously upbeat attitude is expressed in a director’s note: ‘I think it is just as important for a filmmaker to show people of intelligence, character, tolerance and good will, hard at work, as it is to make movies about the failures, insensitivities and cruelties of others.’ Amen.”

headline: Blending Genders, for Some Laughs at the Golden Globes
text: The British actress Emma Thompson tossed her shoes across the stage and slurped a martini, Dean Martin-style. Jennifer Lawrence wore her hair almost West Point short, while the actor Jared Leto and the composer Alex Ebert put up their flowing locks in loose chignons.

headline: Bragging Rights to Share at the Golden Globes
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “American Hustle” left a messy Golden Globes as the big winner on Sunday, capturing three major awards, including best comedy. But voters stayed true to form and spread their love around, handing best drama to an otherwise ignored “12 Years a Slave” and best director to Alfonso Cuarón, for “Gravity.”

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 6-12
text: Sports clearly require excellent hand eye coordination, but frequently a contest’s outcome is determined by a little extra reach!

headline: Golden Globe Winners Reviewed
text: The Times critics review Golden Globe-winning films “12 Years a Slave,” “American Hustle” and “Gravity.”

headline: United States Figure Skating Championships
text: The sights of the 2014 United States Figure Skating Championships.

headline: A Conversation With: Deepak Kapur, Chairman of India National PolioPlus Committee
text: On Monday, India completes three years without a single new polio case. India is finally on the brink of being polio-free, nearly 30 years after the Global Polio Eradication Initiative was established. Celebrations around the country will mark this feat in global health, with cities like Lucknow, Hyderabad and New Delhi lighting up their landmarks.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Breeches of Etiquette
text: A couple of riders on the London metro drew some sidelong glances as they took part in the “No Trousers Tube Ride” on Sunday, part of an international “No Pants Subway Ride” event. The annual happening was started in New York by a comedy group in 2002, and has since become a rite of winter in which pants-less people casually wait at stations along a subway line and hop onboard. Groups in dozens of cities across the world are said to be participating in the event.

headline: Bowed and Remorseful, Former Red Guard Recalls Teacher’s Death
text: Updated, 3:54 a.m. ET | Nearly half a century after Bian Zhongyun was beaten, kicked, tormented and left to die, bloody and alone, at the Beijing girls’ school where she was deputy principal, a daughter of the Communist Party elite has offered public penance — of a kind that instantly brought controversy — for her part in one of the most notorious killings of the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Forecast for Meteorologist’s Workweek: Busy
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — On the first two days of the Australian Open, players gulped water and applied ice packs to foreheads while on changeovers. Fans lathered on sunscreen, wore hats, sought shade. A heat wave has arrived, with temperatures expected to climb well over 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Jan. 13, 2014
text: Take a quiz and find teaching ideas based on two articles, and a series of images, about the kind of fractured writing that can result when English is translated into or blended with other languages.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | All Eyes on the Golden Globe Awards
text: In “Bragging Rights to Share at Globes,” Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply write about Sunday’s Golden Globe awards.

headline: Plans for a Replica of Titanic Floated in China
text: A company in southwestern China has announced plans to build a full-scale replica of the Titanic, the passenger ship that famously sank in 1912. The Seven Star Energy Investment Group, based in Sichuan Province, said it would spend spend 1 billion renminbi, or about $164 million, to build an ocean liner that would be moored on a river bank as a tourist attraction.

headline: Cops, Clowns and Cameras
text: Jill Freedman was always attracted to closed societies, groups that didn’t much want her as a member. But her persistence always paid off.

headline: How Can a Reputation Be Improved?
text: Have you ever seen someone you know, or a celebrity you’ve read about, successfully transform a negative reputation or image?

headline: You’re All Losers
text: The other day someone — I don’t remember who or where — asked an interesting question: when did it become so common to disparage anyone who hasn’t made it big, hasn’t gotten rich, as a “loser”? Well, that’s actually a question we can answer, using Google Ngrams, which track the frequency with which words or phrases are used in books:

headline: Amec Agrees to Buy Swiss Rival for $3.2 Billion
text: LONDON – Amec, the British engineering and project management company, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire a Swiss-based rival for cash and stock in a deal valued at $3.2 billion.

headline: Israel Bids Farewell to Sharon, a ‘Complex Man’
text: SDEROT, Israel — Ariel Sharon, the fighter and farmer from Israel’s founding generation who became a prime minister both revered and reviled, was buried here Monday on a hill overlooking his family ranch, amid twin ceremonies in which he was eulogized as a courageous commander and pragmatic politician who relentlessly defended the land he loved.

headline: Times Minute | Golden Globes Results
text: Also on the Minute, Iran's nuclear deal to take effect and the one-party rule.
