headline: New York Today: How’s He Doing?
text: Updated 10:45 a.m.

headline: Swiss Teenager Beats Date-Krumm in a Battle of Generations
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Six months after winning the junior championship at Wimbledon, 16-year-old Belinda Bencic took the court Monday at the Australian Open against a woman old enough to be her mother.

headline: Tang Wei, Film Star, Reported Victim of Phone Scam
text: It was her graphic onscreen sex scenes with Tony Leung Chiu-Wai in “Lust, Caution,” under the direction of Ang Lee, that placed Tang Wei in the firmament of Chinese stars. She might have become an even bigger household name after the film was released in 2007 if prudish Chinese officials had not put her on an industry blacklist. Producers and directors avoided working with her for years, until at some point she was deemed to have been rehabilitated. She is now acting in films that are shown in mainland Chinese theaters.

headline: Protesters, Angry at Premier, Fill Bangkok’s Central Business District
text: BANGKOK — Thousands of protesters who had spent the night on the streets of Bangkok’s central commercial district marched to government offices early Tuesday as part of a so-called shutdown of the city, a largely peaceful demonstration aimed at removing the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: Sanofi Unit to Buy $700 Million Stake in Rare Disease Company
text: LONDON – The biotechnology unit of the French drug maker Sanofi  agreed on Monday to buy a 12 percent stake in Alnylam Pharmaceuticals for $700 million as part of an expanded alliance to develop treatments for rare genetic diseases.

headline: Matchmaker, Matchmaker, Find Me a Job
text: It’s no coincidence that Sanjeev Agrawal, the co-founder and chief executive of Collegefeed, compares finding a job with dating. Finding The One (or at least The One That’s Good Enough) in both jobs and love is difficult under the best of circumstances, and it’s even harder if you don’t know where or how to start your search.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 13, 2014
text: Update: Jan. 14, 2013

headline: Would You Pay $698,000 for a Head Shop?
text: In my posts I occasionally take a look at businesses for sale, which can offer interesting lessons for both buyers and sellers. This post looks at a specialty retail shop, what’s known as a head shop.

headline: My Old Osaka Home: Suntory of Japan to Buy Maker of Jim Beam
text: Few spirits are as American as bourbon. But the maker of some of whiskey’s most iconic brands, including Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark, will soon belong to an acquisitive Japanese beverage maker.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Makes Its Bid for Bigger Share of Indian Smartphone Market
text: After deliberating for months, Abhilash Sathyendra, a 25-year-old equity adviser in Mysore, India, bought his first Apple phone. He paid 9,000 rupees, or $150, upfront for a black iPhone 4s and swiped his credit card for the remainder, six no-interest monthly payments of $62.50, Saritha Rai reports.

headline: 5 Chinese I.P.O.’s Shelved After Regulator Stiffens Rules
text: HONG KONG – Five companies halted plans to sell shares on Monday after China’s securities regulator moved to tighten restrictions on new listings, the latest sign of challenges as the mainland seeks to reopen its stock markets to new offerings after a yearlong ban.

headline: Ranbaxy Says F.D.A. Lists Possible Violations at Punjab Drug Plant
text: MUMBAI — Ranbaxy Laboratories, India’s largest drug maker, said Monday that the United States Food and Drug Administration had raised concerns about possible violations in manufacturing practices at a plant in the northern state of Punjab.

headline: Thank Ackman for the Beam Deal
text: Monday ushered in the first big deal of 2014: Suntory’s takeover of Beam Inc. But the deal may not have been possible without William A. Ackman.

headline: Chevrolet Doubles Up for Car and Truck of the Year
text: General Motors kicked off the 2014 North American International Auto Show in style Monday, sweeping the awards for the North American Car and Truck of the year with its new Chevrolet Corvette Stingray sports car and Silverado pickup.

headline: Why Barington Still Opposes Darden’s Plan to Spin Off Red Lobster
text: The Barington Capital Group, the activist hedge fund pushing for change at Darden Restaurants, has already said that it is not happy with the company’s plans to spin off its Red Lobster chain.

headline: Suntory’s Deal for Jim Beam
text: Suntory, known for producing Japan’s first whiskey, has agreed to acquire the maker of Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons, among other spirits, for $13.6 billion, DealBook reports. Including the assumption of debt, the deal is valued at $16 billion. Suntory is offering Jim Beam shareholders $83.50 a share in cash, 25 percent above the company’s closing price on Friday.

headline: Men’s Milan Fashion Week: Prada Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Gucci: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Utah, in Opposing Gay Marriage, Finds Three Arguments Are Better Than One
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s order last week halting same-sex marriages in Utah was two sentences long. It was provisional and cryptic, and it added nothing to the available information on where the Supreme Court stands on the momentous question of whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

headline: Hedge Fund Backs Men’s Wearhouse Bid for Jos. A. Bank
text: One of the biggest investors in Men’s Wearhouse is officially on board with the retailer’s $1.6 billion hostile bid for Jos. A. Bank.

headline: Success, European Style
text: Since I’m in Ireland, I should give a belated plug to the very good piece by Fintan O’Toole debunking talk about Irish recovery.

headline: Elliott Turns Its Attention to Juniper Networks
text: Days after throwing its weight around at Riverbed Technology and Celesio, the hedge fund Elliott Management has begun a campaign for change at Juniper Networks, the networking equipment company.

headline: Refreshing the Lunch Box for a New Season
text: The fresh start that sparks in many of us in the new year can sputter out when the first day of school rolls around and those of us who send packed lunches with our children are faced with the gaping maws of empty insulated bags, waiting to be filled.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Arizona Appeal on Abortion Ban
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal from Arizona officials seeking to revive a state law that barred most abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy. The justices offered no reasons for turning down the appeal, as is their custom.

headline: Mediterranean Diet for Diabetes
text: More good news on the Mediterranean diet. Sticking to a Mediterranean-style diet may help reduce the risk for Type 2 diabetes, even when people don’t lose weight or increase exercise levels.

headline: Hudson River Club Forwards Chevron Grant to Group Fighting Oil’s Harms in Ecuador
text: “The Mouse That Roared” comes to mind in pondering a move made in recent days by a tiny, barebones Hudson River environmental and sailing group, The Beacon Sloop Club. The club, which has a tree growing through the roof of its rickety headquarters on the waterfront 50 miles north of New York City, was one of two local groups receiving $1,000 checks from Chevron in November for help advising the oil giant in its cleanup efforts at the site of a former Texaco facility in the nearby community of Glenham, N.Y. (Chevron merged with Texaco in 2000.)

headline: Image of the Day: January 13
text: Devotees taking a holy dip at Sagar Island in the Bay of Bengal.

headline: Carrot, Squash and Potato Ragout With Thai Flavors
text: This is inspired by a recipe in Patricia Wells’s “Vegetable Harvest.” The flavors are both sweet and pungent. Serve it on its own or over rice; Thai purple sticky rice looks particularly pretty against the orange vegetables but any type of rice will do. I’m very happy serving this over brown rice.

headline: The Chrysler 200 Gets a Reboot
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Chrysler 200

headline: Roasted Carrots With Turmeric and Cumin
text: These are based on Suzanne Goin’s turmeric-spiced root vegetables from her wonderful new book “The A.O.C. Cookbook.” I use her technique for roasting the carrots, and use the same spices she uses, but I make the dish with a little less olive oil and butter to cut down on calories. Suzanne serves her mix of carrots, turnips, parsnips and rutabagas with Greek yogurt seasoned with kaffir lime juice and zest, and mint chutney. They are also delicious on their own.

headline: Roasted Sweet Potato Oven Fries
text: I don’t know what I like best about these sweet wedges – the way the sweet potato skins crisp and caramelize, the creamy texture of the sweet flesh, or the subtle flavors of the spices and infused oil.

headline: Grated Carrot Salad With Dates and Oranges
text: The influences here are Moroccan. The orange juice brings out the sweetness of the carrots. The juices combine in a delectable way, the salad sweetened all the more by the dates and cinnamon.

headline: Turkish Pumpkin Soup
text: This is an intriguingly sweet winter squash soup, based on a recipe by Ghillie Basan from her wonderful book, “Classic Turkish Cooking.” The sweetness comes from the squash itself and the allspice and cinnamon, with the addition of only a teaspoon of honey or sugar. The sour and spicy yogurt and chile garnish make a great flavor contrast.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Bel Group, Paris, expanded its relationship with Y&R, part of the Young & Rubicam Group division of WPP, by naming the agency’s Chicago office, known as Y&R Midwest, as agency of record for Bel Brands USA, Chicago, handling duties like brand strategy and social media for cheeses that include the Laughing Cow and Boursin. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million. Y&R already handles Bel Group advertising in markets like Australia, Canada and Europe. The Bel Brands USA account had previously been handled by the Chicago office of Havas Worldwide, part of the Havas Creative unit of Havas.

headline: Airbus Led Rival Boeing in Jets Ordered Last Year
text: TOULOUSE, France — In their rivalry as the world’s leading makers of passenger aircraft, Airbus captured the lead in jets ordered last year, but Boeing delivered more planes to customers.

headline: Another Mayor Felt Christie-Tied Reprisal
text: The night he was elected mayor of Jersey City in May, Steven Fulop got a call from Gov. Chris Christie congratulating him and offering whatever help he could — a pledge that was followed up by texts and emails from Mr. Christie’s campaign and State House aides, who set up a day’s worth of meetings with high-level commissioners in what they promised would be the beginning of a happy relationship.

headline: In Our Pages: January 14
text: 1889: Fake Francs Found in Paris

headline: Ford F-150 Is Now a Lighter Hauler
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Ford F-150

headline: The South’s Greatest Governor
text: Most prominent Civil War figures made a name for themselves through either a military or political career. A few, like Henry Watkins Allen, did both, first as a renowned colonel and later as governor of Louisiana. In fact, Allen’s term as governor undercuts the widespread assumption that Confederate administration was everywhere incompetent and inefficient. As the historian E. Merton Coulter wrote, “It was Henry W. Allen who showed the rest of the Confederate governors how good a Confederate state governor could be.”

headline: Fox Announces Return for ‘24’ and Start of an Updated ‘Cosmos’
text: PASADENA, Calif. — The Fox network made a series of program announcements Monday, including the starting dates for two of its most anticipated projects: the return of the former hit “24” and an update of the famed “Cosmos” series.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 10-12, 2014
text: Last March, after a night of drinking, Caleb Gordley, 16, sneaked into a house two doors down from his own and was shot and killed by its owner in Loudoun County, Va. Immediately after the shooting, Caleb’s parents said they forgave their neighbor, believing it to be accidental.

headline: Spalding Gray Prize Goes to Richard Maxwell
text: The Spalding Gray Award, an annual prize named for the monologuist who died in 2004, will be given to the playwright and director Richard Maxwell, the consortium that oversees the prize announced on Monday. The prize includes a $20,000 commission to create a new work that will be given a full production at each of the organizations in the consortium. They are P.S. 122 in New York; the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh; On the Boards in Seattle; and the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

headline: Suntory’s Deal for Beam Continues a Boom in Alcohol M.&A.
text: Suntory’s $13.6 billion deal for the maker of Jim Beam is the third-largest acquisition by a Japanese company of a non-Japanese company, according to Thomson Reuters, based on a $16 billion valuation that includes the assumption of debt.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Brit Hume Explains Christie
text: Via Media Matters

headline: Stern-Mackenzie One-Round War
text: It’s war. You size up your warriors — all three of them. There’s strongest A, next-strongest B, and weakest C. Your opponent has three different-strength warriors as well. Warriors will fight in pairs (each warrior fights just one fight), and whichever side wins the most contests is the victor.

headline: Extremist Militant Group in Syria Retakes Ground Lost to Rival Rebels
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Making good on threats to contest attacks by former allies on its power and claimed turf, the extremist militant group the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria has retaken significant parts of the territory in northern Syria that rival insurgent groups had wrested away last week, rebel representatives said on Monday.

headline: Foundations Aim to Save Pensions in Detroit Crisis
text: National and local philanthropic foundations have committed $330 million toward a deal to avoid cuts to Detroit retirees’ pensions and to save the Detroit Institute of Arts’ renowned collection, federal mediators involved in the city’s bankruptcy proceedings announced on Monday.

headline: Syrians May Allow the Delivery of Some Aid
text: PARIS — The Syrian government has told Russia that it is prepared to allow the delivery of humanitarian aid to some besieged areas in Syria, including East Ghouta, a suburb of Damascus where 160,000 people have been without assistance for a year, Russian and American diplomats said on Monday.

headline: Email Correspondence Regarding Steven Fulop, Mayor of Jersey City
text: Documents released Monday show that Gov. Chris Christie’s administration aggressively courted the mayor, then abruptly cut ties after he informed them that he would not endorse the governor for his re-election.

headline: Today in Small Business: Learning From the Big Sites
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Times Minute | Farewell to Ariel Sharon
text: Also on the Minute, Dennis Rodman returns to Beijing after his visit to North Korea and saving Afghan artifacts.

headline: Times Minute | Farewell to Ariel Sharon
text: In the Video

headline: Milady’s, a SoHo Stalwart, Shuts Its Doors
text: It was a safe bet that nobody at Milady’s on Sunday night cared much about the Golden Globes or the newest installment of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Across Wall Street, Efforts to Revise a Hard-Charging Culture
text: The high-achieving college students bound for Wall Street jobs have heard the stories of long nights and weekends spent at the office, a grueling schedule etched into big bank culture.

headline: Europe Opens Inquiry Into Licensing of U.S. Films and TV
text: LONDON — The European Commission said on Monday that it had opened an investigation into the ways that major United States film and television studios license their content to European pay-TV providers — practices that the commission said might violate European antitrust rules.

headline: Taylor Swift or Sofia Vergara? Quick, Next Party!
text: LOS ANGELES — There’s a complicated calculus to attending Golden Globes after-parties. Like the show, they’re all in the Beverly Hilton complex, but in far-flung corners. So there’s a scramble as guests and celebrities migrate from one to the other, running through the lobby, where fans congregate with cameras.

headline: Toyota Presents a Curvaceous Extrovert
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: Toyota FT-1 Concept.

headline: Biden Gives Eulogy at Sharon’s Funeral
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke at Ariel Sharon’s funeral in Jerusalem.

headline: For Prada and Gucci, a Similar View of Fall Fashion
text: What do Prada and Gucci have in common? Milan, fleets of P.R. people. Both brands are also designed by women — Miuccia Prada and, at Gucci, Frida Giannini — but this scarcely accounts for their remarkable agreement this season at the men’s fall shows.

headline: Guggenheim Will Invite Architects to Imagine a Finnish Outpost
text: The on-again-off-again proposal to build an outpost of the Guggenheim Museum in Helsinki, Finland, appears to be on again. After city officials there shot down the idea of building the $185 million museum in May 2012, it voted on Monday to reserve a parcel of land on the city’s South Harbor waterfront for the prospective institution. This gives the Guggenheim the green light to start an open international architectural competition to determine who would build the museum.

headline: Justices Cite History as They Voice Doubts on Obama’s Recess Appointments
text: WASHINGTON — In an extended argument that contained large doses of constitutional history and practical politics, the Supreme Court on Monday seemed skeptical of the Obama administration’s contention that it could bypass the Senate to appoint officials during short breaks in the Senate’s work.

headline: Burton Lifland, Judge Who Oversaw Madoff Bankruptcy, Dies at 84
text: Burton R. Lifland, the judge who was overseeing the winding down of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, died on Sunday, according to the clerk for the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.

headline: Scenes of Protest in Bangkok
text: Demonstrators filled the city’s central commercial district Monday as part of an effort to overthrow Thailand’s prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: One Woman’s Dying Wish: A Monthlong Farewell Party
text: Marcy Glanz had been battling uterine cancer since early 2011, but in late November she was given grim news by her doctors — her cancer was so severe that she had only several weeks to live.

headline: Time’s Up for ‘Ticking’ as Wearability Supplants Reliability in Watch Pitches
text: For decades, Timex has been promoted with the theme “It takes a licking and keeps on ticking” and variants like “Life is ticking” and, most recently, “Love what makes them tick.” Now, time has run out on the venerable slogan and its descendants as Timex takes a new tack that reflects the changing role of watches.

headline: So Long BMW 1 Series, Hello 2 Series
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: BMW 2 Series Coupe

headline: Directors Guild Names Its 5 Documentary Nominees
text: Updated, 2:05 p.m. |  Last week, the Directors Guild of America released the five feature directors up for its top prize. Now comes the group’s documentary choices, all of which are also on the Academy’s shortlist:

headline: Alice Munro to Beam In for Night at Symphony Space
text: The Canadian writer Alice Munro couldn’t make it to Stockholm in December for the ceremony commemorating her Nobel Prize because of health concerns, but Ms. Munro will visit New York — virtually, anyway — later this month.

headline: Armond White Expelled From Critics’ Group
text: Updated, 3:25 p.m. |  The New York Film Critics Circle took the rare step Monday of expelling Armond White, the film critic for CityArts, and of suspending the New York Post film critic Lou Lumenick for a year. The group confirmed the moves in a statement.

headline: The Playlist | The Diverse, Influential Sounds Behind James Vincent McMorrow’s Sophomore Album
text: James Vincent McMorrow’s debut album, 2011’s “Early in the Morning,” was a promising, if sometimes frustrating, collection of indie folk songs — the kind of tuneful music one is likely to hear during the more earnest moments of a hit TV drama, or in a dimly lit pub. The Irish singer-songwriter’s full-length follow up, “Post Tropical,” out tomorrow on Vagrant Records, takes McMorrow’s intimate lyrics and hushed vocals and soaks them in ’90s R&B and early 2000s hip hop, often with stunning results. (For proof, listen to the epic “Red Dust,” in which McMorrow bares his soul over a thumping hip-hop beat before the song gives way to lush synths and a falsetto that calls to mind Jeff Buckley’s best work on “Grace.”)

headline: Enhancements for Expedia
text: Expedia, the travel booking website, has stepped up its search game in recent weeks, adding three features to help travelers find — and organize — the best flights possible.

headline: A Bold Move by Suntory
text: For a Japanese corporation, Suntory Holdings has an especially aggressive corporate slogan: “Yatte Minahare,” which roughly translates as “Go for it.”

headline: A Sort of Season for Ennio Morricone
text: The first part of 2014 is slowly shaping up as a low-key Ennio Morricone festival. The Italian composer, who turns 85 in November, is best known for his film scores — some 450 of them, including “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,” with its unmistakable, undulating ocarina figure; and “The Untouchables” and “The Mission,” both packed with gripping, dramatic string writing. And though he conducts rarely in the United States (his last visit to New York was a Radio City concert in 2007), he will be leading a freelance orchestra and choir in two concerts in March — his Los Angeles conducting debut, at the Nokia Theater in on March 20, and a performance at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on March 23.

headline: Recalling Past Threats, Afghans in Tranquil Valley Work to Keep It That Way
text: BAZARAK, Afghanistan — Even among Afghans, who are generally wary of outsiders, the members of the ethnic Tajik population of the Panjshir Valley are an unusually suspicious lot. So it is their good fortune to have been blessed with the closest thing to a naturally occurring “keep out” sign: a deep and narrow gorge at the valley’s mouth that seems tailor-made for obstruction and ambush.

headline: Christie Faces Audit Over Use of Hurricane Relief Money
text: Federal investigators have ordered an audit to determine whether Gov. Chris Christie’s administration improperly spent millions of dollars of relief meant to encourage tourists to visit New Jersey after the devastation of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: McKesson Comes Up Short on Celesio Tender Offer
text: LONDON — The McKesson Corporation said on Monday that it had failed to receive the minimum shareholder support needed for its $8.3 billion acquisition of the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio, despite a sweetened tender offer last week.

headline: After Beam Deal, Few Big Liquor Mergers Left
text: A big whiskey acquisition is a shot in the arm for the global spirits industry, but there may not be many more substantial liquor deals to strike.

headline: BMW Introduces Its M&M Boys
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 BMW M3 and M4

headline: California Democrat to Retire From House
text: WASHINGTON — Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, announced Monday that he would retire at the end of his term, after 40 years in Congress.

headline: Poverty and Inequality, in Charts
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Recalling a Poet’s Vigil for a Life-Extending Gift
text: “According to the latest research, anything could be anything.” This is, to my ear, as crisp and withering a distillation of modern medical care as you’ll find, especially as experienced by a patient desperate for something a bit more concrete.

headline: Golden Globes Telecast Draws Nearly 21 Million Viewers
text: LOS ANGELES — The combination of hit movies like “Gravity” being honored, the return of Tina Fey and Amy Poehler as hosts and intense marketing on social media drove the 71st Golden Globes to a total audience of 20.9 million viewers, an increase of 6 percent from 2013.

headline: Ford Reveals 2015 F-150
text: Paul Stenquist describes the importance of the Ford 2015 F-150.

headline: Chrysler 200 Is Redesigned
text: Jerry Garrett describes the new Chrysler 200.

headline: DiCaprio Nabs Some Treats, and Coogan Assesses the Guest List
text: LOS ANGELES — Where were we in the Globes after-party shuffle? Oh, right: at 10:15, Andrew Dice Clay and Alyssa Milano were waiting patiently in the line to get into the Warner/InStyle party. Over at HBO, held atop and around the Beverly Hilton pool, Sofia Vergara was, indeed, taking selfies, and guests like Hayden Panettiere and Stephen Merchant milled around. Some cast members of “Girls” remained, but Lena Dunham was long gone.

headline: Push to Combat Insider Trading May Go Too Far
text: Last week, BlackRock, the asset management giant, agreed to a settlement with New York State to stop conducting surveys of investment analysts.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 7-13, 2014
text: A political scandal, a chemical spill, the Golden Globes and a same-sex marriage battle: how many of the 10 news stories below have you followed this week?

headline: Calls for Oversight in West Virginia Went Unheeded
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The accidents kept coming, and so did the calls for a plan to improve West Virginia’s chemical safety regulations.

headline: What Patients Don’t Tell Their Doctors
text: A patient’s wife was on the phone, her voice hesitant, unhappy. She didn’t bother with small talk. “I need to talk to you about Tom’s drinking,” she said.

headline: Skeptical of Facebook, Until the Checkbook Came Out
text: A year ago, Josh Miller said that Facebook “may have an irreversibly bad brand.” Soon after, Mr. Miller, a co-founder of a start-up called Branch Media, was giving Facebook some unsolicited advice, suggesting that it “turn to Nike for strategic inspiration.”

headline: A Salad of Roasted Carrots and Miso Dressing Without the Greens
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

text: Introduced on Monday: Mercedes-Benz GLA45 AMG

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Elizabeth Weil and the Newly Grown-Up Shaun White
text: Elizabeth Weil, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the snowboarder Shaun White. Weil is the author of the book “No Cheating, No Dying: I Had a Good Marriage, Then I Tried to Make It Better.”

headline: In Command
text: As I was reading “Duty,” probably one of the best Washington memoirs ever, I kept thinking that Robert M. Gates clearly has no desire to work in the federal government again in his life. That evidently is a fertile frame of mind in which to write a book like this one.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Three Deaths Mar Dakar Rally
text: Three people died last week during the middle stages of the grueling, two-week-long Dakar Rally.

headline: 2014 Detroit Auto Show: Photo Gallery
text: A collection of the new models, like the Cadillac ATS, introduced at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, including slide shows, videos and First Glance critiques.

text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Best-Selling Science Books
text: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.” (1)

headline: Sacrificing Gated Safety for a Lover and Herself
text: Chang-rae Lee’s new novel is part folk tale, part picaresque adventure, part dystopian satire. It signals a bold departure from both the carefully observed realism that distinguished Mr. Lee’s powerful earlier books “Aloft” (2004) and “A Gesture Life” (1999) — and the historical vistas of “The Surrendered” (2010). In eschewing one of his most potent gifts as a writer — his ability to map the inner lives of his characters with sympathy and precision — Mr. Lee has produced an ungainly and strangely inert novel. Instead of creating a palpably real flesh-and-blood heroine, he has chosen to center his book on an anime-like character named Fan; and instead of creating a fully imagined fictional realm (as Kazuo Ishiguro did in his bravura sci-fi-like novel, “Never Let Me Go,” from 2005), he’s dropped Fan into a futuristic world that seems at once overly familiar and unconvincing.

headline: Quail to Serve With Loire Valley Reds
text: You may not associate the Loire Valley with game, but the hunt, especially for birds, is important in this region of France. I had that in mind when I decided on a seasonal preparation for quail to serve with the deliciously sturdy cabernet francs we tasted.

headline: Revisiting the Reds of the Loire Valley
text: Imagine a somewhat small region farmed primarily by myriad family grape growers, many of whom have made wine for generations. They work diverse soils, and because the reds are mostly from a single grape, comparing wines from a multitude of terroirs is fascinating.

headline: Printing the Windows 8 Calendar
text: Q. I use the Windows 8 Calendar app on my computer and would like to print out the monthly view of my schedule to have a paper copy. How do I do this? I press Control+P when I have the calendar page open and nothing happens.

headline: Scene City: Partying After the Golden Globes
text: InStyle and Warner Bros. hosted their annual bash following the awards ceremony.

headline: Ronaldo Dethrones Messi as World Player of Year
text: It did not matter that the voting went mostly as expected; Cristiano Ronaldo cried anyway.

headline: Former Marcos Aide Sentenced in Art Sale
text: A former personal secretary to Imelda R. Marcos was sentenced on Monday to two to six years in state prison in New York for conspiring to sell Impressionist masterpieces belonging to the Philippine government that disappeared when Ferdinand Marcos was ousted as president.

headline: Volkswagen Makes the Golf R an Even Hotter Hatch
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Volkswagen Golf R

headline: Nutcracker Man’s Secret: He Didn’t Crack Nuts
text: An ancient human ancestor who lived in East Africa millions of years ago — nicknamed Nutcracker Man for his big, flat molars and powerful jaws — didn’t actually eat nuts, researchers say.

headline: In the Z06, More Sting for Stingray
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Chevrolet Corvette ZO6

headline: The Flood Next Time
text: The little white shack at the water’s edge in Lower Manhattan is unobtrusive — so much so that the tourists strolling the promenade at Battery Park the other day did not give it a second glance.

headline: A Rising Tide, the Doctor’s Scribe, Sparky on the Operating Table
text: A look at the growing threat of coast flooding in a time of climate change; the stenographer in the doctor’s shadow; reconstructive surgery of all kinds for what ails your pet.

headline: Tent City in Central African Republic Swells as Violence Grips Capital
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — The streets of this capital city’s center are nearly empty. A few citizens slowly walk the wide boulevards, outnumbered by French troops patrolling after recent deadly violence. The battered buildings remain, but much of the city’s population has disappeared.

headline: Why We Buy in a Marked-Up Market
text: When dividends are included, 2013 was the fifth consecutive year of positive performance in the stock market (as measured by the annualized Standard & Poor’s 500 return). The stock market is now up more than 200 percent from the bottom of the financial crisis in March 2009. Returns since those dark days have been unbelievable, including the market’s most recent performance in 2013 of around 30 percent.

headline: Has Christie Lost His Credibility?
text: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie’s troubles are not going away. Questions about whether the governor’s team was responsible for a giant traffic jam in Fort Lee, N.J., convulsed the national news shows over the weekend. More subpoenas are expected, probably for staff members Mr. Christie fired last week. Added to the pyre, federal investigators are now looking into whether the governor misused almost $5 million in Hurricane Sandy relief funds for his “Stronger than the Storm” ads featuring himself and his family in the months before his re-election.

headline: Rodriguez’s ‘Gummies’: Files Detail Doping, Down to Milligram
text: Alex Rodriguez took an energy cocktail on Mondays and a therapy cocktail on Fridays.

headline: Older Pool of Health Care Enrollees Stirs Fears on Costs
text: WASHINGTON — People signing up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act’s federal and state marketplaces tend to be older and potentially less healthy, officials said Monday, a demographic mix that could threaten the law’s economic underpinnings and cause premiums to rise in the future if the pattern persists.

headline: Health Exchange Enrollment Ended With a Surge
text: More than eight million people signed up for private insurance in federal and state exchanges during the initial enrollment period, exceeding the administration’s original goal of seven million.

headline: The Short, Exuberant Life of Sam Berns
text: Judging from media appearances last year that brought him a kind of celebrity — first as the subject of an HBO documentary, then as a speaker at a TEDx conference — Sam Berns seemed to be far healthier than anyone could have anticipated back in 2005, when I wrote about him for the magazine. My article focused on his mother’s search for a cure for his disease, progeria, a rare genetic disorder that makes children seem to age before your eyes, with damage to organ systems — particularly the heart, skin and bones — usually seen only in the very old.

headline: Hard-Liners in Iran Offer Mild Praise for Interim Nuclear Agreement
text: TEHRAN — Iranian hard-liners on Monday cautiously welcomed the completion of an interim nuclear agreement that will provide Tehran with some relief from Western economic sanctions in return for a suspension of certain nuclear activities for six months.

headline: Of New Atheists and Noble Lies
text: I began last week by responding to Jerry Coyne’s broadside against my Christmas column, so I suppose it’s fitting to begin this one by responding to Noah Millman’s lament that I need to “argue with better atheists,” instead of “weak combatants” like Coyne. My facile response to that line is that I’ll argue with better atheists when America’s flagship journal of liberal opinion publishes better atheists attacking things I’ve written; my more serious response is that my quarrel with atheism grows cooler and more modest the more serious (in my admittedly-biased view) the atheist in question. I’ll elaborate on that a bit below, but first, here’s Millman’s more serious complaint about my response to Coyne:

headline: Readers Lash Out About Bill Keller’s Column on a Woman With Cancer
text: Bill Keller’s column in The Times on Monday about Lisa Bonchek Adams has generated a great deal of negative response. Xeni Jardin, the well-known writer who blogs on Boing Boing, sometimes about her own experience with cancer, was outraged, calling it bullying.

headline: Globes Highlights and (of Course) Lowlights
text: LOS ANGELES — It used to be that the best part of awards shows, for those watching at home, was dissecting everyone’s outfits. Now that that happens on screen, too — and online, and often in real time — the best part is dissecting everything, the missteps and scripted and unscripted high points, all capturable and re-viewable in GIF form.

headline: Exploring Planetary Mass
text: A newly discovered planet weighs the same as Earth but is 60 percent larger in diameter. That means the planet, KOI-314c — shown in an artist’s conception — has a very thick, gaseous atmosphere. To determine its weight, astronomers used a method called transit-timing variation: They measured how long it took the planet to orbit its star and how that time was affected by its gravitational pull toward another planet.

headline: Porsche 911 Targa Has a Retro Look and a Space-Age Top
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13 : 2015 Porsche 911 Targa 4

headline: The 71st Annual Golden Globe Awards
text: Last night, the annual Golden Globe Awards ceremony was preceded, as it always is, by an impressive parade of television and film stars going down the red carpet. The Twittersphere was abuzz with trends such as baby bumps and burly beards, and some of the most award-winning looks in front of the Beverly Hilton Hotel happened in groups of three.

headline: Gaming Commission Names Equine Medical Director
text: In an effort to enhance the safety of horses and jockeys at New York racetracks, the New York State Gaming Commission announced Monday the appointment of Dr. Scott E. Palmer as its first equine medical director.

headline: According Animals Dignity
text: As of late Monday afternoon, when I was finishing this column, the most frequently emailed story on The Times’s website for the previous week wasn’t about the polar vortex, Chris Christie or “Downton Abbey.”

headline: For Google, a Toehold Into Goods for a Home
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google, which dominates much of life on the Internet, has been trying to expand beyond computers and telephones to living rooms, cars and bodies. It made its way a bit further into people’s homes on Monday when it agreed to pay $3.2 billion in cash for Nest Labs, which makes Internet-connected devices like thermostats and smoke alarms.

headline: Big Offer for Time Warner Cable Unsettles the Cable Industry
text: Charter Communications sought to upend the cable television industry on Monday, offering $37.8 billion to acquire Time Warner Cable, the country’s second-largest cable operator.

headline: Fins to Feet
text: New specimens of Tiktaalik, a transitional fish, show two pairs of fins that functioned like limbs.

headline: An Ancient Fish’s Four-Wheel Drive
text: Based on fossils found a decade ago, scientists had assumed that the earliest known species of fish to make the momentous transition to four-legged animals, capable of living and moving about on dry land, had developed a kind of front-wheel drive. They used enhanced forward fins to crawl out of shallow waters, and only later adapted their rear fins into limbs.

headline: As Christie Faces New Questions, State Lawmakers Expand Investigation
text: As Gov. Chris Christie prepared to deliver his annual State of the State address on Tuesday, he faced new questions just days after he dismissed two aides, including his longtime political adviser Bill Stepien, in a political payback scandal that involved manufacturing a huge traffic jam last September at the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Inspiration From the Horse Pasture Finds Its Way Into Show Poster
text: DETROIT — Lindsey Simon is a truck lover, so checking out the redesigned Ford F-150 will be one of the first things she does when she visits the North American International Auto Show. But not the very first thing — that will be to make a beeline for the Michigan Hall in Cobo Center, where her grand prize-winning poster will be displayed when the show opens to the public on Jan. 18.

headline: Rising Sea, Sinking Land
text: Tide gauges along the East Coast show a long-term increase in relative sea levels.

headline: Would a Pregnancy Through a Donor Egg Feel Like ‘Mine’?

headline: A Solution That Now Looks Crazy
text: “How the Federal Government Destroyed the Mental Illness Treatment System”: That subtitle is the opening shot across the bow in this jeremiad of a book by the psychiatrist Dr. E. Fuller Torrey. It could just as well have read: “How a group of well-intentioned, starry-eyed idealists made a hash of mental health care.”

headline: PETA’s Donation to Help Save Lives, Animal and Human
text: An animal welfare group is donating $1 million worth of costly training mannequins to medical schools in nine countries to accomplish two goals: giving doctors more modern training, and saving the lives of about 1,000 animals a year.

headline: McConaughey Shimmies, Samberg Remembers
text: LOS ANGELES — The backstage press room at awards shows is where winners get to reveal a little of themselves, regain their composure and thank whomever they were too flustered to acknowledge on stage. “I forgot to thank the Hollywood Foreign Press and my parents, that’s how stunned I am,” said Andy Samberg, a surprise winner for his role on the comedy series “Brooklyn Nine-Nine.”

headline: Bloomberg Gets a Royal Welcome at His Company
text: Bloomberg L.P., the financial news and data company, has rolled out the red carpet for its owner and founder, Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Treasury Department’s Alcohol Shopping List
text: The Treasury Department is requesting a list of every alcoholic beverage that’s being sold at every store and online retailer.

headline: Rebuilding Our Badly Broken Pets
text: DAVIS, CALIF. — Classical music played in the background as a team of surgeons leaned over Mischa, who lay anesthetized on the table, mouth wide open, tongue lolling to the side, all four legs in the air. The owners of the 7-year-old German shepherd had rushed her to the veterinary hospital at the University of California, Davis, after she ran in front of a small private plane and was clipped in the jaw by a propeller.

headline: Glimpses of a North Korea Seldom Seen in the West
text: PBS’s “Frontline” enjoys some morbid good timing on Tuesday night, presenting its report “Secret State of North Korea” in the wake of the execution last month of Jang Song-thaek, uncle of the North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un, and the return to the country this month of the former N.B.A. player and amateur diplomat Dennis Rodman.

headline: With Ruling, Funds to Aid Desegregation in Arkansas Are Ended
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — A federal judge on Monday gave final approval to a legal settlement that would allow the state to phase out payments of millions of dollars to three school districts to fund desegregation efforts, bringing to a close a court battle that has lasted over three decades.

headline: A Mental Alarm Clock
text: Q. Why do I wake up at exactly the same time every night, without any stimulus? It has happened all my life, and it doesn’t even matter what time I went to bed.

headline: ‘Nine-Nine’ and Fox Enjoy Upset at Globes
text: PASADENA, Calif. — This is what it has come to for broadcast television: When a new network show wins a major award, it’s the upset of the night.

headline: Keeping Their Eyes on the Score
text: MIAMI — Miami City Ballet, widely known as one of the world’s leading exponents of choreography by George Balanchine, also has a record of new choreography. Its current quadruple bill, labeled “See the Music,” opens with Balanchine’s “Concerto Barocco” (1941) and has Nacho Duato’s “Jardí Tancat” (1983), a new company acquisition, as a centerpiece. But it also features two works recently made for the troupe, Justin Peck’s “Chutes and Ladders” (2013, to the first movement of Benjamin Britten’s String Quartet No. 1) and Alexei Ratmansky’s “Symphonic Dances” (2012, to Rachmaninoff’s 1940 work of that name).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Israel and Thailand.

headline: Like Solos, but Joined in a Slinky Procession
text: The choreographer Danah Katz waited until the end of her new work, “Thousand Plateaus,” to make a significant disclaimer. “This is an experiment for all of us,” she said on Sunday at the 92nd Street Y, surrounded by the four other members of her company, Danaka Dance; the piece, she added, is still in its “pilot period.”

headline: Proposed Metro-North Link Could Wake Up Sleepy Co-op City
text: It is quiet in Co-op City, the nation’s largest housing cooperative, even though some 50,000 people live there. So quiet that the sound of footsteps crunching on icy sidewalks was louder than the wail of distant police sirens on Friday afternoon. So calm that fewer than a dozen people boarded the express bus, the fastest link to Midtown Manhattan, for its hourlong 2 p.m. trip.

headline: Times Minute | Audit Over Sandy Funds
text: Also on the Minute, rising sea levels and a new owner for Jim Beam.

headline: The Whole World Gets Into the Groove
text: “Are you ready to party with us?” asked Baloji, a Congolese singer, songwriter and rapper, as he kicked his band into a sunny, danceable three-chord soukous groove during Globalfest 2014 at Webster Hall on Sunday night. The song bounded along with lyrics in Lingala. Eventually, in English, Baloji gave instructions for a dance step: “Run for cover — protect yourself, because the army is shooting on you, you, you, you and your people,” he said. “So if you want to stay alive, stay down, down, down,” he continued, cuing the audience to crouch.

headline: Times Minute | Audit Over Sandy Funds
text: In the Video

headline: Soloist and Conductor in One Pair of Shoes
text: Like many top-tier violinists and pianists, Pinchas Zukerman has balanced a regular concert schedule of solo, chamber and concerto performances with his career as a conductor.

headline: The Museum With a Bulldozer’s Heart
text: Last year, the Museum of Modern Art caused a ruckus with a plan to raze its neighbor, the former American Folk Art Museum building, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. So MoMA trustees hired the architecture firm Diller Scofidio & Renfro to explore alternatives to demolition that would still permit expansion.

headline: Leno Holds His Feelings Tight as He Prepares to Exit ‘Tonight’
text: In the months and weeks leading up to his departure from his long, successful run as host of the “Tonight” show, Jay Leno has steered clear of any interviews dealing with his feelings about the impending change in his career. He remains aloof from all that in a session with his longtime friend Jerry Seinfeld for Mr. Seinfeld’s web series “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.”

headline: Frozen Insects, Glowing Fish and a Futuristic Suit
text: Winter tightened its grip last week, making life tough for New Yorkers and other invasive species. Fortunately, we should fare better than the hemlock woolly adelgid.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Man Skirts
text: In London, a trio of provocative men’s wear designers gave gender boundaries a nudge, sending out decidedly masculine interpretations of skirt and dress silhouettes. The kilt figured prominently in Sarah Burton’s latest collection for Alexander McQueen — no surprise, given her predecessor’s heritage and fondness for Scottish history and costume. Recent London College of Fashion graduate Sebastiaan Groenen debuted his line Sebastiaan Pieter in a small, provocative presentation that, in his words, explored “lengths unfamiliar in Western men’s wear,” such as a black crewneck sweater attached to a knit skirt with a mildly salacious slash at the midriff, revealing skin and a trouser waistband beneath. And Christopher Shannon showed a pair of heavy-gauge bi-layer sweaters that extended almost to the floor; their side slits bared taut, worked-out legs that looked anything but femme.

headline: Don’t Try Wooing Action Star Maggie Q with Shark Fin Soup
text: A new video is making the rounds in the effort to blunt China’s appetite for shark fin soup and the resulting global decline in many shark species.

headline: Albums From Bruce Springsteen and Jennifer Nettles of Sugarland
text: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN

headline: Kicking Back: Nature of Choreography Revised, With Beer Cans
text: Debate swirling around the wave of dance presentation in museums hasn’t dissipated over the last couple of years. For one thing, economic inequality between the dance and art worlds isn’t likely to go away. Over the weekend at MoMA PS1, the Swedish choreographer Marten Spangberg added another layer to the conversation with “La Substance, but in English,” a four-and-a-half-hour work performed Sunday afternoon as part of the American Realness festival.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Uber’s Taxi Troubles in France, and Why ‘Her’ Might Offer a Glimpse of the Future
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Three Former Rabobank Traders Charged in Libor Case
text: The Justice Department filed criminal charges on Monday against three former traders from the Dutch lender Rabobank, the latest step in the wide-ranging investigation into the banking industry’s manipulation of interest rates.

headline: Protecting a Source, James Risen Takes His Case to the Supreme Court
text: The Times reporter James Risen took his case to the Supreme Court on Monday, asking that his effort to protect his confidential source be protected.

headline: Tide Gauges Needed for Research Are Often Victims of Storms
text: As the waters of Hurricane Sandy rose higher and higher on Oct. 29, 2012, an instrument on a pier at Sandy Hook, N.J., recorded the ominous tidal surge. The reading hit eight feet above sea level, then nine, then 10 – and every few minutes, the gauge faithfully transmitted its readings to a satellite flying overhead.

headline: Fifth & Pacific Discloses Executive Compensation
text: The Fifth & Pacific Companies, which used to be known as Liz Claiborne and will now be known as Kate Spade & Company, announced several management changes last week. In a regulatory filing on Monday, the company provided details about compensation.

headline: Scene City: The Wrap Dress, Still Flirty at 40
text: A birthday party for Diane von Furstenberg’s emblematic wrap dress.

headline: Overcoming Shyness to Inspire a Seatmate
text: OTHER than a couple of trips to Mexico, one of which involved sneaking a drive from Phoenix into Tijuana with my best friend when we were teenagers, I never really traveled out of the country until I was well into my 20s. Now, as a leadership consultant, author and someone who climbs mountains, I’m always flying. I try to put up with all of the hassles without making too much of a fuss.

headline: Intersection: Style Is Art in Miami
text: Isis Miller, a 27-year-old barista in the Wynwood neighborhood in Miami, looks to Katharine Hepburn’s style for her fashion inspiration.

headline: Kate Young’s Golden Globes Look for Emilia Clarke

For Sunday’s Golden Globes, Young traveled to Los Angeles to dress the “Game of Thrones” star Emilia Clarke, who landed on multiple best-dressed lists in a custom embroidered strapless peplum dress by Proenza Schouler. Here, Young recounts her whirlwind weekend.

headline: Google and Nest: Two Companies in the Business of Understanding You
text: Google has announced it is buying Nest Labs, maker of smart thermostats and smoke alarms, for $3.2 billion in cash. At times like this, it’s normal to ask what is in it for each side.

headline: A Junior Champion at 14, and a Rising Talent for 2018

text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13 Mini John Cooper Works Concept

headline: Running on Fumes in North Dakota
text: A young woman, lured to North Dakota for a truck-driving job in the oil industry, shares her agonizing existence in an isolated boomtown.

headline: Assemblyman From the South Bronx Is Convicted on Bribery and Extortion Charges
text: Eric A. Stevenson, a New York assemblyman, was convicted on Monday of taking more than $20,000 in bribes in return for helping four businessmen build an adult day care center in his South Bronx district.

headline: Stung by Scandal, Giant Pension Fund Tries to Make It Right
text: After a pay-for-play scandal tarnished its reputation, the nation’s largest public pension fund turned to a courtly native of Quebec to help it restore order and improve performance in a crucial investment sector.

headline: How Was Your Stay? Post It
text: Matthew Kolodny, a consultant based in Chicago, used TripAdvisor to help choose a hotel for a recent yearlong assignment in Abu Dhabi.

headline: ‘Running on Fumes in North Dakota’
text: Since around 2006, North Dakota’s oil boom has been a beacon for recession-ravaged Americans. The oil towns in the western part of the state are a land of possibility and opportunity, a “Kuwait on the prairie,” where the American Dream is alive and well in the rural heartland. Or at least that’s the sales pitch that has lured thousands of job seekers.

headline: Europeans Struggle to Set Derivatives Rules
text: Faced with intense lobbying from the oil and commodity industries, the European Union plans what could be a last-ditch effort on Tuesday to reach agreement on one of the biggest issues to come out of the 2008 financial crisis: how to rein in trading of derivatives and other complex instruments.

headline: China: Village Blast Kills 14
text: An explosion on Monday afternoon in a village near Kaili in the southwestern province of Guizhou killed 14 people and injured seven, state news media reported. The news reports said that the authorities suspected that some people at the site had been engaging in illegal gambling, and that the police had begun a criminal investigation of the explosion.

headline: Rap Lyrics on Trial
text: SHOULD rap lyrics be used in court as evidence of a crime?

headline: Nigerian President Signs Ban on Same-Sex Relationships
text: A tough ban on same-sex relationships that threatens violators with 14-year prison terms has been quietly signed into law by the president of Nigeria, Africa’s most populous nation, a step that rights advocates have long feared not only as a repression aimed at gays but as an affront to basic freedoms of speech and assembly.

headline: Seeking Bigger Role, Bradley Invests His Future in M.L.S.
text: Over the last decade, Michael Bradley’s career path has seemed as pragmatic as one of his lateral passes, as persistently frontward as one of his box-to-box runs. It drove him along an ascendant path, to the top European leagues, to an indispensable role on the United States national team. But in recent days has come a dizzying improvisation.

headline: His Heart, My Sleeve: Writing About My Brother
text: On my 40th birthday, I began writing an essay about my brother, Robert, who, for the previous 16 years, had been in and out of mental hospitals. My intention was to write about his life as a patient, and also about the life he’d led before, when he was a bright, gifted young man who showed no signs, until his first breakdown at the age of 19, that any mental problems were likely or inevitable.

headline: The Leadership Revival
text: If you are in politics or public life, you probably had some moment of spine-tingling transcendence. Maybe you read the Declaration of Independence or watched the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s mountaintop sermon, or read Nelson Mandela’s 1964 speech from the dock.

headline: Iraq: Deadly Bombings Erupt in Baghdad
text: At least 29 people were killed as car bombs struck several Shiite neighborhoods in northern Baghdad on Monday. The deadliest bombing, in a market in the working-class Shaab neighborhood, killed at least 11 people, according to witnesses and officials. More than 8,000 Iraqis were killed last year as security deteriorated, and hundreds more have died this month. In recent days Sunni militants, including some linked to Al Qaeda, seized control of the western city of Falluja, challenging the authority of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. The violence on Monday coincided with a visit to Iraq by the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, who appeared to scold Iraq’s political elites for not working together to “stop the senseless deaths of Iraqi women, children and men,” according to a text of his remarks on the United Nations website. “The challenges facing Iraq require all political leaders to fulfill their responsibilities to ensure social cohesion, dialogue and progress over political obstacles,” Mr. Ban said.

headline: Despite Renovations After Hurricane, Unease Persists in the Rockaways
text: The buildings are offset by the Atlantic, a pastiche of warm tones and cool grays, jutting balconies overlooking tranquil landscaped gardens and million-dollar views. The apartment complex is in the Arverne section of the Rockaway Peninsula; it looks as if it could be Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: Secretive Apple Squirms in Gaze of U.S. Monitor
text: Most companies are reluctant to open themselves to outside inspection. Yet Apple is even resisting someone who was appointed by a court to do exactly that, leading to an unusual public feud between the world’s biggest technology company and the Justice Department.

headline: Dastardly, British and Brand New to the Super Bowl
text: PAUL REVERE is recalled for shouting — whether or not he really did — “The British are coming! The British are coming!” Repeat that another time and you will summarize the plot of the first commercial that Jaguar will run during a Super Bowl.

headline: The Asbestos Scam, Part 2
text: Six weeks ago, I wrote a column about a ridiculous lawsuit being brought by Carolyn McCarthy, a congresswoman from Long Island. A smoker for most of her life, McCarthy has lung cancer. Yet her lawyers claimed that it was her “exposure” to asbestos, through the work clothes of her father and brother, both boilermakers, that triggered her cancer. Though McCarthy certainly deserves our sympathy as she fights cancer, it is hard to see her lawsuit as anything but an undeserved money grab — and the latest twist in asbestos litigation, the longest running tort in American history, with no end in sight.

headline: Inquiry Begins Into Airliner That Landed in Wrong Place
text: Federal safety officials said on Monday that they were investigating why a Southwest Airlines plane landed at the wrong airport, a general aviation airfield near its destination with a shorter runway and no control tower.

headline: In All but the Name, a New Nissan Maxima
text: Introduced on Monday: Nissan Sport Sedan Concept

headline: Another Step Toward Nuclear Sanity in Iran
text: If all goes according to plan, Iran will begin freezing and then rolling back its most worrisome nuclear activities on Monday under an agreement reached over the weekend with the United States and other major powers. This would be the most significant restraint ever on a program that has threatened international stability since it was first disclosed in 2002 and an undeniably important step toward the peaceful resolution of a serious dispute. Even so, dangerously misguided forces, including leading Democrats and Republicans in Congress, are working to sabotage it.

headline: Obama Fights a Push to Add Iran Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — With the United States and Iran about to embark on a critical phase of nuclear talks, President Obama is waging an intense rear-guard action to prevent Senate Democrats from supporting strict new sanctions that could upend his diplomatic efforts.

headline: Abortion Rights: A Good Ruling Stands
text: The Supreme Court made a good call, announced on Monday, not to review a 2013 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which struck down Arizona’s 20-week abortion ban as unconstitutional. For women in Arizona, the appellate ruling is critically important in protecting their reproductive rights.

headline: Abortion Rights: Uphold Buffer Zones
text: Abortion is one of the most emotionally fraught issues in American society, and public discussion often turns into an attack on the women who choose to exercise their constitutionally protected rights.

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Alleged Drug Regimen
text: The arbitration ruling released on Monday includes a drug and supplement regimen that Anthony Bosch said he designed for Alex Rodriguez.

headline: Think Back: The Military Budget
text: United States military spending has ballooned since World War II, although Americans have historically been reluctant to go to war. The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains why.

headline: Ford Remakes F-150, the Nation’s No. 1 Vehicle
text: DETROIT — The heady combination of growing sales and big profits has spurred automakers to reinvest heavily in new models and make major changes to some of their most prominent vehicles.

headline: House and Senate Negotiators Agree on Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators reached accord on a trillion-dollar spending plan that will finance the government through September, reversing some cuts to military veterans’ pensions that were included in a broader budget agreement last month and defeating efforts to rein in President Obama’s health care law.

headline: The Man Behind Alibaba’s Eventual I.P.O.
text: JPMorgan Chase has called. So has Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Joe Tsai’s phone is ringing off the hook these days, and you would be forgiven if you have never heard of him.

headline: Japan’s Leader Pledges Aid on Africa Tour
text: TOKYO — Japan’s prime minister finished a three-nation tour of Africa on Monday in which he offered aid and development projects potentially worth billions of dollars to help his nation catch up with China’s enormous footprint on the continent.

headline: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona Overhauls Child Welfare System
text: PHOENIX — Gov. Jan Brewer abolished Arizona’s beleaguered Child Protective Services on Monday, immediately transferring the task of safeguarding abused and neglected children to a new cabinet-level division over which she will have direct oversight.

headline: Aide Fired by Christie Is Called Loyal Team Player, Not Rogue Operative
text: Bridget Anne Kelly is devastated that Gov. Chris Christie denounced her as stupid and a liar — but she also is distraught over how much her actions have damaged him politically.

headline: Guardian Deletes Column About a Cancer Patient
text: The British newspaper The Guardian on Monday removed from its website a controversial column by one of its writers that discussed a woman’s use of Twitter to chronicle her struggle with cancer. In removing it, The Guardian cited an investigation into the column.

headline: Volvo Builds an Ambassador for Future Models
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: Volvo Concept XC Coupe

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 14, 2014
text: “They don’t want anyone checking their work.”

headline: A VW Passat That Sips Fuel Like an Econobox
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: Volkswagen Passat BlueMotion Concept

headline: Enemies of Mexican Drug Gangs Pose a Security Challenge
text: MEXICO CITY — The scenes are incongruous. Inside the heavily guarded colonial state government building in Michoacán on Monday, a solemn lineup of officials vowed that the federal government would restore authority to a region that has descended into lawlessness.

headline: New Mexico Judge Affirms Right to ‘Aid in Dying’
text: A state court in New Mexico said Monday that terminally ill residents have a constitutional right to obtain “aid in dying,” a ruling that could make New Mexico the fifth state to allow doctors to prescribe fatal drug doses that suffering patients can use to end their lives.

headline: Pope With the Humble Touch Is Firm in Reshaping the Vatican
text: VATICAN CITY — Less than a year into his papacy, Pope Francis has raised expectations among the world’s one billion Roman Catholics that change is coming. He has already transformed the tone of the papacy, confessing himself a sinner, declaring “Who am I to judge?” when asked about gays, and kneeling to wash the feet of inmates, including Muslims.

headline: Corrections: January 14, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Nonsense
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Nice and smooth, but a whole lot of nonsense. Allow me to explain so you will GROK what I’m saying.

headline: In Court Fight, Rodriguez Comes Out Swinging Against Players Union
text: It was hardly a surprise that lawyers for Alex Rodriguez went to federal court in Manhattan on Monday to try to halt his season-long doping suspension. What was intriguing was the degree to which the lawsuit they filed to vacate the suspension ended up targeting Rodriguez’s own union, contending that it “abdicated its responsibility” to defend the Yankees’ third baseman as baseball moved to suspend him.

headline: Charges Seen as Unlikely in Scrutiny by the I.R.S.
text: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. investigators do not believe Internal Revenue Service officials committed crimes in the unusually heavy scrutiny of conservative groups that applied for tax-exempt status, a law enforcement official said Monday.

headline: Russia: American Journalist Is Barred
text: David Satter, an American journalist and the author of three books on Russia and the Soviet Union, said Monday that he had been barred from the country by the Russian security services. Mr. Satter had been working in Moscow as an adviser and a contributor to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, which is financed by the American government. In a telephone interview from London, Mr. Satter said the Russian Foreign Ministry told him last month that he had been approved to receive a new visa, but that when he went to pick it up at the Russian Embassy in Ukraine he was told that he had been barred from Russia. An embassy official said the “competent organs” had declared his presence in Russia to be “undesirable,” Mr. Satter said. The American Embassy in Moscow has lodged a formal protest. Kevin Klose, the president of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, called the visa denial a “fundamental violation of free speech and journalistic liberty.”

headline: Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia 76ers like to save their most impressive entertainment innovation for the fourth quarter. So with two minutes left in a recent game, and only after free T-shirts had wafted from the rafters in parachutes and acrobats had dunked off trampolines, did they finally bring out the big gun.

headline: Tepid U.S. Sales Are a Drag on Volkswagen’s Ambitions
text: DETROIT — Volkswagen has outlined ambitious plans to become the world’s top-selling automaker within the next four years, but its lackluster sales in the United States have been a significant drag on meeting that goal.

headline: China: Doctor Is Sentenced in a Case of Baby Trafficking
text: A court on Tuesday sentenced Zhang Shuxia, an obstetrician in Shaanxi Province, to death but with two years’ reprieve for stealing seven babies and selling them. Death sentences with two years’ reprieve are almost always changed later to life sentences.

headline: New York’s Mortgage Bank Hunter May Not Be Able to Direct His Spoils
text: More than a year back, the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, came home bearing a legal pelt.

headline: With Fate of Safe Deposit Boxes Unknown, Bank Customers Fret After Blaze
text: For many people, a bank is a place to safeguard family heirlooms and vital documents from the unpredictable turns of life: theft, fire, flood. But over the weekend, a Citibank branch in Upper Manhattan burned for more than a day, leaving the building a burned-out husk and the fate of the bank’s 300 safe deposit boxes unknown.

headline: Four Talented Brothers, in the Devils’ Familiar Mold
text: Travis Zajac’s face brightens when he talks of long days with his three younger brothers at their favorite rink back home in Winnipeg.

headline: No-Tailgating Rule Spurs Events, but None Dare Call Them Super Bowl Parties
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tailgating will not be permitted in the parking lot at MetLife Stadium before the Super Bowl, so officials from this town — the very town in which the stadium is situated — called a news conference with officials from the neighboring town of Secaucus on Monday to announce alternatives.

headline: Man Killed During Argument Over Texting at Movie Theater
text: MIAMI — An argument over texting at the movies ended in a cellphone user’s death on Monday afternoon when a retired police officer in the audience shot him at a theater near Tampa, Fla., the authorities said.

headline: A Case of Amateurish Cloak-and-Dagger
text: Proof that Alex Rodriguez has gone from defiant to desperate came Monday in the form of a federal lawsuit. In it, he sued not only Major League Baseball to overturn his 162-game ban but also his own players union, which has done its best — often successfully — to protect him for years.

headline: Texas: High School Is Evacuated
text: About 3,600 students were evacuated from Seven Lakes High School in the Houston suburb of Katy on Monday morning after the authorities there discovered a suspicious device in a backpack, officials said. Officials with the Katy Independent School District initially described it as a “potential explosive device,” but it was determined to be a homemade weapon known as a zip gun. An unidentified student was in custody, and a school spokesman said charges were pending. The fear of an explosive device prompted a large police response by the Harris County bomb squad, the F.B.I. and other agencies.

headline: Mixed Reports on State Health Exchange
text: ALBANY — New York is enrolling a significant number of young subscribers on its health insurance exchange, but many of those already enrolled have raised questions about rules that limit which doctors they can see, or are having problems finding out if their doctors are covered, according to testimony at a State Senate hearing on Monday.

headline: California: Octuplets’ Mother Charged
text: Natalie Suleman, who gave birth to octuplets in 2009, has been charged with welfare fraud, the Los Angeles district attorney’s office said Monday. Ms. Suleman, 38, who is known as Nadya Suleman, is accused of failing to report nearly $30,000 earned from public appearances and video royalties since she applied for public assistance last year. A mother of 14, she illegally received more than $16,000 in welfare, the criminal complaint charges.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests Fund-Raiser for Congressman
text: A Texas woman who was a friend of and fund-raiser for Representative Michael G. Grimm has been charged with illegally funneling more than $10,000 into his 2010 campaign, according to court papers and people with knowledge of the case. The charges suggest that a two-year-old federal investigation into his fund-raising is still active.

headline: Defense-Minded Knicks Win Their Fifth in a Row
text: The Knicks and the Phoenix Suns did not always play well Monday night. They played hard. They played it close. And eventually they played into overtime.

headline: Some West Virginia Residents Can Finally Use Water Again
text: After officials in West Virginia announced on Monday that a ban on tap water was being lifted, many residents were excited to take a shower again.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 13, 2014
Sam Berns, 17, Public Face of a Rare Illness, Is Dead
text: Sam Berns, a Massachusetts high school junior whose life with the illness progeria was the subject of a documentary film recently shortlisted for an Academy Award, died on Friday in Boston. He was 17.

headline: How the Courts Constrain Tax Reform
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | anesthetic
text: anesthetic •\ˌa-nəs-ˈthe-tik\• noun and adjective

headline: Thai Leader Vows to Keep Job Amid Protests
text: BANGKOK — As antigovernment protesters continued their occupation of crucial parts of Bangkok’s main commercial and business districts, Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra on Tuesday said she was “protecting democracy” and would not resign.

headline: Over the Side With Old Scientific Tenets
text: Here are some concepts you might consider tossing out with the Christmas wrappings as you get started on the new year: human nature, cause and effect, the theory of everything, free will and evidence-based medicine.

headline: After a Loss, Siblings Try to Reconnect
text: Silence has settled where animated banter and familial laughter were once the norm. The dynamic between Jasmine Morales, 25, and the two siblings who live with her has been thrown off kilter.

headline: Newsstand to Reopen, After de Blasio Helps
text: A month after closing a newsstand on Astor Place that had been operated for 26 years without the proper license, New York City officials have reversed course, agreeing to let the stand reopen and to grant the longtime operator the necessary license.

headline: Injuries to Domestic Helper Cast Light on Abuses in Hong Kong
text: An alleged beating of an Indonesian domestic helper by her Hong Kong employer has drawn new attention to the treatment of the hundreds of thousands of such workers in the territory, raising questions about whether the authorities are vigilant in preventing abuses in such cases.

headline: Robert Pastor, 66, Dies; Guided Panama Treaty for Carter
text: Robert A. Pastor, a White House aide under President Jimmy Carter who shepherded the 1977 Panama Canal treaties to ratification — and was punished for it 17 years later, when conservatives defeated his nomination to be ambassador to Panama — died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 66.

headline: Governor Hopes Speech Will Obscure a Scandal
text: In a political high-wire act, Gov. Chris Christie will try on Tuesday to refocus attention from a controversy over a vindictive traffic jam to the day-to-day work of governing, by outlining plans to extend the school day, lower taxes for homeowners and reduce urban crime.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (Esquire) FRIDAY NIGHT TYKES There’s no quitting in football. But there’s plenty of blood, sweat and tears when you’re a baby linebacker exhausted in 99-degree heat, and the coach orders you to bear-crawl across the field. “I don’t care how much pain you’re in!” Charles Chavarria, a former Marine, bellows at his team, the Junior Broncos. “You don’t quit!” This new reality show follows five San Antonio teams of 8- and 9-year-olds as they try to pass, run and tackle their way to the top of the Texas Youth Football Association, where ranting coaches, obsessive parents and helmet-to-helmet hits are de rigueur. “Sometimes, parents say I may be crossing a little bit of a line,” Mr. Chavarria says. “They need to toughen up. If you don’t push your kids, you’re accepting failure.”

headline: Electrical Problem Blamed in Shangri-La Fire
text: A fire that destroyed hundreds of structures in a Tibetan area in southwestern China was caused by an electrical problem that ignited a curtain, a county official said.

headline: A Dark Look at Modeling in China
text: The insider essay on modeling in China opens with the American author, Meredith Hattam, sitting on a train from Chengdu to Beijing with a 16­-year­-old Ukrainian friend, Lana. The friend is eating a hard­-boiled egg. Ms. Hattam makes it clear that eggs are all Lana will eat for the next 10 days because the modeling agency in Beijing that employs the two of them has cut Lana’s weekly allowance due to her weight. Lana had violated the strict measurement standards laid out in her three­-month modeling contract.

headline: The Skate Escape
text: BANGALORE, Karnataka — On a warm December evening, one of the pioneers in India’s skateboarding scene was giving a private lesson to a 7-year-old girl on dropping in, a terrifying move for novices in which skaters prop their boards up on the edge of a ramp and plunge down the incline.

headline: Kerry Urges Syrian Rebels to Go to Peace Meeting
text: ROME — Secretary of State John Kerry told the Syrian opposition that support for the group could be reduced if it decided not to attend the coming peace conference in Switzerland, Western officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Jan. 14
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Rising Tide Is a Mystery That Sinks Island Hopes
text: In “Rising Tide Is a Mystery That Sinks Island Hopes,” Randal C. Archibold reports on the sudden growth of the largest lake in the Caribbean.

headline: Breathing In vs. Spacing Out
text: Two and a half millenniums ago, a prince named Siddhartha Gautama traveled to Bodh Gaya, India, and began to meditate beneath a tree. Forty-nine days of continuous meditation later, tradition tells us, he became the Buddha — the enlightened one.

headline: Do TV Shows Like ‘16 and Pregnant’ Promote or Discourage Teenage Pregnancy?
text: Do TV shows like “16 and Pregnant” and “Teen Mom” glamorize being a teenage mother or present a cautionary tale?

headline: Generation Y-Me
text: We boomers haven’t heard much about the generation gap lately, although it was a big topic, the stuff of newsweekly covers, decades back. But I’m wondering if this phenomenon — fundamentally different perspectives on goals, behavior and values, based largely on one’s age cohort — resurfaces in later life.

headline: The New York Portfolio Review, Part II
text: What happens when you — O.K., we — put together 150 photographers with 75 top editors, curators, book publishers and gallerists for two days of photo critiques, networking and fun? Well, assignments, shows and sales, for starters. More important, popular demand that we do it again.

headline: Egyptians Vote on New Constitution in Referendum
text: CAIRO — Egyptians trundled to the polls on Tuesday for the third referendum in three years to approve a new constitution, this time to validate the military ouster of their first fairly elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Lowe’s Backs Recommendation Site for Home Projects
text: SEATTLE — Anyone who has gone through a home improvement project knows what a hassle it can be to find a trusted professional to do electrical, plumbing and other work. The big retailer Lowe’s is backing a website that it believes can make the process better for its customers.

headline: Don’t Trust This Spy
text: WASHINGTON — Jonathan Jay Pollard liked to imagine his life was greater than it was. He told fanciful tales to peers while at Stanford in the 1970s, including that he was a Mossad officer and that he had once been captured and tortured by Arabs.

headline: With Familiar Racket and a New Ring, Caroline Wozniacki Is Hoping to Rise Again
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — For Caroline Wozniacki, who spent 67 weeks from 2010 to 2012 ranked No. 1, reaching back to the past for an old, familiar companion just felt right.

headline: Celesio’s Shares Tumble After Failed Bid by McKesson
text: LONDON – Shares of the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio fell nearly 6 percent in trading on Tuesday morning after the McKesson Corporation failed to garner enough shareholder support for its proposed $8.3 billion acquisition to proceed.
