headline: Scores Die in Ferry Accident as They Flee Violence in South Sudan
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — It happened during a panic that has unfolded with frightening regularity in recent weeks. Fighters were advancing. Crowds of civilians fled to the river to escape the violence, rushing into barges to cross the White Nile. Amid the frenzy, officials said Tuesday, more than 200 people were killed when the ferry carrying them to safety went down.

headline: When My Son Flew Out of the Nest
text: Physicists discover particles the way shop owners catch embezzlers: not by seeing them, but by noticing something is missing (in high-energy physics, particles are inventory, energy cash). They smash large particles, then tally up the energy and smaller particles produced. If the reckoning is incomplete, another tiny particle must have been there.

headline: Oyster, a Start-Up for E-Reading, Raises $14 Million
text: With Netflix soaring, investors are betting that a start-up based on the same business model — but for e-books — will succeed as well.

headline: From Hunger to Fame, With a Shoestring Menu
text: SOUTHEND-ON-SEA, England — First she stopped heating her apartment, putting furniture in front of the radiators to try to forget they were there. She unscrewed most of the light bulbs, turned off the hot water, and sold her iPhone, her watch, her television and even her curtains to feed herself and her 2-year-old son.

headline: French Leader Brushes Aside Questions Over Affair
text: PARIS — It was arguably the most important speech of François Hollande’s presidency. His job approval remains at nearly the lowest level of any president in French history. His economic policies have failed to make major inroads in addressing chronic unemployment and persistent deficits. His Socialist Party is restive.

headline: Euro Zone Factory Output Rallied in November
text: PARIS — Factories in the euro zone ramped up output in November after two months of decline, according to data released Tuesday, the latest sign that economic growth in the region might be picking up steam.

headline: Tiger Attacks Terrify Villagers Near Southern Hill Station
text: Over 300 forest and police officers are on the hunt for a tiger that has killed three villagers near the hill station of Ooty in Tamil Nadu, attacks that have terrified local residents and shut down a popular tourist site.

text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

The show plays Wednesday and Saturday at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival.

headline: Wells Fargo’s Earnings Rise 10%, Slightly Ahead of Estimates
text: Updated, 9:30 a.m. | Wells Fargo, which has come to dominate mortgage lending since the financial crisis, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 10 percent from the same period in 2012.

headline: Score Composer as Method Actor
text: LOS ANGELES — Alexander Ebert was a surprise winner at the Golden Globes, for his score for J.C. Chandor’s “All Is Lost.” But the transition to composer is just the latest in a string of professional transformations for Mr. Ebert, currently best known as the frontman of the indie band Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros.

headline: Daily Report: With $3.2 Billion Deal for Nest, Google Makes a Play for Your Home
text: Google, which dominates much of life on the Internet, has been trying to expand beyond computers and telephones to living rooms, cars and bodies, Claire Cain Miller reports. It made its way a bit further into people’s homes on Monday when it agreed to pay $3.2 billion in cash for Nest Labs, which makes Internet-connected devices like thermostats and smoke alarms.

headline: Profit Falls at JPMorgan
text: JPMorgan Chase reported a 7.3 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, underscoring how expensive it has been for the bank to obtain peace with Washington, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. The net earnings of $5.28 billion, or $1.30 a share, fell slightly below Wall Street analysts’ expectations of $1.35 a share.

text: For JPMorgan Chase, legal costs continue to be a millstone.

headline: Eminence Plans Proxy Challenge at Jos. A. Bank
text: Eminence Capital has already declared its support for Men’s Wearhouse and its $1.6 billion hostile takeover bid for Jos. A. Bank and taken the company to court.

headline: Citing Charging Concerns, Tesla Issues a Recall
text: Tesla is issuing a recall action concerning about 29,000 charging adapters for its 2013 Model S electric cars because of a potential fire hazard, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a letter sent to the agency over the weekend.

headline: Ford Gambles on the F-150
text: Ford has unveiled its new F-150 with an aluminum body. The truck may pose an interesting marketing challenge for a company with the slogan “Ford Tough.”

headline: Conservative Group to Air Ads Attacking Health Law in Michigan and Iowa
text: One of the country’s most well-funded conservative groups is betting that public anger against President Obama’s signature health initiative is broad and deep enough to expand the field of competitive Senate races this November.

headline: Task Force Report Urges Municipalities to Stop Hiding Fiscal Troubles
text: WASHINGTON — After years of painful service cuts and devastating bankruptcies, culminating in the financial collapse of Detroit, state and local governments are being urged to stop using budget gimmicks that obscure the true extent of their money problems.

headline: Sarah Paulson Learns to Withhold Judgment
text: LOS ANGELES — Accepting the award for best drama at the Golden Globes, the “12 Years a Slave” director Steve McQueen called Sarah Paulson “the Bette Davis of America.” Ms. Paulson is a theater, film and television veteran, most recently seen in the FX series “American Horror Story.” In “12 Years,” she plays the wife of Michael Fassbender’s sadistic plantation owner; her character, Mistress Epps, has some sadistic streaks of her own, which perhaps seem even crueler judged against her gender.

headline: Ex-SAC Capital Trader Found His Way to Stanford After Harvard Expulsion
text: It has been a bit of a mystery figuring out how Mathew Martoma, who is on trial on federal insider-trading charges, was accepted into Stanford Business School after being expelled from Harvard Law School for forging his transcript. Typically, universities do not look too kindly on academic violations when considering whether to admit applicants.

headline: ‘Satchmo at the Waldorf’ to Open Off Broadway
text: “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” Terry Teachout’s one-man play about Louis Armstrong, will have its Off Broadway premiere at the Westside Theater. It begins previews on Feb. 15, and opens on March 4.

headline: Feigning Deafness, Giving Your Dog’s Email and Other Reader Tips to Thwart Privacy Grubbers
text: After venting my frustrations with an (admittedly very sweet) cashier lady and the entire data mining industry last Friday, I was thrilled to hear from hundreds of simpatico readers who had experienced similar, frustrating encounters and a few who weren’t afraid to administer some digital justice of their own.

headline: After Cancer ‘Disruption,’ a Determined Comeback
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Ross Hutchins is a cancer survivor, but he does not, he will not, define himself that way. He is not happy just to be here, back on a tennis court, back in a Grand Slam. He appreciates the sympathy, but please, enough.

headline: Google Effect Stirs Several Stocks
text: Google has raised the temperature in one small corner of the deal world.

headline: Red Tape Snarls Projects in India
text: MUMBAI, India — The Mumbai Trans Harbor Link, a 14-mile series of pillars supporting an eight-lane highway and a rail line, was supposed to be an artery relieving pressure on India’s financial capital, while feeding a new city and fresh growth.

headline: Little Harm to Boy Who Fell Into Manhole
text: As every New Yorker knows, the city’s sidewalks and streets are poked through with innumerable openings — grates and holes and precarious metal doors that sometimes bend to heart-jumping angles under the weight of a passing pedestrian.

headline: Auto Loans Bring Growth, and Scrutiny, for Banks
text: Car loans may be a boon to banks experiencing lackluster mortgage demand, but automobile lending has come with its own headaches recently.

headline: Times Minute | Christie's Address
text: Also on the Minute, Egypt goes to the polls and a new, lighter, Ford truck.

headline: Times Minute | Christie’s Address
text: In the Video

headline: Richard Ayoade Movie on the New Directors/New Films Slate
text: Richard Ayoade’s follow-up to his feature-directing breakthrough, “Submarine,” is one of the seven selections for the annual New Directors/New Films series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, those organizations said Tuesday.

headline: Rebuffing F.C.C. in ‘Net Neutrality’ Case, Court Allows Streaming Deals
text: WASHINGTON — Internet service providers are free to make deals with services like Netflix or Amazon allowing those companies to pay to stream their products to online viewers through a faster, express lane on the web, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Google Fans the Flame of Connectivity
text: Google has turned up the temperature on the “Internet of things.” The company’s decision to pay $3.2 billion for Nest Labs, a maker of smart thermostats, signals a shift in Silicon Valley’s arc of disruption. Sending data to people on the go looks rather ho-hum next to a future where consumers communicate with, and control, their products remotely.

headline: Girl You Know It’s True! An Opera Inspired by Milli Vanilli Is Set for Brooklyn Run
text: If Anna Nicole Smith and Jerry Springer can be opera subjects, why not Milli Vanilli?  Surely you remember Milli Vanilli, the pop vocal duo — Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus — who left the record business in disgrace in 1990, after it was revealed that their live performances were lip-synced to recordings, which turned out to have been made not by Mr. Morvan and Mr. Pilatus, but by studio singers.

headline: 2 Injured in Shooting at New Mexico School
text: A 12-year-old boy opened fire with a shotgun on Tuesday at the middle school he attends in Roswell, N.M., striking two among the dozens of students who were gathered inside a gym waiting for the first bell to ring, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Subaru’s Pocket Rocket Gets a Distinct Look
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan 14: 2015 Subaru WRX STI

headline: RC F Adds Hot Sauce to Lexus Line
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: Lexus RC F Coupe

headline: The Moto X Heads to Europe
text: LONDON — Motorola Mobility is bringing its struggling high-end smartphone to Europe.

headline: Men’s Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Ian McKellen and Nobel Winners Join Protests Against Russia’s Anti-Gay Laws
text: LONDON — With the Sochi Winter Olympics three weeks away, the British actor Ian McKellen and 27 Nobel laureates have signed an open letter to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, demanding that he repeal recent legislation that is widely condemned for discrimination against gays.

headline: Big Fees for Advisers if Charter Wins Over Time Warner Cable
text: Charter Communications finally unveiled a takeover bid for Time Warner Cable on Monday, offering $37.8 billion for its much bigger rival.

headline: A Conversation With T-Mobile US Executives
text: T-Mobile US, the fourth largest carrier in the United States, started 2014 with an aggressive move: It offered to pay for customers’ termination fees to break up with a rival carrier and switch to T-Mobile.

headline: Flaws in Chemical Laws in the Context of the West Virginia Spill
text: Two staff scientists at the Environmental Defense Fund have helpfully asked and answered the following question in the context of the large and disruptive chemical spill in West Virginia:

headline: Image of the Day: January 14
text: The head priest of Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, displaying a relic of the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: As Parents Age, Asian-Americans Struggle to Obey a Cultural Code
text: SOUDERTON, Pa. — Two thick blankets wrapped in a cloth tie lay near a pillow on the red leather sofa in Phuong Lu’s living room. Doanh Nguyen, Ms. Lu’s 81-year-old mother, had prepared the blankets for a trip she wanted to take. “She’s ready to go to Vietnam,” Ms. Lu said.

headline: SAC’s Cohen Enjoys a Different Type of Court Scene
text: On Monday, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, Mathew Martoma, sat stonefaced in a courtroom in Lower Manhattan, facing insider trading charges.

headline: Central African Republic Violence Ebbs, but U.N. Warns of Flare-Up
text: GENEVA — As a measure of calm returned to the capital of the Central African Republic on Tuesday after weeks of bloody turmoil, the United Nations human rights office warned that the violence could quickly reignite and released a report implicating Chadian members of the African peacekeeping mission in attacks on civilians.

headline: Guild Nominations That Could Skew Your Oscar Pool
text: LOS ANGELES — Awards-watchers pay close attention to editing guild prizes because a nod for best editing is considered a near-absolute necessity for a film to eventually win a best picture Oscar. As the guild notes, “No film has won best picture at the Oscars without also having received at least a best editing nomination since ‘Ordinary People’ in 1981.”

headline: As Gears Multiply, a Transmission Maker Prospers
text: DETROIT — The proliferation of gear ratios in modern automatic transmissions — even 6-speeds are seeming slightly behind the times now — has been good to at least one company.

headline: Judge Rejects N.F.L. Settlement, for Now
text: The judge presiding over the proposed $765 million settlement between the N.F.L. and more than 4,500 retired players who sued the league and accused it of hiding the dangers of concussions has raised significant questions about whether there will be enough money for all of the payouts, medical tests and treatment.

headline: A Flawed Man as Lightning Rod and Empathetic Stumbler
text: A quarter-century ago, Roger Guenveur Smith cajoled his friend Spike Lee into writing him into the script for “Do the Right Thing.” (He played Smiley, the mentally disabled man clutching a photograph of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X.) Now Mr. Smith, who has since constructed stage monologues around figures like Huey P. Newton and Frederick Douglass, has turned his wry attentions to an even more ferocious racial conflagration, this one all too real.

headline: Thailand Protests Are Captured in Social Media and Onstage
text: In the boldest move in two months of demonstrations against the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, Bangkok’s central commercial district has been swarmed by antigovernment protesters, and on Tuesday, the second day of the so-called “shutdown” of the city and its consequences were widely tracked on social media.

headline: Odds and Ends from the Detroit Auto Show
text: At the show, the spotlights are trained upon the next big things. But in the corners you can find oddities.

headline: Infiniti Mixes Formula One With Red Bull
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: Infiniti Q50 Eau Rouge concept

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: An Angry Republican
Kerry Brushes Aside Israeli Official’s Reported Criticisms of Peace Effort
text: KUWAIT — Secretary of State John Kerry brushed aside reports Wednesday that Israel’s defense minister has dismissed his Middle East peace push as naïve and messianic, stressing that he was determined to continue his efforts to secure a peace treaty between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Herb Alpert’s Next Gig in Manhattan: An Art Show
text: Herb Alpert, the musician, composer and record industry executive, is bringing his other passion — art ­­— back to New York City. His giant totem sculptures are coming to New York’s Dante Park later this month, and Mr. Alpert will also have an exhibit of smaller bronze totems at ACA Galleries in Chelsea, beginning Jan. 16.

headline: What’s a ‘Recess’ Appointment?
text: There was a lot of talk about the meaning of words at the Supreme Court on Monday — not exciting words like “life,” “liberty,” or “equality,” but more pedestrian words, like “the,” “recess,” and “happen” — as the justices considered for the first time what, exactly, the recess-appointments clause of the Constitution actually allows.

headline: Voting Under Heavy Security in Egypt
text: Egyptians lined up to vote on a new constitution under the watch of the security forces and military leadership of Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. A bomb exploded early in the day, but no one was injured.

headline: Prototype Sets Stage for New TLX
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: 2015 Acura TLX Prototype

headline: Justices Raise Bar for Suing Foreign Companies
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it harder to sue foreign companies in American courts, prompting a justice in a concurrence to accuse the majority of creating “a new rule of constitutional law that is unmoored from decades of precedent.”

headline: The Gun Report: January 14, 2014
text: Last week, Democratic Rep. Leslie Combs, a state representative from Kentucky, accidentally fired a gun in her Capitol Annex office. A House colleague, who was present at the time, said she was emptying a semi-automatic handgun and, thinking it was empty, pointed it away and down and pulled the trigger. No bullet fragments traveled outside the office.

headline: Protests Over Mississippi Plant Follow Nissan to Detroit
text: DETROIT — Labor activists are using the larger stage of the North American International Auto Show to highlight complaints about conditions at Nissan’s plant in Canton, Miss. Before dawn on Monday, demonstrators from the United Automobile Workers stood in front of Cobo Center, where the show was being held, carrying yellow signs reading, “Tell Nissan: Labor rights are civil rights.”

headline: Video: Despite Growing Military Budget, an Undercurrent of Skepticism
text: The continuing debate over military spending originated as a debate, at the time of the nation’s founding, over whether America should have a military at all. At the time even conservatives like John Adams and Alexander Hamilton, both partial to strong central government, had their doubts.

headline: Sotheby’s Report Defends Chinese Scroll It Sold as Authentic
text: SHANGHAI — Sotheby’s said Tuesday that an ancient calligraphy scroll the auction house sold in September for $8.2 million was authentic, despite recent claims by a group of Chinese art historians who insisted it was likely a 19th-century reproduction.

headline: Sled Dog Days
text: A look at sled dog racing, perhaps one of the first extreme sports, through the lens of the Times photography archive.

headline: New Michael Lewis Book on Financial World Will Be Published in March
text: Michael Lewis, whose colorful reporting on money and excess on Wall Street has made him one of the country’s most popular business journalists, has written a new book on the financial world, his publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Johnny Knoxville’s Makeup Passes the Street Test
text: LOS ANGELES — Johnny Knoxville is not a member of the Academy, nor is the “Jackass” star likely to be anytime soon. But he could be part of an Oscar-nominated movie: “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,” his feature-length hidden-camera comedy, is on the shortlist for best makeup. And Mr. Knoxville is very invested in its chances.

headline: Sled Dog Days
text: Winter packed a punch last week. Most of the country hunkered down, taking shelter from the Arctic temperatures, but for dog sledding, the season has only just begun.

headline: Coffee as a Memory Booster
text: In addition to its other well-known effects, a cup of coffee might improve your memory.

headline: Cocktails Under an 18th-Century Fresco in Milan to Fete a New Star at T
text: WhoT’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, hosted a mix of style connoisseurs, ranging from the fashion arbiters Suzy Menkes, Jim Moore and Tim Blanks, to some of their most illustrious Italian subjects: Diego Della Valle of Tod’s, Frida Giannini of Gucci and three generations of Missonis, including Rosita, Luca and Margherita.

headline: Longtime Morgan Stanley Banker Said to Retire
text: LONDON – A longtime media and telecommunications banker at Morgan Stanley in London has decided to retire after 25 years with the investment bank, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Are Potential Cable Mergers Good for Consumers?
text: With the specter of consolidation looming over the cable operator industry, eyes are already turning to Washington, where regulators are bound to look closely at the antitrust issues surrounding any potential merger.

headline: Federal Officials Return Looted Antiquities to India
text: Relations between India and the United States thawed a bit Tuesday as federal officials returned three stolen antiquities worth about $1.5 million to the Indian Consulate in New York, among them a 350-pound sandstone sculpture snatched from an Indian temple in 2009 that had been among Interpol’s Top 10 stolen works of art.

headline: A Coupe for Cadillac’s BMW-Battling Line
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: 2015 Cadillac ATS coupe

headline: Tunisian Constitution, Praised for Balance, Nears Passage
text: TUNIS — Tunisia’s National Constituent Assembly is close to passing a new Constitution that legislators across the political spectrum, human rights organizations and constitutional experts are hailing as a triumph of consensus politics.

headline: Heroes, Just for One Day
text: LOS ANGELES — Three of the top five grossing movies of 2013 involved superheroes — men in tights or high-tech suits or women who know their way around weaponry. (That’s “Man of Steel,” “Iron Man 3” and the No. 1 grossing film, “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.”) On Tuesday, the Academy announced that the theme for this year’s Oscars is movie heroes. Coincidence? Do you also believe bridges close for no reason?

headline: Springsteen and Clapton to Headline New Orleans Jazz Festival
text: Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, Eric Clapton, Phish and Christina Aguilera are among the artists who will headline this year’s New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, its organizers said on Tuesday. The festival, which is celebrating its 45th anniversary and will be held at the Fair Grounds Race Course from April 25 through 27 and May 1 through 4, will also feature the Canadian indie-rock ensemble Arcade Fire (which will be fresh off its earlier headlining slot at the Coachella festival in California), as well as performers like Robin Thicke, Vampire Weekend, Robert Plant, Trey Songz, Public Enemy and Chaka Khan.

headline: Bridgegate, Benghazi and the I.R.S. ‘Scandals,’ Compared
text: Republicans with the unenviable task of defending Chris Christie seem to have been given talking points of the “yeah, but what about…” variety. Over the last few days, many have tried to downplay the politically motivated traffic jam by comparing it to Benghazi and the allegation that the Internal Revenue Service “targeted” conservative groups.

headline: Bobby Flay’s Next Course
text: Last month, on the day after he turned 49, Bobby Flay could be found where most of his fans expect him to be: racing around with a knife in a big room bathed in spotlights.

headline: No Bluster as Christie Moves From Scandal to His Agenda
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, scrambling to regain his political footing, delivered a high-stakes State of the State address on Tuesday that mixed arms-length expressions of contrition, a defiant assertion that his troubles are no excuse for inaction and a jarringly timed demand for bipartisanship.

headline: Appeals Court Opinion Rejecting F.C.C. Net Neutrality Rules
text: A federal appeals court threw out Federal Communications Commission rules that require Internet service providers to give all traffic equal access through their networks.

headline: Black Sabbath’s 1970s Albums to Be Sold on iTunes
text: The very short list of high-profile artists whose music is not on digital services just got a little shorter with the arrival of Black Sabbath’s classic 1970s albums on iTunes.

headline: Tours for the Younger Traveler
text: As a traveler, I’m in a transition zone. I used to just show up in place with a backpack, a Rough Guide and not much else. The planning was always vague because anything else defeated the point: Tomorrow, who knew?

headline: ‘Always Journeying to Someplace New Gets Old Fast’
text: In his early years, Daniel Klein darted through Europe like a bird of passage, moving from town to town under the same vagabond spell that draws so many young backpackers today.

headline: Text of Christie’s State of the State Address
text: The following is the text of Gov. Chris Christie’s State of the State address, as prepared for delivery.

headline: Men’s Milan Fashion Week: DSquared2 Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Oddities From the Corners of the Detroit Auto Show
text: The press days of auto shows are well known for their bright lights, loud music and hordes of journalists scrambling for the position most advantageous for executive interviews and photos. But only during news conferences. Along the fringes, often in a corridor, visitors to any auto show can often find the strange and interesting.

headline: Nader, an Adversary of Capitalism, Now Fights as an Investor
text: “The next step is to organize the shareholders.” Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, was on the phone, outlining to me his latest cause: plunging into capitalism’s muddy waters and fighting for shareholder rights.

headline: Snowden to Join Board of the Freedom of the Press Foundation
text: Washington — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose leaks of secret documents set off a national and global debate about government spying, is joining the board of a nonprofit organization co-founded by Daniel Ellsberg, the well-known leaker of the Pentagon Papers during the Vietnam War.

headline: A Warhol Show at a Dali Museum
text: The Pop artist and the Surrealist, who were once acquainted, meet again when the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., stages “Warhol: Art. Fame. Mortality,” Jan. 18 through April 27.

headline: A Feverish Welcome for Indian Diplomat in Hometown of Mumbai
text: MUMBAI – For the crowd of about 60 people waiting at the airport here on Tuesday for Devyani Khobragade, the Indian diplomat who was indicted in the United States on charges of visa fraud, the gathering was as much a show of support for Ms. Khobragade as it was a protest against the Americans who, in their view, had humiliated her and her country.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Pakistan.

headline: Bridging the Gap Between BlackBerry and iPhone
text: Despite the popularity of touch-screen smartphones, some BlackBerry users have clung to their phones equipped with tactile keyboards. For those reluctant to let go of their BlackBerry, Typo Keyboard is here to help with the transition to a touch screen.

headline: Met’s Costume Institute to Be Renamed for Anna Wintour
text: When it reopens in May, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s fabled Costume Institute will be renamed the Anna Wintour Costume Center.

headline: Listen to What Your Plants Have to Say
text: Some gardeners swear by talking to their plants to help them grow; now, those plants can talk back.

headline: Documents Spur British Inquiry Over 1984 Raid at Indian Shrine
text: LONDON — Thirty years after Indian troops stormed the Golden Temple at Amritsar, leaving hundreds dead, the British government said Tuesday that it would open an investigation after the release of documents suggesting that British special forces had helped to draw up a plan to attack the building.

headline: Is Marriage Promotion Possible?
text: Now that there’s actually some slight movement in the Republican Party in the direction suggested by “Grand New Party,”  the book I co-authored with Reihan Salam way back in the misty days of 2007-2008, I suppose I should be grateful to Slate’s Matt Yglesias for doing his part to make our ideas seem as reactionary as possible. In a post accusing conservatives of having a “phantom agenda” on marriage promotion, Yglesias raises the question of how, exactly, a movement usually suspicious of government’s effectiveness expects the state to somehow intervene effectively in people’s most intimate decisions, and then offers the following reading of our book:

headline: Life as a Jewish Ghost in Modern Germany
text: Yascha Mounk’s book about growing up Jewish in Germany, “Stranger in My Own Country,” is rickety, not fully assembled, more the frame of a book than the sanded and stained product. Mr. Mounk is a young graduate student at Harvard, born in 1982, and his book is learned but at times not so wise.

headline: Another Democrat in Tight House District Won’t Run Again
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Bill Owens, a Democrat who has clung to his seat in a politically divided district along New York State’s Canadian border by narrowly winning his last two re-election fights, said on Tuesday that he would not run for a third full term.

headline: The Politics of the Binding of Isaac
text: Take now your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah; and offer him there for a burnt offering on one of the mountains which I will tell you. — Genesis, 22:2.

headline: Ad Hits Kay Hagan on Health Care
text: Senator Kay Hagan of North Carolina is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Mutual Funds in the Fourth Quarter of 2013
text: Highlights of mutual fund performance.

headline: Judge Reinstates Some Federal Oversight of Voting Practices for an Alabama City
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Alabama on Monday reinstated federal oversight over the voting practices of a city there, in what election law specialists said was the first such move since the Supreme Court struck down part of the Voting Rights Act in June.

headline: Motherlode Must-Read: ‘The Baby Chase: How Surrogacy Is Transforming the American Family’
text: “The Baby Chase: How Surrogacy Is Transforming the American Family,” by Leslie Morgan Steiner, was among the best books on family from 2013. I’ve been meaning to share it with you for some time, and Amy Klein’s post about donor eggs (“Would a Pregnancy Through a Donor Egg Feel Like ‘Mine’?”) and the resulting discussion of the medicine and ethics of egg donation, and in particular overseas egg donation, provided a perfect opportunity. If you’re at all curious about egg donation and surrogacy (in fact, if you’re just a curious reader at all), “The Baby Chase” makes a fascinating read.

headline: Behind the Olympics: Teaching About Russia in the Putin Era
text: Overview | What is it about Russia and the Olympics? Back in 1980, some 65 nations including the United States boycotted the Summer Games in Moscow (PDF) over the invasion of Afghanistan by the communist-led Soviet Union, as Russia was then known. Thirty-four years later, the athletes are returning – this time to the Black Sea resort of Sochi for the 22nd Winter Olympics – and so is the controversy.

headline: Ad Hits Patrick Murphy on Health Care
text: Representative Patrick Murphy of Florida is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Los Angeles Opera to Present ‘Figaro Trilogy’
text: Opera fans will be able to trace the development of one its most famous characters, Figaro, from barber to bridegroom to older-but-still-wily servant next season when the Los Angeles Opera presents its “Figaro Trilogy.”

headline: A Visitor’s Luxury Room
text: The first time I ate at Villard Michel Richard, the latest restaurant to dance among the frescoes and marble pilasters of the Villard mansion in Midtown, I strongly suspected that I was in an awful hotel restaurant.

headline: Living in Rowayton, Conn.
text: In this 1.4-square-mile coastal village in Norwalk, Conn., the most coveted homes are near the downtown, on the water, or in a beach association.

headline: Where Norwalk and Darien Collide
text: The coastal village of Rowayton, in Norwalk, is no place for anonymity. A 1.4-square-mile peninsula that hooks into Long Island Sound as if anchoring the entire city, it packs so much into so little space that running into neighbors on the narrow streets, in the compact parks, and along the single commercial strip is both inevitable and heartily encouraged by an energetic civic association.

headline: Ad Hits Joe Garcia on Health Care
text: Representative Joe Garcia of Florida is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Art Matters | Two Downtown Manhattan Gallerists Join Forces Upstate
text: Retrospective, the newest art gallery in the hamlet of Hudson, N.Y., inaugurated its space this past Saturday night with “Gambler’s Choice,” a sold-out show of bright, cartoon-inflected paintings by the 27-year-old Brooklyn-based artist Jamian Juliano-Villani. Seemingly worlds away from the white-cube spaces of Chelsea two hours to the south, Retrospective features vintage checkerboard floors and a sculptural tree branch in the bathroom that serves as a toilet paper holder. The project is the brainchild of the art dealers Zach Feuer and Joel Mesler, fixtures of the New York and Los Angeles art worlds. Feuer, who moved upstate several years ago and commutes to his eponymous Chelsea gallery, says he wanted to try something “outside the pressure cooker.” Even Retrospective’s name alludes to what Mesler, the owner of Untitled Gallery on the Lower East Side, called the “speed of the art world” — in which younger and younger artists land exhibitions surveying their already oversize careers. “But ‘Retrospective’ also sounds like an ’80s rock band,” he adds.

headline: For 2 Wall Street Regulators, More Belt-Tightening
text: Two primary regulators of Wall Street are preparing, once again, to make the most of scarce resources.

headline: Seeking Ways to Help the Poor and Childless
text: Last Friday at the Food Bank for New York on 116th Street, I caught a glimpse of the many shapes of need.

headline: Unemployment Extension Is Stalled, With 2 Proposals Defeated in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Unemployment benefits for 1.3 million of the long-term unemployed — and millions more in the future — were imperiled on Tuesday after Senate efforts to reach accord on legislation to revive them collapsed in partisan finger-pointing.

headline: A Major Renovation on the Doorstep of Queens
text: Created in 1909, Queens Plaza in Long Island City was intended as an attractive gateway to the borough for which it was named. But in more recent decades it became known as a haven for drug-dealing and prostitution and as a filthy, noisy eyesore where pedestrians risked their lives as they tried to cope with multiple lanes of traffic.

headline: The Regency Bar & Grill, and More Restaurant Openings
text: Headliners

headline: Obama to Place Some Restraints on Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will issue new guidelines on Friday to curtail government surveillance, but will not embrace the most far-reaching proposals of his own advisers and will ask Congress to help decide some of the toughest issues, according to people briefed on his thinking.

headline: Unexpected Works, Familiar Composers
text: Some composers are so strongly associated with one genre that it’s easy to forget that they dallied in others. A lone string quartet is among the handful of nonvocal works in Verdi’s huge catalog. A Trio for Violin, Clarinet and Piano is one of only a few instrumental works by Gian Carlo Menotti, who composed dozens of operas and musical theater and choral works.

headline: SPX Reaches Accord With Relational Over Board Seats
text: The SPX Corporation, an industrial equipment maker, said on Tuesday that it had struck an agreement with the activist investment fund Relational Investors that could give Relational up to two board seats over the next two years.

headline: Clip: 'Generation War'
text: A scene from the film, directed by Philipp Kadelbach.

headline: Those Ripples in the Water of the Bayou
text: Phil Robertson has run his mouth; an endless number of commentators have fumed or crowed about what he said; and now comes the day of decision. The first new episodes of A&E’s “Duck Dynasty” since that controversy are being broadcast on Wednesday night, and people who were fans of the show before Mr. Robertson’s attention-getting remarks about gays and blacks have to decide whether they’re still fans.

headline: New Classical Notes From Underground
text: It used to be that the virtuoso pianist Yefim Bronfman was not someone you expected to encounter playing in a subterranean East Village club that houses all kinds of contemporary music. Mr. Bronfman has been known for brilliant accounts of mainstream Romantic piano concertos, like Tchaikovsky’s First, a work he played this September at Avery Fisher Hall with the New York Philharmonic.

headline: A History Lesson, Airbrushed
text: “Generation War,” which was broadcast as a mini-series on German television last year, is perhaps more interesting as an artifact of the present than as a representation of the past. As the Second World War slips from living memory, as Germany asserts its dominant role in Europe with increasing confidence, and as long-suppressed information emerges from the archives of former Eastern bloc countries, the war’s cultural significance for Germans has shifted.

headline: The Echoes of War, From One Century to the Next
text: Context may not be everything in music but it can count for a lot. And the context for a performance of Shostakovich’s imposing wartime Symphony No. 7 (“Leningrad”) at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening was cryptically hailed in its title: “Shostakovich for the Children of Syria.”

headline: How Much Time Warner May Be Worth to a Suitor
text: Charter Communications says it is offering a full price for Time Warner Cable. At $132.50 a share, its proposal amounts to a 40 percent premium above where Time Warner Cable’s stock was trading in June, before rumors of a deal surfaced. “We think a lot of the premium is already in the stock,” Charter’s chief executive, Thomas M. Rutledge, told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Oklahoma’s Ban on Gay Marriage Is Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
text: A federal judge in Oklahoma ruled Tuesday that the state’s constitutional amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the federal Constitution, the latest in a string of legal victories for gay rights and one that occurred in the heart of the Bible Belt.

headline: The Joys of Rambling, as Artists and Raconteurs
text: Perhaps someone suggested to all the recipients of the National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Awards that they should stretch things out during Monday night’s ceremony at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Allen Room. Or perhaps the night’s first recipient, Jamey Aebersold, the pioneering developer of “Play-A-Long” books and recordings, did that simply because he felt compelled to, and the others — Anthony Braxton, Richard Davis and Keith Jarrett — played along, to some degree.

headline: A Confused Boy Wants to Play, Even When Others Want to Fight
text: Though licking around the edges of almost every scene, war is never allowed to intrude on the rose-tinted uplift of “When I Saw You,” a gauzy lament on displacement and disruption.

headline: Sea Salts Spiked With Chile, Italian Hot Chocolate and More
text: To Savor: Old Favorites, New Neighborhood

headline: Hungers Unsatisfied: Mouths Full, but Only With Words
text: I’m not sure if this is a spoiler, or simply stating the obvious, but there is no feast in “Feast.” The burnished table remains bare, the performers’ insatiable mouths empty, and wretchedly so.

headline: A Fan-Financed Game With a Retro Feel
text: Perhaps because video games are often, and wrongly, viewed solely as technology, they are thought by many to be perpetually improving. And sure, the past few decades have brought changes. Visuals have shifted from ragged, chunky blocks to three-dimensional computer animation. Sounds have gone from either nonexistent — as in the text adventure games of the 1970s and ’80s — or blips and beeps to fully recorded voice performances and orchestral scores that sometimes rival the best productions for film and television.

text: Also on the Minute, the French president brushes off questions about an affair and a review of Michel Richard's new restaurant.

headline: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
text: Between 4.4 million and 6.5 million immigrants illegally in the United States could gain an eventual pathway to citizenship under proposals being discussed by Republicans in the House of Representatives, according to an estimate published Tuesday by the National Foundation for American Policy, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.

headline: The Embodiment of an Idea, and Some Indelible Hits

headline: Low-Key Impresario at High Altitude
text: LOS ANGELES — For a guy with one of the biggest jobs in movies, John Cooper keeps an extremely low profile. He is the director of the Sundance Film Festival, yet Robert Redford remains its public face. Mr. Cooper loathes red carpets, preferring a quiet life in suburban Los Angeles with his husband and three daughters.

headline: Music Teacher Pleads Guilty to Molesting Girl, 9
text: A 71-year-old music teacher who ran a music school for children in Manhattan admitted in court on Thursday that he had molested a 9-year-old girl under his tutelage, pleading guilty to forcible sexual conduct against a child in return for a two-year sentence, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said.

headline: Three Microphones to Filter Out Ambient Noise
text: The German company Sennheiser has a long history of making headphones and microphones, and those two products have joined in a modernized twist: a Bluetooth ear piece that uses three microphones for noise cancellation.

headline: Sony Prepares for Widespread Use of 4K TVs With a 4K Camcorder
text: The major TV manufacturers are making a line of new 4K televisions — sets with nearly four times the resolution of today’s best mass market sets.

headline: At Auto Show, Tesla Defends Safety Record
text: DETROIT — The North American International Auto Show has a familiar rhythm for automakers making a presentation — gather a crowd, announce new products and talk excitedly about the future.

headline: Order Chinese, and Not by the Numbers
text: Here is one more thing the smartphone has now replaced: Your Chinese-reading friend you drag to restaurants to read the Chinese-only menus. Waygo, an app for the iPhone, is built to translate Chinese characters into English. (An Android version is being tested.)

headline: When Rosanne Cash Is Among Your Close-Knit Friends
text: The blog Mason-Dixon Knitting exists as a series of letters between two friends, Kay Gardiner and Ann Shayne, who share stories about everything from sewing to denim yarn to their husbands and travels. Gardiner — who lives in Manhattan; Shayne is in Nashville — happens to belong to a sewing circle that includes Rosanne Cash, whose new album, “The River and the Thread,” was the occasion for an article about her in last weekend’s magazine.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Competing With North Korea on Credit Card Security
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Listen Up | The Lofty Ambitions of Communion Records
text: Last Tuesday, Ben Lovett, the London-born, New York-based co-founder of the record label and events company Communion, pondered the soon-to-be-packed floor of the Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side. “It makes me feel quite old,” the 27-year-old said. “When you’re 19, you just sort of have limitless energy.” That’s how old he was in 2006, when he launched Communion in its earliest form as a club night in Notting Hill, London. A year later, he also co-founded the folk-rock band Mumford & Sons, which soon became a Grammy-winning touring juggernaut. Meanwhile, Communion has evolved into a promotions giant and global musical tastemaker with a presence in both London and New York. It’s enough to make anyone feel stretched.

headline: Regulators Ease Volcker Rule Provision on Smaller Banks
text: Updated, 7:26 p.m. | Federal regulators on Tuesday bent to the will of the banking industry and some lawmakers and revised a rule that would have forced community banks to take write-downs on a security that many had invested in before the financial crisis.

headline: VL Automotive Destino Red Concept: A Convertible Pipe Dream?

headline: Dozens Reportedly Arrested in Nigeria Amid Antigay Crackdown
text: Homosexual sex is illegal in Nigeria, where in some states ruled by Islamic law gay people can be legally stoned to death. Still, the government in recent weeks has decided to crack down on gay Nigerians both harshly and in secret, arresting dozens of suspected gay men in the country’s north and signing into law a sweeping measure that punishes gay marriage and even the formation of gay associations or clubs with as many as 14 years in prison.

headline: Bailed-Out Bankia Is Symbol of Spain's Financial Revival
text: MADRID — Less than two years ago, Bankia looked like a Spanish version of Lehman Brothers: a big, troubled institution whose collapse threatened to take down a country’s financial system.

headline: Mundane, Meet Dramatic
text: The gold-plated cliché that a picture is worth a thousand words is flipped on its head in “Brand New Ancients,” the thrillingly good, genre-bending show from the young British writer and performer Kate Tempest, at St. Ann’s Warehouse through Sunday. As Ms. Tempest’s gorgeous streams of words flow out, they conjure a story so vivid it’s as if you had a state-of-the-art Blu-ray player stuffed into your brain, projecting image after image that sears itself into your consciousness. Both as writer and performer, Ms. Tempest stitches together words with such animate grace that language acquires an almost tactile quality, and the drama she unfolds — of betrayal, disappointment and violence among a handful of not especially special London dwellers — soars to operatic dimensions.

Generations Blending: Better Dodge The Blades
text: The actor and comic John Hodgman removes the mask he regularly wears — of the complacently geeky, avuncular expert on everything who’s really an expert on nothing — to reveal some of his personal anxieties in “I Stole Your Dad,” his new solo show at the Public Theater. In this agreeable if not particularly substantial monologue, the Under the Radar Festival edges toward more populist terrain than it usually occupies. The show is essentially standard stand-up comedy featuring a familiar performer.

headline: Axe, Switching Gears, Strikes a More Earnest Tone
text: AXE, the men’s fragrance and grooming brand, is known for broad humor in its advertising, but a commercial that will air during the Super Bowl strikes a decidedly somber note.

headline: How the Poor Get Washed Away
text: WHEN Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines in November, killing more than 6,000 people and leaving more than four million homeless, one group was particularly hard hit: the landless poor. More than a thousand of the dead lived in a single squatter camp.

headline: Eni Is Said to Abandon Polish Shale Aspirations
text: LONDON — Eni, the Italian oil giant, is giving up on producing natural gas from shale rock in Poland, not long ago considered the most promising country in Europe for the new fuel source.

headline: Tobacco, Firearms and Food
text: Let’s say your beliefs include the notion that hard work will bring good things to you, that the golden rule is a nice idea though it may occasionally have limits, and that it’s more or less every person for him or herself. Your overall guiding force is not altruism, but you’re not immoral; you’re a good citizen, and you don’t break any major laws. This could describe many of us; most, maybe.

headline: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has implanted software in nearly 100,000 computers around the world that allows the United States to conduct surveillance on those machines and can also create a digital highway for launching cyberattacks.

headline: The Nuts and Bolts of Network Neutrality
text: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected Federal Communications Commission rules that required Internet service providers to treat all traffic equally. The so-called network neutrality rules were championed by Internet companies worried that the carriers could start charging for preferential treatment to information carried on their networks.

headline: The Man on the Wall
text: I’ve always thought that the reason Ariel Sharon was such an enduring presence in Israeli political life is that he personally reflected three of the most important states of mind that the state of Israel has gone through since its founding. At key times, for better and for worse, Sharon expressed and embodied the feelings of the Israeli Everyman as much, if not more, than any Israeli leader.

headline: World Bank Is Expecting Widespread (if Still Possibly Turbulent) Growth for 2014
text: WASHINGTON — After years of recession, financial crisis, fiscal wars and a patchwork recovery, there are relatively few dark clouds on the horizon for the global economy.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Contract Ends Long Lockout
text: One of the most contentious labor battles in the classical music world ended on Tuesday when the musicians of the Minnesota Orchestra, who had been locked out for more than a year, agreed to a new contract with smaller pay cuts than management had initially sought.

headline: Should Drug Enforcement Be Left to the States?
text: With states changing their approaches to drugs -- legalizing marijuana, focusing on treatment -- should the federal government even have a role in drug prosecution?

headline: Under Investor Pressure, Utility to Study Emissions
text: FirstEnergy, one of the country’s largest electric companies, has agreed to work toward reducing its carbon emissions in response to pressure from shareholders including New York State and Connecticut pension funds, New York Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli said on Tuesday.

headline: Small Deal for N.F.L. Games Has Major Implications and Potential
text: The N.F.L.’s plan to sell a package of Thursday night games to a broadcast or cable network represents an unusually modest moment in its recent television history.

headline: Seeking Clues to Obesity in Rare Hunger Disorder
text: Lisa Tremblay still recalls in horror the time her daughter Kristin pulled a hot dog crawling with ants from the garbage at a cookout and prepared to swallow it.

headline: Training Fighters of Future Across Gaza
text: RAFAH, Gaza Strip — Dozens of high school students scrambled among the sand dunes here in recent days, learning how to shoot AK-47 rifles, crawl under barbed wire and jump over burning tires. Their bearded commanders barked at those who were too slow in hoisting iron bars overhead or those who hesitated around the thick flames.

headline: (Not) Writing ‘Click Bait’ Headlines for Fun and Profit

headline: 787’s Battery Emits Smoke a Year After Jets’ Grounding
text: Nearly a year after Boeing’s 787 Dreamliners were grounded for three months because of hazards from their lithium-ion batteries, Japan Airlines said on Tuesday that one of its 787s vented smoke when a battery failed.

text: Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Mexico Faces Obstacle in Curbing Vigilantes Fighting Drug Gang
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexican soldiers met fierce resistance on Tuesday as they began disarming vigilante groups that have been fighting drug gangs in the agricultural lowlands of the western state of Michoacán.

headline: Fighting a McDonald’s in Queens for the Right to Sit. And Sit. And Sit.
text: Shortly after New Year’s Day, Man Hyung Lee, 77, was nursing a coffee in his usual seat in a narrow booth at a McDonald’s in Flushing, Queens, when two police officers stepped into the fluorescent light of the restaurant.

headline: Testifying in SAC Case, Doctor Admits Sharing Data
text: When Mathew Martoma, a hedge fund manager at SAC Capital Advisors, met Joel S. Ross, a prominent physician specializing in Alzheimer’s research, for dinner at a Midtown Manhattan restaurant, Mr. Martoma shocked Dr. Ross with a prescient question.

headline: $1.1 Trillion Bill to Avoid Federal Shutdown Covers Many Local Interests
text: WASHINGTON — A cryptic reference turns up on Page 399 of a six-inch-thick piece of legislation that congressional appropriators unveiled Monday night, calling for an extra $155 million worth of financing for the Department of Energy to promote its nuclear projects.

headline: Joel S. Marcus
text: Mr. Marcus, 66, is the chairman and chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, or REIT, based in Pasadena, Calif. The company, which Mr. Marcus also co-founded in 1994, owns and operates properties in the life science industry, totaling around 17 million square feet, including the Alexandria Center for Life Science on Manhattan’s Far East Side.

headline: Nigeria: Rights Chief Assails Law as Roundup of Gays Begins
text: The United Nations human rights chief Navi Pillay sharply condemned as “draconian” an antigay marriage law that took effect in Nigeria last week, saying Tuesday it violated fundamental rights and risked provoking a surge of antigay violence. Nigeria had already criminalized same-sex relationships, but the new law “makes an already bad situation even worse,” she said in a statement. The law provides for jail terms of 14 years for anyone entering a same-sex union and 10 years for anyone who aids or witnesses such a union or who supports the operation of gay groups. “Rarely have I seen a piece of legislation that in so few paragraphs directly violates so many basic, universal human rights,” Ms. Pillay said.

headline: Bulls, Built to Win Now, Decide to Disassemble
text: CHICAGO — Joakim Noah politely declined to address the news media for five days (including three games) after the Bulls traded the All-Star forward Luol Deng to the Cleveland Cavaliers. Noah, a genial center and often the Bulls’ de facto spokesman, needed to sift through the wreckage of his feelings and process the loss of his friend, “my brother,” as he called Deng.

headline: Tines That Try Men’s Souls
text: Far be it from me to defend what Jon Stewart has demolished.

headline: Garnett Lives His Soccer Dream
text: LONDON — As his team acclimatized to London ahead of their game against the Atlanta Hawks on Thursday, the Nets’ Kevin Garnett tried another sports hot seat for size when he visited Chelsea F.C., long one of his sporting passions.

headline: As Refinancing Wanes, Banks Are Wary of New Loans
text: The stars seem to be aligning in the housing market. Home prices have been rising for many months, and the federal government is providing immense support to bolster the mortgage market. The big banks that make home loans are strong enough to provide credit to borrowers, as seen in the fourth-quarter results reported Tuesday by JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo.

headline: India-America Relations on Edge
text: The Indian diplomat charged with visa fraud and mistreating her domestic worker is back in Mumbai, and tensions between India and the United States have eased. But her case and the issues it raised are not resolved, and the damage to India-America relations is unlikely to dissipate soon. This unfortunate episode is a reminder that while both nations are democracies, neither can avoid the hard work necessary to make the relationship work.

headline: Giants Hire Packers Assistant to Reconstruct Offense
text: The Giants on Tuesday named Ben McAdoo, an innovative Green Bay Packers assistant, as their new offensive coordinator, a move that signals the team’s desire to move away from the system of Kevin Gilbride, who retired Jan. 2.

headline: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
text: CAIRO — One is setting a standard for dialogue and democracy that is the envy of the Arab world. The other has become a study in the risks of revolution, on a violent path that seems to lead only in circles.

headline: The Christie Way
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey tried to change the subject on Tuesday with his annual State of the State speech, talking about longer school days and reducing urban crime. But there is no diverting attention from the unanswered questions about how Mr. Christie and his close advisers have used his office to mete out rewards or punishment for political reasons.

headline: Now Online, Diaries of British Soldiers Detail Horrors of World War I
text: LONDON — The British obsession with the centennial of World War I, the war that did not end all wars, heightened on Tuesday as the National Archives announced that it was putting diaries from British soldiers in the conflict online.

headline: Finally, Congress Does Its Job
text: The last time Congress approved a series of spending bills to pay for the government — its most basic job — was in 2011. Since then, Republican lawmakers, determined to thwart the Obama administration at every step, have forced the government to subsist on stopgap measures that simply carry over or cut previous spending, with no accounting for growth, inflation or changing priorities.

headline: Way Before Rodriguez, Another Yankee Gave Baseball Fits
text: In his written ruling on Alex Rodriguez’s appeal of his 211-game suspension, baseball’s impartial arbitrator raises the name and pathetic case of Steve Howe, the pitcher who was given more chances to play baseball than Billy Martin was given to manage the Yankees.

headline: Christie’s State Address Opening Remarks
text: Gov. Chris Christie opened his 2014 State of the State address noting his administration’s mistakes and its achievements, saying the state of New Jersey is “good, and it is getting better.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 15, 2014
text: “Mistakes were clearly made.”

headline: Corrections: January 15, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: On Camera, a Feminist Hero Gains Complexity
text: Are you an angry woman? That’s the first question James Day asks a smiling, ebullient Billie Jean King in “She Is King,” part of the Incubator Arts Project’s Other Forces festival. Sure, she says, she’s angry about certain things, but then, who isn’t?

headline: Location, Location, Location
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — First, the big news: today’s constructor, Bernice Gordon of Philadelphia, turned 100 years young last Saturday. Let’s let that sink in for a bit, shall we? Not only has Ms. Gordon made it to her 100th birthday, but she is still constructing crossword puzzles, and really good ones at that.

headline: Mideast Strife Turns Trial on Beirut Assassination Into Another Fault Line
text: UNITED NATIONS — Perhaps it was wishful thinking from the start. The huge car bomb that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon nearly nine years ago led to an ambitious international investigation intended to bring about a new era of accountability to a country long splintered by political violence.

headline: Cuomo Saying Little on Bridge Scandal
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is not one to shy away from a political fight. But in the case of the scandal engulfing Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey over retaliatory lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, Mr. Cuomo and his aides have kept to a simple mantra from the beginning: This was and remains a New Jersey issue.

headline: Lobbying Picks Up Over Bill to Toughen Antinuclear Sanctions Against Iran
text: Partisans in the debate over a Senate bill that would threaten onerous new antinuclear sanctions on Iran escalated their lobbying on Tuesday, with critics submitting a letter to lawmakers signed by 62 multifaith organizations urging a delay and supporters pointing to what they called Iran’s insincerity.

headline: Even Supporters Question Cuomo’s Marijuana Plan
text: ALBANY — When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this month that he would allow medical marijuana in New York, the news was greeted with great enthusiasm by those who champion the drug for patients with cancer, AIDS and other serious illnesses.

headline: Bookstore May Have to Flee the Wrecking Ball, Again
text: Twenty-nine years ago, Rizzoli Bookstore, whose Old World charm, hand-wrought chandeliers and big storefront windows make it a favorite of noted authors, book lovers and tourists, fled Fifth Avenue two steps ahead of the wrecking ball.

headline: France: Roma Evictions Increase
text: French authorities sharply accelerated the eviction of migrant Roma squatters in 2013, razing the unauthorized encampments of nearly 20,000 Roma, according to a report by rights groups on Tuesday. The evictions were double those of 2012, according to the French Human Rights League and the European Roma Rights Center. President François Hollande took office in 2012 pledging to break with the strict policies of his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy. But Mr. Hollande has reinforced those policies, demolishing at least 165 Roma camps last year, according to the report. French officials did not respond to requests for comment.

headline: Congo: Fighters Quit, U.N. Says
text: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo said Tuesday that 8,000 fighters affiliated with a variety of armed factions had surrendered since the M23 rebel group was routed in November. Among them are the Hutu militias that Rwanda holds responsible for the genocide 20 years ago. Martin Kobler, the United Nations’ special representative for Congo, said about 50 members of a Hutu group, Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, had surrendered in each of the last two months alone, steadily diminishing what he said was a 1,800-strong force. He said his peacekeepers were focused on rooting out the rest, but warned that the group was not likely to be eliminated by military means alone.

headline: American Weight Lifter Is Suspended
text: Sarah Robles, an American weight lifter who became a crowd favorite at the 2012 Summer Games in London, received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, Usada announced.

headline: Court Weighs Police Role in Coercing Confessions
text: New York State’s highest court heard arguments in two murder cases on Tuesday that plumbed the question of how far the police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations — even to the point of telling suspects a dead victim is still alive, but might survive if they confess to precise details of the crime.

headline: In 9 Seconds, Rangers Watch Lead, Tie and Game Vanish
text: Nine costly seconds was all it took to scuttle the Rangers on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. In that lightning-quick stretch Tampa Bay scored twice for a 2-1 win.

headline: New York Schools Chancellor Honed Blunt Style Over 40 Years
text: Carmen Fariña was known for her meticulous demands.

headline: Knicks Fall to Bobcats, and J. R. Smith Sits Again
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Knicks, making their way back to relevance in the Eastern Conference’s Atlantic Division, arrived here on a five-game winning streak and facing a Bobcats team that had lost eight of its last nine games.

headline: After Family Turmoil, a Commitment to Her Two Siblings
text: Never had the sound of snoring been such a comfort.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 14, 2014
Fire Kills 16 at Factory Making Shoes for Export
text: A fire tore through a shoe factory in eastern China, killing at least 16 people, and the state media said that the police on Wednesday took into custody the owners of the plant, which makes shoes for export around the world.

headline: Teenager Is One of Australia’s Remaining Hopes
text: With a serve that can reach nearly 137 miles per hour and a powerful all-court game, Nick Kyrgios has been gaining attention for some time.

headline: Burton R. Lifland, Bankruptcy Judge in Big Cases, Dies at 84
text: Burton R. Lifland, a pre-eminent federal bankruptcy judge who for three decades rode herd on some of the nation’s biggest corporate rescue efforts and presided over the financial chaos left by the swindler Bernard L. Madoff, died on Sunday in New Haven. He was 84.

headline: Port Authority’s Chairman May Be the Next to Topple
text: It is starting to look as if this could be the traffic jam that ate New Jersey.

headline: Thomas L. Chrystie, Bank Services Innovator on Wall St., Dies at 80
text: When Thomas L. Chrystie became a top executive in the early 1970s at Merrill Lynch & Company, it was a rocky time for Wall Street brokerage firms. A recession, a bear market, high inflation and “stagflation,” the fusion of rising prices and rising unemployment, had stock investors fleeing and taking with them the commissions and fees that brokerage houses lived on.

headline: Return to Normal in Parts of West Virginia Is Marred by Distrust
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The water was back on, but the anxiety had not shut off.

headline: Ideas, Costs and the All-Volunteer Army
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What Ultra-Marathons Do to Our Bodies
text: Ultra-runners are different from you and me. They run more. But a new study of these racers, who compete in events longer than marathons, joins other recent science in finding that they also tend to be older and have some different health concerns than most of us might expect, suggesting that some beliefs about how much activity the human body can manage, especially in middle age, may be too narrow.

headline: Retired Police Captain Feared Attack Before Shooting in Theater, Officials Say
text: MIAMI — A retired police captain who killed a man after an argument over texting in a movie theater told detectives that he feared he was under attack when the victim hit him in the face with an unknown object, police records show.

headline: Word of the Day | amphitheater
text: amphitheater •\ˈam(p)-fə-ˌthe(-ə)-tər also ˈam-pə-ˌthe-\• noun

headline: Christie's State of the State Address
text: The full remarks from Gov. Chris Christie’s speech.

headline: Aide to Late Lawmaker Wins a House Primary in Florida
text: MIAMI — The first race in the 2014 battle for Congress took shape on Tuesday in one of the country’s quintessential swing districts as David Jolly, a former general counsel to the district’s longtime Republican representative, the late C. W. Bill Young, defeated two opponents to win the Republican primary.

headline: For Super Bowl, It’s Back to Basics for Anheuser-Busch
text: The Anheuser-Busch division of Anheuser-Busch InBev, which typically buys the most commercial time during the Super Bowl each year, has a game plan for Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2 that is focused on its two core brands, Bud Light and Budweiser.

headline: In Rare Video, Wife of Jailed Nobel Laureate Reads Poems While Under House Arrest
text: Liu Xia, the wife of the imprisoned Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo, was shown reading two of her poems in a short video aired at an event on Tuesday in New York. The two-minute video was filmed in December and obtained by the Friends of Liu Xiaobo and the Independent Chinese PEN Center, a free-speech advocacy group that Ms. Liu helped establish.

headline: Suing to End Life Support for Woman and Fetus
text: HOUSTON — Lawyers for the husband of a pregnant woman being kept on life support at a Fort Worth hospital against her family’s wishes sued hospital officials on Tuesday, asking a judge to order the doctors to remove her from the machines and declare the Texas law at the center of her case unconstitutional.

headline: Ads Attacking Health Law Stagger Outspent Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats are increasingly anxious about an onslaught of television ads hitting vulnerable Senate and House candidates for their support of the new health law, since many lack the resources to fight back in the early stages of the midterm campaign.

headline: Thousands March Against Thai Leader in 3rd Day of Protests
text: BANGKOK — With no sign of resolution to Thailand’s debilitating political power struggle, antigovernment protesters marched through Bangkok on Wednesday pledging to stop elections next month while the government vowed that they would take place.

headline: Program to Cover Major Illnesses Is Extended
text: A special health insurance program for people with cancer, heart disease and other serious illnesses will be extended for two additional months, through March, so patients can continue treatment while they search for other coverage, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (FXX) HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON (2010) In this feature from DreamWorks Animation, a teenage Viking named Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) befriends Toothless, an injured dragon, on a windswept island; pleases his demanding father (Gerard Butler); and saves the world in the process. The airborne sequences, like the one above, are particularly compelling, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “When Hiccup first climbs on Toothless’s back and urges the dragon to take wing, the hearts of the audience soar with a primitive and durable delight,” he said. “The techniques that enabled this feeling may be dauntingly complicated, but the feeling could not be simpler.” At the beginning and the end, “ ‘How to Train Your Dragon’ is noisy and action-packed in the usual way,” Mr. Scott added, with “eye-straining, ear-popping large-scale effects.” But they are worth sitting through, he wrote, “for the tenderness, beauty and exhilaration that are the movie’s great strengths.”

headline: After Flurry of Changes, Some States Ease Up
text: LOS ANGELES — One year ago, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper, a Colorado Democrat, stood before a state legislature controlled by his party and laid out an aggressive agenda that included a sweeping expansion of gun-control laws after the mass shooting at an Aurora movie house. “Why not have universal background checks for all gun sales?” he asked.

headline: Tussling Over a Name for Beijing’s New Airport
text: What’s in an airport name? In Beijing, a debate has begun over the name of a planned new international airport, the capital’s second. The front-runners are Daxing, Jingji, Lixian, Yongding, Yufa and Zhuque, with the struggle between the two favorites, Daxing and Lixian, seeming to rest on this: What image does China want to present to the world? Money or virtue?

headline: Danish Tourist Says She Was Gang-Raped in India
text: NEW DELHI — A 51-year-old Danish woman said she was gang-raped at knife point by seven or eight men in central New Delhi after she approached them to ask for directions to her hotel, the Delhi police reported on Wednesday.

headline: Washington: More Money Sought for Schools and Wages
text: Gov. Jay Inslee asked lawmakers to increase spending on K-12 education and raise the state minimum wage as the Legislature began work on the first state budget in six years without a major financial shortfall. Mr. Inslee, a Democrat, said in his State of the State speech on Tuesday that improving finances made education spending a priority. The Washington Supreme Court has ruled that education spending does not meet constitutional requirements. Washington already has the nation’s highest statewide minimum wage, $9.32, and Mr. Inslee said there was “ample evidence” that an increase in the $1.50 to $2.50 range “does not kill jobs.”

headline: Florida Governor Chooses Running Mate
text: MIAMI — Gov. Rick Scott named a South Florida property appraiser and former Republican legislator to be his running mate and lieutenant governor, filling a position that had been vacant for nearly a year.

headline: Administration Is Seen as Retreating on Environment in Talks on Pacific Trade
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is retreating from previous demands of strong international environmental protections in order to reach agreement on a sweeping Pacific trade deal that is a pillar of President Obama’s strategic shift to Asia, according to documents obtained by WikiLeaks, environmentalists and people close to the contentious trade talks.

headline: With China Awash in Money, Leaders Start to Weigh Raising the Floodgates
text: HONG KONG — Move over, Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke. Step aside, Mario Draghi and Haruhiko Kuroda. When it comes to monetary stimulus, Zhou Xiaochuan, the longtime governor of the People’s Bank of China, has no rivals.

headline: Ambitious Art on Display at Mumbai’s New Airport Terminal
text: MUMBAI — Airports are normally places people want to rush in and out of, but the developers of the new Terminal 2 at Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai hope to change that. Among the many benefits for flyers coming through Terminal 2 is the opportunity to take in a vast amount of traditional and contemporary Indian art via an ambitious public arts program.

headline: Hong Kong Leader’s Speech Skirts Appeals for Democracy
text: HONG KONG — The chief executive of Hong Kong, in his annual policy address on Wednesday, called for greater government spending on education from kindergarten through college, but said little in response to appeals here for greater democracy.

headline: Test Yourself, Math | Jan. 15, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | ‘The New Face of Polygamy’?
text: In “Polygamy as Lifestyle Choice, and a Reality TV Brand,” John Schwartz reports on the Brown family of the reality show “Sister Wives.”

headline: Spring Festival Gala Performance by Chinese Rock Icon in Doubt
text: An iconic Chinese rocker whose music is closely associated with the 1989 pro-democracy movement is unlikely to appear on this year’s Spring Festival gala on Chinese state television because of censorship concerns, his agent said.

headline: Choosing Sides and a Camera
text: Builder Levy grew up thinking the world could be — had to be — a better place. How he would do his part was almost predetermined. He grew up in a family of what would now be called progressives. He called them Mom, Dad and Aunt Dolly. One day, bored, he put on one of his father’s records, “Which Side Are You On?” It entranced him.

headline: Donors Offer $2.4 Billion to Aid Syrian Civilians, but U.N. Says More Is Needed
text: KUWAIT — Western nations, Arab states and others pledged more than $2.4 billion on Wednesday to help civilians who are suffering because of the civil war in Syria.

headline: American Life Turns Off One Chinese Student
text: Disillusioned by rampant partying, illicit drugs and racial discrimination, one Chinese student in the United States has held nothing back in telling a Chinese news outlet why he is eager to return home.

headline: Where in the World Would You Travel If You Could?
text: At the beginning of each year, the Times Travel section suggests the best places on the globe to visit. The 2014 edition includes photographs and short descriptions of 52 places.

headline: State Television Airs Footage of Major Drug Raid
text: Chinese state television broadcast video on Tuesday of last month’s raid by 3,000 police officers on a village described as a center of methamphetamine production.

headline: New York Today: Water Main Break Snarls Commute
text: Updated 12:06 p.m.

headline: Times Minute | Environmental Compromise
text: Also on the Minute, early 2014 political ads and "Duck Dynasty" returns.

headline: Times Minute | Compromising on the Environment
text: In the Video

headline: Obama Announces Institute to Create Manufacturing Jobs
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — It was President Obama’s first policy-related trip of 2014, but he used it to take care of some unfinished business from 2013.

headline: Better Hearing Through Bluetooth
text: Like many men of his generation, Larry Faust, 61, of Seattle, went to a lot of rock concerts in his youth. And like many men of his generation, his hearing isn’t what it used to be.

headline: German Economy Grows at Modest Pace
text: FRANKFURT — The German economy registered only meager growth in the fourth quarter of 2013, according to early estimates released on Wednesday, as an improvement in consumption was not strong enough to compensate for a decline in investment by business and government and the effects of recession elsewhere in Europe.

headline: Deutsche Bank Suspends Traders Amid Foreign Exchange Investigations
text: LONDON – Deutsche Bank has suspended several traders amid a series of investigations into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Daily Report: Court Rejects F.C.C. Rules Barring Deals on Faster Streaming
text: Internet service providers are free to make deals with services like Netflix or Amazon allowing those companies to pay to stream their products to online viewers through a faster, express lane on the web, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 4: Parents at a Wedding
text: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Bank of America’s Profit Exceeds Estimates
text: Updated, 12:18 a.m. | Bank of America has spent the last five years digging out from its mortgage problems, shoring up its capital levels and laying off employees.

headline: For Some Ski Racers, an Advantage Before the Season Even Starts
text: LA GRAVE, France — In the fight for the World Cup overall title, Marcel Hirscher of Austria already has a 23-point lead over Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway. Unfortunately for Svindal, there might be an even bigger obstacle that he has no control over as he tries to close the gap before the season ends in March.

headline: Militants Unleash Wave of Violence in Iraq, Killing Dozens
text: BAGHDAD — Militants launched lethal and coordinated car bombings in Baghdad on Wednesday, killed truck drivers outside the city and detonated explosives at a funeral tent in a village during one of the deadliest outbreaks of violence in Iraq so far this year, according to health and security officials.

headline: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival
text: The 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival, now in its ninth edition, kicks off in the state capital of Rajasthan on Friday.
