headline: The Global Village Rolled Up in a Carpet
text: This week at the International Furniture Fair in Cologne, Germany, Danskina, the Dutch rug company, is presenting its first collection under its new design director, Hella Jongerius.

headline: Look Before You Climb
text: Maison Martin Margiela, the Paris-based fashion house founded by the reclusive Belgian designer, who parted ways with the business in 2009, has an idiosyncratic, avant-garde style that can go anywhere. Collaborating with L’Atelier d’Exercices, a French company, the design team is producing objects for the home that mix irony, mystery and humor, such as eggs filled with fortune-cookie-type messages and a melted wax candleholder. One of the group’s favored memes is trompe l’oeil, and it has created a series of black-and-white photographs of architectural details, which are printed on an easily repositioned adhesive fabric. The latest, an atmospheric staircase, would add wit and misdirection to any room and bring a new dimension to a cramped studio apartment. The mural measures 7.4 feet by 3.9 feet and is $320. Information: 888-266-1737 or sweetbellausa.com. or at Top Hat, 245 Broome Street, 212-677-4240.

headline: Where Are the Jellyfish, Exactly?
text: How to add a swimming pool with an ocean view to an inland suburban retreat? Put it on the roof. When designing the Jellyfish House, a summer home for a Dutch family in the coastal town of Marbella, Spain, Wiel Arets, an architect with offices in the Netherlands and Switzerland, turned the pool into a central feature of the three-story building by elevating it.

headline: Perfection By the Book
text: Jessica Lamb-Shapiro began writing her new book, “Promise Land” (Simon & Schuster; $25), as a way to make sense of the immense body of self-help literature, from the dawn of religion to modern home management. Wildly funny, it takes a few dark turns as well.

headline: Pro-Progressive Is Better Than Anti-Christie
text: We’re a week into Chris Christie Bridgegate and I’m already bored, not because I don’t think the truth should be ferreted out in the bright light of day, but because the political discussion about it appears to be devolving into pettiness.

headline: The Power Behind the Throne
text: What you’ll need to replace your toilet.

headline: Whose Mall Is It?
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — LAST Saturday, security officers stopped two tall young black men at the entrance of JK Iguatemi, a luxury shopping mall in São Paulo. The young men were wearing flashy tennis shoes and brand-new soccer jerseys. “What are you doing here?” I heard the guards ask. “We came to buy something,” explained one. “My cousin here is a soccer player. From Bragantino.”

headline: Seizing the Throne
text: A few months ago the strangest thing happened with two of our toilets. The water level on both lagged well below normal, even though the pipes were clear. We assumed that the problem was in our septic system. Our plumber suspected otherwise.

headline: Walmart Is Facing Claims That It Fired Protesters
text: The National Labor Relations Board, in a sweeping complaint filed on Wednesday, said that Walmart illegally disciplined and fired employees after strikes and protests for better pay.

headline: Cultivating Hudson: Enter the Tastemakers
text: HUDSON, N.Y. — Ann Marie Gardner has a buzzword for the “urban-rural confluence” she sees fueling this town’s most recent boomlet as a cultural hub. “Rurbanism,” as she describes it, is when urban expats bring their cultural touchstones and appetites with them when they move to a place like Hudson.

headline: Puzzle of Super Bowl Security Has to Include New Pieces
text: As is the case for other major sporting events, securing the Super Bowl is a complex and nerve-racking task that involves the coordination of many law enforcement agencies, the use of technologies like cameras and radiation detectors, and the identification of potential troublemakers.

headline: The Coldest Yard
text: LOS ANGELES — IF I were to attack you and slam you to the ground as you stood in line for your morning coffee, you might not get up. But if I put a helmet on you and put you on a football field, then did the exact same thing, you’d pop up and ask for another. There is something powerful about football, something that grants men temporary invincibility, makes them immune to pain and anguish.

headline: Sheila Guyse, Singer and Star in ‘Race Movies,’ Dies at 88
text: Sheila Guyse, a popular actress and singer who appeared on Broadway and in so-called race movies in the 1940s and ’50s, and who for a time, despite limited opportunities in the entertainment industry, appeared headed for broader fame, died on Dec. 28 in Honolulu. She was 88.

headline: Have Your Job and Moonlight, Too
text: ALMOST a century ago, a hit song lamented the difficulty in persuading American soldiers who saw the world during the Great War to return to their rural homes. The title said it all: “How Ya Gonna Keep ’Em Down on the Farm? (After They’ve Seen Paree).”

headline: Weighing In at the End
text: Three-Fourths of an Ounce, a new line of condolence products including memorial candles and jewelry, is named after measurements taken by the early 1900s Massachusetts doctor Duncan MacDougall. After studying terminally ill people and euthanized dogs, he concluded that a body lost three-quarters of an ounce at the moment of death, so a soul must weigh that much. (Scientists, however, have since discredited his methods and data.) The designer Ted Muehling has contributed polished quartz ovals ($200 each) that weigh, yes, 0.75 ounces. His staff grinds the stones at a workshop behind his Manhattan boutique, on machines with wet sandpaper wheels that emit mournful sounds as they spin. Mr. Muehling, who was brought up Catholic, said the translucent stones remind him of his childhood image of the soul as an internal vapor that grows cloudier with every sin. The polished talismans are also ecumenically reminiscent of crystal orbs that Buddhist temple statues carry and pebbles that Jews place on gravestones. Information: 3-4oz.com.

headline: Theft at Target Leads Citi to Replace Debit Cards
text: Citibank plans to reissue all customer debit cards involved in the data breach at Target, making it the second major bank to do so since the attack was disclosed last month.

headline: Sales at Ralo Tibet Carpet, Jayson Home and Others
text: During Ralo Tibet Carpet’s warehouse sale, through Sunday, many rugs are up to 70 percent off (a 6-by-9-foot Trellis Red rug, regularly $7,130, is $3,565); 29 Howard Street (Broadway), 212-966-7661, tibetcarpet.com.

headline: Pendant Lamps: Theater of Suspension
text: Will Meyer and Gray Davis consider themselves “maniacs” about the lighting in the spaces they design. If nothing else, Mr. Meyer, 45, said, “It needs to make people look attractive.”

headline: Should We Install Underfloor Heat in the Bathroom?
text: Q. Our bathroom is always colder than the rest of our house. Should we install underfloor radiant heating when we remodel?

headline: Giants Fire Two Longtime Assistants
text: The sweeping shake-up of the Giants’ offensive brain trust continued Wednesday when the longtime assistants Mike Pope and Jerald Ingram were fired.

headline: Yahoo Parts Ways With Its No. 2 Executive
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo’s No. 2 executive, Henrique de Castro, has been fired by his boss, Marissa Mayer, a little more than a year after she wooed him away from Google to help her turn around the struggling Internet company.

headline: Federal Contracts Plunge, Squeezing Private Companies
text: The big business of Washington — federal contract work — is losing some steam.

headline: Phones in Subway: On Elevated Lines, Hear the Future
text: Slang and Mandarin commingle on the No. 7 line during the evening rush, and teenagers arrange their meeting spots by text on the N at Coney Island, the Wonder Wheel rising through train car windows at sunset.

headline: Far West Got Drier Last Year, Data Shows
text: Drought conditions in California and elsewhere in the Far West intensified last year, government scientists said Wednesday, adding to concerns about water supplies in the region.

headline: Lebanese Bomber’s Death, and Life, Leave Questions
text: HNAIDER, Lebanon — The last time his mother saw him, he joined the family for dawn prayers as usual. A few hours later, the 19-year-old engineering student had vanished. No one saw him leave, his cellphone was off and text messages went unanswered.

headline: Ken Landwehr, Who Played Key Role in Capture of Serial Killer, Dies at 59
text: Lt. Ken Landwehr, a homicide detective in Wichita, Kan., who played a pivotal role in the capture of the serial killer known as B.T.K., whose terrorizing spree went unredressed for more than 30 years, died at his home on Monday in Wichita. He was 59.

headline: In N.F.L. Suit, Judge Flags Provision Protecting N.C.A.A.
text: The federal judge who rejected the N.F.L.’s concussion lawsuit settlement Tuesday raised a fundamental concern about the deal: whether the $765 million set aside for payouts and medical testing would be enough over the suit’s 65-year life.

headline: The State of the Speeches
text: Let’s discuss state of the state speeches.

headline: New York City to Pay $18 Million Over Convention Arrests
text: New York City will pay nearly $18 million to settle civil rights lawsuits filed on behalf of roughly 1,600 people who claimed they were wrongfully swept up in mass arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention, lawyers for the city and plaintiffs said on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. to Expand Rules Limiting Use of Profiling by Federal Agents
text: The Justice Department will significantly expand its definition of racial profiling to prohibit federal agents from considering religion, national origin, gender and sexual orientation in their investigations, a government official said Wednesday.

headline: Dissent, Guns & Ammo
text: It was a rare peek behind the Oz-like curtain of gun journalism in its role as the gun industry’s mouthpiece: A respected columnist was dismissed from Guns & Ammo magazine in October after he dared to write the obvious — that all constitutional rights, including the right to bear arms, are and “need to be” subject to legitimate regulation. This was heresy for Second Amendment absolutists.

headline: False Reasons for Filibustering Jobless Aid
text: Republican senators are pulling out every fake excuse they can think of for filibustering an extension of jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed on Tuesday. The majority leader, Harry Reid, was mean to us and wouldn’t let us offer amendments, they say. Democrats refused to pay for the benefits. It’s President Obama’s fault people can’t find work because he won’t approve the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: Hauling Bags and Cleaning Planes for Little Pay and No Vacations of Their Own
text: Norman Echeverri’s life once glowed with promise. He held a job at a company in Medellín, Colombia, had a car, laughed, played cards with friends.

headline: Chinese Activists Test New Leader and Are Crushed
text: BEIJING — The 20 or so activists gathered at an isolated guesthouse on the outskirts of the capital, leaving their cellphones behind to avoid detection by the police. China’s first leadership change in a decade was fast approaching, and the group saw an opening for a movement to fight injustice and official corruption.

headline: A Disappointing Internet Decision
text: In a discouraging ruling, a federal appeals court on Tuesday struck down regulations that prohibited phone and cable companies from charging different rates for delivering different types of content to consumers or even blocking certain content.

headline: A Culture of Violence
text: In the South Pacific island nation of Papua New Guinea, one of the world’s most violent places, nearly every woman has experienced some form of domestic abuse.

headline: Mixed Results for Mideast Democracy
text: A constitution is supposed to be a set of governing principles around which citizens can unite and peacefully build a democratic state. Tunisia is providing a constructive path to this goal. Egypt is not. Sadly, Egypt is on the verge of enacting a Constitution that would effectively legitimize last year’s coup and further enable the kind of authoritarian system that the 2011 revolution was intended to displace.

headline: Long-Running D.C. Show Faces a Major Plot Twist
text: WASHINGTON — This week’s news that Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, is planning to retire at the end of the year reverberated around the House of Representatives, where Mr. Miller has served since 1975.

headline: Fuchsia Would Have Killed Her
text: To please a friend, a designer with an aversion to color decided she could stomach turquoise.

headline: Just for You, Blue
text: What do you do when you love bright color but don’t want to be overwhelmed by it? Hire a designer who works almost entirely in white.

headline: A Fine Line Between Summer Sizzle and Too Darn Hot
text: As the soccer world sweats and frets at the prospect of a summer World Cup in Qatar, the rest of the sports world gets on with business at usual: making elite athletes perform in extreme heat.

headline: Illinois: Diocese Releases Papers on Abuse by Priests
text: The Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago released 6,000 pages of documents on sexually abusive priests on Wednesday to victims’ lawyers. The files pertain to 30 priests, 14 of whom are dead and all removed from ministry. Most of the abuse occurred before the mid-1990s. The archdiocese said in a statement that it “did not hide abuse or protect abusers,” and that it reported all the cases to the civil authorities. But victims’ lawyers said the documents showed a pattern of covering up. The archdiocese agreed to release the documents in 2006 during settlements with victims, but it took eight years to negotiate thedetails. The lawyers plan to release the documents next week.

headline: Obama on Surveillance Through the Years
text: Throughout his political career, President Obama has expressed a range of views on balancing national security needs with personal rights and freedoms.

headline: As Inquiry Widens, Port Authority Chief May Lose His Low Profile
text: He has been a close adviser to three New Jersey governors and was appointed state attorney general by a fourth. He was a co-founder of one of the state’s largest law firms. And for two years he has led the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Yet outside of New Jersey political and legal circles, David Samson, 74, has steadfastly maintained a low profile.

headline: How Brave Girls Helped Crack a Taboo
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — For a window into rape culture, consider an 11-year-old girl named Flevian, who says that her grandfather has been raping her almost daily since she was in the first grade.

headline: Obama’s Path From Critic to Overseer of Spying
text: WASHINGTON — As a young lawmaker defining himself as a presidential candidate, Barack Obama visited a center for scholars in August 2007 to give a speech on terrorism. He described a surveillance state run amok and vowed to rein it in. “That means no more illegal wiretapping of American citizens,” he declared. “No more national security letters to spy on citizens who are not suspected of a crime.”

headline: What Some Waiters Never See
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Solving crossword puzzles sometimes feels to me like I’m watching a magic trick being performed. If it’s a particularly clever idea, like the one we have today by Elizabeth A. Long, you might even want to applaud when you tumble to the trick or get to the reveal.

headline: School in India Ensnared in U.S. Diplomatic Spat
text: NEW DELHI — A handout for new teachers at this city’s exclusive American Embassy School, an academic oasis for children of American diplomats and other expatriates, offers some unusual guidance to female teachers whose husbands will also be teaching at the school.

headline: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions
text: JERUSALEM — Israel is on the brink of banning the N-word. N as in Nazi, that is.

headline: Corrections: January 16, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Van Is Found; Ties to Killing Are Sought
text: Investigators have located a minivan they believe may have been used to abduct a Brooklyn real estate developer who was killed this month, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Jan. 15, 2014
Los Angeles Museum Names a New Director
text: LOS ANGELES — After a six-month search that fueled intense speculation, the Museum of Contemporary Art here has confirmed that Philippe Vergne, director of the Dia Art Foundation in New York, has been chosen as its new director.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 16, 2014
text: “I’ve kept them warm when it’s cold, I’ve kept them dry when it’s wet, and I’ve fed them when they’re hungry.”

headline: A Quandary for Mexico as Vigilantes Rise
text: ANTÚNEZ, Mexico — Word spread quickly: The army was coming to disarm the vigilante fighters whom residents viewed as conquering heroes after they swept in and drove out a drug gang that had stolen property, extorted money and threatened to kill them. They even had to leave flowers and other offerings at a shrine to the gang’s messianic leader.

headline: Cuomo Has Raised Over $33 Million for Re-election Bid
text: As he prepares to seek re-election in November, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has already amassed more than $33 million to finance his bid for a second term, his campaign team said on Wednesday.

headline: Early Tallies Show Revised Charter Passing in Egypt
text: CAIRO — A revised Constitution validating the military takeover in Egypt this past summer appeared headed for lopsided approval by more than 90 percent of the votes cast, according to early tabulations in the official and private news media on Thursday, as international monitors raised alarms about the fairness of the plebiscite.

headline: Workers at an Amazon Warehouse Reject Forming a Union
text: In the first unionization vote ever held at an Amazon facility in the United States, a small group of technical workers at the company’s warehouse in Middletown, Del., voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday against forming a union.

headline: De Blasio Announces Steps to Reduce Traffic Deaths
text: Along a Queens corridor busy with traffic, Mayor Bill de Blasio took a moment on Wednesday to stand at the memorial of an 8-year-old boy killed by a turning truck steps from his school.

headline: French Leader’s Policy Proposals Seek Centrist Path
text: PARIS — President François Hollande startled the usually staid world of European economic policy with proposals to take France in a centrist direction with tax cuts for companies, reductions in public spending and a business-friendly tone.

headline: For an Immigrant, a New Home Brings Comfort but Also Isolation
text: In 2002, Yefim Zadov, then 68, came to the United States from Ukraine, looking to change a life that had deteriorated into loneliness and poor health.

headline: A 5-Foot-7 Ranger Makes Tremendous Strides
text: When Mats Zuccarello started this season with no points in seven games, there was enough consternation among Rangers coaches that he was a healthy scratch against the Philadelphia Flyers on Oct. 24.

headline: China: Success Claimed in Test of Weapons-Delivery System
text: China’s Defense Ministry said that it had successfully tested a glider that can travel many times the speed of sound, following a report in the online Washington Free Beacon. Such systems, lobbed high into the atmosphere and then guided down to a distant target, can be used to carry conventional or nuclear weapons past missile defense systems, which are designed to intercept slower missiles at lower altitudes or intercontinental ballistic missiles in space. The ministry said the system was not aimed at any specific country and gave no indication of whether China would deploy armed gliders.

headline: Notes on Blindness (Audio Description)
text: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.

headline: Notes on Blindness
text: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.

headline: Notes on Blindness
text: After the writer John Hull became completely blind, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.

headline: Steinbrenner Calls Alex Rodriguez an Asset
text: In his first public comments since Alex Rodriguez’s drug-related suspension was reduced to 162 games, Hal Steinbrenner called Rodriguez an asset and did not rule out his return to the Yankees in 2015, when his suspension is supposed to end.

headline: ‘Notes on Blindness’
text: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. This short film is a dramatization using those recordings.

headline: U.S. Olympian Explains Positive Test
text: Sarah Robles, an American Olympian who received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, said the test result was because of a hormonal precursor supplement sometimes used in the course of medical treatment for polycystic ovary syndrome. “I accept the conditions of my suspension,” Robles said.  I made a choice to take care of my health as advised by my doctor.” She said she hoped to compete for a weight-lifting spot at the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Conference Championship Probabilities, and How the Patriots Run
text: The Patriots’ running game is finally getting its due. After a 234-yard, 6-touchdown explosion to defeat the Colts in the divisional round, the New England rushing attack is suddenly in the spotlight.

headline: A Christie’s Auction Honors the Passing of a British Design Giant
text: Every now and then an auction comes along which throws light upon hidden secrets of the design world. On Jan. 22, Christie’s London will offer Michael Inchbald: A Legacy of Design, an auction of the varied estate of the talented (but in America, underappreciated) British designer who died last year at the age of 92. His career spanned nearly five decades and included many public and private commissions in the U.K. Among the most notable were the interiors of the Berkeley and Savoy Hotels and projects for the Duke of St. Albans and the filmmaker John Schlesinger (“Darling,” “Marathon Man”). Inchbald executed his interiors in diverse styles, ranging from ’60s groovy to richly baronial. Throughout all of his work, however, there are unexpected juxtapositions of objects and a deep understanding of the role of lighting to create atmosphere.

headline: Matching Jewelry Is Anything but Stuffy
text: Matching your bracelet to your necklace may sound old-fashioned. But the demi-parure — the classic coordinating jewelry set, favored by style icons like Diana Vreeland and Grace Kelly in their heyday — is making a comeback. Not long after Kate Middleton was spotted wearing the style, a host of modern collar-cuff pairings are popping up in designers’ resort collections. Saint Laurent and St. John offer subdued takes on the trend in gold and clear crystals, while Balenciaga’s stone-embroidered padded tubes feel at once organic and futuristic. Other versions look downright rock ‘n’ roll, such as Ca & Lou’s geometric shapes in rose-gold and Givenchy’s black and white stones dangling from oxidized metal chains. Whether worn with a cocktail dress or thrown atop a T-shirt for a touch of sparkle, each pair is an instant outfit-maker.

headline: An Occupy Wall Street Offshoot Has Its Day
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Officer Is Arrested in Bronx Crash
text: An off-duty police detective has been arrested in a hit-and-run crash that occurred in the western Bronx more than a year ago, the police said Wednesday.

headline: Notes on Blindness
text: After the writer and theologian John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. This film is a dramatization using those recordings.

headline: Securing the Super Bowl
text: A stretch of Broadway in Manhattan will be transformed into Super Bowl Boulevard, creating concerns in addition to those about security at the game itself.

headline: Military Opens Investigation Into Photos of Dead Iraqi Militants
text: The United States military said it had begun an inquiry after photographs that appeared to show Marines burning the dead bodies of Iraqi militants appeared on a gossip website.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) UNDER THE GUNN Auf Wiedersehen, Heidi Klum. Tim Gunn steps into hosting mode in this new competition series, in which the “Project Runway” alumni Mondo Guerra, Anya Ayoung-Chee and Nick Verreos must show off their artistic vision and business savvy — while proving themselves as mentors — as they oversee their own fashion empires with teams selected from 15 burgeoning designers. The designer Rachel Roy, the stylist Jen Rade, and Zanna Roberts Rassi, the senior fashion editor of Marie Claire, are the judges.

headline: In a Confrontation, a Secret Is Revealed
Thailand Protests Wane Despite Calls to Shut Down Bangkok
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment demonstrators marched to government offices on Thursday, but their numbers were far lower than they were earlier in the week, when they started their campaign to shut down Bangkok.

headline: World’s Biggest Annual Human Migration Begins in China
text: With a military-style precision that framed something very human and messy, the world’s biggest annual human migration – the Chinese Lunar New Year festival, known as Spring Festival – officially got under way in the first second of Thursday, Jan. 16, and will last 40 days, Chinese officials said.

headline: With $613 Million at Stake, an Albany Rivalry Is Said to Escalate
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has asked people if they think Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York State, wears eyeliner.

headline: Party Issues Rules to Curb ‘Naked’ Corruption
text: It’s official: No more “naked officials” rising in the ranks, the Chinese Communist Party has decreed.

headline: Egypt’s Crackdown Belies Constitution as It Nears Approval
text: CAIRO — A new constitution revised after the military takeover was headed to ratification by more than 95 percent of the votes cast, official Egyptian news media said Thursday, even as the authorities stepped up a crackdown on journalists and dissenters that human rights advocates said belied the charter’s promises of free speech.

headline: In Wilting Heat, Sharapova Escapes 2nd Round
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — As her match dragged more than three hours, Maria Sharapova stomped and grunted and stole glances at her box. Her face twisted into grimaces. She seemed happiest on changeovers, underneath the shade of an umbrella, an ice vest draped over the back of her neck.

headline: A Village Takes Small Steps Toward Reconciliation After Muzaffarnagar Riots
text: FUGANA, Uttar Pradesh– Four months after religious violence shattered generations of coexistence in the rural hinterland of western Uttar Pradesh, community leaders are trying to get Hindus and Muslims to talk to each other again as the first step to removing the fear and bitterness that divides villages in the Muzaffarnagar district.

headline: E-Commerce Competition Intensifies in China
text: TOKYO — An arms race between the two most powerful Internet companies in China has escalated again, with one of them, Tencent, announcing an investment that pushes it further into e-commerce — territory long controlled by its rival, Alibaba.

headline: Outspoken Uighur Scholar Detained in Beijing
text: Updated, 5:35 a.m. | A prominent Uighur economist known for his criticism of the discrimination the predominantly Muslim ethnic group faces in China has been detained by the police, his wife said.

headline: European Car Sales Ended Year on High Note, Sort Of
text: PARIS — European car sales ended 2013 on a strong note, raising hopes of a market rebound, despite another year of contraction.

headline: U.N. Panel Questions Vatican on Handling of Clergy Sexual Abuse
text: GENEVA — The Vatican faced a barrage of pointed questions from a United Nations panel on Thursday about how it had handled decades of reports of clergy sexual abuse, the first such prolonged interrogation by an international body and a moment long awaited by abuse victims in many countries.

headline: ‘Airpocalypse’ Smog Hits Beijing at Dangerous Levels
text: On Thursday, some residents of Beijing woke up with splitting headaches. A curtain of haze had fallen across the city of more than 20 million. It was the first “airpocalypse” of the year in the Chinese capital and nearby provinces, and it had come appropriately enough one year after a similar event had led to widespread anxiety.“How does the smog differ from the apocalypse?” Joe Wong, a comedian from northeast China, wrote on his microblog on Wednesday night, when the pollution levels had begun surging. “After the apocalypse, you no longer worry about the smog.”

headline: Blast in Lebanon Kills at Least 3
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden car in a town in northeastern Lebanon on Thursday, killing at least three people and wounding more than 20, Lebanon’s National News Agency reported.

headline: Jeffrey Wright’s Gold Mine
text: “This is a relationship that could bring us all the things we desire,” Jeffrey Wright said. He was sitting with Samuel Jibila under an awning rigged from rusty metal sheets in front of Jibila’s decrepit house in Sierra Leone. Jibila is the traditional ruler — the paramount chief — of Penguia, a little domain of jungly hills and dusty villages 250 miles from the capital. Wright is an actor who lives in Brooklyn. He has won a Tony, an Emmy and a Golden Globe and most recently appeared as Beetee in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.” And for the last decade, he has been traveling to this isolated area near the Guinea border to run his small gold-exploration company, Taia Lion Resources. He wanted to maintain Jibila’s faith in his company, in his plans, but Jibila, who was surrounded by lesser chiefs in glossy robes, wasn’t feeling faithful.

headline: Youth in Iran: Inside and Out
text: If Iranian youth culture was portrayed in a BBC drama, it might be called “Inside, Outside,” or even “Righteous, Raucous.” That is the duality present in Hossein Fatemi’s “An Iranian Journey,” a series that shows young people’s public modesty and piety vanishing once they escape the wary gaze of authority. These youths play music, drink, smoke, commingle and enjoy other intemperate — i.e., regular — Western activities. They are online, on Facebook, and are politically engaged and simmering, craving freer speech but stifled by the ayatollah’s rules.

headline: Word of the Day | labile
text: labile •\ˈla-ˌbi(-ə)l, -bəl\• adjective

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 16, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Program to End Homelessness Among Veterans Hits Milestone in Arizona
text: In “Program to End Homelessness Among Veterans Hits Milestone in Arizona,” Fernanda Santos reports on Phoenix’s successful effort to provide housing for all of its chronically homeless veterans.

headline: France by the Numbers
text: “You shall not crucify mankind upon a croissant d’or.” That was Alan Taylor’s response (in correspondence) to François Hollande’s embrace of Say’s law — he literally said that “supply actually creates demand” — together with a shift to, again in his own words, supply-side policies. Kevin O’Rourke also weighs in, as did Ambrose Evans-Pritchard . Mark Thoma is your go-to site for the rapidly growing avalanche of horrified snark.

headline: Times Minute | Mutts Take On Westminster
text: Also on the Minute, a widening Air Force scandal and the fate of "Alpha House."

headline: In Greece, Elites Are Starting to Feel the Pain
text: ATHENS — Since the country’s financial meltdown, Greeks have protested what many here criticize as the unfairness of the biting austerity measures that have raised taxes and trimmed salaries and benefits for average Greeks, while the elite escaped similar burdens or being held accountable for their part in creating the mess in the first place.

headline: Times Minute | Mutts Take On Westminster
text: In the Video

headline: How Much of a Priority Do You Make Sleep?
text: You may feel as if there just isn’t enough time in the day to get a good night’s sleep. To get everything done that you need and want to do, you end up going to bed too late and then waking up too early. Or you may think sleep is something you don’t mess around with, and no matter what, you make sure to get your eight hours or more every night.

headline: Trial Opens Into Killing of Lebanese Premier, Absent the Accused
text: LONDON — Almost nine years after Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister, was killed by a truck bomb, an international tribunal opened hearings into the case on Thursday in a courtroom in the Netherlands with lawyers and judges clustered around a mock-up of the crime scene on the Beirut waterfront.

headline: New York Today: Water Main Break, Day 2
text: Updated 10:08 a.m.

headline: Grabbing the Wolf's Tail
text: GARDEZ, Afghanistan — “The Taliban are still here,” a pharmacist who sells medicine to remote villages in the southeast told me last month in this shabby frontier town. “People are anxious about 2014 because the troops are leaving.”

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A School of Red Herrings
text: The Challenge: Can you figure out what is wrong with a 29-year-old former volleyball player who develops some odd aches and pains and a swollen foot?

headline: Apollo to Buy Out Chuck E. Cheese Parent for $1.3 Billion
text: It’s where “a kid can be a kid.” Can it also be where a private equity firm reaps a big return?

headline: Finding Rewards, Financial and Spiritual, in E-Waste
text: Traci Phillips, 42, started a recycling company, Natural Evolution, more than a decade ago, after realizing the hazards associated with electronic waste. Dead cellphones, dilapidated computers, broken video-game consoles and other thrown-away gadgets are laden with toxins like lead, mercury and arsenic. The United States alone produces three million tons of e-waste a year, a figure that’s expected to rise as tech companies churn out new products and consumers snap them up.

headline: Investors Turning to Riskier Investments for Returns, BlackRock Survey Finds
text: Investors looking for bigger returns are increasingly turning to riskier but potentially more rewarding opportunities like real estate and hedge funds, according to BlackRock.

headline: Carpet Bombing: How One Business Is Trying to Get Rid of Bad Reviews
text: Businesses have always lived by word of mouth, but in the old days the process was diffuse, hidden, incremental. Then Yelp kicked things up a few notches. It was bad news for bad businesses.

headline: Daily Report: No. 2 Out at Yahoo
text: Yahoo’s chief operating officer, Henrique de Castro, has been fired by his boss, Marissa Mayer, a little more than a year after she wooed him away from Google to help her turn around the struggling Internet company, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Wary Goldman Reduces Pay Ratio, Even as Profit Rises
text: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | Faced with continuing declines in one of its core businesses and an uncertain regulatory environment, Goldman Sachs is keeping a close eye on what it pays its employees.

headline: Carlyle Buys Johnson & Johnson Testing Division for $4.15 Billion
text: The private equity firm Carlyle Group said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the clinical testing division of Johnson & Johnson for $4.15 billion, its first big buyout of the year.

headline: One Good Man to Save the World
text: Say what you will about Vladimir V. Putin, but he seems to have been very, very good for screen villainy. Despite the collapse of the Soviet Union, Soviet-style skulduggery has remained a durable narrative cliché in recent movies that feature Russian bad guys doing their dastardly worst at home or abroad, from “Iron Man 2” to “Jack Reacher,” “Safe,” “A Good Day to Die Hard.” In “Kick-Ass 2,” one sadistic sicko, a former K.G.B. agent, is even called Mother Russia and wears a red bikini top with a hammer and sickle over each breast. The Ruskie heavy in “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit” played by Kenneth Branagh may be less stacked, but he’s scarcely subtler.

headline: At SAC Trial, Doctor Tells of Surprise at Ex-Trader’s Drug Trial Knowledge
text: Dr. Joel S. Ross took the witness stand for a second day at the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former hedge fund manager at SAC Capital Advisors. During his testimony, Dr. Ross told the jury of seven men and five women how Mr. Martoma knew so much detail about a confidential presentation on a clinical drug trial that Dr. Ross had attended, “it was like he was in the room with me,” Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook.

headline: A Vermeer, With a Cellphone
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Del Potro Falls, Hours After 110-Degree Heat Causes Halt in Play
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Temperatures spiked to incredible heights again at the Australian Open on Thursday, so high that play was suspended for four hours. When the day’s matches were completed early Friday, the temperature had not fallen significantly, but a title contender had.

headline: In Assam, an Idea Whose Time Has Not Yet Come
text: NEW DELHI — In Mumbai, where Jahnu Barua makes documentary films, a normal Indian lunchtime of 2 p.m. more or less corresponds to midday, when the sun is highest overhead. But when Mr. Barua goes back to his home state of Assam, especially during the winter months, the afternoon light is waning by the time lunch rolls around, and is completely gone by the time most people get out of work around 5.

headline: Citigroup’s Earnings Jump 21%, but Still Disappoint Analysts
text: Citigroup’s top executives have been asking investors to be patient with their turnaround plans.

headline: Ranking the Biggest Restaurant Leveraged Buyouts
text: Apollo Global Management’s $1.3 billion takeover of the Chuck E. Cheese’s restaurant empire means a number of things.

headline: Earnings Soar Beyond Forecast at BlackRock
text: The giant money manager BlackRock reported strong fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, as new money flowed into a wide range of its investment products.

headline: Seeking Bigger Sweet Spot, Roger Federer Hopes His Racket Will Grow on Him
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — In the obsessive, superstitious, fine-tuned realm of tennis equipment, the best players hope to fiddle least with two main pieces: their shoes and their rackets.

headline: U.N. Says Executions in Syria by Rebels May Be War Crimes
text: GENEVA — A recent series of mass executions attributed to jihadist rebels in Syria may constitute war crimes and crimes against humanity, Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, said on Thursday.

headline: In Our Pages: January 17
text: 1889: Pope Urges Monks to Sell

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: American Home Owners, Living Larger Again
text: That rattling noise you hear is the average American family moving about in the average American house, which — after a brief pause, due to the downturn — is continuing its historical march to massiveness.

headline: When Slavery and Its Foes Thrived in Brooklyn
text: Heroic terra-cotta busts of Columbus, Franklin, Shakespeare, Gutenberg, Beethoven and Michelangelo gaze down from the lovingly restored 1881 facade of the Brooklyn Historical Society, reminding the approaching visitor of what the place was once meant to represent. The founders of the society — which is now celebrating its 150th anniversary — conceived of its building in Brooklyn Heights as a repository of history that would aspire to the greatest achievements of European civilization. And why not? Brooklyn was the third-largest city in the United States, the architect was George B. Post (who later designed the New York Stock Exchange), and the society’s founders were among the elite.

headline: E. L. Doctorow: By the Book
text: The author of “Andrew’s Brain” and “Ragtime” sometimes puts down a book because he can see where the story’s going. “As you practice your craft, you lose your innocence as a reader.”

headline: Victoria & Albert Museum to Overhaul Baroque and Rococo Galleries
text: London’s Victoria and Albert Museum has announced that it will overhaul its Baroque and Rococo galleries to let in more light and better install 1,100 gems from its collection — including items designed for Marie Antoinette, Catherine the Great and Napoleon.

headline: Surprises and Snubs:  Bold Choices Like ‘Wolf’ Rewarded; Veterans Like Hanks Ignored
text: LOS ANGELES — The Academy may not be as stodgy as people thought. In its nominations it overlooked films and performances that many considered classic Oscar bait, choosing instead to reward indie films and those with bold acting and filmmaking choices.

headline: Raf Simons and the Heart of Art
text: PARIS — Color! Craft! The American flag rolled into soft sculptures framing the runway. Embroidered hands clutching the hem of a jacket. Stripes at the collar, wrists and hem of a tailored coat. And the word “Father” appearing clearly between the splatters of paint.

headline: Hurt by Slower Sales of Smartphones, Best Buy Has Bleak Holiday Results
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A slowing smartphone market and aggressive price-cutting by competitors have struck at the heart of Best Buy, the large electronics retailer.

headline: This Week’s Forecast: What Flu Season May Look Like
text: Jeffrey Shaman, an environmental health scientist at Columbia University, hopes that he and his colleagues will someday change the nightly news. “The way you get pollution reports and pollen counts on the local weather report, you could also have a flu forecast on there,” said Dr. Shaman.

headline: Formula One Chief Faces Bribery Trial
text: LONDON — A court in Munich said on Thursday that it would proceed this spring with a trial on bribery charges against Bernie Ecclestone, the 83-year-old Englishman who has been Formula One’s all-powerful overseer for more than 35 years.

headline: New Ratings Agency Hopes to Compete With Big 3 Outside U.S.
text: LONDON – Challengers have come and gone, but no viable alternative has emerged to supplant the so-called Big 3 credit rating agencies when it comes to international debt financing.

headline: Divisions in the Foreign-Language Category
text: The nominations in the best foreign language film category contain no big surprises, but have produced a divided field. Three of the nominations are from Europe, and are powered by strong individual performances from their leading actors. The remaining two are the Cambodian and Palestinian submissions and depend more on the strength of the story they tell than their cast.

headline: Probiotics May Ease Stomach Upset in Babies
text: A new clinical trial suggests that a daily dose of a probiotic may ease digestive upset in babies.

headline: Matthew McConaughey, a Nominee Who Writes His Congressman
text: LOS ANGELES — You know it’s coming: “All right, all right, all right,” Matthew McConaughey said, on the phone from Malibu moments after receiving an Oscar nomination for his performance as Ron Woodroof, the cowboy-turned-activist stricken with AIDS in “Dallas Buyers Club.”

headline: Maupin Takes Final ‘Tales’ on the Road
text: The author Armistead Maupin begins a tour this month to promote “The Days of Anna Madrigal,” the last novel in his “Tales of the City” series. First published in 1976 as a serial in The San Francisco Chronicle, the stories were praised for bringing the gay, lesbian and transgender subjects and story lines of San Francisco to the general public.

headline: Goldman Sachs Keeps a Lid on Pay
text: Goldman Sachs, a bank once famous for its rich bonuses, is clamping down on pay.

headline: Political Conflict and Art Dominate Documentary Field
text: The nominations in the best feature documentary category set up an almost Manichaean split in the field. Three of the films address various forms of political conflict, while the other two, “20 Feet From Stardom” and “Cutie and the Boxer,” take a look at overlooked artists and their relationship to the artistic process.

headline: A Hiring by Christie Raises Questions Over Cooperation
text: TRENTON — As the New Jersey Assembly voted unanimously on Thursday to authorize an investigation into abuses of power by Gov. Chris Christie’s administration, Mr. Christie seemed to be maneuvering against the inquiry, hiring a high-powered defense lawyer and resisting questions about whether he would cooperate with the Legislature’s efforts.

headline: What’s in a Name? The Equus Bass770
text: DETROIT — Equus is Latin for horse. It’s also English for a certain Hyundai model, but don’t tell that to Equus Automotive. Michael Qualid, a spokesman for the company, said that Equus didn’t know the name had been in use on Hyundai’s premier luxury model when Equus opened in 2006, but he expressed hope that the Korean automaker would not come after a niche marque over its name.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Sarabande’
text: This Poetry Pairing features “Sarabande” by Lucie Thésée and the article “Beneath Martinique’s Beauty, Guided by a Poet” by Sylvie Bigar.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Seems to Accept That Suspension Will Stand
text: Alex Rodriguez appears a step closer to accepting the likelihood that he will not be playing major league baseball in 2014. But he is also confident he will be back.

headline: Image of the Day: January 16
text: Motorists driving through thick fog on the outskirts of Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Index of Millions of New York History Records Available Free Online
text: Updated, Jan. 21

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Valentino Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: U.N. Says Lag in Confronting Climate Woes Will Be Costly
text: Nations have so dragged their feet in battling climate change that the situation has grown critical and the risk of severe economic disruption is rising, according to a draft United Nations report. Another 15 years of failure to limit carbon emissions could make the problem virtually impossible to solve with current technologies, experts found.

headline: David O. Russell Has Said His Thank-Yous
text: LOS ANGELES — “I told everybody thank you already last night,” said the director David O. Russell, whose four stars in “American Hustle” all became Oscar nominees this morning.

headline: Louis Vuitton’s Satellite View
text: PARIS — “It was digital travel — online, via satellites — NASA’s maps from outer space,” said Kim Jones, the designer of the sky blue, all-embracing runway that was the backdrop for the Louis Vuitton show on Thursday.

headline: Harvey Weinstein vs. the National Rifle Association
text: “Philomena” and “August: Osage County” did well for the Weinstein Company in the nominations, even if another of its hopefuls, “Lee Daniels’ The Butler” came away empty-handed. But Harvey Weinstein still managed to grab attention in a different way by announcing on Howard Stern’s radio show that he was joining Meryl Streep – picking up her 18th nomination, for best actress for “August” — in a secret anti-gun movie project.

headline: Louis Vuitton: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Lots of New Patients, Too Few Doctors
text: The first thing my new patient did when she walked into my office was breathe an enormous sigh of relief. “It was so hard to get this appointment with you,” she said. “It took weeks!”

headline: ‘Gravity’s’ Special Effects Flashback
text: Flashback: Britain, the mid-’70s. A teenage lad goes to visit his uncle at work and beholds before him a veritable magic shop.

headline: Facebook Rolls Out Its Version of Trending Topics
text: Facebook is finally rolling out its version of trending topics on a widespread basis — and it’s not using Twitter-style hashtags to organize them.

headline: A Game for Would-Be Deal Makers
text: For young finance professionals, an investment banking deal usually conjures up images of spreadsheets, weekend work and late-night emails from managers.

headline: Times Minute | Oscar Nominations
text: Also on the Minute, a grim climate study and a sampling of a sitzprobe.

headline: Times Minute | Oscar Nominations
text: In the Video

headline: ‘The Wolf of Wall Street,’ in the Hunt for Oscars
text: The debauched tale of Jordan Belfort’s rise and fall has prompted a lot of controversy.

headline: Sabine Heller of A Small World, on Teaching Yourself
text: This interview with Sabine Heller, chief executive of A Small World, an online travel and lifestyle community, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: How Jared Leto Did Not Get the News
text: With Los Angeles shrouded in darkness as the Oscar nominations were being announced early Thursday, Jared Leto was doing his best to pretend to sleep and wondering if perhaps his performance as the transgendered Rayon in “Dallas Buyers Club” had been overlooked.

headline: Motherlode in The Times’s Redesign
text: As I’m sure you’ve noticed, Motherlode (along with all of the other blogs at The Times) has joined the redesign, with a streamlined appearance and new navigation tools. For starters, and most importantly on a blog where reader interaction is a big part of the experience, you can pop up the comments as you read the post by clicking on the number of comments at the top of the post next to the headline. Comments still aren’t available for readers on mobile apps. (For this reason, I am considering a weekly post highlighting the best commentary.)

headline: A Veteran Returns to Gettysburg
text: Growing up just outside Gettysburg, Pa., Jessica Dickey knew from an early age that she was surrounded by a complicated history. On the roads outside her home were signs marking where the Union and Confederate troops had marched. Downtown were buildings flecked with bullet holes. “I was always so intrigued by the idea of the presence of the past, the ghosts of the past,” Ms. Dickey said.

headline: Treasury Sells $3 Billion Stake in Ally Financial
text: The Treasury Department said on Thursday that it had sold $3 billion worth of its shares in Ally Financial, bringing taxpayers’ stake in the auto lender below 50 percent.

headline: On Spying, Woes of Obama Echo Those of Past Presidents
text: WASHINGTON — In his first Inaugural Address, President Obama stirred liberals by proclaiming that “we reject as false the choice between our safety and our ideals.”

headline: A Death-Squad Leader Feels Honored
text: The director Joshua Oppenheimer was at his father’s home outside Washington, D.C., when he got the news that his documentary, “The Act of Killing,” had received an Oscar nomination in the best feature documentary category. But he wasn’t just with his family when the announcement was made: watching with him on Skype from the other side of the world were members of the Indonesian crew that at some personal risk, helped him make his ground-breaking film about the mass killings carried out by the Indonesian armed forces and paramilitary death squads in the 1960s.

headline: Amy Adams, Still a Newbie Even 5 Nominations Later
text: First of all, this is Amy Adams’s fifth Oscar nomination, and she has yet to win. Doesn’t she feel the Academy is being a little sadistic by putting her through this cycle of hype all over again?

headline: Snubs and Favorites of the Oscars Field
text: The Academy Award nominations for 2014 included a few surprises, but “American Hustle” and “Gravity” lead the field.

headline: 36 Hours in Sydney
text: In ever-sunny, easygoing Sydney, don’t let the famous attractions circling the handsome harbor consume all your attention. Focus instead on the evolving neighborhoods where art spaces are cropping up beside train tracks, and innovative, chef-driven restaurants are opening at a rapid clip. If you’re searching for flash, look to Darling Harbour, where celebrity chefs like David Chang and Luke Nguyen have opened outposts in the Star, a ritzy casino and entertainment complex that reopened in 2011 after a renovation costing around $800 million. For more discreet indulgences, seek out the diminutive drinking dens that now pepper the city, the result of a change in local liquor licensing laws that finally made business viable for small bars. Then when it’s time to dry out, the natural beauty of Australia’s most populous city will be waiting along the sandy beaches that lie just minutes from downtown. And don’t worry, you’re bound to pass a certain opera house along the way.

headline: Let’s Cease the Insults, North Korea Says to South
text: SEOUL, South Korea — For years, North and South Korea have hurled invective at each other that would do Shakespearean characters proud.

headline: Leonardo DiCaprio Didn’t Exercise His Producer’s Prerogative
text: LOS ANGELES — Leonardo DiCaprio was at home having breakfast — coffee and eggs, with tomatoes — as he discussed his multiple Oscar nominations for “The Wolf of Wall Street.”

headline: Time Warner Is Planning a Move to Hudson Yards
text: Time Warner Inc. announced on Thursday that it plans to move its headquarters from Columbus Circle to a new, 80-story skyscraper on the Far West Side of Manhattan, ensuring the development of a vast neighborhood made up of office towers, residential buildings, a shopping mall and a park, all built over a 13-acre railyard.

headline: Ford Mustang and Volvo Concept Win Design Awards
text: DETROIT — The Ford Mustang and Volvo Concept XC Coupe won the annual Eyes on Design awards presented at the Detroit auto show on Tuesday.

headline: Why It May Take More Than Former Google Stars to Turn Yahoo Around
text: The Googleization of Yahoo has hit an expensive speed bump.

headline: Free Markets, Infidelity and the President of France
text: PARIS – Is it worse to be an ardent advocate of the free market than a suspected adulterer?

headline: A Reader Behind Bars
text: I am not proud of it, but I will admit to having felt a twinge of envy when I read, over the holidays, of President Obama’s latest book purchases. How amazing would it be to have the president buy, and read, your novel?

headline: New Foundation to Focus on Publishing Art Books
text: Art books, monographs and catalogs are essential for historians, collectors and artists, but they rarely make money. Often oversized and lavishly illustrated on high-quality glossy paper, they are expensive to produce for the relatively tiny number of institutions and individuals who buy them. Enter the Artist Book Foundation, a new nonprofit organization dedicated to publishing fine-art references that otherwise would not be seen. Next month, it will release “Trucks: Recent Works by John Himmelfarb,” to accompany a new traveling exhibition of that Chicago artist’s work that opened last week at the Brauer Museum of Art at Valparaiso University in Valparaiso, Indiana.

headline: Steve Coogan Shares His Victory March
text: LOS ANGELES — Steve Coogan is playing catch-up.

headline: Today in Small Business: Name Your Own Price
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: An Osteoarthritis Primer
text: Maybe we should rewrite that quote usually attributed to Benjamin Franklin. Nothing is certain except death, taxes — and arthritis, the leading cause of disability in the United States.

headline: Deep Emotions Explored in Song
text: Many orchestras talk up the idea of adventurous programming. The Riverside Symphony, founded in 1981 by the conductor George Rothman and the composer Anthony Korf, has been putting the concept into practice for decades. This accomplished ensemble’s next program, on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, is titled “Shadow and Light” and is typically intriguing.

headline: Sally Hawkins’s Jet-Lagged Euphoria
text: The little golden man is, at this point, rather immaterial. To hear Sally Hawkins tell it, she has already won.

headline: Authorities Comb New Jersey Woodland in Hunt for Missing Reporter
text: LONG HILL TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Using all-terrain vehicles, rubber rafts and aluminum motorboats, hundreds of law enforcement officers and volunteers scoured a dense, swampy woodland in central New Jersey on Thursday in search of a Wall Street Journal reporter who went out for a walk last weekend and never returned.

headline: Clothes Inspired on Demand
text: The resourceful American Folk Art Museum continues to explore new ways of using its collection, and in particular to involve living artists in its exhibitions. Its previous attempt, last fall’s “alt_quilts,” presented quilts from its collection and the quiltlike works of three contemporary artists, with weak results. Now, the museum has turned to the fashion world in “Folk Couture: Fashion and Folk Art,” which opens on Tuesday. To explore the idea of fashion designers finding inspiration in all sorts of unexpected places, 13 New York-based designers have been invited to create garments inspired by works they select from the museum’s collection.

headline: Endurance as Art Form
text: It’s been almost two years since Sarah Michelson commandeered the fourth floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art, transforming several thousand square feet into the gleaming terrain for “Devotion Study #1 — The American Dancer.” Some audience members walked out. Others sat transfixed as Ms. Michelson’s dancers rose to the punishing task of walking backward, in circles, for a spectacularly long time, never doubting (or so it seemed) that their bodies would carry them through.

headline: Back Together After a Breakup
text: Jeff Mangum, the songwriter who leads Neutral Milk Hotel, defused some suspense with his 2011-12 solo tours. Those were his first consistent reappearances since the group quietly disbanded after touring for its beloved 1998 album, “In the Aeroplane Over the Sea,” an oblique yet impassioned set of songs inspired by thoughts of Anne Frank, with Mr. Mangum’s ceaseless strumming punctuated by jaunty trombone tunes and outbursts of distortion. Mr. Mangum stayed largely out of sight as the album’s reputation spread and solidified, but his solo concerts showed him fully in command. Now, with the band, patient fans should hear the trombone, too. Elf Power shares the bill.

headline: Guinea Worm Said to Infect Few in 2013
text: Only 148 cases of Guinea worm disease were found in the world in 2013, a 73 percent drop from the 542 cases found one year earlier, the Carter Center announced Thursday.

headline: What Was Behind All Those Whacks?
text: Christina Ricci showed early that she could play creepy: One of her first film credits is as Wednesday Addams in the 1991 movie “The Addams Family.” So the role of Lizzie Borden, the odd Massachusetts woman accused of killing her father and stepmother with an ax in 1892, seems a logical fit. “Lizzie Borden Took an Ax,” a telling of the real-life story being shown on Saturday at 8 p.m. on Lifetime, isn’t shy about speculating on what actually happened in the Borden household in Fall River that bloody August day, though that has remained in dispute for more than a century. The movie also presents the record of Lizzie’s arrest and trial, whose conclusion won’t be spoiled here for the sake of those not up on their murder history. The cast includes Billy Campbell as Lizzie’s lawyer and Clea DuVall as her sister, Emma. Also listed are credits for three “Jump Rope Girls.” You can probably guess why, though the film reminds us that the oft-chanted rhyme is inaccurate. The figures of 40 and 41 whacks are greatly inflated.

headline: Mets’ Parnell Says He’ll Be Ready for Opening Day
text: In September, as the Mets’ 2013 season was coming to a close, Bobby Parnell, the team’s closer, made a rare appearance in the clubhouse. He had been out since July with a herniated disk in his neck, and recently had surgery on it. As he visited with his teammates, he wore a big neck brace and looked thinner. Manager Terry Collins, for one, seemed worried about his appearance.

headline: Unknown No Longer
text: Until his eerie gay murder mystery, “Stranger by the Lake,” was shown last fall at the New York Film Festival, the work of the French director Alain Guiraudie was almost unknown in the United States. Concurrent with the theatrical opening of that movie, the Film Society of Lincoln Center will begin a weeklong retrospective of his work, running Friday through Jan. 30, that spans two decades.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Wheelies: The Better Efficiency Now Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Ethan Hawke, Adapted Screenplay Nominee for Original Characters
text: Question to Ethan Hawke (currently on a layover in Houston, after leaving his family on a beach in Tulum, Mexico, because he had to fly to Los Angeles to collect another movie award):

headline: Turning the Mini-Series Inside Out
text: It doesn’t get much better, in mini-series land, than the consummation of a forbidden love. The writers of “The Spoils of Babylon” liked the idea so much, they did it twice: first, in a steamy scene in a trashy San Francisco hotel room; then, with an encounter on the beach, straight out of “The Thorn Birds.”

headline: Jonah Hill Would Like to Thank Those Teeth
text: LOS ANGELES — Before he talked to the press, Jonah Hill got on the phone with his director, Martin Scorsese, and his co-star, Leonardo DiCaprio, to congratulate one another on the five nominations that their film, “The Wolf of Wall Street,” received. “It took Leo about 45 minutes to figure out how to conference us all together,” Mr. Hill said, perhaps exaggerating just a tad. “It was very sweet.”

headline: Soderbergh to Direct New Play at Public Theater
text: The Oscar-winning film director Steven Soderbergh (“Traffic”) will make his New York theater debut this spring staging the Off Broadway world premiere of a new drama, “The Library,” about the effects of gun violence on a high school student, played by the movie actress Chloe Grace Moretz (“Kick-Ass,” the 2013 remake of “Carrie”). The Public Theater, which will produce “The Library,” made the show announcement on Thursday.

headline: Letters: ‘The Trip to Echo Spring’
text: ‘Intoxicating Prose’

headline: To Sit and Sing: A Musical Tradition
text: A behind-the-scenes look at the sitzprobe for the musical “The Bridges of Madison County.” This theater tradition is the first time a show’s cast and full orchestra practice face-to-face.

headline: You’ve Got Another Chance, Broadway
text: The composer Jason Robert Brown is never happier than when surrounded by musicians. Kibitzing with the string section, directing the percussionist to feather in the high-hat more softly, poking fun at his own orchestrations, Mr. Brown, 43, was in his element on a recent Thursday at a musical theater ritual known as the sitzprobe, an evocative German term for the first time the full orchestra plays with the cast.

headline: Redefining Gender Blueprints
text: For much of his adult career, Russell Tovey has been rather famously out. But he’s built his reputation on playing it straight in British television roles like the werewolf George in “Being Human” and the slacker Steve in “Him & Her,” and as the jock Rudge in “The History Boys,” onstage in New York and London and on film.

headline: One Part Rigor, Two Parts Whimsy
text: It started with a mountain.

headline: Spreading Their Wings and Moving On
text: Stan Douglas

headline: Veggies for the Blazer Set
text: It was midweek on the Upper East Side, and the maître d’ wore a calla lily speared through a tiny braid behind his head and garlands of amulets, including one draped across his brow.

headline: Along Milan’s Streets, Color at Play
text: PHOTOS: In Milan, men battled the chill in everything from bright long coats to plaid vests and patterned wraps. For more images from street style during the Milan men’s collections.

headline: Corvex Turns Down CommonWealth Board Seat
text: A long, contentious spat between the activist hedge fund Corvex Management and CommonWealth REIT, a real estate investment trust, took another twist on Thursday, as the founder of Corvex, Keith Meister, declined an invitation to join the CommonWealth board.

headline: A Sensor Guided by Voice or Gestures
text: Microsoft wants the Xbox One to be the center of a home’s entertainment universe, providing Skype video calls and playing television shows, music and more.

headline: Musical ‘Titanic’ Headed Back to New York
text: “Titanic,” the grandly scaled Maury Yeston musical about the ill-fated luxury liner, had a rocky Broadway run in the late 1990s, finally sinking in 1999, despite having won five Tony Awards, including best musical. But the show is getting what its namesake never had: a second voyage. It is steaming back to Broadway in a new production, to be directed by Thom Southerland (who directed the show in London last year) in the fall. The casting, and production details have not been announced, but a six-week out-of-town run has been booked: the show will be staged at the Royal Alexandra Theater in Toronto from July 22 to Aug. 31.

headline: Czech Police Reveal Discovery of More Explosives in Envoy’s Residence
text: PRAGUE, Czech Republic — The police disclosed on Thursday that they had found additional explosives on Jan. 1 while investigating the explosion of a safe at a residence in Prague that  killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic.

headline: You Sleep More Than You Claim You Do
text: A couple years ago I wrote about how people don’t work nearly as many hours as they claim they do. That is, there’s a big gap between how many hours people estimate they “usually” work versus how many hours they log when asked to keep a time diary, especially for people who already keep long hours. (The typical person who reported having worked 40 hours, for example, actually worked about 37; people who claimed a usual week of 75 hours worked 50.) This discrepancy could be due to fuzzy memories, or a desire to sound more industrious, or both.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: the obesity paradox, vaccines and probiotics. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: The Gun Report: January 16, 2014
text: Gun advocates argue that more guns means a safer society. Though successful defensive gun use is rare, we reported yesterday that a Good Samaritan intervened in a stabbing at an auto parts store and shot the perpetrator.

headline: Hariri Son Discusses Assassination at Lebanon Tribunal
text: As my colleague Ben Hubbard reported, a suicide car bomber killed at least 3 people in a northeastern town in Lebanon, the latest in a string of attacks that many have interpreted as targeting groups backing opposite sides in the civil war in neighboring Syria.

headline: Judge Disallows Plan by  Detroit to Pay Off Banks
text: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a deal that Detroit had negotiated to help it move forward in bankruptcy, but he did offer some hope, saying the city could borrow $120 million it says it urgently needs to provide services to its residents.

headline: Apple and Samsung Widen Lead in U.S. Phone Market
text: Apple and Samsung Electronics, the two technology companies that make almost all the profit in the smartphone market, have grown even stronger in the United States.

headline: For Goldman in Europe, a 3rd Way to Get Paid
text: Updated, 8:44 p.m. | To navigate bonus caps in Europe, Goldman Sachs will offer a new kind of pay class for bankers in Britain and on the Continent, a person briefed on the company’s plans said.

headline: What I Miss When I’m in China (and Arizona)
text: My husband and I have a German shepherd mix named Raz that we rescued when he was a 9-month-old puppy. Today, Raz is always thrilled to go anywhere, whether it’s to the park or to visit the vet. I joke with my managers that I wish our employees jumped up and down and yodeled with joy upon arriving at our company’s office the way Raz does.

headline: Roundabout Theater Will Revive ‘Noises Off’ on Broadway
text: Roundabout Theater Company announced plans on Thursday to mount a new Broadway revival of “Noises Off,” Michael Frayn’s backstage farce about blundering British actors, as well as the Off Broadway premiere of Tom Stoppard’s 1995 play “Indian Ink.”

headline: ‘American Idol’ Keeps Sliding; Ratings Fall 22 Percent for Premiere
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Fox executives were candid about their expectations for the ratings for the premiere of the new season of “American Idol.” Several of them said the same thing here this week: We expect to be down about 20 percent.

headline: Obama Lauds Pledges to Expand College Opportunities
text: WASHINGTON — Mobilized by the Obama administration, and egged on by both the president and the first lady, scores of college presidents along with corporate and nonprofit leaders on Thursday promised initiatives and grants toward enrolling and graduating more low-income minority students.

headline: Great Music for the Great War
text: If 2013 brought the music world bicentennial celebrations of Verdi and Wagner and the centenaries of Benjamin Britten’s birth and the premiere of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” 2014 brings with it a far grimmer milestone: the 100th anniversary of the start of World War I.

headline: Raf Simons’s Colorful Collaboration With Sterling Ruby for Fall/Winter 2014
text: Last night, the Belgian designer Raf Simons and the Los Angeles artist Sterling Ruby presented their collaborative fall/winter 2014 collection in a gutted raw space just off the Place Vendome in Paris. “We have done the whole thing together,” Simons said backstage about creating the label Raf Simons/Sterling Ruby with his friend of nine years. The two met through a gallerist when Simons first purchased a piece of Ruby’s art, and collaborated several years ago on a capsule collection of denim jeans and jackets. For this one-off set of designs for the label, which was presented in place of Simons’s eponymous line, Ruby decked out the runway with his signature large-scale sculptures. Shaped like red-white-and-blue fangs dripping from the ceilings, the artwork set the scene for the colorful clothes: khaki trench coats artfully appliquéd with brightly colored fabric strips and various articles emblazoned with words like “father” and “Abu Lang,” which Ruby explained stood for the phrase “abusive language.” “We loaded a lot of things into the clothing, both in terms of iconography and also our own path,” Ruby added. The pieces spattered with color were the most literal references to their craft — a real artist’s wardrobe.

headline: A Tire That Evolves as It Wears
text: DETROIT — As your tires wear, their ability to maintain grip on wet roads diminishes with reduced tread depth. Michelin has developed a tire that counters the effects of wear with channels that grow wider, and hidden rain grooves that emerge as the tire is used, along with a special rubber compound for wet conditions.

headline: In Age of School Shootings, Lockdown Is the New Fire Drill
text: The bomb threat was just a hoax, but officials at Hebron High School near Dallas took no chances: School officials called the police and locked down the school this week. Separately, a middle school 2,000 miles away in Washington State went on lockdown after a student brought a toy gun to class.

headline: Sluggish Economy Prompts Europe to Reconsider Its Intentions on Climate Change
text: The European Union, which for years has sought to lead the world in addressing climate change, is tempering its ambitions and considering turning mandatory targets for renewable energy into just goals.

headline: With New Contract, Rex Ryan Has Security With Jets, to an Extent
text: Perhaps the most interesting aspect of Rex Ryan’s new contract with the Jets is not the extension, which was expected after management assured his return nearly three weeks ago, but rather its implications. The deal he signed on Thursday protects Ryan through at least the 2016 season. By then, the Jets will have not only made the playoffs again but won a few games there, too.

headline: A Personal Pleasure, and Eager to Share It
text: It is tempting to open a review of “The Surrender,” the staged version of Toni Bentley’s erotic memoir, with a bad joke.

headline: Remembering Amiri Baraka
text: Ben Ratliff and Harmony Holiday discuss the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist.

headline: Trips for Bikers — and Those Who Aren’t
text: Sacred Rides, a Canadian-based outfitter that focuses on single-track mountain bike tours for experienced riders, has introduced a line of Bring-Your-Partner trips that mountain bikers and their non-biking companions can enjoy together.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 19-25
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Lawmakers Weigh Aid for Detroit on Pensions
text: Opening up the delicate question of how much help the State of Michigan ought to provide its ailing largest city, state leaders are weighing whether to devote hundreds of millions of dollars to help spare the pensions of Detroit retirees, while also saving the city’s prized art collection from the risk of sale in bankruptcy.

headline: Reader Comments in the New Design
text: As you’ve no doubt noticed, The Times has redesigned its blogs, including The New Old Age. Readers accustomed to finding comments at the end of the post will discover that they have moved. You can find them now by clicking the icon above the headline of the post, next to the date and time. Alternatively, scroll down from the top of the post and click on the squarish balloon that appears at the top right corner of your browser next to the “Share” button.

headline: Beach Weekend as Drill for a Double Root Canal
text: There’s nothing quite like the romance of a summer squall at the beach. An emotional hailstorm that erupts indoors is a different matter entirely.

headline: On Times Language Use: Dwarfs, Indians and More
text: The Times is made up mostly of words (although video is coming on strong), so it’s not surprising that many of the complaints and questions that come to my office are about language use.

headline: Milestones in Marissa Mayer’s Tenure as Yahoo’s C.E.O.
text: As Yahoo’s chief executive, Ms. Mayer acquired more than 20 companies, but ultimately struggled to turn around the web pioneer.

headline: Disputing the Origins of Four-Legged Treasures
text: New York and Boston butt heads over more than sports teams: Try 18th-century walnut chairs whose origins are at the center of a controversy.

headline: Monumental Cast, but Not Much Plot
text: ANDY WARHOL was a genius, but he could be mean. He loved to make his acolytes squabble. He’d torture visitors by blaring the same pop song over and over.

headline: Baseball’s Expanded Replay Adds to Managerial Strategy
text: Tony La Russa watched about 130 games last season in his role as a special assistant to Commissioner Bud Selig. With the sharp eyes of a Hall of Fame manager, he paid close attention to plays that would need to be reviewed by video.
