text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Younger Christie and a Bridge He Wanted Kept Open
text: A crucial bridge. An anxious public. And Chris Christie at the center of it all.

headline: The Mostly Mindful Parent
text: Mindful Parenting is having a moment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza Strip and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza City, Indonesia, California and Nepal.

headline: Tortuous Trek to Something Like Normal
text: “A Long Way Gone,” Ishmael Beah’s harrowing 2007 memoir of his years as a child soldier in Sierra Leone’s brutal civil war, turned him into not just a best-selling author but also, for many, a potent symbol of hope. Here was someone who had emerged from years of murderous frenzy to write a memoir of not just uncommon horror but uncommon tenderness, topped by a smiling, open-faced author photo one reviewer called “welcome and timely reassurance” of the enduring power of humanity.

headline: Curtain Call | Men's Milan Fashion Week
text: We say goodbye to the fall/winter runway collections with this video that compiles the post-show farewells of 14 designers.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe Returning to Broadway in ‘Cripple of Inishmaan’
text: In a last-minute arrival that will qualify for this year’s Tony Awards, Daniel Radcliffe will return to Broadway in April in the title role of “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” Martin McDonagh’s black comedy about a young man with a sea of troubles who tries to become a movie star. The production, which was mounted in London last summer by the Tony Award-winning director Michael Grandage (“Red”), will begin running at the Cort Theater on April 12, less than two weeks after the closing performance of the Cort’s current double-bill, “Waiting for Godot” and “No Man’s Land.”

headline: Lingenfelter’s Custom Corvettes Blend Eras
text: Lingenfelter Performance Engineering is known for building General Motors vehicles — and occasionally some from Chrysler — that seem capable of breathing fire. The company also sells performance parts and upgrade packages.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Directors Take Divide-and-Conquer Approach
text: Updated, 4:39 p.m. | Disney heroines don’t always ride off into the sunset on a silver steed with Prince Charming. Sometimes they actually come down with …

headline: ‘Lounge’ Acts You Can Dance To
text: They may have started as homespun outfits operating off Off Broadway against long odds, but it’s now clear that institutions like Performance Space 122, Here and the Abrons Arts Center have secured their rightful place in New York’s artistic firmament, staging high-profile festivals across Manhattan.

headline: From Easy Mark to Street Fighter
text: “MOVE slowly,” the instructor cautioned as students of the Krav Maga Institute, grouped in twos, moved menacingly toward each other. “We don’t want to hit our partner.”

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Milan Men’s Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Milan Men’s Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: Facts & Figures: Paper Books, Vinyl Records
text: Via Pew Internet: Only 4 percent of readers are “e-book only.” Print is still Americans’ preferred medium for reading books.

headline: The Scramble: A Simple Greek Lunch
text: Mark Bittman and the Greek chef Diane Kochilas make strapatsada, an easy shredded-tomato-and-egg scramble.

headline: 3 Campers Linked to Fire Are Arrested in California
text: GLENDORA, Calif. — A fast-moving brush fire that erupted Thursday morning has quickly burned at least 1,700 acres of land northeast of downtown Los Angeles, county fire officials said, and fire crews worked throughout the day to contain the blaze.

headline: The Set and Its Designer, Ming Cho Lee, Take Center Stage
text: It is hard to overstate the impact Ming Cho Lee has had on the world of theater design.

headline: Reader Comments in the New Design
text: As you may have noticed, The Times has redesigned its blogs, including You’re the Boss. Readers accustomed to finding comments at the end of a post will discover that they have moved.

headline: After Tina Brown’s Exit, Daily Beast Brings In Editing Help
text: The Daily Beast has hired Noah Shachtman, a former editor at Foreign Policy and Wired, as its new executive editor and has formally elevated John Avlon to editor in chief, according to a memo Mr. Avlon wrote to the website’s staff on Thursday.

headline: Russell Johnson, the Professor on ‘Gilligan’s Island,’ Dies at 89
text: Russell Johnson, an actor who made a living by often playing villains in westerns until he was cast as the Professor, the brains of a bunch of sweetly clueless, self-involved, hopelessly naïve island castaways, on the hit sitcom “Gilligan’s Island,” died on Thursday at his home in Bainbridge Island, Wash. He was 89.

headline: Who Will Win the Foreign Language Oscar?
text: The Academy Award winners for the best foreign language film category have seemed preordained in past years, but the 2014 field has five strong nominees led by the Italian film “The Great Beauty.”

headline: Oscar Snub Is Applauded by SeaWorld Investors
text: Fans of “Blackfish,” a documentary that casts SeaWorld in a harsh light, were dismayed to learn Thursday morning that the film had not been nominated for an Academy Award.

headline: Target Tests Small Store for Urban Shoppers as Young People Pick Cities Over Suburbs
text: Target wants to be a bigger part of city living, by experimenting with going smaller.

headline: Owen Pallett in the Moment
text: When Owen Pallett was working on the musical score to accompany The Times Magazine’s Hollywood feature “Fourteen Actors Acting” in 2010, I got to see him compose right on the spot. He was on set as Solve Sundsbo filmed Matt Damon, and in the interim until Michael Douglas’s shoot later that day, Pallett watched some of the other films that had already been shot and quickly began making notes. He played some short clips of music from the Internet to give us an idea of the kinds of melodies he was thinking of. I have this memory of Pallett pacing about in the dark, cavernous studio, his pad in hand as he came up with ideas for each of the shorts. That fast-working style was partly what inspired Miki Meek, former online editor of the magazine, to suggest we work with him (indeed, he wrote all 14 scores, which were subsequently recorded by the Czech FILMharmonic Orchestra, in less than two weeks).

headline: Uptown Mingles With Downtown
text: They say the old culture-world distinction between uptown and downtown New York has vanished, but on Wednesday evening at Le Poisson Rouge, the Greenwich Village basement club, it still felt like a meeting of two disparate domains. There was delicious incongruence between the sight of Mercedes Bass, the Metropolitan Opera’s elegantly coifed vice chairwoman, and the unmistakable scent of marijuana just a few feet away.

headline: Clip: 'Visitors'
text: A scene from Godfrey Reggio’s film featuring a gorilla from the Bronx Zoo named Triska.

headline: The Source | Doug Aitken
text: Doug Aitken interviews several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.

headline: Dutch Bonanza for the Frick
text: As soon as “Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Hals: Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From Mauritshuis” opened at the Frick Collection in October, lines began stretching around the corner to Fifth Avenue from the museum’s entrance on 70th Street.

headline: A Salty, Sweet, Buttery Taste of Brittany
text: We didn’t come for the miles of shoreline, the promise of seafood feasts or the many history-rich towns. Even the dramatic views and craggy cliffs weren’t a draw. There was only one thing that lured my husband, Mahir, and me to Brittany in northwestern France: salted butter caramel candies.

headline: 1 Choreographer, 3 Works, 2 Premieres, 14 Feet and 2 Pianos (but 1 Pianist)
text: Ballet Next, the three-year-old company directed by the former American Ballet Theater principal Michele Wiles, is dedicated to presenting new choreography with live music. That’s a worthy goal, but whose choreography? The group’s New York performances have been undermined by poor choices. But on Tuesday at New York Live Arts, the company unveiled a program of three works by one choreographer: Brian Reeder. This choice was good.

headline: THE SOURCE
text: Doug Aitken’s ongoing series of conversations with the creative individuals shaping contemporary culture.

headline: A Few Pearls of the Grisly and the Mundane
text: Although it’s well-stocked with French, Dutch and Italian drawings, the Morgan Library & Museum does not have many from Spain, in part because some of the great Spanish painters, Velázquez included, worked out their ideas directly on canvas. So while the Morgan mounted a 100-piece exhibition last fall on the topic of Venetian drawings from the 18th century, its first-ever show of Spanish drawings whips through four centuries in just 25 objects.

headline: Attention, Shoppers: We’re Singing
text: The first thing you noticed was the smell. Lingering fumes attested to a black box theater at the Here Arts Center in the South Village freshly repainted white for the American premiere of “Have a Good Day!” The hourlong musical-theater work, presented on Wednesday evening as part of the Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now festival, was mounted by the Lithuanian company Operomanija, making its United States debut.

headline: ‘Brooklyn Abolitionists’
text: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Historical Society.

headline: Painting With Words, Writing With Color
text: Dahlia Elsayed thinks of the current exhibition of her paintings at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton as similar to a short-story collection. Titled “Dahlia Elsayed: Hither and Yon,” it culls a decade’s worth of work, “and each has its own beginning, middle and end,” she said, describing them as “distinct narratives.”

headline: Clip: ‘Like Father, Like Son’
text: A scene from Hirokazu Kore-eda’s film.

headline: Faith in the Early Age of Reason
text: Narrow windows sometimes afford expansive views. Consider, for example, “Piero della Francesca: Personal Encounters” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an exhibition of four small paintings made for private devotion by one of the foundational artists of the Italian Renaissance.

headline: New Snags for the Self-Employed
text: Borrowers who are self-employed may have a tougher time obtaining a mortgage under new federal regulations requiring lenders to verify applicants’ ability to repay.

headline: Moira Dryer Project
text: Eleven Rivington

headline: Julien Bismuth: ‘An image as the _______ of a surface’
text: Simone Subal

headline: ‘Stay in Love’
text: Lisa Cooley

headline: A Dealer’s Eye, and Life
text: When the history of galleries in postwar New York is written, there will most likely be a chapter devoted to Holly Solomon (1934-2002), the petite and feisty blonde who was a vivid art-world presence for nearly 40 years. In the meantime, her gallery is being revisited in “Hooray for Hollywood!,” a big, sumptuous exhibition spread between adjacent Chelsea galleries, Mixed Greens and Pavel Zoubok. The show has the added advantage of offering a relatively wide-angle view of the 1970s and the ’80s, a period that recent curatorial habit — most prominently at the Museum of Modern Art — has reduced to a depressingly thin gruel of Post-Minimalism, Conceptual art and appropriation art.

headline: After Old Mistakes, Hard Choices Must Be Made
text: The Japanese melodrama “Like Father, Like Son” turns on the kind of cruel twist — children switched at birth — that’s the stuff of tear-wringing headlines and fiction. It begins with the revelation that two 6-year-old boys were given at birth to the wrong families, which now need to decide on the best thing to do. For one set of parents, Ryota (Masaharu Fukuyama) and Midorino (Machiko Ono), a comfortably middle-class couple nestled high in a glass tower, the revelation that their only son, Keita (Keita Ninomiya), isn’t a blood relation is a blow to their tiny family. It’s also a wedge that — day by day, hurt by hurt — transforms these loving parents into sparring partners.

headline: ‘Selling the Dwelling’: ‘The Books That Built America’s Houses, 1775-2000’
text: Grolier Club

headline: Nasreen Mohamedi: ‘Becoming One’
text: Talwar Gallery

headline: Josephine Meckseper
text: Andrea Rosen Gallery

headline: Most New York Voters Are Optimistic About the Mayor, a Poll Finds
text: Two weeks into a new administration at City Hall, New York City voters are highly optimistic about Mayor Bill de Blasio and overwhelmingly endorse his plan to raise taxes on the wealthy to pay for prekindergarten, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll.

headline: No Is All You Need
text: I made a reservation for my wife and me at our favorite restaurant. We were really looking forward to it. I casually mentioned our plans to an acquaintance, and the next day, he told me he had called the restaurant, changed our reservation from two people to four. He then asked, “Would it be O.K. if we joined you?” I didn’t know what to say. I was so astonished that I agreed. But we don’t know this couple very well and soon began dreading a long night of stilted conversation. Was there any way around his maneuver? Anonymous, Louisville, Ky.

headline: Adrift Too Long, Searching for a Navigator
text: I was hurtling toward Brooklyn on the Q train, wearing cherry-red pants that hugged my hips. He was tall, bald, in his early 30s, with pale skin, tired eyes and a thin nose over a goatee. His smile was bashful, but his legs, in baggy track pants, were spread confidently on the orange seat.

headline: The Company They Kept
text: If you were young, gifted and odd, San Francisco was a good place to be in the years after World War II, when big changes were brewing in American art and culture. And that city is the setting for “An Opening of the Field: Jess, Robert Duncan, and Their Circle,” an exhibition that feels like a chunk of Bay Area turf lifted from the past and set down, untrimmed and buzzing, in New York University’s Grey Art Gallery.

headline: What the Writer Had to Edit From ‘12 Years a Slave’
text: To celebrate his Oscar nod for “12 Years a Slave,” the screenwriter John Ridley was visiting the White House on Thursday afternoon — not in a special capacity as, say, an honored guest who had penned a major film but rather as a tourist.

headline: A Performer’s Life Story Leaps ‘Over the Rainbow’
text: The singer Sam Harris, who attracted the world’s attention 31 years ago when he won the television talent contest “Star Search,” belongs to a breed of hyperkinetic entertainer and vaudevillian who has been “on” since early childhood. He is still best known for his extravagantly flowery and emotional rendition of “Over the Rainbow,” the song that capped Wednesday’s opening-night performance of his show “Ham: Slices of a Life,” at 54 Below. The show’s title is also the name of Mr. Harris’s just-published book of essays and stories.

headline: A Spectral Compound of Strange and Familiar
text: Steve Lehman got a knowing laugh Wednesday night while introducing the last piece in his first set at the Stone, a stutter-stepping workout called “Beyond All Limits.” He began by pointing out that it shared a title with a tune by the post-bop trumpeter Woody Shaw. (Perhaps you know it from the classic 1965 album “Unity,” by Larry Young.) And so, Mr. Lehman suggested, this would be a tribute of sorts to Shaw, “even though it sounds completely different.” Ha-ha, replied the crowd, conspiratorially.

headline: Model Casting Is as Distinctive to a House as Its Designs
text: It goes without saying that when putting together a fashion show, designers are as careful with casting as they are in designing their clothes. Nowhere is this more true than in Milan, where the models’ looks are as distinct as the Italian labels they’re representing.

headline: Times Minute | The New Duck-and-Cover
text: Also on the Minute, police officers sleeping on the job and playing tennis through the heat in Australia.

headline: Times Minute | The New Duck-and-Cover

headline: Adding Penthouses for Profit
text: In today’s luxury real estate market, where more is more, and consequently better, developers and their architects have been busy designing penthouse additions to affix atop buildings that they are already converting into condos.

headline: You’d Never Know the Kids Are Upstairs
text: If you’re going to make a movie about four children who are locked in their room for years because their grandfather can’t know they’re alive, the last thing you want to do is play it straight. Unfortunately, that’s the only way Lifetime knows how to play it.

headline: Tripped Up by Crises on the Path to His Opus
text: “The Angola Project,” a trilogy that unfolded on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Invisible Dog Art Center, is an intersection of places and cultures: a modern-day travelogue with stops in Lisbon, Vienna, Detroit, China, New York and, of course, Angola. Picture a tree, its leaves fallen away, to reveal a tangle of curling branches, each leading to a different story, or, in the cast of this trilogy, different sides to many stories.

headline: Window Is Opening for Change in Tax Code
text: Could this be the year that a comprehensive tax reform law is passed by Congress and signed by President Obama?

headline: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
text: Egyptian officials said on Thursday that journalists from the Al Jazeera English network detained on Dec. 29 had confessed to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, which has been declared a terrorist organization by the military-backed government that took power after the ouster in July of President Mohamed Morsi, a member of the group.

headline: A Place Where Kitsch Gets All Dressed Up in Avant-Garde Clothing
text: Seventy-five years ago, the art critic Clement Greenberg wrote the lastingly celebrated essay “Avant-Garde and Kitsch,” defining them as two opposite poles in art. Although they have always overlapped, it’s depressing how far kitsch (mass-produced or widely popular art) now masquerades as avant-garde (challenging experimentalism in art). As proof, just check out the current American Realness festival.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Jan. 17-23
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Taking Brazil’s Rhythms and Stretching Them Out
text: Brazilian popular music has few rivals anywhere for structural sophistication. That hasn’t prevented at least one cabal of experimenters from setting out to add even more intricacies. On Monday night, the third annual “Brazilian Explorative Music,” a concert organized and headlined by the songwriter Pedro Sá Moraes, brought all the members of Coletivo Chama (the Flame Collective) to S.O.B.’s. They brandished advanced ways to construct, dismantle and sometimes disrupt a piece.

headline: Advocates for Workers Raise the Ire of Business
text: As America’s labor unions have lost members and clout, new types of worker advocacy groups have sprouted nationwide, and they have started to get on businesses’ nerves — protesting low wages at Capital Grille restaurants, for instance, and demonstrating outside Austin City Hall in Texas against giving Apple tax breaks.

headline: Jazz Listings for Jan. 17-23
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: On the Trail of a Vicious Killer, Eagerly Licking Their Chops
text: A foul tale foully told, the Israeli horror flick “Big Bad Wolves” begins on a dreamy, once-upon-a-time note with three children playing hide-and-seek. As a boy counts down, two girls, one dressed in red and the other in blue, enter a derelict building. One stays, the other leaves; one dies; the other, well, who knows, much less cares, what happens to her? Certainly not the writers and directors, Aharon Keshales and Navot Papushado, for whom murdered children are just an easy, conveniently blunt and effectively faceless (and headless) means to a self-satisfied, jokey and blood-slicked end.

headline: An Exploratory Stroll Up Park Avenue
text: The proposed Park Avenue Historic District, running from 79th to 96th Street, breaks new ground in landmarks preservation. Instead of sweeping up all the little brownstones and townhouses on the side streets, the district ignores them entirely; this district is all about the multiple-family dwelling. These are the comfortable residences of the rich, just as the brownstones and townhouses were a century ago, but is that alone enough for landmark designation?

headline: Small Plates Redolent of Both Sides of the Pyrenees
text: Walk into Alain’s Wine & Tapas in Nyack and you are likely to hear Spanish guitar music playing in the background. Yet the prominent piece of art in the room is an old map not of Madrid, but of Paris (oddly, with the northern part of the city on the bottom).

headline: Exploring Emotions, Painful and Sincere
text: Longing, loving, leaving: Those are the boundaries of the melancholy, impeccable pop universe that London Grammar has built for itself. It’s a realm of quietly tolling piano chords, modestly picked guitar parts and reticent drums, all deferring to Hannah Reid’s velvety, sustained voice. “This one always makes me cry,” Ms. Reid told the audience at Baby’s All Right, a club in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night as the band started “Stay Awake.” But it was just one of the many lovelorn wishes she would sing during a set that never budged above midtempo and never had to.

text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Sea, Sky, Spray and a Love Triangle
text: “Summer in February” probably deserves some sort of award for its churning romantic atmosphere. This Edwardian period piece is set in the Lamorna artists’ colony in the southwest corner of Cornwall, England, in 1913. The painter Winslow Homer would have been hard put to match the majestic images of spindrift flying from crashing waves in a movie that might facetiously be subtitled “Early ‘Downton Abbey’ by the Sea, Manqué.”

headline: Dance Listings for Jan. 17-23
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Wiki-Validation
text: Last week I wrote a piece for this section about trying to make it into Wikipedia. When I was rejected (for lacking references and, O.K., notability) there was an outpouring of outrage and emoticon frownie faces from friends. I also received many emails from people, several well-known, about their own Wiki trials. “I have been at war with my P.R. agency over the fact that I don’t have a Wikipedia page while it feels to me that every Tom, Dick and Harry does,” said the designer Liz Lange.

headline: Q. and A. | Doug Aitken Unveils the Source, a Collective Meditation on the Nature of Creativity
text: The last time we heard from the multidisciplinary artist Doug Aitken, he was hosting Station to Station, a “nomadic happening” aboard a passenger train traveling from New York to San Francisco, which saw a diverse group of artists, musicians, writers and thinkers stage events in cities across the country. At this year’s Sundance Film Festival, he’s presenting the North American premiere of another group project that explores the nature of creativity, the Source. Several years in the making (an early version appeared in 2012 at the Tate Liverpool), it’s a series of candid four-minute video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.

headline: Italian Port Chosen as Transfer Point for Syrian Chemicals
text: The southern Italian port of Gioia Tauro, one of the busiest in Europe, will be the transfer point for hundreds of tons of the most deadly Syrian chemical weapon compounds en route to their neutralization at sea, the organization responsible for helping oversee the destruction of the arsenal announced on Thursday.

headline: Actions as Well as Prayers
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Fixed Income Drops at Some Big Banks, but Who’s to Blame?
text: Bank executives may want to blame an uncertain economic climate for steep drops in fixed income, but some analysts are questioning that rationale.

headline: Both Ends of a Sculpture Spectrum
text: The sculpture exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington starts with two 19th-century marble figures, each about two feet high, flanking the entranceway like sentinels. One, titled “Industry,” shows a man wearing a miner’s helmet and balancing an ax on his shoulder. The other, called “Commerce,” depicts a sailor leaning casually on a post. Both were made by Emma Stebbins, an American artist who also created the angel that stands atop Bethesda Fountain in Central Park.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 17-23
text: ‘Still Awake Still!’

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 17-23
text: Second annual Black Comic Book Festival (Friday and Saturday) Commentary will be as abundant as illustrations when scholars, artists and collectors gather for this free symposium at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street, Hamilton Heights. One of the earliest black superheroes to appear in mainstream comics is thought to be the Black Panther, who made his debut in Marvel’s Fantastic Four in 1966. At last year’s festival, a costumed Black Panther and Superman mingled with Khalil Gibran Muhammad, the center’s director.

text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Back to the Digital Drawing Board
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — IN less than 20 years, ubiquitous, reliable high-speed Internet access has gone from a vision to a novelty to a fundamental part of the American economy — not to mention our civic, social and personal lives.

headline: The New Midlife Crisis
text: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Los Angeles Wildfire
text: Firefighters battled the Colby fire in Glendora, Calif., which broke out just before 6 a.m. in the Angeles National Forest, about 25 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Video From U.N. Panel Grilling Vatican Officials on Abuse of Children
text: The Vatican’s former top sex crimes prosecutor told a United Nations committee on Thursday that “the Holy See gets it” when he was sharply questioned about the Roman Catholic Church’s slow response to handling cases involving clergy members’ sexual abuse of children.

headline: Domestic Workers, Foreign Tensions
text: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio, a Critic of Charter Schools, May Need Them for His Pre-K Agenda
text: As a candidate for mayor, Bill de Blasio positioned himself as a nemesis of New York’s charter schools, arguing that they had a “destructive impact” on traditional schools and should have to pay to use public classrooms.

headline: Israel and Holocaust Terms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Talk of Tighter Restrictions on Fishing Raises Questions
text: Catching spotted sea trout and flounder along the Gulf Coast is more than just a point of pride for outdoorsmen in Texas. The pastime attracts sporting fishermen from around the world, part of a renowned saltwater recreational fishing industry that adds $2 billion to the Texas economy each year.

headline: An Abused Child’s Death
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Shout-Out to Family on the Menu
text: George Echeverria is a chef and restaurateur with a track record that includes Soigné in Woodmere and Amicale in Huntington Station (both now closed); his latest venture, Eric’s Italian Bistro in Mineola, made its debut in May.

headline: Asbestos Litigation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hanging Out at McDonald’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Leadership of Citizens
text: To the Editor:

headline: India: 3rd Arrest in Rape of Danish Tourist
text: The police in New Delhi arrested a third man on Thursday in connection with the gang-rape of a 51-year-old Danish tourist, who was allegedly held at knife point for three hours by a group of men after she approached them to ask directions to her hotel in the city’s downtown. The police described the man, Bhagat Singh, 23, as a “vagabond” and said that they were still seeking five other men implicated in the attack. The woman refused to submit to a medical examination before she left India on Wednesday, but two of the suspects were carrying property they had stolen from her, the police said.

headline: Scandal in France
text: I haven’t paid much attention to François Hollande, the president of France, since it became clear that he wasn’t going to break with Europe’s destructive, austerity-minded policy orthodoxy. But now he has done something truly scandalous.

headline: Promoting Its Own Products, a Magazine Labels an Ad as News
text: CONTENT from advertisers that resembles editorial coverage, commonly called native advertising, is drawing heightened scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission, which wants to establish guidelines for labeling it clearly. Now Shape magazine has drawn a rebuke for such content from advertising regulators for an unusual case in which it served as both publisher and advertiser.

headline: Sheriff and Judge Battle Over Medical Care in Jail
text: ATHENS — In November, David Conis Jr. sat in a Henderson County courtroom, vomiting repeatedly because of his vacillating blood-sugar levels, terrified that he was facing a diabetic coma.

headline: Guy’s Guys
text: People love a man who tells it straight, the authentic stand-up guy who doesn’t have to let you know he’s that guy. Harry Truman, despite looking like the bank auditor from Bedford Falls, was that guy, and earned his nickname — Give ‘Em Hell, Harry.

headline: A Bistro Sparing Few Details
text: The name of West Hartford’s shiny new brasserie, À Vert (rough translation: “here’s to green!”), celebrates the freshness of locally sourced ingredients while wittily mirroring the name of Treva, the co-owner Dorjan Puka’s superb Italian restaurant just around the corner. A restaurant that’s half a palindrome — how cool is that?

headline: You Can Look, but to Read, You Must Write
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: In South Sudan, Some Lessons of Rwanda Learned, Others Revisited
text: UNITED NATIONS — Twenty years after Rwanda, is the United Nations any better at preventing mass atrocities?

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: In Rare Visit, Nets’ Owner Offers His Support
text: LONDON — It took several weeks for him to break his silence, and when he did, it was in London, not New York or Moscow, where he makes his home for much of the year.

headline: Reflections by America’s Buddha of Banking
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, seemed so calm during the worst hours of the 2008 financial crisis that Timothy F. Geithner, then the Treasury secretary, once described him as a central banking Buddha.

headline: Climate Aids in Study Face Big Obstacles
text: Some of the technologies cited in the latest draft report by United Nations climate experts face significant obstacles before they can be widely put in effect to limit the impact of climate change.

headline: Spending Plan Ignores Overhaul for I.M.F.
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday gave final approval to a $1.1 trillion spending bill for the current fiscal year, leaving behind what might have been the Obama administration’s best chance to overhaul the International Monetary Fund and meet its obligations to the world’s other economic powers.

headline: Under Gang’s Rule, a Mexican City Loses Hope in the State
text: APATZINGÁN, Mexico — Like the shutters closing in an old Western, the metal gates on storefronts in this town slammed shut and their owners fled as first a powerful drug gang took hold and then the federal police and soldiers arrived to restore order, stirring fears of a bloody showdown.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Thick Soles for Sleek Silhouettes
text: The recent rise of the straightforward, unadorned black lace-up shoe has accompanied the growing turn toward minimalism in men’s wear, helping to balance the proportions of an outfit. But it’s the simple shoes with a heavier, thicker sole — less a ’70s revival and more a new platform style this season — that stand out this season. In Paris, Pierre Hardy presented a beautifully refined pair of double-soled shoes in two contrasting black leathers. He explained that they weren’t quite high enough during the first round of sampling, so he had to go back to the factory for a little retooling. “We can all use a little bit of height,” he said, smiling. In Milan, the platform lace-ups at Marni were a bit chunkier, giving a little extra lift. And monochromatic polka dots were applied to some of the thick soles at Jil Sander, adding some nice surface interest and texture.

headline: Korean Community Leaders Urge McDonald’s Boycott
text: Word ricocheted around the Korean enclaves of Queens, then onto the Internet, where it was picked up by Korean news media and sent in translation to the homeland. The situation inspired television news reports, an animated parody and on Thursday culminated in a summit on a Flushing street corner calling for a boycott: all because a McDonald’s had appeared to disrespect several older Korean people who treat a neighborhood branch of the fast-food chain like their living room.

headline: Ohio Execution Using Untested Drug Cocktail Renews the Debate Over Lethal Injections
text: Dennis McGuire took 15 minutes to die by lethal injection Thursday morning at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility in Lucasville for the 1989 rape and murder of a 22-year-old pregnant woman named Joy Stewart.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Scrutiny of Freight Train Safety
text: After meeting with federal regulators on Thursday, officials from the rail and petroleum industries agreed to examine quick ways to improve the safety of freight trains carrying crude oil following a spate of fiery accidents in recent months.

headline: Once Known for a Punch, Now for Smash-Mouth Running
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The coaches at East Mississippi Community College were not quite sure what to make of LeGarrette Blount when he showed up for football practice in 2006.

headline: M.L.S. Draft: Red Bulls Select Two
text: Chris Duvall was at home in Duluth, Ga., sitting on the couch with his mother, father and grandmother when his name was called on Thursday during the second round of Major League Soccer’s draft in Philadelphia.

headline: Banks Keep Their Mortgage Litigation Reserves a Secret
text: From JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion settlement over mortgage securities to lawsuits brought by bondholders, a barrage of litigation has been raining down on Wall Street banks. Yet the banks are not disclosing a number that is crucial for assessing their ability to deal those legal costs. And, curiously, the regulator that has sway over companies’ disclosure practices has not called on the industry to reveal this important figure so that investors can weigh the institutions’ health.

headline: Bumps on a Road to Revival for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It looks as if the Google pixie dust isn’t so easy to spread around.

headline: IBM Plans Big Spending for the Cloud
text: IBM is moving rapidly on its plans to spend heavily on cloud computing. It expects to spend $1.2 billion this year on increasing the number and quality of computing centers it has worldwide.

headline: Converse All You Want, but Don’t Expect Connection
text: It can get pretty lonely for a guy in the middle of an ocean. That proposition — being pursued with intensity on screen by Robert Redford in “All Is Lost” — is also under consideration in the American premiere of “I Am the Wind,” by the Norwegian playwright Jon Fosse, at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Goalkeeper Is Top Pick in M.L.S. Draft
text: Philadelphia, which had four picks in the first two rounds, swapped places with D.C. United to acquire the No. 1 selection over all in the M.L.S. draft and chose Andre Blake, Connecticut’s goalkeeper. Blake is the first goalkeeper to be picked No. 1 in an M.L.S. draft. Chris Duvall, a defender from Wake Forest, was the top pick of the Red Bulls and the No. 22 pick over all. “We like how he gets up and down the flank,” Coach Mike Petke said.

headline: Congress Restricts Drones Program Shift
text: WASHINGTON — In an unusual move, Congress is placing restrictions on the Obama administration’s plan to shift responsibility for armed drones more toward the military and away from the C.I.A., congressional and administration officials said Thursday.

headline: The Convention and the Damage Done
text: The Republican National Convention came to New York City in 2004. The event was mostly unmarred by chaos or violence, unless you count the damage inflicted by the New York Police Department to the constitutional rights of innocent people swept up in mass arrests.

headline: Arizona Hopes New Charter Schools Can Lift Poor Phoenix Area
text: PHOENIX — In Arizona, the charter school movement has sold itself as a safe alternative for middle-class families looking to avoid the maze of underfunded neighborhood schools. The movement is now expanding into this city’s most impoverished area for the first time, starting, in effect, an experiment in urban education.

headline: Mae Young, Unladylike Wrestler Who Loved to Be Hated, Dies at 90
text: Mae Young — make that the Great Mae Young — who pulled hair and took cheap shots, who preferred actually fighting to pretending, who was, by her own account and that of many other female wrestlers, the greatest and dirtiest of them all, died on Tuesday in Columbia, S.C. She was 90, and her last round in the ring was in 2010.

headline: Breach at Neiman Marcus Went Undetected From July to December
text: The computer network at Neiman Marcus was penetrated by hackers as far back as July, and the breach was not fully contained until Sunday, according to people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Kerry Offers Assurances as Syria Talks Draw Near
text: WASHINGTON — As the Syrian opposition neared a decision on whether to attend an international peace conference next week, Secretary of State John Kerry offered a public assurance on Thursday that the Obama administration had not pulled back from its goal of establishing a transitional government that would not include President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Health Care Reform Survives a Lawsuit
text: A long-shot lawsuit that could have damaged the effectiveness of health care reform got a well-deserved brushoff from a federal district judge on Wednesday. The suit was brought with the help of conservative legal groups and cheered on by Congressional Republicans eager to disable the Affordable Care Act.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Jan. 17, 2014
text: The New York Times movie critics on “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” “Generation War” and “Big Bad Wolves.”

headline: All That Remained of 100 Elephants: A Ton of Ivory, Turned Into Trinkets
text: On a winter day in 2012, a man named John C. Fitzpatrick made his way to the fourth floor of 7 West 45th Street, to the offices of Raja’s Jewels, where he expected that he would find a cache of ivory.

headline: Contaminated Water in West Virginia
text: The chemical spill that cut off water to more than 300,000 people in West Virginia for several days has exposed serious defects in state and federal environmental protections that allow many facilities and chemicals to escape scrutiny.

headline: Blue and Gray Still in Conflict at a Battle Site
text: OLUSTEE, Fla. — There is an old saying in this state of seesawing sensibilities: The farther north you go, the farther south you get.

headline: A ‘Preventable’ Tragedy
text: The latest report on the 2012 debacle in Benghazi, Libya, where Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three others were killed in an attack on an American diplomatic mission, offers new detail and a chilling bottom line: the tragedy was “preventable.” Released in unclassified form by the Senate Intelligence Committee, the report reflects a bipartisan consensus about the tragedy that is broadly consistent with the findings of previous inquiries. Even so, it contributes to a better understanding of what happened and why and what must be done to mitigate the chances of its happening again.

headline: The Inequality Problem
text: Suddenly the whole world is talking about income inequality. But, as this debate goes on, it is beginning to look as though the thing is being misconceived. The income inequality debate is confusing matters more than clarifying them, and it is leading us off in unhelpful directions.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say Cease-Fire Deals Prove Deceptive
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — To the starving residents and rebel fighters in the bitterly contested suburbs of Damascus, the offer from the Syrian government can be tempting enough to overcome their deep mistrust: a cease-fire accompanied by the delivery of food supplies, if they agree to give up their heavy weapons and let state-run news media show the government’s flag flying over their town.

headline: Why We Like to Watch Rich People
text: Why do American television and movie audiences like to watch the antics and questionable behavior of the 1 percent?

headline: Forbidden Zone for the Police: Places Ready-Made for a Nap
text: On a police station bulletin board in Queens, the officers of the 108th Precinct can see where their bosses do not want them to go. The auto body shop and the doughnut store, for example, because of suspicions that they offered police discounts. The Irish bar around the corner is forbidden as well, because the commanding officer was wary of drunken trouble.

headline: A First Lady at 50, Finding Her Own Path
text: WASHINGTON — She has perfected a mean forehand, is working on her yoga poses, dishes with girlfriends over brussels sprouts and dirty martinis (one olive) at the Mediterranean hotspot Zaytinya, pushes her two daughters to play two sports — one of her choosing and one of theirs — and said this week that the wonders of modern dermatology, like Botox, are in the realm of possibility for her.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 17, 2014
text: “Old grudges die hard.”

headline: Unspent MetroCard Money Means Millions for M.T.A.
text: Think of it as New York’s biggest sock drawer, except that instead of nickels, dimes and quarters, what is squirreled away in its dark recesses are millions of lapsed yellow-and-blue MetroCards with digital loose change still dangling from their magnetic strips.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 16
De Blasio Names Ex-Bloomberg Official as Health Chief, but Vows New Approach
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who supported many of his predecessor’s health policies, from smoking bans to restrictions on the sale of large sugary drinks, on Thursday named a former top Bloomberg administration health official, Dr. Mary T. Bassett, as his health commissioner.

headline: A Finale of Sorts for David Stern, Who Predicts a More Global N.B.A.
text: LONDON — The Nets-Hawks game here on Thursday was also the occasion for another N.B.A. landmark, the last news conference, as he pronounced it, of David Stern’s 30-year tenure as commissioner, which will end with the 71-year-old Stern’s retirement on Feb. 1.

headline: A Bill Stokes Debate, and Doubt, on Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Its Senate sponsors describe it as a “diplomatic insurance policy” that will help President Obama cut a better nuclear deal with Iran. The White House condemns it as a deal-killer that could put the United States on a path to war.

headline: Corrections: January 17, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: With Rage, He Flails in a World Gone Deaf
text: Hey, who shut off the power?

headline: Woman Trapped in Modern Times (1920s Edition)
text: A desperate life blazes amid devouring shadows in the Roundabout Theater Company’s intensely stylish revival of “Machinal,” Sophie Treadwell’s fascinating play from 1928 about one woman’s captivity in a hell called New York City. That life is embodied by the charismatic British stage and film star Rebecca Hall, in her Broadway debut, so you can bet that it’s going to burn bright.

headline: Now, Look Here
text: Because of a production error, the crossword puzzle that was published in Friday’s print issue, by Ian Livengood, was published in error. The correct puzzle for this date, by Kevin G. Der, appeared online on Friday. The Livengood puzzle will be published online next Friday and the Der puzzle will appear in print that day.

headline: Professors Detail Brutal Tangle With Police
text: The call was a routine medical emergency, a sick man having a bad reaction to medication. But before it was over, it involved the police and led to the wrongful arrest of a City University of New York professor on the Upper West Side. And it all started with a glass of wine.

headline: Galloping Once Again Into a Rainbow Sunset
text: ‘My Little Pony’

headline: Emerging From Dark Past, and Forgiving
text: She was just 12 when she was kicked out of her mother’s house in the Bronx. She developed survival instincts, a brittle attitude and a willingness to engage in unsavory activities, for a price.

headline: Despite a Guilty Plea, a Ruling Allows a Man to Sue New York City
text: A federal appeals court ruled on Thursday that a man whose 1998 conviction for the attempted murder and attempted robbery of a Bronx livery cab driver was reversed but who later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge could still sue the city for violating his rights.

headline: British Police Arrest 2 Women in Terror Inquiry
text: British police officers, acting on intelligence information, arrested two women in London on Thursday on suspicion of terrorism offenses. One was arrested at Heathrow Airport as she was preparing to fly to Istanbul, carrying a “large quantity of cash,” the police said. The second was arrested in northwest London on charges of “suspicion of being involved in the commission, preparation and instigation of acts of terrorism.” The British are carefully monitoring citizens who are trying to travel to Syria to fight or get training with radical Islamic groups or who return from there, usually through Turkey.

headline: China: Uighur Scholar Detained
text: A Uighur scholar known for his criticism of the discrimination against Uighurs, a predominantly Muslim ethnic group, has been detained by the police, his wife said Thursday. The scholar, Ilham Tohti, a professor at Minzu University of China, was taken into custody when 30 to 40 police officers raided his Beijing apartment on Wednesday, said his wife, Guzaili Nu’er. Mr. Tohti, 44, has been one of a few intellectuals willing to speak publicly about what critics call shortcomings in the Communist Party’s management of the Uighur homeland in northwest China. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Hong Lei, said at a regular news briefing on Thursday that Mr. Tohti had been “suspected of breaking the law,” Reuters reported.

headline: Turkey: Prosecutors in Corruption Inquiry Reassigned
text: The Turkish Supreme Board of Judges and Prosecutors on Thursday reassigned 20 high-ranking prosecutors working on a corruption inquiry that has targeted the inner circle of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The reassignments included the chief prosecutor of Istanbul, who has led the inquiry, the biggest threat to Mr. Erdogan since he came to power a decade ago. It was the latest move in Mr. Erdogan’s attempt to quash the inquiry. He has called the investigation a plot against him and his party, which faces three elections in the next 18 months.

headline: Emptying a Building Long Home to Activists
text: The three-story brick building at 9 Bleecker Street in Lower Manhattan, long a celebrated bastion of countercultural activity, was in a state of transitional disarray.

headline: Christie Lawyer Is Known for His Aggressive Tactics
text: The announcement on Thursday by Gov. Chris Christie’s office that it had hired a former veteran prosecutor to help conduct its own internal review into the George Washington Bridge lane closings raised more questions than it answered about how Mr. Christie and his staff will respond to the federal and legislative inquiries into the matter.

headline: Zuccarello Provides the Difference in Another Tight Game vs. Detroit
text: The Detroit Red Wings have been rare guests at Madison Square Garden the past two decades. Now, with the Red Wings part of a revamped Eastern Conference, their red and white sweaters will appear at the Garden more often, pleasing hockey purists who relish games between Original Six opponents.

headline: Unbending at Home, Pacers Rout the Knicks
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Coach Mike Woodson expected that the Knicks would need to play what he called a “perfect” game to compete with the Indiana Pacers on Thursday night. What Woodson got from his team was not the dream scenario. Far from it, in fact.

headline: Deflating End to Last Season Inspires Ducks in Hot Start
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The roots of the Anaheim Ducks’ excellence this season penetrate deep into the soil of last year’s frustration.

headline: Coburn to Leave Senate at Year’s End
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Tom Coburn, the Oklahoma Republican known for his blunt personality and distaste for government spending, will leave office at the end of the year as he battles cancer.

headline: The Times Hires a Technology Columnist
text: The New York Times has hired Farhad Manjoo, a technology columnist at The Wall Street Journal, to write the “State of the Art” technology column that reviews new software and devices.

headline: The Real Health Care ‘War’ on the Young
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Landscapes Tainted by Asbestos
text: For the past few years, Brenda Buck has been sampling the dust blowing across southern Nevada. Until recently, she focused on the risks of airborne elements such as arsenic. But then she started noticing an oddity in her samples, a sprinkling of tiny, hairlike mineral fibers.

headline: Word of the Day | incorrigible
text: incorrigible •\(ˌ)in-ˈkȯr-ə-jə-bəl,\• adjective

headline: Sabathia and Cano Reunite, via Jay Z
text: Pitcher C. C. Sabathia became the latest professional athlete to join Roc Nation Sports, the agency that represents Robinson Cano, Sabathia’s former teammate on the Yankees. Roc Nation announced the deal Thursday and sent out a photograph of Sabathia signing his contract with Jay Z, the head of the company, which negotiated a 10-year, $240 million contract for Cano with the Seattle Mariners in free agency last month. Sabathia, a left-hander who was 14-13 last season, is signed through 2016 with a vesting option for 2017 based on the health of his left shoulder.

headline: Mayor and Speaker to Seek Further Expansion of Sick Pay
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the City Council, are set to outline plans on Friday to significantly expand the number of city businesses required to provide paid time off for sick employees, according to three people told directly of the plans.

headline: Reid Indicates His Support for Medical Marijuana
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s majority leader, Harry Reid, said Thursday that lawmakers should ease their opposition to medical marijuana, telling The Las Vegas Sun, “I think we need to take a real close look at this.”

headline: List of Smoking-Related Illnesses Grows Significantly in U.S. Report
text: WASHINGTON — In a broad review of scientific literature, the nation’s top doctor has concluded that cigarette smoking — long known to cause lung cancer and heart disease — also causes diabetes, colorectal and liver cancers, erectile dysfunction and ectopic pregnancy.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Get Their Own Pregame Show (and It’s an Early One)
text: For the last couple of years, Super Bowl advertisers have been drastically changing their decades-old strategy of keeping mum about their commercials until the spots are broadcast during the game. Instead of trying to surprise viewers, many sponsors are filling social-media platforms with previews, teasers and coming attractions in hopes of stimulating additional interest.

headline: Sweeping New Restrictions Take Aim at Protesters Camped Out in Kiev
text: The Ukrainian Parliament on Thursday pushed through sweeping legislation outlawing the installation of unauthorized tents in public spaces and imposing other new restrictions on protests that seemed aimed at authorizing the government to clear hundreds of demonstrators occupying Independence Square in Kiev, the capital.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 8 P.M. (Disney) CLOUD 9 (2014) Two ace snowboarders — Kayla Morgan (Dove Cameron), who was dropped from her competition team, and Will Cloud (Luke Benward), a former champion trying to recover after the wipeout that ended his career — become unlikely friends and training partners when Kayla is forced to work at the dog grooming shop owned by Will’s mother. Their mission: for Kayla to learn the Cloud 9, the maneuver that ended Will’s reign. In “I Didn’t Do It,” at 9:40, five teenagers — the supercompetitive twins Lindy (Olivia Holt) and Logan (Austin North, above with Ms. Holt), and their three best friends, Jasmine (Piper Curda), Garrett (Peyton Clark) and Delia (Sarah Gilman) — try to explain through flashbacks just how they wound up in weekly predicaments. The mayhem starts as the twins’ parents return from a night out to find their home covered in foam, with pizza falling from the ceiling, a goat in the living room and a missing 91-year-old babysitter.

headline: A Woman’s Liberation, a Nation’s Past
text: The story line of “Gloria,” a drama from Chile directed by Sebastián Lelio that opens Friday, is straightforward enough: The title character, divorced and lonely, with self-absorbed adult children, yearns for a companion and frequents singles events looking for one. Gingerly, she begins a romance with Rodolfo, a retired Navy officer who turns out to be a jerk, and so she is forced to decide whether she is better off alone.

headline: Cut Here, Cut There, but It’s Still 3 Hours
text: What makes a movie long?

headline: Marilyn Horne at 80, Celebrated by Fellow Stars
text: The formidable American mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne turned 80 on Thursday, and to honor her, Carnegie Hall presented a song celebration at Zankel Hall. During the prolonged ovation at the end of this sold-out event, Ms. Horne hugged and kissed all 13 artists who participated, an impressive group that featured both emerging and renowned singers, including the superstar soprano Renée  Fleming and the ageless songstress Barbara Cook.

headline: Reluctant Action Hero, Reborn
text: Someone once said, “Never trust a man with two first names,” but that wit obviously was not referring to Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst and reluctant action hero of Tom Clancy’s series of spy novels. The closest thing pop culture may have to an American James Bond, the character has appeared in four films, which were collectively rereleased in December by Paramount Home Video as “The Jack Ryan Collection.” And now he is the focus of a fifth, “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” which arrived in theaters on Friday. It turns out that every era gets a Jack Ryan to fit the times.

headline: Use of Microblogs Drops Sharply Amid Crackdown
text: The number of users of Chinese microblogs saw a sharp drop last year, as a crackdown on online speech and competition from smartphone messaging apps curtailed the popularity of services like Sina Weibo.

headline: A Conversation With: Summersalt, Band from Meghalaya
text: SHILLONG, Meghalaya — There’s no definitive theory on how Shillong, the capital of the northeastern state of Meghalaya, became known as the rock capital of India. Some say the Khasi culture of most Meghalayans has always celebrated music and is simply continuing to do so. Others cite the hymns brought by Welsh missionaries, while some point to the void created by the lack of Hindi cinema in this mostly Khasi-speaking state.

headline: Facing Tough Race, a Gandhi Isn’t Nominated for Premier
text: NEW DELHI — At a major gathering of the Indian National Congress party on Friday, Sonia Gandhi, the party’s president, announced that her son, Rahul, would not be formally nominated for the post of prime minister ahead of general elections, a decision made after prolonged deliberation within a party braced for a punishing race.

headline: Hiroo Onoda, Soldier Who Hid in Jungle for Decades, Dies at 91
text: Hiroo Onoda, an Imperial Japanese Army officer who remained at his jungle post on an island in the Philippines for 29 years, refusing to believe that World War II was over, and returned to a hero’s welcome in the all but unrecognizable Japan of 1974, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 91.

headline: In Mumbai, One Day at the Stadium, Two Strains of Cricket
text: Last Saturday, Jan. 11, Mumbai’s cricket team lost its final match of the season. The 40,000-seat Wankhede Stadium had several hundred fans in attendance. I imagine that reading this news might befuddle a foreign visitor with an interest in cricket. After all, she might remember, Mumbai’s cricket team won it all last May, in a glitzy final watched by many thousands of screaming fans. What, they’ve already run the course of another season?

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 17, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots
text: In “Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots,” Zach Schonbrun writes about the growing firepower of the ever-popular T-shirt cannon.

headline: China Unveils New Native Operating System
text: Chinese researchers have developed a new mobile operating system intended to break the dominance in China of systems produced by Google, Apple and Microsoft.

headline: Technology Is Not Driving Us Apart After All
text: In September 2008, two graduate students working for Keith Hampton, a professor at Rutgers, raised a camera atop a 16-foot tripod to film down into Bryant Park, the sprawling green space behind the main branch of the New York Public Library. They hit record, then milled about nearby pretending they had nothing to do with the rig, as it semi-surreptitiously filmed the comings and goings of hundreds of New Yorkers. The charade didn’t last. After an hour, Lauren Sessions Goulet, the more senior of the pair, found herself talking to the park’s private security force, which sent her to see their bosses, the Bryant Park Corporation. She was nervous.

headline: Welcome to Watchington
text: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: What Were the Best Movies You Saw in the Past Year?
text: The nominations for this year’s Academy Awards were announced on Thursday, and the three films with the most nominations are “American Hustle,” “Gravity” and “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Times Minute | Kerry on Syria
text: Also on the Minute, smoking even worse than you thought and Michelle Obama's 50th birthday.

headline: Shell Says Quarterly Earnings Will Fall 48%
text: LONDON — Roughly two weeks into his job, the chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell warned on Friday that the oil company’s fourth-quarter results would be lower than financial markets had anticipated.

headline: Times Minute | Kerry on Syria
text: In the Video

headline: A Muted Beginning to Sales of Apple’s iPhone Through China Mobile
text: Apple is counting on a long-awaited agreement with China Mobile, the world’s largest cellular operator, to make major headway in China. But before Apple declares any major degree of success, the technology giant may need to overcome some significant hurdles.

headline: Rise in Bird Flu Cases in China Stokes Worry Before Peak Travel Time
text: HONG KONG — China is disclosing a steadily growing number of cases of H7N9 bird flu, including four more cases announced on Friday, reviving concerns among health experts that the disease may be spreading and could pose a further threat as the world’s largest annual human migration begins ahead of Chinese New Year.

headline: New York Today: Skate City
text: Updated 10:18 a.m.

headline: Between China and Japan, a Tug-of-War Over Africa
text: Diplomatic tensions between China and Japan showed no signs of abating this past week as the two countries traded barbs over Africa.

headline: N.F.L. Conference Championship Matchups
text: Patriots at Broncos

headline: Suchitra Sen, Star of Bengali Cinema, Dies at 82
text: KOLKATA, West Bengal — The Bengali actor Suchitra Sen, who was often called India’s Greta Garbo because of her iconic performances and her reclusive ways, died Friday morning at a Kolkata nursing home after a heart attack. She was 82.

headline: Tension Rises Between Australia and Indonesia Over Migrant Patrols
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An Indonesian government official said Friday that the country would increase maritime security patrols following an admission by Australia of breaching Indonesia’s territorial waters this week during operations to repel boats carrying migrants. The announcement is the latest diplomatic row between the two countries over asylum seekers.

headline: British Regulator Steps Up Review of R.B.S. Loans
text: LONDON – A British financial regulator said on Friday that it had hired a consultant and an accounting firm to assist in its review of the Royal Bank of Scotland‘s lending practices, including claims that the bank pushed some business clients into serious financial difficulties.

headline: Laughing 'Til Death Do You Part
text: A comedy writer, Lew Schneider, and his wife, Liz Abbe, talk about how they’ve kept laughing over decades together in an interview with Dani Klein Modisett for her 2015 book “Take My Spouse, Please.”

headline: Colorful Dries Van Noten
text: PARIS — “How can we bring back color in men’s wear?” Dries Van Noten mused backstage, before sending out groups of men, tough, rough and street smart, wearing blocks of color. There were shades of pink from peony to purple; an Yves Klein blue, with inky shades; and absinthe and neon green trailing to a darker shade of moss.

headline: Take My Spouse, Please
text: After a particularly bad fight with my husband that ended with me curled up in bed in the fetal position, I thought of something people used to say during my 10 years working as a stand-up comic: “Honey, I could never do comedy. That’s the hardest thing in the world.” Burying my head deeper in the pillow, I thought: Even the worst set is over in an hour; this marriage could last a lifetime.

headline: Workers of the World, Faint!
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Just over two years ago, at the Anful Garments Factory in Kompong Speu Province, a young worker named Chanthul and 250 of her colleagues collapsed in a collective spell of fainting. They had to be hospitalized; the production line shut down.

headline: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, acknowledging that high-tech surveillance poses a threat to civil liberties, announced significant changes on Friday to the way the government collects and uses telephone records, but left in place many other pillars of the nation’s intelligence programs.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Meet Maria Contreras-Sweet: An S.B.A. Nominee With Lending Experience
text: Maria Contreras-Sweet, the woman chosen by President Obama to lead the Small Business Administration, has a long and varied résumé: corporate executive, public servant, ambassador for a host of causes.

headline: Shire to Take Loss on Dermagraft Sale
text: LONDON — The Irish biopharmaceutical company Shire has sold its skin substitute Dermagraft to Organogenesis and will record a $650 million loss on the sale.

headline: Phillip Lim Draws Inspiration From America’s West
text: PARIS — A scarf at the neck, a dashing checked jacket and a horse’s-head print on a sweater. It looked like cowboy country.

headline: Lady Gaga to Sing Again in China with ‘Artpop’
text: Lady Gaga can sing legally in China again, more than two years after her provocative lyrics and persona landed her on a government blacklist. The change of heart by the censors means her new album, “Artpop,” can be released in China.

headline: Banks Keep Mouths Shut on Litigation Reserves
text: BANKS’ LITIGATION RESERVES KEPT SECRET  |  Bracing for a barrage of legal settlements for their roles in mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis, banks have been setting aside cash to fund impending payouts. But while understanding the size of these funds, called litigation reserves, is necessary for weighing the banks’ financial strength, many banks are continuing to keep this figure secret, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook.

headline: At the Australian Open, It’s Not the Heat, It’s the Stupidity
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian Sauna Championships, disguised as a Grand Slam tennis tournament, finally ended Saturday. Advancement had depended on survival, on remaining upright, on shade and hydration and on the coolest accessory in sports, something called an ice vest.

headline: General Electric’s Industrial Segments Lift Earnings
text: General Electric is getting back to its industrial roots.

headline: U.N. Says Climate Situation Is Critical
text: And nations are dragging their feet.

headline: You Watch This Film as It Watches You
text: At the beginning of the new film “Visitors,” opening on Friday, an image fades up slowly from black. As Philip Glass’s anticipatory strings play on the soundtrack, the figure dominating the screen is gradually revealed to be a gorilla. But shown in slow motion against a black background, the magnificent animal looks as if she is solemnly posing. Barely moving, she stares right into the lens, and seemingly right into the viewer’s eyes for moments on end.

headline: Easy, Breezy, Trending
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Since 2011, when “The Oprah Winfrey Show” ended its stunning run, daytime TV has been on a desperate search for a new supreme ruler, a star capable of delivering more than enormous ratings (Dr. Phil can do that) and acting as more than a moral compass (bless you, Judge Judy). The job requires a person who can do those things while also serving as an arbiter of American pop culture.

headline: A Debt-Related Charge of $1.2 Billion Puts a Dent in the Profit of Morgan Stanley
text: Updated, 8:38 p.m. |

headline: Syria Proposes Aleppo Cease-Fire as Opposition Weighs Attending Peace Talks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government on Friday proposed a cease-fire with rebel forces in the city of Aleppo and said it was willing to exchange detainee lists with the opposition to pave the way for a possible prisoner exchange.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s China Mobile Deal Gets Off to a Weak Start
text: Apple has been counting on a long-awaited agreement with China Mobile, the world’s largest cellular operator, to reverse its fortunes in China. If the muted reception Friday, when customers were finally able to buy iPhones from China Mobile, is any indication, the companies may have to work harder to whip up enthusiasm, Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: A Missing Comb-Over, a Miffed Actor and Other Surprises
text: LOS ANGELES — In the wake of the Oscar nominations on Thursday, there are snubs and then there are head-scratchers, like how, exactly, did “American Hustle” miss its chance for makeup and hairstyling? The opening minutes of the film are a long paean to the artifice and artfulness of Christian Bale’s comb-over.

headline: Please Be Alert and Aware of Your Surroundings
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Case for a Better U
text: Unemployment has fallen a lot recently, but for a peculiar reason: not so much rising employment as a falling share of the population actively looking for work. This has sparked a debate over how much of the decline in labor force participation reflects a weak job market — why bother looking? — and how much demography, changing culture, and all that. And it looks like one of those debates that will go on, unresolved, for a long time — certainly past the point where a decisive win for one side or the other can inform policy.

headline: Givenchy: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Kolor Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Skills Practice | Persuading an Audience Using Logos, Pathos and Ethos
text: Update: Jan. 22, 2014

headline: The Glittering Crises
text: Many people have pointed out that the euro has ended up functioning a lot like the gold standard — and in so doing has replicated the “gold fetters” that many economic historians say played a big role in the propagation of the Great Depression.

headline: Remains Examined for Link to Missing Boy With Autism
text: Nearly every morning for the past 104 mornings, Avonte Oquendo’s mother, Vanessa Fontaine, has woken up to the same nightmare. But each day, she wiped away tears and pressed on in the search for her missing son, a boy with severe autism who was last seen in early October. Surveillance video showed the 14-year-old darting out of his school in Long Island City, Queens, in the middle of the day.

headline: In Our Pages: January 18
text: 1939: 25 Million Nickels Stolen

headline: Why We Talk About the One Percent
text: Many people in Washington, even those willing to concede that inequality has been rising rapidly, are uncomfortable talking about the famous 1 percent — perhaps because it sounds too populist, too much like an invitation to crowds with pitchforks. For a long time respectable discussion focused on the top 20 percent; today I see my colleague David Brooks talking about the top 5 percent.

headline: Givenchy: Basketball and Bauhaus
text: PARIS — The basketball court was framed by crisscross mesh; the lines were red neon strips. And from the first moment that a model in a tailored outfit stalked the court, followed by outfits with fiery colors licking across the chest, the result was clear: game to Givenchy.

headline: Lost in the Gallery-Industrial Complex
text: A new year. A new New York mayor. Old problems with art in New York. I have a collection of complaints and a few (very few) ideas for change.

headline: Pennsylvania Voter ID Law Struck Down as Judge Cites Burden on Citizens
text: In a strongly worded decision, a state judge on Friday struck down Pennsylvania’s 2012 law requiring voters to produce a state-approved photo ID at the polls, setting up a potential Supreme Court confrontation that could have implications for other such laws across the country.

headline: What They Said: Rahul Gandhi’s Speech at Congress Executive Meeting
text: NEW DELHI – In an unusually passionate speech at the Indian National Congress’s national meeting on Friday, Rahul Gandhi praised the governing party as the defenders of the people’s will and criticized the main opposition as being undemocratic.

headline: Barkhad Abdi Breaks the Cool Rule
text: Few veteran actors might know how to react to Amy Poehler’s admonition that “there’s such a beautiful life lesson here, everyone. Sleep with your limo driver tonight — before he gets famous.” Or Tina Fey’s offer to come to her room: “I’m talking to you, Somali pirates. I am de captain now.”

headline: Citigroup Report Urges Deal-Making, Activist Thinking
text: Citigroup has a stark message for its corporate clients: They are going to have to justify those lofty valuations.

headline: Where to Turn if You’re Shunning Sugar
text: Inspired by Daniel Engber’s recent magazine article about the challenge of creating a natural sugar substitute, readers in the comments section swapped advice about how to satisfy a sweet tooth with fewer calories, including:

headline: Reacting to a Clash Under the Golden Arches
text: Sarah Maslin Nir and Jiha Ham reported this week on a McDonald’s in Flushing, Queens, that for months has been clashing with a group of older Korean patrons.

headline: Hertz’s New Model: Revamped Rental Offices
text: The car rental company Hertz, which has 8,800 worldwide locations, is in the process of revamping several hundred of its branches to make them more user-friendly.

headline: Analysis of Obama’s N.S.A. Speech
text: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the government’s wide net of surveillance at home and abroad. Times reporters provided live analysis of the speech.

headline: James Earl Jones on Darth Vader, Mufasa and, natch, Totes McGotes
text: Your new film, “Gimme Shelter,” is the latest of more than 65 features that you’ve acted in. What’s the secret to longevity? The secret is never forgetting that you’re a journeyman actor and that nothing is your final thing, nothing is your greatest thing, nothing is your worst thing. I still consider myself a novice.

headline: Who Made That Captcha?
text: Before the presidential election in 1996, a computer company called Digital Equipment Corporation set up a website for opinion polls. There was one problem, though: Partisan hackers could use bots to fill the site with useless spam. So D.E.C. put a pixelated image of the U.S. flag at a random spot on the screen that users had to click before they registered their votes.

headline: Tough Sledding
text: There was plenty of snow in New York City for the first weekend of the year after a huge storm hit the Northeast, but sleds appear to have been in shorter supply. The best alternatives, according to the photographer Nolan Conway, who visited several parks in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens to capture the resourceful at play, were made of glossy things and included corrugated plastic and skateboards with their wheels removed. Laundry baskets, broken sleds and mats were O.K.; brown cardboard boxes, lunch trays and trash-can lids didn’t work. And in the dangerous category: sheet metal. Some with real sleds, like Anyssa Mundle, 11, seemed to enjoy using found objects just as much. “This is a check off my Christmas list,” Anyssa said. “Sledding and going in a magazine.” Julie Bosman

headline: The Mistress at the Funeral
text: My good friend just died. In the last weeks of his lucidity, he told me he absolutely wanted his mistress of many years to attend his memorial service. He relayed a few messages through me to her, as he lay dying. His wife did well in her role as caregiver, running an in-house hospice for him. But their marriage was — by his account and all available evidence — in shambles for years. His wife knew the mistress existed, and only in the waning months of his life did my friend sever the extramarital relationship (in order to die with less complexity at home). There will be a funeral, hosted by his family. The dilemma: Enact the expressed will of my friend and ensure the mistress is present or — given the wife’s emotional fragility and proneness to angry outbursts — enact my friend’s constant goal of peace and simplicity for his child. NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK CITY

headline: Reply All: The 1.5.14 Issue
text: A SPECK IN THE SEA

headline: Members of a Very Small Club
text: Last summer, I rented a house from a stranger. Her name was Robin, and when I arrived to collect the keys, she gave me a quick tutorial on the washer-dryer and showed me how to restart the router. There was an uncomfortable intimacy in seeing her space, her cats, her belongings, which I’d been hoping to avoid so I could more easily pretend the house was mine. But when she offered me a cup of tea, I accepted, mostly because I didn’t want her to change her mind about renting the house to me.

headline: Popcast: Hearing Amiri Baraka
text: Most would agree that the essence of the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist Amiri Baraka, who died last week at the age of 79, is words on paper, and the ideas resounding from the words about black art, memory, racism, class struggle and political power relationships. There’s more to it, though.

headline: Hands and Mind: Raf Simons and Sterling Ruby
text: Raf Simons has good taste in art. Mike Kelley, Paul McCarthy, Cindy Sherman, Christopher Wool and Brian Calvin are among the artists whose work he admires and in some cases owns. About 15 years ago, Mr. Simons took a break from fashion to help a Belgian businessman expand his art collection. In more recent years, art has been a keystone of his fashion. He collaborated with Mr. Calvin on some T-shirts for his Antwerp-based Raf Simons men’s label, and in February 2013, he paid brilliant homage to Surrealism in a collection for Dior, where he is creative director.

headline: Why Renters Renovate
text: After finding a two-bedroom one-bath fixer-upper in the financial district last fall, Kelly and Brandon Michon went to work ripping out musty old carpets, dated kitchen appliances and damaged flooring; they scraped away layer upon layer of paint, wallpaper and plaster that had been slapped up over the years.

headline: A Tabloid Bashing, and a Lost Job With the Mayor
text: To those following prospective appointments in City Hall, Lis Smith, a well-respected young political operative who had run Bill de Blasio’s communications effort for the last stretch of his mayoral campaign and throughout his transition, was the obvious choice to lead press operations in the new administration. In the days preceding Christmas, though, the tabloids revealed that Ms. Smith was dating Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto Embraces Pattern
text: PARIS — A splash of orchids brightening a coat, daffodils on an orange suit, blood-red roses enmeshed with snakes and flowers mingled with skulls.

headline: Presidential Policy Directive on Signals Intelligence Activities
text: President Obama released a plan for overhauling the National Security Agency’s bulk data collection program.

headline: Remapping the Territory
text: In “Our America,” Felipe Fernández-­Armesto, a British historian of Spanish heritage at the University of Notre Dame, recasts the pilgrimage of Hispanics in the United States as a rich and moving chronicle for our very present. His book navigates five centuries of painful documents, atrocious statements and dubious literature to argue that the United States was, from its beginning, as much a Spanish colonial southern enterprise as an unending march westward. After long periods of migration, deportation and accommodation, the next United States could well be a pluricultural bilingual power, updating the American dream. “Our America” is perhaps the first history to make the case for this nation’s becoming a bright Latin American country.

headline: An Evolving Field
