The lawmaker, Koichi Hagiuda of Mr. Abe’s governing Liberal Democratic Party, said it was unfair for the United States to expect Japanese leaders to refrain from visiting the Yasukuni shrine, which honors the nation’s war dead, when American politicians can freely honor their fallen soldiers. “If Japan says, ‘It’s unfavorable to pay a visit to Arlington National Cemetery,’ do they refrain from going there?” Mr. Hagiuda, a special adviser to Mr. Abe, was quoted as saying by the Kyodo News Agency. “I assume the United States will say, ‘It’s none of a foreign country’s business.’ ” Mr. Hagiuda was responding to an American government statement expressing disappointment with Mr. Abe’s visit to the controversial Shinto shrine on Dec. 26. Washington feared such a visit could anger other Asian nations, where Yasukuni is viewed as a symbol of Japan’s refusal to come to terms with its brutal 20th-century militarism because it honors all war dead, including convicted war criminals. The shrine also houses a museum that views World War II as a noble struggle by Japan to liberate Asia from white imperialism.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 17, 2014
In Small Town in Canada, Celebrating Hockey With Songs
text: LLOYDMINSTER, Alberta — Thousands of miles wide, Canada is girded by a narrow belt of population stretched thin across its vast landscape. Hockey is the common experience shared in every large city and small town along the way.

headline: Hospital Is Occupied by Protesters
text: Facing a renewed threat of a shutdown, hospital workers occupied Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn Friday afternoon as the hospital’s chief executive shut himself inside his office until the police arrived to escort him out, witnesses said.

headline: Water Is His Life, Particularly When It Starts Gushing in All the Wrong Places
text: The message came in Wednesday at 12:29 a.m.

headline: Knicks’ Dream of Home Streak Runs Into Ugly Truth
text: It was the start of a rare opportunity for the Knicks. Their game Friday night against the Los Angeles Clippers launched an eight-game homestand, their longest such stretch at Madison Square Garden since 1986. About two hours before tipoff, Coach Mike Woodson felt bold enough to float the unthinkable.

headline: A Tale of Two Protesters
text: Once captivated by the energy that stirred in the streets, activists in Egypt and Ukraine are beginning to recognize that protests are limited in creating the change they desire.

headline: Suchitra Sen, Actress Famed in Bengali Cinema, Dies at 82
text: Suchitra Sen, one of India’s best-known movie actresses, who remained famous more than 30 years after she made her last film, died on Friday in Calcutta. She was 82.

headline: Outside Convention Hall, New Cars Often Aren’t on the Mind
text: DETROIT — Inside the North American International Auto Show, the cars are the stars and the razzle-dazzle is nonstop. But outside Cobo Center, where the exhibition opens to the public on Jan. 18, a bankrupt but sometimes surprisingly optimistic city goes about its business. Here are a few scenes from outside the show:

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Showtime) SILVER LININGS PLAYBOOK (2012) Pat Solatano (Bradley Cooper, above), who has returned to the home of his parents (Jacki Weaver and Robert De Niro) after eight months in a mental institution, following a violent crime, tries to tackle the world — and reclaim his estranged wife, Nikki, who took out a restraining order against him — through a physical and psychological regimen he created while locked away. Then he meets Tiffany (Jennifer Lawrence), a heartbreaker who persuades Pat that she can circumvent the law by passing a letter from him to Nikki — if only he’ll enter a dance contest with her. Soon, she is leading, and he is following. “For all its high-flying zaniness, the movie has the sting of life, and its humor feels dredged up from the same dark, boggy place from which Samuel Beckett extracted his yuks,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this best picture Oscar nominee directed by David O. Russell, which also earned nominations for Mr. Cooper, Ms. Weaver and Mr. De Niro, and a win for Ms. Lawrence. “ ‘Silver Linings Playbook’ is crammed with people talking and shouting and weeping and also yielding to what are sometimes called boundary issues but which here turn out to be the mad, loving scrambling of people finding and saving one another,” Ms. Dargis added. “These are characters who get in one another’s faces and occasionally punch a loved one right in the kisser. They must go on, they can’t go on, but together they do.”

headline: Deadly Attack at Kabul Restaurant Hints at Changing Climate for Foreigners
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As country director for the International Monetary Fund, Wabel Abdallah spent years navigating the shoals of scandal in Afghanistan’s financial sector. Vadim Nazarov, a top political officer at the United Nations, dedicated himself over the past nine years to looking for a peaceful solution to the Afghan war. Dhamender Singh Phangurha, a British candidate in the coming elections for the European Parliament, was here on a consulting contract.

headline: A Stampede of Mourners in India Kills at Least 18
text: MUMBAI, India — At least 18 people were killed and 46 were injured in a stampede in an exclusive Mumbai enclave early Saturday morning as mourners paid their respects to a spiritual leader who died Friday.

headline: Scrambled Eggs With Tomatoes, Greek Style
text: In this Sunday’s magazine, Mark Bittman shares some recipes from Diane Kochilas, an American chef of Greek descent, and expresses relief to discover that her recipes are simpler than he had imagined. That’s certainly the case with Kochilas’s strapatsada, which can be made in five minutes.

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Comme des Garçons Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 19
text: “Looking at the rapid growth we’ve seen in bourbon over the recent years, Beam is doing a good job seizing the moment.”

headline: Orchestrating the Orecchiette
How to Suppress the Apology Reflex
text: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

headline: Craft Beer, the (Very) Limited Edition
text: Two weeks ago, a beer drinker in Fresno, Calif., called Hill Farmstead Brewery in Vermont to ask where he could buy its craft beers. “You have to drive to the airport, get a ticket, fly to Burlington, rent a car and drive an hour and a half to the brewery,” the owner, Shaun Hill, replied with a laugh. But he wasn’t joking.

headline: Advice to Customer Service: Don’t Blame the Computer
text: EMAIL: haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: A Netflix Scoreboard: 3 Emmys, a Golden Globe and a Soaring Stock
text: I confess: I’m one of those people who binged on “House of Cards” last February when Netflix released all 13 episodes in one fell swoop.

headline: A Philandering French President, a Complex Election in Egypt
text: The Middle East was much in the news these past days, with all its maddening ambiguities and conflicts on full display.

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Berluti Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: The Rationality Debate, Simmering in Stockholm
text: Are people really rational in their economic decision making? That question divides the economics profession today, and the divisions were evident at the Nobel Week events in Stockholm last month.

headline: Girish Navani, on Why Titles Don’t Matter
text: This interview with  Girish Navani, C.E.O. of eClinicalWorks, a provider of clinical information systems, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Inspecting a Student Loan Spigot
text: A few days after Christmas, ITT Educational Services, one of the nation’s largest operators of for-profit technical schools, reported some unwelcome news. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau had warned the company that it might seek penalties and remedies against it for possible student loan violations.

headline: Tackling Inequality
text: Tackling Inequality

headline: Film Gives a Peek at the Romney Who Never Quite Won Over Voters
text: SALT LAKE CITY — “Mitt,” the documentary about Mitt Romney’s failed quest for the presidency, begins on Christmas Eve 2006, with Mr. Romney, his wife, Ann, and their five sons sitting in their Park City house, weighing the pros and cons of a Romney candidacy.

headline: Rivalry Between Seattle and San Francisco Heats Up the West Coast
text: The Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers act like the N.F.L.’s fiercest rivals, which might seem strange for teams that have never met in the playoffs. Stranger still, the tension’s origins trace to five years ago, when both teams were bad and their current coaches led college programs.

headline: Yahoo’s Asian Lifeline
text: Yahoo’s core business has been eroding. It’s lost ground in display advertising and in online search, and the Wall Street consensus is that its revenue declined last year.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Rodriguez Ban Teaches Lessons, Albeit Late

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 17, 2014
text: This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss the connection between the upcoming World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, and the idea of privacy that’s been put front and center by the N.S.A. leaks and the President’s new reforms. Joe also discusses the data breach at Target, which is the subject of his column today.

headline: The Source | Paolo Soleri in Conversation With Doug Aitken
text: “Reality is a process,” says the Italian-American architect Paolo Soleri, who passed away last year at the age of 93. “So we are a tiny, tiny, tiny, tiny, little processing plant.” Soleri, who is best known for Arcosanti, his experimental planned community in the Arizona desert, talks to the artist Doug Aitken about the importance of the unknowable. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I believe this is Daniel Raymon’s first cryptic crossword puzzle published in The New York Times, and if this one is any indication, he’s got a nice cryptic career ahead of him. This was a fun one.

headline: The Myth of the Deserving Rich
text: Many influential people have a hard time thinking straight about inequality. Partly, of course, this is because of Upton Sinclair’s dictum: it’s hard for a man to understand something when his salary depends on his not understanding it. Part of it is because even acknowledging that inequality is a real problem implicitly opens the door to taking progressive policies seriously.

headline: Army’s New Rhythm
text: American soldiers are struggling to find relevance in the face of an uncertain future.

headline: In Denver, Fans Are Bullish on the Broncos, but Wary of the Patriots
text: DENVER — On a sun-splashed Friday afternoon that felt more like spring than the prelude to an A.F.C. championship game, this football-crazed city showed a self-assured calm before the storm blowing west out of New England.

headline: Eagle Scout. Idealist. Drug Trafficker?
text: Ross Ulbricht’s last moments as a free man were noisy enough to draw a crowd. Employees at the Glen Park branch of the San Francisco library heard a crashing sound and rushed to the science fiction section, expecting to find a patron had hit the floor. Instead, they found a handful of federal agents surrounding a slender 29-year-old man with light brown hair and wearing a T-shirt and jeans.

headline: Dizzying Heights, With Risks
text: KEMP, Tex. — The life of an all-terrain vehicle racer is a peripatetic one, big on low-budget adventures but small when it comes to paychecks. The best racers in the nation were here in October for the ATV Pro Challenge in Memory of Caleb Moore, which offered $30,000 in total prize money, a record for the sport. As on most weekends on the ATV tour, however, it meant that competitors shared recreational vehicles and campers as well as fuel pumps and any other part that failed.

headline: Defying Gravity
text: Extreme sports have grown in popularity, but as athletes scale the heights to became stars, debilitating injuries or death can result.

headline: Still Waiting for New Royalty in Men’s Game
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — One court on Saturday at the Australian Open provided a window into the future of men’s tennis, the possibilities and pitfalls on display.

headline: Patients’ Costs Skyrocket; Specialists’ Incomes Soar
text: CONWAY, Ark. — Kim Little had not thought much about the tiny white spot on the side of her cheek until a physician’s assistant at her dermatologist’s office warned that it might be cancerous. He took a biopsy, returning 15 minutes later to confirm the diagnosis and schedule her for an outpatient procedure at the Arkansas Skin Cancer Center in Little Rock, 30 miles away.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Clutching Men’s Bags, Big or Small
text: It’s a source of mild debate in the style-obsessed sphere whether Victoria Beckham truly originated, or at the very least popularized, the style of clutching — as opposed to toting or carrying — a leather handbag as one would a more diminutive evening style. This manner of wearing a large bag — with an arm slipped through both handles, the one hand supporting the bottom while the straps fall to the side — was surprisingly adopted by some major fashion houses for their men’s wear runway presentations. The slick dudes at Gucci looked no less manly carrying soft pastel leather bags in this fashion, nor did Tomas Maier’s athletic guys wearing the house‘s signature leather bags. At Valentino, an actual clutch replaced the large bag style, but the stylistic technique remained the same. And aside from the aesthetic affectation, this method also provides an added amount of security. It would certainly require a skilled purse snatcher to disentangle the bag from its owner.

headline: At Center Stage Again, Stephens Looks to Rise
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Sloane Stephens, one of the fastest players on the WTA Tour, is a slow starter. She has fallen behind in the first set of her first three matches at the Australian Open and won two of those sets.

headline: G.O.P. Advice for Christie: Pick a Better Team
text: On a conference call with Gov. Chris Christie’s most loyal donors a few nights ago, his brother, Todd, pressed for last-minute cash to pay for the governor’s inauguration, a daylong fete ending on Ellis Island.

headline: Rules for Equal Coverage by Employers Remain Elusive Under Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is delaying enforcement of another provision of the new health care law, one that prohibits employers from providing better health benefits to top executives than to other employees.

headline: Dior Homme: Fall 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Jan. 19
text: In a speech Friday, President Obama vowed to make significant changes to the surveillance programs, run by the National Security Agency, but included important qualifiers to his promises. The president accepted some of the recommendations from an independent panel that argued late last year for significant curbing of N.S.A. power and the imposition of more oversight. But  he left some grumbling that the overhaul will not do enough to protect civil liberties.

headline: Jersey Sponsor Threatens to Bolt Over Anelka
text: Pepe Mel, the new manager of West Bromwich Albion, is looking forward to his first match in charge when his club hosts Everton on Monday in England’s Premier League.

headline: With Plan to Overhaul Spying, the Divisiveness Is in the Details
text: WASHINGTON — The roiling debate over security and liberty did not end with President Obama’s newly announced overhaul of surveillance practices. Rather, it now enters a volatile next phase as intelligence agencies and a divided Congress try to turn principles into policy.

headline: Syrian Opposition Votes to Attend Peace Talks
text: SILIVRI, Turkey — Under intense international pressure and facing a boycott from a third of its members, the National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces voted Saturday to send a delegation to an international peace conference aimed at ending Syria’s civil war.

headline: An Interview With Mitt Romney
text: SALT LAKE CITY —  Mitt Romney’s long journey in search of the presidency began on Christmas Eve in 2006, in Park City, Utah, as he and his family considered the burdens of a presidential bid. On Friday, Mr. Romney returned to where it all started, attending the Sundance Film Festival for the premiere of “Mitt,” a 94-minute documentary chronicling both his 2008 and 2012 campaigns.

headline: Among the Best, but Having to Wait
text: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — The goal of this winter’s Olympic qualifying events in snowboarding is to find the Americans most likely to win a medal in Russia next month.

headline: Trade and the Environment
text: One of the most laudable American goals in negotiating the trade agreement known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership with 11 other countries was to strengthen environmental protections around the world. But a draft chapter of the agreement made public last week by WikiLeaks shows that many of the countries involved in the talks are trying to undermine that goal.

headline: Ann Cavoukian
text: Ann Cavoukian is the information and privacy commissioner in Ontario, Canada, and a longtime advocate of default online confidentiality. Her concept of “privacy by design,” which was developed in the 1990s and encourages embedding privacy protections in information technology and business practices, has recently gained renewed attention and proclamations of support from regulatory agencies worldwide.

headline: Peeling Away the Plastic
text: SALT LAKE CITY — IT’S hard to imagine anything more painful than going through the presidential campaign all over again with Mitt Romney.

headline: A Step Toward Restoring Voting Rights
text: Only seven months after the Supreme Court shattered the Voting Rights Act, a bipartisan group of lawmakers has come up with a bill that would go a long way toward putting it back together. If they can persuade Republicans in Congress to set aside partisanship and allow it to pass, they would begin to restore justice to a deeply damaged electoral process. It would be an ideal way to observe the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday this week.

headline: At Last, Conservative Reform
text: IN American life, political ideas that lack partisan champions are regarded suspiciously, like an attempt to cheat at cards or pay for dinner with counterfeit cash. Because we have only two parties, because those parties are ideologically disciplined, and because everyone is obsessed with the other side’s unrighteousness, there’s a sense that if you aren’t fully on board with an existing partisan agenda, you don’t have any business getting mixed up in the debate.

headline: ‘Neglected Topic’ Winner: Climate Change
text: HERE’S a scary fact about America: We’re much more likely to believe that there are signs that aliens have visited Earth (77 percent) than that humans are causing climate change (44 percent).

headline: Obama’s Homework Assignment
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA will deliver his State of the Union address on Jan. 28, but, for my money, his secretary of education, Arne Duncan, already gave it. Just not enough people heard it.

headline: For the Love of Money
text: IN my last year on Wall Street my bonus was $3.6 million — and I was angry because it wasn’t big enough. I was 30 years old, had no children to raise, no debts to pay, no philanthropic goal in mind. I wanted more money for exactly the same reason an alcoholic needs another drink: I was addicted.

headline: Disaffected Republicans
text: Readers respond to a Jan. 15 letter in which Robert L. Bryant, a lifelong Republican, decried “the choices my party has presented to me.”

headline: Thanks, Mom and Dad, for All Your Support
text: Parents’ web searches show that gender roles continue.

headline: Smoking Is Worse Than You Imagined
text: The latest surgeon general’s report on the health effects of smoking — issued at the 50th anniversary of the pathbreaking 1964 report — offers astonishing new evidence of just how much harm tobacco is causing. Despite the many gains in reducing risks over the past half-century, researchers keep finding new and insidious ways in which smoking is harming the smokers themselves and nonsmokers who breathe in toxic fumes.

headline: Google, Tell Me. Is My Son a Genius?
text: MORE than a decade into the 21st century, we would like to think that American parents have similar standards and similar dreams for their sons and daughters. But my study of anonymous, aggregate data from Google searches suggests that contemporary American parents are far more likely to want their boys smart and their girls skinny.

headline: The Cruelest Pregnancy
text: WHAT would Marlise Munoz have made of all of this?

headline: Sex and the Single Senior
text: WHAT is happening in retirement communities, assisted living facilities and nursing homes? You might imagine quiet reading, crossword puzzles, bingo, maybe some shuffleboard. Think again. Think about sex — unsafe sex.

headline: Obama, Melville and the Tea Party
text: IN 2009, shortly after Barack Obama’s successful campaign for the White House, the McNally Jackson bookstore in Manhattan organized a display of about 50 books that Mr. Obama had read as a young man. The titles were eclectic, with a good number by African-American authors, including Ralph Ellison, James Baldwin and Toni Morrison.

headline: South Sudan Recaptures Town From Rebels
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Amid signs that a cease-fire agreement could be close, the government of South Sudan said Saturday that it had won a significant military victory, recapturing the strategic town of Bor from rebel forces.

headline: You Can Tell Everybody This Is Your Song
text: FOR most of my 20s I played in the indie rock band Sleater-Kinney. We wrote songs, we recorded them, we toured. In my 30s, though, things changed. I started spending most of my time writing or working on the TV show “Portlandia.” I haven’t played many live shows in the past decade, but somehow I feel as if I’m still on tour — not just with my bandmates, but with everyone. So I thought I’d try writing a song again, so I’d have something to play.

headline: Is the Fifth Republic Burning?
text: HOUSTON — FUTURE historians of France may well decide that the Fifth Republic died as it was born: in a traffic incident.

headline: Reaching the Top at Every Rung
text: Jon Cooper has yet to coach a full season in the N.H.L., yet his Tampa Bay team is among the best turnaround stories in the league. The Lightning entered Friday in third place in the Eastern Conference after finishing last season 28th in the 30-team league.

headline: Madison’s Privacy Blind Spot
text: IN his opinion last month regarding the constitutionality of the National Security Agency’s phone-data collection program, Judge Richard Leon wrote that “James Madison, who cautioned us to beware of ‘the abridgment of freedom of the people by gradual and silent encroachments by those in power,’ would be aghast.”

headline: Lean Times for the Lakers
text: The two most decorated teams in N.B.A. history squared off Friday, but the game hardly brought back memories of Bill Russell facing Wilt Chamberlain or Larry Bird battling Magic Johnson.

headline: How I Stopped Procrastinating
text: I learned something about a year ago that I wish I’d learned much sooner. And it happened only after I woke up one morning and couldn’t walk. An X-ray revealed that my hip cartilage had made a unilateral decision to jump ship. I liked my hip cartilage. I thought we’d be together forever.

headline: A Monster of the Dunk Shows Finesse as a Playmaker
text: After the Los Angeles Clippers’ 109-95 destruction of the Knicks on Friday night, a reporter was moving through the visiting locker room, asking each Clippers player for his favorite Blake Griffin dunk.

headline: What Happens When the Poor Receive a Stipend?
text: Growing up poor has long been associated with reduced educational attainment and lower lifetime earnings. Some evidence also suggests a higher risk of depression, substance abuse and other diseases in adulthood. Even for those who manage to overcome humble beginnings, early-life poverty may leave a lasting mark, accelerating aging and increasing the risk of degenerative disease in adulthood.

headline: Celtics Banking on Rondo, for Now
text: BOSTON — In the summer of 2007, Wyc Grousbeck, a co-owner of the Boston Celtics, went for a quiet, solitary walk along a beach on Cape Cod. He had his cellphone, and when it rang, he was ready for the call and even readier for his response.

headline: Bankability Can Desert Tainted Athletes
text: In the 1990s, Alex Rodriguez starred in a commercial for Nike that looked like yet another creative campaign by the sports apparel giant. It was amusing and effective and reflected positively on Rodriguez.

headline: Iowa State’s Legacy of Fervor and Success Is Handed Down
text: AMES, Iowa — Forty-five minutes before Iowa State and Kansas tipped off last Monday, members of the Eby family, all in gold I.S.U. shirts, settled into their seats at Hilton Coliseum. Jeff Eby, who raises corn and soybeans on his 1,000-acre farm in Adel, about 40 miles southwest of here, has been coming to Cyclones men’s basketball games since he was a boy. For 2012-13, he eagerly bought season tickets.

headline: After Love Unravels in Media, Indian Politician’s Wife Is Found Dead
text: NEW DELHI — He was a smooth-talking politician from South India with an international reputation from his time at the United Nations. She was a beautiful Kashmiri from the north when they met in 2009 in middle age and began a relationship partly played out in the media, and social media, glare.

headline: Eddie the Eagle Soars With His Feet Mostly on the Ground
text: WOODCHESTER, England — It is perhaps a mild indictment of ski jumping that outside of a few countries in Europe and Asia, the two most famous jumpers are a Slovene who careened off a slope in the 1970s and a jolly Briton who finished last in the Calgary Olympic Games a quarter-century ago.

headline: Mayor of Hoboken Says Hurricane Relief Was Threatened
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — A swing through Florida proved no sunny retreat for Gov. Chris Christie on Saturday, as well-organized protesters hounded him outside a Republican fund-raiser here, a powerful ally in the New Jersey State House rebuked the governor’s office and new allegations emerged that his administration tried to intimidate a New Jersey elected official.

headline: Greek Prosecutors Focus on Corruption at the Top
text: ATHENS — Since the country’s financial meltdown, Greeks have protested what many here consider the unfairness of the austerity measures that have raised taxes and trimmed salaries and benefits for average Greeks, while the elite escaped similar burdens or being held accountable for their part in creating the mess in the first place.

headline: Readers and Climate Change
text: Thanks so much to all of you for responding to my request two weeks ago for “neglected topics” for me to weigh in on this year. There were 1,300 comments that came pouring in, many with multiple ideas, and I’m still thinking them through. Today’s column takes off on one of the suggestions that came up regularly: climate change. It’s not 100 percent neglected of course, but I think it’s vastly undercovered considering the scale of the issues. So read the column and share your thoughts below.

headline: Olden Goldies
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Hands up if you like spoonerisms. For those of you just joining us, a spoonerism is a word or phrase in which letters or syllables are swapped. That can happen with tips of the slung, sorry, slips of the tongue, and today Dan Schoenholz has spoonerized a set of seven oldies songs.

headline: Overwhelming Vote for Egypt’s Constitution Raises Concern
text: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry on Saturday raised concerns about the fairness of a referendum on Egypt’s revised Constitution after the military-led government announced that it had passed with an extraordinary 98.1 percent of the vote.

headline: Chemical Spill Muddies Picture in a State Wary of Regulations
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Here in West Virginia, residents were still reeling from the chemical spill that left more than 300,000 people without usable water for days, many of them still frightened and unsure whether official assurances that they could once again drink tap water or bathe their children were true.

headline: Region Boiling, Israel Takes Up Castle Strategy
text: JERUSALEM — After a Katyusha rocket fired from Lebanon landed in Israel last month, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Hezbollah, the Shiite militia, and its Iranian backers. But Israeli security officials attributed the attack, as well as a similar one in August, to a Sunni jihadist group linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: After Years at War, the Army Adapts to Garrison Life
text: FORT DRUM, N.Y. — Spec. Perez Brown Jr. spent three years in the Army and two tours in Afghanistan, where on his 23rd birthday a homemade bomb blew up a vehicle in his convoy and he came close to driving over another one just down the road. “That second one might have been for me,” he said.

headline: ‘Bachelor’ Star’s Comments on Gays Spark Uproar
text: PASADENA, Calif. — ABC faced a potential crisis on Saturday over one of its longest-running hits when a storm erupted here over homophobic comments made by the star of the reality series “The Bachelor.”

headline: De Blasio Picks Mark Peters, a Former Prosecutor, to Oversee Investigations
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Saturday that he had picked a respected former prosecutor and civil rights lawyer to fill the top position at the city’s Department of Investigation, an anticorruption agency that will soon take on an expanded role in overseeing the New York Police Department.

headline: Jamaican Bobsledders Seek Money for Sochi Trip
text: With a little bit of perseverance, Jamaica’s Winston Watts has appeared to qualify as a bobsled pilot at next month’s Olympics. Without a little bit of money, though, the latest edition of the Jamaican bobsled team might not actually appear in the Sochi Games.

headline: Torn Between Higher Taxes and Border Hassles
text: LAREDO —  Braving the unusually cold temperatures one recent afternoon, Aurelia Alcantar crossed the Puente de las Américas international bridge from Mexico into this South Texas town. She was going shopping, and crossing the border let her avoid a recent tax increase in her hometown, Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas.

headline: It’s Here: A Library With Nary a Book
For Cubs Fans, Everlasting Hope With Dread to Match
text: CHICAGO — A legion of die-hard Cubs fans converged here at a downtown hotel this weekend for the team’s annual fan convention. They were children and adults, wearing blue-and-red jerseys, hats and face paint, armed with baseball cards, pennants and posters to be autographed.

headline: Run for Speaker as a Marker for Republicans
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: A Consultant Who Stumped for Cruz Makes a Bid for Congress
text: In 2012, Katrina Pierson was crisscrossing Texas in her spare time to help Ted Cruz become the state’s next United States senator. At Republican club meetings, public rallies and on Twitter, she praised Mr. Cruz’s tenacity and commitment to repealing the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Determined to Miss Nothing, Russia Trains All Eyes on Sochi
text: SOCHI, Russia — This may now be the safest city in Russia.

headline: Strong Showing for U.S. at Youth Championships
text: The vitality of the United States’ scholastic chess programs was on display last month at the World Youth Chess Championships in the United Arab Emirates, where 94 Americans took to the boards.

headline: The Surprise Wedding
text: When guests arrived at what they were told was Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Spiegel’s engagement party, they found the space decorated for a wedding.

headline: Remembering Amiri Baraka With Politics and Poetry
text: Amiri Baraka’s funeral began with a wordless tribute on Saturday morning: A procession of African drums and jazz trumpets followed the writer’s coffin through Newark Symphony Hall.

headline: After Cancer, Tour Guide Plans Next Destination
text: Name a place, and Edicson Valderrama, international tour guide, will give you the story.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 18, 2014
Building Faces Wrecking Ball. So Does Couples’ Friendship.
text: As in any fight between longtime friends, there are raw emotions, tarnished memories, tears.

headline: Ex-Official Claims to Speak for Sidelined Syrians
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — For years, Jihad Makdissi was the urbane, outward-looking face of the Syrian government, proclaiming its views in perfect English as the Foreign Ministry’s spokesman. Then, about a year ago, he resigned and fled here, withdrawing his support from President Bashar al-Assad without throwing it to the opposition, quietly waiting, he said, for his chance to be of use.

headline: In Syria, Former Official Says, ‘Nobody Is Winning’
text: The following are excerpts from an interview with Jihad Makdissi, a former Foreign Ministry spokesman in Syria who fled in 2012 as the government of President Bashar al-Assad cracked down on antigovernment protesters. Mr. Makdissi, however, has not supported the rebels. He casts himself as a voice for the Syrians who remain on the sidelines, skeptical of the armed uprising but still wanting change.

headline: Arnold R. Pinkney Dies at 83; Steered 1984 Jesse Jackson Run
text: “There are always more slaves than slave masters,” the Rev. Jesse Jackson roared in a speech in Selma, Ala., early in his 1984 presidential campaign. “We can win! We got master’s degrees in disappointment and Ph.D.s in how to overcome!”

headline: Chryssa, Artist Who Saw Neon’s Potential as a Medium, Dies at 79
text: Chryssa, a Greek-born American sculptor who in the 1960s was one of the first people to transform neon lighting from an advertising vehicle into a fine art medium, died on Dec. 23. She was 79.

headline: Roy Campbell Jr., Avant-Garde Jazz Trumpeter, Dies at 61
text: Roy Campbell Jr., who carried the soulful swagger of hard-bop trumpet into the jazz avant-garde, of which he became a pillar, died on Jan. 9 at his home in the Bronx. He was 61.

headline: ‘American Hustle’ Wins SAG Award for Top Film

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 19, 2014
text: “It may be better to wait and see, but waiting doesn’t make you money. It’s ‘Let me do a little snip of tissue’ and then they get professional, lab and facility fees. Each patient is like an ATM machine.”

headline: Caitlin Homberger, Nicholas Green

Rebecca Cline and Gary W. Cline of New Haven. The Rev. Maria LaSala, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Dwight Hall Chapel at Yale University in New Haven.

headline: Serena Williams Tumbles in Australian Open’s Fourth Round
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — For almost a year, Serena Williams won professional tennis matches at an improbable 96 percent clip. Since her exit from the 2013 Australian Open, she had played 80 matches and had won 77 of them.

headline: Deadly Bomb Blast Rocks Pakistan Military Compound
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A bomb exploded inside a vehicle at a Pakistani military compound in the country’s northwest on Sunday, killing at least 20 members of a paramilitary unit and wounding 30 more, a security official said.

headline: What’s On Today?
text: 1:30 P.M. (Showtime2) AMÉLIE (2001) Audrey Tautou, above, in her breakthrough role, plays a French sprite working as a waitress who lays out elaborate practical jokes as payback for those who offend her friends. When she falls in love with Nino (Mathieu Kassovitz), Amélie finds herself incapable of revealing her feelings and instead turns Paris, recreated through sets and computer-generated imagery, into a kind of treasure hunt as she leaves clues about her identity, and he trails after her. Writing in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell called this comedy from Jean-Pierre Jeunet, whose original title was “Le Fabuleux Destin d’Amélie Poulain,” “a sugar-rush of a movie.” It has, he said, “a hypnotic sense of romance; it’s a fable filled with longing, with a heroine who constantly flirts with failure.” The film’s “fastidious complex of flesh and fantasy is a dazzling achievement,” he added. There is no denying, he said “that ‘Amélie’ is, to paraphrase its title, fabulous.”

headline: Europe’s Dominance Faces a Challenge in a FIFA Bid

But on Monday, Champagne, a Frenchman who once served as FIFA’s deputy general secretary, is set to become front-page news in Switzerland and beyond.

headline: When Elite Parents Dominate Volunteers, Children Lose
text: One long-ago day my mother took cupcakes to school wearing a pale yellow coat — not warm enough for the winter day, but she wanted to look nice. A classmate admired her. I was a little proud. I hoped to impress this classmate, or anyone. My dad was an alcoholic. A friend with a similar childhood calls it “impoverished.” I lacked currency: cash or social sway.

headline: Punk Hangs In There

headline: UI, the NAIRU, and the ZLB
text: I see from Mark Thoma that Chris Dillow is doing battle with the usual idiots suspects, who are once again accusing me of hypocrisy or something for saying that increased unemployment benefits would, under current conditions, reduce unemployment. “But your textbook says that UI raises unemployment!”

headline: The Pope and Chris Christie

So it was with today’s Times report on the internal recommendations Chris Christie has been getting within the GOP. Quoted at some length was a guy named Ken Langone:

headline: 1914: A Map of Tango
text: “This is the map of the kingdom of king Tango. The white parts indicate countries it has subjected to his law. The black parts show those who do not recognize his sovereignty yet. We have, otherwise, marked with a black spot the French cities where bishops have forbidden the faithful to dance tango in their diocese.” — The New York Herald, Paris Edition, Jan. 20, 1914 (From Le Matin)

headline: Lanvin: The Sum of All Looks
text: PARIS — How rare it is to find a show that has everything: slim tailoring, high tech fabrics, colorful accessories, arty drawings, covetable sneakers — and an overall look that sums up men’s wear today.

text: PARIS — Walking into the Turkish designer Umit Benan’s show here, his first in Paris after several seasons in Milan, you noticed that the set resembled a soccer pitch in slight disrepair, an effect accentuated by the chain link fence separating the audience from the runway, parts of it torn away, as if by age or neglect.

headline: Four Traffic Fatalities in Two Days As Mayor Vows to Make Streets Safer
text: A large highway sign flashed orange warnings to pedestrians. Patrol officers in neon vests directed traffic; others gave tickets to drivers and nearly a dozen jaywalkers. And at each corner of West 96th Street and Broadway on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Sunday, residents warned one another to use caution: The traffic here can be deadly.

headline: A Fast Start for ‘Ride Along’ at the Box Office
text: The action comedy “Ride Along” burned rubber at North American theaters, taking in a projected $47.8 million for the four-day Martin Luther King Jr. holiday and leaving another new film, “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” choking on its fumes. “Ride Along” (Universal Pictures), featuring Ice Cube and the increasingly popular Kevin Hart, cost about $25 million to make and continues a winning streak at the box office for movies with predominantly black casts. About 50 percent of opening-weekend ticket buyers were black, with Hispanic moviegoers making up 30 percent, according to Universal.

headline: Chris Chataway, British Runner and Politician, Dies at 82
text: Chris Chataway, a British runner who helped Roger Bannister achieve the first sub-four-minute mile, then broke world records himself before becoming a member of Parliament and a cabinet minister, died on Sunday in London. He was 82.

text: Helen Gao writes an occasional column on overseas education for cn.nytimes.com, the Chinese-language website of The New York Times. This piece is adapted from a column published shortly after the Lunar New Year in 2013.

headline: Poor Mummy, Tossed Around and Then Stashed in a Closet
text: The comic payoffs arrive only sporadically in the new production of Joe Orton’s “Loot” at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Those deliciously perverse epigrams whiz through the air, and the corpse of a beloved wife is frantically hauled about a parlor like a medicine ball being flung around at a gym. But the deadpan style that best serves these antics often slips into a kind of winking archness that announces an awareness of the inspired lunacy of it all. The production, directed by Jesse Berger for the Red Bull Theater, hits its marks with an air of studied effort that tends to put the brakes on the mayhem.

headline: Gold and Survival, Yes, but Scripts and Stars, Too
text: Scan the “our shows” section of Discovery Channel’s website, and it becomes clear that someone in the executive department is obsessed with cold weather, survival and gold. “Frozen Planet,” “Yukon Men,” “Alaska: The Last Frontier,” “Gold Rush,” “Bering Sea Gold” and more are there.

headline: A Little Help From a Friend of Buttercup
text: Very soon now, the airwaves will be jammed with remembrances of the Beatles’ first appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show,” because there’s nothing the baby-boom generation likes better than commemorating 50th anniversaries. If you stare hard enough at the clips of those screaming young female fans from February 1964, you can see an unspoken question in their eyes: “Will one of these guys, in 2014, be singing a song aimed at my grandchildren or even my great-grandchildren about dressing up as a superpower-endowed little girl?”

headline: Tunefully Purveyed Snake Oil, Anyone?
text: On Jan. 7, two days before the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Bartlett Sher’s 2012 production of Donizetti’s “L’Elisir d’Amore” was scheduled to open, the company announced that the soprano Anna Netrebko had the flu and would not perform the role of Adina. Curiously, the announcement specified that Ms. Netrebko, probably the most celebrated soprano in opera right now, would miss the first two performances but planned to return for the third. Singers grappling with an illness usually cannot anticipate how long their incapacity will last.

headline: Tipping a Hat to Country Music Pioneers
text: If there were an appropriate emoji ideogram for the Bristol Sessions, the 1927 recordings that helped start the framing of what we now know as country music, it wouldn’t be a cartoon face conveying anger, sadness or gratitude — nothing that simple. It might be one of the lesser-known ones: the image of Japanese-carp wind socks on a flagpole, the flags flown on Children’s Day in Japan representing high hopes to navigate the currents of an uncertain life and grow up with health and courage.

headline: Repertory of Mandolin Is in Motion
text: Pianists can spend a lifetime learning a vast established repertory, but a greater degree of creativity is essential for double bassists, trumpeters or mandolinists hoping for careers in the spotlight.

headline: Where Guitars Sound Like Orchestras or Brawling Geese
text: When the guitarists Fred Frith and Nels Cline played their first public duet on Saturday night at Subculture, it didn’t always sound like guitar music. It sounded, at times, like a sanitation truck’s trash compactor, like an orchestra tuning up, like a brawl between flocks of geese, like a creaky water pump, like a collapsing carillon and like a slowed-down train wreck.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 20
text: GATHERING IN DAVOS The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, will begin with a ceremony on Tuesday evening. World leaders scheduled to attend the forum include Shinzo Abe, prime minister of Japan; David Cameron, prime minister of Britain; Benjamin Netanyahu, prime minister of Israel; and Hassan Rouhani, president of Iran. The United States will be represented by Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary; Penny Pritzker, secretary of commerce; and Gina McCarthy, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who will discuss President Obama’s climate action plan. This year’s celebrity in residence is Matt Damon, who will receive an award for his charitable work. Some of the speeches and panels will be posted on the forum’s website, weforum.org.

headline: He’s Hard as Nails, Hard to Nail Down, Too
text: Tucked away at the end of Gabriel Sherman’s disingenuous Roger Ailes biography, there is a note on sources that should have opened the book. Mr. Sherman has done a lot of interviewing, but there are so many citations of “author interview with a person familiar with the matter” that “The Loudest Voice in the Room” may set a record for blind items and the untrustworthiness they engender. It would have helped to know right from the get-go why Mr. Sherman found this kind of journalism necessary.

headline: Paramount Takes Step With Digital Film
text: Paramount Pictures became the first major Hollywood studio to stop delivering movies on 35-millimeter film in the United States, offering them only in digital format, The Los Angeles Times reported. The change reflects a shift toward use of digital projection. Only about 8 percent of about 40,045 United States theaters screens are equipped to show movies only in a film format, according to the National Association of Theater Owners, The Los Angeles Times said. Statistics compiled by the Motion Picture Association of America showed that the number of nondigital screens in the United States dropped to 6,387 by the end of 2012, from 33,319 in 2008. The last Paramount picture delivered to some theater owners in a film format was “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues,” The Times reported. Many of the remaining film-only screens are in small towns, where owners have been hard pressed to afford a conversion.

headline: Repeated Phrase

headline: Fifty States of Fear
text: The British philosopher Bertrand Russell, writing as World War II was drawing to a close in Europe, observed that “neither a man nor a crowd nor a nation can be trusted to act humanely or to think sanely under the influence of a great fear.” Russell’s point was that irrational fear can propel us into counterproductive activities, ranging from unjust wars and the inhumane treatment of others to more mundane cases like our failure to seize opportunities to improve our everyday lives.

headline: In a City on Okinawa, Mayor’s Re-election Deals a Blow to Marine Base Relocation Plan

headline: Reviving a Life Saver, the Tourniquet
text: As far back as Alexander the Great’s campaigns, tourniquets were wartime staples, used to stanch the bleeding of wounded soldiers. But they became a last resort for both military and civilian emergency personnel after World War II, when medical experts blamed the prolonged cutoff of blood for frequent amputations.

headline: ‘China’s Web Junkies’
text: Compulsive Internet use has been categorized as a mental health issue in many countries, including the United States, but China was among the first to label “Internet addiction” a clinical disorder.

headline: Brazil’s Latest Clash With Its Urban Youth Takes Place at the Mall
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The images have already been so jolting to Brazil’s elites that President Dilma Rousseff has convened a meeting of top aides to form a response and business owners have obtained injunctions to shut them down: thousands of teenagers, largely from the gritty urban periphery and organizing on social media, going on raucous excursions through shopping malls.

headline: Confident Nets Spoiling for Rematch With Knicks
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Their rivalry is still just budding, but the Nets are hoping to use an embarrassing loss to the Knicks last month as fuel when the teams meet for the second time this season, Monday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Proposed Abortion Restrictions in Spain Face Backlash
text: MADRID — Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy’s proposal to enact some of the toughest abortion restrictions in Europe has exposed his already unpopular government to a building political backlash and criticism from the European Parliament, while reinvigorating his Socialist opponents and opening divisions in his own conservative Popular Party.

headline: Hasbro Gives Its Transformers Toys a New Look
text: When Hasbro conceived its Transformers toy line 30 years ago, the concept was simple: robots that turned into vehicles faster than you could say “more than meets the eye.”

headline: Life as a Female Journalist: Hot or Not?
text: LOS ANGELES — IN 2009, I wrote a cover story for Wired magazine about the anti-vaccine movement and profiled Paul Offit, a leading proponent of vaccines for children. Dr. Offit is a man. I am a woman. That was sufficient grounds for things to get ugly.

headline: Many Choices for Tanaka With Deadline Approaching
text: Masahiro Tanaka’s baseball fate will be decided by Friday afternoon, and it appears that more than a half-dozen teams have made bids for him or are prepared to. The Yankees, the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Arizona Diamondbacks, the Chicago White Sox and the Chicago Cubs are said to be among the teams in hot pursuit of Tanaka, a Japanese right-handed pitcher.

headline: Fixing Disability Courts
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — IT’S hard to imagine a more cynical fraud. According to an indictment unsealed last week by the Manhattan district attorney’s office, post-9/11 phobias of airplanes and skyscrapers were among the fictitious ailments described by retired New York City police officers and firefighters who, in a scheme involving as many as 1,000 people, are accused of ripping off the Social Security disability system by filing false claims.

headline: Trying to Salvage Garbage Time
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When the Knicks played the Nets on Dec. 5 at Barclays Center, the game presented the rare opportunity for Carmelo Anthony to watch the final minutes of a blowout win from the bench. He enjoyed the experience.

headline: The ‘How Are You?’ Culture Clash
text: “WHEN an American asks me this question, it’s like a wall of ice crashing down between us.”

headline: The Undeserving Rich
text: The reality of rising American inequality is stark. Since the late 1970s real wages for the bottom half of the work force have stagnated or fallen, while the incomes of the top 1 percent have nearly quadrupled (and the incomes of the top 0.1 percent have risen even more). While we can and should have a serious debate about what to do about this situation, the simple fact — American capitalism as currently constituted is undermining the foundations of middle-class society — shouldn’t be up for argument.

headline: Crowded Out of Ivory Tower, Adjuncts See a Life Less Lofty
text: His students call him “Prof,” and in the classroom James D. Hoff looks like any other English professor, circulating among the undergraduates and urging them to recite, savor and interrogate the texts of writers as varied as James Baldwin, Stephen Crane and the Beat poets.

headline: Egypt Says Twitter Post by Liberal Was Crime
text: CAIRO — A prosecutor on Sunday charged one of Egypt’s most prominent liberal intellectuals with insulting the judiciary because he posted a message on Twitter criticizing a court ruling against three American nonprofits that promote democracy.

headline: Tortorella’s Temper Lands Him in Trouble Again
text: John Tortorella had kept his temper in check remarkably well this season, but in an explosion of fury Saturday night, his inability to ignore provocation got the better of him. Now Tortorella, the Vancouver coach, almost certainly faces a substantial fine and may be suspended.

headline: When Children Become Criminals
text: New York is one of two states, the other being North Carolina, in which 16-year-olds are automatically tried as adults. This is the case despite overwhelming evidence that sending children into adult courts, rather than the juvenile justice system, needlessly destroys lives and further endangers the public by turning nonviolent youngsters into hardened criminals.

headline: Dangerous Inaction by the Election Commission
text: For all its signature dysfunction, the Federal Election Commission has a staff of professionals working to track big money and shady behavior in the nation’s congressional and presidential campaigns.

headline: Undefeated Connecticut Leaves No Doubts at Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — C. Vivian Stringer, the women’s basketball coach at Rutgers, appeared on the video scoreboard before Sunday’s game against Connecticut in a film clip intended to stoke her players and the announced 6,480 fans at Rutgers Athletic Center.

headline: A-Rod’s Drug Testing
text: Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez took testosterone lozenges before games. He applied testosterone cream every evening and injected H.G.H. regularly. And yet he never failed a drug test. Evidence that he broke antidoping rules surfaced through other channels. In January 2013, The Miami New Times linked a “rejuvenation” clinic — Biogenesis of America — to Rodriguez and other players, putting in motion an investigation by Major League Baseball, which culminated in a 162-game suspension for Rodriguez and an official report, released last week, detailing his regimen.

headline: Arkansas Town’s New Owner Has Visions of Its Renaissance
text: WILSON, Ark. — The little farm towns here in Delta cotton country spin by, each rusting grain silo and boarded-up discount store fading into the next.

headline: What’s Happening With the Air Force?
text: If the Air Force cheating scandal disclosed last week were a singular event, it would be easier to accept Pentagon assurances that America’s nuclear deterrence and military readiness have not been compromised. But it is the latest in a series of breaches that have raised alarms about discipline and competency in the Air Force.

headline: An Attack on Westerners Helps Bridge a Divide in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — His suicide vest packed with steel pellets the size of musket balls, the Taliban bomber walked down the potholed street to the entrance of the Taverna du Liban. Behind the thin steel door, in a small guardroom, three men huddled for warmth from the cold Kabul winter.

headline: U.S. Snowboarding Olympians Include Siblings
text: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — Arielle Gold began snowboarding at age 7 to be more like Taylor, her older brother. These days, Arielle, 17, and Taylor, 20, spend much of their summers training together in the gym and their winters riding together, pushing each other to be better.

headline: Publisher Struggles in Chase for Growth
text: Timing matters when it comes to news. I had been reading about Aaron Kushner’s audacious strategy to invest in journalism ever since he bought The Orange County Register in 2012 for about $50 million and the assumption of $110 million in pension obligations. After years of covering layoffs, I wanted to write a different kind of tale about newspapers.

headline: Juveniles Facing Lifelong Terms Despite Rulings
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In decisions widely hailed as milestones, the United States Supreme Court in 2010 and 2012 acted to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, accepting the argument that children, even those who are convicted of murder, are less culpable than adults and usually deserve a chance at redemption.

headline: For Super Bowl Jet-and-Helicopter Set, Urging Buses and Rail
text: It can seem like an impossible math problem, packed with variables that include the reliability of famously fussy rail systems, conditions at the region’s oldest operating airport and the whims of Mother Nature in the dead of winter.

headline: U.N. Invites Iran to Syria Talks, Raising Objections From the U.S.
text: The announcement by Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, that he had invited Iran to a peace conference to end the war in Syria drew strong objections on Sunday from American officials, who suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending and that the invitation might need to be withdrawn.

headline: Nonprofit Clinic Offers ‘Bridges of Health’ to Philadelphia’s Illegal Immigrants
text: PHILADELPHIA — Like many other immigrants, Mery Martinez has no legal status in the United States, no health insurance and no money.

headline: Influence in Paradise: An Annotated Tour
text: Lawmakers from Washington travel to resorts across the United States for multiday fund-raising events that often mix business and pleasure.

headline: On ‘Downton Abbey': the First Black Character Makes an Appearance
text: “While it was shocking and sad to see such a likable character as Anna suffer, the fact is that women – in those days and even today in many parts of the world – were subjected to this horrible crime as well as the shame and long-term damage in its aftermath. … The show took a unique opportunity to portray an important reality and I thought it was done appropriately.” – Steven Feinstein, Massachusetts

headline: An Unsung Hero of Civil Rights
text: This year America will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, a candidate for the greatest legislative accomplishment of the last century. We will recall the presidents who launched (J.F.K.) and landed (L.B.J.) this profound if incomplete attempt to repair the damage racism had done to our democracy and our humanity. We will esteem the leaders and martyrs of the movement that forced the issue onto our national conscience, including the man we honor on this holiday. We will recall, too, the Southern Democrats who stood — and stalled — in defense of segregation, and the Republicans who later capitalized on the outcome with a cynical appeal to white resentment. We will lament the current attempts by several states, with the Supreme Court’s blessing, to roll back the basic franchise promised in the Civil Rights Act (and reinforced by the Voting Rights Act the following year). And we will probably invoke the legacy of this great law many times as we debate the status of millions of undocumented residents and the rights of gay Americans.

headline: A Loophole Allows Lawmakers to Reel In Trips and Donations
text: VAIL, Colo. — After some time in the hot tub, an evening cocktail reception and a two-and-a-half-hour dinner in a private dining room named Out of Bounds, Representative Adrian Smith, Republican of Nebraska, made one last stop, visiting the lounge at the Four Seasons Resort hotel here to spend more time with the lobbyists and other donors who had jetted in from Washington, D.C., to join him for the weekend getaway.

headline: Iraq Again Uses Sunni Tribesmen in Militant War
text: BAGHDAD — At a command center in western Anbar Province, Iraqi military officials are handing out guns and cash to local Sunni tribal fighters who are battling militants for control of Iraq’s largest province.

headline: Lucrative Getaways
text: Here is a look at some fund-raising events that lawmakers hosted, often far from their home states. The charges represent the hotel and meal costs that lawmakers or their leadership PACs paid.

headline: Tijuana Airport Parking, Just Over the Border
text: SAN DIEGO — In the barren Southwest, a good portion of the 1,900-mile border between the United States and Mexico is being fortified with walls, electronic surveillance and trenches.

text: All right! There’s a new girl on the block!

headline: Common Gripes Greet Common Man Party, Now Running Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — You could hardly blame Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s new chief executive, for looking dour as he drove to work this week, barely 20 days after his anticorruption Aam Aadmi, or Common Man, party upended Indian politics and took control of one of the world’s most populous cities.

headline: The Significance of Winning One for Welker
text: DENVER — Wes Welker gave a speech. Then he sent a message, the contents of which were unavoidably mixed.

headline: For Christie and MSNBC, a Messy Divorce Plays Out in Public View
text: It was a match made in moderately minded Northeast Corridor heaven.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Community Center Honoring 2 Slain Nuns, Forced Out of Its Home
text: Faith demands sacrifice. Maura Clarke and Ita Ford, two Maryknoll nuns, understood that when they went to work among the poor in Central America. The Cold War turned white-hot in El Salvador when they, along with Jean Donovan and Sister Dorothy Kazel, were raped, tortured and murdered by the Salvadoran military on December 2, 1980.

headline: Thunderous Defense and Crowd Lift Seahawks to Super Bowl
text: SEATTLE — It was loud, so, so loud at CenturyLink Field on Sunday. The press box shook and the crowd rumbled and heaved and Pete Carroll, the Seahawks’ coach, paced the sideline raising his arms, pleading the crowd for more, more, more.

headline: Building Toward the Home of Tomorrow
text: The home of the future — complete with helper bots and automated appliances — has long been the stuff of science fiction. The tech world is determined to make it a reality.

headline: Surging Rangers Overwhelm Capitals
text: The Rangers are on a roll. With Henrik Lundqvist stopping pucks with aplomb and multiple goals from Rick Nash, the team is skating with as much confidence as it has displayed all season.

headline: China Reports Cooling Down of Economy
text: HONG KONG — China’s economy expanded 7.7 percent in the final three months of 2013, compared with a year earlier, underlining that the world’s second-largest economy has continued to lose the supercharged momentum of recent decades.

headline: A Colossal Bridge Will Rise Across the Hudson
text: David Capobianco was a toddler in 1964 when the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge slowly soared over his neighborhood of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and tethered it to Staten Island. As he grew up, the improbable notion of assembling something so big and of such gossamer design propelled him to become a civil engineer.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Governor Tells Donors: ‘Come See Me Next Year’
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told top Republican donors on Sunday that his presidential ambitions were on hold until next year, amid a widening state investigation into a bridge closing ordered by his aides, and further allegations that he has bullied local officials.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 12-18
text: Often at sports events, the mix of action, location, light and “atmospherics” can create hypnotic visuals that complement the lure of competition.

headline: Tappan Zee Bridge Opens for Business in 1955
text: A December 1955 article in The New York Times on the opening of the Tappan Zee bridge.

headline: Bryan Brothers Upset in Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The top-seeded American team of Bob and Mike Bryan fell with surprising speed, 7-6 (9), 6-4 in 78 minutes, in the third round of men’s doubles to an unheralded pair, Eric Butorac of Boston and Raven Klaasen of Cape Town.

text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Coming a Long Way on Smoking, With a Way to Go
text: Fifty years ago this month, Dr. Luther L. Terry issued the first “Surgeon General’s Report on Smoking and Health,” which cited smoking as a cause of lung cancer in men. The hefty report landed like a bombshell on a complacent public, bombarded daily by tobacco advertising and surrounded at work, home and play by people who smoked.

headline: U.S. Attorney Said to Meet With Hoboken Mayor
text: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., Dawn Zimmer, said that she met on Sunday afternoon with federal prosecutors who are investigating her allegation that Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno threatened to withhold federal funds that could have helped her city recover from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Cuomo’s Budget Is Said to Include Ethics and Campaign Finance Reforms
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, seeking to prod recalcitrant lawmakers to take action after a rash of embarrassing corruption scandals in Albany, plans to use his budget proposal this week to push for approval of new ethics laws and a public financing system for state political campaigns, administration officials said.

headline: Swindlers Use Telephones, With Internet’s Tactics
text: SEATTLE — Phone swindles are practically as old as the telephone itself. But new technology has led to an onslaught of Internet-inspired fraud tactics that try to use telephone calls to dupe millions of people or to overwhelm switchboards for essential public services, causing deep concern among law enforcement and other groups.

headline: Lynch’s Third-Quarter Blast Breaks Pacific Northwest Logjam
text: SEATTLE — The showdown between Beast Mode and the Inconvenient Truth, the nicknames for Marshawn Lynch and Frank Gore, the star running backs of the Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers, was one of many subplots expected to emerge from the N.F.C. championship game.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 20, 2014
text: “Fake emails are usually pretty easy to spot because you can look and see if it came from Bank of America or from FreeEmailAddressInEgypt.com. With the phone, you don’t have that option of researching.”

headline: In New Country, Mother Sacrifices Precious Family Time to Pay Bills
text: Antonia Caba did not have any tissues so she used a paper towel to dab away her tears, taking care not to smudge her meticulously applied makeup as she described how she had tried to provide for her children in this new country.

headline: Woman and 2 Daughters in Queens Are Found Stabbed to Death at Home
text: The police are investigating the stabbing deaths on Sunday of a Queens woman and her two daughters, police and fire officials said.
