headline: With University’s Help, New Park on Harlem River Is a Marshland Sanctuary
text: Muscota means “place in the reeds” in the language of the Lenape, Manhattan’s original Native American inhabitants, and a new park that opened quietly in mid-January at the northern tip of the island appropriately bears the name.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 19, 2014
Citing Costs, N.H.L. Injury Study Urges More Safety
text: An author of a new medical study said the high cost of paying injured N.H.L. players should push the league to stiffen what he described as inadequate measures to prevent brain trauma, including rules that still allow fighting.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 8:10 A.M. (Starz) CHARLIE BARTLETT (2008) After being kicked out of private school for making fake IDs, Charlie (Anton Yelchin, above) goes the public route, arriving at a high school in a chauffeured limousine, wearing a navy blazer with a Latin insignia and toting a briefcase. An instant pariah, he discovers a road to popularity paved with prescription drugs. Soon, he has become a sort of therapist, dispensing advice and medication to classmates. Hope Davis plays his flaky, depressed mother; Robert Downey Jr. is the high school’s alcoholic principal, whose relationship with Charlie turns into warfare, once he learns that Charlie is dating his rebellious daughter (Kat Dennings). “In the movie’s funniest scene, Charlie and his business partner, Murphy, the school bully who beat him up and dunked his head in the toilet when he first arrived, dispense Ritalin to the students and turn a dance into a frenzied free-for-all with bare-breasted girls running down the halls,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The movie, directed by Jon Poll from a screenplay by Gustin Nash, is never more amusingly subversive than in this scene, which suggests the hypocrisy of American attitudes toward drugs without putting it in words.” Still, he said, “as the movie dashes from one base to the next, it never coalesces into the character-driven, serious comedy with heart that you want it be.”

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Juan Gelman, Argentine Poet Who Challenged Junta, Dies at 83
text: Juan Gelman, an Argentine poet who challenged the petty and profound tyrannies of his country’s military junta — including those directed against his family — in works that established him as a formidable presence in the Spanish-language literary canon, died on Tuesday at his home in Mexico City, where he had lived for many years. He was 83.

headline: Dr. Donald Morton Dies at 79; Melanoma Expert Pioneered a Cancer Technique
text: Dr. Donald L. Morton, a son of an Appalachian coal miner who gained renown as a surgeon for helping to develop a widely used technique for detecting and treating certain kinds of cancer, died on Jan. 10 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Defense Becomes Issue as Warriors Try to Keep Pace
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Album sales declined again this year. Total sales, a figure that includes CDs, cassettes, digital albums and LPs, fell 8 percent from 2012 to 2013, to 289 million.

headline: ‘Gravity’ and ‘12 Years’ in Unprecedented Tie for Producers Guild Award
text: LOS ANGELES — In an indication of how highly competitive this year is for film, the Producers Guild of America announced a tie for its best feature award on Sunday. “Gravity” and “12 Years a Slave” both took the top honors, the first time there has been a tie for the award. The producers prize is considered a good forecaster for the eventual Oscar best picture winner; the two prizes have matched up for the last six years.

headline: China Growth Figures Show Rapidly Narrowing Gap With U.S. Economy
text: China’s economic growth figures released Monday morning may show a slowdown, but they still indicate that China is growing almost four times as fast as the United States in dollar terms, rapidly closing the gap in the size of the two countries’ economies.

headline: Work on New Chinese Aircraft Carrier Reportedly Underway
text: A senior Communist Party official in northeastern China said that China was at work on a home-built aircraft carrier and had plans to operate a fleet of at least four of the vessels, a Hong Kong newspaper reported.

headline: A Conversation With: Anthropologist Mukulika Banerjee
text: “Voting in elections is considered sacrosanct by a large majority of Indians,” Mukulika Banerjee writes in the introduction to her new book, “Why India Votes.” That observation forms the backbone of the anthropology professor’s work, an ethnographic study of 12 sites in India during the 2009 general elections, which explores the motivations and opinions of Indian voters on a range of issues related to the electoral process.

headline: Deutsche Loss Underlines European Economy’s Dependence on Banks
text: With its surprise report of a billion-euro fourth-quarter loss, Deutsche Bank has provided another reminder that the financial crisis has never really ended for European banks — raising questions about whether the Continental economy can recover before they do.

headline: Woman and 2 Daughters in Queens Are Found Stabbed to Death at Home
text: The police are investigating the stabbing deaths on Sunday of a Queens woman and her two daughters, police and fire officials said.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buying Back Oriental Brewery
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Monday that it would repurchase Oriental Brewery, the South Korean brewer, in a deal valued at $5.8 billion, nearly five years after it sold the company to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Nintendo Shares Recover Slightly After Plunge
text: TOKYO — Nintendo shares plunged on Monday, then recovered much of their losses as investors focused on indications that the company was softening its resistance to mobile video gaming.

headline: South Korean Trade Official Abducted in Libyan Capital
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Gunmen have kidnapped a South Korean trade official in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, according to the South Korean government, which advised its citizens Monday to leave the country.

headline: From Chinese Students in Germany, a Technology Promise to the Motherland
text: Illustrating the grip the Communist Party and government try to maintain on overseas Chinese students, researchers and businesspeople, an exchange of letters between President Xi Jinping and Chinese students in Germany has produced passionate promises from the students to serve the motherland — and deliver “advanced technology” back to China, the state news media reported.

headline: The Photographer and His Printer, Partners in Art and Love
text: Leonard Freed’s photos from Harlem, Brooklyn and the historic 1963 March on Washington lay on a workroom table in the home he shared with his wife, Brigitte. She stood over the images — as she has over his reputation — with a slight smile of pride.

headline: Celebrating Martin Luther King’s Birthday
text: Like most schools across the United States, we’re off today in observance of the life and legacy of Martin Luther King. The weekly News Quiz will be published on Tuesday, and a new edition of What’s Going On in This Picture? will be available early next Monday.

headline: A Conversation With: Jonathan Shainin, Newyorker.com News Editor
text: Jonathan Shainin was the senior editor at The Caravan, an English-language long-form journalism magazine, for three years before leaving India in October to become the news editor at The New Yorker’s website, where he commissions and edits both domestic and international news stories. He sat with India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival over the weekend to discuss the possibilities and pitfalls of foreign correspondence in India and India’s evolving media landscape.

headline: At Versace, Grace Jones Meets Lady Gaga
text: PARIS — It was Lady Gaga’s ode to Donatella Versace from her “Artpop” album come to life. The performing artist sat front row, her waterfall of blond hair looking so like her designer mentor’s that the two might have been soul sisters.

headline: Claudio Abbado, an Italian Conductor With a Global Reach, Is Dead at 80
text: Claudio Abbado, a conductor whose refined interpretations of a large symphonic and operatic repertory won him the directorships of several of the world’s most revered musical institutions — including La Scala, the London Symphony Orchestra, the Vienna State Opera and the Berlin Philharmonic — died on Monday at his home in Bologna, Italy. He was 80.

headline: Saint Laurent’s Rock Kids Grow Up
text: PARIS — As Salma Hayek walked into the Saint Laurent men’s show wearing a feminized black tuxedo that traced her curves, she looked like a poster girl for the company’s rebirth.

headline: Majority of New York Voters Say They Would Re-elect Cuomo, Poll Finds
text: With his re-election campaign looming, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has enviable approval ratings from New York voters and general support for many of his newest proposals, including legalizing medical marijuana, according to a new poll released on Monday. But his specific plan for the drug — to use an obscure law, and not new action by the State Legislature, to provide it to patients — is much less popular.

headline: Suicide Blast in Pakistan Kills at Least 13
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A suicide bomber struck Monday morning near the Pakistani military’s general headquarters in Rawalpindi, killing at least 13 people, including six soldiers, officials said.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buying Back Oriental Brewery for $5.8 Billion
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Monday that it would repurchase Oriental Brewery, the South Korean brewer, in a deal valued at $5.8 billion, nearly five years after it sold the company to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Blinkx Founder to Join Venture Firm Balderton Capital
text: LONDON – Suranga Chandratillake, the founder of the British Internet media company Blinkx, is joining the European venture capital firm Balderton Capital.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Emily Bazelon on Anonymous’s Brand of Vigilante Justice
text: Emily Bazelon, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about efforts by Anonymous, the online collective, to push law enforcement to reopen rape cases that they believe have been mishandled. Bazelon, who is the Truman Capote Fellow for Creative Writing and Law at Yale Law School, is the author of “Sticks and Stones: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy.”

headline: Temporary Nuclear Deal With Iran Takes Effect
text: The first orchestrated rollback in Western antinuclear economic sanctions against Iran took effect on Monday under Tehran’s temporary agreement with world powers, as all sides reported that the steps initially promised had been fulfilled.

headline: In Letter, Former Premier Denies Using Office for Personal Gain
text: In a letter to a Hong Kong newspaper columnist, former Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said he had a clean conscience about his time in office.

headline: British Financial Services Sector Optimistic, Survey Finds
text: LONDON – Financial services firms in Britain are increasingly optimistic about the business environment heading into the first quarter and are prepared to add as many as 15,000 new jobs in the quarter, according to a survey released on Monday.

headline: A Trophy Hunt That’s Good for Rhinos
text: Let’s stipulate up front that there is no great sport in hunting a black rhinoceros, especially not in Namibia’s open countryside. The first morning we went out tracking in the northern desert there, we nosed around in vehicles for several hours until our guides spotted a rhino a half mile off. Then we hiked quietly up into a high valley. There, a rhino mom with two huge horns stood calmly in front of us next to her calf, as if triceratops had come back to life, at a distance of 200 yards. We shot them, relentlessly, with our cameras.

headline: Venezuela May Meet New Reality, and New Price, at the Pump
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela has the world’s cheapest gasoline, about 6 cents a gallon, a price so low that drivers often fill their tanks for less than a dollar and tip the gas station attendant more than the cost of the fuel pumped into their cars.

headline: Police and Protesters in Ukraine Escalate Use of Force
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The catapult that went up on a central street of this city on Monday was a clear sign that the protests that have been going on here for more than two months were taking a darker turn.

headline: 3-D Printing Moves Closer to the Mainstream
text: You know that inkjet printer sitting under your desk? The one with the old, crusty ink cartridges that are collecting dust because you no longer use it? Well, you can move it aside now and buy a fancy, new 3-D printer.

headline: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin, but Iran Is Not Invited
text: WASHINGTON — American and other Western diplomats on Monday managed to salvage the long-awaited peace conference on Syria, which had seemed on the verge of unraveling before it even began when Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, issued an unexpected invitation to Iran to attend.

headline: Daily Report: Closing In on the Internet-Enabled Home
text: The concept of outfitting everyday objects — from garden products to bathroom fixtures — with sensors and connecting them to the web, often called the Internet of Things, has been brewing for several years. But the announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market, Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: Federer’s Revival Faces Crucible, Starting With Murray in Quarterfinals
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — New racket, new coach, old Federer.

headline: Pelé Backs Frenchman for FIFA Presidency
text: LONDON — When Jérôme Champagne announced Monday that he would run for the presidency of FIFA, the world governing body of soccer, few outside the world of soccer administration had heard his name before. But Champagne, a former diplomat and FIFA adviser, can count on the backing of someone with a much more recognized name: Pelé.

headline: A Conversation With: Author Antony Beevor
text: Since 1998, the British military historian Antony Beevor has written six books on the Second World War –“Crete,” “Berlin,” “Stalingrad,” “D-Day,” “Paris” and “The Second World War,” — in which he re-creates the military strategies and the on-the-ground military conflict. At the Jaipur Literature Festival over the weekend, Mr. Beevor talked to India Ink about how he wrote his 2012 book, “The Second World War,” the treatment of the conflict’s gruesome aspects and why the war still interests readers.

headline: Electra Partners to Take Majority Stake in British Shoemaker
text: LONDON – The British private equity firm Electra Partners said on Monday that its funds would take a majority stake in the British shoemaker Hotter Shoes.

headline: After the Times Redesign, Complaints and Changes
text: I’ve seldom had as much response to any post as to one earlier this month – from the first day of the redesign of The Times’s website: about 1,000 comments on this blog, in addition to hundreds of emails to my office.

headline: Missionary Jailed in North Korea Asks U.S. to Help Free Him
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A Korean-American missionary who has been jailed in North Korea for more than a year appeared at a news conference in Pyongyang on Monday and appealed to the United States government to negotiate with Pyongyang to secure his release.

headline: In Paris, Schiaparelli Returns to Couture
text: PARIS — “I loved the trousers,” Carla Bruni said in her seductive whisper as she hitched up her jeans, referring to pajamas patterned with miniature tribal warriors. It was an outfit from Schiaparelli, reintroduced as a couture house on Monday after a 60-year hiatus.

headline: Woman Chosen to Lead Central African Republic Out of Mayhem
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Cheers broke out in the National Assembly building here on Monday as representatives chose the mayor of this beleaguered capital to serve as the interim president of the Central African Republic, a country in the grip of a sectarian civil war.

headline: Bike Trips With a Boost
text: If the thought of cycling in the Alps or even keeping up with your more buff partner in the rolling hills of Tuscany exhausts you, consider taking an electric bike, newly offered by the Britain-based outfitter Inntravel.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dior Homme Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: In Our Pages: January 21
text: 1939: Trans-Atlantic Flights To Start

headline: Roasted Cauliflower Gratin With Tomatoes and Goat Cheese
text: Roasting is one of my favorite ways to prepare cauliflower, and I have always loved preparations that pair the vegetable with coriander seeds. I use coriander seeds and cinnamon to season the tomato sauce that I toss with the roasted cauliflower and sautéed red onions, then add a couple of eggs beaten with goat cheese.

headline: Potato and Sorrel Gratin
text: When a friend offered me sorrel from her garden I accepted gladly. I love the tangy flavor of this green leafy vegetable and will always buy it if I see it in my farmers’ market. You don’t need much to contribute lots of lemony flavor and vitamins C, A, iron, calcium and magnesium. The gratin is not a typical creamy sliced potato gratin; it’s more like a potato pie. I cook the potatoes first, then slice or dice and toss with the wilted sorrel, eggs, milk and cheese.

headline: Roasted Eggplant and Red Pepper Gratin
text: Roasting eggplant requires less oil than frying. It is important to let the roasted eggplant and roasted peppers drain in a strainer, otherwise the gratin will be watery. I recommend roasting the vegetables several hours or a day before you wish to make this. Adding cooked rice to the mixture will result in a firmer gratin.

headline: Fennel, Kale and Rice Gratin
text: I like the contrast of pale and dark green in this gratin, and the sweet anisy fennel flavor against the more intense cruciferous flavor of the kale.

headline: Roasted Squash and Red Onion Gratin With Quinoa
text: I have given you several winter squash gratins over the years; this is my favorite to date, because of the sweet layer of flavor of the roasted squash and the texture of the black quinoa.

headline: A Queen Bee’s Secret, Pinpointed
text: In the highly organized colonies of bees, wasps and ants, the queen has a monopoly on breeding; workers do not reproduce when a fertile queen is present. Just how she accomplishes that has been something of a mystery. Previous studies have shown that queens use chemical signals to keep workers sterile, but the few chemicals identified so far did not appear to be related to one another.

headline: Screen Actors Guild Awards Red Carpet
text: Stars including Lupita Nyong’o in Gucci and Jennifer Lawrence in Dior attended the SAG awards.

headline: Three-Piece Suits, Breakfast Meetings, and Overwork
text: No, this isn’t more about “American Hustle”; it’s a commentary on James Surowiecki’s interesting piece on the cult of long hours. I don’t exactly disagree with his argument, but I’d place the emphasis a bit differently.

headline: Objectively Pro-Unemployment
text: Jonathan Chait makes a good point about the deficit scolds: whatever they may say, they have in practice played a key role in promoting short-run fiscal austerity and therefore in keeping unemployment high.

headline: Interview: June Squibb
text: At the Critics’ Choice awards, June Squibb speaks with Melena Ryzik about her role in Alexander Payne’s black and white film “Nebraska.”

headline: Thom Browne and Donatella Versace Both Put on a Show
text: PARIS — It’s somehow fitting that Sunday marked the end of the fall men’s shows here in Paris, with Thom Browne among the last to show his collection, as well as the beginning of couture week, with Donatella Versace getting a jump on her fellow designers with a show on Sunday night.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 20
text: A Republic Day parade rehearsal in New Delhi.

headline: Video: The Roots of ‘Nebraska’s’ Feisty Wife
text: LOS ANGELES – At 84, June Squibb is one of the unlikely ingénues of this Oscar season, lauded for her feisty performance in Alexander Payne’s “Nebraska.” Of course, Ms. Squibb has put the work in, starting with her big break, onstage in Ethel Merman’s “Gypsy” in 1959. Since then, as the Bagger’s colleague Brooks Barnes writes, Ms. Squibb “has kept plugging away and plugging away and plugging away,” taking acting classes and auditioning. Though she had worked with Mr. Payne before, she still put herself on tape to play the foul-mouthed Kate, the wife of Bruce Dern’s sullen patriarch in “Nebraska.”

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Lanvin Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: In the Matter of Kim Guadagno
text: One of the interesting and bittersweet aspects of the burgeoning Bridgegate-plus scandal in New Jersey has been the centrality of local newspapers. The original story wasn’t broken by the crack investigative reporters at the New York Times, or the fake-scandal-chasers at 60 Minutes. It was broken by the transportation reporter of the Bergen Record.

headline: The Source | Liz Diller
text: Doug Aitken interviews the architect Liz Diller of Diller Scofidio + Renfro.

headline: More Monster and Hats
text: Our challenge this week was suggested by Chris Roat, who calls it “one of my favorite puzzles of the year.” And Dr. Roat sees a lot of puzzles — he’s an active participant in Bay Area puzzle competitions and a longtime Google employee currently up to something top-secret at Google X. His suggestion for this week is a continuation of our recent Andrew Luck Monster Problem. Put on your headgear and get ready for —

headline: Hyundai to Sponsor Artworks in Turbine Hall at Tate Modern
text: Since 2012, when Unilever stopped funding art installations at Turbine Hall, the cavernous entrance to the Tate Modern in

headline: Lieutenant Governor Calls Hoboken Mayor’s Claims ‘Illogical’
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — The fenced-off piles of rubble at the northern end of this city bear no resemblance to the limestone towers of Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. But the connection between the two plots on opposite sides of the Hudson River is at the core of Gov. Chris Christie’s latest political headache.

headline: Taliban Attack Kills G.I. at an Afghan-U.S. Base
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Behind a truck bomb, Taliban gunmen in military fatigues staged a brazen raid on Monday against a sprawling base shared by American and Afghan forces in southern Afghanistan. Afghan officials said an American soldier was killed in the attack, which took place a few miles from where the Taliban movement was founded nearly 20 years ago.

headline: Casting ‘Nebraska’ Via Radio and Other Producing Secrets
text: LOS ANGELES — June Squibb, an actress for more than 50 years, had to audition on tape to play Bruce Dern’s feisty wife in “Nebraska,” but much of the rest of the cast came from wide open calls in the Midwest.

headline: Failed Talks With Militants Prompt Many to Flee in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Thousands of residents have fled Falluja in recent days, fearing worsening violence after the failure of negotiations between local leaders and jihadist militants to end a standoff that has lasted weeks, leaders from the city said Monday.

headline: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Thom Browne Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Oil Industry Nears a Big Asset Sell-Off
text: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it would sell its minority interest in an Australian liquefied natural gas project to the Kuwait Foreign Petroleum Exploration Company for about $1.1 billion.

headline: Peugeot Shares Tumble as Capital Plan Comes into Focus
text: PARIS — Shares of PSA Peugeot Citroën, the largest French automaker, fell sharply on Monday as the outline of a proposed tie-up with a Chinese partner became clearer.

headline: Aam Aadmi Protest Shuts Down Central Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — The heart of India’s capital came to a standstill on Monday after Arvind Kejriwal, the Delhi chief minister, and members of his Aam Aadmi Party squared off with the central government in a public demonstration to demand that the Delhi police should be under state, not federal, control.

headline: Some Alluring Sex Ideas For Dolphins in Your Life
text: Isabella Rossellini’s fascination with sex makes for an odd, occasionally endearing evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space, one that suggests a class by a high school biology teacher who is angling for a suspension. And lecherous types take note: Although the show is about sex, it’s not at all sexy. If anything, it is likely to cause you to be creeped out by the very thought of such activity any time soon.

headline: In Paris, The Start of Summer Couture
text: The couture season opened with drape from Versace, cutouts from Dior and a splash of color from the newly revived house of Schiaparelli.

headline: Carnal Carnivals of Song and Dance
text: LONDON — There’s no accounting, it seems, for the unspeakable places a man might be driven by a wayward libido. On my first morning on British soil this month, I opened the newspaper to discover not one but three accounts of eminent entertainment personalities — a soap opera star, a disc jockey, a broadcaster — charged with molesting girls and women. (“Roache assaulted me in ‘Coronation Street’ toilets when I was 14, woman tells court,” one headline read.)

headline: Sundance: A Food Documentary That Hopes to Start a Movement
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Stephanie Soechtig’s “Fed Up,” as one might guess from the title, is not a cheery little documentary. While not quite delivering a Michael Moore-style vituperation, Ms. Soechtig and her executive producers — among them Katie Couric and Laurie David — make their exasperation extremely clear.

headline: Video of New Jersey Lt. Governor Denying Hoboken Mayor’s Allegation
text: Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno of New Jersey flatly denied allegations made over the weekend that she linked federal aid to support of the Christie administration, as my colleague Alan Feuer reports.

headline: Department of Corrections, and Not
text: So Bret Stephens of the WSJ has contacted the Times to protest my remark, in today’s column, that his error in using nominal incomes has not been corrected on the WSJ’s website. I actually anticipated something like this, and saved a copy of his original column as it appeared yesterday, just in case a correction suddenly appeared.

headline: Crystal Bridges Museum Buys a Frank Lloyd Wright House
text: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art is fast becoming more than a place to see a historic sweep of paintings by masters like Gilbert Stuart, Asher B. Durand, Norman Rockwell and Andy Warhol.  An architecturally historic house will soon be relocated to the museum’s 120-acre campus in Bentonville, Ark.

headline: Delhi’s Leader Holds Protest Over Police
text: NEW DELHI — This city’s most vocal protest leader once again shut down the heart of downtown, snarling traffic for tens of thousands while he and his supporters shouted slogans denouncing police corruption.

headline: W.H.O. May Begin Webcast of Health Ministers’ Meeting
text: The World Health Organization, responding to an angry letter to a British medical journal, says it may soon start streaming its annual meeting of the world’s health ministers on the web.

headline: The Source | Liz Diller in Conversation With Doug Aitken
text: “We like to take impossible things and actually make them happen,” Liz Diller says. A partner at the multidisciplinary architecture firm of Diller Scofidio + Renfro, which has been celebrated for its recent work on the High Line and Lincoln Center, as well as on numerous other projects in New York City and beyond, Diller also discusses being a “problem maker” and the unique opportunity she’s had as an architect to build in her own city. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: The Problem With Science, Civil War Medicine, Inside Thyroid Supplements
text: A new column on science in the raw — data, that is; a historical view of battlefield fallout, as seen through a new collection at the Mütter Museum in Philadelphia; that supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.

headline: Inside Thyroid Supplements
text: That supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.

headline: Law’s Expanded Medicaid Coverage Brings a Surge in Sign-Ups
text: WELCH, W.Va. — Sharon Mills, a disabled nurse, long depended on other people’s kindness to manage her diabetes. She scrounged free samples from doctors’ offices, signed up for drug company discounts and asked for money from her parents and friends. Her church often helped, but last month used its charitable funds to help repair other members’ furnaces.

headline: Thyroid Supplements With a Kick
text: Feeling sluggish? Having a hard time getting out of bed in the morning? Gaining weight?

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Saint Laurent Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Risk in Caring for Abusive Parents
text: Who could condemn someone for staying far away from a parent, even an ailing or dying parent, who mistreated him or her as a child? The last time I wrote about this emotional subject, most readers understood that response. Many who had suffered through similar experiences said they had taken the same stance.

headline: He’s Traveling in First Class, but He’ll Still Look at Your Recipe
text: SINCE I’m in the food and entertainment business, practically all my flights are business-related, flying from Atlanta to either New York City or Los Angeles. I am a pilot and have my own eight-seater Cessna, and when I fly my own plane it’s spectacular. But there are positives when flying commercial.

headline: A Taste of My Own Manners
text: When I started my internship, in 1986, I was given a beeper, which was handed over with a certain sense of ceremony and a certain yoke of obligation. Before cellphones were omnipresent, the beeper was a badge of professional importance: I’m a doctor — life and death depend on my instant availability.

headline: Airline Hits Sour Notes With the Wait Times on Customer Calls
text: AFTER George Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue” was born, it became a classic of the Jazz Age. But if you ask me, it died this month. The cause was overwork. “Rhapsody” would have been 90 years old on Feb. 12, the anniversary of its first performance in 1924.

headline: China Exports Pollution to U.S., Study Finds
text: BEIJING — Filthy emissions from China’s export industries are carried across the Pacific Ocean and contribute to air pollution in the Western United States, according to a paper published Monday by a prominent American science journal.

headline: $28,000 a Night: Hotels Race to Attract Superrich Clientele
text: In most hotels, luxury is measured by the thread count of the linens (minimum 400, please) or the brand of the bathroom toiletries. But for those at the highest end of the market, where the only restraint on consumption is how conspicuous they want to be, a race to the top has broken out, with hotels outdoing one another to serve this tiny, if highly visible, niche.

headline: Fighting a Cold
text: Q. What’s the best remedy for a cold?

headline: What Does the Producers’ Tie Mean for the Season?
text: “TIE AT THE PGA AWARDS!” went the alarm-bell tweet from Kris Tapley, a chronicler of the Oscar race at Hitfix’s In Contention blog. Since the news Sunday that “12 Years a Slave” and “Gravity” took home the Producers Guild top prize, awards prognosticators have been busy dissecting what it means for the season.

headline: Sundance Q. and A. | Astrid Bergès-Frisbey
text: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Canada Chooses Three Sisters for Its Olympic Skiing Team
text: The Dufour-Lapointe sisters grew up chasing one another down the ski slopes near Montreal, their hometown. But next month they will be chasing one another down the slopes at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, as the three sisters — Maxime, Chloé and Justine — will all be members of Canada’s freestyle ski team.

headline: Yogurt Joins Super Bowl Snack Parade
text: WHO would have thought X Super Bowls ago, or even V, that there could be as many commercials for yogurt during a game as for candy?

headline: ‘She. Herself. Naked.': The Art of He Chengyao
text: Wearing only underpants, He Chengyao faces the camera, the long acupuncture needles sticking out of her body making her look somewhat like a human porcupine. The performance art piece, now a video and a photograph, is titled “99 Needles.”

headline: Texas Company, Alone in U.S., Cashes In on Nuclear Waste
text: ANDREWS, Tex. — Standing at the lip of what might be America’s most valuable hole in the ground, Rodney A. Baltzer cataloged the features that he said would isolate the radioactive waste to be buried here for thousands of years.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Atelier Versace Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: For Spot in Artists’ Loft, Impress a Critic: The City
text: About every other month, an obscure mini-committee of two artists meets behind closed doors at New York’s Department of Cultural Affairs on Chambers Street. In their hands are stacks of applications from self-described artists seeking formal certification from the city, giving the panel influence over millions of dollars in lucrative real estate deals.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and the Philippines.

headline: Familiar Silhouette Is Quick to Dispel Shadow of Doubt
text: TAMPA, Fla. — On the back fields of the Yankees’ minor league complex Monday, the familiar silhouette of Derek Jeter was suddenly apparent, a sign that spring training could not be far away.

headline: The Final Frontier’s Financial Limits
text: A decade after swinging into orbit around Saturn, NASA’s venerable Cassini spacecraft is still working, well beyond the four years of science the space agency had hoped to get. But the spacecraft is running low on maneuvering fuel, and its managers want to end with a scientific bang — an ambitious agenda that includes 22 orbits through a gap between the planet and its innermost ring before sending the craft on a death plunge into Saturn in 2017.

headline: Treat Humans, Too
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: An Outdated Solution
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Costs of Climate Change
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Art Matters | “The Mothership” Lands in Downtown Los Angeles
text: Currently eight and a half months pregnant with her first child, the artist and curator Carly Jo Morgan has been exploring themes of motherhood since long before her own was imminent. Years ago, she designed a tribal-futurist “Mothership” collection for her jewelry line, All for the Mountain, that led to a commission from Sonia Rykiel. And recently, she became a certified birth doula. Now Morgan is co-curating a women’s art show, called “The Mothership,” which opened last Thursday at Dilettante, a creative incubator and event space at the edge of the Arts District in Downtown L.A. “I started thinking about the idea of a force that is guiding these vessels — these women and artists,” explains Morgan, who lives in a cabin in Topanga Canyon, of the show’s concept. “Being pregnant, I do feel very connected to the divine feminine. But growing a baby is also very sci-fi.”

headline: Longer Life Span Tied to Energy Use in Primates
text: Most mammals reach adulthood within months and die in their teens or 20s. Not so with humans and other primates, which take years to become adults, then live for decades and reproduce infrequently.

headline: Manning Fans Swing Early Betting Line to Favor Broncos
text: LAS VEGAS — Who will win Super Bowl XLVIII? We will know in less than two weeks. Who should be the betting favorite? The oddsmakers and early bettors have differing opinions. Soon after the Seattle Seahawks dispatched the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game, they were made the favorites, by up to 2 ½ points, by a majority of sports books here.

headline: Giambattista Valli: Spring 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: New Truths That Only One Can See
text: Since 1955, The Journal of Irreproducible Results has offered “spoofs, parodies, whimsies, burlesques, lampoons and satires” about life in the laboratory. Among its greatest hits: “Acoustic Oscillations in Jell-O, With and Without Fruit, Subjected to Varying Levels of Stress” and “Utilizing Infinite Loops to Compute an Approximate Value of Infinity.” The good-natured jibes are a backhanded celebration of science. What really goes on in the lab is, by implication, of a loftier, more serious nature.

headline: Betting on the Handicappers, Not the Horses
text: Could it be that where mighty HBO failed, the fledgling Esquire Network has succeeded?

headline: For Revered Concertmaster, the Start of a Long Goodbye
text: When you have served as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic for 34 years, it is only appropriate that your farewell should be a drawn-out affair. Glenn Dicterow, who will retire from this post in June to take up a teaching position at the University of Southern California, is being celebrated with star billing throughout the Philharmonic’s season.

headline: ‘Extinct’ Shark Reappears, and Sochi Awaits Snow
text: There is no certainty in science, only knowns and unknowns. Last week, researchers reversed some conventional wisdom about trees. A shark species thought to be extinct turned up in a fish market — 48 times. And no one seemed sure how much to fear the chemical spilled into West Virginia drinking water. Just imagine what we won’t know next week.

headline: Knicks Are Baffled in Blowout Loss to Nets
text: The Nets began to set screens in the game’s opening minutes, and they never stopped. They set screens at the top of the key. They set screens near the left elbow. They set screens on Raymond Felton and Iman Shumpert, and the Knicks switched and scrambled. They could never figure it out.

headline: Bolshoi’s Balanchine, From Stage to Screen
text: Sunday’s HD broadcast of George Balanchine’s pure-dance and full-length “Jewels,” live from the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, was — though by no means without drawbacks — both newsworthy and artistically noteworthy. One historic aspect occurred not in the dancing but at intermission.

headline: A Five-Band Countdown to Goodbye
text: “Hold on, I just want to Instagram this,” a young woman said to her friend as they stepped outside of 285 Kent on Sunday night for some fresh air, then stopped to regard the nondescript exterior of the building.

headline: Stark Reminders of How Uncivil a War It Was
text: PHILADELPHIA — More than 40 years after losing his right arm in the Civil War, Henry S. Huidekoper, a lieutenant colonel in the Union Army, had long since adjusted, and no longer found himself trying to reach for things or write with his missing hand.

headline: Guggenheim Is to Show Rare Murals by a Futurist
text: As a capstone to its coming show “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe,” the Guggenheim Museum has managed a rare coup: securing the first loan of five major Futurist murals from the central post office in Palermo, Sicily, where they have hung since being commissioned for the space in the 1930s.

headline: Trying On the Ties That Bind
text: Nothing better than being trapped in a house with your love, right? The extreme intimacy, the disintegration of private space, the presumption of omnipresence — those are the building blocks of a lasting relationship, no?

headline: An Attempt to Outdream a Surrealist
text: “Kafkaesque” has become a strangely fuzzy and elastic adjective. It can be taken to mean anything from the vaguely surreal to the deeply anxiety-inducing, from the psychologically disorienting to the bureaucratically complex — anything that summons any sort of association with such classic Kafka works as “The Trial,” “The Castle” or “The Metamorphosis.”

headline: A Great Big World and Linnea Olsson Release Albums
text: A GREAT BIG WORLD

headline: Seeing X Chromosomes in a New Light
text: The term “X chromosome” has an air of mystery to it, and rightly so. It got its name in 1891 from a baffled biologist named Hermann Henking. To investigate the nature of chromosomes, Henking examined cells under a simple microscope. All the chromosomes in the cells came in pairs.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,292 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: IBM Restarts Talks on Low-End Server Business
text: IBM has restarted efforts to sell its low-end server business and is in talks with companies including Dell and Lenovo, two people briefed on the process said Monday.

headline: Poet’s Archive Goes to University of Texas
text: Billy Collins, a former United States poet laureate and the rare poet to send books onto the best-seller list, can now claim another feather in his cap: a sale of his archive to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin, where his papers will sit beside collections of such greats as E. E. Cummings and T. S. Eliot. They include dozens of notebooks containing observations, notes, doodles, clippings and extensive drafts of poems, published and unpublished. There is also wide correspondence, audio and video recordings, childhood writings and diaries. Mr. Collins, 72, said by email that he had decided to sell his papers when he “started making a mental pile” and realized just how much material there was, including more than a few jottings on cocktail napkins, envelopes and other scraps. “I remember one occasion when the lines of a poem occurred to me while I was walking around the city with no pen and nothing to write on,” he said. “So I ducked into a bank and started writing the poem, standing up, on the backs of deposit slips. I used the bank pen that was attached to a desk with a chain, all of which made for a rather short poem. I tried to look very serious as if I were making a monster deposit.”

headline: In Performance: Peggy Shaw
text: The Obie-winning performer and writer Peggy Shaw performs a scene from her solo piece “Ruff,” about her life before and after a stroke. The show is at La MaMa.

headline: U.N. Dispute Brings West Bank Differences to the Fore
text: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — The children roaming the alleys of this Palestinian refugee camp north of Ramallah have been out of school for seven weeks. Food distribution is at a standstill, as are the camp’s regular health services. This crowded, concrete warren of roughly 15,000 residents is seething with anger.

headline: War Crimes Experts Call Syrian Defector’s Photographs ‘Direct Evidence’ of Assad’s ‘Killing Machine’
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, Jan. 22 | Thousands of post-mortem photographs of scarred, emaciated corpses, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from the security forces of President Bashar al-Assad, appear to offer “direct evidence” of torture and execution on a mass scale, a team of legal and forensic experts concluded in a report made public on Monday.

headline: At Least 2 Die in Omaha After Explosion and Fire
text: OMAHA — At least two people were killed and more than a dozen injured here on Monday after part of a plant that manufactures food supplements for animals collapsed, burst into flames and set off a struggle for survival for those trying to escape the crushing debris.

headline: A Popular Chinese Social Networking App Blazes Its Own Path
text: SHANGHAI — Every half-hour or so, Jenny Zhao, young and wired, unlocks her iPhone 5 to connect with friends using Weixin, China’s wildly popular social messaging app.

headline: Deutsche Bank Loss Underlines European Economy’s Dependence on Banks
text: With its surprise report of a billion-euro fourth-quarter loss, Deutsche Bank has provided another reminder that the financial crisis has never really ended for European banks — raising questions about whether the Continental economy can recover before they do.

headline: At Midway Point, Sundance Lacks Bidding Wars
text: PARK CITY, Utah – By Monday, the fifth day of the 10-day Sundance Film Festival here, distributors had sampled about 50 films and decided – so far, at least — that none required an instant bidding war and a Brink’s truck.

headline: Theft of Data Fuels Worries in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A string of senior executives at three credit card companies in South Korea offered to resign on Monday after a huge theft of client data that may have affected 20 million people in this nation of 50 million.

headline: Syria: 14 Companies Bid to Destroy Chemical Weapons
text: Fourteen private companies, including four from the United States, have bid for contracts to eradicate 500 tons of chemicals in Syria’s munitions stockpile, as well as to destroy the residue from the most dangerous poisons that are to be neutralized at sea, the organization responsible for helping to oversee the elimination of the arsenal said Monday.

headline: Boston Fed’s Latest Role: Community Organizer
text: BOSTON — Economists do not tend to be social activists. And that is especially true if they work for the Federal Reserve, let alone run one of its 12 regional banks.

headline: Japan: New Leak Detected at Crippled Reactor
text: Highly radioactive water found in a reactor building at the destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant offers new evidence that the reactor’s containment vessel was breached during the accident, the plant’s operator said Monday. The operator, the Tokyo Electric Power Company, said a remote-controlled robot had found water on the floor of the heavily contaminated No. 3 reactor building that was even more radioactive than expected. The high radiation level suggests that the water had leaked from inside the reactor itself, where it would have come in contact with the melted-down fuel core. Nearly three years after the accident, the exact condition of the plant’s three damaged reactors remains unclear since high radiation levels and flooding make it impossible for workers to inspect them.

headline: When One Party Controls the Day
A Globe-Trotting Serial Entrepreneur Finds Roots in China’s Start-Up Scene
text: Richard Robinson tended bar in the Virgin Islands, taught English in Prague, picked grapes in France, painted houses in Norway and toiled at a BMW factory in Munich. But little prepared him for the adventure that awaited him in Hong Kong.

headline: Obstacles on the Road to Mideast Democracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Greece: Prison Escapee Vows to Fight Again
text: A leftist Greek guerrilla who walked away from a prison while on furlough this month announced his return to terrorism on Monday. The fugitive, Christodoulos Xiros, did so in an online video and letter, in which he called on “comrades of armed action” to unite to protest the repercussions of three years of economic austerity in Greece. “Once again I have taken the decision to thunder the guerrilla rifle against those who stole our lives and sold our dreams for a profit,” the letter said. It was dated Jan. 14 and signed by Mr. Xiros, who described himself as “a free member of November 17,” once considered Greece’s deadliest terrorist organization. Mr. Xiros, 55, was serving multiple life terms at the Korydallos Prison near Athens for a series of attacks carried out by the group, chiefly against Greek, British and American business and political targets over nearly three decades. He has been at large since failing to return from a nine-day furlough that began on Jan. 1.

headline: U.S. Plans Naval Backup for Olympics
text: The American military’s European Command is drawing up plans to have two Navy warships in the Black Sea at the time of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, next month, should they be needed to evacuate Americans in the event of a terrorist attack or any other emergency, a Pentagon official said Monday. American transport planes would also be on the call in the region. So far, the Pentagon has not put the plans into effect, although that order could come in a matter of days, the official said. The ships are to be passing through the region as part of a regularly scheduled deployment, and the planes would remain at their bases, probably in Europe, until ordered to help. The planning was first reported by CNN on Monday. The State Department would coordinate any evacuation of Americans. Any plans to use the American ships or planes would be done in coordination with and with permission from Russia, American officials said.

headline: Cuomo and Attorney General Agree on Division of JPMorgan Funds
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Eric T. Schneiderman, New York State’s attorney general, have reached an agreement on how to divide a big piece of the $613 million the state received as part of a securities settlement with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Racers Unhappy With a 1-2-3 Finish by Mini at the Dakar Rally
text: Nani Roma of Spain celebrated an anticlimactic and controversial victory in the two-week-long Dakar Rally, which ended Saturday near Valparaíso, Chile. Roma had taken the lead in the rally during the first week, but his teammate, Stephane Peterhansel, the 11-time Dakar winner and defending champion, gradually cut Roma’s lead from 39 minutes to just two minutes by Wednesday. Another teammate, Nassar Al-Attiyah, ran in third place.

headline: Treatment for Addiction
text: To the Editor:

headline: Michigan: Study Disputes Stray Dog Numbers
text: Preliminary findings from a survey of Detroit’s stray dog population estimated that the city has fewer than 3,000 loose dogs on its streets on any given day. The count was made public on Monday by the World Animal Awareness Society, which used volunteers to collect data from around the city last year. It challenges previous reports that as many as 50,000 abandoned dogs live in vacant homes in Detroit. Tom McPhee, the executive director of the survey group, said more attention should be focused on responsible pet ownership.

headline: Still Committed to Haiti
School Lockdown Drills
text: To the Editor:

headline: Make Legal Memos Public
text: To the Editor:

headline: Demand Grows for Hogs That Are Raised Humanely Outdoors
text: SHUSHAN, N.Y. — Turn down the road to Flying Pigs Farm here, and two or three of Michael Yezzi’s pigs are probably standing in the middle of it.

headline: The Obama-Bush Nexus
text: Our current president and his predecessor in the Oval Office are typically cast as opposites, antonyms, not just far apart on an ideological spectrum but cats of wholly different stripes.

headline: Notable in Their Absence From Davos
text: The annual parade of boldface names at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is always striking. This year’s attendees at the meeting, which begins Wednesday, will include Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe; the billionaire Bill Gates; JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon; and the movie star-philanthropist Matt Damon.

headline: Burke and Hardaway Gone, Yet Michigan Rolls On
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Trey Burke’s Michigan homecoming Friday night began with pregame jitters, followed by a lonely walk onto the court and then an early exit to the bench.

headline: Scottsdale Classic Car Auctions Total $249 Million, Improving on 2013 Results
text: Scottsdale, Ariz. — The opening sales of the 2014 classic-car auction season, which took place here last week, often set the market direction for the year. This year’s sales, according to a tally compiled by Hagerty, an insurer of vintage vehicles, totalled $249 million, up from $224 million in 2013 (2,815 lots sold, compared with 2,699 last year). The average sale was $107,096, up from $100,176 a year ago.

headline: Canadian Company Behind Bike-Sharing Programs Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
text: OTTAWA — The Canadian company that designs and builds the bicycles and supporting technology for bike-sharing systems around the world, including those in New York and London, sought bankruptcy protection on Monday.

headline: Does Brazil Have the Answer?
text: Not long after I got back from my recent trip to Brazil, I called some economists to gain a better understanding of where the country stood economically. To me, Rio de Janeiro felt a little like Shanghai: there was plenty of high-end shopping in neighborhoods like Ipanema — and plenty of poverty in the favelas, or slums. There was also a lot in between. What is most striking to a visitor is how many middle-class citizens there seem to be. Cars were everywhere; traffic jams, I’ve come to believe, are a sign of a growing middle class. It means people have enough money to buy automobiles.

headline: A Tragedy on 10th Avenue
text: Firefighters, coming up the same stairwell the victims were using to descend from above, entered the fire floor, and opened the stair doors and the apartment door, sending the smoke up as if through a chimney.

headline: Pre-K on the Starting Blocks
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to offer full-day preschool to every New York City 4-year-old hasn’t yet rounded the corner from election slogan to classroom reality. But it’s moving: a public-relations campaign on Friday started blitzing the city with leaflets and emails to drum up support for the tax to pay for it.

headline: Manning Is on the Verge of the Sublime
text: DENVER — Peyton Manning may not need another Super Bowl victory to solidify his place in football history, although his lingering detractors might suggest otherwise. But if there is debate about whether Manning’s legacy could use a boost, there is no doubt that a defeat of the Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl XLVIII will elevate him to an unparalleled position in the game.

headline: Counterintuitive Advice When You Hear ‘Fire!’ in a High-Rise: Stay Put
text: The first clang of the alarm came as many residents of the modern high-rise in Hell’s Kitchen, Manhattan, were sitting down to brunch or opening the Sunday paper. Quickly came the screams — “Fire!”— and an acrid smoke that blackened windows and seeped under doors and through air vents. Few knew exactly where in the 42-story building the fire was. Some tried and failed to reach 911 operators, who were overwhelmed by calls. Many decided to flee.

headline: A Potentially Harmful Merger
text: A proposed merger between two of the largest suppliers of food to restaurants, hotels and school cafeterias could significantly reduce competition and drive up prices of the meals Americans eat outside their homes. Of all the money consumers spend on food, nearly half is spent at restaurants.

headline: The Art of Presence
text: Tragedy has twice visited the Woodiwiss family. In 2008, Anna Woodiwiss, then 27, was working for a service organization in Afghanistan. On April 1, she went horseback riding and was thrown, dying from her injuries. In 2013, her younger sister Catherine, then 26, was biking to work from her home in Washington. She was hit by a car and her face was severely smashed up. She has endured and will continue to endure a series of operations. For a time, she breathed and ate through a tube, unable to speak. The recovery is slow.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 20, 2014
Detention Must Be Paid
text: Millions of Americans can’t find work and have lost their unemployment benefits because Congressional Republicans insist the government can’t afford to help them. But there is no shortage of money when it comes to hunting down unauthorized immigrants.

headline: Saratoga Springs Doesn’t Need a Casino
text: Early this summer, New Yorkers can expect to see proposals for four new casinos upstate. Some communities in the Catskills and Western New York are ready to welcome these gambling meccas, especially if they come with good jobs, as promised.

headline: Otis G. Pike, 92, Dies; Long Island Congressman Took On C.I.A.
text: Otis G. Pike, a longtime congressman from New York who spearheaded an inquiry in the 1970s into accusations that the intelligence establishment had abused its power, died on Monday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 92.

headline: How to Compensate Victims of Terrorism
text: Sometimes the U.S. government sets aside money for victims of mass violence. More often, survivors and families pursue lawsuits and receive private donations. Which is more fair?

text: PARIS — As a candidate for the French presidency in 2012, François Hollande promised to be more boring spouse than flamboyant seducer.

headline: An Athlete for Two Seasons Can Double Up on Games

text: Maureen Brown can tell stories about kittens. Happy stories, sad stories, funny stories.

headline: Carroll Addresses the Tension Over Sherman’s Postgame Actions

headline: 2 Birthdays and 2 Ends of the Income Spectrum
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has pledged to use the remainder of his presidency to address income inequality, which he calls “the defining challenge of our time.” This holiday weekend, Mr. Obama had an intimate look at how vast wealth disparities in America have become.

headline: Elderly Patrons End Dispute With a McDonald’s in Queens
text: A group of elderly Korean patrons has reached an agreement with the owner of a McDonald’s in Queens to avoid the restaurant during busy lunch hours, ending a dispute over whether they were spending too much time seated at tables drinking coffee.

headline: Old Job Is Hurdle for Napolitano on Campuses

headline: Schools Deputy to Run Bank Street College
text: Shael Polakow-Suransky, who helped lead an overhaul of city schools under former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and became an advocate of more rigorous and routine testing, will become the next president of Bank Street College of Education, the school will announce on Tuesday.

headline: Super Sunday, and the Crowd Goes, Um, Silent
text: Fans of the Seattle Seahawks collectively call themselves the 12th Man, an extra player with a noise level so pounding at their home stadium that seismologists have recorded minor earthquakes during big plays.

headline: Johnson’s Versatility Is Driving the Nets
text: The last basket that Joe Johnson sank on Monday afternoon — a wide-open, 27-foot 3-pointer — spurred the first faint “Brooklyn” chants inside Madison Square Garden as the Nets flagellated the Knicks, 103-80.

headline: Parties Seize on Abortion Issues in Midterm Race
text: WASHINGTON — When the Republican National Committee gathers for its winter meeting here on Wednesday, the action will start a few hours late to accommodate anyone who wants to stop first at the March for Life, the annual anti-abortion demonstration on the National Mall. And if they need a lift to the meeting afterward, they can hop on a free shuttle, courtesy of the Republican Party.

headline: As Community Mourns, Police Search for Father of 2 Dead Toddlers
text: Deisy Garcia was not just a member of her church, Iglesia Naciones Unidas en Cristo. She was one of its pearls — one of 11 dancers in the group Rosas de Sarón, a team of women who performed five dances each Sunday.

headline: For New York City’s First Lady, a Chief of Staff but Still No Defined Role

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SALINGER (2013) With Paul Alexander’s book “Salinger” as his starting point, Shane Salerno layers biographical material with archival photographs, re-enactments and interviews with high school students, celebrities and even murderers to shed light on J. D. Salinger, above — from his World War II experiences and relationships with younger women to his decision to live in a fortress of privacy. Philip Seymour Hoffman, Edward Norton, John Cusack, Martin Sheen, Tom Wolfe and Gore Vidal offer perspective. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film, presented here by “American Masters,” “less a work of cinema than the byproduct of its own publicity campaign.” He added: “It does not so much explore the life and times of J. D. Salinger as run his memory and legacy through a spin cycle of hype. Salinger moved to the woods of New Hampshire partly to escape the intrusions and indignities of American celebrity culture. ‘Salinger’ is that culture’s revenge.”

headline: Shanghai Doctor Dies of Bird Flu
text: Shanghai health officials say that a doctor has died of H7N9 bird flu, adding to concerns about a recent upturn in the disease’s spread in China.

headline: For Aam Aadmi Interns, Politics Involves Paperwork and Occasional Screaming Protest
text: MUMBAI – In the second week of his internship with the Aam Aadmi Party, Nitish Sharma, a final-year law student, found himself in a crowd of men wearing white Gandhi caps at the gates of Raj Bhavan, the Maharashtra state governor’s sparkling mansion perched on the edge of the Arabian Sea.

headline: For Micah’s Birthday, His Grandfather’s Blessing
text: At 91, my father, Irving Effron, can barely remember his children’s names, though he has acute recollections of long-forgotten battles that he fought as a Marine in the Philippines during World War II. My mother, Ruth, grieves for the loss of the guy who swept her off her feet on a Rockaway beach the summer after he came home from the war. That guy was here up until a few years ago, when dementia set in and Irving’s rare good days became something to cherish, even as his bad days became more numerous.

headline: 32 Arrests at Rally for Airport Workers Near La Guardia
text: The police arrested 32 people outside La Guardia Airport on Monday afternoon at a march in support of airport contract workers having a paid holiday on Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday.

headline: Pakistan Goes After Militants in Northwest
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani jets pounded suspected militant hide-outs in North Waziristan on Monday night for the first time in years, signaling that the government was prepared to take the fight to the center of the insurgency that has racked Pakistan. There were at least 40 casualties in the airstrikes.

headline: A Conversation With: Author Jerry Pinto
text: Jerry Pinto’s first novel, “Em and the Big Hoom,” referring to the narrator’s nicknames for his parents, was released last year after decades of introspection and dozens of scrapped drafts. In the years he was working on the novel, he also published 14 works of nonfiction and poetry, as well as worked as a journalist in his native city of Mumbai. India’s biggest names in literature have heaped praise upon his fiction debut, although in reality his novel straddles an immensely porous border between fiction and memoir.

headline: Human Rights Watch Criticizes Inaction on Syria
text: BERLIN — The advocacy group Human Rights Watch sharply criticized international powers on Tuesday for the way they are dealing with the civil war in Syria, saying that the desire to bring President Bashar al-Assad’s government to the negotiating table should not become a pretext for failing to protect civilians caught in the conflict, which has claimed more than 100,000 lives.

headline: Agitating for Justice and Freedom With a Camera
text: Like an Old Testament prophet, the photographer Danny Lyon has agitated for his fellow man to pursue justice and freedom. This was not always a popular message, nor a lucrative one, but that wasn’t how he saw his role.

headline: Do You Apologize Too Much?
text: Most of us say things like “um,” “you know” and “like” as meaningless conversational filler, but in a recent essay, one woman writes in The Times about realizing how often she said “sorry” — and how she broke the habit.

text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A suicide bomber blew himself up early Tuesday in a neighborhood in south Beirut where the Shiite militia and political party Hezbollah holds sway, the most recent in a series of such attacks that have targeted civilian areas across Lebanon in recent months.

headline: In Files, a History of Sexual Abuse by Priests in Chicago Archdiocese
text: CHICAGO — One priest, the Rev. William J. Cloutier, was accused of raping a boy in his summer cottage, locking the door when the 13-year-old started screaming, and then brandishing a handgun while threatening to kill him if he told anyone. Another, the Rev. Robert C. Becker, would take boys to a trailer where, they said, he slept beside them and molested them. And the Rev. Joseph R. Bennett was accused of raping a girl with the handle of a paten, a plate used to hold eucharistic bread.

headline: Bosnia’s Lessons for Syria
text: WASHINGTON — DESPITE the last-minute diplomatic row over the cancellation of the United Nations’ invitation to Iran, the “Geneva II” peace talks between the government of Bashar al-Assad and the Syrian opposition are scheduled to start today, with support from NATO members and Russia. But the process faces daunting challenges.

headline: Daily Report: Homegrown Social App Dominates Chinese Market
text: Weixin (pronounced way-shin) is this country’s killer app, a highly addictive social networking tool that allows smartphone users to send messages and share news, photos, videos and web links, much like America’s WhatsApp, or Line, a Japanese communications and messaging app. In the United States, a similar version is known as WeChat, David Barboza reports.

headline: Peaceful Swiss Resort Takes On Troubles of Syrian War
text: MONTREUX, Switzerland — The expectant melancholy typical of resort towns in the winter has given way here, at least in the center of this lakeside village, to something edgier, as if a piece of the Green Zone had levitated here from Baghdad.

headline: Why 2013 Was Our Best Year Ever (Except for One Crucial Metric)
text: January has rolled around again, and it’s time for me to take stock of how my business performed in 2013. This has been an annual event for me (these are my corresponding posts for 2012, 2011, and 2010).  And this is the executive summary: great year! In fact, it was the best ever — with the exception of one important metric.

headline: Work Weekends and Long Hours, Fund Manager Advises Young Bankers

text: PARIS — “Noble” is a weird word to use for a modern male wardrobe. Some of the clothes are bound to be sporty, rather than the familiar uniform of smart suits and military coats once associated with a nobleman.

text: KIEV, Ukraine — As demonstrators in ski masks scuffled with the police here on Tuesday evening, opposition leaders accused the government of provoking the very violence it has been condemning in an effort to discredit and possibly split the protest movement.

headline: A Conversation With: Graphic Novelist Vishwajyoti Ghosh
text: Vishwajyoti Ghosh, a graphic novelist and artist based in Delhi, is curator of the book “This Side That Side: Restorying Partition,” an anthology of graphic narratives from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. His first graphic novel, “Delhi Calm,” was published in 2010. At the Jaipur Literature Festival, Mr. Ghosh spoke with India Ink about the significance of collaborating with 48 different contributors, and what it means for younger generations to retell the history of Partition in a graphic format.

He screamed as if he won the tournament. He screamed as if he won the lottery. He screamed so loud for so long the chair umpire issued a warning.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Rebecca Mead

headline: Three’s a Trend | Two-Faced Coats
text: Double-faced cashmere is one of the softest, most luxurious fabrics around — specially woven with two “right” sides, or faces, so that the wearer feels the ultrasoft fiber both on the inside and out. It’s a hallmark of many high-end fashion collections, as there’s no difference in quality between the front and the back of the fabric. And the drape of a coat made with this material, unencumbered by the usual structure, is loose and fluid, like a bathrobe. At Valentino, a new capsule, haute couture collection for men included a classic, double-faced cashmere coat in camel that looks as luxurious as it feels. Varied versions of the high-class standby included Tomas Maier’s olive offering at Bottega Veneta, which he layered over equally cozy, athletic-style pants and zip top. And at Louis Vuitton, the designer Kim Jones draped a gray, peaked lapel coat over the shoulders of a suit and tank top, for the height of elegance.

headline: Which Authors or Books Have Worked on You as ‘Negative Influences’?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and Daniel Mendelsohn discuss their “negative influences”: works that have inspired them to take an opposing approach in their own writing.

headline: Encore, for the Norwegian Curlers and Their Pants
text: LAS VEGAS — The sun had set on the Strip and some members of the Norwegian curling team were taking a break from competing in a tournament here. They were ready to hit the town, the Bellagio, perhaps, and maybe dinner at Caesars Palace. But the men knew that tourists would not recognize them as Scandinavian stars of an obscure sport.

headline: JPMorgan Is Said to Drop Out of Another Offering in China

headline: Thai Leaders Declare State of Emergency in Bangkok

headline: English F.A. Charges Anelka Over Contentious Gesture

headline: The Twist to This Pro Bono Campaign? The Rights are Priced
