Now a nonprofit organization has adapted the practice for its own charitable purposes.

headline: Running Economies Into the Sand
text: Hmm. Allies of the Cameron government are now taunting Hollande as having run the French economy “into the sand” — presumably by contrast with the British triumph. How does that look in terms of, you know, actual numbers?

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Letmein’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Video: Bradley Cooper and That Perm
text: LOS ANGELES — Quick, viewers of “American Hustle”: can you separate Christian Bale’s swindler Irving Rosenfeld from his elaborate comb-over or Bradley Cooper’s tightly wound F.B.I. agent from his coiled perm? (To say nothing of high-maintenance wife Jennifer Lawrence’s towering updo.) The David O. Russell film was nominated for an Academy Award for its costume design but, in a highly noted snub, not for its hair or makeup.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Dior Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: A Dylan Tribute Concert Is Getting New Life
text: The Bob Dylan reissue machine has already refurbished Mr. Dylan’s complete catalog and has regularly revisited the vaults to offer compilations of outtakes and rarities. Now, Columbia Records’ historical division, Legacy Recordings, has turned its attention to a Dylan footnote, though a hefty one, the concert the label presented at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 16, 1992, to commemorate the 30th anniversary of its relationship with Mr. Dylan. A remastered high-definition video version, on DVD and Blu-ray, and a refreshed two-CD edition, are due out March 4. Both versions will include extra performances and rehearsal material.

headline: Protesters Make Do with Donated Snacks and Lack of Toilets
text: NEW DELHI — Since he began his protest on Monday, coughs and sniffles have punctuated the speeches by Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister and leader of the Aam Aadmi, or Common Man, Party. A thin gray scarf, tied around his head vertically, protected his ears in a minimalistic way, reminiscent of a lonely security guard. He was the Common Man with the common cold.

headline: Delhi Chief Minister Calls Off Protest After Deal to Put Two Police Officials on Leave
text: NEW DELHI — Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister, called off his party’s sit-in protest over women’s safety on Tuesday night after the central government agreed to place on leave two police officials who the Aam Aadmi Party accused of failing to protect women.

headline: Vitter to Run for Louisiana Governor
text: Senator David Vitter, a Republican once tarred by scandal, announced on Tuesday that he will run for governor of Louisiana.

headline: Apple Wins Temporary Stay on Court Monitor
text: Apple won a small victory on Tuesday in its attempt to oust a court-appointed monitor who is responsible for overseeing the company’s compliance with federal antitrust laws.

headline: Fiat Completes Acquisition of Chrysler
text: A classic American car manufacturer has officially become 100 percent Italian.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in Paris
text: It was another great season for men’s wear in Paris, which wrapped up over the weekend. Some credit has to be handed to the beautiful City of Lights itself, a stunning backdrop for the Fall/Winter 2014 collections. Some of the designers presented their most thoughtful and memorable shows yet, including the following top five.

headline: Readers Respond: Managing an Overflowing Inbox
text: If you were one of the people who sent me an email last year and I didn’t respond, I’m sorry. As I noted in my column this week, I probably deleted it.

headline: Image of the Day: January 21
text: Tata Motors launched a new car Vista Tech in Bangalore, Karnataka.

headline: Urban Grit in Philly’s Fishtown
text: In the Fishtown area of Philadelphia, Sarah Anderson, a boutique owner, says her style is inspired by ’70s B-level horror movies.

headline: The Trap of Too Many Choices
text: I recently got a new smartphone. In the setup process, I was presented with all sorts of options. Selecting a language was pretty easy, but I had to think harder about some of the other ones. Did I want the phone to use my location? Did I want to share data anonymously? Did I want to log in with an existing account or did I need to set up a new one?

headline: Turkish Leader, Amid Scandal at Home, Visits Brussels to Try to Repair Ties
text: PARIS — Buffeted by a corruption scandal and accusations of creeping authoritarianism, Turkey faces long odds in its bid to join the European Union even as the country’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, visited Brussels on Tuesday to try to repair a badly frayed relationship with Europe.

headline: Bouchra Jarrar: Spring 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Gay Couple? Are You Amending a Tax Return?
text: Tax season is not traditionally a time of year Americans look forward to. But this year may be different – at least for some.

headline: Horizon:  Artifacts of the Mayans; ‘Tales of the City’ Finale
text: ART

headline: More Producers’ Secrets: ‘Captain Phillips’ and the Defining Screen Test
text: The producer Michael De Luca let an audience of indie filmmakers and wannabes in on some secrets at a discussion at Sundance on Tuesday morning. But Mr. De Luca, whose credits include “The Social Network,” “Moneyball,” “Magnolia” and the coming film adaptation of “50 Shades of Grey,” already revealed some secrets at the Producers Guild nominee panel in Los Angeles, which he attended last week as a producer of “Captain Phillips,” a contender for the best picture Oscar.

headline: Caramoor Sets Lineup for Summer Festival
text: The Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts has announced the classical music and opera programming for this summer’s festival, which will open on June 21 and run through Aug. 6. The performances, held on a 90-acre estate in Katonah, N.Y., include an opening-night concert in which the violinist Joshua Bell will be the soloist in the Sibelius concerto, part of a program by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, Cristian Macelaru conducting.

headline: A Paul Taylor Dance Reunion at Koch Theater
text: The Paul Taylor Dance Company has announced that it has added an extra performance to its season at the David H. Koch Theater, on March 23 at 6 p.m., for which 46 of the company’s alumni have accepted Mr. Taylor’s invitation to appear onstage beside members of the current company.

headline: Ars Nova to Stage New Play From Debate Society
text: The Debate Society, the quirky three-person theater troupe, will follow up its breakthrough hits “Buddy Cop 2” and “Blood Play” with “Jacuzzi,” which focuses on a group of characters who populate the “7th-best ski resort in southwest central Colorado.”

headline: DNA Confirms Body Parts Belong to Missing Boy With Autism
text: First there was the disappearance: a 14-year-old boy with autism last seen walking out of his school by the Queens waterfront last fall. Then there were the months of searching, the posters of a fresh-faced teenager that a city came to know simply as Avonte.

headline: France to Return 3 Artworks Looted in World War II
text: PARIS — France’s culture minister, Aurélie Filippetti, on Tuesday pledged to return three artworks looted in World War II “without delay,” including a 17th-century landscape by the Flemish painter Joos de Momper.

headline: Funds Created to Offload Credit Risk From Big Projects
text: The Mariner Investment Group, a $10 billion global alternative investment firm, has created two funds that will buy up credit risk from deals used to finance large projects in areas like infrastructure, transportation and energy, allowing financial institutions, including European banks, to free up capital they would otherwise need to hold under regulatory requirements.

headline: Martoma Defense Walks a Tightrope
text: The trial of Mathew Martoma presents a challenge often seen in recent insider trading prosecutions: how to mount a defense denying any wrongdoing when the defendant is unlikely to testify. One way to persuade a jury to return a not-guilty verdict is by focusing on the ordinary nature of the trading to raise questions about whether any confidential information was even used.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 14-Jan. 20, 2014
text: Droughts, dogs, football, movies and more: how many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

headline: After Hours | At Town Hall, A Chance to Shamelessly Worship the Indomitable Carol Channing
text: Gay men of a certain age have strong feelings about Broadway divas, who modeled an outsize swagger in an era when they themselves couldn’t. Of all the give-’em-heck floorboard belters in this particular canon, few have attained the sainted status of Carol Channing, the blond-mopped, lisping “Hello Dolly” icon who turns 93 next week with her stage brio intact. When she was helped onstage last night at Town Hall for a special birthday tribute, grinning widely and wearing a white bouclé jacket and slacks, the cavernous house, packed mostly with middle-aged and older gay men, jumped to its feet and, for 10 minutes straight, released the sort of primal roar that might have accompanied a winning Superbowl pass.

headline: Bananas are Chemicals, Too
text: Via a Facebook post by longtime science writer Boyce Rensberger of a piece on the science and technology website IO9, I found a set of clever and provocative illustrations created by James Kennedy, a high school chemistry teacher in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: U.S. and Russia Discuss Olympic Security
text: BRUSSELS — Even as Russia imposes the most intensive security apparatus in Olympic history, the top military officers from the United States and Russia have opened discussions about using sophisticated American electronic equipment in a new effort to help secure the Winter Games in Sochi next month.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Christie Sworn In for Second Term
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey took the oath of office at the War Memorial Theater in Trenton on Tuesday.

headline: America to Obama: We’re Not Listening
text: President Obama has come before the American people so many times now to promise transparency, declare his respect for civil rights and privacy, and vow to create a rational policy on government spying, that no one seems to be listening anymore.

headline: Everything Is Strange, and Therein Lies the Point
text: Romantic love in the films of David Lynch is more than passion; as often as not, it is a dangerously morbid obsession expressed in songs that thread through the soundtracks like the tempting voices of sirens. The title song of “Blue Velvet”; Roy Orbison’s “In Dreams,” from the same movie; and Chris Isaak’s “Wicked Game,” from “Wild at Heart,” are prime examples of songs that dangle the keys to supernatural mysteries.

headline: Conjuring the Global Dangers of Water
text: The PBS science program “Nova” has been trying to quicken its pace lately, generating episodes pegged to newsmaking events like Hurricane Sandy and the Boston Marathon bombing. “Killer Typhoon,” about the catastrophic storm in the Philippines in November, is the latest, and from it we learn once again that water is something to be feared.

headline: Data Breaches Are Scary, but Don’t Panic. React.
text: It’s always upsetting when you are notified by a business, whether it is a credit card issuer or a retailer, that your personal or financial information may have been stolen in a data breach. The recent incident at Target stores, one of the largest corporate breaches in recent years, affected millions of people.

headline: ‘Here Lies Love’ Will Return to the Public Theater
text: The critically acclaimed musical “Here Lies Love,” which uses discotheque atmospherics to explore the celebrity life of former first lady of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos, will return starting March 24 to the Public Theater for an open-ended run, one of the producers, Joey Parnes, said on Tuesday.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: MLK Edition
text: Friday marked the 25th anniversary of the Cleveland Elementary School shooting in Stockton, Calif., the first mass shooting of schoolchildren in American history. In the space of three minutes, five kids ranging in age from 6 to 9 were killed and 29 others were wounded, as was a teacher.

headline: As Images of Attacker are Shared, Thai Government Issues Emergency Rule
text: As my colleague Thomas Fuller reported from Bangkok on Tuesday, the government in Thailand has declared the imposition of emergency rule to start on Wednesday.

headline: Wheelies: The More Emotional Camry Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: At Rao’s in Los Angeles, Red Sauce and Rivalry
text: LOS ANGELES — Seward Street runs through a patch of film production studios and empty lots in Hollywood. It is dimly lit, usually deserted and a little spooky at night. But the other Friday evening, the red glow of a neon sign splashed across the road. A security guard and a parking valet stood out front, and a steady stream of people walked into what is, as it turns out, a restaurant, a Rat Pack outpost of dark wood, red leather booths and twinkling year-round Christmas lights.

headline: Discovery Takes Controlling Stake in Eurosport
text: Discovery Communications on Tuesday said it had taken a controlling 51 percent stake in Eurosport International, a pan-European sports media group, in a deal that values the company at $1.2 billion.

headline: Numb to Violence? Fans, Maybe, but Not Players
text: SEATTLE — The National Football League markets and manufactures controlled violence and mayhem better than any other league in the history of organized sports.

headline: Catching the Olympic Spirit in Lake Placid, N.Y.
text: The Sochi Winter Olympics in Russia open in about two weeks with peerless sports pageantry and a cavalcade of athletic accomplishment that will captivate the world. Sitting at home, it will be easy to get caught up in the Olympic spirit gazing from afar at what seems like a picture-perfect snow globe setting where various acts of derring-do and stylish grace are celebrated with medals and everlasting tribute.

headline: An LED Bulb Is Both Dimmable and Affordable
text: Here’s a bulb you might think about licking rather than lighting. Philips’s cut the weight of its new SlimStyle lamp down to about three ounces by eliminating the heat sink found in most other LED lamps.

headline: J. Mendel | The Company
text: Gilles Mendel on the history and heritage of J. Mendel.

headline: Pussy Riot Coming to Brooklyn
text: Pussy Riot is coming to Brooklyn.

headline: Sundance: A Veteran’s First Visit
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Though he’s only made three features, Anton Corbijn could be considered something of a veteran filmmaker here at Sundance, where indie directors borrowing favors from family rule the scene.

headline: J. Mendel | The Fur
text: Gilles Mendel discusses the making of a fur dress for his Spring 2014 show.

headline: J. Mendel | Behind the Dress
text: Gilles Mendel discusses the process in which a dress is made.

headline: J. Mendel | The Show
text: The gown and the fur dress at the Spring 2014 runway show.

headline: G.E. to Buy Health Care Analytics Firm
text: General Electric announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to purchase API Healthcare, a software and analytics firm that helps medical companies manage their work force.

headline: Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Berlin Men’s Shows
text: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.

headline: Curtain Call | Paris Men's Fashion Week
text: To mark the conclusion of Paris Men's Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.

headline: A Welcome Formula for Dow Chemical
text: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb is putting the right accelerant into Dow Chemical. Shares of Dow jumped more than 7 percent at one point on Tuesday after Mr. Loeb called for a split of its petrochemicals and specialty chemicals businesses. He may be overly optimistic about the financial benefits, but a rough sum of the parts suggests merely breaking up Dow, a $52 billion company, could increase its value by a fifth.

headline: German Energy Official Sounds a Warning
text: BERLIN — Germany’s new energy minister on Tuesday struck a sobering tone about the country’s ambitious goals for making its energy sector more reliant on renewable sources, saying that rising costs risked losing public support and jeopardizing the powerful German industrial base.

headline: A Rare View of Wildebeest Calves
text: August is the prime month for safarigoers to visit the Serengeti in Tanzania for the migration of the wildebeest, but travelers who want to escape the crowds during this peak time and still want to see these animals would do well to head to the southern Serengeti during calving season.

headline: ‘Are You Lonesome Tonight?’ From Elvis Presley to Kacey Musgraves
text: “Are You Lonesome Tonight?”

headline: Narcissa Opens in the Standard East Village
text: Headliners

headline: East Coast Storm Brings Snow and Disruptions to the New York Region
text: New Yorkers are used to a lot of overheated discussion about impending snow.

headline: He Is the Captain Now (at Least Everyone Tells Him So)
text: As far as film debuts go, it’s hard to find a more auspicious one than that of Barkhad Abdi, playing the Somali pirate who kidnaps Tom Hanks in “Captain Phillips.” Mr. Abdi, a limo driver in Minneapolis when he was cast from an open call, learned about acting on the fly from the director, Paul Greengrass, whom he credited with helping craft his performance.

text: Solve Crosswords against the clock

text: Photos from New Jersey, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Bulgaria.

headline: Justices Appear Divided on a Sweeping Challenge to Public Workers’ Unions
text: WASHINGTON — A broad challenge to public sector unions was met with a mixed response on Tuesday at the Supreme Court.

headline: Heir Apparent at Pimco to Step Down
text: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | The giant asset manager Pimco lost its heir apparent and most prominent spokesman on Tuesday when Mohamed A. El-Erian unexpectedly announced that he was stepping down from the company.

headline: Excluded Iran Says Its Role at Talks on Syria Will Be Missed
text: TEHRAN — After Iran was invited to and then disinvited from a coming peace conference on Syria within the span of 24 hours, Iranian officials and commentators said on Tuesday that it was the attendees who would be missing out.

headline: Language by the Book, but the Book Is Evolving
text: OXFORD, England — To compile a dictionary of nearly every word in the English language was an endeavor typical of Victorian times, complete with white-bearded gentlemen, utter confidence and an endearingly plodding pace. After a quarter-century, the first installment emerged in 1884. Its contents? “A to Ant.”

headline: Ex-Governor of Virginia Is Indicted on Charges Over Loans and Gifts
text: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were indicted Tuesday by a federal grand jury on charges of accepting more than $140,000 in loans and gifts in exchange for promoting the business of a political patron who was seeking special favors from the state government.

headline: They’re Young, Female and, Darn It, Need to Work
text: For so long, women tried to succeed as much as men.

headline: A New York Home for Riis’s ‘Other Half’
text: Ted Gup, a professor of journalism at Emerson College, has donated a first edition copy of Jacob Riis’s “How the Other Half Lives” — a searing exposé of life in New York tenements, published in 1890 — to the New-York Historical Society, the society announced on Tuesday. The copy was owned by Riis, who not only wrote for “How the Other Half Lives,” but also illustrated it with his own photographs. It includes his signature and a date (Nov. 15, 1890), as well as marginal annotations that expand on some of the ideas in the text.

headline: Factoring in the Mystique of Long Lines
text: Independent thinkers find this hard to admit, but when you see crowds of New Yorkers standing outside a bakery or putting their names on the list at the door of a restaurant, more often than not the food they’re hanging around for is worth eating.

headline: A Change in the Kitchen
text: Last week at Marea, a New York haunt of the powerful and the polished, Lauren DeSteno moved up from executive sous-chef to chef de cuisine. It may sound like a mere tweak of a title, but in a small way it is revolutionary.

headline: Taking On a Master and His Many Complexities
text: The Takacs Quartet played Bartok, long one of its specialties, in two superb concerts over the weekend at Zankel Hall. Not only was the music making excellent, but I was also reminded throughout the performances of the clean, resonant acoustics of this subterranean space, which is celebrating its 10th season.

headline: Two Troupes Evoke Endlessness in Words and Movement
text: In an attempt to evoke eternity, three dancers play triangles, chant overlapping phrases and contort themselves into elaborate yoga poses. Later, three other dancers count to 3,000, as they go through ballet steps and banal conversations that strive for Freudian uncanniness. It’s another evening at the American Realness Festival, the experimental performance series that closed on Sunday.

headline: Recession’s True Cost Is Still Being Tallied
text: On Sept. 15, 2008, the investment bank Lehman Brothers collapsed after a long struggle to avoid bankruptcy, paralyzing the world’s financial networks and tipping the United States economy into an abyss from which it has not yet fully emerged.

headline: Trotsky’s Pursuer Finds a Pursuer to Call His Own
text: If Gabriel García Márquez’s “Love in the Time of Cholera” turned the romance novel into literature, and Mario Vargas Llosa, with “Conversation in the Cathedral,” applied French 1950s nouveau roman techniques to the political thriller, the Cuban writer Leonardo Padura, known for detective thrillers, has made his entrance to the Latin American Modernist canon by writing a Russian novel.

headline: American Starts a Luxury Resort to Share the Argentina He Loves
text: VISTA FLORES, Argentina — It is hard to find fault with lunch at Siete Fuegos, the restaurant at the new Vines Resort & Spa in the Mendoza province. The steak is grilled to medium-rare perfection. The sparkling torrontés wine nicely complements the homemade dulce de leche ice cream. The open-air dining room looks upon acres of vineyards set against the snow-capped Andes.

headline: 2 Friends Reach Across the Aisle on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — The two women might at first seem more like political rivals than a reminder of the way things used to work in Washington.

headline: To See or Not to See? A Season for High Art
text: Not all potential theatergoers look to New York’s stages hoping to see singing Mormons or the warbling witches of Oz, and this season, producers would give their horses, if not their kingdoms, for their attention and ticket-buying dollars.

headline: Times Minute | Syrian Peace Negotiations

headline: Search for the ‘Next Big Thing’ Yields Soaring Valuations
text: You probably saw that Google is paying $3.2 billion in cash for Nest Labs, a maker of smart thermostats that has no profit and perhaps $300 million in revenue.

headline: Kasparov’s Moves in Run for Chess Office Raise Ethical Concerns
text: Garry Kasparov, the former chess world champion, announced in October that he was running for president of the World Chess Federation, the game’s governing body. He also announced a slate of candidates who were his nominees to lead the organization in various geographic regions.

headline: Homes a Short Walk From Princeton Prove a Tough Sell
text: A development in Princeton, N.J., was intended to entice wealthy buyers with the promise of luxury living in a vibrant downtown setting.

headline: Key Witness in Martoma Trial Says He Lied to F.B.I.
text: Dr. Sidney Gilman, the government’s star witness in its case against Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, testified on Tuesday that he lied to F.B.I. agents and regulators for nearly a year about passing inside information to Mr. Martoma.

text: Recent Sale

headline: $1 Billion for a Perfect N.C.A.A. Bracket, Courtesy of Warren Buffett
text: Each March, tens of millions of brackets are filled out in the hopes of predicting the outcome of the N.C.A.A.’s men’s basketball tournament. But the odds that a bracket will be perfect, that is, every game guessed correctly, are long — to the tune of 9.2 quintillion to one.

headline: Several Chefs Cooking a Latin Recipe, Blending Melodies and Genres
text: Folk, pop and classical music meet in unlikely places in South America. That was one recurring motif, along with nimble fingers, attention to detail and a sense of humor, in Monday night’s concert at Merkin Concert Hall. It was the evening half of the New York Guitar Festival’s free pair of concerts, “Guitar Marathon: Las Americas,” which was recorded for WNYC’s Soundcheck. The afternoon show had featured North American music, down through Mexico. The evening concert was a quintuple bill largely chosen by its headliner, the Brazilian guitarist Badi Assad, with musicians from Brazil, Uruguay and Peru and a repertoire that also embraced Argentina and Venezuela.

headline: Jonathan J. Landau
text: Mr. Landau, 39, is the chief executive of the Fortis Property Group, a private real estate development and investment company based in Brooklyn that focuses mainly on office and residential properties. The company is involved in several multifamily projects in the New York area, including condominium buildings in North Williamsburg and Brooklyn Heights.

headline: ‘Joplin’ Will Make Way For ‘Joneses’ on Broadway
text: “A Night With Janis Joplin,” a Broadway musical that has been a modest seller at the box office, will close in February and then aim to reopen in March at another space in New York City, the producers announced on Tuesday evening. They declined to specify a closing date or identify the possible new space, only saying in a statement that they were “finalizing a wonderful option to move to another venue.”

headline: Pope Urges Davos Notables to Remember the Less Fortunate
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Participants of the World Economic Forum, from corporate chieftains to government ministers, are expected — encouraged, actually — to spend their time amid the snowy hills of Davos networking and talking shop.

headline: Woman Posts Video of Phone Confrontation Accusing Ex-Teacher of Sexual Abuse
text: A 28-year-old California woman posted on YouTube last week a secret telephone recording of her confrontation with a former middle school teacher who acknowledged sexually abusing her as a 12-year-old. The former teacher expressed regret for her actions during the recorded conversation, which has gone viral online.

headline: What Is Working in New York
text: The following are updates on basic services following the snowstorm.

headline: Video Shows Toronto’s Mayor Using Jamaican Patois in Obscene Rant About Police Surveillance
text: Last Updated, 7:23 p.m. | Two months after he claimed to have embraced sobriety, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto was caught on video late Monday complaining about police surveillance of him and his associates in a drunken, obscenity-laced rant peppered with Jamaican patois.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Men’s Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Men’s Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Broad City’
text: The new Comedy Central series features Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson, two popular online comedians. Amy Poehler is a producer.

headline: Twitter Q. and A. on Syria Peace Talks
text: As diplomats and politicians gathered in Switzerland for a highly anticipated peace conference on Syria, Anne Barnard, The Times's Beirut bureau chief, answered readers’ questions via Twitter on the continuing conflict and the expectations for the talks. She discussed the exclusion of Iran from the conference, opportunities to improve the delivery of humanitarian aid and prospects for the future.

headline: Abundance Doesn’t Mean Health
text: The relatively new notion that around a third or more of the world’s population is badly (“mal”) nourished conflates hunger and diet-spawned illnesses like diabetes, both of which are preventable.

headline: The Holes in a Theory of Suicide
text: Forensic experts said a theory that Michelle O’Connell shot herself with her boyfriend’s gun lacked credibility.

headline: WikiLeaks, Drought and Syria
text: In the 1970s, I got both my bachelor’s and master’s degrees in modern Middle East studies, and I can assure you that at no time did environmental or climate issues appear anywhere in the syllabi of my courses. Today, you can’t understand the Arab awakenings — or their solutions — without considering climate, environment and population stresses.

headline: S.&P.’s Account of an Irate Treasury Secretary
text: Government officials made no secret of their displeasure when Standard & Poor’s downgraded the debt of the United States in 2011.

headline: Lex Fenwick, Dow Jones Chief, Resigns in Shift by News Corp.
text: Lex Fenwick, the hard-driving chief executive who stumbled in his efforts to transform Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, has resigned effective immediately as the company rethinks its strategy.

headline: IBM: The Cloud Taketh Away
text: If you wondered why IBM has moved so fast on cloud computing in the past couple of months, look at Tuesday’s earnings report. Then get ready for even more action, including sales of business units and staff cuts.

headline: Sarah's Uncertain Path
text: Profiling a pregnant teenager in Missouri, this short documentary provides a window into rural poverty in America's heartland.

headline: Apple iPhone Sales Expected to Break Records
text: Last year analysts and critics said Apple iPhone sales would continue to drop. Some said this was because the phone’s design wasn’t different enough from previous models. Others predicted declines because of the iPhone’s screen size, saying it was too small compared with all those XL and XXL Android smartphones.

headline: Same-Sex Newlyweds Sue Utah After Series of Rulings
text: DENVER — The legal saga in Utah over same-sex marriage grew even more complicated on Tuesday as four couples who had married during the brief window they could do so sued the state over its recent decision not to recognize their marriages or provide any new state benefits to same-sex newlyweds.

headline: ‘Sarah’s Uncertain Path’
text: Sarah, the subject of this Op-Doc video, lives in a rural town in western Missouri. She is in 10th grade. For generations almost no one in Sarah’s family has finished high school. Sarah vows that she does not want to follow in those footsteps. But how will her life be different? She became pregnant at 15. Her son will be born in February.

headline: The Women in the Kitchen
text: A wave of female chefs like Lauren DeSteno is rising through the culinary ranks. More than ever, women fill the jobs that will produce the next generation of restaurant leaders.

headline: States Cutting Weeks of Aid to the Jobless
text: RIEGELWOOD, N.C. — After losing her job as a security guard in June, Alnetta McKnight turned to food stamps and unemployment insurance to support herself and her 14-year-old son. But her jobless payments ran out after 20 weeks, and now they are living on close to nothing.

headline: Disarming the White House
text: WASHINGTON — AMID the coverage of the Christie controversy and the latest budget deal, it was easy to miss the news about last week’s oral arguments before the Supreme Court in the case of National Labor Relations Board v. Noel Canning. And yet the Canning case represents the biggest threat to presidential power in decades, and the stakes in the decision are extremely high.

headline: Tennis’s New Concern: Data Harvesting
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The strangest story of this Australian Open so far involved a man, a smartphone, a consultant service for online gambling, a tennis match, an arrest, allegations of corruption, a new law and much confusion. Naturally, it unfolded without precedent.

headline: Verizon Plans to Buy Intel Media Division to Expand Its Television Services
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Verizon Communications wants to make TV available whenever customers have an Internet connection, and on whatever screen they are looking at. On Tuesday, the company announced a shot in the arm for those ambitions.

headline: Bee Deaths May Stem From Virus, Study Says
text: The mysterious mass die-offs of honeybees that have wiped out roughly a third of commercial colonies each year since 2006 may be linked to a rapidly mutating virus that jumped from tobacco plants to soy plants to bees, according to a new study.

headline: Investors Seek Yields in Europe, but Analysts Warn of Risk
text: LONDON — When Ireland recently made its first offering of new debt since leaving its bailout program, the Irish prime minister, Enda Kenny, was already focused on where the money would come from next.

headline: Trying to Control Nerves That Conjure Up Threats
text: There are triggers everywhere, Khristina Olivo said. They surround her.

headline: Banks Take On European Debt, Despite Underlying Problems
text: ATHENS — A wave of euphoria has swept over financial markets because investors now think Europe’s sovereign debt crisis may be ending. But the enthusiasm masks a lingering problem. The harsh austerity programs used to regain their confidence have fanned deep recessions and high unemployment across Southern Europe.

headline: Visiting Scene, Court Calls Forth Memories of Massacre at a Mall
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Stephen Juma stood in front of the Westgate shopping mall on Tuesday for the first time since the haunting Saturday four months ago when he was directing traffic outside the parking lot. He spoke flatly as he recalled how three gunmen leapt from a car and began shooting, shattering a nation’s sense of security.

headline: Texas Prepares to Execute Mexican Despite Concerns That His Arrest Violated Law
text: HOUSTON — Texas officials moved ahead with their plans to execute a Mexican citizen convicted of killing a police officer, even as pressure continued to mount from the State Department, the Mexican government and an international human rights commission to halt the execution because the arrest 20 years ago violated international law.

headline: $2 Billion Deal in Works for Puerto Rico
text: Puerto Rico, which is battling a financial crisis of high unemployment and a crushing debt load, is under pressure to show investors and credit-rating agencies that it can still borrow money from the capital markets.

headline: As Losses Mount, Knicks Play Down Pointed Remarks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Coach Mike Woodson said Tuesday that he was unfazed by Tyson Chandler’s pointed remarks about the Knicks’ defensive schemes after a blowout loss to the Nets on Monday. Having players publicly voice their frustrations is less than ideal, he said, but at least it shows that they care.

headline: Wartime Claim to Fame Divides 2 Italian Towns
text: NETTUNO, Italy — The landing of Allied forces 70 years ago who went on to liberate Rome in World War II is now the focus of a conflict between two seaside towns over which one has the right to commemorate the event.

headline: Food Banks Anticipate Impact of Cuts to Food Stamps
text: WASHINGTON — Late last year, staff members at the Capital Area Food Bank here began fielding requests for larger deliveries from the dozens of soup kitchens and food pantries that it supplies as more and more people showed up seeking help.

headline: The Washington Post is De-Kleining
text: Ezra Klein of Wonkblog is leaving the Washington Post. Not news, exactly — the impending move has been all over the blogs for a while. But now it’s official. And may I say respectfully to the Post: You idiots!

headline: Knicks Not a Pretty Picture When Painted by Numbers
text: An old Johnny Mercer song said you should “accentuate the positive” and “eliminate the negative.” For the Knicks, at the season’s midpoint, that is proving to be a difficult task.

headline: Old McDonald’s
text: THERE’S an old Italian saying, “A tavola non si invecchia,” which means: At the table, you don’t grow old. All of us, of whatever age, need to socialize in public places to feel connected and alive.

headline: Yale Students Tangle With University Over Website
text: The idea did not seem controversial at first: Peter Xu and Harry Yu, twin brothers who are seniors at Yale University, set out to build a better, more user-friendly version of the university’s online course catalog. But as Mark Zuckerberg found when he decided to build a better version of Harvard’s undergraduate student directory, these things can take on a life of their own.

headline: How Gov. Christie Moves Forward
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, in his second inaugural address on Tuesday, promised to avoid what he called the “attitude of Washington, D.C.” Those in the nation’s government, he said, believe that “I am always right and you are always wrong.”

headline: Sexual Orientation Is No Basis for Jury Exclusion, a Federal Appeals Court Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Gay men and lesbians may not be excluded from juries based on their sexual orientation, the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled on Tuesday.

headline: A Cap on Wall Street Bonuses?
text: The European Union is trying to limit pay that rewards excessive risk by banks. Should the United States do the same?

headline: A Rebuff to Overbroad Watch Lists
text: Public trials are a cornerstone of a democratic society. But in the looking-glass world of legal challenges to the federal government’s terror watch lists, even people who succeed in showing that they were mistakenly included on such a list have no easy path around the walls of official secrecy and obstruction.

headline: Another Syria Peace Conference
text: Few peace conferences have been set up amid the unrelenting pessimism that surrounds the talks involving Syria that open Wednesday in Switzerland. But while a peace agreement is unlikely to be reached anytime soon, the meeting can still produce useful results. That has to be the approach of the conveners, including the United States, Russia and the United Nations. Crucial early goals should include a cease-fire and the delivery of humanitarian assistance to millions of desperate civilians.

headline: At Senior Bowl, the Focus Is on the Ground Game
text: MOBILE, Ala. — If the playoff performances of the bruising Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch did not illuminate how much the N.F.L. still values the rushing game, the scene Monday at Senior Bowl practices brightened the picture even more.

headline: Buses for Tech Workers in San Francisco Will Pay Fee
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A transit agency here voted unanimously on Tuesday to start a pilot program to oversee tech company buses, but the volatile issue is a long way from being defused.

headline: Snowden Denies Suggestions That He Was a Spy for Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden on Tuesday adamantly denied as “absurd” and “smears” the suggestion by the leaders of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees that he might have been a Russian spy when he downloaded archives of classified National Security Agency documents and leaked them to journalists.

headline: Bankruptcy Case Lifts Curtain on Bike-Share Operator
text: OTTAWA — The bankruptcy protection filing of the Canadian company that has supplied the bicycles and the technology behind most of the bike-sharing programs in major American cities is revealing a complicated and messy financial foundation.

headline: Broken at the Bridge, a Basic Law of Politics
text: Here are two reasons Gov. Chris Christie and his people are hiring top-shelf criminal defense lawyers.

headline: No Fines for Stores Displaying a Dress Code
text: As a result of a settlement reached Tuesday with New York City, seven small stores owned by Hasidic merchants in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will not have to pay any fines for posting signs in their windows saying: “No shorts, no barefoot, no sleeveless, no low-cut neckline allowed in this store.”

headline: Corrections: January 22, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: For U.N. Chief, a Dance of Diplomacy Is Halted by a Misstep
text: UNITED NATIONS — Over the weekend Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, with a reputation for being risk averse, took a significant risk. He choreographed a precise diplomatic sequence on Syria that relied on others to perform their roles equally precisely. The choreography did not go as planned, and Mr. Ban stumbled under the spotlight.

headline: Knicks Have a Star Magnet: Courtside Seats
text: They call it Celebrity Row, the six prime courtside seats in Madison Square Garden reserved for the three most prominent celebrities (plus guests) at any given Knicks game. For the game against the Miami Heat on Jan. 9, they were filled by an actor, a musician and a model: David Duchovny, Paul Simon and Kate Upton.

headline: More Problems for American Couple Accused in Qatar
text: An American couple accused in Qatar of starving their 8-year-old adopted African daughter to death were gratified a few months ago when a judge temporarily released them from prison after nearly a year, with orders to remain in the wealthy gulf emirate pending verdicts in a case that defense lawyers said was so flimsy it should be dismissed.

headline: Hitches in Compromise at a McDonald’s
text: Maybe it was the snow. Or a lack of communication.

headline: 2013 Listed as One of the Warmest Years on Record
text: Two government agencies said Tuesday that 2013 was among the warmest years in the global temperature record, though they differed on exactly where it ranked. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration ranked it as the fourth-warmest year since 1880, tied with 2003. NASA, which uses slightly different methods to compile global temperatures, ranked 2013 as the seventh-warmest year, tied with both 2006 and 2009. Both agencies say that the 14 warmest years in the historical record have all occurred since 1998. Australia was a global hot spot in 2013, suffering the warmest year on record in 104 years. But the United States, which had set a record in 2012, had only its 37th warmest year on record in 2013.

headline: Out of Hamlet’s Shadow Again, and Into the Spotlight
text: Dear Rosencrantz. Gentle Guildenstern. The Prince of Denmark’s old school friends have been popping up around town in this Shakespeare-soaked season, though usually they stay in the background, onlookers and minor players amid the brooding and bloodshed of “Hamlet.”

headline: A Mapped Out Story
text: Administrivial Alert! In the Thursday, January 23, 2014 puzzle, there are elements in the print version that cannot be replicated electronically. We recommend using the PDF for the best solving experience.

headline: A Start-Up Run by Friends Takes On Shaving Giants
text: EISFELD, Germany – For more than 93 years, the Feintechnik factory in this small German town an hour north of Nuremberg has produced billions of razors, its machinery transforming steel by the ton into the mathematically precise blades that end up in low-end safety blades and the hardest-to-manufacture five-blade razors.

headline: A Movie Date, a Text Message and a Fatal Shot
text: WESLEY CHAPEL, Fla. — There’s a sticker on the door of the Grove 16 Theater just outside Tampa: no weapons.

headline: Cost of Educating New York City’s 4-Year-Olds Proves Difficult to Calculate
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio promised to provide prekindergarten classes to every 4-year-old in New York City for $342 million a year. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he could do the same — at a fraction of the cost.

headline: Chief of Chicago Hospitals Will Return to New York
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday named new leaders for New York City’s $7 billion public hospital system and its Department of Small Business Services, emphasizing a need to expand and preserve health care in all neighborhoods and to assist immigrant-owned businesses and those in boroughs outside Manhattan.

headline: Adored Walrus Goes to Texas as Aquarium Renovates
text: Mitik has left the building.

headline: Letting Go of a 4-Year-Old Who Was Beaten and Burned
text: Even in a city accustomed to the rhythm of crime and violence, this stood out. A 4-year-old boy, dead, prosecutors said, after a caregiver beat, tortured and starved him.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 21, 2014
Photo Archive Is Said to Show Widespread Torture in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Emaciated corpses lie in the sand, their ribs protruding over sunken bellies, their thighs as thin as wrists. Several show signs of strangulation. The images conjure memories of some of history’s worst atrocities.

headline: John Dobson, an Inventive Itinerant Guide to Stargazing, Dies at 98
text: Hour after hour, night after night, decade after decade all over planet Earth, John Dobson rolled his homemade telescopes to street corners and national parks to show people the heavens. “Look at Saturn,” he would say. “No charge.”

headline: Scrappy Islanders Overcome Rangers’ Two-Goal Cushion
text: The Islanders find ways to perform the unusual at Madison Square Garden. After Rick Nash scored two first-period goals for the recently dominating Rangers, the visitors appeared to be on the ropes.

headline: U.S. Military Eyes Afghan Force of 10,000, or a Pullout
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has proposed to President Obama that 10,000 American troops remain in Afghanistan when the international combat mission there ends after this year, or none at all, senior government officials said Tuesday.

headline: Blatche Puts on a Show as the Nets Keep Rolling
text: Andray Blatche put his shoulder down and charged right past Kyle O’Quinn, rose to the basket and rattled it with a one-handed, windmill slam. The play was quickly shown over and over on the Barclays Center scoreboard, even as play continued on the other end, and fans gasped each time at its intensity.

headline: Indonesia: Leader Expresses Support for Abused Maid
text: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono joined thousands of Indonesian migrant workers abroad and at home on Tuesday in expressing outrage at the alleged torture of an Indonesian maid by her Hong Kong employer. In his first publicized comments on the case, Mr. Yudhoyono insisted that “the law will be upheld” during a phone call with the maid, Erwiana Sulistyaningsih. Ms. Erwiana, 23, returned to Indonesia this month and is being treated at a hospital in the central Java town of Sragen for physical abuse. Mr. Yudhoyono’s comments came a day after the police in Hong Kong arrested a 44-year-old woman in connection with the alleged abuse of Ms. Erwiana. On Sunday, thousands of foreign domestic workers rallied in support of her in the city.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 22, 2014
text: “It is very rare to have this kind of government-backed, industrial, machinelike, systematic torture and killing of human beings, the likes of which we haven’t seen since Nuremberg.”

headline: In Front of Small Crowd, Devils Come Up Big Against Blues
text: NEWARK — The few hardy fans who made it through the snowstorm to Prudential Center on Tuesday night saw the Devils skate to their biggest victory of the season, a 7-1 trouncing of the usually strong St. Louis Blues.

headline: New Security Report Confirms Everyone Is Spying on Everyone
text: Lest we forget, the National Security Agency is in good company.

headline: Word of the Day | interdict
text: interdict •\ˈin-tər-ˌdikt\• verb

headline: Just Compensation for Jurors
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: A Conversation With: Author Vikram Chandra
text: Vikram Chandra, a writer and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, explored the underworld of Bombay, now known as Mumbai, in his 2006 novel “Sacred Games.” In it, he looked at the links between organized crime, Bollywood stars, beggars and spies, and his book demonstrated how, despite problems like caste wars and corruption, India manages to hold itself together.

headline: Minicars Are Worst Performers in Small-Overlap Front Crash Test
text: A group of 11 minicars did the worst of any class of vehicles tested so far in the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s newest and toughest trial, the small-overlap front crash test.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (Ovation) THE FASHION FUND Emerging designers compete to be named the Council of Fashion Designers of America 2013 Vogue Fashion Fund winner — with its $300,000 grant and yearlong mentorship — in this new series, which covers studio visits, a Vogue photo shoot and a presentation at New York Fashion Week. The selection committee includes Anna Wintour, above, the editor in chief of Vogue; Diane von Furstenberg, the president of the council; Jenna Lyons, the president and creative director of J. Crew; and Andrew Rosen, the chief executive of Theory. In this premiere episode, the group deliberates over hundreds of applicants in an effort to determine the final 10.

headline: A Leader of Pro-Government Faction Is Shot in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — A leader of a pro-government faction was shot and wounded outside his home in northeast Thailand Wednesday, one day after Thailand’s prime minister declared the imposition of emergency rule in Bangkok and surrounding areas as tensions in the country escalated.

headline: Report Details Overseas Accounts of Chinese Elite
text: Chinese elites have set up extensive offshore companies that allow them to conceal funds abroad, according to a new report from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists. The report, which is based on leaked documents covering thousands of tax haven clients, lists more than a dozen of China’s wealthiest people as well as relatives of top officials, including the Chinese leader Xi Jinping, and descendants of Communist Party “red nobility.”

headline: Facing Outcry on East Side, Mayor Admits Snow Removal Efforts Fell Short
text: As the snowstorm grew in intensity on Tuesday evening, whipping through the streets on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, something quickly seemed amiss. Where were all the plows? Why was the city’s wealthiest enclave a slushy, frozen mess?

headline: Protests for Xu Zhiyong
text: One of China's best known legal activists, Xu Zhiyong, went on trial Wednesday in Beijing. Dozens of protesters staged a brief and noisy show of support for him.

headline: Syrian Peace Talks Open With Vitriol, as Official Rails at Rebels
text: MONTREUX, Switzerland — From its early moments on Wednesday, the long-delayed peace conference on Syria was marked by acrimony when Syria’s foreign minister described Syrian rebels as “evil” and ignored appeals by Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, to avoid invective or even to yield the floor.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 22, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Roger Federer Finds a Higher Level as Other Stars Fall
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — All week at the Upset Open, the favorites have fallen as if engaged in a game of superstar dominoes. Serena Williams toppled first. Then Maria Sharapova. Then Novak Djokovic. Then Victoria Azarenka.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Norwegian Curlers Are Back, and So Are Their Pants
text: In “Norwegian Curlers Are Back, and So Are Their Pants,” Mary Pilon writes about the Norwegian curling team’s colorful attire.

headline: Unrest Deepens in Ukraine as Protests Turn Deadly
text: KIEV, Ukraine — A deepening civil uprising in Ukraine turned deadly on Wednesday, and this embattled capital veered toward chaos, after at least three demonstrators died during clashes with the police and the first direct negotiations between President Viktor F. Yanukovich and opposition leaders yielded only threats and ultimatums.

headline: Supporters Protest as China Puts Rights Advocate on Trial
text: The Chinese authorities put one of the country’s best-known legal advocates, Xu Zhiyong, on trial on Wednesday. His alleged crime: instigating street protests during which participants railed against official corruption and criticized education policies they said discriminate against rural children.

headline: Israeli Strike Kills 2 Palestinians, One a Militant, in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli airstrike in the northern Gaza Strip early on Wednesday killed two Palestinians, one of them a militant who Israel said had been responsible for recent rocket attacks against southern Israel.

headline: Your Next Job Application Could Involve a Video Game
text: Brittni Daron jumped through a lot of hoops before she landed her job as a solution consultant at Oracle. At the tech giant, as at other firms in Silicon Valley to which she applied, she endured weeks ­ — and occasionally months — of phone interviews, in-person interviews, mock presentations, personality tests and technical tests for both the skills she claimed to have and those she didn’t. This might sound a little ridiculous, but it’s not unusual. I’ve met lots of job seekers in the last few years who underwent a similar form of H.R. torture — spelling quizzes, math exams and oddball brainteasers (“If you were a pizza-delivery man, how would you benefit from scissors?”) — only to walk out of the interview room wondering what they’d really just been tested for. “Basically, I could never figure out what they got out of it that qualified or disqualified me for the job,” Daron told me.

headline: Do Parents Have Different Hopes and Standards for Their Sons Than for Their Daughters?
text: Parents want all their children, whether they are boys or girls, to be happy and successful. Yet a recent study of Internet search data suggests that American parents do in fact hold different expectations for their children based on sex. For one, they want their boys to be smarter and their girls skinnier.

headline: Black Performers, Fading From Frame, and Memory
text: The harder you look at Carrie Mae Weems’s “Slow Fade to Black” — blurred, soft-focus images of mid-20th century stars like Marian Anderson, Dorothy Dandridge, Billie Holiday and Eartha Kitt — the more you see.

headline: Yahoo’s Mayer Views 2014 as Tech ‘Tipping Point’
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – The rapid adoption of smartphones and the applications that run on mobile devices will make 2014 a “tipping point” that radically changes the way people work and live, said Marissa Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive.

headline: Speaking Out Against Vote’s Date, a Thai Citizen (and Election Panel Member)
text: BANGKOK — Like the protesters trying to overthrow the Thai government, Somchai Srisutthiyakorn says he is against holding elections next month and does not think they will help resolve the country’s increasingly violent political turmoil.

headline: New York Today: A Foot of Snow, a Tough Commute
text: Updated 12:27 p.m.

headline: Wheelies: The Calling All Aluminum F-150 Mechanics Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Couture Looks
text: Some of the images from the summer 2014 couture shows in Paris.

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 5: A Tug of Wills
text: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Hit 60 and the Must-Have Lists Change
text: There was a lot of old lady stuff I swore years ago I would never do: Take an aqua exercise class, bring groceries home in a wheelie cart, address a waiter as “Young Man,” own a plastic pill box with the days of the week on it. And I am proud to say I have yet to address a waiter as “Young Man.”

headline: Why Rovio Looks to Coca-Cola For Inspiration
text: Peter Vesterbacka is the chief marketing officer for Rovio, the Finnish gaming and entertainment company behind the Angry Birds franchise. A former executive at Hewlett-Packard, he joined Rovio in 2010, and has helped to steer the company from its Finnish roots to become a global brand with more than two billion downloads for its Angry Birds games. Mr. Vesterbacka is now in charge of expanding Rovio’s brand, including a push into emerging markets like China and new areas like movies and theme parks. The following is an edited interview.

headline: The Start-Up Vortex of Doom
text: Starting a tech company is expensive. That’s why those who start one — unless they can do everything themselves, including designing, coding and selling — must accept fund-raising as an early goal.

headline: Big Web Crash in China: Experts Suspect Great Firewall
text: Updated, 10:30 p.m. |

headline: The Old King of the New Spain
text: MADRID — You know a monarchy is in trouble when the queen is jeered at the Royal Theater, of all places, and by a classical music audience. This happened to Queen Sofía of Spain last year in Madrid — a scene then repeated elsewhere with other members of the royal family.

headline: SkyBridge Capital’s Founder Sees Potential of Activist Investors
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – The official themes of the World Economic Forum this year may include innovation and sustainability.

headline: Chinese Web Outage Blamed on Censorship Glitch
text: Chinese authorities on Wednesday suggested that a major disruption of the Internet in China this week was the work of hackers. But others blamed the massive outage on a malfunction of the government’s own Great Firewall, the sprawling, hidden infrastructure used to restrict what ordinary Chinese can see online.

headline: How Inactivity Changes the Brain
text: A number of studies have shown that exercise can remodel the brain by prompting the creation of new brain cells and inducing other changes. Now it appears that inactivity, too, can remodel the brain, according to a notable new report.

headline: On Davos Panel, Calls to Curb Government Data Collection
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – The intersection of technology and privacy issues presents a unique challenge for businesses as governments increasingly seek to collect vast amounts of data on the public, a group of business and political leaders said on Wednesday.

headline: Weak I.P.O. a Seeming Setback for Hong Kong’s Superman
text: HONG KONG – Is Hong Kong’s Man of Steel getting a bit rusty?

headline: Europe, Facing Economic Pain, May Ease Climate Rules
text: LONDON — For years, Europe has tried to set the global standard for climate-change regulation, creating tough rules on emissions, mandating more use of renewable energy sources and arguably sacrificing some economic growth in the name of saving the planet.

headline: Daily Report: San Francisco to Charge Tech Buses a Fee in Pilot Program
text: A San Francisco transit agency voted unanimously on Tuesday to start a pilot program to oversee tech company buses, but the volatile issue is a long way from being defused, Malia Wollan and David Streitfeld report.

headline: El-Erian Resigns From Pimco
text: In 2012, William H. Gross, the founder and co-chief investment officer of the Pacific Investment Management Company, known as Pimco, called Mohamed A. El-Erian his “heir apparent.” But on Tuesday, Mr. El-Erian, Pimco’s chief executive and co-chief investment officer, unexpectedly announced that he would step down from his position in March, Nathaniel Popper and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. The news shattered any hope that Mr. El-Erian would be the firm’s next leader and called into question who would become the public face of the asset manager.

headline: Poem for a Snowy Winter
text: Dear Diary:

headline: VMware Buys Mobile Security Firm for $1.54 Billion
text: Looking to shift its software offerings, VMware has struck a $1.54 billion deal to bolster its mobile technology.

headline: Manuela Frey Transforms Backstage at Bouchra Jarrar
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Couture Collections in Paris. Here, the model Manuela Frey before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Madeleine Cofano.

headline: Music Directors Named for Ojai Festival
text: Presumably this year’s Ojai Music Festival in California, scheduled for June 12 to 15, with Jeremy Denk as its music director, is sufficiently settled that its artistic director, Thomas W. Morris, is looking ahead. Mr. Morris announced on Tuesday afternoon the music directors for the next three years. Steven Schick, the percussionist and conductor, will oversee the 2015 festival. The opera and theater director Peter Sellars, who has staged several productions at Ojai, will take over in 2016. And the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen, who was the festival’s music director in 2001, will return to lead the festival in 2017.

headline: In an Emergency, Call 100. Or is it 1098? Or 103?
text: BANGALORE — “Have you had lunch?” the caller inquired solicitously of the Bangalore police constable who was answering calls on the emergency hotline, and then wanted to know what she had eaten. The constable told him to hang up.

headline: Party City to Try Again to Go Public
text: Party City Holdco Inc., the party supply retailer that runs about 850 stores, has filed documents to raise as much as $500 million through an initial public offering.

headline: It Is Time to Rethink Insurance Regulation
text: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Sold on Yankees, Masahiro Tanaka Gets $155 Million
text: They met with Masahiro Tanaka for almost three hours at a private residence in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Jan. 8, and the length of the session left the Yankees feeling encouraged. After all, their eight-member delegation had been allotted only one hour to meet with Tanaka, the prized Japanese right-handed pitcher, and his agent, Casey Close, but instead the give-and-take kept going and the Yankees kept making their pitch.

headline: ‘Another Terrible Day for Pakistan’ as Polio Workers Shot
text: Just days after India was declared polio-free, three health workers vaccinating against the disease in neighboring Pakistan were shot and killed. According to the group Human Rights Watch, at least 22 polio vaccination workers were killed and 14 wounded there in 2012 and 2013. Working as part of a team is hazardous duty in Pakistan, where (as the Times reported earlier this year) anger over American foreign policy has led to a “disastrous setback for the global effort against polio.” This summer, Pakistan was believed to be “closer than ever” to eliminating the disease with only 21 reported cases as of July 2013, but by the end of the year that number had risen to 85 for the year, up from 58 in 2012.

headline: Muddy Waters Turns Up Heat on Auditor of Chinese Firm
text: Carson C. Block has already issued a blistering critique of NQ Mobile, a Chinese mobile security company. Now, he is going after NQ Mobile’s auditor.

headline: The First Amendment Protects Abortion Providers, Too
text: On Friday a district court judge in North Carolina issued a ruling that blocked the state’s ultrasound law from going into effect — a move worth celebrating on the 41st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, and at a time when Republican-led states are rushing to enact aggressive new abortion restrictions.

headline: Financial Sector Can Help Bolster Africa’s Economy, Panelists Say
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – One of the stated aims of this year’s World Economic Forum is inclusion. A panel discussion on Africa’s future, one that included two sitting presidents from that continent, did its best to emphasize that theme.

headline: How to Help Homeless Families
text: Seeing Dasani Coates standing alongside the dignitaries at Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inauguration earlier this month was a heartening sign. In December, the 12-year-old girl’s struggles living with her family in a decrepit city shelter had been vividly captured in this newspaper in Andrea Elliott’s series “Invisible Child.”  Dasani’s story struck a chord. More than 2,200 readers commented online, expressing sentiments that ranged from admiration for her grit to outrage at the Dickensian circumstances in which she lived. De Blasio had laid out an aggressive agenda to help the city’s most vulnerable residents, promising to expand affordable housing and revive rental-assistance programs for homeless families. Here was a gesture to suggest he was serious.

headline: Trove Is a Treasure for News Junkies
text: Donald E. Graham has sold The Washington Post, but he’s not quite done shaking up the news business.

headline: Image of the Day: January 22
text: India celebrates its annual republic day on Jan. 26.

headline: Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Paris Men’s Shows
text: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.

headline: Bitcoin a Fool’s Gold Standard
text: I cannot judge whether Bitcoin represents a technological breakthrough, but I am confident that the pseudocurrency’s popularity shows widespread economic amnesia. If Bitcoin ever became a real currency, it would suffer from the crippling problems of the gold standard.

headline: In Our Pages: January 23
text: 1889: A Parisian ‘Jack the Ripper’

headline: Armani Celebrates His Couture Line
text: PARIS — For “One Night Only” — though actually for two days, ending Thursday — Giorgio Armani is displaying the progress of his Armani Privé line.

headline: Ex-Goldman Trader Tourre Fights S.E.C. Penalties in Fraud Case
text: Fabrice Tourre’s Wall Street career is over.

headline: Arizona’s First Concours Crowns a ’25 Hispano-Suiza Best in Show
text: PHOENIX — Amid the madness of the annual Scottsdale auctions, Arizona held its inaugural concours d'élégance on Jan. 12, giving the state a chance to show its stuff in the elite realm of high-end classic cars. When all the gleaming cars had been judged, a 1925 Hispano-Suiza H6B Cabriolet de Ville won the best in show at the 2014 Arizona Concours d'Élégance.

headline: Letters: ‘Little Failure’ and More
text: Curses, Hopes and Fears

headline: What Handel Heard on the Way to the Forum
text: In the era of Netflix’s acerbic political satire “House of Cards,” it’s not hard to see the appeal of Handel’s “Agrippina,” which made its composer’s international reputation when it opened in Venice in 1709. The opera’s ancient Rome is a hotbed of deception and infighting, but music of dazzling variety and eloquence shoots it through with humanity.

headline: Some Businesses Go Creative on Prices, Applying Technology
text: Many business owners struggle with pricing. Should their first concern be covering costs or figuring out what the market will bear? How do they determine what the market will pay without raising prices high enough that some customers flee? And can they offer discounts without damaging their price brand?

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Anticipatory Shipping’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Have You Tried Any New Pricing Strategies?
text: We’ve just published an article about how small companies are starting to use pricing strategies and technologies that previously had been available only to large companies.

headline: Philharmonic Lines Up ‘Joan’ and a Dvorak Festival
text: There will be new music and world premieres, and not just in the Contact! series of contemporary music. There will be a week of film scores, and a festival devoted to Dvorak. And Avery Fisher Hall will once again be adapted to present a staged event: Arthur Honegger’s dramatic oratorio “Joan of Arc at the Stake.”

headline: What Would Ron Woodroof think?
text: Hell yeah!

headline: A Gilded Goddess Would Rather Be in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — Can we speak frankly? New York really didn’t deserve Diana.

headline: Einhorn Discloses Stakes in BP and Anadarko
text: The hedge fund manager David Einhorn has made a pair of bets on the oil sector.

headline: At Davos, Debate on Whether Banks Have Learned Their Lessons
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Paul Singer, the founder of the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Wednesday that he remained skeptical that the financial markets were safer despite the changes enacted in the banking industry and by regulators after the financial crisis.

headline: Times Minute | Inactivity and the Brain
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Inactivity and the Brain
text: Also on the Minute, peace talks on Syria and "Broad City" premieres.

headline: What’s in Your Fish Oil Supplements?
text: Millions of Americans take fish oil supplements to promote heart and vascular health. But a new analysis suggests that some consumers may not always get what they are paying for.

headline: Conservatives and the CBO
text: Conservatives have recently made a horrifying discovery: if you look not at nominal but at real incomes, Census data do not show a rising tide raising all boats — they show income actually falling for the bottom quintile. Some of them have responded by turning to a CBO report that took account of transfers and taxes, and shows the income of the bottom fifth rising a bit — 18 percent — between 1979 and 2007.

headline: On Drones, Keeping the Public in the Dark
text: We don’t get to say this very often on The Times editorial page, but Senator John McCain was absolutely right last week to decry a secret deal in the 2014 spending bill. He pointed out that the bill contained a classified section that prohibited the Pentagon from taking over the C.I.A.’s role in carrying out drone strikes, as President Obama has proposed.

headline: Ominous Text Message Sent to Protesters in Kiev Sends Chills Around the Internet
text: As my colleague Andrew Kramer reported, protesters and journalists standing in the vicinity of fighting between the riot police and demonstrators in Kiev on Tuesday received an ominous text message on their phones: “Dear subscriber, you are registered as a participant in a mass disturbance.”

headline: Between Couture Shows, a Fashionable Party
text: On Tuesday evening, in the break in the couture schedule between Bouchra Jarrar that afternoon and Armani Privé that night, many in the fashion crowd gathered at the residence of the United States ambassador on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honoré (currently without an actual ambassador since Charles Rivkin ended his tenure this summer) for a party to honor Richard Baker, the chief executive of Hudson’s Bay Company, which recently acquired Saks Fifth Avenue. That morning, Mr. Baker had been to the Chanel show, his first time at couture.

headline: A Safe Harbor Without Full Protection
text: A recent ruling by a bankruptcy judge in New York adds to a growing body of opinions that appear to leave the door open for actions under state law that would normally be prohibited in federal bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: A Young Picky Eater Surprises His Parents in the Kitchen
text: Have a picky eater? Christine Zanchi and her husband, Fran Nostrame, an I.T. operations engineer at I.B.M., do. They have twin 4-year-old sons, both of whom critiqued what was on the table before they even sat down. They considered one twin, Andrew, the picky one. He turned his nose up at most everything while his brother Nathaniel ate and tried more foods.

headline: Talent Agency Specializing in TV News Is Acquired
text: N. S. Bienstock, the best-known and largest agency serving television news personalities and producers, including Anderson Cooper and Bill O’Reilly, has become a unit of the United Talent Agency, the major Hollywood representation firm.

headline: Caroline Shaw: 'Improvisation'
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Caroline Shaw performs an improvised piece with violin, voice and a loop station.

headline: Feeling For | A Modern Heirloom from Fine Jewelry’s Heiress Apparent
text: Among the usual presentations by the fine-jewelry stalwarts of the Place Vendôme happening this couture week, one newcomer stands out. This Thursday, the young designer Charlotte Dauphin de la Rochefoucauld — of the aristocratic French family — will debut her label, Dauphin, with a collection of 21 sparkling yet streamlined styles that she describes as “an ode to a contemporary woman.” Her pieces have a pared-down, architectural quality, with contours molded to accommodate the body’s movements; this standout rose-gold-and-diamond collar took nine months to shape so that it sits on the shoulders and collarbone just so. It’s a marvel of minimalism — yet totally regal.

headline: Renée Fleming to Sing National Anthem at Super Bowl
text: When the soprano Renée Fleming steps up to the microphone at MetLife Stadium to sing “The Star-Spangled Banner” on Feb. 2, she will be the first opera singer ever to sing the anthem at the Super Bowl. That’s odd, given the song’s range (an octave and a half) and difficulty, but so far the closest the NFL has come to having an opera star sing the anthem was in 2002, when it tapped Mariah Carey, whose mother was an opera singer (and who had the necessary range).

headline: An Old Tale for a New Year
text: New York City, which has the largest Chinese population of any city outside Asia, will celebrate the Lunar New Year with a bang on Jan. 31, heralding the start of the Year of the Horse. According to “The Race for the Chinese Zodiac,” by Gabrielle Wang, with illustrations by Sally Rippin, “horses are funny, popular, fearless and hard-working. … They are also confident, spirited, honest, sensitive and brave.” Those born in 1930, 1942, 1954, 1966, 1978, 1990 and 2002 (and any babies expected in 2014) can count themselves lucky to be born under the energetic Equus.

headline: Chilean League Fines Club for Map of Palestine on Jersey
text: A club in Chile that is popular among fans of Palestinian descent has been fined by the country’s soccer league for wearing game jerseys in which the No. 1 was depicted by a 1947 map of Palestine before the creation of Israel.

headline: Violent Protests in Ukraine
text: Scenes from Kiev, where two protesters were killed during clashes with the police.

headline: Quiet in the Caribbean
text: I wrapped my arms around Leonardo, our “moto” driver, as he pushed our overloaded Yamaha across the hot, potholed concrete.

headline: Restaurant Report: Fishing With Dynamite in Manhattan Beach, Calif.
text: When putting together Fishing With Dynamite, David LeFevre had a specific sort of nostalgia in mind. The floor tiles are stripes of red, orange and blue; the chef and owner said they reminded him of the classic Ocean Pacific T-shirt with a sunset emblazoned across the chest. Beneath the bar, skateboard trucks have been repurposed as hooks for purses, and Japanese lobster buoys hang from the ceiling. “It took probably 50 visits to flea markets over two years,” said Mr. LeFevre about compiling items to decorate his East Coast-meets-West Coast seafood restaurant, which opened in April. “It was tough to describe, but I knew when people saw it, they would be like, ‘Oh, God, the space is so comfortable and right.’ ”

headline: Singing, Dancing and Economics
text: January is a heady, if exhausting, month in New York for lovers of experimental theater. If you didn’t get your fill at the Under the Radar or the Coil festivals, fear not. Just around the corner is more venturesome theater, this time from the acclaimed collective Rude Mechanicals from Austin, Tex. The company has previously presented its productions “The Method Gun” and “Dionysus in 69” in the city. Those shows illustrated the company’s interest in exploring the history of theater making; the latest production tilts toward Hollywood.

headline: A Note on the Political Economy of Populism
text: All indications are that President Obama will make inequality the central theme of his State of the Union address. Assuming he does, he will face two different kinds of sniping. One will come from the usual suspects on the right, shrieking “class warfare”. The other will come from a variety of people, some of them well-intentioned, arguing that while sure, inequality is an issue, the crucial thing now is to get the economy growing and create more jobs; these people will argue that populism is a diversion from the main issue.

headline: VMware Looks to Improve Its Cloud With AirWatch
text: For the technology world, 2014 has become momentous quickly, with billions of dollars moving around and thousands of people losing their jobs. It is all happening as the industry builds for the dominant feature of the next few decades: supercomputing everywhere.

headline: Video of Vigil for Purdue Student Shot and Killed in Classroom
text: More than 1,000 students and staff members at Purdue University gathered in the bitter cold for a candlelight vigil Tuesday night to remember 21-year-old Andrew Boldt, who was shot and killed inside a classroom in the university’s Electrical Engineering Building by a fellow teaching assistant.

headline: London Theater Journal: Running Their Mouths
text: LONDON — For all those arriving here limply from distant shores, there’s a guaranteed cure for jet lag at the Harold Pinter Theater. It’s called “Mojo,” and it turns out to be the West End’s version of a quad espresso, laced with steroids.

headline: Car Seats to Face Crash-Test Standards
text: DETROIT — Federal regulators moved on Wednesday to address a glaring hole in auto safety rules by proposing new crash-test standards to better protect children in car seats.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Spring 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: In Performance: Caroline Shaw
text: “I don’t really call myself a composer,” Caroline Shaw told Zachary Woolfe, writing for The Times, despite the fact that she won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in Music for “Partita for Eight Voices,” a vocal work that Mr. Woolfe described as a “dazzling, emotionally generous take on a Baroque dance suite.”

headline: Chinese Activist’s Lawyers Call His Trial Unfair
text: BEIJING — The central actors in the trial of one of China’s most influential legal activists remained largely silent on Wednesday morning to protest what they said were flaws in the country’s politicized judiciary.

headline: At a Mexican Hotel, Plump a Pillow, Adopt a Pet
text: Travelers don’t need frequent flyer points to get a free night at an upscale hotel in Mexico. They just need to be willing to go home with a little extra baggage.

headline: Snow Jobs
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’m starting this conversation off on a train leaving a very snowy New Haven. The original plan was to make it home to Washington, but I’m pretty sure that in an hour or so the train will be inundated by snow. Mass panic will overtake the passengers.
