There will be an apocalyptic war of all against all in the snack car, as various passengers claw for the few remaining turkey sandwiches while I am scrunched over in the corner hoarding the little bottles of Chablis. Picture that Cormac McCarthy novel, “The Road.” You’ll have the general idea.

headline: Former Foxconn Managers Detained in a Bribery Case
text: SHANGHAI — Authorities in Taiwan detained several former managers of Foxconn Technology on Wednesday as part of a widening investigation into whether they accepted millions of dollars in bribes from the company’s supply-chain partners.

headline: Japan’s Leader Revels in Limelight at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Few of the panels organized by the World Economic Forum this year had drawn as much anticipation as the one featuring Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe.

headline: U.S. Panel Suggests Ways to Reduce Voting Delays
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan panel created by President Obama after many voters waited hours to cast ballots in 2012 on Wednesday recommended ways to keep delays to no more than a half-hour. But changes are up to the states and 8,000 local jurisdictions, where voting laws have been a partisan battleground since the 2000 presidential recount.

headline: Classical Playlist: Olivia Block, William Christie, Raschèr Saxophone Quartet and More
text: BLOCK: ‘Karren’Olivia Block, electronics, field recordings(Sedimental)Known as a designer of aural environments, the Chicago musician Olivia Block gets lumped together with electronic improvisers and installation artists. That might not be altogether wrong, but the two tremendous pieces that constitute her newest LP are as rigorously assembled, finely detailed and dramatically taut as any modern composition you might care to name, each evoking a dreamlike story without words. (Steve Smith)

headline: Bankers Urge Britain to Remain Part of European Union
text: LONDON — The British Bankers’ Association and Citigroup have filed notice with the British government strongly backing a single market, the European Union. The two are emphatically encouraging Britain to step up its influence in Brussels rather than pull back as public sentiment in Britain for inclusion in the European Union wanes.

headline: When They Don’t Know They Are Ill
text: Soon after his wife was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia, Bill Floyd consulted a neurologist who had been a member of his church. People with this illness don’t know they have it, the doctor warned. They don’t understand that anything is wrong.

headline: Obama Seeks to Raise Awareness of Rape on Campus
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday renewed pressure on colleges and universities to prevent and police sexual assaults on their campuses, creating a task force of senior administration officials to coordinate federal enforcement efforts.

headline: Art About Nothing. No, Really.
text: The acoustics in the Werner and Elaine Dannheisser Lobby Gallery, on the fourth floor of the Museum of Modern Art, aren’t so great — or not ideal, at least, for dancing nonstop while reciting John Cage’s seminal “Lecture on Nothing,” as Eszter Salamon does in her 2010 solo “Dance for Nothing.”

headline: Paris Couture Week: Alexandre Vauthier Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Crowdfunding Tips for Turning Inspiration Into Reality
text: MIKE WHITEHEAD’S big idea was to design a better cast-iron skillet. Stephanie Turenko’s big idea was to make an animated short film about her Ukrainian grandmother. Colin Owen’s big idea was to manufacture a hard-to-steal bike light.

headline: Skier Flirts With Danger
text: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” professional skiers Todd Ligare and others discover a technical line in Alaska that requires jumping two crevasses.

headline: Americans Scramble for Propane Amid High Prices and Bitter Cold
text: As a second arctic blast barreled through most of the Midwest and Northeast this week, Americans who use propane to heat their homes are scrambling to deal with sharply higher prices and a limited access to the fuel.

headline: Nuclear Corps, Sidelined in Terror Fight, Produces a Culture of Cheating
text: WASHINGTON — Top military officials were quick to voice outrage over revelations last week that 34 officers responsible for launching the nation’s nuclear missiles cheated on monthly proficiency tests, but few expressed surprise.

headline: Bigger Role for Video Games Is Planned at Tribeca Film Festival
text: The annual Games for Change festival, which promotes the development and distribution of video games with an educational or social-minded focus, will partner with the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival, the organizers announced this week. While video games have had a presence at the film festival — Rockstar’s “L.A. Noire” was featured in 2011, and Sony’s “Beyond: Two Souls” was included in 2013 — this partnership represents a more formal integration of games and films.

headline: Shifts in Art Market at Center of Loeb-Sotheby’s Debate
text: Daniel S. Loeb is wrestling with Sotheby’s over a new art paradigm. Mr. Loeb, the founder of the hedge fund Third Point, is essentially estimating the the auction house should be more like its privately held archrival Christie’s.

headline: Next for Tony-Winning Actor Porter: Writing a New Play
text: New works by Billy Porter (the star of “Kinky Boots”), David Ives (“Venus in Fur”) and the New York premiere of a comedy by Theresa Rebeck (“Smash”) will make up the 2014-15 season at Primary Stages, the Off Broadway company announced on Wednesday. Casting and run dates are to be announced.

headline: Pain Relievers May Amplify Flu Spread
text: Taking drugs like aspirin, acetaminophen or ibuprofen when you have the flu reduces fever and makes you feel better, but it may have unintended consequences.

headline: Video: Skier Flirts With Danger, and Almost Pays
text: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Goodyear Reaches Severance Deal With French Union
text: PARIS — Striking workers at a Goodyear tire plant in France agreed on Wednesday to accept severance pay that they said was three times as much as the company had initially offered, clearing the way for the facility to close after a bitter conflict that escalated into a “boss-napping.”

headline: Santander Consumer Prices I.P.O. at $24 a Share
text: Updated, 7:10 p.m. | Santander Consumer USA, the American auto-lending arm of the Spanish banking giant Grupo Santander, priced its initial public offering at $24 a share, a person briefed on the process said late Wednesday.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Invests in Human Resources Firm Zenefits
text: Venture capitalists, it seems, are crazy about human resources software.

headline: The Gun Report: January 22, 2014
text: Dinyal New, 41, lost her only children to gun violence in the span of 19 days. Lee Weathersby, 13, who was a strong student at Alliance Academy in east Oakland, Calif., was gunned down as he made his way home from a party at the Boys & Girls Club on New Year’s Eve.

headline: App Smart: Tracking Food Intake
text: The Times’s Kit Eaton discusses three apps to help you keep tabs on what you eat.

headline: Watch What You Eat, Using Your Phone as a Guide
text: I have always been skinny, but I do need to watch what I eat. So I count my calories — with the help of smartphone and tablet apps.

headline: Dabbling in Microsoft Is Enough for Gates
text: Bill Gates, the chairman and former chief executive of Microsoft, is more involved with the company now than he has been in years. But he does not — repeat, not — want to run it.

headline: Report Says China’s Elite Use Offshore Companies
text: BEIJING — Members of the Chinese elite, including some of the country’s most politically connected figures, have set up a large number of offshore companies that allow them to conceal billions of dollars abroad, according to a report released Wednesday by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, a Washington-based group that works with a number of news organizations around the world.

headline: Springsteen Is No. 1
text: This week on the music charts, Bruce Springsteen has racked up yet another No. 1.

headline: Below the Line: Production Design on ‘12 Years a Slave’
text: After envisioning larger-than-life sets for Wes Anderson, the production designer Adam Stockhausen had to make the transition from whimsical to historical for “12 Years a Slave.” The designer, who along with the set decorator Alice Baker, is up for an Oscar for the film, said that there are similarities between Mr. Anderson’s more upbeat projects (“Moonrise Kingdom,” the upcoming “Grand Budapest Hotel”) and Steve McQueen’s somber slave drama.

headline: Vintage Tools Help Turn Appetizers Into a Meal
text: Like a glass of prosecco before a more robust wine, Haydn’s sunny string quartets are often served as an appetizer to a weightier work. But the London Haydn Quartet  has sought to elevate the status of Haydn’s some 75 string quartets, exploring the many neglected gems of his vast catalog.

headline: NBC Looks to Cosby to Revive Its Comedy Prospects
text: Few performers in history have meant more to a network than Bill Cosby has to NBC, so it is hardly surprising that NBC has reached out again to the famous comic in what appears to be another hour of comedy need.

headline: Living in Manhasset, N.Y.
text: An affluent Nassau County hamlet within the Town of North Hempstead is an easy commute from Manhattan.

headline: Couture in Paris
text: Couture designers show their collections in Paris

headline: A Place on Manhattanites’ Map
text: Patrice Burke and her husband, Tim, are on the verge of moving into a two-bedroom two-and-a-half-bath house across from a small park in the heart of Manhasset, steps from the train station. “It’s a wonderful neighborhood, where people really care about their kids, and other people’s kids,” said Ms. Burke, who has a 2-year-old son but has had longer experience with child care in the community as an occasional babysitter for her brother’s children, now 8 and 11.

headline: Renowned Scholar in Egypt Charged With Espionage
text: CAIRO — An internationally respected Egyptian political scientist said Wednesday that prosecutors had filed espionage charges against him, making him the second such scholar targeted this month in a widening crackdown on dissent against last summer’s military takeover.

headline: New Forces Join Lawsuit Fighting Palisades Tower
text: Two months after work began on LG Electronics USA’s new headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., new opponents have jumped in the battle to scale back the project, which they see as a blight on the Hudson River landscape.

headline: Yanks on a Budget? Yeah, Right
text: You’re rich and you’re famished and you’re eager for something new. You find the fanciest restaurant, order everything on the menu and raise a toast. Problems solved. This is going to cost you, but you knew that when you walked in.

headline: A Race Against Time for a Second Child
text: Updated, 9:27 a.m. |

headline: Scene City: Another Night for Armani
text: Giorgio Armani hosts “Only Night Only” fete during Paris Couture Fashion Week.

headline: Justices Seem Stumped on Calculating Damages Over Child Pornography
text: WASHINGTON — In a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday that was part math problem and part seminar on the nature of culpability, the justices seemed to agree on just two things.

headline: A Long and Winding Road
text: Sometimes when I’m facing uncertainty or upheaval, I try to think back to what I expected life to be like as a professional soccer player when I first made that my goal.

headline: An Upbeat Brown Urges California to Save Surplus
text: SACRAMENTO — When Gov. Jerry Brown stepped up on Wednesday to deliver his 11th State of the State speech — a record for California, he was told — the governor momentarily put aside his prepared remarks to offer a more casual greeting.

headline: Airy Enough to Take Flight
text: Magical handwork separates haute couture from the rest of fashion, but it depends on modern ideas to be relevant. Looking at the Paris spring shows online, what stands out are lightness and agility, soothing colors and a reductive view of luxury that feels unusually sensitive to the times.

headline: Putin’s Olympic Fever Dream
text: Anatoly Pakhomov was elected mayor of Sochi after the type of ersatz campaign that passes for democracy in Russia. It was 2009, and he had been appointed acting mayor — effectively the local manager of the massive construction project already underway — and in Russia incumbency means victory. His many prospective challengers included a K.G.B. veteran accused of poisoning the fugitive secret-service officer Aleksandr Litvinenko with polonium; a prima ballerina who had become even more famous after the Bolshoi dismissed her for being overweight; and a pornographic actress, Yelena Berkova, who ran a campaign ad that showed her gamboling topless along one of the Black Sea beaches that first made Sochi popular in the early 20th century.

headline: Treasury Secretary Sends Warning on Debt Limit
text: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew warned Congress on Wednesday that the government would most likely exhaust its ability to borrow in late February, setting up yet another fiscal showdown with Republicans, and this time earlier than congressional leaders had anticipated.

headline: Absence of Snow Brings Out Hikers and Horses in Yosemite
text: One skier’s drought is a potential hiker’s gift.

headline: Expanding the Meaning of ‘One Night’
text: PARIS — “One night only?” the editor of a prominent fashion magazine asked as she glanced at the invitation summoning her and practically the entire fashion crowd gathered in Paris for the couture shows this week to a dinner party being hosted by the designer Giorgio Armani. “If so, it must be the longest night in history.”

headline: Rangers Trade Del Zotto to Predators
text: The Rangers traded defenseman Michael Del Zotto, who was once considered one of their most promising prospects, to the Nashville Predators on Wednesday for defenseman Kevin Klein.

headline: “I Watched The Film The Song Remains The Same”
text: A new song by Sun Kil Moon.

headline: The Tea Party and Conservative Reform
text: My Sunday column hailed recent forays by Senators Mike Lee and Marco Rubio as evidence that finally, finally, the ideas that conservative policy reformers have been batting around for a few years may be getting some traction in actual Republican politics. Along the way, I briefly characterized the Tea Party-versus-establishment battle that’s dominated G.O.P. politics as having a “policy substrate,” but too often just being “about posturing and score-settling.” This was, of course, a simplification of a more complex story, and I appreciate the response from Mike Needham of Heritage Action — a figure, it’s fair to say, much involved in the grassroots-establishment fight — because it gives me an opportunity to expand and clarify a bit.

headline: Ready to Strut in Ready-to-Rent
text: All the world is, alas, no longer a stage. ’Tis a red carpet.

headline: Interpreting the Data: 10 Ways to Teach Math and More Using Infographics
text: From stock prices and unemployment rates to trends in tuition and quality of life, the ability to understand and interpret quantitative data is more important than ever in understanding the world.

headline: Traveling Back in Time From the Left, With Context
text: Billy Yalowitz is a young man caught between generations. In “East Towards Home,” his one-act musical drama, the fictional Billy is a Jewish New Yorker, a self-described red-diaper baby (Mommy and Daddy were Communists) born too late for his parents’ revolution. Mostly he’s a Woodstock-era kid who gets stuck regularly in the apartment-building elevator being interrogated by old ladies whose distinguishing accessory is an omnipresent shopping cart.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Giorgio Armani Privé Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Robot Vacuum Makes War on Cat Hair
text: The robots are coming. Every week, it seems, announcements hail a coming era of personal robots: machines that will ingratiate themselves into our homes by liberating us from despised chores like folding fitted sheets.

headline: Roomba 880: A Clean Sweep
text: The Times’s Damon Darlin tests out the Roomba 880, which is quite an expensive vacuum cleaner that is worth the premium.

headline: Hints of Sierra Leone’s Progress From an Unexpected Source
text: One morning last April I was in Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital, reporting the story that ran in the magazine this past weekend about Jeffrey Wright’s attempt to mine gold in the country’s hinterlands. I first spent time in Sierra Leone 14 years ago, during its horrific civil war. Now I followed Wright — along with a team from a major expat mining company that he hoped would become his partner — into Sierra Leone’s statehouse. They were going to meet with the country’s president, Ernest Bai Koroma, to make sure they had the government’s support.

headline: New Products for Aging Hair
text: Keratin, a protein found in hair, is the star ingredient of many anti-aging products, though Dr. Alan J. Bauman, a hair expert, pointed out that “you can’t put keratin back into hair; you can only fill it in temporarily.” Here are a few recommendations.

headline: In Cape Town, Fashion With a Side of Fries
text: Step in to I Love My Laundry in Heritage Square in Cape Town, and you’ll think you’ve entered a glamorous wine bar or supper club. You’d be only partly right. The narrow room is dominated by a communal table flanked by 16 upholstered high-back chairs, and at a glance it seems that the only nod to the location’s peculiar name is the clotheslines strung with artwork, prints and pillowcases for sale, or the price tags attached to wine bottles with clothespins. But listen closely and you just might hear the whir of washing machines. I Love My Laundry is a dim sum bar. And an art and wine shop. And a weekly private fondue party. It’s also a front — literally — for a laundromat. In fact, laundry delivery is the core business.

headline: Valentino: Spring 2014 Couture
text: Paris

headline: In Milwaukee, a District for a Bite or a Brew
text: Walker’s Point is historically a factory ward and still home to a sprawling Allen-Bradley plant, operated by Rockwell Automation, and its landmark clock tower. In the past two years, small start-ups have re-energized this working-class neighborhood south of the Milwaukee River. Its cache of brick warehouses has drawn transplants including public Radio Milwaukee, which moved in last fall, and an outpost of the local Stone Creek Coffee. Now the city’s go-to district for innovative artisanal food, it also has a nice smattering of antiques shops for between-bites browsing.

headline: Icahn Adds eBay to His Targets in Technology
text: Updated, 7:08 p.m. | As if taking on Apple wasn’t enough, the activist investor Carl C. Icahn has another big technology company in his sights: eBay.

headline: Bunking With the Stars at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The leftover lobster was up to no good.

headline: An Extra 2 Seconds Means the World
text: Rachel Joyce’s second novel, “Perfect,” is better and less treacly than her first, “The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry.” It is eerier, too. Ms. Joyce builds her novel around two 11-year-old English boys who have heard that the year 1972 will be two seconds longer than other years and wonder about the cosmic consequences this change may have. It should go without saying that Ms. Joyce makes the two seconds matter a great deal.

headline: Times Minute | Deadly Protests in Kiev
text: Also on the Minute, Mayor Bill de Blasio responds to snowplowing complaints, and a pair of unlikely celebrities.

headline: Times Minute | Deadly Protests in Kiev
text: In the Video

headline: Tempting and Dangerous. They Sing, Too.
text: “Do you know what it means to be the insensate apparatus of a homicidal mythological order?” The composer and soprano Kate Soper, portraying Polyxo, one of three mellifluous murderesses of ancient legend, poses that question not long into “Here Be Sirens,” her substantial new musical-theater piece. The Morningside Opera is presenting the work’s premiere engagement at Dixon Place on the Lower East Side.

headline: Portable Charger Adds New Feature: Speakers
text: Typically, when a technology company expands its product line, it sticks to its strengths. PowerStick.com, the Canadian company behind the handy PowerStick portable charger, has lately been upgrading its line to offer new features, like increased battery life and solar technology.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza Strip, Pakistan and Philadelphia.

headline: Push Comes to Shove in Brooklyn
text: Snow fell at a punishing slant across the darkened warehouses along Union Street in Gowanus, Brooklyn. It couldn’t be further from the sunny retirement communities of Florida, but inside one former factory, the spirit of St. Petersburg lived on.

headline: Caucus Click: Ruing Roe
text: On the anniversary of the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade decision, abortion opponents gather in Washington for the annual March for Life, and, despite the exceptional cold, this year was no exception as hundreds of thousands marched through the capital.

headline: Sundance: Reactions From the Secret Screening of ‘Nymphomaniac’
text: PARK CITY, Utah — It was the whisper heard up and down the mountains and across the packed restaurants and pop-up lounges of Main Street here — which film would be the top-secret surprise screening that publicists and festival organizers at Sundance started touting early this week? Promising a “highly anticipated film by a major filmmaker” that should not be missed, the guesses included Wes Anderson’s “Grand Budapest Hotel,” Lars von Trier’s epic “Nymphomaniac” and — jokingly — the next Tyler Perry or Muppets movie.

headline: England’s Angry Young Man Returns as a Live Wire With Attitude
text: A sense of isolation seems an unlikely affliction for the protagonist of the new stage adaptation of “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner,” the story by Alan Sillitoe that was made into a classic 1962 British movie. As portrayed by a dynamic Sheldon Best in Roy Williams’s contemporary rewrite, at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2, the disaffected Colin bounces around the stage with a buoyant energy that’s matched by his assertiveness and his verbal agility. Far from being a moody sort festering with grievances against a culture determined to put him in a box, this Colin seems to have enough drive to punch his way through any barriers.

headline: For Tresses Feeling Their Age
text: Is hair the new skin? Serums, BB creams, massages and lasers are among the new products and services addressing the issue of women’s aging locks. Many go well beyond covering the gray, which has been the market’s focus (indeed, Diane Keaton let her gray shine, to widespread acclaim, at the Golden Globes).

headline: A Vogue Alum Dives Into Digital With Zappos
text: IN THE 11 MONTHS since the fashion eminence André Leon Talley parted company with Vogue, he has pursued a number of new gigs. Since February, he has been an editor at large for the Russian version of Numéro magazine. There was talk of a late-night TV show, which has not gotten off the ground. “Nothing has happened with that recently, no meetings, nothing is happening,” Mr. Talley said. (“My Ed McMahon would be Gloria von Thurn und Taxis,” he joked.) Recently he interviewed Diane von Furstenberg for “Entertainment Tonight.”

headline: A Tudor Soap Opera Fills a Stage
text: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — Thomas Cromwell, the guileful right hand to King Henry VIII, was said to be fluent in many tongues and adept at double talk in all of them. But I imagine even he would be impressed by the act of translation that is taking place in his name at the Swan Theater here.

headline: A How-Not-To Manual for Working Politicians
text: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were accused Tuesday of taking more than $160,000 in loans and gifts in a quid-pro-quo relationship with a favored campaign donor, Jonnie R. Williams, Sr. The couple denied the charges and the courts will ultimately settle the accusation of criminality. Still, the federal indictment, with its glittery descriptions, reads as a How-Not-To manual for working politicians.

headline: The Women’s Under-26 Trial for World Youth Teams
text: Only three teams entered the women’s under-26 trial in Atlanta at the beginning of this month. A round robin eliminated one, and the other two played a 96-board match to determine the American entry in the World Youth Teams Championships.

headline: Feeling For | An Eco-Lightbulb that Looks Better Naked
text: Old-fashioned filament bulbs may cast a warm, flattering light, but their century-old technology leaves a substantial carbon footprint. What’s more, they’re in trouble with the law. A federal regulation passed in 2007 calls for the production of energy-wasting incandescents to effectively cease as of Jan. 1 of this year — though existing bulbs will remain on store shelves, and ambience-minded interior designers aware of the regulation have for several years been furtively stockpiling them. Last week, Congressional Republicans — apparently not fans themselves of the ghoulish glow of energy-efficient compact fluorescent (C.F.L.) bulbs — attached a provision to the new spending bill that eliminates funding for the law’s enforcement.

headline: The Bubble Canard
text: Ah, this one never goes away. I’ll leave the cleanup in the excellent hands of Dean Baker. He’s right to say that anyone trying to make this particular claim is revealing what’s wrong with them, not with me. But I’d quarrel with his “either a fool or a liar” line; why not both?

headline: In the Founder’s Footsteps
text: The experience of Balanchine choreography in performance is as intensely multilayered as anything in the arts. A little ballet, less than 20 minutes long, can plunge us into consuming revelations of style, expression, drama, history, morality, entertainment; into a demonstration of dancing to music as the most exciting interconnection of time and space possible; into complex overlaps among classicism, Romanticism and modernism; into the tension between pure form and poetic communication. And into the capacity of human beings to demonstrate the ideal.

headline: Wells Fargo Sells Servicing Rights on $39 Billion in Mortgages
text: In another sign of the banking industry’s retreat from the mortgage market, Wells Fargo is selling servicing rights on $39 billion of home loans to a nonbanking firm.

headline: Bugs in Chrome Browser Could Give Access to Microphones
text: Web developers can exploit bugs in Google’s Chrome browser to listen through a computer’s microphone — even if the browser window is not open, according to a developer who publicly reported the vulnerability Wednesday.

headline: Gaining Accolades, Friends and Steam
text: LOS ANGELES — Lupita Nyong’o was giving a surprise birthday party for her best friend, Ben Kahn. She pulled out a tray of sweets — “vegan, gluten free,” she noted — and organized a rendition of “Happy Birthday” as Mr. Kahn, 32, who has known Ms. Nyong’o since their college days, grinned. He was being feted at a glittery, exclusive soiree here, surrounded by Hollywood luminaries.

headline: When Your Smartphone Shuts Down From the Cold
text: Imagine this: You’re shoveling snow in the blistering cold from another arctic blast. You stop for a moment and pull out your smartphone to see the temperature — “Is it minus 10 degrees yet? It feels like minus 30.” — then your phone shuts off. You frantically press the power button a few times. Nothing. It’s dead, or at least it seems that way.

headline: Excerpt: 'Rake'
text: Greg Kinnear stars as a troubled lawyer in this new Fox comedy.

headline: The Euthanasia of the Rentier
text: A commenter quotes John Maynard Keynes:

headline: He’s a Train Wreck, but Still Kinda Cute
text: He is late, yes, but he is under a lot of pressure. He can’t understand why she can’t understand.

headline: A Stifled Soul Toughs It Out With At-Home Acts
text: “Towheads,” a film written and directed by and starring Shannon Plumb, is a whimsical yet deeply disturbing story about the infantilization and isolation of a stay-at-home mom in Brooklyn. Penelope (Ms. Plumb) is a creative woman with two young children who is trapped under the economic thumb of her husband, Matt, a film director (played by Ms. Plumb’s husband, the director Derek Cianfrance). Matt’s face is not shown, a treatment similar to the handling of adults in a “Peanuts” animated special.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales Starting the Week of Jan. 23
text: Hitting the Racks

headline: Verizon Publishes First Transparency Report on Data Requests
text: Verizon Communications on Wednesday published a so-called transparency report describing when and why it receives requests for customer data, like phone records or emails, from law enforcement and government agencies.

headline: The Source | Theaster Gates
text: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Theaster Gates.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Snowfall in New York
text: After a foot of snow hit New York City overnight, travelers complained of canceled journeys and uncleared streets. In his first major test the new mayor, Bill de Blasio, defended the city's response.

headline: Fraternity Suspended After King Day-Themed Party Mocks Blacks
text: Arizona State University suspended a fraternity, Tau Kappa Epsilon, after members organized a Martin Luther King Day “Black Party,” mocking African-Americans. The fraternity urged guests to show up wearing hoodies, baggy basketball jerseys and bandannas and then share photos of themselves on social media platforms, using hashtags #blackoutformlk, #ihaveadream and #mlkparty.

headline: A Chat With Greenpeace’s Departing U.S. Chief on Old and New Environmentalism
text: I was able to fit in 15 minutes this afternoon for an “exit interview,” in essence, with Phil Radford, who is leaving Greenpeace after 10 years of old-fashioned and innovative environmental activism, five at the helm of the organization’s American branch.

headline: Lenovo Near Deal for IBM’s Server Business
text: Lenovo is close to finalizing a deal for IBM’s low-end server business, according to people briefed on the process.

headline: Footage of Mayhem on the Streets of Kiev
text: As my colleague David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, at least two protesters were shot to death on the streets of the Ukrainian capital on Wednesday during pitched battles between the riot police and demonstrators.

headline: When Making Money Is an Obsession
Tsongas’s Cancer Battle
U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,293 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: The Middle-Class Squeeze
text: To the Editor:

headline: Occupy Starbucks?
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Resting Place for France’s ‘Great Men,’ Calls to Include More Women
text: PARIS — As the builders were putting the final stones in place on the Panthéon, France’s monument to some of its most important figures, a young Napoleon wrote, “Men of genius are meteors destined to burn to light their century.”

headline: Purpose After the War
text: To the Editor:

headline: Child Hunger in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strong Finish to 2013 for Netflix as Profit and Subscriptions Soar
text: Netflix racked up another quarter of impressive growth to finish 2013, surpassing 30 million paid subscribers in the United States for the first time and predicting continued growth through the first quarter of this year.

headline: A New World Around Every Corner
text: Not unlike Christopher Columbus, Joseph Gonzalez is in search of the New World. And he has found it some 480 times.

headline: Finding a Needle in a Digital Haystack
text: PLEASANTON, Calif. — LAST year the private sector spent $67.2 billion on cybersecurity services. Nevertheless, according to a recent investigation by Verizon, 60 percent of successful hacks were not detected until months after the attacks began. In the wake of recent high-profile hacker attacks against Target, Neiman Marcus and other retailers, the obvious question is: Why hasn’t all that money done any good?

headline: A Second Chemical Was Part of West Virginia Chemical Spill, Company Reveals
text: The chemical spill that left 300,000 West Virginia residents without usable water involved more chemicals than the company responsible had previously reported, officials revealed this week, leading the state’s Department of Environmental Protection to order that company to give a full accounting of the chemicals that had leaked into the Elk River.

headline: Abortion Opponents March in Washington on Anniversary of Roe v. Wade Decision
text: Thousands of abortion opponents descended on Washington for the annual March for Life rally on Wednesday on the 41st anniversary of the decision in Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court case that legalized abortion.

headline: Owning Up to Being a Home-Schooling Parent
text: Sitting across from the principal, I tried to argue — in a logical, lawyerly way — that my third grader’s standardized test scores were compelling evidence that she needed more than “Clifford, the Big Red Dog.” Although my daughter was bored to distraction by the simple books the teacher assigned, maybe I should have thought twice before requesting special treatment.

headline: U.S. Offshore Wind Farm, Made in Europe
text: MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass. — Carl Horstmann strode around the floor of his factory here, passing welders honing head-high metal tubes as sparks flew. He is one of a dying breed: the owner of Mass Tank, a steel tank manufacturer in a down-at-the-heels region that was once a hub of the craft.

headline: Serena Williams May End Boycott of Event at Indian Wells
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Thanks in part to a movie about Nelson Mandela, Serena Williams has moved toward ending her more than decade-long absence from a high-profile tour event in Indian Wells, Calif.

headline: Own Less, Live More
text: An Oregon couple is liberated by a house that is cheap to operate and small enough to vacuum in five minutes.

headline: Freedom in 704 Square Feet
text: Early in their marriage, Lily Copenagle and Jamie Kennel began crafting a plan for living, scribbling house designs and lists of must-haves on notepads and paper napkins.

headline: We’ve Got Your Number
text: A generation ago, the Supreme Court was faced with deciding whether the police needed a warrant before installing a newfangled device at a telephone company switching office that could record the numbers dialed from a particular telephone. The answer the court gave was no.

headline: The Source | Theaster Gates in Conversation With Doug Aitken
text: “I have this great problem of space,” Theaster Gates says. “When planners use words like blight and underdeveloped, it’s like actually what you are talking about is available land.” The artist and urban planner talks to Doug Aitken in an abandoned property on Chicago’s South Side that he calls the Archive House. By adding a reading room and a space for records, Gates has reimagined the property as a hub for artists. Gates (who chatted with Perry Chen of Kickstarter in a conversation published by T last year) has made it his mission to repurpose unused buildings to transform local communities. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Michigan Governor Asks State Lawmakers to Provide $350 Million for Detroit
text: DETROIT — With time growing short for leaders here to file a plan for this city’s emergence from bankruptcy, Gov. Rick Snyder on Wednesday urged Michigan’s Legislature to provide $350 million to lessen possible cuts to the pensions of Detroit retirees and save the city’s art collection from the threat of sale.

headline: A Tell-All Born From Goldman Gossip
text: The parody Twitter account @GSElevator, a stream of darkly funny, frequently callous anonymous snippets purportedly overheard in elevators at Goldman Sachs, has offered comments on a dizzying range of topics to its more than 600,000 followers.

headline: Reading Books Is Fundamental
text: The first thing I can remember buying for myself, aside from candy, of course, was not a toy. It was a book.

headline: The Luck of the Pontiff
text: President Obama is going to visit the pope! He’s been to the Vatican before, but not with this pope, who is perhaps the only person in the world almost everybody likes.

headline: Lessons Learned, H&M Returns to Super Bowl With New Beckham Spot
text: THE Seattle Seahawks are not the only ones returning to the Super Bowl for a second appearance. So, too, is the retailer H&M, coming back with a commercial that seeks to build on what the company learned two years ago.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Schedule Is Unexpectedly Open After Lindsey Vonn’s Season-Ending Injury
text: SAN DIEGO — For someone who feels as much at home here as a Torrey pine, Tiger Woods enters this week’s Farmers Insurance Open feeling strangely out of sorts. Because of the PGA Tour’s switch to a wraparound schedule that began in October instead of January, Woods, the world’s top-ranked player and the reigning player of the year, will make his season debut Thursday from a pot-bunker-size hole in the FedEx Cup playoff race.

headline: Gay Marriages Confront Catholic School Rules
text: SAMMAMISH, Wash. — Eastside Catholic prides itself on teaching acceptance. At the end of Crusader Way, by the school’s entrance, banners hang celebrating “relationships” and exhorting passers-by to “remember to take care of each other.” Students use a sign-language gesture to remind one another of the school’s emphasis on unconditional love.

headline: Martha Beck, Who Founded the Drawing Center in New York, Dies at 75
text: Martha Beck, an art curator who made use of a converted warehouse to found the Drawing Center, an alternative museum in downtown Manhattan that provided a first showplace for emerging artists and an unlikely setting for rarely seen drawings by the likes of Michelangelo, Rembrandt and Cézanne, was found dead on Jan. 6 in her apartment in Manhattan. She was 75.

headline: Giants Hire Another Assistant for Offense
text: For the second time this month, the Giants hired a quarterbacks coach from the N.F.C. North to help resurrect their downtrodden offense.

headline: Modern Family Matters
text: When I asked readers for “neglected topics” that journalists should cover more in 2014, one of the suggestions was a delicate but vital topic: family breakdown and the rise of single-parent households.

headline: ‘No Luck’ for a Growing Family
text: It all started with small talk.

headline: Exporting U.S. Rules for Foreign Banks
text: One of the biggest loopholes on Wall Street may soon close.

headline: Ukrainian Standoff
text: The standoff in Kiev, Ukraine, is now two months old, and it has claimed its first fatalities: two men who died of bullet wounds and a third who fell to his death. With tensions at a dangerous level, and Ukraine’s citizens inflamed by both economic policy and new laws against public assembly, President Viktor Yanukovich met with the three most prominent opposition leaders: the popular boxer Vitali Klitschko, the former economics minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk, and the far-right nationalist Oleg Tyagnibok.

headline: Details Slip By Insider Trial’s Main Witness
text: Dr. Sidney Gilman, the government’s most important witness in the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, showed signs of a faulty memory on the stand on Wednesday.

headline: A Plan to Make Voting Easier
text: A superb report released Wednesday by the Presidential Commission on Election Administration can be summarized in one quick sentence: There are many ways to make voting easier in America. There shouldn’t be the slightest whiff of controversy or partisanship about that concept, or the important suggestions made in the report. But, of course, there is, and that makes the commission’s persuasive logic and research all the more valuable.

headline: Heavy Load in Japan, but a Star Is Used to It
text: When a high-profile Japanese pitcher comes to the United States, the news cycle breaks down into three parts: How good is he? How much will he cost? How much has his arm been abused?

headline: Leaning Right in Hollywood, Under a Lens
text: LOS ANGELES — In a famously left-leaning Hollywood, where Democratic fund-raisers fill the social calendar, Friends of Abe stands out as a conservative group that bucks the prevailing political winds.

headline: Political Rumble Over Pre-K
text: Leave it to New York’s top two political alpha males: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio are locked in a contest over something they both agree on. Mr. de Blasio wants to offer free, full-day prekindergarten to every 4-year-old in New York City and pay for it by raising taxes on wealthy residents. Mr. Cuomo is promising to pay for full-day prekindergarten across the entire state, without any tax increase.

headline: State Dept. Learned in November of Photos Said to Show Torture in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration first learned last November about a harrowing trove of photographs that were said to document widespread torture and executions in Syrian prisons when a State Department official viewed some of the images on a laptop belonging to an antigovernment activist, a senior official said Wednesday.

headline: De Blasio Sets Ambitious Goal for Affordable Apartments
text: After Mayor Edward I. Koch instituted his housing plan in the 1980s, New York City created tens of thousands of affordable apartments by renovating vacant buildings in neighborhoods that had been ravaged by arson and abandonment.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 22, 2014
New Push Is Made to Free an American While Iran Is at the Negotiating Table
text: Advocates for a former Marine imprisoned in Tehran more than two years ago are seeking to use a diplomatic window created by the temporary nuclear agreement with Iran to gain his release.

headline: Cousins, Across the Color Line
text: EL CERRITO, Calif. — I learned about her through the comments section of an article in Publisher’s Weekly. I had recently published a book of poems crafted out of family stories, and it had been written up, along with a brief interview. In the interview, I reckon with the complicated history of my family — I am a white descendant of Thomas Jefferson — and the fact that some of my ancestors were slave owners from 1670 until the Civil War.

headline: Seahawks’ Richard Sherman, Like Cornerbacks Before Him, Plays Man-to-Man and Goes Toe to Toe
text: SEATTLE — I spent three seasons of my college football career at Morgan State University backpedaling.

headline: Enjoying a Total Meltdown
text: Jeff Zimmerman, 45, a glass artist, has described his work as a series of “controlled accidents.” The latest results of his live-and-let-melt sensibility went on display this week at R & Company (formerly R 20th Century) in TriBeCa. It is Mr. Zimmerman’s fourth solo show, and it features the crinkled vessels he’s become known for, along with mirrors embedded with reflective glass orbs, geometric pendant lamps and a giant undulating chandelier.

headline: Fighting Extremism on a Broader Level
text: Instead of putting out fires following every disaster fueled by sectarian violence, what can world leaders do to fight extremism on a more permanent, global level?

headline: Helping Poor Defendants Post Bail in Backlogged Bronx
text: In October, James Broadus II, then 31, was arrested in Co-op City, the Bronx, and charged with petty larceny and assault. He was accused of taking a book bag from one man and choking another. A judge set bail at $1,000.

headline: Comment by Cuomo Outrages Republicans
text: ALBANY — Still searching for a way, and a person, to beat Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo this fall, the state’s Republican Party may have, at least temporarily, found a talking point: comments by the governor that candidates who are “extreme conservatives” — which he defined as pro-assault weapon and anti-abortion — have “no place in the state of New York.”

headline: When Political Spouse Helps Cause a Downfall
text: Virginia’s first lady needed a designer dress for her husband’s inauguration.

headline: Organizer Says It Will Reinstate Appearance Fees for Top Racers
text: In a reversal, Competitor Group, the organizer of dozens of high-profile running events around the world, said it would immediately reinstate appearance fees for elite athletes.

headline: In New Jersey, Claims Elevate Mayor’s Profile
text: Friends call Dawn Zimmer the “accidental politician.”

headline: Lee and Morty Kaufman: Cleaning Up in Their 90s
text: Valley Stream, N.Y. — “I was retired for 30 years, until at the age of 90 I got swept up in this commercial bit,” Morty Kaufman said.

headline: Corrections: January 23, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Turkey: More Police Are Fired or Reassigned
text: Nearly 500 police officers were either fired or reassigned on Wednesday, local news outlets said, part of what appears to be a purge related to a graft inquiry that has already ensnared many of the prime minister’s allies. News reports said at least some of the reassigned officers took part in the large corruption investigation. Government critics fear the continuing changes in personnel — hundreds of police officers have already been purged — are meant to derail the investigation. Government officials insist, however, that the changes are legitimate efforts to eliminate what they call a “parallel state.” That refers to those in the judiciary and the police force loyal to a rival of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Wednesday’s reshuffle followed the relocation on Tuesday of nearly 100 judges and prosecutors, a move made during Mr. Erdogan’s first visit in five years to Brussels, where he confronted European Union officials’ concerns about the separation of powers and a free judiciary in Turkey.

headline: If You Want to Be Loved, Be Lovable
text: Administrivial Alert!In today’s (Thursday, Jan. 23, 2014) puzzle, there are elements in the print version that cannot be replicated electronically. We recommend using the PDF for the best solving experience.

headline: Family of South Carolina Boy Put to Death Seeks Exoneration 70 Years Later
text: SUMTER, S.C. — After South Carolina electrocuted George J. Stinney Jr. in 1944, his family buried his burned, 14-year-old body in an unmarked grave in the hopes the anonymity would allow him to rest in peace.

headline: Iran: Surge in Executions Worries Rights Experts
text: United Nations human rights experts called on Wednesday for an urgent halt to a surge in executions in Iran in recent weeks, observing that the more moderate tone adopted on human rights since President Hassan Rouhani’s election last year has yet to yield any moderation in the country’s punitive practices. Iran reportedly hanged 40 people in the first two weeks of January, 33 of them in the last week, Ahmed Shaheed, the United Nations expert monitoring human rights in Iran, and Christof Heyns, the organization’s expert dealing with summary executions, said in a joint statement released in Geneva. The hangings carried out by Iran since the start of the year follow the execution of 625 people, including 28 women, and a number of political detainees in 2013, an increase of more than 100 over the number of recorded executions the previous year, Mr. Shaheed said.

headline: South Korea: Kidnapped Trade Official Is Rescued
text: A South Korean trade official kidnapped by gunmen in the Libyan capital of Tripoli was rescued on Wednesday by local security forces, who raided the kidnappers’ hide-out, the South Korean Foreign Ministry said on Thursday. The official, Han Seok-woo, the head of the Tripoli office of the government-financed Korea Trade-Investment Promotion Agency, suffered no injuries during the rescue operation, the ministry said in a statement. “The four kidnappers were arrested by the Libyan security officials,” the statement added. Mr. Han, 39, was on his way home from work on Sunday afternoon when four gunmen stopped his car. South Korea then issued a warning against traveling to Libya and asked the 551 South Korean nationals there to leave.

headline: With ‘Virginia Way,’ State Thought It Didn’t Need Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The gift-giving scandal that federal prosecutors described in evocative detail in their indictment on corruption charges Tuesday of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, would be ample evidence of a possible crime in some states.

headline: New Speaker Gives Her Allies Plum Posts
text: Two weeks after prevailing in a bitter race for City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito on Wednesday distributed the spoils of her victory, rewarding allies and punishing at least a few adversaries as she assigned plum Council posts.

headline: Some Parents Bemoan Icy Treks as de Blasio Stands by Choice to Keep Schools Open
text: Anthony M. Armstrong, principal of Middle School 74 in Bayside, Queens, was having a miserable morning. He was groggy from a night of worrying about slippery sidewalks, and a tire on his Chevrolet Equinox had nearly gone flat on his way to work.

headline: Arizona Fraternity Party Stirs Concerns of Racism
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Arizona State University is investigating accusations that members of a fraternity gave a party to commemorate Martin Luther King’s Birthday at which nonblack students mocked blacks by donning loose basketball jerseys, flashing gang signs and drinking from hollowed-out watermelons.

headline: Fire Destroys Biodiesel Refinery in Mississippi
text: A small biodiesel refinery that turns chicken fat into truck fuel was reduced to ashes on Wednesday by powerful explosions and a huge fire.

headline: Hendrickson, Ailing Star in Ski Jump, Is Named to U.S. Team
text: Sarah Hendrickson, the reigning world champion in the women’s ski jump, was named to the United States Olympic team Wednesday even though she has not competed this season.

headline: A Secluded Compound in St. Thomas
text: This cliffside beach compound has island-stone walls embedded with coral and shells. It overlooks a quiet cove.

headline: House Hunting on ... St. Thomas
text: A BEACH BUNGALOW IN SECRET HARBOR

headline: The Call of the Worn
text: “I admit it, I’m a hoarder,” said Annie Hurlbut Zander, who often gets messages from antiques dealers telling her they’ve got something weird she needs to see. “That’s kind of what happens when you get a reputation for oddball stuff.”

headline: Douglas Davis, Newsweek Critic and Internet Artist, Dies at 80
text: Douglas Davis, who had parallel careers as an art critic for Newsweek and as an artist himself, doing work that explored the possibilities of video and the Internet as creative and interactive mediums, died on Jan. 16 in Queens. He was 80.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 23, 2014
text: “I have never seen a bigger outage. Half of the world’s Internet users trying to access the Internet couldn’t.”

headline: Knicks’ Defensive Disarray in Loss to 76ers Puts Woodson on the Spot
text: The list of items that have haunted Knicks Coach Mike Woodson started early this season — practically from opening night. There were personality conflicts with Iman Shumpert, then J. R. Smith, then Chris Smith, then Beno Udrih. Critics nitpicked Woodson’s lineup choices before games and then admonished him over his time management at the end of games. Woodson was not being tough enough on players. He was being too tough on players.

headline: Philadelphia Principals Fired in Cheating Scandal
text: Three Philadelphia Public Schools principals were fired last week after an investigation into test cheating that has implicated about 140 teachers and administrators, a spokesman for the district said Wednesday.

headline: Leslie Lee, Playwright Who Enlarged Black Life Onstage, Dies at 83
text: Leslie Lee, a playwright whose award-winning work, much of it with the Negro Ensemble Company, focused on stretching the boundaries of the African-American experience as it was portrayed on the stage, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: What You Get For … $700,000
text: A trilevel penthouse in St. Louis, a 1920s house in Madison, Wis., and a foursquare in Denver

headline: What You Get For ... $700,000
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: Sugar Bowls and Creamers: Adding Sweetness and Light
text: Like many people, Jane Kim enjoys a good cup of coffee. But as an architect who has designed several coffee shops, she has given more thought than most to what makes for a satisfying coffee-drinking experience.

headline: John J. McGinty III, Who Gave Away His Medal of Honor, Dies at 73
text: John J. McGinty III, a retired Marine Corps officer who received the Medal of Honor for saving the lives of dozens of his men during an enemy attack in Vietnam, but later relinquished it for religious reasons, died on Friday in Beaufort, S.C. He was 73.

headline: These Can Go Anywhere
text: Among the eclectic goods at the 60th Winter Antiques Show, which opens Friday, will be a set of library steps. “It’s an unusual piece of furniture,” said Wendell Castle, 81, who designed the piece in 1977 as a departure from staircases, which were more his usual thing. Speaking from his studio in Scottsville, N.Y., he added: “You don’t have to have a specific site. I always like to make things that can go anywhere.”

headline: A Niche for Oomph
text: PIQ, a gift shop that opened last week at Grand Central Terminal, in a space formerly occupied by Pylones, is, like its predecessor, wildly colorful. But the similarities end there. “The Pylones look was about cuteness, and I was tired of cuteness,” said Frédéric A. Rambaud, a founder of the Sarut Group, which manages Pylones stores in New York (two remain) and an owner of the new PIQ. “There’s a new aspect in retail that’s a mix of day-to-day with designer toys. So the grandmother can come in and find something for the grandchildren, and at the same time find something for herself.”

headline: Sales at Canvas, From the Source and Others
text: Everything on Arcadia Home’s website is 30 percent off, through Jan. 31 (a reverse painted mirror jewelry box, regularly $260, is $182; a hand-felted wool flowers tree skirt, regularly $340, is $238); use code HAPPY at checkout, arcadiahomeinc.com.

headline: Into Everyday Life, a Few Drops Fall
text: Ruan Hoffmann, who was born in Pretoria, South Africa, did not set out to be a product designer. He considers his expressionistic ceramic pieces to be art, not craft, and has shown them in galleries and museums throughout Africa and Europe. But after an exhibition of his work at the Anthropologie store in Rockefeller Center in 2011, the retailer encouraged him to create for a mass audience. Mr. Hoffmann set about designing everyday products that would enhance people’s lives. “It’s a big thing to ask of ordinary objects,” he said. “It’s a lot to wish for from a shower curtain, for instance, but then again it could be the catalyst for a daydream.” The Jardin Des Plantes collection, which will be introduced on Thursday, includes dinnerware, bedding, curtains, hardware, wallpaper, vases and, yes, a shower curtain ($108). The rest of the items are from $10 to $1,298. Information: 800-309-2500 or anthropologie.com.

headline: For the Laid-Back, a Limited Edition
text: David Weeks designed Semana, a leather-and-steel lounge chair, in 1999, but couldn’t find sturdy enough fabric for its production. (Habitat in London was able to solve that problem and sold the chair for 10 years, paying Mr. Weeks a royalty.) Then, while vacationing in Marfa, Tex., last year, he discovered Big Bend Saddlery, whose eighth-of-an-inch-thick leather had the heft he had long sought.

headline: Host’s Pride Rests on an Aging, and Aching, Star Skater
text: It has long been difficult to imagine Russia’s first Winter Olympics without Yevgeny Plushenko, and now that will no longer be necessary.

headline: Faded Beauty
text: In a life-size cabinet of curiosities in Kansas City, Mo., the strange and quirky intermingle, and reupholstering is frowned upon.

headline: Texas Executes Mexican Man for Murder
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Despite opposition from the State Department, Mexican officials and Latino advocates, Texas executed Edgar Arias Tamayo on Wednesday night, putting to death a Mexican citizen whose case raised questions about the state’s duty to abide by international law.

headline: Resort’s Artistic Streak
text: Usually, we see a designer’s sketches as insight into the creative process behind the final product. But in the resort collections, scribbles are front and center on statement garments and accessories. Chicken scratch has become a new way of coloring inside the lines, like on a Cedric Charlier shirt with a black scribbled collar set atop a salmon sketch pattern, or on a leather Balenciaga dress covered entirely in childlike scrawl. And as one standout piece — a herringbone-scribbled Marc Jacobs bag with a cheetah-print flap and pink-and-white handle — proves, these artistic accessories look best paired with other eye-catching patterns and colors.

headline: A Swede’s Second Set of Heartfelt Electronic Beats
text: “My music is the opposite of an escape,” says Eric Berglund, the mastermind and sole member of the Swedish synth-pop act CEO. Over the years, Berglund has become an iconic figure in the Swedish musical landscape, creating glossy arrangements equally indebted to Top 40 and experimental dance music. Before striking out on his own, Berglund was one half of the alt-pop duo The Tough Alliance, which during the mid-2000s helped to popularize the Balearic style, a more chilled-out, polycultural brand of dance pop inspired by Ibiza’s club D.J.s. The two also founded the Gothenburg-based record label Sincerely Yours, whose signees — including jj, Air France and The Honeydrips — share a similar sensibility.

headline: Financial Reform Remains a Work in Progress
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

text: lexicon •\ˈlek-sə-ˌkän also -kən\• noun

headline: Li Na Gets Back to Open Final; Wawrinka Reaches His First
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Li Na experience continued Thursday afternoon in what was billed as a news conference but came across more like a one-woman show. Li alternated between funny, introspective, philosophical and bemused.

headline: Watchdog Report Says N.S.A. Program Is Illegal and Should End
text: WASHINGTON — An independent federal privacy watchdog has concluded that the National Security Agency’s program to collect bulk phone call records has provided only “minimal” benefits in counterterrorism efforts, is illegal and should be shut down.

headline: Upward Mobility Has Not Declined, Study Says
text: The odds of moving up — or down — the income ladder in the United States have not changed appreciably in the last 20 years, according to a large new academic study that contradicts politicians in both parties who have claimed that income mobility is falling.

headline: Hoboken Mayor Is Said to Have Told of Threat
text: Federal authorities in New Jersey have interviewed several witnesses who said the mayor of Hoboken told them in May about a state official’s threat to withhold hurricane recovery funds if the mayor did not support a development project favored by the governor, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Security Check Firm Said to Have Defrauded U.S.
text: The company that conducted a background investigation on the contractor Edward J. Snowden fraudulently signed off on hundreds of thousands of incomplete security checks in recent years, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

headline: A Japanese Thread in the Bronx
text: It all began with Hideki Irabu, who joined the Yankees in 1997 but never lived up to the initial fanfare that greeted him. Hideki Matsui did fulfill expectations, arriving in 2003 and becoming a steady and admirable presence in the Yankee lineup through 2009. After Matsui came Kei Igawa, a left-hander who was unable to pitch effectively in the major leagues.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (Discovery) THE FIGHTERS In the gritty neighborhood of South Boston, boxing has a rich heritage as not merely a pastime but a way of life. But the sport’s popularity has declined over the past 20 years, and Peter Welch, the gym owner and former fighter above, is determined to bring it back. In this new series, Mr. Welch works with trainers from rival boxing gyms across the city, who will choose their top amateur fighters to represent them in bouts. After seven days of intensive training, the fighters will take their professional futures — and their reputations — to the ring.

headline: Governor Says It’s All Settled but the Money
text: Andrew M. Cuomo arrived at The New York Times in an expansive mood on Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo Sweetens Pre-K Deal: ‘Whatever’ Mayor Needs
text: A day after Mayor Bill de Blasio rebuffed his proposal to set aside $1.5 billion to pay for prekindergarten classes, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo came back on Wednesday with a new offer: a blank check.

headline: A Conversation With: Pankaj Ghemawat, IESE Business School Professor
text: Pankaj Ghemawat, a professor of global strategy at the IESE business school in Madrid, and Steven Altman, a senior research associate at IESE, released the 2013 Depth of Globalization report in November, which measures the globalization levels of 139 countries based on flows of trade, capital, information and people. The study found that India, ranked 123rd, was one of the least globalized economies.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o: ‘Impostor’ to Ingénue
text: This year’s Oscar ingenue is Ms. Nyong’o of “12 Years a Slave.” She says it took encouragement to get over the feeling of being an outsider, a phenomenon she dubs “acute impostor syndrome.”

headline: Chinese Rights Advocate Releases Statement on Goals
text: One of China’s best-known human rights advocates, Xu Zhiyong, went on trial in Beijing on Wednesday, accused of disturbing order by organizing public gatherings calling for equal rights to education and for officials to reveal their wealth. Mr. Xu remained silent in protest for much of the prosecution’s case, but then tried to defend himself in a statement to the court.

text: Take the Quiz

headline: Couture Styles

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A ‘Feminist Moment’ in the Food World
text: In “A Change in the Kitchen,” Julia Moskin writes about how a new vanguard of women is emerging as the next generation of leaders in the nation’s best restaurants.

headline: U.S. and Iran Offer Clashing Accounts of the Civil War in Syria
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Secretary of State John Kerry and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran offered clashing accounts on Thursday of the civil war in Syria, and the role that Tehran is playing in the conflict.

headline: Lonnie Holley, the Insider’s Outsider
text: One night in October, just a couple blocks from Harvard Square, a young crowd gathered at a music space called the Sinclair to catch a performance by Bill Callahan, the meticulous indie-rock lyricist who has been playing to bookish collegiate types since the early ‘90s. Callahan’s opening act, Lonnie Holley, had been playing to similar audiences for two years. A number of details about Holley made this fact surprising: He was decades older than just about everyone in the club and one of the few African-Americans. He says he grew up the seventh of 27 children in Jim Crow-era Alabama, where his schooling stopped around seventh grade. In his own, possibly unreliable telling, he says the woman who informally adopted him as an infant eventually traded him to another family for a pint of whiskey when he was 4. Holley also says he dug graves, picked trash at a drive-in, drank too much gin, was run over by a car and pronounced brain-dead, picked cotton, became a father at 15 (Holley now has 15 children), worked as a short-order cook at Disney World and did time at a notoriously brutal juvenile facility, the Alabama Industrial School for Negro Children in Mount Meigs.

headline: Where the Ice, and the Population, Is Thinning
text: The landscape in Ciril Jazbec’s photographs of the Arctic is impressive, but not nearly as captivating to him as the people whose daily routines have been affected by rising temperatures and tides. “I am interested in the people,” he said. “Climate change is merely in the background.”

headline: Why Do We Like to Watch Rich People on TV and in the Movies?
text: A recent Room for Debate post begins, “Several Academy Award contenders like ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’ and ‘American Hustle’ glorify white-collar criminals and scammers, and many reality TV shows embrace the wealthy, too. A new series, ‘#RichKids of Beverly Hills,’ is the latest example of our enthusiasm for ‘ogling the filthy rich.’ Why are we so obsessed with watching the antics of the 1 percent?”

headline: Lenovo Agrees to Buy IBM Server Business for $2.3 Billion
text: Lenovo said on Thursday that it would pay $2.3 billion for IBM’s low-end server business, successfully concluding a deal that had fizzled a year earlier after the two parties failed to agree on a price.

headline: China Tries to Close Provincial-Sized Hole in Economic Statistics
text: The growth figures for China’s provinces add up to more than the national total with several yet to report, a discrepancy that experts say can be chalked up to politics and poor bookkeeping.

headline: Man Posts Bail Amid Claims He Relayed Scores to Bettors

headline: A French Clown’s Hateful Gesture
text: PARIS — Sixteen years ago, the leader of the far-right National Front, Jean-Marie Le Pen, deemed the Holocaust a “detail in the history of the Second World War.” Today, a popular comic known as Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala (his stage name is simply Dieudonné) claims “not to know, between the Jews and Germans,” who’s telling the truth — “but I have my own little ideas on the subject.” We know what those ideas are: Dieudonné invited onstage at one of his shows Robert Faurisson, a “theorist” of Holocaust denial, who argues that the extermination of the European Jews is a Jewish invention.

headline: Tanaka Heads for a Strange Land With a Title in His Sights
text: TOKYO — Major league sluggers hit hard. Coaches are careful with pitch counts. And New York has bad weather.

headline: 2 Wall Street Moguls Champion Gay Rights
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – When the World Economic Forum made “inclusiveness” one of its pillar themes, it was safe to assume the assembled corporate leaders would discuss economic issues.

headline: Caution in Davos Over Report of Growth in Europe
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — An index of industrial activity in the euro zone has reached its highest level since mid-2011, according to a report released on Thursday. But policy makers, business leaders and economists gathered at the World Economic Forum here seem deeply skeptical about whether growth will be strong enough to cut high levels of youth unemployment in the bloc.

headline: Deciding How Much Employees and Owners Should Make
text: In my last post, I wrote about my decision not to pay year-end bonuses. As usual, I received some insightful comments in response, including several suggesting that I start sharing more information with my employees so that they have a better sense of how the company is doing. This is something I have thought about quite a bit and I intend to do.

headline: Investigative Stories Delve Into the Use of Offshore Companies by Chinese
text: The first big China investigative story of the year has come from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which on Tuesday published, in tandem with several Western news organizations, a detailed look at the widespread use of offshore companies and tax havens by Chinese businesspeople and relatives of Communist Party leaders.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Names New Music Director
text: The Bolshoi Theater has named Tugan Sokhiev of the Orchestre National du Capitole in Toulouse, France, as its new music director and chief conductor, the theater announced earlier this week. He fills the vacancy left by Vassily Sinaisky, who resigned abruptly last month.

headline: Daily Report: N.S.A. Surveillance Program Is Illegal, Watchdog Says
text: An independent federal privacy watchdog has concluded that the National Security Agency’s program to collect bulk phone call records has provided only “minimal” benefits in counterterrorism efforts, is illegal and should be shut down, Charlie Savage reports.

headline: Abe’s Version of History Doesn’t Sit Well With Chinese
text: Historians and columnists have made comparisons between Britain and a rising Germany in 1914 and the current tensions between Japan and China; a hot topic at the start of the centenary year of World War I.

headline: When One Person Lives a Lie
text: In the Jan. 16 Unhitched column (“In a Confrontation, a Secret Is Revealed”), Deborah Wells-Clinton and Phil Clinton discussed their 28-year marriage and the enormous secret he had kept from her: Mr. Clinton is gay. Their split, after such a long union, was difficult, but they were able to retain a friendship.

headline: Staring at You, Staring at Me
text: What’s in a face? The first and final images in Godfrey Reggio’s brooding, wordless film “Visitors” are of a gorilla staring into the camera. You can read anything you want into the beast’s inscrutable gaze. Its deep-set eyes may convey primeval wisdom or atavistic aggression, or both, depending on your mood and the impulse to anthropomorphize what you see.

headline: AOL Buys Gravity, a Firm That Personalizes Web Searches
text: AOL, the giant Internet portal turned media company, said Thursday morning that it had acquired Gravity, a company that allows users to personalize their Internet and social searches through filters.

headline: Another Rights Advocate, Hou Xin, Is Tried in Beijing
text: A Chinese rights advocate who was part of a group calling for an end to corruption and for officials to disclose their financial assets was tried in Beijing on Thursday on charges of “gathering a crowd to disturb public order,” her lawyer said.

headline: Nokia Struggles to Project a Bright Future Without Phones
text: LONDON — Microsoft’s push into the smartphone market may not get off to the best start.

headline: Lenovo in Deal for IBM’s Server Unit
text: Lenovo announced on Thursday that it would acquire IBM’s low-end server business for $2.3 billion, signaling the successful completion of a deal that fell through a year ago, Neil Gough and David Gelles write in DealBook. The server unit, which includes IBM’s x86 server business, brings in an estimated $5 billion in revenue a year.

text: The crime gripped the public’s imagination, for both its magnitude and its moxie: In the predawn hours of Dec. 11, 1978, a group of masked gunmen seized about $6 million in cash and jewels from a cargo building at Kennedy International Airport.

text: DAVOS, Switzerland – An old concept may be coming back into vogue as business leaders and governments struggle with ways to address high unemployment rates among young people after the financial crisis: the apprenticeship.

text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The government of South Sudan and rebels loyal to the country’s ousted former vice president signed a cease-fire agreement on Thursday, holding out the prospect of peace after more than a month of fighting that has torn the new nation apart.

text: PARK CITY, Utah — Distribution is typically the much-sought-after prize for filmmakers here at the Sundance Film Festival, and the higher the price, the better. Not so for the director Sam Green, whose unusual film, “The Measure of All Things” is billed as a “live documentary.”

Ms. Ulvestrand, a former development worker in Latin America and a social worker with Norway’s immigrants, says she is comfortable around foreigners and different cultures.

headline: Senator Is Lobbying for Inquiry on Herbalife

Ackman walked the halls of Congress last year, telling any lawmaker who would listen that he believed Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company, was a fraud. He finally got a break on Thursday, when Senator Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts sent letters to federal regulators urging them to investigate the company.

headline: Universal Plans to Expand Harry Potter Theme Park
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Forget the long lines for the rides at Universal’s Wizarding World of Harry Potter here. Nearly four years after opening, the attraction is still so popular that visitors routinely wait more than an hour just to get into a shop that sells wands.

headline: Everything New Is Old Again
text: Logistical note: I’ll be traveling the next couple of days — family, not work — so little if any blogging. headline: Much Transformed, Jersey City Is Ready to House Super Bowl Teams
text: JERSEY CITY — In recent years, the Jersey City waterfront, with its sweeping view of Manhattan, has gone from a scruffy ne’er-do-well near the wrong end of a Hudson River tunnel to a gentrifying bedroom community for younger Wall Street commuters, who say it is more convenient than Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg or Fort Greene, and also more affordable.

headline: 1924: Black Flags Fly All Over Russia To Mourn Lenin
text: MOSCOW — Lenin, the founder of Bolshevism, died this morning [Jan. 22]. After an illness lasting nearly two years, his condition became suddenly worse yesterday, and at five this morning  he lost consciousness, death following two hours later from paralysis of the nerve centres. He was fifty three years old.

headline: After Shaky Beginning, Sides Report Progress at Syria Peace Talks
text: GENEVA — The fragile efforts to begin a diplomatic process to end the war in Syria seemed on Thursday night to be on track to produce a first round of negotiations, even though the two sides did not appear ready to meet face to face as had initially been hoped.

headline: Fashion, Fairness and the Olympics
text: The February issue of Vogue, which will begin to show up on newsstands this week, includes details and a photo of something new from the celebrated fashion designer Alexander Wang, but it’s not quite like anything he’s done before, and it’s more than a piece of apparel. It’s a statement of solidarity, a cry of protest and a sign of just how many people from just how many walks of life are determined not to let the Olympics come and go without shining a light on Russia’s discrimination against, and persecution of, L.G.B.T. people.

headline: English National Opera Music Director to Depart
text: The English National Opera announced a surprise shakeup of its artistic administration on Thursday morning. Edward Gardner, the 39-year-old conductor who has been the company’s music director since 2007, and whose work has been highly regarded critically and successful with audiences, will leave the company after the 2014-15 season to become chief conductor of the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra in Norway. He will return to the company as a guest conductor in 2016.

headline: Village Council in India Accused of Ordering Rape
text: NEW DELHI — A young woman in West Bengal was gang-raped this week on the order of a village council, to punish her for planning to marry a man from outside the village, according to the Indian police.

headline: CreatureCast: Swimming With Cilia
text: Cilia are hairlike structures that project from cells. They can move in coordinated, rhythmic waves that propel organisms through water.

headline: Moving, Without Feet to Do So
text: Cilia are hairlike structures that project from cells. They can move in coordinated, rhythmic waves that sweep fluid across the cell surface. If cells are fixed in place, this creates a current of fluid; the cilia that line our respiratory tract remove mucus and debris in this way. If the cilia are on the outside of the organism, the current they create can move the entire organism. This episode of CreatureCast presents two organisms that use cilia for locomotion. One is small and unicellular, the other is a much larger animal.

headline: Video: Lupita Nyong’o
text: Lupita Nyong’o, the actress who plays the tortured slave Patsey in “12 Years a Slave,” is this season’s classic ingenue: nominated for an Oscar for her very first feature film role. But as the Bagger writes Thursday, Ms. Nyongo’o has at times felt overwhelmed by the red-carpet attention: “I think everything in my life has prepared me for this,” she said of playing Patsey, “and then nothing has prepared me for the red carpet.” Read what else she had to say here.

headline: Image of the Day: January 23
text: Thursday marked the 118th anniversary of the birth of Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, an Indian freedom fighter.
