text: JPMORGAN’S DIMON TO GET RAISE  |  Despite the legal troubles that JPMorgan Chases faced in 2013, which amounted to more than $20 billion in fines, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chairman and chief executive, is getting a raise, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig write in DealBook. The pay increase follows the board’s move last year to cut Mr. Dimon’s compensation in half, to $11.5 million as reprimand for allowing a multibillion-dollar trading mistake known as the London Whale.

headline: Jana Partners Presses Juniper Networks to Cut Costs and  Make Other Changes
text: The activist hedge fund Jana Partners has set its sights on Juniper Networks, calling on the networking company to tighten its belt and give more money back to shareholders.

headline: New Law to Ban Manual Removal of Human Waste Disappoints
text: NEW DELHI — Last month, human rights advocates should have rejoiced after the central government enacted the most stringent law against what is euphemistically called manual scavenging, which is the removal of human waste with bare hands.

headline: Apollo Tyres Open to Transactions Despite Cooper Tire Deal Collapse
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – Apollo Tyres of India remains open to future strategic acquisitions despite the collapse last year of a potential $2.5 billion deal with the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, its vice chairman said Friday.

headline: U.N. Leader Says Banks Should Finance More Sustainable Businesses
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, on Friday called on banks and other financial companies to increase financing for development of sustainable energy sources and businesses with low carbon footprints.

headline: A Man Without a Nation, in Italy
text: “What’s missing from movies nowadays is the beauty of the moving wind in the trees,” D. W. Griffith told The American Mercury, not long before he died in 1948. Griffith made his reputation with blockbusters like “The Birth of a Nation” and “Intolerance,” but in the end, his sense of the medium was founded on the sense of physical reality that the first motion pictures afforded.

headline: In a Blizzard of Sounds, the Intuitive Maestro
text: BURBANK, Calif. — On Sunday’s Grammy Awards ballot for producer of the year, next to four names that have been well known and well rewarded for 10 to 15 years — Pharrell Williams, Dr. Luke, Jeff Tweedy, Rob Cavallo — is Ariel Rechtshaid. He is pop’s sudden question mark, both for his profusion of good-to-great work over the last year or two and for the dissociative confusion you might experience when scanning the list of albums he’s worked on as a producer or a songwriter in that period.

headline: 2 Sides in Syria Peace Talks Agree to Meet in the Same Room, Averting a Breakdown
text: GENEVA — The participants in the fragile Syrian peace conference agreed on Friday to meet in the same room for the first time, in a last ditch agreement that averted a potential collapse.

headline: Geopolitical Tensions Fly During Panel on American Interests
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – The World Economic Forum is usually considered a big networking event, where high-powered people schmooze in relatively cozy comfort.

headline: In Our Pages: January 25
text: 1914: Liner Set for 3rd-Class Traffic

headline: Thai Court Says Delay of Elections Is Constitutional
text: BANGKOK — A Thai court ruled Friday that a postponement of coming elections, which protesters have worked feverishly to block, is lawful under the country’s Constitution.

headline: A Spilled Cup on the No. 1 Train
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Financial Companies in ‘Street Fight’ With Cybercriminals
text: DAVOS, Switzerland – Financial companies are engaged in a escalating battle with increasingly sophisticated criminal organizations and some governments trying to hack into electronic payment systems, MasterCard’s top executive said Friday.

headline: Sundance: The Plastic Surgeon and the Actor, a new Comedy Team
text: PARK CITY, Utah — “Did you like our movie?” Earl Lynn Nelson boomed point-blank from the stage, after a screening of the comedy “Land Ho!” in which he stars. The audience in the Egyptian Theater here on Wednesday evening cheered and applauded, then lined up to pose for photos with him.

headline: Victoire de Castellane’s Blinged-Out Sculptures at Gagosian
text: As the head of Dior’s haute joaillerie division since 1998, Victoire de Castellane has infused the luxury brand’s precious offerings with a signature pop whimsy. In 2007, she began toying with sculpture in the form of small-scale works festooned with jewels and anchored by sand-cast silver bases. Beginning January 28, they will be on display at Gagosian’s London gallery in her latest fine-art exhibition, “animalvegetablemineral,” which takes its name from a parlor game. The works incorporate flora and fauna motifs, as well as rough, unpolished geodes — the raw material for the precious stones de Castellane knows and loves. Each is presented beneath a glass globe (“as they would in a natural history museum,” she explains) and christened with a girlish name (Cana Glitter Night Baby, Lunae Lumen Holly Clorum). And although the pieces are art, de Castellane couldn’t help but incorporate a sparkling bauble, to be detached and worn, into each one. “Creating jewelry is my way of expressing myself,” she says. “It’s like a language.”

headline: Treat Reckless Driving Like Drunk Driving
text: On a rainy, foggy night earlier this month, a New York City taxi driver making a left turn at a light apparently did not see my 9-year-old nephew and his 6-foot-3 father crossing the street at a crosswalk, beckoned by a lighted “walk” sign. Whether because of haste, inattention, cellphone use or perhaps the poor weather conditions, the cab driver drove directly into them. My beloved nephew, Cooper Stock, died instantly. His father suffered minor injuries. The Manhattan District Attorney’s office is investigating the circumstances of Cooper’s death.

headline: U.N. Sounds Alarm as Iraqis Flee Violence
text: GENEVA — The United Nations sounded an alarm Friday over the deepening conflict involving militants linked to Al Qaeda in Iraq’s Anbar Province, saying the number of people forced to flee their homes was the highest since the sectarian violence of 2006-8, during the American-led occupation.

headline: Umit Benan’s Homage and Thom Browne’s Nature Trail
text: PARIS — With heads down and shoulders hunched, the models trooped across an earthen floor behind a wire mesh screen.

headline: Kris Van Assche: A Bolt of Lightning
text: PARIS — At the Krisvanassche show, the designer put what looked like a bolt of lightning on the lapel of a jacket or at the breast of a coat — which could have been a reminder of the arrow-straight tailoring in which he excels.

headline: Seeing My Friend Depicted in ‘Lone Survivor’
text: I dreaded the idea of seeing my old roommate’s death depicted on screen in the movie “Lone Survivor.” But when I saw a pair of Birkenstocks walking away from the camera on the big screen, I knew someone had taken the time to get the details right. Someone really cared about this story.

headline: Germany’s Finance Minister Praises Progress Made in Crisis Countries
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — One of Germany’s top political leaders on Friday offered unusually generous praise for Greece’s efforts to deal with its economic crisis, and said that other European countries should help Greece deal with an influx of immigrants to prevent them from becoming fodder for right-wing parties.

headline: U.S. Oil Production Keeps Rising Beyond the Forecasts
text: OIL production in the United States rose by a record 992,000 barrels a day in 2013, the International Energy Agency estimated this week.

headline: Skills Practice | Creating ‘Character Recipes’
text: Onion, tomatoes and ground beef are a few of the many ingredients Adam Nagourney includes in his recipe for meatballs with marinara sauce. Pretty straightforward. But what if you wanted to take the recipe format and use it to illustrate how to “cook up” a character like Huckleberry Finn or Lady Macbeth? What “ingredients” would you need? A dash of courage for Huck? A pinch of paranoia and a pint of blood for Lady Macbeth?

headline: Sharing an Android Tablet
text: Q. Is it possible for two people to use one Android tablet and keep their apps and settings separate?

headline: Aftermath of Explosions in Egypt
text: Scenes from Cairo, where at least six people were killed in four bombings. Demonstrations broke out in support of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi and against the Muslim Brotherhood hours later.

headline: Is It Immoral to Watch the Super Bowl?
text: In the summer of 1978, during a preseason game, a wide receiver for the New England Patriots named Darryl Stingley lunged for a pass just out of his reach. Before he could regain his balance, he was hit by Jack Tatum, an Oakland Raiders defensive back. It was clear at once that Stingley was, in gridiron parlance, “shaken up on the play.” Team doctors rushed to his side.

headline: After Private Speech on Israel, de Blasio Is Pressed on Openness Pledge
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio gave an unannounced speech at a Manhattan gala of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the leading pro-Israel lobbying group, assuring its members that “part of my job description is to be a defender of Israel.”

headline: Photographs of the Old Penn Station
text: The razing of New York’s Penn Station in 1963 still ranks as one of the city’s great architectural disasters. At the time, The New York Times wrote, “We will probably be judged not by the monuments we build but by those we have destroyed.” Walter Chandoha, a photographer who is now 93, remembers the old train station fondly. He was living in New York in the late 1940s and studying at N.Y.U. on the G.I. Bill when he would duck out between classes, Rolleiflex in hand, and wander around the city. Penn Station was a cherished spot, even before it was slated for demolition. “When I look at the pictures now and I see the magnificence of it, I think, How could anybody knock this thing down?” Chandoha says. “It’s like knocking down the Colosseum or the Brandenburg Gate. It’s impossible to imagine.” Julie Bosman

headline: The Buyback
text: On a rainy Saturday afternoon, my husband and I finally gave up our guns. How we came to possess a small arsenal speaks to a past, though, not a predilection. We’re neither hunters nor collectors; we sign petitions demanding stricter controls and call our congressmen to do likewise. But throughout the years of my husband’s career as a diplomat, spent mostly in chaotic corners of Africa and Latin America, we acquired guns: mementos of the often-turbulent history that we witnessed. Strange as it was to have the weapons among our possessions, we could no more part with them than, say, burn an old photo album.

headline: Reply All: The 1.12.14 Issue
text: FUTURE BOY GROWS UP

headline: Discrimination at the Barber Shop?
text: I am a woman with a short, boyish hairstyle. Is it unfair that I am charged more for a haircut than a man with similarly short hair? Different prices for different genders seems to me like a sexist relic from a less enlightened time. When I called local salons to find a new stylist (mine moved away), many of them balked when I said I should be charged the men’s rate because I have short hair. Many salons claim that “it has always been done that way.” This seems like a very bad excuse for an antiquated and discriminatory policy. YUKI MURATA, SANTA FE, N.M.

headline: Magnus Carlsen, Chess Champion: ‘My Moves Speak for Themselves’
text: You became the world chess champion after a win in November. How did you go about training for the big match? The most important thing to study is opening theory, but I also study the latest trends to try to stay ahead, discovering new schemes and doing tactical exercises. I try to get into a chess mood.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Couture Collections Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of the Spring 2014 Paris Couture Collections, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.

headline: The Guns of the Hudson
text: The sleepy Hudson River Valley community of Cold Spring, N.Y., is arguably one of the most idyllic villages in the state. Sitting on the east bank of the Hudson, it offers spectacular views of the Highlands across the river, including the United States Military Academy at West Point. Its art galleries, antique shops, and fine restaurants make for a delightful weekend getaway for residents of New York City, an hour to the south.

headline: The Year in Adaptation
text: Cinematic book adaptations dominated 2012, with “Life of Pi,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and “Anna Karenina” springing from novels, and “Lincoln” and “Argo” drawing their stories from the nonfiction shelves. There was plenty of bookish inspiration in 2013, but the results elicited less enthusiasm. Martin Scorsese’s Oscar contender, “The Wolf of Wall Street,” was adapted from a memoir by Jordan Belfort. (The book begins: “You’re lower than pond scum.”) The movie’s leading man, Leonardo DiCaprio, also played the most famous literary character brought to the screen in 2013: Jay Gatsby. In The New Republic, David Thomson wrote his review in the form of a letter from Jay himself, who judged: “It’s stupefying, it’s vulgar, it’s demeaning.”

headline: Economic Shifts in U.S. and China Batter Markets
text: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | The ascent of developing countries over the last decade has been fueled by two global trends: the steady rise of China and the willingness of the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy.

headline: There Must Be Some Misunderstanding
text: Ben Marcus achieved the startling visions of his first story collection, “The Age of Wire and String,” and the novels “Notable American Women” and “The Flame Alphabet” largely by placing the reader in strange and unfamiliar worlds that turned out to be our world after all. The stories of his new collection, “Leaving the Sea,” still contain peculiar linguistic and perceptual tics, but he has added to his arsenal narratives that are less relentlessly unfamiliar, less rigorously dis-enchanted, populated by characters full of longing and visible regret, though for what is not always clear. For fans of the old style, like me, there are still plenty of messed-up points of view, and we can be reassured that while most of the work in this collection begins on familiar ground, it happily disintegrates into confusion and dread. In the end Marcus presents a deeper range of identification for the reader, more emotional complexity, but still plenty of the chair-gripping alienation that marked his previous books.

headline: Writer of a Certain Age
text: When I started out as a television dramatist in the ’60s, it was a truism that the more fanciable the female lead, the higher the ratings. Casting was a simple matter of sitting by the director while he flipped through acting photo directories and selected his preference. Theater was no different. When I took to writing plays in the ’70s, it was understood that if two mature women were talking onstage, audience members would cough and shift in their seats, but if two men of any age were talking, the audience would pay some attention. And if a man of any age and a young woman were alone onstage, you could hear a pin drop.

headline: Possession
text: If, as the Shaker lyrics suggest, it truly is a gift to be simple, consider the emotional intricacies of Rachel Urquhart’s transfixing debut novel, “The Visionist.” Urquhart’s characters, many of them Shakers or Shakers-to-be, lead lives gifted with devastating complexity. Their paths resemble not the austere angles of a Shaker meetinghouse but rather the rapturous choreography of the dances Shakers were known for and named after.

headline: Taking Flight
text: Unlikely alliances are a staple of fiction, and the unlikelier the better, from Huck and Jim floating down the Mississippi to Frodo and Gollum creeping toward Mordor — because the real drama lies in watching how dissimilar characters turn out to be brothers (or sisters) under the skin. Sue Monk Kidd followed this principle in her best-selling first novel, “The Secret Life of Bees,” in which a 14-year-old white girl and her family’s black servant join in fleeing abuse in the South Carolina of the civil rights era. Kidd’s latest novel, “The Invention of Wings,” also set largely in South Carolina, involves another unusual duo, in this case a slave and a daughter of the family that owns her.

headline: The Vanishing
text: On Dec. 4, 1872, the brigantine Mary ­Celeste was discovered abandoned, adrift in the North Atlantic near the Azores. The ship was empty and its crew missing, although its cargo and provisions were intact, as were the crew’s possessions. The weather was calm and the ship was seaworthy, but no trace of the crew — or of the captain’s wife and 2-year-old child — was ever found. Newspapers around the world carried the story, and it inspired one of Arthur Conan Doyle’s first published pieces of fiction, “J. Habakuk Jephson’s Statement,” printed anonymously in the British journal Cornhill. From then until the present, dozens of other investigations, novels, historical accounts, television documentaries and movies have been devoted to what has become the prototypical ghost ship. Given this background, what could Valerie Martin possibly contribute to the story in her new novel?

headline: The Anti-Snuggle Task Force
text: The funny side of Sandy; Agatha Christie vs. Chris Christie.

headline: Unreconciled
text: Given the extraordinary truth of Las Vegas, a city that began after all as a glint in a mobster’s eye, you might wonder what possible iniquities are stored up in a novel purporting to tell its secret history. Is it, perhaps, a double-bluff, in which the real life of the city is one of stable communities and spiritual growth — Marilynne Robinson’s “Gilead” with slot machines?

headline: Commitment
text: Roddy Doyle’s new novel, “The Guts,” begins with a conversation about Facebook. Jimmy Rabbitte, the hero of Doyle’s 1987 novel, “The Commitments,” and a key figure in that book’s two successors, “The Snapper” and “The Van,” sits in a pub with his father, Jimmy Sr. The two men are arguing (or simply talking; it can be difficult to tell in Doyle’s starkly profane dialect), and the son explains social networking thus to his dad: “It’s like a club but yeh have your own room, for the people yeh want to meet. Except there’s no room an’ yeh meet no one. Unless yeh want to.” For a moment, perhaps, we think we know what to expect: a rambunctious comedy about aging musicians, working-class life, rock ’n’ roll, something fundamentally upbeat, because that’s what Doyle does. Even his darker books — “The Woman Who Walked Into Doors,” say, that raw tale of a woman’s abuse at the hands of her alcoholic husband — have a way of seeming spry, sunny underneath their patina of hardscrabble realism. So we’re ready for the comedy of crusty ­middle-aged Jimmy and his father navigating the dubious world of text messaging and mobile phones (after all, we haven’t seen them fleshed out in a novel since the 1990 of “The Van”). But the younger Jimmy has something else on his mind.

headline: Under the Covers
text: For writers, literature is a talent show: Those with the most talent win. Readers are more fortunate: Everybody wins. Quality reading exercises the crucial dialogue with yourself, the dialogue you must undergo to become yourself, to know where on the vista of existence you can place your own identity and awareness.

headline: Private Life
text: Oh, how taxing it is to be Noël Coward in his declining years, trundling between two homes in Jamaica with only one servant to pour the brandy. (The other, alas, is off for the week.)

headline: Grand Illusions
text: The story could hardly be simpler. Five young Frenchmen leave their village to fight in the Great War. Some will be grievously injured, some won’t return.

headline: Albee’s ‘Death of Bessie Smith’ Is Extended in Brooklyn Run
text: A community theater in Brooklyn has extended its run of Edward Albee’s early play, “The Death of Bessie Smith,” which is being staged inside the Interfaith Medical Center, a hospital in Bedford-Stuyvesant that is on the verge of closing.

headline: Then We Came to the End
text: Nonfiction books about death tend to skew toward self-help (grieving, coping), spirituality (is heaven real?) and last lessons (“Tuesdays With Morrie”). In The New York Times Book Review last summer, Meghan O’Rourke noted a surge of writers chronicling their own decline and suggested that the trend represents a “natural outgrowth of significant social changes in how we experience disease and death.”

headline: A Sense of Snow
text: Winter and discontent. The future Richard III pairs those elements in the first line of Shakespeare’s play, and they are also paired, with piercing chill, in James Scott’s debut novel, “The Kept.” It is 1897. Elspeth Howell is making her way to an isolated cabin in upstate New York. Elspeth is pursued by cruel weather and her past as “a sinner,” a woman besieged by “anger, covetousness, thievery.” Unlike “false and treacherous” Richard, she believes she has conquered her worst impulses. She bears gifts for her five children and her husband, Jorah. She longs for the comforts of home. What she discovers, instead, is the worst kind of retribution — a slaughter of innocents triggered by her own compulsive history.

headline: Ex-Governor of Virginia Is Released After Arraignment
text: RICHMOND, Va. — The former governor of Virginia, Bob McDonnell, and his wife, Maureen, will remain free pending their trial on corruption charges after being arraigned Friday in Federal District Court in Richmond.

headline: What I Love | Anna Netrebko
text: The soprano’s brightly painted Upper West Side apartment has commanding views of the Hudson River.

headline: Anna Netrebko Decorates
text: The Russian-born soprano Anna Netrebko lives with her son, Tiago (and sometimes with her sister,  Natalia), in a condominium high above Lincoln Square. The terraces, the high ceilings, the line of windows with sweeping views of the Hudson River, the quick walk to work at the Metropolitan Opera, the gym and swimming pool on-site — all are worth singing about.

headline: Who Made That Tricycle?
text: In March 1877, James Starley, a sewing-machine maker in Coventry, England, unveiled a strange offshoot of the tricycle. It had one large wheel on the left and two much smaller ones on the right. The rider sat between the wheels, driving with a pair of levers and steering on a crank. A few years later, Starley’s new designs had grown so popular that the queen bought two for herself.

headline: Pipeline Fight Lifts Environmental Movement
text: WASHINGTON — Environmentalists have spent the past two years fighting the Keystone XL pipeline: They have built a human chain around the White House, clogged the State Department’s public comment system with more than a million emails and letters, and gotten themselves arrested at protests across the country.

headline: Image of the Day: January 24
text: Indian tennis player Sania Mirza during a mixed doubles semi final match at the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne.

headline: The Doctor-Go-Round
text: When each new test finds a new problem.

headline: In Russia, Couriers Halt Parcel Delivery
text: MOSCOW — Russia has never been an easy country in which to deliver packages because of its vast size. The government just made it a lot harder for anyone buying things online.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘My Life in Middlemarch’
text: This week, Rebecca Mead discusses “My Life in Middlemarch”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Scott Stossel talks about “My Age of Anxiety”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘My Age of Anxiety’
text: This week, Rebecca Mead and Scott Stossel.

headline: On the Right
text: THE GREAT DEBATE  Edmund Burke, Thomas Paine, and the Birth of Right and Left  By Yuval Levin Basic Books, $27.99.

headline: Inside the List
text: Roger and Me: Gabriel Sherman’s unauthorized biography of Roger Ailes, “The Loudest Voice in the Room,” saunters onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 9. The book doesn’t arrive without controversy: Ailes, the founder and president of Fox News Channel, refused to cooperate with Sherman and went so far as to grant exclusive access to a rival journalist, the Rush Limbaugh biographer Zev Chafets, in evident hopes of pre-empting Sherman with a friendlier account. (Chafets’s book, “Roger Ailes: Off Camera,” was published in March 2013 and spent a week on the e-book nonfiction list.) On NPR’s “Fresh Air” last month, Sherman described his efforts to interview Ailes in terms that called to mind Michael Moore’s early documentary “Roger and Me,” about the General Motors chief executive Roger Smith. “I reached out to Roger Ailes more than a dozen times in the two and a half years I was doing the researching and writing, both in person and in writing,” he said. “I traveled to different states to see him at public events to tell him I was eager to sit down and discuss every fact in the book. Ultimately, it was his decision not to participate.” Ailes’s opposition, he continued, had provided “a crash course in what it must be like to be involved in a political campaign. . . . I’m not the story. Roger Ailes is the story. But he has elevated me to a place where it’s this kind of me-­versus-him dynamic.”

headline: Lessons From a Master Cat Photographer
text: Walter Chandoha, who has been mastering the art of cat and dog photography for more than 60 years, shares some of his secrets.

headline: Sundance: A Dark Mood Pervades This Edition
text: PARK CITY, Utah – As always, cineastes spent Sundance on a cloud. They marveled at “Calvary,” a blackly comedic exploration of religion, and lit up over emerging talents like Alex Ross Perry, director of the acerbic “Listen Up Philip.”

headline: Bitcoin Is Not Yet Ready for the Real World
text: Mark T. Williams, a former commodities trading floor senior executive and Federal Reserve Bank examiner, teaches banking, finance and risk management at Boston University School of Management.

headline: Movie Review: 'Gloria'
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "Gloria."

headline: The 30-Year-Old Macintosh and a Lost Conversation With Steve Jobs
text: On a late-November day in 1983, Steven Levy, then a freelance journalist for Rolling Stone, got into a car outside 10460 Bandley Drive, in Cupertino, Calif.

headline: In the Alps, a Walk in the Sky
text: Visitors will feel like they’re floating above the Alps with “Step Into the Void,” a new five-sided tempered-glass enclosure located at the tip of the Aiguille du Midi mountain peak. The enclosure lies at one end of the world’s tallest skywalk structure, which stands at 3,842 meters (12,605 feet) and overlooks the French commune of Chamonix.

headline: Truth and Consequences for a War Photographer
text: The ethical commandments on the digital manipulation of photographs in journalism are simple and direct: you do not add or subtract any element of an image in post processing. Ever. If a photo didn’t turn out exactly how you had imagined, there is no laptop digital do-over.

headline: Movie Review: 'Stranger by the Lake'
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "Stranger by the Lake."

headline: Russia Plans to Extend Snowden Asylum, Lawmaker Says
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Russia plans to extend its offer of asylum to Edward J. Snowden beyond August, a Russian lawmaker said Friday at the World Economic Forum here.

headline: Some States Are Moving to Loosen Their Estate Taxes
text: FOR most of the United States, the estate tax is now something only the very wealthy have to plan for. The federal exemption for an individual this year is now $5.34 million, or $10.68 million for a married couple. And that amount is indexed to inflation, so it will continue to rise.

headline: Following Your Dream Brings Bliss, but Not Always Money
text: WHEN Trent Brown was laid off from his job as a sales representative in 2010, he chose to view it as an opportunity to make a life change. Instead of searching for some other company job, he decided to help his wife, Janell, expand her cupcake and cake-making hobby into a business. Just six months after he lost his job, they opened One Sweet Slice in the Salt Lake City area where they lived.

headline: Times Minute | Deadly Blasts in Cairo
text: Also on the Minute, the economics of climate change and a look at the tricycle.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Visitors,’ ‘Gloria’ and ‘Stranger by the Lake’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the wordless film “Visitors,” the French drama “Stranger by the Lake” and the Chilean film “Gloria.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Times Minute | Deadly Blasts in Cairo
text: In the Video

headline: Recommended Reading
text: NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Cameron Sees Technology as Unlikely Ally of Western Workers
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The specter of rich countries losing jobs to cheaper workers in emerging economies and increasingly to smart machines has been an important theme at the World Economic Forum this week. As Eric Schmidt of Google put it: “The jobs problem is going to be the defining problem of the next two to three decades.”

headline: Decoding Ariel Rechtshaid
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Ariel Rechtshaid, the Grammy-nominated producer of songs by Sky Ferreira, Vampire Weekend, Justin Bieber and others.

headline: More Views on Nuclear Power, Waste, Safety and Cost
text: Here’s another round in a continuing exploration of views on next steps for nuclear power. Earlier this week, I received a letter arguing for a fresh push on nuclear technologies, building on the argument of James Hansen and three other climate researchers that I wrote about last fall.

headline: Today in Small Business: Clam Diggers and Worm Harvesters
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Former Interpreter for The Times Is Killed in Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Noor Ahmad Noori, an Afghan interpreter who formerly worked for The New York Times in Afghanistan, was found beaten and stabbed to death, wrapped in a sack and dumped on a roadside late Thursday outside Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, where he lived, government officials and family members reported.

headline: Big Raise for JPMorgan’s Dimon Despite a Rough Year
text: Updated, 9:09 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase, after a year marred by scandal and stiff regulatory penalties, has decided to award its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, $20 million in compensation for 2013, an amount that will further inflame the debate over the accountability of senior bank executives.

headline: Paperback Row
text: LOVE IS A CANOE,  by Ben Schrank. (Picador/Sarah Crichton, $16.) Her marriage in trouble, the heroine of Schrank’s novel — a crackling sendup of the New York publishing industry and an inquiry into the fragility of human relationships — turns for help to the author of “Marriage Is a Canoe,” a classic self-help book she read as a child.

headline: The Source | Aaron Koblin
text: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Aaron Koblin.

headline: Popcast: Decoding Ariel Rechtshaid
text: Among the A-list names in this year’s Grammy ballot for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical, is Ariel Rechtshaid, who has been a pop pro since his teenage years but has only recently and suddenly, at 34, become a subject of great interest.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: DUTY: Memoirs of a Secretary at War,  by Robert M. Gates. (Knopf, $35.) One of the few Obama administration members who come off well in this frank account — probably one of the best Washington memoirs ever — is Hillary Clinton.

headline: Co-ops Chill, Condos Don’t
text: The phrase “white-glove Manhattan co-op” has invariably conjured the image of a fortresslike residence whose precincts could be stormed only via a gantlet distinguished by mountains of paperwork and a daunting personal interview. The New York condominium, the relatively new kid on the block, has seemed the opposite: laissez-faire in everything, from rules governing pets and smoking to regulations determining who could rent an apartment.

headline: Matsuev Postpones Carnegie Hall Concert
text: Updated, 1:17 p.m. | The pianist Denis Matsuev has postponed a Carnegie Hall concert scheduled for Thursday, Jan. 30, because he is being treated for pneumonia, the hall announced. It said in a statement that Mr. Matsuev is “currently in Moscow under doctor’s care and not permitted to travel,’’ and that he had been forced to cancel or reschedule a number of concerts in the United States, Israel and Russia. Mr. Matsuev, who has been active in cultural preparations for the Winter Olympics in Sochi, is scheduled to play a concert there on Feb. 6 at the  Zimniy Theater. One of his representatives, Silke Zimmermann, said that “we firmly count on his participation” at the Sochi games. Mr. Matsuev’s Carnegie Hall appearance — which was to feature the music of Schumann, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky — has been rescheduled for June 15.

headline: Movie Review: 'Visitors'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Visitors."

headline: Big Ticket | At $14 Million, Two Are Better Than One
text: Two condominiums high in the north tower of the venerable Century at 25 Central Park West that were marketed as a single entity — to assemble a full-floor residence with panoramic views — sold for $14 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: At BP, There’s Optimism in the Corner Office
text: LONDON — It has been nearly four years since the oil drilling disaster in the Gulf of Mexico killed 11 people and brought the wrath of the United States government and legal system down on the British energy giant BP.

headline: Goldman May Restrict Employees’ Use of Chat Services
text: Updated, 2:43 p.m. |

headline: Mike Huckabee’s War for Women
text: I’m not a doctor, but I’ve figured out that the birth control pill is a form of contraception. Take the pill daily; don’t get pregnant.

headline: After Controversy, ‘Duck Dynasty’ Draws a Smaller Audience
text: Duck season is proving a bit hit and miss so far this year.

headline: Claudio Abbado Commemoration at La Scala to Be Live Streamed
text: A public commemoration of the conductor Claudio Abbado, who died on Monday at 80, will be live-streamed from Milan’s La Scala Opera House on Jan. 27 to allow “the global audience of the web” to participate, the theater announced on Monday. Daniel Barenboim will conduct the “Funeral March” from Beethoven’s third Symphony at 6 P.M. in Milan, noon Eastern Standard Time, and the event will be streamed on the theater’s website and on Youtube.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Maison Martin Margiela Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Requiem for a Minivan
text: Stella, my 8-year-old, was crying. Her little shoulders heaved with sobs. Her face, buried into my belly, left streaks of tears on my T-shirt. Her grief was acute. I helplessly rubbed her back, murmuring soothing sounds.

headline: Banker Says Letting Banks Fail Is Essential to Rebuilding Public Trust
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Rules enacted since the financial crisis have eliminated the need to designate banks as “too big to fail” in a number of countries in the next economic disruption, said Urs Rohner, the chairman of the Swiss bank Credit Suisse.

headline: Homies in Verona, Gangstas in Elsinore
text: In 1848, a reviewer for Graham’s Magazine described “Wuthering Heights” as “a compound of vulgar depravity and unnatural horrors, such as we might suppose a person, inspired by a mixture of brandy and gunpowder, might write for the edification of fifth-rate blackguards.” Presumably, this grumpy writer would have cared even less for the Thug Notes version.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘My Age of Anxiety’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Nathan Heller reviews “My Age of Anxiety,” Scott Stossel’s memoir about his own incapacitating nerves and the larger legacy of the disorder. Mr. Heller writes:

headline: A Lawyer and Partner, and Also Bankrupt
text: Anyone who wonders why law school applications are plunging and there’s widespread malaise in many big law firms might consider the case of Gregory M. Owens.

headline: Shulamit Aloni, Outspoken Israeli Lawmaker, Dies at 86
text: Shulamit Aloni, a longtime left-wing Israeli minister and Parliament member who was an early champion of civil liberties, challenger of religious hegemony and outspoken opponent of Israel’s occupation of the Palestinian territories, died Friday at her home in Kfar Shmaryahu, a Tel Aviv suburb. She was 86.

headline: Aide Arrested in Child Pornography Case Is Found Dead
text: WASHINGTON — A former chief of staff for Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, who was arrested last month on charges stemming from his possession of child pornography was found dead on Thursday in the basement of his parents’ home in Maryland, apparently in a suicide, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Gates and Summers Push Global Health Drive as Moral Imperative
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Pouring money into improving health care in developing countries is a profound moral mission, according to Bill Gates and Lawrence H. Summers — and huge achievements are well in reach.

headline: Alfonso Cuarón May Be a DGA Favorite, but ‘Philomena’ Is Rising Fast
text: LOS ANGELES – The Directors Guild Awards, to be held here on Saturday, are usually a reliable barometer of which way the wind is blowing, best picture-wise. Even last year, when the guild saw fit to give its top prize to Ben Affleck, who had been famously snubbed in the directing category by the Academy, it was an indication of how much love there was for his movie “Argo,” which went on to win best picture.

headline: Opossums Are Unloved, Yet Hard to Resist
text: The Virginia opossum is more closely related to kangaroos and koalas than to the rats and rodents with which it is frequently compared. North America’s only native marsupial, the opossum is probably more frequently observed in New York City trash cans than in New York City parks.

headline: Erosion of Argentine Peso Sends a Shudder Through Latin America
text: BUENOS AIRES — Cities across Argentina are still unnerved by all the looting that broke out last month after police officers went on strike, protesting salaries eroded by rampant inflation. Residents fumed over blackouts that left them sweltering during a recent heat wave. Then the currency plunged this week, the steepest decline since the nation’s economic collapse in 2002, stirring fears that another major financial crisis could be around the corner.

headline: The Gun Report: January 24, 2014
text: As regular readers of this blog know, Chicago has the highest toll of gun violence in the nation. Which is why a billboard there equating an AR-15 with baseball and apple pie strikes many as tone-deaf.

headline: Review: 2014 Land Rover Range Rover HSE
text: Land Rover’s fourth-generation Range Rover has an familiar silhouette, a sumptuous interior and a price as steep as the hills it can conquer.

headline: Not Your Grandmother’s Gratin
text: In my kitchen, leftovers often become the inspiration for a week of Recipes for Health. This happened last week. If you had opened my refrigerator on Sunday you would have found a selection of roasted vegetables, which I had prepared over the weekend for various dinners and recipe tests. By Tuesday those vegetables had found their way into three winter gratins.

headline: ‘Grace of Monaco’ Will Open the Cannes Film Festival
text: Olivier Dahan’s film “Grace of Monaco,” featuring Nicole Kidman as the actress Grace Kelly, is the opening-night selection for the 67th Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced today.

headline: How to Take a Perfect Cat Photo (or at Least Make a Living as an Artist)
text: The Look pages in this weekend’s magazine feature Walter Chandoha’s pictures of the old Penn Station, which he took in the late 1940s in between classes at N.Y.U.’s School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance (now the Stern School of Business). After one of these photographic excursions, Chandoha found a stray kitten in the Village and took it back to his home in Astoria, Queens.

headline: Video: Range Rover Offers Off-Road Capability in an Opulent Package
text: The luxury off-road mission of Jaguar Land Rover’s Range Rover is a curious thing. Last time I checked, polar fleece formal wear never made it big, not even in Seattle. And yet, everywhere I go, people fawn over this opulent S.U.V.

headline: After a Long Trip, a Good Predators Debut for Del Zotto
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Michael Del Zotto made his debut with the Nashville Predators on a good note with a 2-1 road win over the Vancouver Canucks on Thursday night. A former Rangers defenseman, Del Zotto is hoping to tune up his N.H.L. career in Music City after being traded on Wednesday for Kevin Klein.

headline: Running Wild, Wheelies to the Wind
text: They gather usually once a week on dirt bikes of all varieties, cruising down the road, engines revved, wheelies popped as they turn the streets of Baltimore into an urban playground. They are called the 12 o’clock boys, and they are the subject of a new documentary of the same name opening Friday. They are also seen as a menace by some in the city’s Police Department and as a danger by some residents.

headline: A Template 007 Named Fleming
text: “Everything I write has a precedent in truth,” Ian Fleming once said, and next to James Bond, his greatest creation may have been himself. A failed stockbroker, the rakish Fleming imbibed drink, women and the family fortune as he tried to escape the shadow of his adventurous older brother Peter and the disappointment of his formidable mother. Then the Naval Intelligence Division cornered him, using his talent for spinning a tale in the World War II effort.

headline: Hardware Shop Owner Sculpts Art From Odds and Ends
text: DeLuca General Store, an old-style hardware shop on Bay Street in the Rosebank section of Staten Island, has a Norman Rockwell-looking storefront with windows displaying garden tools and plumbing supplies.

headline: Bragging Rights of an Up-and-Comer
text: Martin Garrix became dance music’s boy wonder last year, thanks to “Animals,” a springy and chipper slice of progressive house with just a touch of attitude. It made him, at 17, the youngest D.J. with a No. 1 chart hit at Beatport, the online electronic music store.

headline: Like John Wayne, but in Anoraks
text: The doldrums of winter in the city can really get to you. What could be worse? The filmmaker Jessica Oreck, with her Kickstarter-financed documentary “Aatsinki: The Story of Arctic Cowboys” (at IFC Center through Thursday), has an idea. Her film follows the brothers Aarne and Lasse Aatsinki and their crew over one year as they herd reindeer in Finnish Lapland, inside the Arctic Circle.

headline: Star-Crossed Meets Hip-Hop
text: A decade has passed since Rennie Harris Puremovement graced the stage of the Joyce Theater. In dance, that’s practically forever. Beginning on Tuesday, the company, led by the astute and poetic hip-hop choreographer Mr. Harris, is back with a selection of repertory favorites, including a newly excerpted and remounted version of “Rome and Jewels.” That Bessie Award-winning work from 2000 — created in collaboration with the dramaturge Ozzie Jonesand the composer Darin Ross — transfers Shakespeare’s “Romeo and Juliet” and “West Side Story” to a captivating b-boy world pitting the Monster Q’s (the Montagues) against the Caps (the Capulets). Mr. Jones reprises his role as narrator, while the astonishing Rodney Mason returns to star as Rome.

headline: Art of Collision, Sticks to Cymbals
text: Steven Schick, a star in the world of solo percussion music and the author of “The Percussionist’s Art,” celebrates his 60th birthday with two concerts at Miller Theater that trace the trajectory of this repertory.

headline: Before and After, Paris in the 1800s
text: Two exhibitions opening this week sample opposite ends of the history of photography. First is Charles Marville, appointed official photographer of Paris in 1862. Over the next eight years, he documented old parts of the city destined for a drastic makeover, then photographed the new boulevards, gas lamps, pissoirs and other amenities that transformed Paris into a modern metropolis. “Charles Marville: Photographer of Paris,” opening Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, presents about 100 of his lucid and evocative photographs. (Through May 4, 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

headline: The Source | Aaron Koblin in Conversation With Doug Aitken
text: “There’s all this invisible infrastructure that’s surrounding us,” says the digital media artist Aaron Koblin, who serves as the Creative Director of the Data Arts Team at Google. With visualization projects such as “Flight Patterns,” he has sought to bring that hidden world to light. Koblin speaks with the artist Doug Aitken about the intersection of art and technology as part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Making Waves at Sea, and in the Studio
text: The frontwomen of Warpaint agree: In the event of an apocalypse, they would outfit themselves more sensibly than Beyoncé. “You’re not going to be wearing a shirt” that is “just barely covering your nipples,” Theresa Wayman said of the futuristic video for the recent Beyoncé song “Superpower.” Emily Kokal added, “You’re going to be covering yourself from the elements.”

headline: Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi
text: The co-directors and co-writers discuss their vampire film "What We Do in the Shadows" at Sundance.

headline: Love That Dare Not Sing Its Name
text: In the acclaimed 2005 film “Brokeback Mountain,” based on the short story by Annie Proulx, Heath Ledger played Ennis Del Mar, a Wyoming ranch hand in a furtive, decades-long gay affair. He kept his words gravelly, mumbling and few, as if he’d been blocked up by a life of secrets. It was a voice powerfully affecting in the quiet close-ups possible in the movies, but it wouldn’t register in the grandeur of an opera house.

headline: Draghi Sees Progress in Euro Zone, but Puts Banks on Notice
text: DAVOS, SWITZERLAND — Some banks in the euro zone could go out of business as a result of intense official scrutiny they will face this year, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said Friday as he presented a generally upbeat view of the European economy that was, however, laced with warnings.

headline: Old Democratic Name (Nunn) Stakes Bid on Shifting Georgia
text: PERRY, Ga. — As a little girl, Michelle Nunn clutched her father’s hand as they strolled the pecan groves of the family’s 2,400-acre farm, a moment captured in a black-and-white photograph that Sam Nunn used to help win election to the Senate. It hangs in a Sam Nunn exhibit in this small city south of Macon, where the main thoroughfare is Sam Nunn Boulevard.

headline: An Old-Style Jazzman, and Voices of Iran’s Past
text: George Cables

headline: Sundance Video:  Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi Are Onto Something
text: PARK CITY, Utah – Vampires have finally descended on Sundance. In its 30th year the festival may be, as Manohla Dargis writes more vital than ever to the indie film scene. But that doesn’t mean it’s immune to the lure of big thrill entertainment that the undead provide. This year’s festival had not one but three vampire flicks: the high-profile “Only Lovers Left Alive,” from Jim Jarmusch, starring Tilda Swinton and Tom Hiddleston; “Girl Walks Home Alone at Night,” billed as “cinema’s first Iranian vampire western;” and “What We Do in the Shadows,” from writer-director-stars Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement.

headline: Small-Town Crank Finds His Following
text: America’s love affair with British TV may have reached a peak with “Downton Abbey,” but viewers are also finding plenty of room in their hearts for the decidedly different “Doc Martin,” a decade-old series about a cantankerous doctor and the ensemble of quirky neighbors and patients he looks down on in the fictional Cornwall coastal village of Portwenn.

headline: Gestures of a Hot Hand
text: “Ooooooh!” shrieked the New York City Ballet dancer Tiler Peck, held high in the air, her body bent into a backward arch, her feet almost touching her head, as her partner, Robert Fairchild, ran across the studio. “Ooooooh!” shrieked the dancers in the room, half-laughing, some hiding their faces in their hands, as Ms. Peck rocked dangerously forward, almost toppling over his head.

headline: The 2015 Lincoln Navigator: A Familiar Shape With a New Face
text: The Lincoln Navigator first appeared in 1998 as an upscale Ford Expedition, which in turn was a larger version of that era’s Ford Explorer. If you saw the 2015 model coming from far away, or in low light, you might not be able to tell that anything had changed over the last decade and a half. But the Lincoln Motor Company assures us that the Navigator, familiar in profile as it is, is better than ever.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Topping Up
text: Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow.

headline: Dismay for Pay at JPMorgan Chase
text: Jamie Dimon’s bonus represents another whale of a fail for JPMorgan Chase. The board’s decision to give its chairman and chief executive a 73 percent raise, to $20 million, is unjustifiable after last year’s performance. Shareholders should have a loud say against this pay – and the lead director, Lee Raymond.

headline: Portrait of a Wily Holocaust Survivor
text: Theresienstadt was called Hitler’s “gift to the Jews.” In an 18th-century military town some 40 miles north of Prague, this “model ghetto” was established to show the world that life in a concentration camp was practically halcyon. Grown-ups lingered over delicious meals between fulfilling workdays and evening concerts or lectures. Children devoured sweets. Soccer matches were played in the town square.

headline: Republicans Vote to Streamline Nominating Process
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican National Committee moved Friday to consolidate its presidential nominating process in 2016, a pre-emptive effort to avoid a drawn-out campaign that many in the party say could imperil their effort to reclaim the White House.

headline: All Together Now, Eyes on the Screen
text: You start off a brash outsider, testing the limits of acceptability, and if you’re good enough and lucky enough, you eventually become the Establishment, explaining to your children why the things you’re passionate about aren’t too boring for words. Such is the trajectory of Michael Dorf, who founded the edgy music club Knitting Factory in 1986 and, 22 years later, City Winery, where middle-aged singer-songwriter types pluck and warble for patrons having braised rabbit and merlot-cabernet blends. Mr. Dorf, 51, plans to open City Winery outposts this year in Nashville and Napa Valley, Calif. On March 31 he will present his 10th annual benefit concert at Carnegie Hall to raise money for music education, this one dedicated to the songs of Paul Simon. He lives in TriBeCa with his wife, Sarah Connors, 49, a film producer, and their children, Sophia, 10, and 15-year-old twins, Eli and Zachary (who was away on a recent Sunday). The family has a rescue mutt and a rabbit.

headline: Wheelies: The Muppet Toyota Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Cowboy Poetry and Rodeos
text: Next week marks the 30th anniversary of the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering, in Elko, Nev., a tradition sponsored by the Western Folklife Center in that city. Poets, storytellers, musicians, radio personalities and now even bloggers come together to promote the occupational and artistic traditions of the rural West.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Dior’s Didactic Runway, Chanel’s Couture Sneakers and Kanye’s Latest Designs
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 18 – 24

headline: Don’t Blame the Maps
text: DO the Republicans owe their current congressional majority to gerrymandering? At first glance, it seems self-evident that they do. In the 2012 election, the Democrats won the popular votes for the presidency, the Senate and the House of Representatives. But somehow in the House — for whose seats Republicans controlled the redistricting process in many crucial states — the Republicans managed to end up with a 16-seat majority despite losing the popular vote.

headline: Pasta With Parsnips and Bacon
text: Parsnips add a certain sweetness to a cozy winter pasta dish thick with cream and bacon.

headline: Mutually Beneficial to Pasta and Parsnip
text: PAIRING PASTA WITH PARSNIPS is not one of the more obvious matches. Their starchy natures make them seem too similar, the kind of couple that finishes each other’s sentences, which can be dull company indeed.

headline: Washington Theaters to Produce Women’s Theater Festival
text: Nearly four dozen theaters in the Washington D.C. area are joining forces to produce the Women’s Voices Theater Festival, a celebration of contemporary female playwrights that will take over the Washington theater world for eight weeks starting on September 14, 2015. The festival is being organized by Molly Smith, the artistic director of Arena Stage, and Eric Schaeffer, the artistic director of Signature Theater, who announced the project on Thursday.

headline: Bach Inventions and a Monk Tribute, Using All of the Piano
text: Bach wrote his set of 15 Two-Part Inventions as teaching pieces for amateurs of the keyboard, as he put it in a preface. Each work unfolds as just two contrapuntal lines, two voices, one for each hand.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Midtown co-op with a fireplace in every room; an Upper West Side condo in a full-service building; and a Midwood Park home with a circular staircase.

headline: Serendipity: 1. Spreadsheet: 0.
text: Wherever she goes, Jennifer Lee Illes carries a big, black North Face backpack bulging with items like workout clothes, mint tea bags, sheet music from her a cappella singing group and aviation cards from the flying lessons she has been taking. Ms. Illes, a strategy and operations manager for Google in Ann Arbor, Mich., likes to be overprepared.

headline: In the Ghost With the Most, Drivers May Haunt the Back Seat
text: It’s a great time to sell fancy cars. At the Hilton Head Island Concours d’Elegance last fall, I met a Rolls-Royce salesman who was on his way to Atlanta to deliver a Wraith to a customer. The factor that limits sales of Rollses, he told me, is the factory itself: It literally can’t build them fast enough to satisfy demand.

headline: Duel at the Old Fulton Fish Market
text: Robert LaValva’s epiphany came early one February morning in 2005, as he watched London’s Borough Market come alive.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A colonial in Syosset, N.Y., with four bedrooms, each with a bath; and a Hillsborough, N.J., home built around the core of a 1920 farmhouse.

headline: Chinatown Revisited
text: My mother is the oldest of five siblings, most of whom grew up in New York’s Chinatown. They are voracious eaters and bargain hunters, and lifelong visitors to Chinese neighborhoods everywhere. When we talk about a good Chinatown, we point to certain signs: live fish for sale, dragon eyes in sidewalk produce displays, smokers, crowds.

headline: Amy Tan’s Evolving Sense of China
text: In 1949, Amy Tan’s mother boarded one of the last ships heading from Shanghai to San Francisco before “China became Red China and the bamboo curtain descended.” There, her mother reunited with her husband and the couple relocated to Oakland, where a couple of years later she was born.

headline: The Ecstasy of Excess, the Agony of the Sticker
text: BIG SUR, Calif. — Every carmaker makes compromises. Feature enhancements, like a little more legroom or a touch more horsepower, are weighed against the effect on a model’s sticker price. But what if, in an alternative universe, money could bend the laws of physics, and vehicles were created only to transport mortals to the highest state of driving satisfaction?

headline: Not Your Average Spirit
text: The Wraith, named for a soul-sucking ghost that casts spells and cannot be vanquished, is the most powerful Rolls-Royce ever produced.

headline: Kiev Truce Falls Apart, and Unrest Resurges
text: KIEV, Ukraine — With President Viktor F. Yanukovych and antigovernment demonstrators at an impasse here, a cease-fire disintegrated on Friday night as the Ukrainian capital convulsed in renewed violence and fire bombs lit up the night sky.

headline: Modern Civility, Retail Division
text: Retail is not without its dark alleys. As with those other public areas prone to a high incidence of bad manners (airplanes and restaurants), stores can be breeding grounds for the impulsive and the exigent. Enter the customer who greets unexpected delays with donkeylike braying. Enter the salespeople who clump idly in lush profusion but who then atomize upon approach.

headline: Weekend Reading: Looking Back at Our View From the Alps
text: As the World Economic Forum concludes in Davos, Switzerland, we’re looking back at some of our past coverage of the elite gathering.

headline: Loehmann’s, Out of Step and Closing Down
text: Whenever a store, bar, restaurant or other institution closes in New York after decades, there’s a tendency to mourn the loss of an entire way of life, a vanished style of inhabiting the city that can no longer flourish in the context of new economies with new people too young, too preoccupied, too cavalier to appreciate the old and intrinsically superior, more genuine folkways. It is hard to mine the same kind of resonance from the closing of Loehmann’s, now shutting down after 94 years, if only because the hunger for discount would seem to be eternal. And yet the end of Loehmann’s still says something about our altered expectations of the retail experience.

headline: Goldman’s Cautious Approach to Hiring the Well-Connected
text: Goldman Sachs, like other big banks, has been scrutinized for its hiring practices in China. The question federal authorities are investigating is whether banks hired the children of powerful Chinese officials in an attempt to win lucrative business.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Jeep Struggles to Repair Vehicles 14 Months After Recall
text: Fourteen months after Chrysler said it would recall about 745,000 Jeep Grand Cherokee and Jeep Liberty sport utility vehicles because the front or side air bags might deploy without the vehicle being in a crash, about 94 percent of them had not been repaired, leaving some owners angry and scared.

headline: Officials Blame Human Error for the Latest Blow to the Reputation of Metro-North
text: The sprawling shutdown that halted commutes for nearly two hours across Metro-North Railroad on Thursday night was traced to a simple disconnected wire — overlooked by technicians who were trying to replace a power supply unit, transportation officials said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Egypt, Central African Republic and Thailand.

headline: Emery Roth Lived Here
text: Renowned for elegant prewar Manhattan apartment buildings like the Beresford and the San Remo, Emery Roth, the prolific New York City architect, designed many distinctive buildings in the 1920s and ’30s. His body of work is so rich that today an apartment listing in an “Emery Roth-designed building” invokes a certain cachet that is not lost on brokers.

headline: After a Son’s Death, Parents Channel Their Grief Into Activism
text: They had not been like this. They rarely signed petitions or spoke at public hearings. They did not write imploring letters to elected officials, push to see the mayor, go before legislative bodies to speak. They did not do those sorts of things.

headline: Humor, Locked and Loaded
text: Is this the year the Academy Awards finally gave comedy some respect?

headline: Evening Hours | Out in the Snow
text: The weather didn’t keep partygoers at home.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Topping Up
text: Topping Up Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow. Early last week, men on their way to work started out with no hats, no scarves and coats flapping open. By Friday, you could only see their eyes. One man wore fur trousers, top left. Another wrapped himself in a carpet, while the garment district tailor continued to stitch away. In Bryant Park, a man stood over the open fire pit. For some, a fedora was enough, and a black topcoat set off red kid gloves.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials in Merger Talks With Texas Industries
text: Martin Marietta Materials, a big producer of sand and gravel, is in late-stage talks to acquire Texas Industries, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Fruit Fly Brothers Tend to Cooperate
text: In pursuit of a mate, male fruit flies often engage in combat, battling one another with their front legs.

headline: For Sea Scallops, the Bare Minimum
text: Sea scallops are one of winter’s divine treats, and one of the best places to enjoy them is Paris. In every fish market there, you see great piles of them on display, still in the shell, ready to be shucked to order.

headline: Submerging Markets
text: Currencies in formerly fast-growing emerging markets have been falling sharply this week. The Argentine peso and the Turkish lira, for example, were each down more than 1 percent against the dollar on Friday afternoon.

headline: That Positive Feeling, and Why It’s Shared
text: AFTER READING Maria Konnikova’s fascinating post in The New Yorker about what makes stories go viral, I wondered if designers were thinking more and more along the lines she described when they create collections.

headline: Flood Ebbs, Insurance Woes Don’t
text: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., isn’t the only one complaining that her Hurricane Sandy relief money has been held hostage.

headline: Architect Goes Home, to Recall and to Work
text: Richard Meier is returning to his roots with two new developments in New Jersey, where he grew up.

headline: In Nuns’ Suit, Justices Block Key Mandate in Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday extended a temporary order from Justice Sonia Sotomayor barring the Obama administration from enforcing the contraception coverage requirement of the Affordable Care Act against an order of Roman Catholic nuns.

headline: How Henry Hudson Got His Perch
text: In the Jan. 12 Metropolitan section, Lisa W. Foderaro wrote a guide to some of the more obscure historical markers that dot New York City. We asked readers to post their comments and questions about New York monuments on the City Room blog, and enlisted Jonathan Kuhn, NYC Parks director of art and antiquities, to answer the queries. Here, a selection from the online conversation, edited and condensed.

headline: The Sexual Healer
text: On the subject of sex, a subject that makes so many stammer, clam up or crack wise, Esther Perel, a couples therapist and author, is uncommonly eloquent, even rhapsodic. That particular rhetorical gift is apparently in high demand: Last July, Ms. Perel gave an opening talk at Summit Outside, a three-day meeting of 900 entrepreneurs and creative types held on Powder Mountain in Eden, Utah.

headline: A Firebird, a Mermaid and a Bit of Mozart
text: The Russian conductor Andrey Boreyko’s stock is evidently riding high at the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Boreyko, 56, who made his debut with the orchestra in 2007 and has since returned regularly, is about to complete his second consecutive subscription week at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Let’s Change the World. Cheers!
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Around midnight on Wednesday, Nicolas Berggruen, the billionaire investor, philanthropist and art collector, walked into a loud party in a cozy Swiss chalet co-hosted by Jimmy Wales, a founder of Wikipedia. As dance music blared and colored lights played on the ceiling, Mr. Berggruen greeted Boris Johnson, the mayor of London.

headline: The Hillary Clinton Cover’s Planetary Disruption
text: For The Times, the good news is that its magazine cover featuring Hillary Rodham Clinton as a planet is generating all kinds of buzz even before its distribution with Sunday’s paper.

headline: After Hours | An Opera Finds Pathos in the Milli Vanilli Saga
text: The deconstructed, multiroom opera “Wow (Work in Progress)” at BRIC Arts in Brooklyn, about the late-’80s rise and fall of Milli Vanilli, isn’t the first to wring classical tragedy from modern-day cultural calamity — the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage did it with pieces about Anna Nicole Smith and Jerry Springer — but it might be the strangest. The creative trio of Joe Diebes, Christian Hawkey and David Levine cast the story of the braided European pop duo, who fell from grace when it was revealed that they’d been lip-syncing all along, as a postmodern tragedy about two handsome naïfs devoured by the pop-culture machine.

headline: Unreleased Miles Davis Performances to Be Released
text: Two hours of previously unreleased performances by Miles Davis, leading a band that included Chick Corea, Keith Jarrett, Dave Holland, Airto Moreira and Steve Grossman, will be included in “Miles at the Fillmore – Miles Davis 1970: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 3,” a four-CD set to be released by Columbia/Legacy on March 25.

headline: Ales of The Times: Belgian Pale Ales
text: The Belgians make a lot of beers that defy categorization. The tasting panel gathered 23 that have one thing in common: they are excellent summer quenchers.

headline: Pastoral Icon or Woolly Menace?
text: YOU don’t have to look far to see the woolly influence of sheep on our cultural lives. They turn up as symbols of peace and a vaguely remembered pastoral way of life in our poetry, our art and our Christmas pageants. Wolves also rank high among our cultural icons, usually in connection with the words “big” and “bad.” And yet there is now a debate underway about substituting the wolf for the sheep on the (also iconic) green hills of Britain.

headline: Judge Orders Hospital to Remove Pregnant Woman From Life Support
text: FORT WORTH — A Texas judge ruled Friday that a Fort Worth hospital may not keep a brain-dead pregnant woman on life support against her family’s wishes, and ordered doctors to take her off the machines by 5 p.m. on Monday.

headline: For Banking Group, Australian Open Becomes a Marketing Opportunity in China
text: An avid tennis fan and amateur player, Katrina Taylor was watching the fourth-seeded Li Na at the Australian Open when she noticed something odd: The courtside signage was in Chinese.

headline: Everyone Wants a Piece of This Wandering Monster
text: Mary Shelley’s famous motherless child enters the angels-and-demons world of an apparent franchise bid in “I, Frankenstein.” Stuart Beattie’s solemn, ho-hum film largely shuns Shelley’s anguished creator as a character and turns his lonely monster into a football between the forces of good and evil: protective gargoyles and demons who covet his secret to immortality.

headline: Quietly Ascending Rock’s Peaks
text: How things become popular is never less than a mystery, and in the age of the post-genre ecosystem, of the YouTube sensation, what becomes popular isn’t nearly as legible as it once was. What was once fringe is now mainstream, what was mainstream is now fringe.

headline: Collector Auctions Suggest Recovery Is Nearly Complete
text: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ. — The classic-car auctions here last week were remarkable for not being especially remarkable: No bubbles burst, and neither did the market make another vertical leap.

headline: ‘Needs Some T.L.C.’ Proves a Powerful Boost to Prices
text: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ. — The sales results from the major collector-car auctions that wrapped up here last week included a long list of record prices and strong indications that the recovery of a market battered by the recession was nearly complete.

headline: Revelatory Archive of a Giant of Jazz
text: WASHINGTON — Max Roach, the great drummer and bandleader and paradigm-shifter of jazz, though he disliked that word, never finished an autobiography.

headline: Desert Stars
text: This year’s Arizona auctions offered no huge surprises, though the high prices realized by a few “barn finds” proved that originality is becoming an ever more prized attribute.

headline: Versatility on Screen and Off
text: NAME Amy Adams

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Amy Adams’s Fashion
text: Ms. Adams, who was in three films last year, has a style that is versatile on and off the screen.

headline: Museums Follow the Call of a Clooney Movie
text: There’s nothing like the advent of a George Clooney movie to put historical institutions on a war footing. Timed to coincide with the Feb. 7 release of “The Monuments Men,” about the heroics of the soldiers and scholars who chased after European cultural treasures plundered by the Nazis, both the Smithsonian Institution and the National WWII Museum in New Orleans announced new ventures. The New Orleans museum said it would open a permanent gallery about the unit in 2016. It will show, among other things, how the soldiers descended into an Austrian salt mine to recover masterpieces hoarded there by Germans. The exhibition will highlight the recovery of works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Picasso and Leonardo da Vinci and the continuing search for works like Raphael’s “Portrait of a Young Man” and Michelangelo’s marble “Mask of a Faun.” Meanwhile in Washington on Feb. 7, the Smithsonian Institution’s Archives of American Art will open an exhibition called “Monuments Men: On the Frontline to Save Europe’s Art, 1942-1946.” It will showcase the work of the scholars in the original unit, one of whom is played by Mr. Clooney.

headline: The District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y.
text: The District 3 Winter Regional took place at the Hilton hotel in Rye Brook, N.Y., from Jan. 14 through last Monday.

headline: Times Minute | Markets Take a Hit
text: Also on the Minute, Bob McDonnell's fall and Thug-Notes for the classics.

headline: Times Minute | Markets Take a Hit
text: In the Video

headline: The Company I Keep
text: The very title of this blog suggests the continual shifting of ground underneath all of us of a certain age. Whatever we thought old age meant yesterday, it means something different today.

headline: By the Numbers: Oscar’s Track Record With Black Filmmakers
text: By the numbers, the Oscars are still a tough game for black filmmakers.

headline: On the Horizon: Berlin International Film Festival; ‘This Is Not a Silent Movie’
text: Film On Feb. 6, the 64th Berlin International Film Festival, or Berlinale, will begin . The film festival will award lifetime honors to the British director Ken Loach and feature over 400 films, including the world premiere of “The Monuments Men,” about an Allied group who recovered stolen artworks from the Nazis, with George Clooney and Matt Damon.

headline: Sympathy for the Toffs
text: Last year, we turned on the plutocrats. Everyone from Pope Francis to Bill de Blasio denounced them. Even Bill and Hillary Clinton, erstwhile champions of pro-business centrism and donor sleepovers at the White House, decided it was prudent to jump on the populist bandwagon. So why are we still smitten with the toffs of “Downton Abbey”?

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 24
text: Subjects include carriage horses in Central Park, the swearing-in ceremony for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and sledding in a Queens park.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 24
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include carriage horses in Central Park, the swearing-in ceremony for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and sledding in a Queens park.

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Items from Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Trade Shows
text: The polar vortex’s return this week was a nuisance to most New Yorkers, but it provided optimal conditions for appreciating the Fall/Winter 2014 wares on offer at the men’s clothing and lifestyle trade shows MAN, Capsule and Project. Among the heritage and camping-supply items that usually abound at these events, a few new lines stood out. Below are the 10 best pieces — some basic, some inclement-weather specific, but all refreshingly new.

headline: Google Pushes Back Against Data Localization
text: The big tech companies have put forth a united front when it comes to pushing back against the government after revelations of mass surveillance. But their cooperation goes only so far.

headline: Letter to Obama From American Detained in Egypt
text: Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen whose Egyptian father belongs to the Muslim Brotherhood, was detained in Cairo in August, as our colleague David Kirkpatrick reported last year.

headline: Distrust in America, War in Syria and Protests in Ukraine
text: In a speech on Jan. 17, President Obama spoke of the challenge of a world “that is remaking itself at a dizzying speed.” The subject of his address at the Justice Department was the complex issues of security, privacy and the limits of government power raised by revelations about the National Security Agency’s spying. That debate continued to rage through the last week. But Mr. Obama could have been speaking as well about conflicts in places like Syria and Ukraine, which seemed to become more intractable with every effort at resolution.

headline: Video of Deadly Bombing in Cairo
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, at least six people were killed and 70 injured in a string of four bombings that targeted police installations across Cairo on Friday. A closed-circuit television camera captured video of the largest blast, a car bomb, which exploded outside the city’s main police headquarters, killing four and badly damaging a museum and library. The bombers responsible for the attack were also briefly captured on video.

headline: Natural Gas Prices Soar as Mercury Plummets
text: HOUSTON — Natural gas prices spiked by nearly 10 percent on Friday to levels not seen since 2010 as another wave of freezing weather brought surges of heating and electricity demand.

headline: The Politics of How to Pay for Pre-K
To Stop Another Snowden
text: To the Editor:

headline: Home Prices in 20 Cities
text: An interactive graphic showing how home prices have changed since you bought your home.

headline: A Spike in Options Trading Before Herbalife’s Stock Fell
text: Last week, before a senator released letters that sent the shares of Herbalife into a tailspin, certain investors were positioning themselves to make money if the stock fell.

headline: Dignity for Farmworkers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Congress and the Climate
text: To the Editor:
