headline: Top Republicans to Call for Legal Status for Some Immigrants
text: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leadership’s broad framework for overhauling the nation’s immigration laws will call this week for a path to legal status — but not citizenship — for many of the 11 million adult immigrants who are in the country illegally, according to aides who have seen the party’s statement of principles. For immigrants brought to the United States illegally as young children, the Republicans would offer a path to citizenship.

headline: Hong Kong Man Seeking to Issue Book About Xi Is Held in China
text: HONG KONG — Three months ago, Yiu Mantin, a retired engineer from Hong Kong, crossed into mainland China for a short visit, as he had done many times. But this time he disappeared into the hands of the police, and his family and friends believe he was singled out because of his second career — book publishing — and especially because he planned to distribute a withering denunciation of President Xi Jinping.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 6 P.M. (Starz Cinema) ORANGES AND SUNSHINE (2011) Emily Watson, above, portrays Margaret Humphreys, a social worker in Nottingham, England, who, starting in 1986, exposed the deportation of as many as 130,000 children from orphanages and group homes in Britain to Australia between the 1940s and 1967. One deportee, now an adult, recalls that he was told, at 10, that he was being sent to a sunny paradise where he could pick oranges off trees. Instead, many of the youngsters found themselves forced into hard labor and enduring physical cruelty and sexual abuse at places like the Bindoon Boys Town, presided over by the Christian Brothers, a Roman Catholic order. The victims were informed that their parents were dead, while their parents — mainly unwed mothers deemed unfit — were told that their children had been placed for adoption in better homes. “This film presents a chilling portrait of bureaucratic stonewalling and denial as Margaret presents her evidence to politicians who meet her accusations with indifference and skepticism, express only a vague regret and assume no responsibility,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this drama, directed by Jim Loach from Ms. Humphreys’s 1994 book, “Empty Cradles.”

headline: Pete Seeger, Champion of Folk Music and Social Change, Dies at 94
text: Pete Seeger, the singer, folk-song collector and songwriter who spearheaded an American folk revival and spent a long career championing folk music as both a vital heritage and a catalyst for social change, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: How Rahul Gandhi Did in His First TV Interview
text: NEW DELHI — It was a highly anticipated TV event on Monday night: Rahul Gandhi, the leader of the Congress Party’s election campaign, sat down with Arnab Goswami of Times Now, the most aggressive journalist on an English-language television network in India, for the politician’s first formal TV interview.

headline: Mass Slaughter of Vulnerable Shark Species in China, Wildlife Group Says
text: Tipped off by a Chinese wildlife protection group that a “shark slaughterhouse” of vulnerable species, including the whale shark, was operating in a town in Zhejiang Province on China’s eastern seaboard, the activists Alex Hofford and Paul Hilton traveled there to take a look.

headline: Former Military Chief Refuses to Testify in Bosnia Genocide Trial
text: LONDON — Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military commander facing war crimes charges in The Hague, refused to testify on Tuesday at the trial of his former political ally, Radovan Karadzic, saying he did not wish to prejudice his own case and was medically unfit to give evidence.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Jan. 28
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | South Bronx Students May Have Found Site of Slave Burial Ground
text: In “South Bronx Students May Have Found Site of Slave Burial Ground,” Lisa W. Foderaro writes about a student project that may have uncovered forgotten history.

headline: Building a Harley Faster
text: While working the line at Harley-Davidson’s factory in York, Pa., Mark Dettinger noticed a small problem. The plastic piece that held electrical parts to the front of a motorcycle, a piece about the size of a hardcover book, wasn’t fitting correctly. Every time a new bike came down the line, it took a few extra shoves to push it into place. In fact, it took an extra 1.2 seconds. But Dettinger, who had spent some 20 years at the York plant, knew that every second counted. With 400 motorcycles built each shift, on two shifts a day, an extra 1.2 seconds per bike added up to 2,200 lost bikes annually. Millions could be lost in revenue. Maybe it wasn’t such a small problem.

headline: 1964: Sen. Smith Becomes First Woman To Seek Presidential Nomination
text: Margaret Chase Smith announces her run for the presidency. Northeast Historic Film

headline: Making Pictures, Finding Solutions in Nicaragua
text: The health crisis Ed Kashi encountered among sugar cane workers in Chichigalpa, Nicaragua, last year was stark. Over the course of two weeks he spent in the area, there was a funeral every day for workers who had died of chronic kidney disease. Though he had gone there on a commission for a nongovernmental organization that was helping the workers, he left convinced that he had to continue his documentation on his own.

headline: The Crowdfunding Site Indiegogo Raises $40 Million
text: Several years ago, the notion of crowdfunding — asking strangers to contribute money to help and idea or project become a tangible reality — seemed like a far-fetched way to successfully and repeatedly finance creative and business ventures.

headline: Who Does Hip-Hop Belong To?
text: After Sunday’s Grammy Awards, Macklemore sent a public apology via text to Kendrick Lamar, whom he had just beaten out for best rap album. Macklemore, who is white, bested four black musicians, including Mr. Lamar, in winning his award in this historically black music genre. Should Macklemore be apologizing? Did he “rob” the other award contenders? Is this just another example of whites appropriating and profiting from historically black music, as some might say Elvis Presley and other early rock ’n’ roll musicians did in the 1950s? Can music transcend race or ethnicity to belong to its fans? Or is our history too scarred by inequality?

headline: Ukrainian Prime Minister Resigns as Parliament Repeals Restrictive Laws
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Mykola Azarov, the prime minister of Ukraine, resigned on Tuesday, hours before a planned vote of no confidence by Parliament that could have stripped him of his powers.

text: WASHINGTON — After five years of fractious political combat, President Obama declared independence from Congress on Tuesday as he vowed to tackle economic disparity with a series of limited initiatives on jobs, wages and retirement that he will enact without legislative approval.

headline: Argentina on the Brink
text: More than a decade after it defaulted on its foreign debts, Argentina is again facing a financial crisis caused largely by misguided government policies.

headline: Pete Seeger is Gone, but His Circles of Song Ring On
text: Pete Seeger spent his life surrounded by circles of song with varying dimensions.

headline: What Does It Mean When a Gay Son Takes His Husband’s Surname?
text: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: My husband and I are thrilled that our son, who is in his late 20s, will be marrying his boyfriend in California this spring. I was not so happy, however, when he told me he’ll be dropping our last name and taking his fiancé's. When I married my husband in the early ‘80s I hyphenated my name, which felt like a good compromise. My husband and I are very hurt by our son’s decision, particularly since neither of us know any other same-sex couples who have chosen to do this (and we’d hoped to have grandchildren that carry on our family name). I also worry what this says about the dynamics of their relationship. I don’t want to be the mom who meddles with her son’s happiness, but am I right to be concerned? And how should I go about expressing my feelings? — Anonymous

headline: The Contract Is Signed. And Now the Negotiation Begins.
text: We are trained in business that the ultimate goal is to get our client to sign on the dotted line. Once there’s a signature on a contract, our job as deal maker is done. All that’s left is to deliver on our end of the agreement.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Eases Some Rules on Data Disclosure
text: The Obama administration says it will allow Internet companies to give customers a better idea of how often the government demands their information, but will not allow companies to disclose what is being collected or how much, Matt Apuzzo and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: A Top Manager Resigns From China’s Foreign Exchange Agency
text: SHANGHAI – An American-trained fund manager who returned to China to help invest the world’s largest foreign exchange reserves has left his government position, the Chinese state-run news media reported on Tuesday.

headline: Bank of Montreal Parent Acquires British Asset Manager for $1.2 Billion
text: LONDON – In a bid to expand its wealth management offerings in Europe, the Bank of Montreal’s parent company said on Tuesday that it would acquire F&C Asset Management of Britain for 708 million pounds, or about $1.2 billion.

headline: Tunisians Take a Step Forward
text: The country unveils an inclusive new constitution.

headline: Palestinian Leader Says He Can Accept Israeli Military in West Bank for 3 Years
text: TEL AVIV — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said in an interview shown Tuesday that he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a three-year transition period as part of a peace deal. But Mr. Abbas said “whoever proposes 10 or 15 years for a transition” was not serious about an agreement.

headline: Protest Songs, From Seeger to Sting to Springsteen
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: ScienceTake: Moles on the Move
text: The terrors of the lawn look as though they are swimming as they tunnel, but they put a lot of force behind their shovel-like paws.

headline: Uncovering the Secrets of Mole Motion
text: The question of how moles move all that dirt when they tunnel just under the surface of lawns has never attracted the extensive study that other forms of locomotion — like the flight of birds and insects, or even the jet-propulsion of jellyfish — have.

headline: Can You Spell That, Please?
text: Publishing tens of thousands of words a day, on tight deadlines, we know we can’t avoid all errors. But it’s frustrating to run correction after correction for certain mistakes that are predictable and therefore eminently avoidable. In my last post, I talked about millions and billions. This week, consider Katherine and Katharine.

headline: In Performance: Okwui Okpokwasili of ‘Bronx Gothic’
text: This week’s video features Okwui Okpokwasili in a scene from “Bronx Gothic,” her solo show which grew out of a series of notes passed between two 11-year-old girls. Directed by Peter Born, the piece, which Ms. Okpokwasili wrote and stars in, continues through Feb. 1 at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church.

headline: Operas Filled With Forbidden Love in Madrid
text: MADRID — Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” a tale of forbidden, ill-fated love, was presented at the Teatro Real this week when one of the major events of the international opera season was also taking place at the theater: the Tuesday premiere of the composer Charles Wuorinen’s “Brokeback Mountain,” an adaptation of the acclaimed short story by Annie Proulx, who wrote the libretto. The “Tristan,” in a production by Peter Sellars, with video by Bill Viola, is a powerful staging that is new to Madrid. On Monday, the house was packed for the fifth performance of the run, attended by Queen Sofía of Spain, who waved to onlookers from the royal box, though among the applause there were scattered boos that could have been motivated by any number of political and economic issues.

headline: Lawmakers Go on the Record for Clinton
text: On Monday, Hillary Rodham Clinton again said she had not yet decided whether she would run for president in 2016. That has not stopped the Democratic Party from coalescing around her.

headline: Casablanca Capital Urges Changes at Cliffs Natural Resources
text: The activist hedge fund Casablanca Capital disclosed on Tuesday that it had taken a 5.2 percent stake in the mining company Cliffs Natural Resources and urged it to spin off its international assets and make other changes.

headline: Time Warner Cable Can Take Heart in History of Failed Hostile Bids
text: If Time Warner Cable manages to avoid a takeover by Charter Communications, will its stock price plummet?

headline: French Court Rejects Residency Request by Roma Family
text: PARIS — A French court rejected on Tuesday a request for residency from the family of Leonarda Dibrani, a teenage Roma girl whose expulsion from France sparked days of protests and a national controversy last year.

headline: Egypt Locks Morsi in Soundproof Cage During Trial
text: CAIRO — Mohamed Morsi, the deposed Egyptian president, appeared in public on Tuesday for the second time since his detention after the military takeover in July, this time locked in a soundproof glass cage as the defendant at a criminal trial.

headline: A Romance 38 Years in the Making
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the surest signs of a film’s front-runner status is its ability to be parodied. So it’s got to be good news for Spike Jonze and the team behind “Her” that the film has attracted plenty of knock-offs, from “Saturday Night Live’s” version with Jonah Hill, “Me,” to the countless takes on YouTube, like “Troubleshooting her,” which imagines a software upgrade that helps fix the problems that develop when you fall for your computer. (“Would you like Element Software to send you a new OS1 that is not looking for anything serious right now? Reassure you that your ex-OS1 didn’t deserve you, and that you’ll meet someone new, besides he or she was, like, crazy anyway”?)

headline: Money and Class
text: My post on Americans starting to recognize class realities has brought some predictable reactions, which I’d place under two headings: (1) “But they have cell phones!” and (2) it’s about how you behave, not how much money you have.

headline: Syrian Talks Disrupted by Congress’s Approval of Aid to Rebels
text: GENEVA — New fireworks erupted at talks between the Syrian government and the opposition here on Tuesday, as the government sharply criticized a recent decision by the United States Congress to approve continued support for the Syrian rebels, and the United Nations’ top mediator decided not to continue talks in the afternoon.

headline: Tension Grows Between Japan and China
text: Relations between China and Japan have been strained since World War II. But now, the regional clash is having a global economic effect, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The battle was on full display last week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, setting off fears that the souring relationship could pose direct economic risk to businesses across the globe. And there may be no one to defuse the situation.

text: President Obama will deliver the State of the Union address to members of Congress and the American people Tuesday night. Times reporters and editors will provide analysis of the speech as it is delivered, but before the president speaks, we’d like to hear from you.

text: Updated: Comments from the tech company Cisco Systems were added to this post. |

headline: Sign of a Chill: E.U. Doesn’t Set Table for Putin
text: BRUSSELS — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has for years trumpeted grand ambitions for Moscow’s relations with the European Union, pushing to break down visa barriers and urging the creation of what he calls a “harmonious economic community stretching from Lisbon to Vladivostok.”

headline: Tax Gains in Europe Lift Profit 90% at Ford
text: DETROIT — Ford Motor, the nation’s No. 2 automaker, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 90 percent, to $3 billion, mostly because of favorable tax benefits related to investments in its European operations.

headline: Fantex Moves Forward With Football Player I.P.O.
text: Fantex, a start-up looking to sell stocks tied to athletes’ future earnings, is getting back in the game after taking a couple of hits.

headline: Adding Up the Costs of Data Breaches
text: There seems to be an announcement almost weekly that a retailer has been the victim of a cyberattack in which consumer information has been stolen. Has this become the next wave of 21st century white-collar crime as the world of electronic credit and payments opens up companies to more and more thefts of financial information?

headline: Food Matters | A Paris Restaurant Where Dessert Is What’s for Dinner
text: “It’s time to rethink the conventions of a meal,” says the French restauranteur Philippe Baranes. That’s just what he’s done with Paris’s first all-desserts restaurant, Dessance — the name is a neologism that combines ‘dessert’ with the French word for birth, ‘naissance’ — which recently opened in a 17th-century townhouse in the city’s Marais district. “Some people find it confusing or even disturbing, but there’s no reason a dish can’t be savory and sweet at the same time,” he says. “My idea was to break the cloisonnéd way in which we think about food.” The menu at Dessance doesn’t run toward the pastries, cakes and tarts that a desserts-only concept might imply, but rather offers a small but intriguing collection of dishes that can be eaten as both desserts and main courses, including, for example, a surprising combination of violet-colored vitelotte potato purée with raw and poached apples, arugula and marjoram granité.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Starts a Music Video Contest
text: The Tribeca Film Festival is collaborating with Genero, a company that makes connections between musicians and filmmakers on a contest that it is calling “Tribeca Interactive & Interlude: A Music Film Challenge.” The idea: make a music video for one of three recently released songs — Damon Albarn’s “Heavy Seas of Love,” Aloe Blacc’s “Ticking Bomb” or Ellie Goulding’s “Dead in the Water.” The prize, one for each song, is $10,000 and a trip to New York to attend the festival, which runs April 16 to 27. And the videos will be used in the promotional campaigns for the recordings.

headline: R.B.S. to Reduce Foreign Exchange Benchmark Offerings
text: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Tuesday that it would reduce the range of foreign exchange benchmarks it offers to clients who trade currency markets.

headline: The Editorial Board’s SOTU Wish List
text: President Obama will deliver the annual State of the Union address tonight at 9 p.m. As someone who has covered these speeches since 1989, I sometimes wish the president would just send a written report up to Congress, which is all that is required by the Constitution, instead of giving a speech that is too politically massaged, filled with too much ritualistic applause, goes on too long and is watched by a dwindling number of Americans.

headline: Tarantino Sues Gawker for Posting Film Script
text: LOS ANGELES — Quentin Tarantino filed a suit against Gawker Media, accusing the web news service of illegally posting on its Defamer site a link to his unproduced script titled “The Hateful Eight,” The Hollywood Reporter said on Monday.

headline: Share Your Story About Postpartum Depression
text: Setting up a nursery and bringing home a newborn evokes images of blissful mothers, delighting in the joys of parenthood. But the experience of pregnancy and caring for a baby can also cause feelings of depression, anxiety and, in rare cases, psychosis. Pam Belluck, a New York Times health reporter, will be examining new efforts by scientists and doctors to better understand the causes and consequences of postpartum mood disorders.

text: Welcome to a week of Great Ideas From Readers.

headline: Who Are James Joyce’s Modern Heirs?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Rivka Galchen and Pankaj Mishra discuss James Joyce’s legacy today.

headline: Challenges for the Yellen Fed
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Albert Cashier’s Secret
text: In the spring of 1914, a Civil War veteran named Albert Cashier arrived at the Illinois state hospital for the insane with symptoms of advanced dementia. As a young private, Cashier had fought at the siege of Vicksburg, where he and his comrades broke the spine of the Confederacy, and his name was inscribed on the Illinois victory monument there. He had lived out the intervening years in modest circumstances, working as a farm hand, a laborer and, on occasion, a street lamplighter, one of the many former soldiers whose civilian lives never achieve the glory of their wartime service. He was destined for the same obscurity in death, had it not been for a secret that the state hospital made public: Albert Cashier was actually a woman named Jennie Hodgers.

headline: More Ships Sailing the Caribbean
text: A fleet of new ships in the Caribbean could mean not just greater selection but better deals for tropics-bound sailors. In November, the year-old, 3,502-guest MSC Divina began sailing year-round to the Caribbean from Miami. The new 4,000-passenger Norwegian Getaway launches Feb. 8, offering Caribbean itineraries from its home port, also Miami. In May, Princess Cruises introduces the 3,560-passenger Regal Princess in the Mediterranean; it will move to Fort Lauderdale in November to serve the eastern Caribbean. Making its debut in November, Royal Caribbean International’s 4,905-passenger Quantum of the Seas will offer regular Caribbean and Bahamas sailings from Cape Liberty, N.J.

headline: Lloyds Banking Group to Cut More Than 1,000 Jobs
text: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group said on Tuesday that it would eliminate an additional 1,080 jobs as part of a restructuring plan first it began in 2011.

headline: ‘King Kong’ Will Stomp Onto Broadway in December, Producer Says
text: The next big-budget musical heading to Broadway, “King Kong,” featuring a 20-foot-tall puppet in the title role, will open at the Foxwoods Theater in December, according to the chairman of the Australian production company mounting the show.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Seals Deal for Texas Industries
text: Martin Marietta Materials has agreed to acquire Texas Industries in an all-stock deal worth more than $2 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday morning.

headline: Readers’ Photos of Light in the City
text: Readers were invited to take a photograph showing how light — or the lack of it — affected their daily life in the city. This is what they captured.

headline: Turkey’s Central Bank Aggressively Raises Rates
text: FRANKFURT — Turkey’s central bank aggressively raised rates late Tuesday, in a drastic move aimed at bolstering the currency. But it is unclear whether the move will be enough to satisfy international investors and repair the central bank’s reputation.

headline: Google Buys A.I. Company for Search, Not Robots
text: “I’d like to go on a vacation somewhere warm over the summer, but only have a budget of $1,000. Where should I go?”

headline: Cherished Beams of Sunlight, as Captured by Readers
text: As New York City grows ever more vertical, sprouting fresh batches of breathtakingly high towers by the year, one of the casualties has been natural sunlight. Streets, stoops and parks are growing darker, and people’s apartments are too, which we explored in an article last month. We asked readers to submit their experiences of light and shadow in New York City, and discovered anew how deeply personal light, and its absence, is for people living in this space-deprived town.

headline: Today in Small Business: Raising Prices
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Palm Springs, a Refreshingly Rustic Alternative to Midcentury Modernism
text: Doug Smith has essentially spent his adult life hosting one nonstop party. In the ’70s, he ran a beachside cafe in Greece that was frequented by yachts tracing paths through the Aegean Sea. In the ’80s, he transformed a 1924 Moroccan-style villa in Palm Springs into the lush, hallowed retreat Korakia Pensione. He’s gutted a

headline: Authorities Name the Rest of Task Force on Seized German Art
text: BERLIN — Thirteen experts in art history, provenance research and restitution issues have been appointed to assist German authorities in establishing the history of hundreds of artworks discovered in the Munich apartment of Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of a well-known Nazi-era art dealer.

headline: The Boulevardier Is Back on the Menu
text: The cocktail revolution has had its share of successful salvage projects, forgotten drinks of yesteryear that have staged a modest comeback on bar menus. The Aviation, the Last Word and the Sherry Cobbler are among these Lazarus libations.

headline: A Dynast’s Flailing Makeover
text: NEW DELHI — In September, Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Congress Party and scion of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty, made an unannounced public appearance at a news conference in New Delhi. Minutes previously, Mr. Gandhi had called up Ajay Maken, the party’s general secretary, to ask him his whereabouts.

headline: Image of the Day: January 28
text: An activist in Bangalore, Karnataka, during a protest against the Supreme Court’s reinstatement of section 377 that bans gay sex in India.

headline: J.C. Penney Amends Poison Pill Plan
text: J.C. Penney altered its poison pill plan on Tuesday as it seeks to defend itself against potential activist investors and preserve a tax benefit.

headline: The Grammys: Old Rockers, Young Goths and Public Apologies
text: Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the Grammy Awards.

headline: As Apple Shares Fall, Icahn Plucks More
text: Wall Street investors were shaken by Apple Inc.’s latest quarterly results. But not Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Grammys Popcast: Old Rockers, Young Goths and Public Apologies
text: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis won a lot of awards at the Grammys on Sunday: no surprise, given their YouTube hits, their narrative of scrappy ascendance and their clear moral messaging, not to mention last year’s advances in cultural borrowing on the part of white artists in pop and hip-hop. (And the even newer advances in apologizing for success through that borrowing.)

headline: Headphones Designed for Work or Play
text: When I last wrote about in-ear headphones from Sol Republic, I criticized their design because they kept falling out of my ears unless I sat perfectly still.

headline: Merger Puts New Face on Opposition Election Bid in South Africa
text: LONDON — Opponents of South Africa’s governing African National Congress drew battle lines on Tuesday for national elections, announcing a merger that will give the main opposition party its first black candidate for president as it seeks a broader political legitimacy to challenge the long dominance of the A.N.C.

headline: Times Minute | Pete Seeger’s Political Legacy
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Seeger's Political Legacy
text: Also on the Minute, Obama on the minimum wage and how moles dig.

headline: Indian Supreme Court Won’t Review Gay Sex Ban
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Tuesday dismissed a motion to review a December decision that reinstated a 19th-century ban on gay sex.

headline: How to | Frame a Picture
text: T’s European editor, Rita Konig, offers subtle insights into packaging and hanging art.

headline: Smear Today, Gone Tomorrow?
text: Last week I mentioned local news reports about the bizarre and vicious smear campaign Kim Guadagno, Chris Christie’s lieutenant governor, waged against an artist involved with the New Jersey Arts Council. Today the story is in the Times. Ms. Guadagno sure seems like a real piece of work — as do several other close associates of governor yells-at-people.

headline: Pushing Inaction on Immigration
text: Some moderate Republicans are finally worried enough about alienating large chunks of the American electorate that they are considering the idea of giving legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants in the United States – and even citizenship to a much smaller group.

headline: Teach the Super Bowl: Ideas for Subjects Across the Curriculum
text: How can you make this week’s Super Bowl relevant to your curriculum? Whether debating football-related controversies, making predictions, analyzing ads, writing descriptions, understanding data and statistics or learning about head trauma, we have ideas for using The Times and the Learning Network to do it.

headline: Video of Palestinian President is Shown at Tel Aviv Conference
text: As my colleague Jodi Rudoren reported, the Palestinian president has said in a recorded interview that he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a three-year transition period as part of a peace deal.

headline: On the Problem of Defining Upper Class
text: Aha. When I wrote about the problem of saying where upper class begins, I somehow forgot that the whole thing was explained long ago by Gordon Gekko:

headline: Louis C. K. to Release His First Feature Film Online
text: The great white whale for Louis C. K. completists is now in sight. On Wednesday at noon, he will release “Tomorrow Night,” his rarely seen first feature film (which he wrote, directed and played a cameo role in) on his website where it will be available for $5. The movie was shown at the Sundance Film Festival in 1998 but never got distribution.

headline: Jimmy Carter Book on Women’s Rights Is Set for March Release
text: Simon & Schuster will publish a new book by Jimmy Carter on the treatment of women, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Ukraine’s Uncertainties Include Financial Aid
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As Ukraine’s political crisis has deepened, an economic question looms: Will Russia continue to bail out the country if it again tilts to the West?

headline: A Video Lesson in Picture Framing
text: “Each frame does something different to the picture,” says Rita Konig, T’s European editor. In this new video for T, she takes a trip to the Lacy Gallery in West London to have a print of a red onion by the artist Rory McEwen framed. Along the way, she shares her sometimes unorthodox philosophy on picture framing, then goes on to offer a few thoughtful pointers on picture hanging as well.

headline: Reflections on Falluja and the Impermanence of Victory
text: Before there was a battle for Falluja, we threw darts.

headline: Kocherlakota and the Cultists
text: Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Minneapolis Fed, is the prodigal son of monetary stimulus. He was the Fed’s leading hawk a few years ago, reflecting in part the ultra-freshwater macro doctrines of the Minnesota econ department and his bank’s closely associated research department. But he did something amazing: he looked at evidence, listened to his critics, and changed his views — becoming the Fed’s leading dove.

headline: Serbian Ex-Fugitives Mladic and Karadzic Reunite in Court
text: PARIS — One is a former warrior known as the Butcher of Bosnia who spent more than 15 years on the run in his native Serbia, where he was finally captured.

headline: Super Bowl Attracts a Marijuana Message
text: New Jersey probably looks a lot like home to the Denver Broncos. The billboards, anyway.

headline: With Eye on Spain, Liberty Said to Join Hunt for ONO
text: LONDON — On the heels of its $13.7 billion deal on Monday to buy the Dutch cable operator Ziggo, John C. Malone’s Liberty Global media company is now reported to be in talks to acquire the Spanish telecoms operator ONO, according to The Financial Times.

headline: The Gun Report: January 28, 2014
text: More than 7,000 children and teenagers were hospitalized for firearm injuries in 2009, according to a study in February’s Pediatrics. That works out to twenty young people per day. Six percent of those hospitalizations resulted in a death.

headline: A Familiar Trip for a Pre-Crisis Buyout
text: Another big pre-crisis buyout is heading for an unexpectedly safe landing. Seven years after taking travel technology company Sabre private for $5 billion, owners TPG and Silver Lake Partners are making the round-trip return to public markets. It’s one of many boom-time deals whose badly timed takeoff led to a bumpy ride.

headline: Second Outdoor N.H.L. Game in the Bronx Is a Hot Ticket
text: Ticket demand for the Rangers-Islanders game at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night has increased, a sign that the N.H.L.’s strategy of staging two outdoor games in the metropolitan area during Super Bowl week is succeeding.

headline: State of the States
text: The State of the State speech, that annual display of policy and pride, can be a call to action, plea for patience and, in some cases, an early look at a re-election platform.

headline: Report Says BBC Executives’ Oversight of Digital Project Was Flawed
text: LONDON — An independent report published on Tuesday accused the BBC of significant management failings in connection with an abandoned 126 million pound digital project, saying the broadcaster failed to assess the initiative properly or provide adequate oversight of its progress.

headline: Pakistani University Cancels Event Promoting Teenager’s Memoir
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Malala Yousafzai may be a global celebrity, but in her home province, she remains a focus of controversy.

headline: Thai Aristocrat Joins Political Fray, Backing Elections
text: BANGKOK — With a buzzer installed in her house to summon her servants and a royal title that helps secure choice tables at Bangkok restaurants, Malinee Chakrabandhu is a bona fide member of the Thai aristocracy.

headline: Complete Ben Jonson Released Online
text: Shakespeare may get all the love on the modern stage, but his contemporary Ben Jonson has just grabbed a share of the limelight in cyberspace.

headline: A Small Window Into Apple, Courtesy of Tim Cook
text: Apple sold more iPhones and iPads over the last quarter than any other quarter. Yet Apple’s profit was flat compared with last year, and iPhone sales were down in North America, raising questions among investors about how much room Apple has to grow.

headline: Pigs in Blankets, Artful Pie Pans, Gluten-Free Cakes and More
text: To Snack: Wee Pigs Till the Wee Hours

headline: Beyoncé Doesn’t Faze ‘Frozen’s’ Songwriters
text: LOS ANGELES — “Frozen,” the Disney-animated and Oscar-nominated hit, is also one of the longest-running blockbusters of the season, with a 10-week streak at or near the top of the box office. The company announced that a sing-along version of the film would be shown at more than 1,000 theaters around the country on Friday even as its directors, Jennifer Lee and Chris Buck, are in Japan, in advance of its March 15 opening there. (That’s more international dollars for Disney, if the popularity of a foreign language-version of the film’s theme song, “Let It Go,” is to be believed. )

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: The U.S. Department of Agriculture briefly suspended poultry processing at one of the biggest Foster Farms plants in California because it was infested with live cockroaches. But Bill Marler asks, why does the U.S.D.A. and its food inspection service have the authority to shutter a plant for cockroaches but not for salmonella?

headline: Introducing Jennifer Blumin, New Business Group Member
text: In my last post, we met two of three new members to join the She Owns It business group. This post introduces the third.

headline: For Fliers, a Month Marked by Cancellations
text: The new year has gotten off to a rough start for fliers, with winter storms causing tens of thousands canceled flights in the first few weeks of 2014 (more than in January 2012 and January 2013 combined) and a forecast that has both airlines and passengers bracing for another blow this week.

headline: Pete Seeger
text: The folk musician and activist at the Beacon Sloop Club.

headline: Super Bowl Teams Meet the Media
text: Images from the N.F.L.’s Super Bowl media day on Tuesday at the Prudential Center in Newark, where hundreds of reporters interviewed players from the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos.

headline: A Softer Front Page: The Readers React
text: Consider the media habits of Mathew Ingram, a senior writer on media and technology at GigaOm, the online news site.

headline: Robert Diamond’s New Firm Hires Executive From J. C. Flowers
text: As Robert E. Diamond Jr.  builds his new firm — his latest venture since leaving Barclays as chief executive — he has hired some experienced help to serve by his side.

headline: Times Minute | State of Union Preview
text: On the Minute, a look ahead to this evening’s State of the Union address — from President Obama’s tone to the expected Republican response.

headline: Harkness Foundation for Dance Names New Director
text: For more than three decades, Theodore S. Bartwink, the executive director of the Harkness Foundation for Dance, has helped distribute millions of dollars in grants to scores of dance companies. But with Mr. Bartwink now 85, and recovering from injuries he sustained when he was struck by a car last year, the foundation announced that he would be retiring.

headline: Living in Mendham Borough , N.J.
text: A Morris County town with a direct train line to Manhattan and nearby corporate employers.

headline: An Outpost of New England
text: Does it still exist, the town with a mud hole for fishing, a four-lane bowling alley, and Labor Day festivities with a 70-year history? A place where the schools and the scenery are far above average?

headline: Printing a Photo From a Phone
text: Q. I have a photo on my phone that I want to print out and give to a friend, but how do I get it off my phone? Do I need a special photo printer or can the regular printer I use do it?

headline: Keep the Joy, Take Back the Fun
text: Is life as a parent “all joy and no fun”? That’s the premise, or at least the title, of Jennifer Senior’s book on “The Paradox of Modern Parenthood.” Janet Maslin reviewed the book for The Times under the wonderful headline “My Kid’s Idle for a Second? Oh, Horrors!” (You can hear Ms. Senior talk about the book in the video below this post.)

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | First Stop, the Barker Bowl
text: It’s been a while since we dusted off the gowns and hit a party in the name of journalism; too long, 760 days too long in fact — not that we’ve been counting every agonizingly boring night since we last assumed our alter ego Nocturnalist and hit the town, notebook in hand.

headline: Dreaming About a Summer Rental? Act Soon
text: The race is on. There may be snow on the ground but if you want to rent a summer house in some of the most competitive markets in the northeast — the Hamptons, Cape Cod, the Jersey Shore — it’s time to put down your shovel and pick up your checkbook. Novice renter? Not to worry. Here’s a primer.

headline: Hotel Review: Lumeria Maui
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Tosca Cafe in San Francisco
text: After working our way through gridlock around the bar, my husband and I reached the gatekeeper at the dining room. It was 7:15 on a Wednesday evening, and the wait for a table, we were told, would be “45 minutes to an hour and a half.”

headline: TV Stations in Los Angeles to Share a Channel to Free Up Spectrum
text: WASHINGTON — Two broadcast television stations in Los Angeles will become the first participants in a pilot test of the government’s plans to eventually free up and auction off more airwaves for use in wireless broadband, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: U.N. Takes New Steps in Central African Republic
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday to impose a travel ban on and freeze the assets of people suspected of war crimes in Central African Republic, as the European Union prepared to send a battalion to protect civilians from an unrelenting sectarian war there.

headline: A Swipe at Traditional Banking at a Forum Illuminating Bitcoin
text: A hearing Tuesday on the regulatory future of Bitcoin instead turned into a forum on the shortcomings of the traditional banking industry.

headline: Prince Files Lawsuit Over Links to Music File-Sharing Sites
text: Prince Rogers Nelson — the artist known as the artist formerly known as Prince — has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in San Francisco against 22 Internet users who, the singer’s lawyers say, are responsible for posting links to unauthorized recordings of his concerts. The filing, which was first reported on Torrent Freak, a website devoted to file sharing and copyright issues, describes the 22 bloggers as part of a network who used their blogs and Facebook pages to distribute the recordings. Prince hopes to recover $1 million from each. Only two of the 22 — Dan Chodera and Karina Jindrova — are listed by their real names. The others are listed by Internet handles like PurpleHouse2, PurpleKissTwo and TheUltimateBootlegExperience.

headline: Times Minute | State of the Union Preview
text: In the Video

headline: Irish Government Ordered to Compensate Abuse Victim
text: DUBLIN — The European Court of Human Rights ruled on Tuesday that a 49-year-old Irish woman was entitled to compensation for the government’s failure to protect her from sexual abuse as a child when she attended a publicly financed Roman Catholic primary school in the 1970s.

headline: More Than Just a Pretty Seed
text: Pomegranates are beautiful, of course, but they can seem more suitable for garnishing than gratification.

headline: Clip: 'Charlie Victor Romeo'
text: A scene from the film directed by Robert Berger, Patrick Daniels, and Karlyn Michelson.

headline: Super Bowl Visitors Guide
text: A guide to all things Super Bowl XLVIII around the New York/New Jersey metro area.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, China and Greece.

headline: From a Nest of Rhythm, Teaching the Young to Fly
text: Many ballet dancers, after retiring, go on to start their own schools. Jacques d’Amboise, who had a celebrated career of almost 35 years with New York City Ballet, found his second calling even before he left the company, when he established the National Dance Institute in 1976. This is no elite ballet academy but a far-reaching nonprofit that teaches kids about the joy of movement (something that strict classical training can’t always claim to do). The real lessons, of course, are in areas like self-confidence and teamwork.

headline: The Price for Super Bowl Volunteers
text: Volunteerism has become as much a part of the Super Bowl as the Roman numeral identification of games, allowing those who cannot attend the games to be a part of the festivities by welcoming those who can.

headline: A Critique of an Upbeat Assessment of Nuclear Power’s Prospects
text: The Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit group long focused on risks attending the use of nuclear energy, has posted a critique of the pro-nuclear letter from four longtime analysts that was the focus of a recent piece here titled “More Views on Nuclear Power, Waste, Safety and Cost.”

headline: Moscow 57 on Delancey Street and More Restaurant Openings
text: Headliner Moscow 57

headline: Fine Tempura, Piece by Delectable Piece
text: TOKYO — Last year at a counter in a small restaurant here, I ate tempura that seemed elevated to an art form, like the finest sushi.

headline: What’s In It | Protein Bars
text: Protein bars offer convenience, but they can also contain as much sugar as a candy bar and the calorie count of an entire meal.

headline: A Look Inside the Protein Bar
text: Protein is the hot ingredient of the moment in processed foods, joining the terms organic and low-fat as a major selling point to pitch to health-conscious shoppers. While carbohydrates and many fats are still widely regarded as suspect, protein is being proudly added to products throughout the grocery store, especially the snack aisle, which has made way for a new star: the protein bar. But a closer look shows that its blessings are mixed.

headline: With Social Media’s Rise, the Pulpit Isn’t Just the President’s Anymore
text: WASHINGTON — Twitter has fast become the conventional-wisdom clearinghouse and real-time echo chamber for major political events, so it was not surprising Tuesday evening when Twitter also became the forum where opinion on President Obama’s State of the Union address seemed to crystallize before he had even finished speaking.

headline: Profit Surges for AT&T, Outstripping Expectations
text: SAN FRANCISCO — AT&T finished 2013 strong despite aggressive moves from T-Mobile US, the smaller wireless carrier.

headline: New York Property Managers Devise Survival Plans for the Next Disaster
text: In the hectic days that followed Hurricane Sandy, the only place that John Ambrosini could find cell service was on a hill near his home on the North Shore of Long Island.

headline: Fred and Barney Would Feel Right at Home
text: The steakhouse is in trouble. Not financial trouble, because new ones keep opening, but spiritual trouble. Its soul is unwell. Because many other restaurants now offer better beef, the steakhouse serves little purpose except as a stage set for the dwindling number of occasions that require men to bond by spending money and consuming red meat together.

headline: With Ad Dollars Elusive, Yahoo’s Revenue Falls
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Under the turnaround plan devised by Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, the company gained traffic and mobile users in 2013 and introduced a bevy of products, like a slick digital food magazine and a mobile weather app.

headline: Wall Street Listens for Litigation and Tax Clues in Obama’s Speech
text: Like last year, Wall Street might not be at the top of President Obama’s agenda in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night. But that doesn’t mean the financial community won’t be listening for certain cues.

headline: Severe Cold Moves New York’s Homeless to Seek Help
text: Anthony Scott managed to survive in the nooks and crannies of Manhattan for two winters, burrowing under piles of blankets and cardboard on West 31st Street if he could not find a spot at Pennsylvania Station, the Port Authority Bus Terminal or on the E train.

headline: The Star Treatment for a Little-Known Work
text: I’m a little ashamed to admit I wasn’t entirely looking forward to the pianist Marc-André Hamelin’s recital on Monday evening at Zankel Hall. The centerpiece was a rare performance of the Sonata in E minor (Op. 25, No. 2) by Nicolas Medtner (1880-1951), a Russian composer — well known neither in his time nor ours — championed by Mr. Hamelin.

headline: Kellogg Foundation to Give  $40 Million to Aid Detroit Institute of Arts
text: The W.K. Kellogg Foundation announced Tuesday that it would contribute $40 million toward the broad philanthropic effort announced earlier this month to try to save the collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts and to avoid cuts to municipal pensions in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy case.

headline: Lower Manhattan Landlords Compete for BNY Mellon
text: A venerable Wall Street firm’s search for a new home has set off a fierce competition among developers in Lower Manhattan, highlighting the challenges in a commercial district that has acres of vacant office space even as towers are under construction.

headline: The Urban Home Away From Home
text: But why that McDonald’s?

headline: Marinara Sauce
text: Every home cook should have a basic marinara sauce in his or her repertoire. Julia Moskin makes a simple recipe from Lidia Bastianich’s book, “Lidia’s Commonsense Italian Cooking.”

headline: It’s Not About 007, but It Sort of Is
text: To answer your main question first: about 10 minutes.

headline: Marinara Worth Mastering
text: The first thing to know about marinara: it’s not a synonym for tomato sauce.

headline: Erskine Bowles to Lead Morgan Stanley Board
text: Morgan Stanley announced Tuesday that Erskine Bowles, who has served as a director of the board since 2005, had been named as lead director.

headline: Yahoo Earnings Shed More Light on Alibaba’s Growth
text: Yahoo is nominally the focus of its fourth-quarter earnings report, but another company is receiving just as much scrutiny: Alibaba of China.

headline: Interview: Alfre Woodard
text: Melena Ryzik speaks to the actress at the Screen Actors Guild awards.

headline: In Search of Confidence
text: The consumer confidence figures just released showed an increase, but they remain at a level that is historically low.

headline: Video: Alfre Woodard’s Sole Scene
text: LOS ANGELES — Alfre Woodard has just one scene in “12 Years a Slave,” but it is a pivotal one for the film and for the screenwriter, John Ridley. The moment, which was not in the Solomon Northup memoir on which the film is based, involves the slaves Patsey (Lupita Nyong’o) and Solomon (Chiwetel Ejiofor) visiting another plantation for a tea party of sorts held by a slave turned favored lady, Mistress Shaw (played by Ms. Woodard). Mr. Ridley invented the scene, and it was the most difficult thing he wrote, he said, containing one of the few touches of humor in the film.

headline: For Soggy Everton, No Bright Side in Loss to Liverpool
text: LIVERPOOL, England — Everton Manager Roberto Martínez is a genuinely upbeat man, a coach who can seemingly find positives in anything. When his former team, Wigan, was relegated from the Premier League last year, he admitted to disappointment, but noted that the club was on “fantastic financial footing” and had a promising “football philosophy.”

headline: An Iraq Blasted Open, Sketched From the Inside
text: The literature of American warfare tends to land in overlapping waves, like an invasion. First come the novels by the war correspondents. Then, in time, fiction begins to arrive from the returning combatants. Only later, like cries of the wounded after a barrage subsides, can the other side finally make itself heard.

headline: Comparing Obamacare to Its Alternative
text: FROM the moment the ink dried on March 23, 2010, Republicans said they intended to “repeal and replace” the Affordable Care Act. They have voted more than 40 times to wipe the law from the books. But Republicans have never gotten around to describing, in detail, the set of policies they believe should replace Obamacare. That is, until yesterday.

headline: An Artistic Life Retraced, in Fantasy and Memory
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The best thing about Douglas Dunn’s dances is how they are unlike anyone else’s. His eclectic works also differ from one another, but they all seem to express a particular, peculiar sensibility: elegant, eccentric, serious, wry, fascinated by contradictions, susceptible to beauty but skeptical, too.

headline: In a First, Northwestern Players Seek Unionization
text: CHICAGO — The increasingly contentious and complicated relationship between the N.C.A.A. and its top amateur athletes took another step toward a legal showdown on Tuesday when a group of Northwestern football players appealed to the National Labor Relations Board with the first effort by college athletes to join a labor union.

headline: A Medici to Spray Paint and Graffiti Artists
text: “Times have changed,” Aaron Goodstone said stoically, eyeing the spruced-up brick tenement at Ridge and Stanton Streets on the Lower East Side, now hip, where his friend Martin Wong once lived. Thirty years ago, when Mr. Goodstone was a teenage graffiti artist, he vied with drug dealers for the corner pay phone to reach Wong in his buzzerless sixth-floor walk-up: a salon, a studio, an archive and a refuge among the crumbling buildings and gated storefronts.

headline: Live Coverage of Obama’s 2014 State of the Union Address
text: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night, and Times reporters and editors are providing analysis during the speech.

headline: House Votes to Restrict Payments for Abortions
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to impose tighter restrictions on federal payments for abortions, thrusting the issue of a woman’s right to terminate a pregnancy into the polarizing politics of an election year.

headline: Agnes Varis Trust to Give $3 Million to Gibney Dance
text: The Agnes Varis Trust will give $3 million to Gibney Dance, the formerly all-women dance troupe that is known for its social activism and is about to expand its operations to 280 Broadway in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Answers to a Puzzling Deal at Alibaba Remain in the Shadows
text: The Chinese Internet giant Alibaba is looking to join the ranks of Google and Microsoft with an initial public offering that could give it a value of more than $100 billion. But the company’s recent acquisition of the Hong Kong-listed company Citic 21CN shows just how much we still don’t know about Alibaba and its business.

headline: Military Is Asked to Return Guantánamo Inmate to Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for a Yemeni man who has been held for 12 years without trial at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, asked a parole-style military board on Tuesday to recommend that he be sent home, where he planned to teach and possibly start a “milk and honey farm” or work for his father’s tailoring business, according to a prepared statement.

headline: Met Opera Reports Falling Attendance
text: Although the Metropolitan Opera is raising more money from donors and earning more from its “Live in HD” movie theater presentations, it is making less at the box office, selling just 79 percent of its seats in the 2012-13 season, it announced in a financial filing.

headline: Capturing Football’s Snaps, Crackles and Pops in Madden NFL
text: BURNABY, British Columbia — The football players strutted down a 40-yard strip of synthetic turf, yelling, jumping and flailing their arms to whip the fans into a frenzy. But there was no stadium and no crowd here on this recent day, only a barnlike studio with an animator directing the mock celebration and a few computer technicians recording the movements with dozens of high-speed motion-capture cameras that zero in on 65 reflective markers Velcroed to the players’ uniforms.

headline: Examining the Timing of J.C. Penney’s Poison Pill Change
text: J.C. Penney’s announcement on Tuesday that it had set a new, lower threshold for its poison pill raises the question: Why now?

headline: Gallery | A New Book Looks Back at Miami Beach’s Legendary, Soon-to-Be-Revived Surf Club
Drama Where You’d Want It the Least: In the Cockpit
text: The visible action in “Charlie Victor Romeo,” a new 3-D film adaptation of a stage play first performed in 1999, consists of unfamiliar actors in familiar uniforms reciting verbatim dialogue from official transcripts. Directed by Robert Berger, Patrick Daniels and Karlyn Michelson, it is a curious hybrid of documentary and experimental theater. It is also one of the most terrifying movies I have ever seen.

headline: What Private Equity Is Listening for in the State of the Union
text: In his State of the Union speech on Tuesday night, President Obama is expected to highlight a willingness to bypass Congress to get things done. That new stance could make private equity bosses nervous.

headline: Planned Comcast Tech Center Raises Sights in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — The city that once boasted that no building would be higher than William Penn’s hat atop City Hall is getting a new skyscraper, to be the city’s tallest and more than twice as high as the iconic statue.

headline: Alan B. Abramson
text: Mr. Abramson, 67, is the president and chief executive of Abramson Brothers, a family owned commercial real estate company that owns and manages office buildings, mainly in Midtown. The company was founded in 1957 by Mr. Abramson’s father and uncle, Manville and Junius Abramson.

headline: Meeting the Cost of Conceiving
text: Melanie Martin, a surgical nurse in San Diego, said she and her husband cut every corner they could think of to save up enough money to pay for conceiving a child through the technique known as in vitro fertilization.

headline: Seeking Better Legal Help for Immigrants
text: In the next several days, the deans of the nation’s top law schools will be notified of a new job opportunity for their graduating students. Applicants must be high achievers who want to be part of a groundbreaking start-up, live in New York City, train with veteran lawyers and help create a new paradigm in immigration representation.

headline: Confronting Old Problem May Require a New Deal
text: We look back upon the Great Depression as a discrete event with a beginning and an end; a long and profound economic shock but one that turned out to be nonetheless temporary. In the 1930s, however, many feared that what John Maynard Keynes clinically called “equilibrium at less than full employment” might, in fact, be the new normal — forever.

headline: The Next Accident Awaits
text: WASHINGTON — THE United States is facing an industrial chemical safety crisis. The horrifying chemical spill that recently contaminated the drinking water of hundreds of thousands of people in West Virginia is the latest in a relentless series of disasters and near-misses across the country.

headline: Madden NFL: The 33rd Team
text: A group of athletes, animators and technicians use motion capture technology to make the football video game Madden NFL as realistic as possible from every tackle to scrimmage line fidget.

headline: After Crisis, Greeks Work to Promote ‘Social’ Economy
text: ALONIA, Greece — The feisty owner of a small family business that makes detergents has never had time for anticapitalist firebrands. So he was suspicious and skeptical when he was approached by left-leaning activists campaigning to purge “profiteers” from the market.

headline: Texas: Woman at Center of Struggle Will Be Cremated
text: The brain-dead pregnant woman who was taken off life support after her family’s battle to gain custody of her body from a Fort Worth hospital will be cremated, her mother said Tuesday. Marlise Muñoz, 33, had been on life support since November against her family’s wishes. The hospital had refused to disconnect her, citing a Texas law that prohibits doctors from withdrawing life support to pregnant patients. The hospital removed her from the machines on Sunday after a judge’s order. She was 22 weeks pregnant. Her fetus, which the hospital said was not viable, was a girl.

headline: An American Family Returns to the Table
text: A brand that garnered brickbats — and bouquets — last year for its take on modern family life is returning with another 30-second parable about diversity, this time during Super Bowl XLVIII, the year’s biggest showcase for advertising.

headline: Hedge Funds Sniff for Even Bigger Payouts From Banks
text: One of the biggest bets on Wall Street rests on a theory that also deeply unsettles Wall Street.

headline: Morrie Turner Dies at 90; Broke Race Barriers in Comics
text: Morrie Turner, a cartoonist who broke the color barrier twice — as the first African-American comic strip artist whose work was widely syndicated in mainstream newspapers, and as the creator of the first syndicated strip with a racially and ethnically mixed cast of characters — died on Saturday in Sacramento. He was 90.

headline: Afghan Justice Proves Complicated in Killing of 9-Year-Old Boy
text: HERAT, Afghanistan — The case has consumed this city in western Afghanistan for over a year: A 9-year-old boy, Ali Sena Nowruzi, is kidnapped on his way to school by his trusted friend and bodyguard, and then is found beaten to death.

headline: A Man of No Words, the Seahawks’ Lynch Finally Delivers a Few
text: NEWARK — The mercurial Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch was fined $50,000 by the N.F.L. this month for declining to speak with the news media this season.

headline: Prisoner of the Green Room
text: Well, I’m at CNN; said my pre-SOTU piece. Now to sit through the speech, and comment after. Unfortunately, it seems that nobody brought the bourbon. .

headline: ‘Fragile Five’ Is the Latest Club of Emerging Nations in Turmoil
text: The long-running boom in emerging markets came to be identified, if not propped up, by wide acceptance of the term BRICs, shorthand for the fast-growing countries Brazil, Russia, India and China. Recent turmoil in these and similar markets has produced a rival expression: the Fragile Five.

headline: SAC’s Counsel Testifies at Insider Trading Trial in Unexpected Move by the Defense
text: Peter Nussbaum, the general counsel of SAC Capital Advisors, took the witness stand on Tuesday in a bold and surprising move by the defense at the insider trading case of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC trader.

headline: Frigid Blast Disrupts Life in South and Midwest as Emergencies Are Declared
text: CHICAGO — In Alabama, snow made roads impassable and forced some schools to prepare to keep students overnight. Many people in metro Atlanta planned to sleep in offices and hotels. And here in Chicago, where winter usually brings a shrug, parents scrambled to find day care after public school classes were canceled Tuesday for the fourth day this month.

headline: Rebels in Syria Claim Control of Resources
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamist rebels and extremist groups have seized control of most of Syria’s oil and gas resources, a rare generator of cash in the country’s war-battered economy, and are now using the proceeds to underwrite their fights against one another as well as President Bashar al-Assad, American officials say.

headline: Pete Seeger, Neil Young and the Importance of Letting Go
text: Four decades later, Pete Seeger couldn’t let it go.

headline: Video Notebook: Fans at Media Day
text: Fans who attended media day on Tuesday shared their impressions.

headline: For $28.50, All the Super Bowl Hype a Fan Could Stand
text: NEWARK — Super Bowl media day has its traditions. Reporters and other credentialed people, some in character costumes, ask the teams’ players serious and inane questions.

headline: Roadblocks on Health Reform
text: Onerous restrictions imposed by Missouri on federally approved counselors who help people understand and enroll in health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act have rightly been blocked by a federal district judge in Kansas City. Although the ruling by Judge Ortrie Smith applies only to Missouri, its reasoning applies to similar laws or regulations adopted by more than a dozen Republican-led states that are doing their best to sabotage health care reform.

headline: Iran: U.N. to Visit Uranium Mine
text: United Nations nuclear inspectors arrived in Iran on Tuesday to examine a uranium mine in the southern part of the country, Iranian news agencies reported. Their visit is part of a temporary international agreement aimed at resolving the longstanding dispute over the Iranian nuclear program, which Iran says is for energy and medical use but which Western nations and Israel suspect is a cloak for developing the ability to make bombs. Under the accord, which took effect on Jan. 20, Iran agreed to freeze most uranium-enrichment activities for six months and allow inspectors more intrusive access, in return for a relaxation of some Western economic sanctions. An exact date and a location have not been set for talks aimed at achieving a permanent agreement.

headline: More Winter, Less School
text: “Schools open. I’m cheering, kids aren’t. I just went over to the dark side.”

headline: A Court’s All-Hands Approach Aids Girls Most at Risk
text: SAN LEANDRO, Calif. — Toni J., an effervescent 16-year-old who talks on speed-dial, lives with 11 family members in West Oakland, on a street buffeted by gang activity and poverty. Her mother died of an overdose, her father in a revenge shooting. In ninth grade, she was raped while on probation for shoplifting.

headline: China: Chicken Sales Suspended Over Concerns About Avian Flu
text: As the Chinese get ready for Lunar New Year feasts, several areas in China have banned the sale of live chickens, and the Hong Kong government started culling 20,000 of the birds on Tuesday, as fears grew over the spread of avian influenza. The decision to kill the chickens, all from a single Hong Kong market, came after officials detected a new case of the deadly H7N9 virus in a bird imported from mainland China, across the border from Hong Kong in Guangdong Province. In southeastern China, New Year’s festivities often include the killing of a chicken. Contact with live poultry remains the main means of transmission for the virus. The H7N9 virus was first detected in March, and more than 200 cases have been reported so far, with roughly 50 deaths tied to the flu.

headline: Video Notebook: Richard Sherman
text: Richard Sherman of the Seattle Seahawks spoke to the media on Tuesday about being at media day and his reputation as a talker.

headline: Outsiders, Not Auto Plant, Battle U.A.W. in Tennessee
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At the Volkswagen plant nestled in Tennessee’s rolling hills, a unionization drive has drawn national attention as business groups worry about organized labor’s efforts to gain its first foothold at a foreign-owned automobile plant in the South. In a region known as anti-union, many view VW’s response as unusual, if not topsy-turvy.

headline: Prisoner of the Green Room 2
text: OK, since there isn’t any bourbon I guess I’ll try some live-blogging.

headline: Japan: Report of Possible Talks With North Korea to Thaw Ties
text: Japanese and North Korean officials may have held secret talks over the weekend in Vietnam, Kyodo News reported Tuesday, in an attempt to thaw frozen ties between the two nations. The Japanese news agency cited an unnamed Japanese diplomat as saying officials from the two nations were in Hanoi on Saturday and Sunday and may have met there. However, the top Japanese government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, denied Tuesday that a meeting had taken place. Japan cut off talks in 2012 after North Korea launched a rocket over Japan.

headline: Any Question Thrown at Him, Richard Sherman Has It Covered
text: NEWARK — The spectacle within the spectacle began at 12:45 p.m. Tuesday, when Richard Sherman, escorted by security through a horde of photographers, arrived at his podium. Over the next hour he answered questions from Deion Sanders and Randy Moss. He finished lyrics to Beyoncé songs and was given an Xbox One.

headline: Comcast Profits Up Sharply, Along With TV Subscribers
text: Comcast, the nation’s largest cable provider and the owner of NBCUniversal, on Tuesday reported a sharp increase in profit for the fourth quarter of 2013, helped by an increase in television subscribers after six years of decline.

headline: Why Kerry Is Scary
text: TEL AVIV — It is pretty clear now that Secretary of State John Kerry will either be Israel’s diplomatic salvation or the most dangerous diplomatic fanatic Israel has ever encountered. But there isn’t much room anymore for anything in between. This is one of those rare pay-per-view foreign policy moments. Pull up a chair. You don’t see this every day.

headline: Dealing With Pot
text: DENVER — There’s a lot of giggling in Colorado, and about Colorado, these days.

headline: Drug Shows Promise in Advanced Prostate Cancer When Used Before Chemotherapy
text: The prostate cancer drug Xtandi prolonged lives and delayed tumor progression when used before chemotherapy in a study of men with advanced cases of the disease, researchers said on Tuesday.

headline: Popular Flood Insurance Law Is Target of Both Political Parties
text: A major flood insurance bill was a rarity when it passed what is widely derided as a do-nothing Congress in 2012, but a year and a half later, there is now an enthusiastic bipartisan effort to gut it.

headline: Using His Voice to Bring Out a Nation’s
text: Pete Seeger sang until his voice wore out, and then he kept on singing, decade upon decade. Mr. Seeger, who died on Monday at 94, sang for children, folk-music devotees, union members, civil-rights marchers, antiwar protesters, environmentalists and everyone else drawn to a repertoire that extended from ancient ballads to brand-new songs about every cause that moved him. But it wasn’t his own voice he wanted to hear. He wanted everyone to sing along.

headline: Open-Source System to Be Offered by Dell
text: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear and software from like Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard. While that is unlikely to be a huge business soon for Dell, it lends credibility and muscle to what has been a growing effort to dislodge these incumbents through cheaper, easier-to-build equipment. If Dell and others can do that, a result would be lower costs at the large data centers run by Google, Facebook and large banks and companies. Cheaper networking could also make the Internet even more ubiquitous.

headline: DeVry Becomes an Unlikely Olympic Powerhouse
text: They have no mascot or motto, no home rink, oval or stadium. They have no hockey team, curling squad or figure skaters. They have no coaches, no athletic director, and their basketball team once lost by 117 points.

headline: Pitcher Refuses to Wear Cap That His Injury Helped to Bring About
text: In an effort to protect pitchers from line drives, Major League Baseball approved a padded-cap design Tuesday for optional use this season. But a pitcher whose injury helped accelerate the effort, Brandon McCarthy of the Arizona Diamondbacks, deflated much of the excitement by declaring he would not use it.

headline: Similar to a Yodel
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always fascinating how word people tend to “see” things that I would bet many people might overlook. It just so happens that somewhere there exists a whole list of people whose names contain letters that spell out something they are connected to, and Michael Black has found four of them.

headline: For Seeger, Years of Singing and Sailing to Save His Hudson River
text: As much as he was known around the world as a troubadour of idealism, Pete Seeger was at bottom a plain-spoken citizen of Beacon, N.Y.

text: In his State of the Union address, President Obama said that 2014 could be “a breakthrough year for America,” but that Washington needed to rebuild trust with Americans.

text: President Obama said the system needed to be fixed if the United States was serious about economic growth.

headline: Principles? What Principles?
text: To help appreciate President Obama’s fifth State of the Union address, with its to-do list of executive actions and its implicit fatalism about working with Congress, I suggest a preliminary visit to that citadel of reason, the Republican Party. There, the great minds and loud voices of the right are debating whether to adhere to the strategy of confrontation and sabotage that appeases the radicals in the conservative base, or to introduce a measure of pragmatism that might broaden the party’s appeal.

headline: Looking Callous at the SOTU
text: Having covered more State of the Union addresses than I care to count, I know perfectly well that the applause breaks are ritualistic. But during tonight’s speech, there were several moments that were emblematic of the partisan divides in this country, and the callous nature of Republican domestic policy.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 29, 2014
text: “I’m eager to work with all of you. But America does not stand still — and neither will I. So wherever and whenever I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunity for more American families, that’s what I’m going to do.”

headline: Capitalism vs. Democracy
text: Thomas Piketty’s new book, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” described by one French newspaper as a “a political and theoretical bulldozer,” defies left and right orthodoxy by arguing that worsening inequality is an inevitable outcome of free market capitalism.

headline: The Diminished State of the Union
text: Every winter since 2009, President Obama has stood at the podium of the House and pleaded for the cooperation of Congress. For the last three State of the Union speeches, he has largely been ignored. That has left a growing trail of unfinished business: background checks for gun buyers, immigration reform, a higher minimum wage, tax fairness, universal preschool.

headline: Obama on Raising the Minimum Wage
text: The president said he would issue an executive order in the coming weeks to increase the minimum wage for federal contractors to $10.10 an hour.

headline: Knicks Are Tough to Figure Out, and on This Night, Tough to Stop
text: Everything was open for the Knicks on Tuesday night: backdoor layups, 3-pointers, the lane. After Tyson Chandler converted an alley-oop dunk in the second quarter, he gave himself a good three seconds to stare menacingly at the crowd before retreating on defense.

headline: Two Men, Long on N.F.L.’s Radar, Are Charged With Making Counterfeit Tickets
text: A small-time counterfeiting team that had apparently forged dozens of Super Bowl tickets was arrested at a White Castle restaurant in the Bronx on Monday, the authorities said.

text: When Amalia C. and Melissa M. decided to start a family, they went through the well-trodden steps most same-sex couples take in New York City.

headline: In France, a Battle to Keep Menus Fresh
text: PARIS — Sit down at a cute Parisian bistro and the chances are the onion soup, the paté and the boudin blanc set before you weren’t prepared from fresh ingredients delivered that morning.

headline: Super Bowl Fans, Do Not Forget: It’s New Jersey
text: NEWARK — As the rest of the world streamed into the colossal Prudential Center on Tuesday for a religious service known as Super Bowl media day, a singular, defiant voice called from black loudspeakers propped outside a nearby tractor-trailer.

text: It was easy to imagine the blue bikes in fair weather, spinning over the East River during the morning commute, or toward the sidewalk cafes of SoHo for a twilight meal.

headline: Dashing for Big Yardage, Not for Shot at Medals
text: Denver Broncos kick returner Trindon Holliday could not help wondering what might have been had he pursued his dream of competing in the Summer Olympics.

headline: Texas: Candidate’s Daughters Respond to Criticism
text: The two daughters of Wendy Davis, a candidate for governor, put out an open letter on Tuesday in response to a newspaper article questioning aspects of her account of rising from teenage mother to Harvard Law School graduate. The Dallas Morning News reported this month that the daughters of the Democratic candidate stayed with her second husband in Texas while she attended school and that he won custody when the couple divorced. Ms. Davis’s campaign has said the couple had joint custody. Republicans and conservatives accused her of misleading voters. Dru Davis, 25, said in her letter, “Sadly I feel the need to be crystal clear on the malicious and false charge of abandonment as nothing could be further from the truth.”

headline: Bernard Perlin, a New York Painter of Varied Styles, Dies at 95
text: Bernard Perlin, an American painter who displayed a mastery of light and line across seven decades and a wide range of work, including wartime propaganda posters, street scenes of New York and effervescent views of Italy, died on Jan. 14 at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 95.

headline: What the State of the Union Address Means for 2014
text: What President Obama’s speech means for the midterms, his agenda and his relationship with Congress.

headline: I’m Looking Through You
text: The least productive Congress in nearly half a century has rarely looked more out-of-sorts than during the speech that put its members on notice for their irrelevance. That, essentially, was the triumph of the rhetorical trick President Obama employed in his fifth State of the Union address.

headline: Big and Fast Tight End Poses a Threat to an Intimidating Secondary
text: NEWARK — To find the end zone against a hard-hitting Seattle secondary known as the Legion of Boom, the Denver Broncos may have to rely on a player some call Mr. Red Zone. The name sounds like a comic book character, but Sunday in Super Bowl XLVIII, the performance of Julius Thomas, the Broncos’ tight end, will go a long way in determining how well Denver’s offense fares against the N.F.L.’s No. 1 defense.

headline: In L.A., Blurring the Line Between Art and Housewares
text: It’s no surprise that many sculptors have a yen for making furniture. After all, the tools are right within reach, and the process isn’t that different. In Los Angeles, which has a long history of furniture manufacturing and an abundance of interior spaces to fill, a growing number of young artists are making forays into the realm of domestic utility. “There’s a lot of sculpture out there that doesn’t want to admit to being furniture,” says the local artist Michael Rey, who has of late branched into objects that retain his affinity for the visual language of cartoons and ’90s pop culture.

headline: Exercise to Age Well, Whatever Your Age
text: Offering hope and encouragement to the many adults who have somehow neglected to exercise for the past few decades, a new study suggests that becoming physically active in middle age, even if someone has been sedentary for years, substantially reduces the likelihood that he or she will become seriously ill or physically disabled in retirement.

headline: She’s a 29er
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”
