headline: State of the Union, as It Was Spoken and as Decoded
text: WASHINGTON — In an excellent scene from “Mitt,” the new documentary about the former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney’s two presidential campaigns, the filmmaker asks one of Mr. Romney’s sons, Josh, whether all the hassle and indignity of campaigning is worth it. Josh Romney hesitates, saying that he had been so “trained” to deliver scripted happy talk in media interviews, that this might be hard. “To actually speak my mind is very different,” he finally says.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) NASHVILLE Juliette (Hayden Panettiere) surprises Jeff (Oliver Hudson) by refusing to apologize for her behavior during her induction into the Grand Ole Opry. Luke (Will Chase) introduces Rayna (Connie Britton, above) to someone who could help make her distribution deal a reality and then surprises her with a Nascar vehicle promoting her brand. And Deacon (Charles Esten) discovers that his own deal might not be what he anticipated.

headline: Obama on Army Ranger Remsburg
text: The president introduced Congress to Sgt. First Class Cory Remsburg, who was severely injured by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan and whom Mr. Obama first met in 2009.

headline: The Inner Sanctum
text: Diagram showing how far apart were the offices of Gov. Chris Christie and the deputy chief of staff fired for her role in the Fort Lee lane shutdown.

headline: Air Force Expands Inquiry Into Cheating
text: Defense Department officials said on Tuesday that 30 more Air Force members had cheated on tests of their knowledge of how to launch nuclear missiles, doubling the number caught up in the scandal. The expanded list comes two weeks after the Air Force announced that a drug inquiry had been widened to include a scandal in which 34 officers responsible for safeguarding nuclear weapons had cheated, or were aware of cheating, on monthly tests.

headline: Rep. Michael Grimm Threatens an NY1 Reporter
text: WASHINGTON — Footage showed Representative Michael G. Grimm physically threatening a reporter in the Capitol, shining a harsh light on the embattled Staten Island Republican in the hours after President Obama’s State of the Union address here on Tuesday.

headline: McCain Calls China a ‘Rising Threat’ in Baucus Confirmation Hearing
text: President Obama’s choice to be ambassador to China sat through a tough-sounding lecture in Washington on Tuesday from a Senate colleague who accused Beijing of regularly abusing human rights and planning to reassert its historic regional dominance. He then said that he largely agreed.

headline: Islamist Party in Tunisia Hands Power to Caretaker Government
text: TUNIS — Tunisia’s Islamist party Ennahda ceded power on Tuesday to a caretaker government, ending a strife-ridden two years as the country’s first elected government after the Arab Spring of 2011. The government departed under pressure, criticized for failing to halt rising terrorism and steady a faltering economy, but Ennahda was nevertheless assured of its place in Tunisian politics.

headline: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Kolkata Book Fair
text: KOLKATA — The 38th Kolkata Book Fair may have lost the Kolkata Literary Meet, which has spun off into a standalone event, but it has filled the void by adding the three-day Kolkata Language and Literary Festival, which is set to be inaugurated by Shashi Tharoor, the minister of state for human resource development.

headline: 2014: Paul’s State of the Union Response
text: The Republican senator from Kentucky released his own response to the State of the Union address.

headline: A Soprano Is Facing ‘Star-Spangled’ Jitters
text: The soprano Renée Fleming — who has sung at the World Series, at the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Concert in front of Buckingham Palace and at a gala before President Obama’s 2009 inauguration — sounded awed. “If you’d said six months ago, ‘You’re going to be singing in the Super Bowl,' ” she said, “I’d have said, ‘Not possible, no way.’ ”

headline: For Christie, Politics Team Kept a Focus on Two Races
text: His campaign called them “the Top 100,” the swing towns that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey wanted to win as he prepared for a re-election campaign. Capturing these towns, sometimes referred to as mini-Ohios or mini-Floridas, would validate the governor’s argument that he would be the most broadly appealing Republican choice for president in 2016.

headline: European Deal on Winding Down Failed Banks in Peril
text: BRUSSELS — Barely a month after European officials announced the creation of a system for winding down failed banks, it appears the plan could fall victim to a disagreement between member states on the European Council and the European Parliament.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 29, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Beings Not Made for Space
text: In “Beings Not Made for Space,” Kenneth Chang writes about the health challenges of human spaceflight.

headline: Operatic Cowboys in Love, Onstage
text: MADRID — When the news came five years ago that Charles Wuorinen was writing an opera based on “Brokeback Mountain,” the 1997 Annie Proulx short story that was made into an Oscar-winning film in 2005, it seemed at first a baffling mismatch of composer and subject. Mr. Wuorinen, 75, built his reputation as and remains an unabashedly complex Modernist. “Brokeback Mountain” is the immensely sad tale of the impossible love between two Wyoming cowboys.

headline: Dozens of Rebels Killed After Philippine Peace Deal Is Struck
text: MANILA — More than 40 people were killed and a school district supervisor was kidnapped in separate episodes around the island of Mindanao, days after a landmark peace deal was struck with the largest Muslim insurgency group in the Philippines, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Confessions of a Tiger Couple
text: One gray afternoon in November, on the eve of the Harvard-Yale football game, Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld were preparing for their postgame party. Furniture had been moved, vulnerable rugs had been rolled into corners. Their older daughter, Sophia, a junior at Harvard, had just called, and Chua returned to the living room bearing some news for her husband.

headline: Just When You Thought Quinoa Couldn’t Be Crunchier
text: Not long ago, quinoa was as mysterious as dark matter. Few could even pronounce the name of this ancient, disk-shaped “super grain” from the Andes, mistakenly calling it kwih-NO-ah (it’s KEEN-wah). It tasted a little strange, home cooks didn’t know what to do with it and only vegan restaurants put it on menus.

headline: Scars, Visible and Invisible, in Bosnia
text: It seemed like a simple question: How old are you?

headline: How Long Is It O.K. to Linger in a Cafe or Restaurant?
text: McDonald’s, Starbucks and other cafes and restaurants have become popular gathering spots for everyone from teenagers to the elderly. This month a McDonald’s in Queens finally arranged a truce after months of mounting tension with a group of elderly Korean patrons who have been using the restaurant as a meeting place for several hours each day. Do you ever think about overstaying your welcome in a public space?

headline: Shell Selling a Stake in Brazilian Oil Project
text: LONDON – Royal Dutch Shell said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell a minority interest in an offshore Brazilian oil project to Qatar Petroleum International, the emirate’s vehicle for oil and gas investments abroad, for about $1 billion.

text: Also on the Minute, behind the scenes of Madden NFL and this month's Recipe Lab featuring marinara sauce.

headline: Times Minute | Obama’s Modest Speech

headline: New York Today: Will Super Bowl Blvd. Clog Midtown?
text: Updated 11:28 a.m.

headline: Flat Sales of Wii U Put Nintendo in the Hot Seat
text: TOKYO — Nintendo said on Wednesday that poor sales of the Wii U game console had caused a big drop in revenue in the first nine months of its financial year, adding pressure on the company to execute a strategic turnaround.

headline: President Karzai’s Perfidies
text: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan seems to have decided that there is nothing lost, and maybe something to be gained, in destroying his relationship with the United States. While such behavior may serve his interests, it does not serve his long-suffering country’s.

headline: Wheelies: The Export Import Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Touring States, Obama Pushes Modest Agenda
text: WEST MIFFLIN, Pa. — As President Obama took to the road on Wednesday to promote an “opportunity agenda” that he vowed to enact with or without Congress, lawmakers began sorting through issues on which they may yet come together during what promises to be a treacherous midterm election year.

headline: U.N. Inspectors Visit Uranium Mine in Iran, Media Report
text: LONDON — United Nations nuclear inspectors began a visit on Wednesday to a uranium mine in southern Iran, state media reported, describing Tehran’s readiness for the scrutiny as a good-will gesture to demonstrate peaceful intent.

headline: The Co-Founder Dilemma
text: The idea for Posse struck me while relaxing in my apartment one Sunday afternoon. I didn’t know how to run a technology company, wasn’t at all confident the idea would work, and feared I might end up with egg on my face. In the interests of spreading the personal and financial risk, I asked a few friends to help.

headline: Fido Prefers Organic
text: I was invited for dinner at some old friends’ place the other day and I thought it would be nice to go to my local Greenwich Village pet store and pick up a treat for their dog, Manny. It is not that I am so crazy about Manny, who is a mix of a poodle and something even more annoying; I have had mixed feelings about him ever since he ate one of my sneakers. I just thought I would get him something he might enjoy chewing on as a diversionary tactic.

headline: The State of the Union, by the Numbers
text: The figures behind the language of this year's State of the Union address.

headline: Daily Report: Yahoo’s Revenue Falls, Though Alibaba’s Rises On
text: Despite the turnaround effort led its chief, Marissa Mayer, Yahoo is still falling further and further behind in the race for Internet advertising. The company said on Tuesday that revenue and operating profits declined in the fourth quarter of 2013 and would continue dropping in the first quarter of this year, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Apple Store Update: Is It a Clue That a New Apple TV Is on the Way?
text: When most companies add a new section to their website, few people notice. But most companies aren’t Apple.

headline: Ruling Looms in Italy for Amanda Knox in ’07 Killing
text: FLORENCE, Italy — For years, the fate of Amanda Knox has been in the hands of a succession of Italian courts, called on to determine whether on the night of Nov. 1, 2007, she killed Meredith Kercher, her roommate and fellow foreign exchange student in the university town of Perugia. On Thursday, a court in Florence is expected to present its ruling.

headline: Russia Defers Aid to Ukraine, and Unrest Persists
text: KIEV, Ukraine — A former Ukrainian president warned on Wednesday that the country is now on “the brink of civil war,” and Russia added to the gloom by announcing the suspension of its financial aid package, which was all that had been keeping Ukraine solvent.

headline: Strong Chrysler Earnings Help Fiat Turn Profit
text: DETROIT — The world’s newest auto giant on Wednesday chose a formal name, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, and a borderless corporate structure that spans the Netherlands, Britain, Italy and the United States.

headline: Can Accessories Make Google Glass More Stylish?
text: Even self-described tech geeks want to make Google Glass look a little less geeky before they wear it.

headline: State of the Union Highlights Economic Inequality
text: In his State of the Union address before Congress on Tuesday night, President Obama promised to do something about economic disparity in a “year of action,” vowing to act alone if necessary. While Mr. Obama covered a broad swath of issues, his message centered on income inequality. “Those at the top have never done better,” he said. “But average wages have barely budged. Inequality has deepened. Upward mobility has stalled.”

headline: Barclays to Cut Up to 400 Jobs in Its Investment Bank to Trim Costs
text: LONDON – The British bank Barclays is preparing to eliminate as many as 400 jobs in its investment bank as part of an effort to trim costs, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Hedgies Versus Teachers
text: So one thing I learned last night is that the right has a new meme: inequality is the fault of the government — you see, it’s all those overpaid government workers.

headline: Get Your Hot Chocolate Here!
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Video: Proud of ‘Wolf’s’ Language
text: LOS ANGELES — Terence Winter read “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Jordan Belfort’s memoir of his shady financial, narcotic and sexual dealings, before it was even published. “I got the book when it was still in galley form” from the producer Alexandra Milchan, he said. “I could not put it down. I read it in one sitting.”

headline: Sotheby’s, Under Pressure, to Pay Special Dividend and Buy Back Shares
text: When the billionaire hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb and a group of activist investors emerged as the biggest shareholders in Sotheby’s last year, it looked as if a battle was brewing at the auction house.

headline: German Leader Criticizes U.S. Over Pervasive Surveillance
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel took perhaps her sharpest swipe yet at pervasive American intelligence surveillance, saying on Wednesday that Washington had endangered its standing by violating the freedom of the individual, a value for which it is admired abroad.

headline: Whatever It Takes? No, It Takes Whatever
text: I think Josh Marshall gets this right. Obama came across relatively relaxed last night, basically because he knows two things: he isn’t getting anything substantive out of the GOP, but he’s achieved a lot, and his signature achievement is looking increasingly secure. The real theme of the SOTU was “Whatever.”

headline: Reader Idea | Writing Book Reports With Help From New York Times Book Reviews
text: All this week, we are featuring Great Ideas From Readers, lesson plans from teachers who teach with The Times. If you’ve used The Times in your classroom and would like to see your idea on our blog, write in and tell us what you’ve done.

headline: Dow Chemical Resists Spinoff Proposal and Increases Stock Buybacks
text: Updated, 10:48 a.m. | Dow Chemical on Wednesday appeared to rebuff a proposal by an activist hedge fund manager, as it also announced measures intended to make shareholders happy.

headline: Making the Case for Ambitious Diplomacy
text: For a few moments during President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday evening, he sounded as if he was channeling Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: Atlanta Officials Gamble on Storm and Lose, and Others Pay the Price
text: ATLANTA — There are bad commutes, and then there is what happened here this week.

headline: After ‘I’ll Break You in Half,’ Grimm Apologizes
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island, once considered a rising star in the Republican Party, touched off a political firestorm after delivering unusually vitriolic threats against a reporter inside the United States Capitol building on Tuesday night, just moments after the State of the Union speech.

headline: Playing With Toys and Saving Lives
text: “Apollo 13” is a good movie, but one 95-second stretch is what turned it into it a geek classic.   Their Command Module disabled, three astronauts use the Lunar Module as a lifeboat. Carbon dioxide is building up. The Command Module’s filters are available to scrub the air, but they’re square, and the receptacles for them on the Lunar Module are round. “Well, I suggest you gentleman invent a way to put a square peg in a round hole … rapidly,” the flight director Gene Kranz in Houston tells his engineers.

headline: Attack on Gay Journalist Not a Hate Crime, Police Say
text: The police on Wednesday charged a Queens man in the beating of a gay journalist in Midtown Manhattan but said the attack was not a hate crime.

headline: Rep. Grimm Threatens NY1 Reporter
text: Following Tuesday’s State of the Union address, Representative Michael Grimm of Staten Island threatened an NY1 political reporter, Michael Scotto.

headline: The Sunny Side of the Unemployment Report
text: David A. Rosenberg, the chief economist at Gluskin Sheff, a Canadian research firm, is not known for his rose-colored glasses. Indeed, when he was at Merrill Lynch in New York, there were complaints that he was too negative.

headline: Tension Builds in Israeli Coalition at a Critical Juncture in Peace Talks
text: TEL AVIV — Simmering tension between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and one of his right-wing political partners boiled into open hostility on Wednesday, threatening to reshape Israel’s governing coalition at a critical juncture of the American-brokered peace talks with the Palestinians.

headline: My Coach, the Bully
text: When Dr. Nancy Swigonski, a pediatrician who often talks with families about bullying, saw a local high school coach yelling at players, calling them stupid and lazy, she tried to speak with her.

headline: The Source | Beck in Conversation With Doug Aitken
text: “It’s such a dispersal, making a song,” Beck says. “Hoping something works, or connects, somewhere, with somebody.” In conversation with Doug Aitken, the genre-hopping 43-year-old musician and producer likens songwriting to sculpture, calling it “just shaped chaos.” The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Justice Dept. Vows to Find Hackers of Target
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Wednesday that the Justice Department was committed to finding the hackers behind the holiday season theft of credit card data from millions of Target customers.

headline: Flipping the Switches on Facebook’s Privacy Controls
text: FACEBOOK is all about sharing.

headline: A Trainer and Father, Supporting Both Sides of a Rivalry
text: The Montreal Canadiens and the Boston Bruins will meet at TD Garden on Thursday night in the 723rd regular-season game between the two Original Six franchises.

headline: Social Liberalism as Class Warfare
text: My Sunday column tried to take the ongoing debate over marriage and upward mobility in a slightly different direction, by prodding social liberals to acknowledge the ways in which their own ideological vision and its victories – legal and cultural both – have played a role in the married, two-parent family’s decline. I don’t think my argument has won many converts, but rather than respond to the responses right now I wanted to highlight one of the arguments that inspired the column in the first place: This essay from Steve Randy Waldman (the brother, I believe, of the novelist Adelle Waldman, familiar to my readers from an earlier round of kulturdebating), which makes the case that “marriage promotion” as social conservatives often describe it is “a destructive cargo cult,” with altars and rings standing in for the runways and tarmacs that World War II-era South Sea Islanders allegedly built in the hopes of attracting military airplanes.

headline: Movement Seen in Talks Over Syria, Despite Gap
text: GENEVA — After five days of deadlock and dispute in the Syrian peace talks, opposition negotiators on Wednesday seized on hints of government willingness to discuss political transition as evidence of progress. Yet the United Nations mediator dampened expectations, saying he did not anticipate any substantial result from the current round of talks, which are scheduled to end Friday.

headline: Thomas M. Sherak, Head of the House of Oscar, Dies at 68
text: Thomas M. Sherak, a film studio executive who as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences helped expand its mission beyond the annual awarding of Oscar statuettes, died on Tuesday at his home in Calabasas, Calif. He was 68.

headline: As I Was Saying About Web Journalism ... a Bubble, or a Lasting Business?
text: Last week, it occurred to me that the departure of Ezra Klein, the creator of The Washington Post’s influential Wonkblog, to join the young company Vox Media was a bit of a moment — an inflection point in the emergence of a news economy online. When I pitched a column about it, my long-suffering editor said, “Please don’t explain the Internet to people, David.”

headline: Fed Decision Day: What to Watch For
text: President Obama gave a long speech Tuesday night about the things government can do to help the economy without ever mentioning the Federal Reserve. Presidents rarely do. But it’s also the case that folks at the White House, like most Fed officials, think the central bank already has done as much as it should.

headline: Portrait of the Artist as a Child
text: Why is it that little children, who romp gleefully though museum halls in their preschool years, grow into kids who would rather do anything than walk through an exhibition? If only they knew how much they have in common with the men and women who made the work on the gallery walls, rebels all. Three new books, one each on Vasily Kandinsky, Alexander Calder and Pablo Picasso, present the artists in imaginative and appealing ways that should leave adults surprised by what they learn and children feeling they’ve encountered brilliant kindred spirits.

headline: Carnegie Hall Plans South Africa Festival This Fall
text: A three-week festival of the music and arts of South Africa, a series featuring the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato and a monthlong Before Bach celebration of early music will be among the highlights of Carnegie Hall’s 2014-15 season, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Life Story of Wendy Davis Swings From Strength to Flash Point in Texas Campaign
text: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis is learning the perils of campaigning on her personal biography.

headline: Today in Small Business: 51 Start-Up Failures
text: Washington

headline: At Restored Landmark in Times Square, Mixing ‘Brash and Beautiful’
text: Who are America’s four best-loved actresses?

headline: House Approves Farm Bill, Ending a 2-Year Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives on Wednesday passed a bill authorizing nearly $1 trillion in spending on farm subsidies and nutrition programs, setting the stage for final passage of a new five-year farm bill that has been stalled for more than two years.

headline: Wall Street Is a Short-Attention-Span Theater for Obama’s Speech
text: Investors had a there’s-not-much-to-see-here reaction to the president’s State of the Union address and turned their focus quickly to something else on Wednesday morning

headline: In Our Pages: January 30
text: 1939: William B. Yeats, Poet, Dies

headline: On Losing It (or Not)
text: I’m always on the alert for any proof I can muster that my missteps, mistakes, misunderstandings and failures of memory are just the stuff of normal human-being-ness — and not the signs of mental decline as I age.

headline: Analyst Who Worked on Herbalife Leaves Pershing Square
text: An investment analyst who played a leading role in Pershing Square Capital Management’s bet against Herbalife has decided to leave the hedge fund, according to a letter sent to its investors.

headline: Atlanta’s Residents and Officials Turn to Social Media Amid Snowstorm Chaos
text: Updated, 5:08 p.m. A few inches of snow continued to paralyze Atlanta and other parts of the southeastern United States on Wednesday, as my colleagues Kim Severson and Alan Blinder reported. Thousands of motorists were stranded in their cars overnight, while others abandoned their vehicles and slept in shopping centers. Hundreds of accidents were reported. Some schools kept students through the night, scrambling to feed them.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Rag & Bone Men’s Fall/Winter 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Times Minute | Secrets of Successful Aging
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Secrets of Aging
text: Also on the Minute, Wendy Davis fights back and Greece's no-middle-man movement.

headline: ‘Big Block of Cheese’ Day: The White House Offers a Chance to Ask Questions
text: After the State of the Union Address, the White House is embarking on a day of social media outreach: “The First-Ever Virtual ‘Big Block of Cheese Day.'” First, a brief history lesson: according to the current administration, President Andrew Jackson in 1837 placed an ad announcing an open house at the White House — an opportunity for any and all to mingle with the president and his staff. The event featured a 1,400-pound block of cheese that sat in the main foyer of the White House.

headline: Classical Playlist: Zuill Bailey, Natasha Paremski, Leon Kirchner and More
text: BRITTEN: Cello Symphony and Cello SonataZuill Bailey, cellist; North Carolina Symphony, Grant Llewellyn, conductor; Natasha Paremski, pianist(Telarc)Benjamin Britten composed several important works for his younger friend and colleague the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich. The longest, most substantial score was the Symphony for Cello and Orchestra (1963), a dark, wrenching and overpowering piece that Britten once called “the finest thing I’ve written.” An exciting new recording — a live performance in vivid sound — couples the brilliant, searching American cellist Zuill Bailey with the fine conductor Grant Llewellyn and the North Carolina Symphony. The CD includes Mr. Bailey’s gripping account of Britten’s 1961 Cello Sonata, with the pianist Natasha Paremski. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: China’s Biggest Bank Gains Entree Into Trading in London
text: Updated, 8:19 p.m. | LONDON — The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China agreed on Wednesday to buy a controlling interest in Standard Bank’s global markets business in London for $765 million.

headline: Making Consignment Stores Destination Shopping
text: Perhaps fittingly for a onetime director of guest relations at an amusement park, Donna Speigel has turned the Snooty Fox chain of shops — consignment shops, no less — into Cincinnati destinations. Her customers come from as far away as Indianapolis and Louisville, even paying $25 to reserve a seat on “Fox Hunt” tour buses, where they are served boxed lunches and company lore. At the stores, they get wine and dessert and typically shop, if not until they drop, at least until they have taxed the bus’s overhead racks and lower storage compartments with their purchases.

headline: Unpopularity of the House Could Turn Senate Races
text: WASHINGTON — To Representative Steve Daines, Republican of Montana, his vote this month against a 1,582-page, $1.1 trillion spending bill was at once a stand for fiscal sanity and a protest against spending cuts to rural communities, a “constructive no,” as he put it last week.

headline: Investors Still Wary of Efforts to Shore Up Currencies
text: FRANKFURT — Emergency measures by Turkey and South Africa to stop a headlong flight of foreign investors had little effect on Wednesday. The financial markets all but ignored increases in official interest rates aimed at strengthening the countries’ currencies.

headline: He Was Deadly in Cha-Cha, Too
text: It should surprise no one that the actor Cole Horibe, cast as Bruce Lee in David Henry Hwang’s new play, “Kung Fu,” about Lee’s remarkable career, was a contestant on the reality show “So You Think You Can Dance.” Lee’s fighting in movies like “Enter the Dragon” that established him as a martial arts legend always mixed brutality with a balletic elegance. And Lee himself was a dancer, even, believe it or not, winning a cha-cha competition in 1958.

headline: A Decision Deferred: Turning Off the Pacemaker
text: Nobody really knows exactly how many Americans are walking around with pacemakers and defibrillators. But with surgeons implanting at least 225,000 pacemakers and 133,000 defibrillators each year, “there probably are a couple of million” out there now, said Dr. Paul S. Mueller, a Mayo Clinic general internist and bioethicist.

headline: A Conversation With: Times Now Editor in Chief Arnab Goswami
text: Arnab Goswami, editor in chief of the Times Now television news channel in Mumbai, landed one of the biggest interviews in Indian journalism in recent years when he spoke with Rahul Gandhi, the Congress Party vice president.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘The Grandmaster’
text: When the cinematographer Philippe Le Sourd teamed up with the director Wong Kar-wai to make “The Grandmaster,” he was expecting a six-month project. Those six months turned into three years, making the production felt as epic as the life story at the heart of the film: that of the kung fu master Ip Man. Mr. Le Sourd, nominated for his work on the film, shot in various locations and sometimes in extreme weather conditions.

headline: Ice Strands Thousands in South
text: Thousands of commuters were trapped in cars overnight on highways in the greater Atlanta area and hundreds of students remained inside dozens of schools Wednesday morning.

headline: Top Intelligence Official Assails Snowden and Seeks Return of N.S.A. Documents
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top intelligence official on Wednesday delivered a scorching attack on Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, and called on him and his “accomplices” to return the trove of classified documents he took from the N.S.A.

headline: Enough With the Teaspoon Approach
text: David Brooks: Gail, back in the early 1980s, I bought my first computer, a Kaypro. It was big, clunky, slow and by today’s standards, unbelievably primitive. Let’s face it, the State of the Union address is the Kaypro of political events. We ought to totally re-engineer the whole enterprise.

headline: Snowden Speaks to German Television
text: In an interview with German television, Edward J. Snowden said that despite feeling threatened, he does not lose sleep because he still believes that what he did was “the right thing to do.”

headline: Study Says New Method Could Be a Quicker Source of Stem Cells
text: A surprising study has found that a simple acid bath might turn cells in the body into stem cells that could one day be used for tissue repair and other medical treatments.

headline: Jessica Alba’s Edgy Elegance
text: The Girl: The actress paired her one-of-a-kind floral motif white-leather dress with layers of rock and roll — tousled tresses, a dark cranberry lip, black strappy sandals and edgy jewelry — at last night’s Hollywood Stands Up to Cancer event.

headline: A Mafia Legacy Taints the Earth in Southern Italy
text: CASAL DI PRINCIPE, Italy — The Italian state arrived in the heartland of the Camorra mafia this month bearing a backhoe. Police officers in polished black boots posed for television cameras as the backhoe clawed into an overgrown field, searching for barrels of toxic waste or some other illegal industrial sarcophagi.

headline: Not All Monuments Men Were Men
text: In February 1952, as Europe rebuilt after World War II, Ardelia Ripley Hall arrived in Bonn, Germany, to play her part in a bold American military mission that had begun about a decade earlier.

headline: History, Yes, but Movie History
text: In a lighthearted scene in “The Monuments Men,” an Army officer played by Bill Murray gleans clues about stolen art from a German dentist while getting a tooth yanked.

headline: A Culinary Trip to Cape Town
text: Red Savannah, an upscale travel company in Cheltenham, England, founded by the ex-Abercrombie & Kent chief executive George Morgan-Grenville, recently introduced a seven-night culinary trip to Cape Town and surrounding areas.

headline: Image of the Day: January 29
text: A member of a wedding band at a roadside in New Delhi.

headline: More Vegetables, Please (But Hold the Red Peppers)
text: The “picky eater” ate broccoli pizza!

headline: Why the Owner of a Growing Business Found Time to Start a School
text: We just published an interview with Donna Speigel, owner of the Snooty Fox chain of consignment shops. Last year, the 11 stores rang up more than $5 million in sales. As Ms. Speigel explains in the interview, she has turned her Cincinnati-area shops into destinations that routinely lure people on tour buses from as far away as Louisville and Indianapolis. But Ms. Speigel has also been creative on another front. In 2006, she opened a nonprofit school for people with special needs in Covington, Ky. called the Conductive Learning Center of Greater Cincinnati. Moreover, the school is largely funded through special Snooty Fox initiatives, notably a popular platinum credit card.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,500,000
text: BIG SUR, CALIF.

headline: Homes for $1,500,000
text: This week’s properties include a house with a Pacific view in California, a townhouse in Virginia and a Creole home in Louisiana.

headline: Why Is Latin America So Progressive on Gay Rights?
text: Defying stereotypes, the region is ahead of the U.S. and Western Europe. What explains Latin Americans' support for gay rights?

headline: Man Admits Killing 2 Women With Hammer, Officials Say
text: A woman and her daughter were bludgeoned to death in their Queens home by the woman’s live-in boyfriend, who called 911 and confessed that he had “killed them because they are witches,” law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Pete Seeger, Jamming at the Beacon Sloop Club
text: The folk musician and activist Pete Seeger played a lively role in the Beacon Sloop Club, which he helped start in 1969. It started as a campaign to clean up the Hudson River — the group’s symbol is a sloop that Seeger built called the Clearwater — and has continued as a monthly part-advocacy, part-fellowship gathering to which people bring food, talk and make music. At the meetings, Seeger would call out, “Now everyone get in a circle, make it big for everyone.” Chairs would scoot around. “No, it’s not big enough. It has to include everybody.”

headline: App Smart: Job Hunting
text: Today you only have to look as far as your pocket to find new work because there are many apps for mobile devices that can help.

headline: Remember Want Ads for Jobs? Now You Find Them on a Phone
text: What do you do when you lose a job or need bigger challenges than your present one offers? Start that job hunt. You could earn more money or even prove the person who fired you wrong by landing a better job elsewhere.

headline: A Dutch Jihadist in Syria Speaks, and Blogs
text: Last summer, a Dutch public television producer scanning the Internet for information on foreign fighters in Syria stumbled on something he had never seen before: Instagram photos of a man wearing the uniform of the Royal Netherlands Army who appeared to be fighting alongside Islamist rebels against government forces.

headline: An Advanced Degree in Quiet
text: As she began her junior year at New York University, Vanessa Csordas-Jenkins planned to live with two friends. But the plan fell through, and she and her friends ended up in the Broome Street dorm along with four strangers.

headline: Citing Growth, Fed Again Cuts Monthly Bond Purchases
text: WASHINGTON — In its final major decision under the leadership of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it would continue to slowly dismantle its stimulus campaign, citing “growing underlying strength in the broader economy.”

headline: The Gun Report: January 29, 2014
text: • Having a gun range on your property is legal in Florida, thanks to a 1987 law allowing anyone to fire anything they want on their own land. Doug Varrieur, who has turned the front yard of his home on Big Pine Key into a makeshift range, was looking for a way to teach his eyesight-impaired wife how to shoot her self-defense pistol without the inconvenience of going to a commercial gun range, “which is 50 miles round trip, costs $45 an hour and is enclosed in a building with people shooting around you that you don’t know,” he told the Miami Herald. The only rules to discharging firearms on residential property are that you can’t fire over a paved public road, highway or street, or occupied dwelling.

headline: In Rare Public Forum, Architect Defends Decision to Take Down Former Folk Art Museum
text: An architect typically doesn’t go before the public to defend a private project. But on Tuesday night Liz Diller of Diller Scofidio & Renfro stood before a crowd of 650 people, many of them her peers, to explain in detail the six-month process by which her firm tried to save the former home of the American Folk Art Museum before deciding it was impossible.

headline: And the Grammy-Goers Go to ...
text: After Beyoncé shook her booty, Lorde took selfies with Taylor Swift, and Madonna wobbled offstage, the real partying began Sunday night, as Grammy winners and losers decamped to various after-parties across Los Angeles.

headline: Crime Writer Henning Mankell Says He Has Cancer
text: Henning Mankell, a master of Scandinavian crime literature, has been diagnosed with cancer, he said Wednesday in a Swedish newspaper.

headline: Neanderthals Leave Their Mark on Us
text: Ever since the discovery in 2010 that Neanderthals interbred with the ancestors of living humans, scientists have been trying to determine how their DNA affects people today. Now two new studies have traced the history of Neanderthal DNA, and have pinpointed a number of genes that may have medical importance today.

headline: 20 Al Jazeera Journalists Face Charges in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors said on Wednesday that they were charging 20 journalists working for the Al Jazeera television network with conspiring with a terrorist group and broadcasting false images of “a civil war that raises alarms about the state’s collapse.”

headline: All Right, There Are Two Republican Parties
text: Republican pundits have been arguing recently that immigration reform could splinter the party ahead of the 2014 elections. They shouldn’t be worrying about immigration. The Republicans’ response to President Obama’s State of the Union showed that the G.O.P. is actually two parties, or perhaps even more.

headline: Grammys Spur Streaming; Katy Perry Single Hits No. 1
text: Lorde may have been the Grammy Awards’ most talked-about artist on Sunday night — more of the 15.2 million Grammy tweets were about her than any other act, Twitter reported — but when it came to streaming music, Daft Punk appears to have gotten the biggest early lift.

headline: Applaud, Tweet and Repeat at the State of the Union
text: Immediately after a president’s State of the Union address is delivered, news organizations frequently seek to answer a question: How many times did members of Congress stand and applaud? In this era when social media has become an important arena for politics, and in some ways eclipses the statements and interviews representatives and senators issue after an address like the State of the Union, another question may be more important: How many tweets did members of Congress send during the speech?

headline: Dow Chief Says Buffett Supports Him in Loeb Fight
text: Dow Chemical may have expanded its stock buyback program and dividend, but it showed little inclination to make further concessions to activist investors like Daniel S. Loeb.

headline: Migration of Monarch Butterflies Shrinks Again Under Inhospitable Conditions
text: Faltering under extreme weather and vanishing habitats, the yearly winter migration of monarch butterflies to a handful of forested Mexican mountains dwindled precipitously in December, continuing what scientists said was an increasingly alarming decline.

headline: “The Sound of a Tree Falling”
text: The title song from Terry Roche’s album.

headline: State of the Union: Few Horatio Alger Stories
text: There were a lot of pedigree shout-outs Tuesday night in the State of the Union address and the responses, generally in reference to humble beginnings.

headline: “Francis”
text: A song by Terre Roche.

headline: New Owner of Patch Lays Off Hundreds
text: Just two weeks ago, AOL announced that it was handing over the majority stake in Patch, its troubled local news enterprise, to Hale Global, an investment company that specializes in turning around troubled companies through technological innovation. Hale said at the time that its intention was to keep operating all of Patch’s 900 sites and that no staffing decision had been made.

headline: Sotheby’s Sets Financial Path. Now, for the Art.
text: Sotheby’s is revamping its financial science — now, for the art. The auctioneer’s stock popped, at least initially, on the news on Wednesday of a $300 million special dividend and new criteria for investment. The plan addresses some aspects of the critique by the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb. But governance and broader strategy remain at issue.

headline: Messages of ‘Relentless, Spiraling Bloodshed’ from the Central African Republic
text: The emergency director for Human Rights Watch, Peter Bouckaert, has documented some of his most vivid warnings yet on the killing in the Central African Republic, describing a country in the “relentless, spiraling bloodshed” of sectarian retaliation on the civilians left behind as rebels withdraw.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
text: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

headline: Dining in Dublin, From Boxty to Blaa
text: Manor Street, the main street that runs through the neighborhood of Stoneybatter in north Dublin, is lined with traditional pubs. L. Mulligan Grocer, as its name suggests, is housed in a former pub and food shop. And it fits right in: A long bar, lined with taps, dominates the right side of the room.

headline: Dublin, Beyond the Guinness Storehouse
text: For the alternative R & B artist James Vincent McMorrow, the world’s image of Dublin fails to capture what makes the city special for locals.

headline: House Hunting in ... Austria
text: A RESTORED FARMHOUSE OUTSIDE SALZBURG

headline: A Farmhouse Outside Salzburg
text: A four-bedroom home built in 1890 is on the market for $1 million.

headline: Military Plans Reflect Afghanistan Uncertainty
text: WASHINGTON — American and NATO military planners, facing continued political uncertainty about whether foreign troops will remain in Afghanistan after December, have drawn up plans to deploy a force this summer that is tailored to assume a training mission in 2015 but is also small enough to withdraw if no deal for an enduring presence is reached, alliance officials said.

headline: Wry Hybrid of Debonair and Tetchy
text: Debonair, an adjective that fits the actor and singer James Naughton to a T, isn’t a word that describes the despairing, grandiose and perverse fantasists who inhabit the songs of Randy Newman. But Mr. Naughton, 68, whose anthology of Mr. Newman’s work opened the 16th season of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series at the Allen Room on Tuesday evening, persuasively empathized with Mr. Newman’s cranky, woebegone characters. Typical is the narrator of “You Can Leave Your Hat On.” Addressing a woman who may be a prostitute as she strips and shakes her breasts, he grunts, “You give me reason to live.”

headline: Grammy Producer Responds to Trent Reznor’s Angry Critique
text: The executive producer of the Grammy Awards has responded to a public complaint by Trent Reznor that his performance at the show was “disrespected.”

headline: Pet Owners Brace for Chinese New Year Fireworks
text: The explosions of Lunar New Year fireworks are considered a sound of celebration and a deterrent to evil spirits. But they also are responsible for injuries and fires and cause air quality, which is already poor in many parts of China, to worsen.

headline: Palestinian Shot Dead by Israeli Forces in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man, Muhammad Mahmoud Mubarak, 21, was fatally shot on Wednesday by Israeli forces in the West Bank. The Israeli military said in a statement that Mr. Mubarak opened fire first at a military post north of Ramallah and that soldiers fired back “to eliminate the imminent threat to their lives.” There were no casualties among the soldiers.

headline: Apps With No Rules? No Problem
text: Toca Boca, the Swedish app developer that makes digital products for children, is slowly building a formidable library of apps.

headline: What Would You Do With Eight Tiny Subarus?
text: Look through the automotive listings on any city’s Craigslist page, and you’re bound to find a fairly predictable list of vehicles like pickups, S.U.V.'s and late-model sedans from Detroit and Japan. But once in awhile you come across something unique.

headline: Video From Snowden’s German TV Interview
text: Updated, 8:12 p.m. | In excerpts from an interview with German television made available to The Lede on Wednesday, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden said that he sleeps well in Russia, where he enjoys temporary asylum, despite reading recently on Buzzfeed that some of his former colleagues in United States intelligence would like to kill him. “I don’t lose sleep because I’ve done what I feel I needed to do,” Mr. Snowden said. “It was the right thing to do and I’m not going to be afraid.”

headline: Excerpt From 'Brokeback Mountain'
text: A scene from the opera.

headline: Obama Kicks Off His ‘Opportunity Agenda’
text: A day after his State of the Union address, the president visited a Costco warehouse in Maryland to promote his economic plan and discuss raising the minimum wage.

headline: On View | Frank Lloyd Wright’s Love-Hate Relationship With the American City
text: Frank Lloyd Wright was generally not a fan of cities. He thought them dirty, congested and hollow. In his 1932 book, “The Disappearing City,” he wrote of the American metropolis: “A parasite of the spirit is here, a whirling dervish in a whirling vortex.” The exhibition “Frank Lloyd Wright and the City: Density vs. Dispersal,” which opens this Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, examines the legendary architect’s feelings about urbanism through his plans for a horizontal anti-metropolis he called Broadacre City, a lifelong project that some consider to have been a blueprint for suburbia. Perhaps surprisingly, there are also schemes for several unrealized skyscrapers, the very icons of the cities he held in such noisy contempt.

headline: Europe’s Banking Risk Plan Is a Long Shot
text: The European Union on Wednesday revealed a long-awaited proposal to reduce the systemic risk posed by big banks, a measure that would bring the bloc’s regulations more closely into line with those of the United States. But it is unlikely to become law anytime soon.

headline: For a Wife, the Musing Never Stops
text: Two innovative books published in the 1970s used fragmentation and discontinuity to create kaleidoscopic portraits of their heroines’ lives. Renata Adler’s “Speedboat,” narrated by a woman who worked at a tabloid newspaper, jump-cut among vignettes from her life to capture the incongruities of her experience and the larger incongruities of American life in the ’60s and ’70s. Elizabeth Hardwick’s “Sleepless Nights,” whose narrator bore more than a passing resemblance to the author, mapped the contours of her life by putting memories, aphorisms and observations on shuffle.

headline: Below the Bikini Line, a Growing Trend
text: For the last decade, the Brazilian bikini wax has seemed to dominate salons and popular culture alike, leaving its adherents completely bare (or with just a suggestion of hair) in their nether regions.

headline: Daring to Be Free, in a Story Line and in the Marketplace
text: Perhaps the most impressive thing about Broken Age, an enchanting, imaginative fable from Double Fine Productions, is that its makers have created a video game that is at least as interesting as the story of how it was made.

headline: Wendy Davis Responds to Criticism
text: In a speech Tuesday night, the Texas state senator and Democratic candidate for governor responded to accusations that she has misstated details of her experience as a single mother.

headline: Singing of Toilets, Instead of for Tonys
text: In 1956, Hank Beebe was a young composer just getting started in the New York theater when he auditioned for something his agent had called “the Chevy show.” It sounded like a big break. “I thought he meant the television show with Dinah Shore,” Mr. Beebe said.

headline: In TriBeCa, a Savile Row Fantasy
text: THERE ARE ONLY a few ways to utter the sentence “I’ve seen a lot of hand-rolled pocket square edges, and those are by far the best,” and most of them are awful, pretentious, smug. Nick had it down, though.

headline: Loving Ice Cream and an Older Woman
text: Wednesday was the day that the world had no idea it had been waiting for: the day that Louis C. K. made available online a movie that has gone virtually unseen since he filmed it a decade and a half ago. The movie, which he wrote and directed, is called “Tomorrow Night,” and he has described it as having been living in film cans since receiving a few festival screenings way back when.

headline: Blending In With Her Environment
text: Chelsea Darling’s look begins with her name. The 24-year-old New Orleans hairstylist was born Chelsea Martin, but then she read an article about how choosing a name was a way to shape an identity. So she adopted the moniker Chelsea Darling, inspired in part by the ’60s and ’70s style she favors, the era of Candy Darling and Sid Vicious.

headline: Obama on Foreign Policy
text: In his State of the Union address, President Obama addressed crucial foreign policy issues.

headline: From the Wetlands to Williamsburg, the Zen Tricksters Ride Again
text: It could have been the Wetlands circa 1994, except that it was Brooklyn Bowl in 2014. Which doesn’t seem possible, since that would make me … hmm … carry the 1 … and. Really? You know what they say: All the years combine. …

headline: Attorney General on Target Data Breach
text: Speaking before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Eric H. Holder Jr. confirmed that the Justice Department was investigating the credit card data theft that affected millions of Target customers.

headline: After Big Bet, Google Is to Sell Motorola Unit
text: Larry Page, Google’s co-founder and chief executive, likes to talk about “big bets” and “moonshots.” But the thing about moonshots is that they can crash into earth.

headline: Law Enforcement Strikes Back in Bitcoin Hearing
text: Law enforcement officials testified on Wednesday that virtual currencies like Bitcoin had opened up new avenues for crime that government has not been able to keep up with.

headline: Top Russian Biathlete Reportedly Fails Doping Test
text: A Russian biathlete who is the reigning women’s European champion has been suspended for a doping violation just a week before the Olympic opening ceremony in Sochi, according to Russian reports. The suspension dealt a blow to the Olympics host country and cast a pall over one of Russia’s signature sports.

headline: Leaping Uncontained by the Stage or the Screen
text: When the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova announced last year that she would be joining the Royal Ballet, many New Yorkers were disappointed, fearing that a commitment to London would mean that we would see less of her here, where she has danced superlatively with American Ballet Theater. And indeed Ms. Osipova is not scheduled for Ballet Theater’s 2014 Metropolitan Opera House season. Yet on Monday, New Yorkers could watch her with her new colleagues in “Giselle,” via one of the Royal Opera House’s cinema broadcasts.

headline: For a New Jersey Mayor, a Surprise Invitation to the Super Bowl
text: The mayor of East Rutherford, N.J., the town in which Super Bowl XLVIII will be played on Sunday, finally has a ticket to the game.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Gaza City and Atlanta.

headline: Check-In by Smartphone
text: Aiming for efficiency, two Aloft hotels will begin offering keyless check-ins, allowing smartphone-equipped guests to bypass the front desk and proceed directly to their rooms, where doors will open when activated via Bluetooth technology and the phone is held in front of the lock.

headline: Be Careful at the Book Club, the Author Might Be There
text: The living room in the plush apartment on Central Park West was filled with all the trappings of a traditional book club.

headline: Snowboarders Explore Their Backyard
text: Jeremy Jones, a professional snowboarder, built a career on exploring remote mountains by helicopter and snowboarding down them. Then he began to discover his backyard under the power of his own feet.

headline: Obesity Is Found to Gain Its Hold in Earliest Years
text: For many obese adults, the die was cast by the time they were 5 years old. A major new study of more than 7,000 children has found that a third of children who were overweight in kindergarten were obese by eighth grade. And almost every child who was very obese remained that way.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Explores His Own Backyard
text: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and now “Higher.” These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard remote mountains under his own power.

headline: Itaú Unibanco Buys Controlling Stake in CorpBanca of Chile
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Brazilian bank Itaú Unibanco has acquired a controlling stake in the Chilean bank CorpBanca, a move that follows its growing ambitions to expand in Latin America.

headline: Big Profit at Facebook as It Tilts to Mobile
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Ten years after its founding as a simple website for a few thousand Harvard undergraduates to manage their social lives, Facebook is a far different company.

headline: A Whirl of Memories and Ardent Invention, From Nureyev to Now
text: New York’s Dance on Camera festival has now reached its 42nd edition. Started as a Dance Films Association initiative and itinerant for its first 25 years, it found a home at the Film Society of Lincoln Center in 1996. The schedule for the 2014 season, which runs from Friday through Tuesday, is crowded.

headline: ‘American Idol,’ at 13, Is Trying to Stay Relevant
text: Audiences, like French presidents, can’t always be trusted.

headline: District 3 Winter Regional’s Friday Open Pairs
text: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., two weeks ago, the winners of the Friday Open Pairs were Bjorn Fallenius and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City. They were originally announced as second, but a score correction moved them into first by 0.84 match points ahead of Gail Greenberg and Jeff Hand of New York City. Third were Ann Borgschulte of Lexington, Mass., and Stephen Gladyszak of Chelsea, Mass.

headline: A Soviet Composer’s Circle of Friends
text: It takes a village to raise some composers to prominence. That was the lesson to be learned from an onstage discussion on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard School that preceded one of the six free concerts in the school’s remarkable Focus! festival.

headline: For Already Vulnerable Penguins, Study Finds Climate Change Is Another Danger
text: Life has never been easy for just-hatched Magellanic penguins, but climate change is making it worse, according to a decades-long study of the largest breeding colony of the birds.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month, three novels and three collections of stories, each with a vivid sense of place, including an absurdist version of the Midwest, a gritty corner of British Columbia and a fictional Eastern European country in 1939.

headline: Industry in North Dakota to Cut Flared Natural Gas
text: HOUSTON — Faced with growing criticism and lawsuits, an oil industry task force representing hundreds of companies in North Dakota pledged on Wednesday to make an all-out effort to capture almost all the natural gas that is being flared in the Bakken shale oil field by the end of the decade.

headline: Obama’s Call for a ‘Year of Action’
As China’s Economy Slows, the Pain Hits Home
text: HONG KONG — Piles of unsold coal line rural roads in north-central China. Some iron ore mines near Beijing are operating at a fraction of capacity. Chinese farm products are even increasingly scorned by the Chinese consumer.

headline: The Prognosis Is Grim, but I’m Living My Life
He Had a Hammer, and His Hammer Was Song
text: To the Editor:

headline: Citigroup Joins Rivals in Permitting Junior Bankers to Take Saturdays Off
text: Memo to junior bankers at Citigroup: You can soon join your friends at other Wall Street banks in taking Saturdays off.

headline: Which Vision for Oscar?
text: LOS ANGELES — At some point, deep in the four and a half years it took to make “Gravity,” Alfonso Cuarón, the director and co-writer, screened his lost-in-space saga for a test audience. And? “It was a disaster,” he said.

headline: Why Are We Talking About Wendy Davis’s Choices?
text: Wendy Davis, a Texas state senator and Democratic candidate in the race to become governor of Texas in 2015, has been under attack for blurring and misstating details of her story as a single mother. If Wendy Davis were Henry Davis, would the national media — including The New York Times (Texas Democrat Defends Back Story Under Criticism) — be covering the attacks on her as she and her opponents battle to define her personal and family history?

headline: C.I.A. Drone Bases
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jobless in North Carolina
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nederlander Organization Agrees to Improve Disability Access at Its Theaters
text: The Nederlander Organization has agreed to increase access for disabled people at the nine theaters it operates on Broadway, lawyers for the federal government said Wednesday.

headline: Times Minute | Grimm's Blow-Up
text: Also on the Minute, when journalists migrate to online upstarts, and is climate change killing baby penguins?

headline: Times Minute | Grimm’s Blow-Up
text: In the Video

headline: Q. and A. | Playwright Thomas Bradshaw on Race, Porn and Suburbia
text: Thomas Bradshaw’s plays have elicited belly laughs from some viewers and disgust from others. Naysayers have called the 33-year-old playwright’s shows, which include “Purity,” “Burning” and “Job,” “ugly fantasies” and “horror shows.” One Chicago theater critic went so far as to warn Bradshaw to get out of town. The reactions are due to the fact that Bradshaw, who is black, stages outrageous behavior — including child rape, racially charged sex and modern-day slavery — in casual, conversational ways.

headline: Aiming for Recognition, Axa Trims Its Name
text: AXA EQUITABLE is taking an ax to its name, trimming it to Axa so it will conform in the United States with the French-based company’s brand elsewhere.

headline: On Any Given Night Out
text: “It’s just supper, baby,” the celebrity chef Mario Batali said merrily on a frigid Friday evening, surveying a dinner-party scene of the sort some would give their eye teeth to join.

headline: A Sporty Classic With Fresh Detailing
text: Flip through any of the latest fashion magazines and you’ll be struck by the ubiquity of the sports influences for spring: loads of mesh, track pants, crunchy Teva-style sandals — remember those sparkly numbers at Prada? — and athletic bomber jackets like the ones here, any of which will raise your outerwear game. No everyday bombers, these jackets are reimagined with luxe fabrics and cool embellishments. Another reason to like them: their versatility. Wear over sporty looks, like a mesh top and silk track pants; or as Elettra Wiedemann (shown here) did, wearing her Giambattista Valli as a statement piece over trousers and a print top.

headline: In London, Fashion History Up Close
text: For those who were shut out of the blockbuster “Savage Beauty” show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2011 or, because of the crowds, couldn’t get close enough to the Alexander McQueen clothes to actually see them, a trip to London may be in order.

headline: Standing Tall on Its Own
text: On the Grammys red carpet on Sunday, there were plenty of notable outfits, like Katy Perry’s Valentino couture dress and Taylor Swift’s all-grown-up Gucci gown, and some genuine moments of oddness. (Madonna. Enough said.) But perhaps no single sartorial touch drew as much attention as did the oversize hat Pharrell Williams wore as he jauntily walked past the paparazzi and chatted with Ryan Seacrest, who, strangely, never thought to ask, “What are you wearing?” (Mr. Williams later told another interviewer it was vintage Vivienne Westwood.) The hat invited comparisons to the Royal Canadian Mounties, Smokey Bear and even the Arby’s logo. And, inevitably, within minutes of its appearance, the hat had its own Twitter account, @Pharrellhat, and, by the next morning, more than 16,000 followers.

headline: Anything but Uniform
text: No matter what happens Sunday in the Super Bowl between the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos, there will be one West Coast team that comes out a winner: Nike.

headline: Winter-White Makeup
text: Winter white is a fresh choice for clothing, but the dry-cleaning bills can be downright chilling. This season, the shade is also widely available in makeup, with somewhat less risk to your pocketbook.

headline: Did Google Really Lose on Its Original Motorola Deal?
text: Updated, 8:57 p.m. |

headline: Personal Trainer, Worn on a Wrist
text: My first experience with a fitness tracker was memorable. It fit snugly in my pocket and estimated the number of steps I took and the calories I burned each day. There was just one problem: It seemed to think I was getting roughly the same amount of exercise regardless of whether I was jogging around a track or eating French fries in a diner. After about two weeks, I stopped wearing it, most likely because I lost it.

headline: ‘Loud, Strong, Committed and Always in Search of America’
text: Pete Seeger, who died at 94 on Monday, inspired generations of musicians to think about music in a particular way – or, it turns out, many particular ways, depending on the musician. Some were inspired to consider the nature of the instruments they played, and for banjo players in particular, Mr. Seeger was a role model and a master teacher. For most, though, he was the consummate political singer, a campaigner for free speech and the right to protest, whether the cause was personal rights or the state of the environment. Since Mr. Seeger’s death, several musicians and others who were inspired by him spoke about their experiences with Mr. Seeger.

headline: A Super Bowl View in the Meatpacking District
text: With prices for a luxury box at the Super Bowl hovering at $500,000, some New Yorkers may be wondering where they can toss back a few glasses of Dom and enjoy this all-American pastime with other well moisturized types who aspire to be high rollers. Enter FC Gotham, a flashy sports lounge that opened recently in the meatpacking district.

headline: Super Bowling Down Broadway
text: Super Bowl sideshows have taken over 13 blocks of Broadway, building up to Sunday's game. A toboggan run, goal-kicking nets and autograph hunters now jostle with New Yorkers along the fabled street.

headline: Obama’s Speech Raises Hopes of Advocates of Mortgage Finance Overhaul
text: The president’s State of the Union address on Tuesday provided a glimmer of hope for those looking for action to revamp America’s mortgage system.

headline: New Concern About Testosterone and Heart Risks
text: A large new study found that prescription testosterone raised the risk of heart attacks in older men and in middle-aged men with a history of heart disease, prompting some experts on Wednesday to call for more extensive warning labels on the drugs.

headline: Dynamic Duo: Alfonso and Jonás Cuarón
text: The father-son filmmaking team Alfonso and Jonás Cuarón talk about the draw of space, character and their Oscar-nominated film, “Gravity.”

headline: A Barneys Campaign Embraces a Gender Identity Issue
text: Arin Andrews and Katie Hill do not look out of place in the new Barneys New York campaign. Both have nonexistent hips, are right in the ballpark of six feet tall and aren’t yet old enough for a legal drink. But there’s one marked difference between them and the models you ordinarily see on runways and in the pages of Vogue and Elle: Mr. Andrews, 17, was born a girl, and Ms. Hill, 19, a boy.

headline: Address by Obama Drew Fewest Viewers Since 2000
text: More networks than ever before covered the State of the Union address Tuesday night, but the total audience still came in lower than any year since 2000.

headline: Sales at Metropolitan Window Fashions and Others
text: Sight Unseen is discounting everything on its site by 20 percent, through Saturday (the Pyramid lamp by Bzippy & Co., usually $275, is $220); 347-748-1231, shop.sightunseen.com.

headline: A Hotel That Takes in the Neighborhood
text: When the Broome hotel opens on Feb. 14 in SoHo, it will have a European look, but the furnishings will be mostly homegrown. “We wanted local artisans and vendors,” said Vincent Boitier, one of the four French partners and a previous owner of L’Orange Bleue, the SoHo restaurant that closed in 2012.

headline: Marcel Wanders’s Wonders
text: It took some time for the Dutch designer Marcel Wanders to get his professional bearings. He attended four art and design schools, ultimately graduating from one in Arnhem, in the Netherlands, in 1988 (with honors). Then his career took off. In the 1990s, he joined the influential collective Droog Design, and in 2001 he was a founder of the furniture company Moooi.

headline: A Model Instrument
text: Peter Dilworth, a graduate of the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Maxwell Bogue, a toy inventor, have put the idea of 3-D printing into the hands of everyday users without the need for software or even a computer.

headline: A Mystery at the Bend
text: LOS ANGELES — New arrivals to this city are often told by locals to hop in the car and take Sunset Boulevard to the Pacific Ocean. It is a beautiful drive, world famous. It is also an initiation into the California myth without the downsides: you glide past the traffic-clogged 405 freeway, wind through rustic canyons where movie stars live and breathe in the ocean breezes west of Brentwood, as if nature had provided Angelenos with free air-conditioning.

headline: Sometimes Asparagus Is More Than Asparagus
text: Helen Yoest didn’t set out, as she said recently, to write a horticultural Kama Sutra. It was sort of an accident. Ms. Yoest, a garden writer, was researching an article on avocados when she learned that the fruit was considered an aphrodisiac. What makes it so, she wondered: The nutrients? The shape? Bingo. Turns out their reputation dates to the Aztecs, who marveled at how avocados grew in pairs, and named the plant “the testicle tree.”

headline: Blue Bottle Raises $25.75 Million, Including From High-Powered Friends
text: Few brands are as beloved in the tech community as the Blue Bottle Coffee Company, a nearly 12-year-old purveyor of gourmet brews made in painstakingly detailed fashion.

headline: Major Expansion Ahead at The Washington Post
text: The Washington Post has significantly increased its budget and plans to make dozens of newsroom hires under its new owner, the Amazon founder Jeffrey P. Bezos, the paper’s executive editor, Marty Baron, said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: Planters: Best Supporting Actors
text: It may seem like an odd time to be thinking about planters, with signs of the polar vortex still in evidence. But as Jon Carloftis, a garden designer with clients like Google and Maker’s Mark, said, “Now is the time everyone needs something green in their life.”

headline: Boeing Shares Fall as It Cautions on Its Profits in 2014
text: After doubling over the last year, Boeing’s stock dropped 5.3 percent on Wednesday when the plane maker projected flattening profits in 2014.

headline: Music Data Firms to Collaborate on Internet Radio Platform
text: Gracenote, a digital music data service that the Tribune Company bought last month for $170 million, is quickly moving forward with its plans for a customizable Internet radio program that would let consumer brands, car companies and anyone else have their own music app.

headline: Extra Arms (and Teeth) for Wrangling Firewood
text: In our family, it is my job to build and poke at fires in our wood-burning fireplace. I use wrought-iron tools I bought on eBay, and they have served me well. But this winter, I tested something new: Grill Daddy King Tong fire tongs (about $45), which promised to let me manipulate smoldering logs with less effort.

headline: Should I Update the Flooring in My Entry Hall?
text: Q. The floors in our home are mostly hardwood except for the entry hall, which is dated tile. Is it worth replacing?

headline: If You Can Make It Here...
text: Sure, a Super Bowl always produces a hero or two, but William C. Rhoden says a Super Bowl hero made in New York carries a little something special.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: If You Can Make It Here …
text: Sure, a Super Bowl always produces a hero or two, but a Super Bowl hero made in New York carries a little something special.

headline: Get Game-Ready with Shopping Events Starting the Week of Jan. 30
text: Get Game-Ready

headline: Despite Decades of Enmity, Israel Quietly Aids Syrian Civilians
text: NAHARIYA, Israel — Two brothers, ages 10 and 8, were playing marbles outside their home in a town in Syria when a rocket decapitated the older one and critically wounded his sibling. Having rushed the surviving child to a local hospital, the mother recalled, medics told her: “If you want to save your son, you should take him to Israel.”

headline: Knicks’ Shumpert Is ‘Day to Day’ After Shoulder Injury
text: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson said the sprained right shoulder Iman Shumpert sustained in Tuesday’s victory over the Boston Celtics would be re-evaluated Thursday morning. Appearing Wednesday on ESPN Radio, Woodson said Shumpert was “day to day” but cast doubt over his availability for Thursday’s game against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Obama’s Free-Trade Conundrum
text: WASHINGTON — IN his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama focused on reversing the growth of economic inequality in the United States and restoring the American dream. At the same time, he also announced his support for fast track authority that would limit Congress’s role in determining the content of trade agreements.

headline: Syrian Opposition’s Calm at Talks Surprises as Officials Falter
text: GENEVA — The Syrian government officials were expected to present themselves as the grown-ups at the peace conference here, representatives of a capable, sovereign government facing opponents they call political amateurs at best, and at worst, terrorist rabble.

headline: New York Wants to Banish a Symbol of Love: Mute Swans
text: In the war against invasive species, the targets are typically unappealing. Think feral pigs, snakehead fish, Asian long-horned beetles and emerald ash borers. But now, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has declared war on mute swans — the jumbo, snow-white waterfowl with the long, graceful necks — which were introduced from Europe in the late 1800s for their aesthetic appeal.

headline: John R. Huizenga, Physicist at Fore of Nuclear Era, Dies at 92
text: John R. Huizenga, a physicist who helped build the world’s first atom bomb, solve dozens of atomic riddles and debunk claims that scientists in Utah had achieved nuclear fusion in a jar of water, died on Saturday in San Diego. He was 92.

headline: Obama Orders Creation of ‘MyRA’ Savings Accounts
text: Making good on a State of the Union address promise, President Obama on Wednesday ordered the creation of new employer-sponsored savings accounts intended to help more people get started saving for retirement.

headline: Detroit Art Museum Offers Plan to Avoid Sale of Art
text: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class collection has been targeted as a potential source of cash to help dig Detroit out of federal bankruptcy, announced Wednesday that it would raise $100 million to help save itself, joining a group of private foundations that have already pledged $370 million toward the effort.

headline: A Checkered History
text: Americare Certified Special Services, the home health care agency seeking to expand its role, has faced lawsuits and federal and state inquiries.

headline: Maryland Gunman Wrote in Diary About Killing People
text: For more than a year, the 19-year-old gunman who opened fire at a shopping mall in Columbia, Md., last Saturday, killing two skateboard store employees, made sporadic references in his journal about killing people and showed awareness that he struggled with mental illness, police officials said Wednesday.

headline: New York State Recommends Expanding License of Health Agency With Checkered Past
text: It was a medical scheme that shocked the public conscience when it came to light in 2001: Two dozen mentally ill residents of a Queens adult home were forced to have unnecessary prostate surgery that generated tens of thousands of dollars in government fees.

headline: A Pioneering Black Quarterback’s Lasting Legacy
text: LONG BEACH, Calif. — President Obama, hosting the undefeated 1972 Dolphins at the White House last summer, made his way around the green room before moving out for a public ceremony.

headline: Plan on Repaying Debt Is Presented to Detroit’s Creditors
text: Drawing the bankrupt city of Detroit a step closer to remaking itself, the city’s emergency manager on Wednesday provided creditors with a detailed proposal for how much of the city’s $18 billion debt Detroit intended to pay back.

headline: Threat by Staten Island Lawmaker Adds to a Reputation as Hot-Tempered
text: Representative Michael G. Grimm is a hothead.

headline: How to Get More Early Bloomers
text: WHEN New York City’s mayor, Bill de Blasio, went to Albany earlier this week to talk about his program for universal preschool, the discussion reportedly focused on funding, not on whether or how preschool would actually help children. President Obama seemed equally confident when he introduced his plan for universal preschool last year, flatly stating, “We know this works.” But the state of research is actually much murkier. And unless policy makers begin to design preschool programs in ways that can be evaluated later, the situation won’t get any clearer.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Presidency
text: It was hard to watch President Obama during Tuesday’s State of the Union address and not see a man who has had his coat trimmed and his ambitions adjusted.

headline: Wall Street’s New Housing Bonanza
text: Wall Street’s latest trillion-dollar idea involves slicing and dicing debt tied to single-family homes and selling the bonds to investors around the world.

headline: How Preschool Got Hot
text: All of a sudden, early childhood education is really, really popular. Everybody’s favorite. If early childhood education were an actor, it would be Tom Hanks or Meryl Streep. If it were a video game, it would be Candy Crush or Angry Birds, minus the spyware.

headline: Tests Said to Find Formaldehyde in West Virginia Tap Water
text: Tests on the water supply in Charleston, W. Va., a week after a chemical spill tainted the city’s water system turned up traces of formaldehyde, suggesting that “there’s a lot more we don’t know” about the consequences of the spill, an environmental expert told a state legislative committee on Wednesday.

headline: How Pressure Mounted for Development in Hoboken
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — Last May 8, a severe rainstorm left the streets of this city flooded once again, causing the mayor, Dawn Zimmer, to recall the inundation from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Pre-K, the Great Debate
text: Against all odds, prekindergarten is gaining ground.

headline: U.S. Says Russia Tested Missile, Despite Treaty
text: WASHINGTON — The United States informed its NATO allies this month that Russia had tested a new ground-launched cruise missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with a landmark arms control accord.

headline: Colleague of SAC Leader Was Not Alerted to Trades
text: The billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen kept one of his closest associates at SAC Capital Advisors in the dark about the hedge fund’s rapid selling of a substantial stock position in two drug companies, just days before the companies reported disappointing results of a clinical trial for an Alzheimer’s drug.

headline: The Farm Bill Could Have Been Worse
text: Few bills of real substance emerge from today’s polarized Congress, and those that do tend to be misshapen lumps. They have enough useful provisions to win approval from Democrats, but are weighed down by the dangerous and occasionally bizarre demands of the many branches of the Republican Party.

headline: Uncertainty Over Whether N.F.L. Settlement’s Money Will Last
text: As intriguing football matchups go, Sunday’s Super Bowl has nothing on one looming down the turnpike in federal court in Philadelphia — with Judge Anita B. Brody the ultimate referee.

headline: Secrecy Behind Executions
text: It is bad enough that the death penalty is barbaric, racist and arbitrary in its application, but it is also becoming less transparent as the dwindling number of death-penalty states work to hide the means by which they kill people.

headline: New Government for Czech Republic
text: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic appointed a new center-left government on Wednesday, ending a protracted period of political paralysis that has destabilized the country. The freshly installed prime minister, Bohuslav Sobotka, 42, has pledged to shepherd the country toward stability following a corruption scandal last summer that forced Prime Minister Petr Necas to resign. A subsequent interim government failed to win parliament’s confidence. Mr. Sobotka, a Social Democrat, has pledged to combat some austerity measures of previous conservative governments.

headline: Academy Rescinds Song Nomination for ‘Alone Yet Not Alone’
text: LOS ANGELES —The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its governors had voted to rescind an Oscar nomination for the song “Alone Yet Not Alone,” from the movie of the same title, because one of its creators, Bruce Broughton, had improperly advised fellow members of the Academy’s music branch that he was in the running for a nomination.

headline: Presidential Power vs. Congressional Inertia
text: In his State of the Union address, Obama said he would work around Congress. What are the strengths and risks of such action?

headline: After Keeping Company With Mobsters, Politician Now Speaks Their Language
