text: Years ago, a Newsday editor had a great idea for a young reporter. Go, he told me, to the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club and see what the boys are doing on the first day of deer-hunting season.

headline: Iraq: More Violence in Baghdad
text: Car bombings and shootings in Baghdad on Wednesday killed at least 19 people, according to security and medical officials, adding to a death toll that has been rising quickly. The four car bombs targeted Shiite neighborhoods. Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, meanwhile, called on Sunni tribes in Falluja to support the Shiite-led government’s forces so they can storm it and clear out antigovernment Sunni militants.

headline: The Siren Song of the Hebrides
text: Lured by the beaches and the otherworldly light on a Scottish island, a family builds an unconventional beach house there.

headline: The Lure of the Hebrides
text: The Scottish Hebrides are known for an almost otherworldly allure that draws visitors back year after year.

headline: Warrantless Surveillance Challenged by Defendant
text: WASHINGTON — A Colorado resident charged with terrorism-related offenses challenged the constitutionality on Wednesday of a 2008 law allowing the National Security Agency to conduct a sweeping program of surveillance without warrants on American soil. The challenge — the first of its kind — could lead to a Supreme Court test of the program.

headline: Jump in Prostitution Arrests in Super Bowl Week
text: Four days before the Super Bowl, just a few blocks from the N.F.L. extravaganza known as Super Bowl Boulevard on Broadway in Midtown Manhattan, a different scene was playing out Wednesday at Midtown Community Court on West 54th Street.

headline: Senator Asks Veterans Agency to Review How Financial Advisers Are Accredited
text: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri is asking the Department of Veteran Affairs to examine its process for accrediting thousands of financial advisers in the face of concerns over abuses of veterans’ benefits.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Jan. 29, 2014
Remembering My Mother’s Obsession
text: Of all the troubling events from my childhood, one of the most enduring remains the afternoon I visited a prisoner serving a life sentence for murder. It was 1978 and I was 9 years old, escorted to Western Penitentiary in Pittsburgh by my mother, who, compelled by a lifelong objective of raising her son’s awareness of injustice in the world, no doubt considered this to be a well-suited occasion.

headline: Russell Wilson, a Standout Who’s Easy to Miss
text: It was no surprise that Super Bowl week launched with a frantic rush to surround Richard Sherman but with plenty of good space available in the presence of Russell Wilson. That injustice of unbalanced attention revealed far more about the malleability of the news media — especially during the long, news-starved run-up to the game — than it did about either player.

headline: Obama to Meet Jordanian King
text: President Obama host King Abdullah II of Jordan next month at Sunnylands, a sprawling desert estate in Rancho Mirage, Calif. The White House said Mr. Obama and the king would discuss the Middle East peace process and the Syrian civil war, which has sent a wave of refugees into Jordan.

headline: A Former Regulator Returns to Private Practice
text: Before David Meister was butting heads with Wall Street’s top defense lawyers, he was one of them.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 30, 2014
text: “It was like something you would see if they told you the plague broke out and you had to run for your life.”

headline: Pakistani Premier Forms Group to Start Talks With Taliban
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif named a four-member commission on Wednesday to initiate peace talks with the Pakistani Taliban, saying he would pursue a dialogue with the militants despite recent terrorist attacks that have left the country reeling.

headline: Maryland: Shooting Suspect Wrote of Death
text: The suspect in a deadly shooting at a mall wrote about killing people in his journal and said that he was ready to die, the police said Wednesday. The man, Darion Aguilar, 19, “expressed a general hatred of others” in entries over the past year, the Howard County police department said. Mr. Aguilar wrote that his plan was set, but did not say what that meant, and apologized to his family for what he was about to do, the police said. The police said Mr. Aguilar wrote that he might need help for a mental health problem, but never told his family. The police believe Mr. Aguilar killed two employees of the skate shop Zumiez on Saturday at the Mall in Columbia before killing himself.

headline: Facing Complaints, Columbia’s President Calls for Transparency in Assault Inquiries
text: Columbia University’s president, responding to complaints about how the institution investigates and punishes sexual assaults on campus, announced new policies on Wednesday intended to make its procedures more transparent.

headline: Chancellor, a Lover of Collisions, Has the Seahawks Ready for a Final Clash
text: JERSEY CITY — Kam Chancellor, a safety for the Seattle Seahawks who is known as one of the N.F.L.’s most punishing hitters, proclaims his bad intentions on his shoulders, both tattooed with the word “Bam.”

headline: Stringer to Unveil Changes for New York City’s Pension System
text: Dozens of city pension managers would have to regularly report their personal investment transactions, and placement agents for investment managers would be banned from doing any business with New York City’s $150 billion retirement system, under a reform plan to be announced on Thursday.

headline: Foundations Band Together to Get Rid of Fossil-Fuel Investments
text: Updated, 3:08 p.m. | Seventeen foundations controlling nearly $1.8 billion in investments have united to commit to pulling their money out of companies that do business in fossil fuels, the group announced on Thursday.

headline: Global Design Du Jour
text: PARIS — On Sunday, the British designer Tom Dixon was a guest of honor at a cocktail party at Eclectic, a new restaurant in the 15th Arrondissement here. Mr. Dixon had designed the space, with his usual flair for muscular materials (in this case, concrete warmed by splashes of gleaming metal). He was being feted by Maison et Objet, a trade fair held every January and September, which had anointed him, along with Philippe Nigro of Paris and Dimore Studio of Milan, a “designer of the year.”

headline: Corrections: January 30, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Sure, Son, I’ll Be in Your Skin Flick
text: The land of id is flooded with sunshine in Thomas Bradshaw’s “Intimacy,” the sensationally square new play that is putting the X (make that triple X) back into sex on 42nd Street. Pornography is the subject of this sui generis comedy from the New Group, which opened on Wednesday night on Theater Row. You might even say that porn is its form.

headline: Riddled With Spelling Problems
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we discuss today’s puzzle, I’d like to take a moment to talk about the format changes in our commenting system, as well as the issues that have occurred as a result. The Times is well aware of the general reaction that readers across the website, not just on Wordplay, have had to the changes, as well as the specific bugs you have reported.

headline: California: Charges Against Bus Company Dropped
text: State labor officials have dropped charges that a Chinese high-tech bus company was paying a handful of workers below minimum wage. Last fall, investigators said that the company, Build Your Dreams, was paying workers here temporarily from China in Chinese currency equivalent to less than $8 an hour, the state’s minimum wage. But the company, known as BYD, has provided bank documents that showed the workers were paid the equivalent of $12 to $17 an hour in California. On Tuesday, lawyers for the state labor agency removed citations that ordered nearly $12,000 in back wages. The company agreed to pay $1,900 in penalties for paying the workers in Chinese currency rather than dollars. The company has won several contracts to create electric buses across the country, including in Los Angeles. It operates its American headquarters in downtown Los Angeles and a manufacturing plant in northeast Los Angeles County.

headline: Four Airlines Are Told to Raise Some Wages by $1 an Hour
text: After a lengthy campaign by airport contract workers to receive better wages, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey sent a letter to several airlines late Tuesday ordering them to increase pay for some employees.

headline: Jason Kidd Grows in Role, Along With Beard
text: While Nets players have made strides this month forming a team identity, they have seen Jason Kidd take steps to fine-tune his identity as their coach.

headline: White-Glove Treatment for Super Bowl Trophy
text: Justin Tuck said the gloves were too small.

headline: American Stocks Bounce Back
text: American markets bounced back on Thursday, buoyed by relatively strong economic growth in the United States.

headline: A Huge N.B.A. Rivalry: Sneaker Collections
text: P. J. Tucker, a forward with the Phoenix Suns, really likes sneakers. He likes them so much, in fact, that he needs four locations to store his collection.

headline: Judge Limits Expert Testimony on Terrorism in Manhattan Bomb Case
text: Saying he wanted to avoid turning the trial into a “referendum on terrorism,” a state judge handling the case of a Manhattan man accused of planning pipe bombings said on Wednesday he sees no need for an expert on Islamic terrorism to testify at the defendant’s coming trial.

headline: Riz Ortolani, Film Composer Who Wrote a Love Anthem, Dies at 87
text: Riz Ortolani, an Italian composer of dozens of film scores, whose Grammy-winning instrumental melody featured in the 1962 film “Mondo Cane” evolved into “More,” the celebrated anthem of love covered by sensuous crooners around the globe, died on Jan. 23 at his villa outside Rome. He was 87.

headline: Set to Play, Harvin Is Drawing Attention
text: For a player who tied for 392nd in the N.F.L. in receptions this season, Percy Harvin is getting an awful lot of attention in the lead-up to Super Bowl XLVIII.

headline: Rangers Beat Another Rival, Completing a Double Play in the Bronx
text: An intense game at Yankee Stadium between two longtime rivals, the Rangers and the Islanders, ended on Wednesday night with the fans on their feet, gasping as the Islanders’ Kyle Okposo, bidding for the tying goal, shot the puck inches wide of the net.

headline: For Organist, the Best of Both Worlds
text: For the Islanders’ organist, Paul Cartier, the surreal novelty of an outdoor hockey game at Yankee Stadium put him in a completely familiar place.

headline: Before Big Game, Stepping Into Media’s Big Top on Radio Row
text: Within minutes of one another, Dan Marino, Darryl Strawberry and Mark Messier walked through the crowd of tables in the Metropolitan Ballroom on the second floor of the Sheraton Times Square Hotel on Wednesday.

headline: Failed EuroVegas Bid Was Still a Boon for Spanish Casinos
text: MADRID — Even though Sheldon G. Adelson, the American billionaire casino magnate, abandoned his plans for a $30 billion casino and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid last month, he has nevertheless helped get the roulette wheels spinning here for the first time in almost a century.

headline: Suede Safari Style
text: In 1968, Yves Saint Laurent introduced its first belted safari jacket, which propelled the hunting-expedition look into mainstream fashion. This season, Saint Laurent’s designer Hedi Slimane updated the original, introducing a more polished, shorter version in solid suede. And the safari legacy lives on in other designers’ resort collections, where monochromatic, all-suede staples abound in shades ranging from light camel to dark mahogany. The thick buckle strap becomes a simple, yet sleek design element on an Alexander McQueen skirt, Calvin Klein halter and Gucci boot — a nod to the practical, waist-cinching detail of the trench. And the velvety skin adds sturdy softness to a pair of Jimmy Choo sandals and a Proenza Schouler cross-body bag.

headline: U.S. Aid to Afghans Flows On Despite Warnings of Misuse
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With billions of dollars in American aid increasingly flowing straight into Afghan government coffers, the United States hired two global auditing firms three years ago to determine whether Afghanistan could be trusted to safeguard the money.

headline: Word of the Day | vivisection
text: vivisection •\ˌvi-və-ˈsek-shən, ˈvi-və-ˌ\• noun

headline: Be-Bopera: ‘Charlie Parker’s Yardbird’ Coming From Opera Philadelphia
text: Opera Philadelphia has commissioned Daniel Schnyder, a composer and saxophonist who works in jazz and classical music, to compose a chamber opera about the jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker, the company is expected to announce Thursday. The work will have a libretto by Bridgette A. Wimberly, and is being produced in a partnership with Gotham Chamber Opera, in New York. It is expected to have its world premiere in Philadelphia in June 2015 in a production directed by Ron Daniels, with later performances by Gotham Chamber Opera.

headline: The Disappointing Office of Financial Research
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Wireless Mergers Will Draw Scrutiny, Antitrust Chief Says
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s leading antitrust enforcer said this week that it would be difficult for the Justice Department to approve a merger among any of the top four wireless phone companies, casting doubt on recent speculation that T-Mobile and Sprint might consummate a deal in coming months.

headline: New York City Council Gets a New Speaker
text: Melissa Mark-Viverito was sworn in as speaker on Wednesday.

headline: 3 Injured in Staten Island Gas Explosion
text: A gas explosion and fire Wednesday night at a house on Staten Island injured three people — one critically — and forced the evacuation of more than a dozen homes, according to the Fire Department.

headline: A Pioneer of Street Photography Leaves Behind Strong Images of Indian Women
text: AHMEDABAD, Gujarat — A little over five weeks before his first exhibition in the United States, one of India’s first street photographers sat crossed-legged on a bed in his home in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, and pulled out one of his favorite photographs. It was an image taken in 1937 of women washing clothes on the banks of the Sabarmati river that cuts through Ahmedabad.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (CNN) THE SIXTIES: THE BRITISH INVASION Tom Hanks is among the executive producers for this special, which looks at the quest by British bands to conquer the American music scene, starting with the breakthrough performance of the Beatles, above, on “The Ed Sullivan Show” on Feb. 9, 1964. It also examines the revolution in fashion, advertising, politics and sexual mores, and looks at groups that followed, like the Animals, the Kinks, the Hollies, the Dave Clark Five, the Who and the Rolling Stones. Comments by Smokey Robinson; Graham Nash; Ahmir Thompson, a.k.a. Questlove; and Micky Dolenz make the case that the British invasion was actually a reciprocal flow of influences back and forth with American artists like Bob Dylan, the Beach Boys and Motown musicians.

headline: After Weak Earnings, Shell Halts Plan to Drill in Alaska
text: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it would not pursue its contentious and accident-plagued effort to drill in Alaska this year as it confirmed a steep fall in profit in the fourth quarter.

headline: Santander’s Profit Doubles but Misses Expectations
text: LONDON – The Spanish lender Banco Santander reported on Thursday that its profit more than doubled to 1.06 billion euros in the fourth quarter as it continued to benefit from declining charges for bad loans. But the earnings still came in below analysts’ expectations.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Ice Storm Strands Thousands in Ill-Equipped South
text: In “Ice Storm Ambushes South, Stranding Thousands,” Kim Severson and Alan Blinder report on the unusual weather event that paralyzed parts of the Deep South.

text: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: Do You Ever Feel Overlooked and Underappreciated?
text: New Jersey has long suffered from an inferiority complex and found itself the butt of one too many jokes. Even now, as the host to Super Bowl XLVIII this weekend, the state still worries it is playing second fiddle to New York City. Have you ever felt like New Jersey — that you didn’t get the respect you deserved?

headline: Continuing Unrest Could Undermine Thailand’s Economy
text: HONG KONG — Thailand’s economy tends to bounce back vigorously from the coups, street protests and natural disasters that trouble it every few years. This time, however, could be different: As the nation’s once buoyant growth is slowing, investors and businesses are growing increasingly frustrated with the current political gridlock.

headline: Dassault Systèmes to Buy San Diego Software Firm
text: LONDON – Dassault Systèmes of France said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the San Diego-based scientific software company Accelrys in an all-cash deal for about $750 million.

headline: New York Today: For Non-Fans, an Open Field

headline: Talks Stall as President of Ukraine Calls in Sick
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Critical negotiations between the embattled Ukrainian government and opposition leaders were thrown into disarray on Thursday when President Viktor F. Yanukovych went on sick leave, complaining of a respiratory infection.

headline: Notes on a Tour of the Indian Women’s Movement
text: MS. GUPTA : Walking through the red-light areas of Sonagachi or lobbying in Albany for the New York State laws against human trafficking, Gloria and my life have interwoven into shared writing sessions,  rallies, meetings, dinners, books, conversations, late night phone calls across continents, brainstorming and sometimes movies. With her, I have experienced how movements move and how immense the feminist movement is.

headline: Super Bowl Prediction: Slight Edge to Seahawks
text: Football fans should be in for a treat Sunday, as Denver and Seattle ended the season ranked No. 1 and 2 in the Advanced NFL Stats efficiency model by virtue of each team’s dominance on one side of the ball. For the Broncos, that side is obviously offense, led by quarterback Peyton Manning. And for the Seahawks, it is defense, led by their smothering secondary.

headline: Suggesting an Alternative to Performance Reviews
text: My last post documented my frustration with the performance-review process. But I don’t like to complain about something that doesn’t work without thinking of a replacement, so over the last several years, I’ve developed a new model I call performance coaching.

headline: Facebook Unveils New Tool to Read Posts and News
text: Users of Apple’s iPhone are about to get a new way to browse their Facebook feeds and find other interesting articles that have been posted on the service: a visually focused application called Paper.

headline: Daily Report: Cutting Losses, Google to Sell Motorola Unit
text: Google announced on Wednesday that it would sell Motorola Mobility to Lenovo for $2.91 billion, less than two years after paying $12.5 billion to acquire it, Claire Cain Miller and David Gelles report.

headline: Why the U.S. Embassy Releases Pollution Data in Beijing But Not in Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — The United States government measures air quality levels in both its Beijing and Delhi embassies, but it only publicizes the results from its Beijing monitor. Why?

headline: In Motorola Purchase, Lenovo Gains Big Footprint in Smartphones
text: TOKYO — Apple and Samsung Electronics dominate the smartphone business, controlling about half of the sales and most of the profits. An ever-changing roster of also-rans has struggled to close the gap.

headline: Google Sells Motorola Unit to Lenovo
text: Lenovo seems to be on a buying binge, and not even Google can escape. In its second deal in a week, the Chinese company, once best known for making personal computers, announced that it was buying Google’s Motorola Mobility smartphone unit for $2.91 billion. Last week, Lenovo acquired IBM’s low-end server business for $2.3 billion.

headline: Wizard Who Made Art Jump Off the Page
text: TWENTY years ago, while browsing in an antiques store near Phoenix, Ellen G. K. Rubin, a book collector, spied something intriguing at the top of a rickety shelf. It was a pop-up book, “Moko and Koko in the Jungle,” that had been opened up to reveal a stand of banana trees, more than a foot tall, teeming with animal life.

headline: Trapped by A.L.S., He Urged His Daughter to Fly Free
text: When I was 18 I watched my father perform what would be his final surgery.

headline: Loot No Longer
text: PARIS — I worked nights from a leather chair in my living room, armed with an iPad, a telephone and a notebook. My mission was to see if I could reconnect Jewish families and others with fine art pillaged from their relatives during World War II.

headline: Blackstone Earnings More Than Doubled in Fourth Quarter
text: Updated, 3:00 p.m. | The soaring stock market was a boon last year to private equity firms looking to sell their holdings to investors. For the Blackstone Group in particular, a series of well-timed sales helped the firm double its profit in the fourth quarter.

headline: Reader Idea | Using Times Articles for ‘Copy-Change’ Text Collaborations
text: All this week, we are featuring Great Ideas From Readers, lesson plans from teachers who teach with The Times. If you have used The Times in your classroom and would like to see your idea on our blog, write in and tell us what you’ve done.

headline: Former Chief of Akamai Joins General Catalyst as Partner
text: Paul Sagan, a former chief executive of Akamai Technologies, is starting a new chapter as a venture capitalist.

headline: ‘Gravity’ and the Directors’ Contest
text: Major industry awards like those handed out by the Screen Actors Guild and the Producers Guild usually offer clues to the eventual best picture Oscar winner. But with “American Hustle,” “12 Years a Slave” and “Gravity” each collecting a big precursor prize, it’s turned into a three-way race. That was confirmed when the Directors Guild honored “Gravity” and its filmmaker, Alfonso Cuarón, a prize he couldn’t have expected after one disastrous test screening.

headline: U.S. Envoy to Visit Sri Lanka as Pressure Builds for War Crimes Inquiry
text: NEW DELHI — A top State Department official is expected to arrive in Sri Lanka on Friday, just three days after the United States announced that it would again seek a resolution at the United Nations Human Rights Council pressing for an investigation into allegations of war crimes in Sri Lanka.

headline: A Case for Cheaper Broadband in Schools
text: A nonprofit organization with its roots in the high-tech industry has gathered some 40 executives to demand that the Federal Communications Commission change how it is wiring America’s schools.

headline: Economy Is Expanding, but Obama’s Legacy May Be Slipping Away
text: Five years into the Obama presidency, the American economy is finally showing some momentum.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Willing to Raise Offer for Jos. A. Bank
text: Men’s Wearhouse may be willing to increase its bid for Jos. A. Bank in the continuing takeover battle between the two men’s suit retailers.

headline: Talking Talent | Sarah Jessica Parker, Star of the Off-Broadway Play ‘The Commons of Pensacola’
text: The Emmy Award-winning actress Sarah Jessica Parker is just a month away from seeing her new shoe line, SJP, hit Nordstrom stores on Feb. 28. She designed the 25 made-in-Italy styles alongside George Malkemus, the C.E.O. of Manolo Blahnik — whose heels carried Carrie around Manhattan for the six seasons of “Sex and the City” — but the SJP collection will fall at a more affordable price point, ranging from $195 to $500. Before she kicks off a multicity tour for SJP, Parker will take her final bow as Becca in the Manhattan Theatre Club production of “The Commons of Pensacola,” on Feb. 9. Last week, she chatted about the Lynne Meadow-directed play — in which she stars alongside Blythe Danner, who plays her mother — the much-anticipated heels and what she does when she sees the “Sex and the City” tour bus go by.

headline: A Big Advocate of French in New York’s Schools: France
text: In the fugue of tongues on New York’s streets, French has never been a dominant voice. And as surging numbers of Asian and Latino immigrants continue to tip the balance of foreign languages toward Chinese and Spanish, the idea of learning French, to some, may seem kind of quaint, even anachronistic.

headline: Militants Attack Transportation Ministry in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Militants attacked the Transportation Ministry compound in Baghdad on Thursday morning, killing seven people, according to security officials.

headline: Amanda Knox Is Re-Convicted of Murder in Italy
text: FLORENCE, Italy — Amanda Knox and her former boyfriend were convicted on Thursday for a second time in the 2007 murder of Meredith Kercher, who shared an apartment with Ms. Knox in the university town of Perugia, where both women were exchange students. The presiding judge in the Florence court sentenced Ms. Knox to 28½ years in prison and the boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, to 25 years.

headline: Andhra Pradesh Assembly Rejects New Delhi’s Proposal to Create New State
text: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — After two months of contentious debate, often interrupted by protests, the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly on Thursday rejected New Delhi’s proposal to create a new state of Telangana out of Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Obama and G.O.P. Facing Opposition to Trade Pacts
text: WASHINGTON — For companies like General Electric and Honeywell, it would help open untapped global markets, lift exports and create middle-class American jobs. For labor groups like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Teamsters, it is a threat to American workers, bound to lead to lost jobs and lower wages, as well as rising corporate profits.

headline: Low Vitamin D Tied to a Pregnancy Risk
text: Using preserved blood samples of pregnant women, researchers have found that low vitamin D levels are associated with an increased risk for severe preeclampsia, a serious and sometimes fatal disorder of pregnancy.

headline: Officials Remain in the Hot Seat as the South Thaws
text: ATLANTA — Parts of the Deep South sputtered slowly toward normalcy on Thursday, two days after a winter storm crippled vast stretches of the region and created unprecedented gridlock in its most populated areas.

headline: Istanbearish
text: OK, did we need this? Turkey? Who was paying attention to Turkey?

headline: This Star of England, in Person
text: LONDON — Along St. Martin’s Lane, the girls are lining up for their “little touch of Harry in the night.” No, that is not a snarky reference to another case of untoward groping by a member of Parliament, a subject of much conversation here. The exchange these young women are awaiting is something more, shall we say, celestial.

headline: Gary Shteyngart: By the Book
text: The author of the novel “Super Sad True Love Story” and, most recently, the memoir “Little Failure” likes books in which people suffer. “If there’s no suffering, I kind of tune out.”

headline: Activists Solicit Shareholders to Replace Board at CommonWealth REIT
text: CommonWealth REIT, the embattled real estate trust, recently extended an olive branch to the activist shareholders pressing the company for change.

headline: A Real-Life ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Reunion, Minus the Wolf
text: Moviegoers cringed at the many scenes of debauchery and dishonesty in “The Wolf of Wall Street,” a film based on the real-life shenanigans of the boiler room kingpin Jordan Belfort.

headline: Image of the Day: January 30
text: President Pranab Mukherjee at the memorial of Mohandas K. Gandhi at Rajghat in New Delhi.

headline: Dawn Zier of Nutrisystem on When Your Company Is Adrift
text: This interview with Dawn M. Zier, chief executive of Nutrisystem, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Justice Dept. Starts Quest for Inmates to Be Freed
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department wants low-level drug criminals who were sentenced under tough laws from the days of the crack epidemic to ask the president for early release from prison.

headline: Really Counting the Epithets in ‘Wolf’
text: LOS ANGELES — So just exactly how many four-letter epithets are there in “The Wolf of Wall Street”? (You know which one we mean.) For weeks, the number floating around the Internet has been 506: that’s a count promoted by Variety and other outlets, and trumpeted as the highest number for an R-rated movie. But the sleuths at Slate did a little investigating and, as it turns out, that figure is based on — at best — a blog estimate amplified by Wikipedia. And what’s more, it’s a lowball.

headline: Broncos vs. Seahawks, Atop the Empire State Building
text: The world’s most colorful football debate began on Monday evening — at the top of the Empire State Building.

headline: In Our Pages: January 31
text: 1889: Prince Rudolf Dead

headline: Landed at the Wrong Airport? Imagining a P.R. Response
text: A Southwest Airlines jet touched down at the wrong Missouri airport this month, a mix-up that comes two months after a cargo jet landed at the wrong airport in Kansas. How will the industry bounce back from the embarrassing publicity? Herewith, some suggestions for an emergency P.R. campaign.

headline: Why the Homeownership Rate Is Misleading
text: Jed Kolko is chief economist and vice president for analytics at Trulia, an online marketplace for residential real estate.

headline: An Alibaba Rival Plans Its Own I.P.O. This Year
text: SHANGHAI – JD.com, one of China’s biggest e-commerce companies, said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it planned to raise $1.5 billion this year in an initial public offering in the United States.

headline: Henry Waxman, Key Democrat and Force for Health Care Law, Is to Retire
text: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, a diminutive Democratic giant whose 40 years in the House produced some of the most important legislation of the era, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year.

headline: Diageo Reports Slower Growth
text: LONDON — Selling beer and liquor in emerging markets has for a long time been investors’ main attraction to Diageo. On Thursday, some investors sold their shares because of it.

headline: Viacom Quarterly Profit Rises 16%, Lifted by Cable Fees and Lower Costs
text: Lower costs at Paramount Pictures and higher subscriber fees at cable networks like Nickelodeon, Comedy Central and VH1 helped Viacom report a 16 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income on Thursday.

headline: Can You Tie Them in a Knot?
text: N.B.A. sneakers have become a way for players to express themselves within league guidelines. So try and match the player with his footwear.

headline: When Doctors Give Patients Money
text: Recently a few of my colleagues were sitting together and one asked if any of us had ever given money to a patient. There was an awkward pause, and then the stories starting coming out — a few dollars for a co-pay, or to help a frail patient take a cab instead of a bus; a bag of food or an extra meal. “How could I not,” one doctor said, “when my patient’s immediate need could be solved by the small change in my coat pocket?”

headline: Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld, ‘Tiger Couple’
text: “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother” was Amy Chua’s first real foray into pop-cultural polemics. Her new book, written with her husband Jed Rubenfeld, enters the same cultural minefield.

headline: Bieber Faces Assault Charge in Toronto
text: In this week’s episode of the Justin Bieber Show, the 19-year-old Canadian singer has returned to his homeland, only to find himself once more chatting with the police. This time, he went to the Toronto police voluntarily, a stark contrast with last week’s installment, in which Mr. Bieber was arrested in Miami Beach and charged with driving under the influence, resisting arrest and driving without a valid license.

headline: Mayor Says New York City Will Settle Suits on Stop-and-Frisk Tactics
text: New York City will settle its long-running legal battle over the Police Department’s practice of stopping, questioning and often frisking people on the street — a divisive issue at the heart of the mayoral race last year — by agreeing to reforms that a judge ordered in August, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday.

headline: Lauder Calls for New Panel to Resolve Nazi Art-Looting Restitution Issues
text: Ronald S. Lauder, an art collector and philanthropist who is president of the World Jewish Congress, called on Thursday for the establishment of a new commission, made up of German and foreign experts, that would resolve once and for all the issue of art looted from Jews by the Nazis. Some of these works, Mr. Lauder said, still hang in German museums and even government offices.

headline: Today in Small Business: Joke Products
text: • Here are seven policy initiatives from the president’s State of the Union address that could affect small businesses.

headline: Southwest Will Begin Flights to Caribbean
text: Southwest Airlines took a step toward becoming an international carrier this week with the announcement that it would begin daily service to Aruba, the Bahamas and Jamaica this summer.

headline: Playwright Sues to Salvage Play Deconstructing ‘Three’s Company’
text: The New York playwright David Adjmi, best known for Off Broadway satirical works like “Marie Antoinette,” went to federal court on Thursday to try to salvage his play “3C,” which has been tied up by the copyright owner of “Three’s Company,” the landmark television comedy that Mr. Adjmi deconstructs through a dark lens in “3C.”

headline: Wheelies: The Retooling for the F-150 Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Quarterly Earnings Fall at Exxon Mobil and Shell
text: For the second quarter in a row, Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell on Thursday reported sharply lower earnings because of a decrease in oil prices, declining production and soaring expenses for megaprojects around the globe.

headline: Lenovo’s Merger Spree Challenges Investors’ Faith
text: Lenovo prides itself on being a modern multinational, but its approach to divulging information remains frustratingly old school.

headline: A Copy of David Adjmi’s Legal Complaint Filed in Federal Court
text: The playwright David Adjmi asked the Southern District Court of New York to declare that his play “3C” does not infringe on the copyright of “Three’s Company,” the television comedy that ran from 1977 to 1984.

headline: Showing Deaf Players They Fit In, Too
text: NEWARK — Hearing aids in, lip-reading skill at the ready, Derrick Coleman, a Seattle Seahawks fullback, fielded question after question from reporters at Super Bowl media day. Most of them were about his hearing loss.

headline: Equality as Handout
text: In his State of the Union address, President Obama endorsed a basic feminist concept that no national politician would dare contradict: “A woman deserves equal pay for equal work.” Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, who delivered the official Republican response to the president’s speech, didn’t hesitate to endorse the principle in a Wednesday CNN interview: “Republicans and I support equal pay for equal work,” she said.

headline: Another Super Bowl Ad Fest, This Time on the Cellphone
text: Want to see the Vince Lombardi Trophy that goes to the Super Bowl winner? Take a left in 15 feet. Looking to buy some Super Bowl merchandise? Try the fourth floor of Macy’s, straight ahead.

headline: Times Minute | Henry Waxman Retires
text: In the Video

headline: The Combination Drawing Club and Taco Bell
text: If the cold New York weather has you looking for indoor activities, a little-known (and free) drawing club is held most Wednesdays from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. at the Taco Bell on 14th Street just west of Union Square. The artist Jason Polan started the Taco Bell Drawing Club nine years ago and still attends many of the weekly meetings. Polan is a prolific artist; he has drawn every piece of art in the Museum of Modern Art (not once but twice) and is currently on a mission to draw every person in New York. The club meetings are open to anyone who wants to show up and draw. Having visited recently, I decided to ask Polan some questions about the group.

headline: Times Minute | Henry Waxman Retires
text: Also on the Minute, an audit of U.S. aid to Afghanistan and Barneys New York launches a transgender ad campaign.

headline: Libyan Investment Fund Sues Goldman Over Loss
text: Updated, 7:01 p.m. | Libya’s sovereign investment fund has filed a lawsuit against Goldman Sachs in London’s High Court, claiming that the bank made more than $1 billion in derivatives trades that became worthless, but left Goldman with a profit of $350 million.

headline: 18 Charged With Operating Prostitution and Drug Ring
text: Just days before the kickoff of Super Bowl XLVIII, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman on Thursday announced charges against 18 people for operating a high-end prostitution and drug trafficking ring.

headline: Shopping Cart Injuries Remain Common
text: Shopping carts might not seem like a particularly dangerous place for a child, but from 1990 to 2011, an average of 66 children a day wound up in emergency rooms after injuries sustained in and near them.

headline: Biathlete Leaves Russian Team After Testing Positive
text: Irina Starykh, a biathlete who was one of Russia’s brightest hopes for an Olympic medal in Sochi, announced Thursday that she was stepping down from the team because of a doping violation.

headline: Delay in Chemical Arms Pledge Criticized
text: The United States sharply criticized Syria on Thursday over delays in the timetable for eliminating its chemical weapons, accusing the Syrian government of deliberately stalling their removal from the country to gain bargaining leverage and — in a new complaint — reneging on a pledge to destroy the 12 facilities that produced them.

headline: Dark Side of Capital in Emerging Markets
text: It is no fun to be a central banker in an emerging-market country when investors suddenly grow doubtful.

headline: As Gaza Tunnels Closed, Hamas Lost Cash, Israeli Official Says
text: TEL AVIV — Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, is in severe economic straits, having lost a major source of income in recent months because of an Egyptian clampdown on hundreds of smuggling tunnels, a high-ranking Israeli military official told reporters at army headquarters here on Thursday.

headline: Another Way to Think of ‘Captain Phillips': 2 Guys at Work
text: LOS ANGELES — There aren’t too many quotable lines in movies this season, but one that could have legs is “I am the captain now,” from “Captain Phillips.” At a Writers Guild panel here this week, the Oscar- and guild-nominated screenwriter Billy Ray, whose credits include little flicks like “The Hunger Games,” discussed his approach to shaping the true story of the hostage situation aboard the Maersk Alabama.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
text: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a scene from his film featuring Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto.

headline: Wintertime Bargains in Budapest
text: On a drizzly mid-January evening, I stood at the arches of the wall of Buda Castle, overlooking the Danube and the 19th-century Chain Bridge that links Buda with Pest. Beyond the bridge, the mist turned the Hungarian parliament into a glowworm.

headline: Obama Once Disdained Clinton’s Small Steps and Now Takes His Own
text: NASHVILLE — In the summer of his first year in power, President Obama made clear that he envisioned a lofty mission. “I wasn’t sent here to do school uniforms,” he told aides one day in the Oval Office. The implication was clear: He did not want to govern like Bill Clinton.

headline: U.S. Is Seeking Death Penalty in Boston Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said Thursday that it would seek the death penalty against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man accused of killing and maiming people with homemade bombs at the Boston Marathon finish line last year.

headline: The Super Bowl of Sports Gambling
text: Vegas Runner strode into the sports book of the Las Vegas Hotel & Casino, a fat diamond stud glittering in his left earlobe. Moving through the cavernous room as though it belonged to him, he reached a bar table where his friend R. J. Bell was waiting and flashed a smile. “My man!” Vegas Runner bellowed.

headline: The Power Breakfast Starts a New Day
text: NEW YORK is filled with enterprising women eager to turn up for breakfast at 8 a.m., decked out in eye shadow and Akris. They sip green tea and push a spoon around a bowl of oatmeal while speaking fervently of “protecting the brand.”

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Delay Spike in Flood Insurance Rates
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday passed a bill to delay sharp increases in flood insurance rates for millions of property owners in coastal and flood-prone areas.

headline: An Artistic Celebration of the Beauty, Spectacle and Masculinity of Soccer
text: This Sunday might be the big game, but the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) hasn’t forgotten about the other football — or soccer, as we refer to it in the United States. Opening the day of the Super Bowl, “Fútbol: The Beautiful Game” examines the sport through works of art ranging from video and photography to painting, sculpture and large-scale installation.

headline: Fitness Trackers: Lifeline or Flatline?
text: In this week’s personal technology column, I reviewed the Fitbit Force, a sleek new personal fitness tracker that is worn on the wrist. My feelings were mixed. I thoroughly enjoyed tracking my daily and weekly activity levels, and looking at the pretty visualizations that the Fitbit software creates from that data, but it was hard to parse deep insights from that information. The software, which is fairly sophisticated, still seems like it is not quite smart enough to help me figure out how to change my personal habits to be more healthy. I couldn’t recommend spending $130 on a rubber bracelet that tells me what I already know works — eat less, move more — to live well and stay in shape.

headline: Celebrating Sestinas at Poets House
text: Followers of contemporary American poetry can’t fail to notice that traditional forms, employing rhymes and recognizable meters, are pretty firmly out of fashion. Browsing through the January issue of Poetry magazine, an admittedly unscientific but fairly typical sampling, you find almost exclusively free verse. Most of today’s poets, to paraphrase Robert Frost, seem to be quite happy playing tennis without a net.

headline: The Gun Report: January 30, 2014
text: While President Obama spoke about the need for gun control in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, there was a shooting at Tennessee State University. A 20-year-old man was shot in the leg during an argument over a gambling debt following an intramural basketball game. Neither the shooter nor the victim were students.

headline: Another Option for an Upgrade From Windows XP
text: Q. I’m still running Windows XP on my computer; can I upgrade to Windows 7 instead of Windows 8?

headline: South by Southwest Festival Adds a TV Section
text: LOS ANGELES — After dabbling with previews of TV series like “Girls” and “Bates Motel,” the South by Southwest festival will add a television tier to its annual film programming, the festival said on Thursday.

headline: Banks Could Still Face Tougher Capital Requirements to Prevent Crises
text: FRANKFURT — Ever since the end of the 2008 financial crisis, the world’s leaders have searched for ways to shore up the banking system.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
text: In this video, the director Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a scene from his period film about Ron Woodroof, a Texas rodeo rider who is diagnosed with H.I.V. The scene features Matthew McConaughey as Ron, Jared Leto as his business partner, Rayon, and Kevin Rankin as Ron’s old friend T. J. “Dallas Buyers Club” received six Oscar nominations and arrives on DVD Feb. 4.

headline: A Dive Into the Arts for Black History Month
text: When Frank Owens, a seasoned Broadway pianist and onetime musical director for David Letterman, was invited to play music by the jazz composer Mary Lou Williams at a Hofstra University concert celebrating Black History Month, he saw it as a new challenge.

headline: Problem In the Classroom? Tread Lightly
text: This week’s question is from a parent seeking advice on how to handle a conference with an ineffective teacher.

headline: Boston Ballet to Conclude 50th Anniversary Tour at Lincoln Center
text: The Boston Ballet has chosen Lincoln Center as the place where it will wrap up its 50th anniversary tour. The program, which is scheduled to run from June 25 through June 29 at the David H. Koch Theater, will include a new work by José Martinez; Alexander Ekman’s “Cacti”; and classics like Nijinsky’s “Afternoon of a Faun,” William Forsythe’s “The Second Detail” and George Balanchine’s “Symphony in Three Movements.” “This tour will be the grand finale to our 50th season,” said Mikko Nissinen, the company’s artistic director. “Many of the pieces we’re presenting are new to the United States.”

headline: Video Notebook: Russell Wilson
text: Seattle Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson spoke to the media about his teammate Derrick Coleman.

headline: A Comedy That Plays to the Home Crowd
text: It’s a good thing that “Admit One” is such a good-natured comedy. Otherwise, several prestigious American institutions of higher learning might sue.

headline: Annual Profit Nearly Flat for Luxury Group LVMH
text: PARIS — LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury goods group, said Thursday that its profit was almost flat last year amid flagging demand for some of its core fashion brands in key markets like China and the impact of weaker currencies in its main overseas markets.

headline: Shoulder Pads Slim Down in Faster, Sleeker N.F.L.
text: Terrance Knighton, a 6-foot-3, 335-pound defensive tackle for the Denver Broncos, has the sumptuous nickname of Pot Roast. Perched on such a massive frame, his shoulder pads appear almost decorative, as if they were tassels on a drum major.

headline: Husband-and-Wife Chefs Split From Calliope
text: Nearly two years after opening Calliope, the popular country-French bistro in the East Village, Eric Korsh and his wife, Ginevra Iverson, the chefs and partners, have left the restaurant in a split with Eric Anderson, the other owner. The couple told Mr. Anderson of their departure Thursday morning.

headline: With Disaster Near, Debating God’s Existence
text: Now, this is what a psychiatrist’s office should look like. The wall of books; the African art; the Greek, Roman and Egyptian artifacts on the desk; the Oriental rugs; and the imposing, tapestry-draped couch. This is the sunlit London study of Dr. Sigmund Freud in TheaterWorks Hartford’s decidedly satisfying new production of “Freud’s Last Session,” and what better place to debate the existence of God?

headline: Lawsuit Questions Square’s Start-Up Story
text: Updated, 4:55 p.m. | Included comment from a spokesman from Square.

headline: New Ambitions for the Symphony of Westchester
text: What’s in a name? Plenty, according to the conductor Barry Hoffman.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Is Formed in Mississippi to Protect 6-Term Senator in G.O.P. Primary
text: WASHINGTON — A group of Mississippi Republicans, moving to counter spending from out-of-state conservative groups, have created a “super PAC” to help Senator Thad Cochran fend off a primary challenge and will begin airing a television ad on Friday.

headline: Razed Neighborhoods in Syria
text: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

headline: N.S.A. Choice Is Navy Expert on Cyberwar
text: WASHINGTON — In nominating Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers as the new director of the National Security Agency on Thursday, President Obama chose a recognized expert in the new art of designing cyberweapons, but someone with no public track record in addressing the kinds of privacy concerns that have put the agency under a harsh spotlight.

headline: Human Rights Watch Shares Images of Razed Neighborhoods in Syria
text: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

headline: Beatles ’14: Two Hotels Celebrate an Anniversary
text: In February 1964, the Beatles made their first trip to the United States, igniting Beatlemania stateside from New York to Miami. Fifty years later, hotels the band visited then are marking the anniversary in ways small and large.

headline: Homing In on a Couple’s Basquiat Drawings
text: Longtime collectors like Herbert and Lenore Schorr are luckier than most. In 1981, while visiting the Annina Nosei Gallery, which was then on Prince Street in SoHo, the couple met Jean-Michel Basquiat, fell in love with his work and bought one of his paintings. That purchase was quickly followed by others — drawings as well as canvases — and, over the years, the Schorrs amassed one of the most important Basquiat collections in the country. The Schorrs also became friends with the artist, who died of a drug overdose at 27 in 1988, and occasionally bought a painting or drawing right out of his Manhattan studio.

headline: Gallery | The Pioneers of Graffiti Art, Through the Eyes of KAWS
text: When the painter Martin Wong moved to New York in the late 1970s, the colorful graffiti around his new hometown so enthralled him that he began collecting and archiving what he knew would soon become historically significant art. He spent the next decade gathering pictures of the artists and their now painted-over masterpieces from photographers like Martha Cooper, who famously documented the emerging art form. In the ’80s, when gallerists began commissioning various mixed-media paintings from the graffiti artists — which were easier to display than tagged subway cars or building facades — Wong began to collect those too.

headline: For the Super Bowl, a Cruise Ship Becomes a Shrine to Beer
text: When doors finally opened to the newly christened Bud Light Hotel on Thursday, visitors saw more than the luxurious inside of a new cruise ship. They entered a floating shrine to the beer.

headline: What Republicans Say Versus What Republicans Mean
text: Now that the State-of-the-Union cameras are off, House Republicans are eager to discard their frozen smiles and return to their jobs of undermining virtually every goal President Obama set out in his speech on Tuesday night. They made that clear in a letter that the top four House officials sent to the president today, which purports to seek agreement on four points in the speech. It actually does quite the opposite.

headline: Super Bowl Will Again Be a Showcase for Automakers
text: As the Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks get ready for the Super Bowl, automakers have also prepared for their own game-day competition: television ads.

headline: Revenue and Profit Rise at Google, but Mobile Is a Persistent Challenge
text: SAN FRANCISCO — There is no denying that Google has become a mobile company. Now, Google — along with shareholders, industry partners and advertisers — is trying to figure out what that means.

headline: With California Syrahs, an Asian-Accented Chili
text: Entering the room with a firm handshake, the enjoyably earthy and assertive California syrahs we tasted require food that will not back off.

headline: The Real Challenge for Reform Conservatism
text: I wrote a post last week about whether a conservative reform project would necessitate a return to Bush-era deficit spending, or whether there’s any space available between “deficits don’t matter” Republicanism and Tea Party-era austerity. Since then, a number of writers have looked at the emerging conservative policy blueprints — which now include, mirabile dictu, an actual health care reform proposal! — and argued that their core weaknesses is an unwillingness to endorse new spending. Thus Danny Vinik, in a fair-minded post for Business Insider:

headline: Republicans’ Immigration Blueprint Leaves Party at Odds and Democrats Hopeful
text: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — The House Republican leadership’s call on Thursday to provide legal status for 11 million undocumented workers, and possible citizenship for those brought to this country as children, caused sharp division within the party even as it provided a starting point for negotiations with Democrats on overhauling the nation’s immigration system.

headline: Text of Republicans’ Principles on Immigration
text: On Thursday, Congressional Republicans released a one-page document, obtained by The New York Times, outlining their blueprint for immigration overhaul.

headline: Arahmaiani: ‘Fertility of the Mind’
text: Tyler Rollins

headline: Sue Williams: ‘WTC, WWIII, Couch Size’
text: 303 Gallery

headline: Guy Ben Ner: ‘Soundtrack’
text: Postmasters

headline: Saul Fletcher
text: Anton Kern Gallery

headline: Amazon to Raise Fees as Revenue Disappoints
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon investors might have finally heard the news they have been waiting for: The retailer is raising shipping fees.

headline: Senator’s Son, 26, Arrested in Colorado on Drug Charge
text: WASHINGTON — The son of Senator Mark Udall, Democrat of Colorado, was arrested this week on drug possession and trespassing charges, the Boulder County sheriff’s office said Thursday.

headline: It Started With Charcuterie
text: The mounted, tusked boar’s head on the wall immediately sets the Pass, Matthew Ridgway’s restaurant, apart. The table near the entrance with artisanal products for sale — honey, olive oil and what looked to be house-canned produce — takes it a step farther from the mainstream.

headline: Obama on Job-Driven Training
text: At a General Electric plant in Wisconsin, the president spoke about finding better ways to help Americans learn skills and signed an executive order for a review of federal job-training programs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Syria and Afghanistan.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | Where Food and Football Intersect
text: It was billed as an evening fusing football with flavors of New York, but the pastrami on rye could have been a monarch’s take on that city signature – a jewel-like gobbet of meat with caraway-scented brown butter – the kegs were filled with wine, and the hot dogs (brace yourself, oh true New Yorkers) were of a variety from Puerto Rico.

headline: Dave Pasternack to Open a Restaurant in Chelsea
text: Dave Pasternack, the chef and a partner at Esca, the Italian seafood restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen, is planning to open another restaurant come spring. This time it’s without B & B Hospitality, the Bastianich-Batali group, which owns Esca.

headline: Saying Goodbye to a City and Its Characters
text: The hills are still firmly in place, the Golden Gate Bridge remains a bright symbol of welcome, but San Francisco has changed radically since Armistead Maupin began charting the interlocking lives of a handful of its colorful fictional denizens in 1976. The city that was once a beacon for people looking to escape the strictures of conformity — and the puritanical streak in American culture — has now become a high-amenity bedroom community for the epicenter of the tech universe, Silicon Valley. And so the bohemian aerie at the center of Mr. Maupin’s beloved “Tales of the City” novels, 28 Barbary Lane, has now passed from the hands of Anna Madrigal, the one-woman marijuana dispensary who presided over her tenants as both a spiritual guru and a surrogate mother. Now, the building belongs to dot-commers who, in the words of one of the characters from Mr. Maupin’s new novel, “The Days of Anna Madrigal,” have “made it look like a five-star B and B.”

headline: My Invisible Head Not Talking Economics
text: Soundcheck on WNYC, talking musical tastes.

headline: Beyond the Large TVs, a Dancing Dragon
text: Patrons at 2one2, a pan-Asian restaurant named for its address on Merrick Road in Rockville Centre, enter through the bar. And it’s quite a bar, too, taking up almost half the space, with five large televisions, a 90-inch screen on another wall and plenty of room for a mingling crowd.

headline: Georgia Storm Response ‘Not Fast Enough’
text: Gov. Nathan Deal said that he was not satisfied with the response to this week’s winter storm and that an internal review would be conducted.

headline: Scarlett Johansson Chooses SodaStream Over Oxfam After Dispute About West Bank Factory
text: Updated, 5:49 p.m. | Forced to choose between two endorsement deals, the actress Scarlett Johansson decided Wednesday to end her charitable work on behalf of Oxfam, an antipoverty group that opposes trade with Israeli settlements, and continue as a paid “brand ambassador” for SodaStream, a company that manufactures products in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Williamstown Theater Festival to Feature Renée Fleming and Chita Rivera
text: The soprano Renée Fleming and the Tony Award-winning actress Chita Rivera will be part of the 2014 main-stage season at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: For Blackstone, a Pot of Gold Remains Out of Reach
text: Eight years after its inception, the biggest private equity fund in history has yet to meet its own minimum expectations.

headline: California Syrahs, on Such a Winter’s Day
text: California syrah seemed like a losing proposition back in 2010. Through the 1990s, growers had bet big on the grape. Plantings of syrah in California increased from fewer than 200 acres in 1990 to more than 17,000 by 2004. But sales of syrah wines crashed, and the pace of planting slowed to a trickle.

headline: Race Gap on Conventional Loans
text: African-American and Hispanic borrowers have been largely shut out of the conventional mortgage market, according to a new report from Zillow and the National Urban League. Citing 2012 loan data reported under the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, along with results from a Zillow poll of 700 mortgage applicants in December, the analysis found that whites accounted for about 69 percent of all conventional mortgage applications. The share of applications filed by blacks was under 3 percent; Hispanics represented only 5 percent.

headline: Bette in Spokane Blogging
text: So, I wondered about “Bette in Spokane”, mentioned in the official GOP SOTU response. I wondered how she could face a $700 a month increase in premiums, and speculated that she must have had “a really bare-bones policy offering hardly any protection.”

headline: Finding Common Ground on the State of the Union
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant Treasury secretary for economic policy from 2006 to 2009.

headline: An Employer Tells Congress the Health Care Mandate Could Triple His Costs
text: On Tuesday, while many were preparing for President Obama’s State of the Union address, Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee dived deep into the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate.

headline: Goldman Awards Blankfein $14.7 Million in Stock Bonus
text: Updated, 8:20 p.m. |  Goldman Sachs’s board granted its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, restricted shares worth $14.7 million as part of his pay package for 2013, according to a filing made public on Thursday.

headline: Japanese Cuisine, From Scratch
text: On two different visits to RameNesque, a new Japanese cafe with a brisk takeout business in downtown Peekskill, we couldn’t get our table to stand still. Despite our best efforts — jamming folded paper napkins under the stand, jostling the table this way and that — the wobbles won out. Chopsticks, water glasses, ramen bowls, ramekins — all skittered around on the high-gloss wooden table top like so many pointers on a Ouija board.

headline: Maher Wants His Show to Decide a House Race
text: Bill Maher makes little effort to hide his own contempt for many politicians, most of them Republicans. Now, he wants to take it to the next level: finding one he might be able to help oust from office.

headline: Two Takes on a Tiger Couple
text: The two photographs above, which accompany Jennifer Szalai’s article about Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld in this weekend’s magazine, weren’t made with mirrors or by changing their poses — they were produced by two separate cameras that fired at the same moment. The photographer Barbara Probst, who shot the couple (authors of the new book “Triple Threat: How Three Unlikely Traits Explain the Rise and Fall of Cultural Groups in America”) in her first effort for the magazine, is known for her simultaneous exposures. Recently, I asked her some questions about her work.

headline: Vintage Auction Catalogs With Personal Provenance
text: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — Vintage auction catalogs, despite competition from growing online databases, still sell by the tens of thousands a year from the offices here of the specialist dealer Jeffrey Eger. Well, not quite offices.

headline: Emerging Markets Inflow Numbers Point to Exit by Bond Investors
text: With investors on edge following the recent weeks of turmoil in emerging markets, the release this week of updated capital inflow data by the Institute of International Finance could not have been better timed.

headline: When the Prescription Is Fresh Air
text: Can a tenement window be “truly magnificent”? That’s what the architect Dan Allen says about the newly installed windows at the 1912 Cherokee Apartments, just off York Avenue, between East 77th and East 78th Streets.

headline: Godwin Help Us
text: Not my line, alas — Jonathan Chait uses it as the excerpt for his report on the WSJ’s editorial defending Tom Perkins, now famed for comparing criticism of the one percent to Kristallnacht. And boy, am I jealous.

headline: Google’s Sale of Motorola Could Help Samsung
text: Google’s imminent sale of its handset business to the Chinese computer maker Lenovo could benefit Samsung Electronics more than Lenovo and make life more difficult for other Android manufacturers.

headline: An Education in India’s Diverse Cuisines
text: In India, kolam is the decorative practice of stenciling rice-flour patterns on the ground. In Newtown, Kolam is a restaurant, one that evokes that art form in a combination of geometric designs that color its dark velour wall coverings and valances.

headline: The Source | James Turrell
text: Doug Aitken interviews the artist James Turrell.

headline: Tappan Zee Crane Arrives by Boat
text: A huge crane arrived in New York Harbor in January, after a 6,000-mile ocean journey from San Francisco. It will be used to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

headline: Times Minute | Ads That Track You
text: Also on the Minute, Ukraine's president goes on sick leave and a 400-foot crane arrives in New York.

headline: ‘Whoever’ Ad
text: The organization Mississippi Conservatives released an attack ad against State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is running against Senator Thad Cochran in a Republican primary.

headline: Oscar Shorts, From Surreal to Oh So Real
text: You may have seen the eye-popping 3-D animated Disney short “Get a Horse!” In this spicy visual appetizer, which accompanies the megahit “Frozen,” Mickey and Minnie Mouse and their friends Horace Horsecollar and Clarabelle Cow enjoy a hayride until the appearance of Peg-Leg Pete, who tries to run them off the road. As Mickey and Horace fight with Pete, these hand-drawn, black-and-white animated characters are forced through the screen, emerging as colorful CGI versions of themselves. A frantic battle royal ensues as a raft of Disney characters jump in and out of the screen and chase one another in circles.

headline: The Mythic and Heroic, Just Inches Tall
text: In case you haven’t noticed, the Frick Collection has been on something of a bronze statuette kick over the last decade. During that time, it has mounted five monographic or survey shows of these small collectibles, all organized by the estimable curator Denise Allen.

headline: Times Minute | Ads That Track You
text: In the Video

headline: Southwest and JetBlue Buy Washington Airport Rights
text: Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways said on Thursday that they had bought the takeoff and landing rights at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington that the Justice Department required American Airlines and US Airways to sell as a condition of their merger.

headline: It’s Him, Not Her
text: I have a mostly sweet and fairly well-behaved 10-year-old son. But sometimes he is really mean to Siri (the simulated assistant on my phone’s operating system). He’ll say things like, “You’re a stupid idiot, Siri.” Do you think we should punish him for statements like these? If he ever called an actual person a stupid idiot, he would be in huge trouble.

headline: How Much Is Too Much to Pay for Jos. A. Bank?
text: Men’s Wearhouse may be willing to raise its bid to buy its rival, the men’s suit retailer Jos. A. Bank, but analysts on Wall Street are wondering: How much is too much?

headline: Is It Love, or Stockholm Syndrome?
text: The heaving, bubbling euphemism driving Jason Reitman’s “Labor Day” is a juicy homemade peach pie just out of the oven. Its creator, Frank (Josh Brolin), is an escaped prisoner who shows Adele (Kate Winslet), a single mother held captive in her own home, the secrets of baking. That lesson takes place over a sleepy holiday weekend in September 1987. Carefully noting every detail is her nerdy 13-year-old son, Henry (Gattlin Griffith).

headline: Why Can’t I Have a Washing Machine?
text: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Source | Liz Glynn
text: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Liz Glynn.

headline: Dutch Masterwork, Under Reconstruction
text: “Tim’s Vermeer” is a little documentary that tracks how one man’s love turned into revenge. The title figure — well, one, anyway — is Tim Jenison, a scientist, inventor and restless hobbyist with deep pockets and famous friends, including Penn Jillette, who produced the movie, and Teller, who directed. In the 1980s, Mr. Jenison founded NewTek, a hardware and software company that scored an early success with the creation of Video Toaster, an affordable desktop video-production tool. Since then, this autodidact, now in his late 50s, has done this and that, including embarking on a multiyear odyssey to discover whether the movie’s other, better-known, subject, the Dutch master Johannes Vermeer (1632-75), used any kind of optical tools when he created his extraordinary paintings.

headline: It Started With a $2 Poster
text: The Japanese galleries at the Metropolitan Museum have been pulling crowds since John T. Carpenter became curator in 2011. He has taken the permanent collection, shaken it up, threaded it through with strategic loans and, like a good teacher, unfurled it logically around graspable themes. Who could resist a show that tells the art history of a complex culture, as Mr. Carpenter did last year, entirely in images of birds?

headline: Box, an Online Storage Start-Up, Is Said to File for an I.P.O.
text: Updated, 7:21 p.m. | Box, an online storage and document-sharing provider, has filed confidential paperwork to go public, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Food Matters | The Godfather of Hipster American Dining Serves Up a Fresh Dish: Enlightenment
text: It’s been almost a decade since Taavo Somer co-opened Freemans, the seminal Lower East Side gastropub that ushered in a new epoch of American comfort food and rustic, taxidermy-heavy restaurant design. Since then, he’s launched several other restaurants and expanded his atavistic men’s wear line, Freemans Sporting Club. The man once described as the “patron saint of hipsters” also became a dad, trimmed his beard, began spending more time at his farmhouse upstate and loudly proclaimed his distaste for the culture he’d come to represent.

headline: Crystalline Glory, Frozen in Time
text: Before she directed “The Fabulous Ice Age,” Keri Pickett was a photographer who had never contemplated making a film. Her uncle, the former figure skater Roy Blakey — an avid collector of ice-show memorabilia — changed all that.

headline: Yahoo Reports Attack on Mail Accounts
text: Another day, another breach.

headline: Do Not Look Down in This Class
text: “The actor’s gift,” according to the director and theatrical sage Peter Brook, “is the connection between pure imagination and the body itself.” For him, the technique of acting is at once physical and metaphysical, a discipline of the face, limbs, voice and spirit. “Peter Brook: The Tightrope,” a concise new documentary directed by Simon Brook, offers a rare glimpse behind the scenes as its subject (who happens to be the filmmaker’s father) instructs a group of actors in the rigor and simplicity of his method.

text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: childhood obesity, testosterone therapy and the amount of exercise that might save you from an early death.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Obama Reaches Out After Shooting of Nashville Student
text: NASHVILLE — President Obama sought on Thursday to comfort a high school community devastated by the death of a 15-year-old student who was killed with a handgun less than 48 hours before the president’s arrival here.

headline: Gospel Without Hallelujahs
text: Anyone unfamiliar with the traditional African-American spirituals that the great operatic tenor Lawrence Brownlee performed on Wednesday at the Allen Room can be forgiven for mistaking them for concert art songs. If Mr. Brownlee and his accompanist and arranger Damien Sneed didn’t tell you, you might not realize that beloved spirituals like “There Is a Balm in Gilead,” “Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child” and “Down by the Riverside” belong to an oral tradition of gospel music distinct from carefully notated classical art songs.

headline: Super Bowl Fever Hits Midtown, but Many There Aren’t Catching It
text: The orchids are dying, and Cliff Jacobs blames the Super Bowl.

headline: The Other Super Bowl Underdog
text: WHEN Bruno Mars takes the stage at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., this chilly Sunday evening to perform at the Super Bowl halftime show, in front of the biggest audience he’s ever played to, he can take some solace that his set only needs to be about 12 minutes long.

headline: A Clarinet Does Scenes
text: The formal and emotional crux of “The Big Picture,” David Krakauer’s 90-minute multimedia tribute to movie music at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, is “Shoah Trilogy,” a medley of themes from films about the Holocaust. Mr. Krakauer’s clarinet girded each with a piercing wail in the premiere on Wednesday night, communicating anguish, outrage and catharsis.

headline: De Blasio to Settle Stop-and-Frisk Suit
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that the city had reached an agreement with civil rights lawyers who argued that the Police Department’s policy violated minorities’ rights.

headline: Need the Best for Your Next Occasion? Call Westminster Palace
text: LONDON — Overindulgence in food and drink has long been one of the hazards of political life for members of Britain’s Parliament. But no longer. Abstemiousness seems to be the order of the day.

headline: Digital, Analog and Waterlogged
text: “What Is a Photograph?” asks the title of a disappointing exhibition at the International Center of Photography.

headline: A Woman Whose Ecstasy Ignited a Riot
text: Nicely immersive if largely uninformative, “Breaking the Frame” is best appreciated as a chance to spend time with the painter, filmmaker, author, performance artist and epic cat lover Carolee Schneemann (born 1939). One of the leading female figures of American avant-garde cinema, Ms. Schneemann is best known for “Fuses” (1965), a gorgeous onetime scandal that features explicit images of her having sex with her partner, the composer James Tenney. “I can consider ‘Fuses,’ ” Ms. Schneemann once wrote, “not simply as a film but in its revelatory cultural erotic intrusion — a vision (message) of genital sexuality and female pleasure which vitalized and agitated the art world.”

headline: Jazz Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Last Look at Old Paris, Before Demolition
text: In the massive construction site that was late-19th-century Paris, the photographer Charles Marville was just a few steps ahead of the wrecking ball. As an official city photographer working under Napoleon III and his controversial urban planner, Baron Haussmann, Marville recorded some 425 views of narrow, picturesque streets that were to be replaced by Haussmann’s grand boulevards.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Casting a Documentarian’s Eye on Dance’s Past and Its Future
text: Dance class: It’s a place that we rarely associate with political skirmishes, cultural upheavals or socioeconomic pressures. But two films in the 42nd Dance on Camera festival, which begins on Friday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, remind us that the studio, the ballet barre, the halls of college dance departments — just like any social space — are realms where all of these tensions play out, in both quiet and dramatic ways.
