text: Dear Diary:

headline: Verdict in March for 3 in France Accused of Intent to Fight in Syria
text: PARIS — The first trial of French citizens accused of trying to join the rebellion in Syria concluded Friday after lawyers for the government and the defendants presented their arguments in a Paris courtroom.

headline: House G.O.P.’s Immigration Plan Presents Tough Choices for Obama
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and his allies may soon confront a difficult decision: whether to abandon the creation of a new path to citizenship for 11 million illegal immigrants and accept tough border security and enforcement measures that they have long criticized.

headline: Audit Planned in Fraud Case as Navy Reinstates Shipper
text: The Navy has quietly lifted the suspension of a shipping contractor under investigation for possible fraud, allowing the company to compete for new work. In exchange, the company has agreed to pay for an independent audit that could help the Justice Department determine how much it may have overcharged the government.

headline: Determined Voters in Thailand Ready to Repel Protesters
text: BANGKOK — All of the extreme emotions, the fears of lawlessness and the concerns about violence breaking out in Sunday’s election in Thailand are on display in a community called Lat Krabang, a few minutes’ drive from the main international airport here.

headline: The Source | Liz Glynn in Conversation With Doug Aitken
text: “I think about functioning as somewhere between an architect and a scientist,” says Liz Glynn. “So I create the space and set up an experiment, but then I get out of the way and sort of see what happens.” In conversation with Doug Aitken, the 32-year-old artist from Los Angeles talks about her work, which includes site-specific installations for performances and collective happenings as well as modern-day monuments and handmade sculptural objects. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Elaine Stritch, Broadway Legend: ‘Entertaining Is Hard’
text: After years of vowing to retire, you gave up your cabaret act at the Cafe Carlyle and your apartment at the Carlyle Hotel and moved to Birmingham, Mich. What made you finally take the leap? I wasn’t getting the quality of work that I wanted to get. I’m a funny age — funny ha-ha, funny peculiar, funny, funny. I could hardly open my mouth on the stage without getting a laugh. That’s a pretty sensational thing to brag about, but it’s also dangerous. I had a great time, and I’m very glad it’s over. Oh, my God, it’s hard. Entertaining is hard.

headline: Our Young-Adult Dystopia
text: I sometimes wonder what Dante or Milton or any of those guys would make of the modern appetite for the young-adult epic. It wasn’t always a lucrative thing, writing grand, sweeping, fantastical stories, you know. It was a job for nose-to-the-grindstone, writing-for-the-ages types, and worldly rewards were low. Milton died in penury, blind and obscure; Dante met his maker in literal exile. Would they look with envy upon their celebrated and moneyed modern analogues — your J. K. Rowlings, your Suzanne Collinses?

headline: Reply All: The 1.19.14 Issue
text: THE ONLINE AVENGERS

headline: Grown-Up Clothes
text: When I was 19, I went to New York City, my first trip East. I’d won a Mademoiselle contest and would be one of 20 young women working at the magazine for a month in the summer. It was 1953, and I was excited but also frightened and daunted; I hadn’t been on an airliner before, and no one I knew had been to New York except my Sioux Falls uncle, Bill, a buyer for a department store. In case of difficulties, I was to call my Uncle Bill’s New York friend, Mr. Herbert Solomon.

headline: Who Made That First-Person-Shooter Game?
text: “It was like playing with dolls,” says the video-game designer and 3-D graphics creator John Carmack, thinking back to the computer entertainments before Call of Duty, Halo, Doom and all the other “first-person-shooter” games. “In a typical game of that time, your character was maybe 16-by-16 pixels in an overhead view. Maybe it did some cute things that made you smile. But you were still controlling a tiny little thing on the screen.”

headline: Breaking: Kids Are Obnoxious
text: Rachael Ray violates the Third Commandment; Richard Sherman takes on “Peanuts.”

headline: Get Out of My Subconscious!
text: Our subconscious beliefs, which we cannot easily understand or change, motivate many of the decisions we make. Some companies use manipulative branding techniques that create untrue associations between their products and some deep human desires   —   like sex or social status   —   with the goal of having the viewer establish this connection unconsciously. The desired result, presumably, is that the consumer will then buy the product with the misguided intent of fulfilling said desire. Is this practice unethical? ADAM GIDDING, NEW YORK

headline: There’s a Reason That Rye Is Having a Moment
text: If we were playing a round of word association a few years ago and you said, “Rye,” I wouldn’t have skipped a beat before saying, “Pastrami.” For most of my drinking life, rye whiskey seemed like tough-guy stuff, cowboy stuff. And to drink as they drank (or at least as I imagined they did) seemed affected or unduly performative. Why would I replace my everyday Irish whiskey with rye? Why trade the bourbon in my manhattan for another brown American spirit?

headline: The Empire State Building in Ice
text: Every winter, hundreds of thousands of tourists visit the Harbin Ice and Snow World in northeast China, near the Songhua River, to see its vast collection of elaborately carved ice structures, many of them illuminated with colorful LEDs. The arduous task of quickly collecting all that ice for an exhibition that opens in early January begins in mid-December, and the ice city has been getting bigger every year. This time around, 180,000 cubic meters of ice were used. Some of the finished sculptures this year, which remain in place until March, are a homage to structures around the world, from the Colosseum to the Empire State Building. Zengyu Wang, the executive manager of the event, says the local government in Harbin dreamed up the festival as a lure to promote winter tourism. When visitors see the ice for the first time, he says, they have one reaction: “Very shocked.” Julie Bosman

headline: Japan’s Public Broadcaster Faces Accusations of Shift to the Right
text: TOKYO — First, there was the abrupt resignation of a president accused by governing party politicians of allowing an overly liberal tone to news coverage. Then, his newly appointed successor immediately drew public ire when he seemed to proclaim that he would loyally toe the line of the current conservative government.

headline: Judge’s Family Denies Pride Was Behind Rejection of 3rd-Highest Award
text: NEW DELHI — The family of the late Jagdish Sharan Verma, the former Supreme Court chief justice whose report helped strengthen Indian sexual assault laws, said it had rejected one of India’s top awards for the judge because he would have never accepted it had he been alive.

headline: Investors and Customers Yearn for an Apple iThingamajig
text: Let’s play a little game. If you were Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, and you could have any gadget in the world that you wanted, what would it be? Forget that such a gadget doesn’t exist yet. Remember, you’re the chief executive. of Apple — you can just pick up your iPhone 10, scroll down to Jony Ive’s number and tell him to build you an iThingamajig.

headline: Clamor Grows for Syria to Deliver on Chemical Arms Pledge
text: The head of the United Nations chemical weapons watchdog added his voice on Friday to calls on Syria to accelerate the elimination of its chemical weapons, a day after Washington accused the Syrian government of deliberately stalling the weapons’ removal from the country to gain bargaining leverage and — in a new complaint — reneging on a pledge to destroy the 12 facilities that produced them.

headline: Putting Prestige in Service of Comedy
text: LOS ANGELES — Before his name appeared, however incongruously, on a list of possible cast members for a new Fox comedy set in a fictional Brooklyn police precinct, Andre Braugher had an epiphany.

headline: Oscar Shorts on View
text: What will take home the Oscar in the documentary short subject category? Will it be “Cavedigger,” Jeffrey Karoff’s film about a cave artist in New Mexico? Or “The Lady in Number 6,” Malcolm Clarke’s portrait of a 109-year old Holocaust survivor? For those looking to make an educated guess on their Oscar ballot, a series of programs featuring this year’s nominees is in theaters nationwide today. The series has become an annual event, with the shorts programs divided into three feature-length compilations: animated, live-action and documentary.

headline: Walmart Trims Its Profit Forecast for the 4th Quarter
text: Walmart lowered its profit expectations for the latest quarter, citing cuts to food stamps and an especially tough winter.

headline: Abuse Claims in Ukraine Rise Among Protesters
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Alarm mounted on Friday among Western diplomats and rights groups over the scale and severity of abuses during the civil unrest in Ukraine after an antigovernment protest leader who had been missing for a week stumbled out of a snowy forest to say he had been crucified.

headline: The Force of Japanese Exports Is Weakening
text: JAPAN posted a third consecutive trade deficit in 2013, providing more evidence that the power of the Japanese export machine has faded.

headline: With Persistence, He Caught the Girl Next Door
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more.

headline: Under Pressure
text: Parenthood as we know it — predicated on the unconditional exaltation of our children — is no more than 70 years old, and it has gone through radical readjustments over the past two generations. As children went from helping on the farm to being the focus of relentless cosseting, they shifted “from being our employees to our bosses,” Jennifer Senior observes in her trenchant and engrossing first book, “All Joy and No Fun: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood.” Senior, a contributing editor at New York magazine, examines what it means to be a parent, through interviews with a handful of families who are neither typical nor extraordinary. These are snapshots, not longitudinal documentaries, but in the way of good snapshots, they tell more than one might notice at first glance, and they allow for cautious universalizing. She supplements these vignettes with extremely impressive research, weaving in insights from philosophy, psychology and an occasionally overwhelming mélange of social science reports.

headline: The Badger With a Comb-Over
text: LOS ANGELES – David O. Russell had a nickname for Christian Bale’s character in “American Hustle,” the combed-over, paunchy yet confident swindler Irving Rosenfeld.

headline: He Accused
text: The Dreyfus Affair, which splintered French society of the fin de siècle and continued to divide it well into the 20th century, began on the morning of Oct. 15, 1894, with the arrest for high treason of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus. Dreyfus was a 35-year-old artillery officer, a high-ranking graduate of the elite École Polytechnique and the École de Guerre (the French Army’s war college), and was chosen on the basis of his grades and overall performance to train with the army’s general staff. Robert Harris, in his fine novel “An Officer and a Spy,” lucidly retells the famous, bizarrely complicated and chilling story. His narrator is Lt. Col. Georges Picquart, who was promoted to that grade six months after Dreyfus’s arrest and put in charge of the general staff’s statistical section (the coy sobriquet of a counter­intelligence unit), and went on to become one of Dreyfus’s improbable and indispensable saviors.

headline: Parenthood
text: CUT IT OUT

headline: A Brooklyn Artery in Transition
text: The dream of turning Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn into a grand residential boulevard is still just that — a dream. Even so, residential development along the thoroughfare took off about a decade ago when the area was rezoned, and now, after a recession-induced break, construction has begun again at a somewhat frenzied pace.

headline: Affordable Housing Conundrum
text: New Yorkers in truly affordable apartments sometimes find their sweet deals come with sacrifices.

headline: A Bookstore on the Brink
text: Last month, The Times reported that the Manhattan home of Rizzoli Bookstore, a visually stunning literary outpost in an old limestone mansion on 57th Street, was to make way for a high-rise development. The news galvanized two passionate and beleaguered groups: readers and preservationists.

headline: The Truly Affordable New York Apartment
text: In a city of soaring real estate prices, New Yorkers love to hear the tales of people who found the Promised Land: a truly affordable apartment.

headline: Letters: Robert Gates’s ‘Duty’ and More
text: Robert Gates’s ‘Duty’

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MY LIFE IN MIDDLEMARCH,  by Rebecca Mead. (Crown, $25.) A beguilingly straightforward account of Mead’s lifelong admiration for George Eliot as a novelist and as a role model for bright, provincially born girls like herself.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE REAL JANE AUSTEN: A Life in Small Things,  by Paula Byrne. (Harper Perennial, $16.99.) Contrary to Virginia Woolf’s pronouncement, in 1928, that “we have lives enough of Jane Austen,” Austen’s appeal has proved irresistible. Byrne’s vividly persuasive biography shirks chronological constraints, using objects of special significance to Austen — an East Indian shawl, an ivory miniature, velvet cushions — to depict her as an exuberant, worldly woman of fierce convictions.

headline: Inside the List
text: Healthy Distance: Sarah Addison Allen’s “Lost Lake,” about a young widow trying to recover from grief at a magical Georgia resort, is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 5. It’s Allen’s fifth novel — or sixth, if you count the early romance she wrote under a pseudonym — but her first since announcing, in a 2011 Facebook post, that she had advanced-stage breast cancer. (“For those of you who don’t want to read the word ‘boob,’ ‘breast’ or ‘bazookas’ a gazillion times,” she wrote, “I’ll let you know how it ends: I’m going to be fine. Now, for the rest of you, I’m going to reveal more about my cleavage than I think I’ve ever told anyone.”)

headline: Breaking In
text: On a March evening in 1971, eight antiwar protesters burglarized an F.B.I. office in Media, Pa., just outside Philadelphia, with astonishing ease. A few weeks of elementary surveillance had shown them the vulnerability of the target: There were no cameras to elude, no alarms to disconnect. Because the building contained residential apartments, the group chose the night of the first Joe Frazier-­Muhammad Ali heavyweight championship fight, an ideal distraction. It turned out that the Pennsylvania office, like so many others across the country, had almost no physical protection. Security was largely symbolic, resting on the bureau’s carefully buffed reputation for efficiency in tracking down America’s “most wanted” criminals, from bank robbers to atomic spies. Put simply, no one messed with J. Edgar Hoover’s F.B.I.

headline: Secrets of Success
text: Quanyu Huang’s new book, “The Hybrid Tiger: Secrets of the Extraordinary Success of Asian-­American Kids,” may sound like yet another flogging for hapless Western parents, but it’s not.

headline: The Marriage Plod
text: How disgusting the British find themselves! Let me rephrase that. If you were to go by the output of a certain strand of young, male British fiction writer, you could easily be forgiven for thinking the main activity of British life is being disgusted by the physical form of oneself and one’s fellows. Ian McEwan began a short story noting the peculiar smell asparagus lends the urine (“it suggests sexual activity of some kind between exotic creatures”). Martin Amis spent large parts of his early career detailing his characters’ bleeding gums and cracked molars. Will Self’s books come so awash in bodily fluids that if you were to throw them against a wall they’d most likely stick. Male self-disgust, rooted in the moist tumult of adolescence, and extended into one’s 20s and 30s under cover of literary careers aping the clinical imperturbability of Nabokov and Joyce, has almost bequeathed us its own genre. We might call it, in the manner of those outraged letters to British broadsheets, “Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells.”

headline: In the Grip of Madness
text: July 2006: Haya Tedeschi, 83, waits at her home in Gorizia, on the Italian-Slovenian border, northwest of Trieste, for the arrival of the son who was stolen from her 62 years earlier, during the war.

headline: Winter Cabbage With a Mediterranean Flair
text: One of the things I appreciate about this produce-limited time of year is that it forces me to devote a week of Recipes for Health to cabbage. I love this nutrient-dense cruciferous vegetable for many reasons: the way it sweetens as it cooks in the pan; the price per pound; the way it is comfortable in a soup or a pie, a stew, a gratin or a salad, a stir-fry or a timbale. Yet I sometimes forget to pay attention to cabbage. It can be overshadowed by other winter vegetables like kale, its more fashionable cousin.

headline: Start-Up Aims to Circumvent Rules on Private Stock Sales
text: You have likely heard of “first world problems.” But here is a Silicon Valley problem — and a company trying to solve it.

headline: Lonely Hunter
text: At the Brooklyn Museum, an exhibit called “War/Photography: Images of Armed Conflict and Its Aftermath,” which went up in November, featured a photograph by Nina Berman of a young Marine sergeant, Ty Ziegel, who was horrifically injured and disfigured by a suicide bomb in Iraq in 2004. Returning home, he underwent scores of surgeries and in 2006 married his sweetheart in Illinois. The marriage didn’t last, and Ziegel died in December 2012. But nobody who saw the “Marine Wedding” series will be able to forget him — or the damage wrought by war on his body, his life and his family. Joyce Carol Oates’s new novel puts the homecoming of a similarly wounded warrior at its center, doing with words what the Berman portraits did with images.

headline: Liberated and Unfree
text: As the 150th anniversary of the Civil War heads toward its conclusion, the anniversary of Reconstruction, the turbulent era that followed, looms on the horizon. Properly commemorating it poses a challenge, since for no period of American history does a wider gap exist between scholarly understanding and public consciousness.

headline: The Unknown War
text: They called it the “Aleutian stare.” During World War II, American soldiers stationed in the remote, windswept archipelago stretching for 1,100 miles west of the Alaskan mainland fought a secret war against Japanese invaders. Driven mad by the cold, the isolation and the “dim, colorless light,” some were taken away in straitjackets, gazing into the distance, “unfocused, unspeaking.” The rest of the country didn’t even know they were there.

headline: Are We There Yet?
text: Just as Arthur Phillips’s “Prague” follows a group of Americans living not in the title city but in less trendy Budapest, Mary Miller’s terrific first novel, “The Last Days of California,” never quite makes it to the Golden State. And I don’t think it’s giving anything away to say it doesn’t turn out to be the last days, either.

headline: Limits of Endurance
text: Alvin Townley, the author of books about naval aviation and Eagle Scouts, has written a gripping account of the “Alcatraz Eleven,” a group of American prisoners of war in North Vietnam who formed a tough core of heroic resisters despite brutal and relentless efforts to break them and convert them into fodder for the Communist propaganda machine. Readers of even passing acquaintance with the Vietnam War will most likely know of Jeremiah Denton’s televised 1966 interview — one of the first glimpses of the life of United States military pilots who had been shot down and captured. American viewers watched in horror and puzzlement as Denton, an emaciated, hunched figure dressed in gray prison garb, defiantly telegraphed the word t-o-r-t-u-r-e by blinking out the letters in Morse code. His brave act was followed by yet more torture, and some time later Vietnamese authorities bundled him along with 10 other men out of the infamous Hanoi Hilton, as Hoa Lo prison in the North Vietnamese capital was known (and where John McCain, probably the most famous P.O.W. of the war, would be held). The destination of the Eleven was an even filthier hellhole a few miles away, which they nicknamed Alcatraz.

headline: At a Distance
text: Penelope Lively is writing from another country, a place she calls “old age.” She is 80, and so, she assures us, she is now “a native” of this territory, an “authority.” “Dancing Fish and Ammonites” is about growing old, about memory and history, about reading and writing and the way experiences become associated with certain objects — with a book, say, or a piece of pottery. Lively has explored these themes before, in her many novels and in a handful of previous memoirs. This time, though, she says she wants to address them more abstractly: “I find myself thinking less about what has happened to me but interested in this lifetime context, in the times of my life.” She’s not trying to tell us a story.

headline: Stab in the Dark
text: Isabel Allende says that RIPPER (Harper, $28.99) is her first murder mystery, and that it was a lot of fun to write. It’s probably more accurate to say that this ungainly but thoroughly charming book is the author’s own eccentric notion of a murder mystery, and that it’s a lot of fun to read. Also, it features a teenage sleuth — “idiosyncratic of appearance, timorous of character, but magnificent of mind,” according to her besotted grandfather — who is pretty much irresistible.

headline: Boy Trouble
text: Peter Huang, the worshiped son in a family of daughters, has just one wish: to be a girl. His father, a Chinese immigrant, has another: to erase completely, and by force if necessary, evidence of his Asian heritage. Father and son have almost nothing in common except for the belief that self-acceptance is anathema.

headline: This Week's Movies: Jan. 31, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics on "Tim's Vermeer," "That Awkward Moment" and "Labor Day."

headline: De Blasio on Hot 97: New Sound for Mayoral Radio
text: The interview ended with a pulsating reggae track, its lyrics an ode to the pleasures of high-quality cannabis.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Secrets to Success
text: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh discusses “The Hybrid Tiger” and “The Triple Package”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Betty Medsger talks about “The Burglary”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Secrets to Success
text: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh and Betty Medsger.

headline: When Buying Stock in Gluttony Is a Good Investment
text: ARTHUR LEVITT JR., the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, acknowledged that he found “The Seven Deadly Sins” irresistible — so much so that he plunked down $5,000 as an initial investment and has since put in more.

headline: Cheerios: Hard for Racists to Swallow
text: Never mind the point-spread, New Jersey weather, momentum shifts and Newtonian replays. Just keep an eye out for the Super Bowl’s first unscheduled time out, when the huge television audience can catch that famous Cheerios commercial family — the one that so enraged racist Americans several months ago, featuring a manly black actor as father, a serene white mother and their charming interracial seven-year-old, Gracie.

headline: A Perfectionist Does Opera His Way
text: Every once in a while, the Russian stage director Dmitri Tcherniakov has a nightmare. He’s ready to go to the theater and run a rehearsal when he realizes he has forgotten what he is supposed to do there, what he wants to tell the performers.

headline: Not Easygoing, and Not Sure About a Donkey
text: PARIS — The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky has created four ballets to music by Leonid Desyatnikov: “Russian Seasons” (New York City Ballet, 2006), “Old Ladies Falling Out” (Territory festival in Moscow, 2007), “Lost Illusions” (Bolshoi Ballet, 2011) and “Opera” (La Scala Ballet, 2013). Both men are Russian, and both have worked at the Bolshoi in Moscow, where Mr. Ratmansky, 45, now artist in residence at American Ballet Theater, was the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet from 2004 to 2008, and Mr. Desyatnikov, 58, was music director from 2009 to 2010.

headline: A Songbird Finding Strength in Her Nest
text: While other students at Juilliard wanted to sing Verdi and Rossini, the mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke, 31, gained a reputation as a quick study willing to learn new pieces written by her composer colleagues.

headline: Beatle Fans Hear Yesterday Again
text: It was inevitable, time marching on as it does, and yet it also hard to believe: Half a century has passed since the Beatles touched down in New York for the first time, on Feb. 7, 1964, and seduced the country with three performances on “The Ed Sullivan Show” and three concerts, one at the Washington Coliseum and two at Carnegie Hall. Everything about them — their pudding basin haircuts, their Cardin suits and pointed boots, their sharp, irreverent sense of humor — seemed outlandish, compared with American pop groups. And though their music was firmly rooted — as they were always quick to point out — in American rhythm and blues, soul and rock, they produced a sound that was fresh, energetic and unmistakably their own.

headline: Jelly vs. Need, Comparing Two New Social Q & A Apps
text: In case anyone was looking for further evidence that the five-star rating system is broken, I heard a horrific story the other day from someone who used Yelp to select a five-star-rated veterinarian when his vet was out of town, only to get stuck with a $10,000 vet bill and a dead pet.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Gravity’
text: Updated, 10:26 a.m. | Jany Temime, the costume designer of Alfonso Cuarón’s space thriller “Gravity,” was scared. After a 40-year career packed with period pieces and one of the biggest fantasy franchises in movies (“Harry Potter”), she was facing the great unknown: space. In 3-D, no less.

headline: Walter De Maria’s Grand and Gritty Home
text: A former Con Edison substation on the Lower East Side reimagined by the internationally renowned artist/sculptor/composer Walter De Maria as a cavernous home studio, storage facility, and dedicated laboratory for the gestation of his monumental works, is about to enter the market at $25 million.

headline: Exclusive | 421 East 6th Street
text: The sculptor and artist Walter De Maria, who died last summer at age 77, was drawn to the building by its lofty ceiling heights, unusual windows, and absolute privacy.

headline: Times Fashion Critic Cathy Horyn to Retire
text: Cathy Horyn, The New York Times’s chief fashion critic, is retiring, the paper said Friday. Ms. Horyn has been with The Times since 1998 and has been in her current position since 1999.

headline: Navigating an Informant’s Shadow World
text: BERLIN — Ten years ago, Yuval Adler, an aspiring Israeli filmmaker, chanced upon a video on a Middle East website that captured one of the most brutal moments of the Palestinian uprising. The footage showed a gang of militants dragging a suspected collaborator through the streets of Bethlehem, and shooting him dead before a crowd of onlookers. “I remember thinking: ‘What is going on there? How does somebody get into that situation?’ ” Mr. Adler said. “If these are the stakes in becoming an informant, how would the Israelis manage to recruit somebody?”

headline: At a Concert Full of Musical Stars, a Spotlight on Their Teacher
text: It’ll be 70 years this spring since a 17-year-old Gabriel Kosakoff shouldered his trombone and marched out of the High School of Music and Art, dreaming of fame and fortune in the world’s top concert halls.

headline: An App to Search for Street Art
text: The destruction of the graffiti mecca 5Pointz, in Long Island City, last fall was a devastating blow to the community of street art in New York City and around the world.

headline: As Facebook Turns 10, How Has It Transformed Your Life?
text: In February, Facebook will be 10 years old.

headline: Accounting for Dimon’s Big Jump in Pay
text: The compensation and management development committee of JPMorgan Chase’s board has three members, all seasoned business luminaries in their own right. Lee R. Raymond, the chairman, is the former long-serving chairman and chief executive of Exxon Mobil. Stephen B. Burke is chief executive of NBCUniversal. William C. Weldon is the former chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Johnson.

headline: This Week’s Cover Accurately Predicts the Super Bowl Winner (Half of the Time)
text: The cover of the magazine that you get in your Sunday Times may not be the same as your neighbor’s. In an effort to be equally supportive of (or offensive to) Seahawks and Broncos fans, we printed two covers, which will be distributed randomly to Times subscribers.

headline: Times Minute | Tray Tables Up
text: Airlines remake the staid in-flight safety video. Also on the Minute, the immigration debate and the origin of the first, first-person shooter game.

headline: Times Minute | Tray Tables Up
text: In the Video

headline: No Help for Farm Bill From Miffed Kansans in the House
text: Few states are as identified with farming as Kansas. Among its nicknames are the “The Wheat State” and “American’s Bread Basket.” And Kansas’s lawmakers are quick to point out the importance of agriculture to the state’s economy.

headline: Days Before the Kickoff, a Timeout at Forty Ate
text: There were moments last week, during the run-up to Sunday’s Super Bowl, when the hordes of football fans thronging Broadway for the N.F.L.’s pregame festivities appeared to outnumber even the characters handing out fliers and asking, “Do you like comedy?” During one such moment, as others rode toboggans down a snowless slope, a couple from Interlaken, N.J., made their way to the second floor of the Renaissance New York Times Square Hotel, overlooking the madness, to refuel over lunch at Forty Ate, a pop-up restaurant conceived by the football league and the restaurateur Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group. The hosts offered Thursday-to-Saturday ownership of choice tables for $50,000 (drinks not included), but found only four takers. The rest of the restaurant’s 72 seats went to ordinary reservation-makers and walk-ins.

headline: Image of the Day: January 31
text: Members of the Chinese community performing a lion dance as part of Chinese New Year celebrations in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Bank of America Settlement on Bonds That Soured Is Approved
text: A New York State Supreme Court justice on Friday approved an $8.5 billion settlement between Bank of America and a group of mortgage securities investors, but the ruling contained a caveat that could create new problems for the bank.

headline: Landrieu Patriarch Talks About Family’s Political Prospects
text: In an interview  for Friday’s article about the fortunes of his political family business in Louisiana, Moon Landrieu, the former New Orleans mayor and patriarch of the Landrieu family,  weighed in on its prospects. His son, Mayor Mitch Landrieu of New Orleans, has a Democratic primary on Saturday and his daughter, Senator Mary Landrieu, also a Democrat, is facing a grueling re-election race later this year in increasingly Republican Louisiana.

headline: Art Reaches New Heights in Alps
text: GSTAAD, Switzerland — In the summer of 2012, the London-based artist Christian Marclay was scouting locations around this postcard-perfect ski resort town in the Swiss Alps, looking for inspiration.

headline: ‘Back to the Future’ Musical Planned for London Opening
text: “Back to the Future,” Robert Zemeckis’s 1985 comedy starring Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly, a teenager zapped from the 1980s back to the 1950s, is being transformed into a musical.  It is expected to have its premiere in London in 2015, a spokesman for Colin Ingram, one of the show’s producers, said on Friday.

headline: Investing in Safety
text: An oil boom in La Salle County, Texas has created a growing need for emergency workers.

headline: A Concession Worker Is Ready for Super Bowl Duty
text: Not everyone in a uniform at MetLife Stadium on Super Bowl Sunday will wear a helmet. Inez Keyes will wear a smile. High-fiving fans and co-workers while serving beer, she is the Peyton Manning of hospitality. (“Go Beertenders!”) Ms. Keyes, 55, one of nearly 3,000 concession workers for Delaware North Companies, has brought her A-game to Giants and Jets games in the Meadowlands for 22 years, going from counter worker to cashier to beertender on the 100 Concourse. (She also supervises a concession stand at the Izod Center.) Ms. Keyes commutes two hours from Canarsie, Brooklyn, taking two subways and two buses to New Jersey; her routine will vary slightly on Super Bowl Sunday, but despite the later kickoff, she will still leave the house early to be in place for the big game.

headline: Big Ticket | Glass Aerie at a Record $50.9 Million
text: A stunning glass-sheathed penthouse at the pinnacle of Chelsea’s Walker Tower, the 1929 Art Deco skyscraper that underwent a ballyhooed conversion from iconic office building to 47 luxury condominiums, sold for $50,912,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price was $55 million; monthly carrying costs are $9,361.81.

headline: “Where the Hell Is Robert E. Lee”
text: A song by Chelsea Crowell.

headline: Prince Said to Drop Suit Against Fans
text: Prince has apparently thought better of the lawsuit he filed against 22 of his fans earlier this month, seeking $1 million from each for posting video recordings of his concert performances. Or perhaps the lawsuit was simply a shot across the bow, meant as a reminder that Prince – who has threatened his fans and collectors with legal action in the past – would not tolerate trading in unauthorized recordings of his work.

headline: Obama Outlines Plan to Help Unemployed
text: President Obama announced initiatives to help the long-term unemployed get jobs from both the private and public sectors.

headline: Today in Small Business: the Most Promising Companies
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Copenhagen Women’s Shows
text: A glimpse at what guys and gals are wearing this season.

headline: Artist Files Suit Over Missing Empire State Building Paintings
text: For many years, visitors to the concourse level of the Empire State Building walked by a series of large, lush paintings that seemed to be abstractions but that actually represented the atomic or molecular structure of the materials — brick, steel, cement, aluminum — used in the skyscraper’s construction.

headline: More Mindfulness, Less Meditation
text: Here’s the promise: Meditation – and mindfulness meditation, in particular – will reduce your cortisol level, blood pressure, social anxiety and depression. It will increase your immune response, resilience and focus and improve your relationships — including with yourself. It will also bolster your performance at work and provide inner peace. It may even cure psoriasis.

headline: Teacher and Troll Both Start With ‘T’
text: By all accounts, young people are gravitating away from watching television in the traditional way, but that’s not stopping Nickelodeon from going after very young people. On Monday afternoon at 1, the channel unveils “Wallykazam!,” an animated series full of early literacy lessons for preschoolers. It’s a “Sesame Street” approach transplanted to a land of magic and kid-friendly mythical beings.

headline: Harmonic Requiem for a Genre
text: It won’t be grand: no overtures or entr’actes or glossy souvenir programs for sale in the lobby. But “Roadshow: The Fall of Film Musicals in the 1960s,” through Friday, has five of those rare birds — Hollywood musicals — glittering and strutting across the screen at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: What Lives On After Death
text: Since it began organizing exhibitions in 2012, the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation has looked far and wide for artists, staying mostly clear of the career of its famous founder, who died in 2008 and wanted the foundation to serve as a home for idiosyncratic, politically vocal work.

headline: Translations That Move
text: Ballet and modern dance once were bitter enemies. Yet because dancers tend to be blessed with curiosity, ballet dancers sneaked off to modern classes, and modern dancers turned up in ballet studios.

headline: Three Composers Basking in Bach
text: Although the Miller Theater at Columbia University is indelibly tied to contemporary composers and early music, the voluminous canon of Johann Sebastian Bach has long formed a third pillar of that institution’s programming. But this season, the theater’s customary Bach series gets an intriguing overhaul with Bach, Revisited, a three-concert sequence in which prominent living composers pair selections by Bach with their own works to try to illuminate connections.

headline: The Musical Trail of an Explorer
text: The Panamanian pianist Danilo Pérez is an exceptional musician, even without much framework, as in the loosest, most intuitive moments of Wayne Shorter’s current band, of which he’s been a member since 2000. But he puts a lot of framework in his own music: He wants to represent jazz within its broadest possible contexts of place and history. He’s about to release a new record, “Panama 500” (Mack Avenue), which integrates Panamanian folklore, European classical music and jazz. Some of it describes the Spanish explorer Vasco Núñez de Balboa’s crossing the isthmus of Panama in 1513.

headline: Did George Washington Want to Burn New York City?
text: Q. As George Washington’s birthday nears, I recall a story that he tried to burn New York City during the Revolution. Really?

headline: Orhan Pamuk’s Istanbul
text: On a windswept afternoon in mid-December, the writer Orhan Pamuk stood in a leafy square around the corner from Istanbul University, absorbed in a 40-year-old memory. He walked past parked motorcycles, sturdy oaks and a stone fountain, browsing through secondhand books in front of cluttered shops occupying the bottom floors of a quadrangle of pale yellow buildings. Sahaflar Carsisi, Istanbul’s used-book bazaar, has been a magnet for literary types since the Byzantine era.

headline: 36 Hours in Manchester, Vt.
text: Manchester may never be the ultimate Ski Town, U.S.A. Its gilded mansions and upscale factory outlets continue to draw more shoppers than ski bums. But this bucolic town in southern Vermont, blessed with two nearby ski resorts and backcountry trails that meander through the picturesque Battenkill Valley, is emerging as a popular winter getaway among Bostonians, New Yorkers and even Europeans looking to get acquainted with Vermont’s unspoiled Green Mountains, while also exploring Manchester’s bounty of local arts-and-crafts shops and artisanal restaurants. Its most recognizable property, the stately Equinox Hotel, underwent a major overhaul a few years ago. And the town just installed a pair of traffic roundabouts along the main strip to ease congestion. Don’t expect Aspen, or even Stowe. But Manchester has its own relaxed, if sophisticated, ambience that is making it a popular four-season destination.

headline: In East Africa, Safaris That Leave a Lighter Footprint
text: “Want to have lunch with the elephants?” That sounded like an offer we couldn’t refuse — even if at least half the menu was bound to consist of hunks of grass and splintered acacia branches. Luckily, the human side of the invitation included gazpacho, zucchini frittata and salad. My husband and I did mind our manners, keeping our picnic well inside the Land Rover while a herd of our multi-ton hostesses grazed peacefully a few yards away, surrounded by children of all sizes. Introductions were made by our guide, Seronoi, and his spotter, Jackson, who identified our companions by the distinctive shape of their heads, ears and tusks. What better welcome to Samburu National Park, and to the sort of experience we’d hoped to find on safari in East Africa.

headline: Eclectic East Austin
text: A mile from downtown, East Austin has historically been a working-class neighborhood, a vibrant enclave heavily populated by African-Americans because of an earlier era of segregationist laws — and later, a home to Mexican-American residents. These days, it’s also the city’s newly fashionable arts district, with studios, galleries, cocktail bars, cafes and all manner of food trucks popping up on most every block. Beloved taquerias and barbecue joints, ramshackle carwashes and Christian outreach ministries now jostle against shiny condos, fancy restaurants and, in refurbished bungalows, groovy hair salons with names like Peacock and Orbit.

headline: A New Delhi Market for Savvy Shoppers
text: Mehar Chand Market, a bustling stretch of road in the heart of New Delhi, India’s capital, has recently emerged as the hottest shopping area in the city among cognoscenti on the hunt for one-of-a-kind finds. Gone are the longtime drugstores, tailors and small groceries that catered to nearby residents, many of them government workers. Today, young designers have opened boutiques along this half-mile strip on Lodhi Road, selling everything from home goods to the latest fashions. The wares all have a distinct Indian touch, whether it’s a silk sari fashioned in bright colors or a bright pillowcase shot through with an ethnic pattern. And their reasonable prices compared with other upscale retail districts in town stand out.

headline: Russia’s Ice Skating Resurgence
text: After almost a decade without any top-level women’s figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.

headline: In Russia, Skating Booms Again
text: MOSCOW — After almost a decade without any top-level women’s figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.

headline: K.K.R. Buys Stake in German Soccer Club
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, a private equity giant with its hands in a range of businesses, from natural gas to maritime finance, has bought into a new sector: German soccer.

headline: Security Concerns on a Honduran Island
text: Honduras has the highest murder rate in the world, but the country’s idyllic Bay Islands have long been considered a safe haven, largely immune from the drug-fueled violence that has plagued the Honduran mainland. However, a string of recent crimes on Roatán, the largest of the Bay Islands, has prompted outrage, with some residents calling for greater autonomy and more effective policing for the islands.

headline: A Bird Flies South, and It’s News
text: DUXBURY, Mass. — The snowy owl seemed almost complacent, showing the confidence of a top predator whose bright yellow eyes suggested she might be sizing you up as a weaker combatant — or perhaps a large snack.

headline: Renaming the Tappan Zee After Pete Seeger Is a Terrible Idea
text: Pete Seeger, who died this week at 94, was not only a folk singer of near-mythic status but also an ardent environmentalist who helped save the Hudson from turning into New York’s Cuyahoga.

headline: Powder in Letters Near Super Bowl Site Is Not Hazardous, Authorities Say
text: Several letters containing a suspicious substance sent to locations in New York City and New Jersey, causing a large-scale response by the authorities, have been found not to be hazardous after preliminary testing, according to a statement issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Giving Credit: A Work in Progress at The Times
text: Curtis Tate, a reporter for McClatchy News’s Washington bureau, spent a recent weekend generating spreadsheets from a database on hazardous materials for his story on the increasing amount of crude oil spilled in rail accidents.

headline: A Leader Shows Vulnerability in Turkey’s Cash Crisis
text: ISTANBUL — First, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan criticized the bold move by Turkey’s central bank this week to raise interest rates sharply to halt the decline in the country’s currency, telling reporters that higher borrowing costs would lead to inflation — an argument that contravenes accepted economic logic.

headline: Need Tax Help? I.R.S. May Not Be the Best Place to Go
text: IF you’re ready to file your 2013 federal income tax return, you can do so starting now. The official start of tax-filing season arrived later than anticipated because of a delay caused by last year’s government shutdown.

headline: A Parting Gift as Ben Bernanke Hangs Up His Cleats
text: Ben S. Bernanke now has his own baseball card.

headline: New York Court Archivist Isn’t Letting Retirement Stop Him
text: It was just another day at the old grind on Wednesday for Bruce Abrams, 66, an archivist at the Division of Old Records in Manhattan: the rat race commute, a brown-bag lunch and eight hours retrieving files and organizing archival material, as he has done for 30 years.

headline: What I Love | Dan Kainen
text: The artist, author and inventor lives in an East 12th Street apartment featuring his custom designs and furnishings.

headline: Space-Saving D.I.Y. in the DNA
text: Dan Kainen’s pride and joy is his broom closet. It’s an amenity that’s not normally found in a 750-square-foot apartment, but Mr. Kainen has cleverly created and camouflaged storage units throughout his miniloft in Greenwich Village.

headline: Classically Trained
text: WHOSally Hawkins

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Sally Hawkins’s Fashion Choices
text: The English actress, who is nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress, has an eclectic style.

headline: “When the Master Calls the Roll”
text: A song by Rosanne Cash.

headline: Petite Crevette, the House of the Flying Lobster
text: On a mild night in January, Neil Ganic, wearing a white chef’s coat, his signature porkpie hat tilted low, greeted customers at his restaurant, Petite Crevette. The room appears to be the foyer or staging area of a larger place, but this is pretty much it: maritime curios, tight tables, original artwork and framed photos below an aqua-green ceiling. Two line chefs, sequestered in the minuscule kitchen behind a barricade of coolers and counter space and hanging bric-a-brac, conjure aromas of grilled fish and saffron amid the soft sound of Latin jazz. Most who enter either know Mr. Ganic personally or know of him and his rather formidable reputation.

headline: First, You Must Kill Your Inner Movie Star
text: When dance artists share an evening, it’s natural to want to know what they’re doing in the same place. Who put them together and why? On Thursday, the choreographers Niv Acosta and Tess Dworman presented new works at New York Live Arts, and the junction was worrying: They brought out the superficial in each other.

headline: I Am Not A Wise Man
text: A wise guy, yes. And maybe — I like to think so — someone with a pretty good though by no means error-free track record on depression economics. But Chris House is right, even though he refuses to say what nutty things I’ve said that come remotely close to Ed Prescott.

headline: New York Hotels Have Rooms for Super Bowl Weekend
text: It’s not too late to book a room in New York for Super Bowl weekend. In fact, many hotels are still advertising availability, attempting to entice last-minute travelers with tailgate party packages and post-game “detox” deals.

headline: The Policy Lapsed, but No One Knew
text: Sometimes you do everything right and it still goes wrong.

headline: Report Opens Way to Approval for Keystone Pipeline
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department released a report on Friday concluding that the Keystone XL pipeline would not substantially worsen carbon pollution, leaving an opening for President Obama to approve the politically divisive project.

headline: The Best Special Effects of the Last 35 Years
text: We hardly need proof of how quickly technology is moving, but sometimes it’s nice to get a refresher.

headline: Microsoft Said to Be Close to Naming a New Chief
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft has spent five months looking for a new face to help the company evolve along with the mobile age. Turns out, it seems to be choosing a familiar face and largely sticking to its current path.

headline: Lone Fan Tackles the N.F.L. Over Super Bowl Ticket Prices
text: Josh Finkelman’s quest for Super Bowl justice began on a Monday in December with the click of a computer mouse. The day before, a busy football Sunday, the Seattle Seahawks had demolished the St. Louis Rams and the sport’s postseason landscape was finally shaping up.

headline: Signs Point to a ‘Seinfeld’ Reunion, if Ever So Brief
text: It may be all about nothing, but that would only be appropriate.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Google’s Stock Split Comes as Shares Hit Record Highs
text: Remember when Google announced plans to split its stock, creating a third class of shares? No worries if you couldn’t; the technology titan announced it in the spring of 2012.

headline: Winter Olympians to Follow on Instagram
text: The Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, are bound to include plenty of “How’d they do that?” moments. Athletes have perfected moves that demand a double-take: gravity-defying ski jumps, jaw-dropping snowboarding tricks on the halfpipe, flawless ice dancing routines.

headline: After Meeting, Republicans Seem Unsure of Way Forward
text: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — House Republicans ended a three-day retreat here united in their division. They agreed they wanted to “go big” with a midterm election agenda that would give voters a clear choice, and not simply be a campaign focused on their criticism of President Obama.

headline: The Gun Report: January 31, 2014
text: On Jan. 6, Todd Kuchman and his brother, Jaye, founders of the Denver-based Advanced Ballistic Concepts, launched the multiple impact bullet, a 3-shots-in-1 round that splits into several fragments. Meant for self-defense, the shrapnel is held together by a Y-shaped ballistic-strength fiber, which makes for better accuracy than a shotgun’s blast of pellets, thus minimizing the chances of hitting unintended people or things. The company’s slogans include, “Because you can’t afford to miss” and “First hit advantage is everything!”

headline: Book Review Podcast: Secrets of Success
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Sandra Tsing Loh reviews two new books about success in America: “The Hybrid Tiger” by Quanyu Huang and “The Triple Package” by Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld. Ms. Loh writes:

headline: The Low-inflationary Trap
text: Dean Baker is, of course, completely right here. There isn’t a red line you cross when going from positive to negative inflation, with all sorts of bad things suddenly happening. What matters is inflation relative to the rate that best suits your circumstances. Since the euro area would clearly be best off with an inflation rate well above current levels, this is a disastrous report:

headline: A Campaign for Mayor, and for a Mate
text: When Chris Coffey talks about love, he often talks about New York.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 31
text: Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.

headline: About That Coin
text: Some comments I’ve seen indicate that people still think the trillion-dollar platinum coin idea was self-evidently ridiculous. Guys, you missed the memo — literally. From last month:

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Tim’s Vermeer,’ ‘That Awkward Moment’ and ‘Labor Day’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the documentary “Tim’s Vermeer,” the romantic comedy “That Awkward Moment” and the drama “Labor Day.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Are They Selling Sex or Beer? It’s Super Bowl Media Literacy Bingo!
text: My children (12, 9, 8 and 7) all fully understand that one watches the Super Bowl as much for the advertisements as for the game, especially when one’s team isn’t playing. And here on the East Coast, Super Bowl watching tends to be a family affair for people with young children. (As my husband said when I mentioned missing Super Bowl parties, “You want to take the kids to a party at 6:30 on a school night?”)

headline: You Can’t Beat These Wedding Singers
text: LOS ANGELES — My fiancée, Robyn Monks, and I were standing in a row with 32 other couples at the Grammys last Sunday night in one of those cavernous entryways to the Staples Center arena (the kind through which beasts and fighters might have passed in Rome’s Colosseum), and we were about to enter and be married by Queen Latifah on live television.

headline: From High Above Times Square, a Super Bowl Tease
text: The football carnival that has taken over 14 blocks of Broadway around Times Square may be fun for Super Bowl crowds, but those who work in the surrounding buildings are growing weary.

headline: Passions in a Pastor’s Wake
text: At the Rev. Carmen Mason-Browne’s farewell party in January, many supporters stood to give impassioned testimonials to the profound effect she had had on them in her two years as interim pastor at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. One spoke of her poetic sermons, another of her initiative to include children in the service, and another of her commitment to social justice.

headline: Contender for Microsoft Helm Seen as Unlikely to Shake It Up
text: As Microsoft hunts for its new chief executive, the firm appears to have zeroed in on a true company man who has spearheaded Microsoft’s efforts to stay on the cutting edge.

headline: Syrian Talks, Ending First Round, Fail Even to Agree on Easing Aid Blockade
text: GENEVA — The first round of the Syria peace talks ended on Friday without achieving even its most modest goal: easing the Syrian government’s blockade on the delivery of food and medicine to besieged communities.

headline: A Super Bowl Party Briefly Interrupted by ‘I Dos’
text: Most engaged couples who are planning a wedding date usually pass on Super Bowl Sunday, but Rachel Graham and Julian Ho have a different game plan, as do Shawna Cook and Brian Mascarelli.

headline: Verizon Wireless Prepares Network for TV Broadcasting
text: Cord cutters, the people who cancel their cable TV subscriptions in favor of Internet-based alternatives, are a looming threat for the television industry. Verizon Wireless wants to capitalize on that.

headline: A Couple of Contradictions
text: In the course of working on the profile of Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld that I wrote for this weekend’s magazine, I came across many things that had been written about the couple — some of them so contradictory that they almost canceled each other out. Chua’s supporters see her as a courageous truth-teller, willing to sacrifice her good name to show how permissive parenting has put American children in peril; her critics see her as a cynical pop-cultural savant, exploiting stereotypes and anxieties to sell some books. Reactions to Rubenfeld have been similarly erratic, though less extreme. Here is a sliver of what’s out there.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence’s Big Dior Contract, Transgender and 62-Year-Old Models and the Next Dame of the British Empire
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Beekman area co-op with a garden; a Battery Park City condo with many amenities; and a Ditmas Park Victorian built in 1910.

headline: Christie Linked to Knowledge of Shut Lanes
text: The former Port Authority official who personally oversaw the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, central to the scandal now swirling around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, said on Friday that “evidence exists” that the governor knew about the closings when they were happening.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A Huntington Bay cottage on a wooded half-acre and a Greenwich colonial with a stone fence and heated pool.

headline: Triage for Treasures After a Bomb Blast
text: CAIRO — A man in a white lab coat sat alone among piles of blown-off ceiling, mangled metal and splintered wood here on Thursday inside the Museum of Islamic Art — home to a world-renowned collection that covers centuries of art from countries across the Islamic world. He carefully separated ochre-tinted pieces of old glass from the clear shards of modern showcases.

headline: “Hardin Wouldn’t Run”
text: A song by Johnny Cash.

headline: When Owning a Home Is Cold Comfort
text: The declining fortunes of the middle class in New York City are often most easily observed in the context of gentrification and soaring real estate valuations. There is an obvious doom that befalls anyone renting long-term in a neighborhood on a rapid trajectory to preciousness. This doom, or fear of it, in turn leads to an intensified idealization of homeownership — though the ownership rate in the city, at just over 30 percent, is less than half the figure for the country over all — a sense that there could be few problems immune to solution had one had the foresight (and resourcefulness) to a buy a brownstone in Brooklyn for $400,000 in 1995.

headline: Letter From Wildstein’s Lawyer on Lane Closings
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey knew about the lane closings as they were happening, a letter released on Friday by the lawyer of David Wildstein said.

headline: A Cadillac That Says ‘Achtung’
text: Cadillac still has a ways to go to match the cachet of German luxury brands, but the third-generation CTS puts Cadillac firmly in the conversation.

headline: Finally, Real Diva in Lineup for Game
text: Since 1967, the national anthem has been sung at the Super Bowl by a boy band and a college a cappella group. It has been belted by a morning-TV host and bugled by a trumpeter (four times!).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Sri Lanka and China.

headline: Lives of the After-Party
text: “Got the boss coming!” a security worker shouted.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | A Near-Cigar With Mike Ditka
text: The air pooled with machine-generated smoke, wisps rising into the rafters of the cabaret bar, where the presently chic tropes of such places — taxidermy creatures like a fox and a crow — peered down into the audience. But onstage, flanked by velvet curtains, in place of a sultry singer was a very different sort of star: the septuagenarian former football coach Mike Ditka.

headline: Weekend Reading: Super Bowl Quotes for Wall Street
text: Big banks are giving their junior workers time off just in time for the Super Bowl. This week we’re looking at quotable National Football League stars and Wall Street financier counterparts.

headline: Since They Lost Sammy
text: In last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, N.R. Kleinfield wrote about Gary Eckstein and Amy Cohen, who became activists for safer streets after their son, Sammy, was struck and killed by a van in Brooklyn. A reader responded via email:

headline: The Stakes Off the Field
text: Should states be able to legalize sports betting and would that be worthwhile?

headline: Taking Aim at Android, After a Jilting at Nokia
text: HELSINKI, Finland — Marc Dillon still remembers the sick feeling that overcame him when Nokia announced it was scrapping a software project that he and hundreds of other developers had spent years creating.

headline: A Break From Opera for Orchestra in Madrid
text: MADRID — In keeping with a long tradition in classical music, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Madrid is an ensemble with two identities. It is the official orchestra of the Teatro Real, this city’s major opera company, and as such has been working hard of late, especially this week.

headline: Good Enough? That’s Great
text: What’s the best way to recalibrate a marriage as the years pass? I wish I had the answer, because clearly millions of us would like to know.

headline: Anti-Gay Policies Chill Viewers’ Interest
text: Outraged by a new Russian law that outlaws “homosexual propaganda” and by President Vladimir Putin’s recent remarks that gays who go to Sochi for the Olympic Winter Games should “stay away from children,” some gays and lesbians are planning to boycott watching the Olympics on TV.

headline: At First, Love Runs Hot, but Then It Always Cools
text: During her recital at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote explored “Les chemins de l’amour” (“The Paths of Love”), tracing a romantic arc of bliss, ambiguity and despair. “Les Chemins,” the title of the Poulenc song that opened the program, set the mood for an evening of mélodie, beautifully accompanied by the eminent British pianist Graham Johnson.

headline: Scientific Pride and Prejudice
text: SCIENCE is in crisis, just when we need it most. Two years ago, C. Glenn Begley and Lee M. Ellis reported in Nature that they were able to replicate only six out of 53 “landmark” cancer studies. Scientists now worry that many published scientific results are simply not true. The natural sciences often offer themselves as a model to other disciplines. But this time science might look for help to the humanities, and to literary criticism in particular.

headline: The Transformation of Lady Edith
text: Poor, sad Lady Edith. Early on in “Downton Abbey,” the PBS “Masterpiece Classic” family saga, it seemed that the much-overlooked, undervalued middle sister of the Crawley clan had been dealt a rough hand. Her assertive nose, wan manner and decorously dowdy wardrobe had apparently rendered her marriage prospects slim to nil. Be kind to her, she has so few advantages, Lady Cora, her mother, urges Edith’s sister Mary. To which Mary peevishly replies that Edith has none at all.

headline: Get Them While They’re Green
text: The first time I went to Thailand, of the various unfamiliar items in the vegetable market, it was glossy bright green peppercorns, fresh ones, in juicy clusters, that were the most exciting.

headline: The German Lessons Are Paying Off
text: When Cadillac set out to revive its arthritic cars and unfashionable image, beginning with the original CTS sedan of 2003, the brand seemed as retirement-ready as many of its customers.

headline: CTS Vsport: The BMW Beater
text: A $60,000 sticker price rarely suggests a bargain among automobiles.

headline: Cadillac Lays Its Wreath to Rest
text: Cadillac takes its insignia, which it calls “the crest,” very seriously. But that doesn’t keep it from tinkering with the logo every now and then.

headline: Review: 2014 Cadillac CTS
text: The last two generations of Cadillac’s CTS have come close to running with the best Germany has to offer. G.M.’s third try confidently drives to the front of the pack.

headline: Musharraf’s Request to Leave Pakistan for Treatment Is Rejected
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A special court on Friday rejected a request by the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf to leave Pakistan for medical treatment and instead issued arrest warrants in the treason case against him, according to lawyers in the case.

headline: Critic of Online Ad Firm Blinkx Is Part of the Controversy
text: LONDON — A Harvard Business School professor has raised pointed questions in an article about an Internet advertising company, prompting a plunge in its stock price. He himself, though, is now a subject of controversy.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Game On
text: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown Manhattan, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Game On
text: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival. For the well-bundled fans: marching bands, cheerleaders, uniforms of the Broncos and Seahawks. For thrill seekers: a toboggan slide. As cameras click everywhere, police and their mounts remain vigilant. The sharp-eyed spied an actual football player, on his way to a broadcast booth.

headline: Movie Review: 'That Awkward Moment'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "That Awkward Moment."

headline: Movie Review: 'Labor Day'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Labor Day."

headline: "Building" by Steven and William Ladd
text: Steven and William Ladd's magical, whimsical worlds are the subject of a new show at the Mingei International Museum. This video illuminates the brothers’ inspirations and creative process.

headline: Movie Review: 'Tim's Vermeer'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Tim's Vermeer."

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 31
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.

headline: The Magical World of Steven and William Ladd
text: The magical, whimsical worlds created by the artists Steven and William Ladd are the subject of “Function and Fantasy,” a new exhibition at the Mingei International Museum in San Diego. The brothers, who work out of a studio in New York City’s Chelsea neighborhood, brought their individual practices together more than a decade ago, when Steven was designing clothes and William was making intricate beadwork. Soon William’s beadwork found its way onto Steven’s clothes, and a deep collaboration began to evolve. They formed an accessories company, incorporating work so complex that it takes them up to three years to complete a single handbag. Ideas for packaging led them to the tower installations that now lie at the heart of their artistic practice.

headline: In North Carolina, Sites That Honor Black History
text: Thirty-seven sites that highlight the contributions of African-Americans to the  business, spiritual, educational and civic life of   Wilmington, N.C.,  are detailed in the recently published African American Heritage guide.

headline: No Timetable for Relocating a Franchise to Los Angeles, Goodell Says
text: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that there was no timetable for putting a team in Los Angeles despite news reports that the owner of the St. Louis Rams, Stan Kroenke, had bought 60 acres in central Los Angeles, which presumably could hold a stadium.

headline: Apple Executives Met With F.D.A. to Discuss Mobile Medical Applications
text: Apple has signaled strong interest in health-monitoring technology, which could wind up in a widely anticipated smartwatch.

headline: $100,000 Reward Is Set for Stolen Stradivarius Violin
text: The Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra announced late Friday afternoon that a $100,000 reward was being offered to anyone who provides information that leads to the safe return of the 1715 Stradivarius violin stolen from the orchestra’s concertmaster, Frank Almond, after a chamber concert in Milwaukee on Monday evening. Susan Loris, a spokeswoman for the orchestra said she was unable to identify the source of the reward money. It could be the orchestra, the anonymous owner of the violin (it was given to Mr. Almond as a permanent loan in 2008) or others.

headline: When Simplicity Trumps Complexity
text: The notion of stealing a show through simplicity and understatement may seem counterintuitive if not oxymoronic. But your intuition and mine are not Arvo Pärt’s, and this is a feat Mr. Pärt achieves with some regularity, as he did on Wednesday evening in the fourth program of the annual Focus! festival of contemporary music at the Juilliard School.

headline: Parched, California Cuts Off Tap to Agencies
text: LOS ANGELES — Responding to one of the worst droughts in California’s history, state officials announced on Friday that they would cut off the water to local agencies serving 25 million residents and about 750,000 acres of farmland.

headline: Going Off the Grid, and Being Showy About It
text: PHILADELPHIA — A newbie camper wanders off into the woods in “Cherokee,” the new play by Lisa D’Amour having its premiere at the Wilma Theater here. His subsequent disappearance sparks a strange series of events, as his wife and the two friends joining him on a back-to-nature spree find themselves gradually acclimatizing to their radically altered lives as they spend days and weeks hoping for his return.

headline: Red Carpet Project
text: Of all the fashionable events that take place during awards season, the red carpet at the Academy Awards remains the main attraction. Explore an archive of Oscar red carpet looks that spans 17 years by name, designer, color, silhouette and year.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Stock Bet Yields Windfall on Paper
text: When Morgan Stanley’s share price fell to $20 in 2011, the bank’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, and several of his top lieutenants tried to encourage investors by buying up stock with their own money. Now, that put-your-money-where-your-mouth-is approach appears to have paid off.

headline: A Hand-Me-Down With a History
text: Rambling over the back roads that neighbor Duke Farms, a 2,700-acre estate and nature preserve in central New Jersey, the 1952 MG TD called to mind a little pooch eager to impress the big hounds at the dog park: The confident bark of its exhaust belied the timid 55-horsepower bite of its tiny 4-cylinder engine.

headline: Keeping It in the Family
text: Randy Mehrberg’s 1952 MG TD was a gift from his uncle Morty, who taught Randy to drive in the MG decades ago.

headline: Injured Actor Is Suing ‘Spider-Man’ Producers
text: Daniel Curry, a young actor who was seriously injured in August while performing in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” filed a lawsuit this week accusing the show’s producers, engineering consultants, and others of negligence in the design and operation of a mechanical lift that Mr. Curry was using onstage when he was hurt.

headline: You Are Like the People These Guys Make Up
text: “TJ and Dave,” the hourlong improv show by the Second City veterans TJ Jagodowski and David Pasquesi, the premier improv duo working today, unfolds so seamlessly that it makes you wonder: Are these guys really making all this up on the spot?

headline: Jointly Forging a Movement, Cheek by Jowl
text: She is a white Unitarian activist spinster from a good family in Brooklyn. He is one of the greatest African-American intellectuals of the 20th century. “Dr. Du Bois and Miss Ovington” finds them on a Sunday afternoon in 1915, and the burning question is supposedly whether she can talk him out of resigning from the N.A.A.C.P., of which they are both founders.

headline: Carmakers to Share Repair Data
text: There is good news for motorists who have been turned away from local independent repair shops with an explanation that only the automaker’s dealership can correct a particular problem.

headline: Flitting Between Watery Dream and Reality
text: WASHINGTON — The consistent visual beauty of the Mariinsky Ballet’s production of “Swan Lake,” which opened at the Kennedy Center this week, is astonishing. No other staging today so perfectly locates this ballet in the medieval age of chivalry; no other sets, costumes and lighting are so ravishingly satisfying in terms of color, style, period, atmosphere.

headline: Bridge at the District 3 Winter Regional
text: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., two weeks ago, the winners of the Sunday A/X Swiss Teams were Jeff Aker of Briarcliff, N.Y., Victor King of Hartford, Conn., and Glenn Milgrim and Barry Rigal of New York City. They finished 8 victory points ahead of Dori Cohen of Woodbury, N.Y., Robert Gordon of Northport, N.Y., Kelley Hwang of New York City, and Richard Popper of Wilmington, Del. Third were Sue Picus, Alex Ornstein and Craig Ganzer of New York City, and Gene Saxe of Briarcliff, N.Y.

headline: True South | New Orleans Dining
text: T’s contributing editor Sara Ruffin Costello recommends Marti’s, which is off North Rampart Street, and Killer Poboys in the Erin Rose Bar on Conti Street, both in the French Quarter.

headline: For a Silky Hip-Hop Romeo, a Juliet of His Own Making
text: The beloved hip-hop choreographer Rennie Harris returned to the Joyce Theater for the first time in 10 years on Tuesday night, and the two-hour program — even one frustratingly made up of older dances and excerpts — was worth the wait. The prolific Mr. Harris works like a fiend. To all the nervous producers in the world: it’s O.K. to take a chance on Mr. Harris’s sophisticated view of hip-hop. We could have handled something new, something untested.

headline: BowlesSimpsonism
text: Jonathan Chait — who’s been on a roll — has fun with the idea that the Bowles-Simpson commission is a model for, well, anything:

headline: Evening Hours | Keeping Warm
text: Even frigid weather could not halt the party circuit.

headline: Times Minute | Did Christie Know?
text: A former aide claims that Gov. Chris Christie was aware of the lane closings while they were happening. Also on the Minute, the end of a rough month on Wall Street and this year's Super Bowl ads.

headline: Times Minute | Did Christie Know?
text: In the Video

headline: Fashion’s Fertile Ground for Inspiration: Gardens
text: Seasons, colors, lighting and scale are no less important in building a good garden than they are in designing a good fashion collection. The two subjects, which have more crossover than some might realize, are explored in a show at the Garden Museum in London that opens Friday, aptly titled “Fashion & Gardens.” “Our national obsession with gardens and landscape is the greatest contribution England has brought to the world of fashion,” says the British writer and historian Nicola Shulman, a trustee of the Garden Museum in London, who leaped at the opportunity to curate the exhibition. Through art, historical photographs, artifacts and a look back at notable runways from designers like Yves Saint Laurent and Valentino, Shulman explores the intricate relationship between the two design genres from the days of Elizabeth I up to recent runway shows.

headline: Super Bowl Sideshows Starring Puppies, Kittens and Fish
text: The Puppy Bowl has long been the big dog when it comes to alternative programming during the Super Bowl. When the stadium lights went out at the big game last year, more than a million viewers filled the time by flocking to the canine contest.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Normal Person
text: I have to admit, I had a hard time warming up to Arcade Fire’s new album. It was a break from the previous sound, and it’s taken me a while to find the thread of continuity. But I have been listening, and am increasingly getting it. As I mentioned on WNYC (btw, I start at around the 25-minute mark) my appreciation of their music grows when I get a chance to hear them do stripped-down performances, like this one just up, which among other things shows that the intensity and commitment is undiminished. Also that they’re having fun:

headline: As Argentine Peso Falters, President Keeps a Low Profile
text: BUENOS AIRES — As Argentines stew over a currency crisis that has shaken markets around the world, many residents here are asking the same question: Where is the president?

headline: Domino’s Delivery Workers Settle Suit for $1.3 Million
text: Carlos Rodriguez Herrera said he often worked 65 hours a week as a deliveryman for a Domino’s pizza shop on East 89th Street in Manhattan but was paid for just 45 hours. A co-worker, Anatole Yameogo, remembers working from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. one Saturday, but his pay stub said he worked just five hours that day.
